You're going to have to remember this exception with that brain of yours and rely on the SRS to bestow this knowledge upon you. The second reading, which is less common but still common enough, makes more sense. It is こんねん and just follows the jukugo patterns.

Name: Three Hundred
Mnemonic: You have three hundreds. What does that come out to? Three hundred.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a little bit weird, so be careful. You should already know the on'yomi readings, but the ひゃく rendakus to びゃく. This pattern will repeat itself with 三 + many counter kanjis that can rendaku, so pay attention for it as you read Japanese.

Name: To Add Something
Mnemonic: Remember 足りる? That is "to be enough." How can you make something be enough? You keep adding things to the pile until you reach that point where there are enough! That's why this verb is to add something, because you keep adding things until you 足りる.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 足りる, so if you know that you can add things up to this.

Name: To Be Able To Do
Mnemonic: When you exit and come, apparently it means to be able to do. I think of it like you're leaving a location (出) to do a task and then you come (来る) back after you did it. Perhaps you were waiting in a room training like someone from Dragonball. When you leave the room, you are ready to fight the enemy and win. You train in that room to be able to do whatever you need to do, and only leave and come back alive because you were able to do it.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are a bit strange. They're both kun'yomi readings, where 出 is で and 来る is きる. This is different from the reading you originally learned with 来る (くる), though, so be careful. If you can remember that and remember the kun'yomi readings from the previous vocab, you should be able to learn this one's reading as well.

Name: To Be Cut
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. Here's a refresher to help you remember the  き portion of this word: Something is snapping. Turns out that something is your arm. Your arm is a 木 (き) that grew out of you one day. "What's this ki doing here?" you ask. Then it suddenly breaks in half! "OW OW OW! My ki! It's been cut!!"

Name: To Be Photographed
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means copy, but what is a copy? It is basically a photograph, which is why this word means to be photographed, or to be in a photograph. You know this one is "to be photographed" because it ends with a る. Someone thinks you're "rude" so they're photographing you.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the 写す vocab, but here's a refresher just in case: You have to remember the うつ part. You're being rude, right? That's why you got photographed. Why are you rude? You're doing beatboxing, constantly saying うつうつうつ over and over again. Say it out loud, too.

Name: To Carry Something Out
Mnemonic: The meaning of this word is pretty strange, having very little to do with the kanji meaning you learned. This word means to carry something out. Maybe you can think of it like someone is saying "You (う) go do that task!" to get yourself to carry out the task. Whatever you do, just know this is a weird exception word, so you may have to do some extra work to remember it.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is also a strange exception. You have to remember the おこな portion. Maybe this mnemonic will help: You have to carry out a task but don’t know how. “Oh, Conan!” (おこな) you shout. You always shout “Oh, Conan!” when you have to carry out something tough, because it summons the spirit of Detective Conan. He’s a genius, so his spirit can help you with anything at all. Even your WaniKani reviews. Go ahead and try it now. Shout “Oh, Conan!” Did you do it? Good. Now carry out those reviews!

Name: To Die
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means death, so the verb version is to die.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Eat
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means eat so the verb version is to eat.
ReadingMnemonic: You have to remember the た portion if you want to be able to read this word, which uses the kun'yomi reading. Think about yourself eating some tacos (た). Imagine yourself eating it, that raw beef taste in your mouth (either like it or hate it).

Name: To Fix
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fix so this vocab word means to fix. This is when you're fixing something, as in doing the actual physical action of fixing.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to learn the なお part. Think of it this way. You need to fix something! It's urgent! You have to fix it now! (なお).

Name: To Get Fired
Mnemonic: The になる part means "to become," so literally this means "to become neck." If you think about it, when something becomes neck, it has to do with you getting your head cut off (at the neck). But, in today's modern society we don't do that too often. Instead, this means you lose your job, aka to get fired.
ReadingMnemonic: This word contains the reading you learned with the kanji. Everything else is hiragana.

Name: To Grow
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. Remember how 生きる means "to live?" Well this is what happens right after it starts to live. It begins to grow!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When something starts to grow it also learns to laugh. Imagine a little plant growing out of the ground laughing. "Ha (は) ha ha ha!" it says, as it sprouts out of the ground.

Name: To Have
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means have, so this verb version means to have. An alternative meaning is to exist, because having something means that it exists for you.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To have something is very nice. But now, the only thing you possess are screams. Imagine this. You are in a totally empty room with no possessions. You open a little box and look inside. It contains screams that yell: "AAAAHHHH" (あ).

Name: Tohoku
Mnemonic: The East North area of Japan is called Tohoku or the Tohoku region. It was the region hit by the 2011 Tohoku Earthquake. This can also mean northeast region when talking about China or Japan, but for other countries (and for the direction) we'd use 北東.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You learned the on'yomi reading for 北 when you learned 北西, but here's another mnemonic to help you remember: Tohoku has its fair share of hocus (ほく) pocus too. I guess you can go to any northern region and the people there are gonna try to hocus-pocus you, so you gotta watch out. And Japan's Tohoku region (the northeast region) is no exception when it comes to hocus pocus!

Name: To Know
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means know so the verb version means to know. It can additionally refer to how one comes to know something, so it also means to learn or to find out.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already with the kanji, so you're good to go! Yay!

Name: Tokyo
Mnemonic: The East Capital in Japan is Tokyo. If you look on a map and compare it to 京都 (Kyoto, the other capital in history), you'll see it's East of Kyoto, making it the East Capital, Tokyo.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Tonight
Mnemonic: The now night is the current night, aka tonight.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Pass Away
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This word is actually two words put together, though. 亡く means "be deceased." なる means "to become." So put that all together and you have to pass away or to become deceased. It's basically a polite way to say something died (死ぬ).
ReadingMnemonic: To learn to read this kanji you have to remember the な part of 亡く, though our mnemonic will use the whole thing. If you're about to become deceased, you are probably knocking (なく) on death's door.

Name: To Spread Out
Mnemonic: Remember 広い? Well this is like that, except a verb. When something does the action of getting wide, it means to spread out, to extend, or to stretch.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 広い, too, so as long as you knew that you knew this reading as well.

Name: To Take
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means take, so the verb version is to take something.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You already know this kun'yomi reading, so you should be able to read this word.

Name: To Think
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means think so the verb version is to think.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with this kanji, but here's a reminder of the mnemonic just in case: You have to remember the おも part to read this word. To do this, though, you'll have to think about that guy... hmm... what was his name? He's on The Simpsons... he's the bartender? I think? Oh! Moe (おも) is his name! Thank you. Now I remember. If you don't know Moe from the Simpsons use a different Moe, perhaps the one from the Three Stooges? You should be able to come up with one.

Name: To Turn Toward
Mnemonic: You know that the kanji means yonder, which is like "over there." This is the verb version of "yonder." That being said, "to yonder" isn't really a thing, so you have to think of what happens when you "look yonder." This word means to turn toward or to face. You're looking yonder, but you have to turn towards said yonder to look that way.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You turn to face a new direction and look out into the distance. There is a single cow out there. It turns to face you too, and says moo (む).

Name: To Walk
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means walk so the verb version means to walk.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ある portion. Imagine yourself going to walk outside. But, as you walk, you walk like a pirate. You have a peg leg, a parrot, and a hook. Lastly, you say "arrrrr" (ある). Go ahead, say it out loud while walking around your room like a pirate. It will help.

Name: Tune
Mnemonic: This almost shares the meaning with the kanji. It's essentially the same thing, though when it's alone it refers to a specific piece of music (aka a tune).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji as well, so you should be able to read it.

Name: Underground
Mnemonic: If you're in the middle of the ground, then you're most likely underground. Are you a moleperson? That's pretty cool.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Underground
Mnemonic: Below the ground is underground.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Uneasiness
Mnemonic: When you're not relaxed, what do you feel? Uneasiness is what you'd feel.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: United States Of America
Mnemonic: America is the country of rice. I guess this is from all those rolling plains and such we have. Another way to say America in Japanese is アメリカ, but this is another more formal (and older) way. "Rice Country" aka United States Of America, United States, America, or USA.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Unknown
Mnemonic: Something that is not bright is cloudy and fuzzy. What do you think when you look into the fuzzy clouds? It is the unknown, the unclear, the uncertain.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Uppercase Letters
Mnemonic: You have big writing letters. What do you think these are? THAT WOULD HAVE TO BE UPPERCASE LETTERS, RIGHT? Whoops, sorry, caps lock was on for a moment, there.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. However, 大 uses the kun'yomi reading and 文 is an exception here, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this: Whenever you see an uppercase letter, you shout "おお, Moe!" (おおも). Your buddy Moe taught you the letters in the first place, so when you get stuck, you yell for him to come help you. And he always does. What a good guy.

Name: Utilizing
Mnemonic: If you make lively use of something, you're probably utilizing it or making practical use of it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Venus
Mnemonic: The gold star is Venus. It's the only planet in our solar system that's the same color as gold.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Which
Mnemonic: Remember how どれ means "which one"? どの has a very similar meaning: which. Whereas どれ is used on its own, どの is used before a noun to ask "which" out of three or more options. So for example, どの本 is "which book (out of that pile)?".

Name: Whisper In Ear
Mnemonic: You feel your ear getting… hit? This is the feeling of a whisper in your ear; perhaps a secret, or some other confidential tidbit of information. Whatever it is it has impact, which is why it feels like a hit!
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

Name: Winter Holiday
Mnemonic: The winter rest! Wait, nobody calls it that. This is a winter holiday or winter break.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for these are both the kun'yomi readings. Hopefully you learned them when you were doing vocab in the previous levels so that all you have to do now is combine the two separate words into one bigger word. Please don't take a winter break until you figure this word out.

Name: Wool
Mnemonic: A sheep's fur is wool.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Wrist
Mnemonic: Your hand's neck is your wrist!
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!

Name: Younger
Mnemonic: When you have someone who has years below your own, this person is younger than you.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this one is kind of strange. It is the kun'yomi reading for both of the kanji. You know the kun'yomi readings from earlier, back when you learned the vocab 年 and 下.

Name: Younger Sister
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Your younger sister is really into emotes (いもうと). Look up this word if you're not a teenage girl. Just imagine her sending you these on your phone over and over. You tell your younger sister: "HEY, STOP SENDING ME EMOTES."

Name: After This
Mnemonic: From after, just means after this or from now on.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Around Here
Mnemonic: この means "this" so この辺 just means this area.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for the kanji portion is just what you've already learned with the kanji 辺 so this shouldn't be a difficult one to read for you.

Name: Arriving Ahead
Mnemonic: If you get there previous to something rotating (回り), you are arriving ahead, or going ahead in anticipation.
ReadingMnemonic: This consists of a couple kun'yomi readings put together. You can tell it's kun'yomi because of the hiragana sticking out at the end. In previous levels, you learned both the words 先 and 回る (verb version of 回り). If you know those, you should be able to put them together to learn the reading of this word as well.

Name: Balloon
Mnemonic: A wind boat. This is a strange one for sure. You may assume this is like one of those giant balloons you can go ride around in, and you'd be partly right. Really, this word covers the general word balloon, though it especially has to do with the toy-style balloons (or smaller balloons). It's a little round wind ship!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Bill
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. When you see this word after a number, it’s for physical bills of money.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a suffix that takes the on’yomi reading, which you’ve learned already! You'll also see this pronounced ふだ, but that's when it's a standalone word or part of a compound, rather than a suffix. So if you answer with that reading, you'll be prompted to enter the suffix reading instead.

Name: Bird
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: When you think about birds, what is the most common bird you can think of? What bird do you hate the most or like eating the most? Either one will work. Now, imagine yourself going up to that bird. You did something terrible. You tore (とり) off its wing and started eating it (pretend it's cooked first, if that makes you less nauseous).

Name: Black
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of black? It's also black. Special Note: The noun version of black also exists in Japanese. It is just 黒 with the same pronunciation, but minus the い which makes it adjective-tastic.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think of black things. One very common black thing is the common crow (くろ). Associate those two together.

Name: Black Person
Mnemonic: A black person is simply a Black person, kind of like how a 白人 is a "White person," but a different  color.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: Imagine a Black person you know well wearing coke jeans (こくじん). Yep, jeans made entirely from coke bottles. That's actually a thing. Look it up if you don't believe me.

Name: Blue Sky
Mnemonic: This is simply a blue sky (aka a blue sky!).
ReadingMnemonic: You'd think that this word would use on'yomi readings to read it, but it doesn't (shake that angry fist at the kanji gods!). Instead, it's double kun'yomi, probably because this word is really like two separate words put together, "blue" and "sky." In the previous level you unlocked these two separate words, learning their readings. That means you should be able to read this as well. One quick note is the rendaku-fication of 空 as well. It becomes ぞら.

Name: Boat
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're riding in a boat. It's great. Imagine it being the best time you've had in your life. You tell everyone: "This is fun, eh?" (ふね). You're on a Canadian ship, which is why you add the "eh" in there. Say this out loud wherever you are right now while imagining the sea smell, the wind, and the excitement of boats.

Name: Classroom
Mnemonic: The teaching room is just a classroom.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Conjugated Form
Mnemonic: You know that 活用 means "conjugation" and that 〜形 means "form," so that means this is the conjugated form!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Diary
Mnemonic: When you write down your day (and do it every day) that's your diary.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: When you write down your day in your diary, in fact you write only about Nicky (にっき). You love Nicky so much, your diary is full of Nicky this, Nicky that. Ah, Nicky is just the best.

Name: District Of A Town
Mnemonic: A street you can see with your eye isn't soooo big you can't see it (like a town would be), but it's still pretty big because it has a street. This section of the town is the district of a town, or a city block (though specifically one of an irregular size).
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, so use those and you'll be A-Okay.

Name: Doll
Mnemonic: Something that is person shaped that isn't a person? That has to be some kind of doll or puppet.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, and the reading of 形 is a bit of an oddball, here's a mnemonic to help you: Did you know that all dolls at Nintendo are made out of gyoza dumplings (にんぎょう)? They'll also regularly try to get you to eat them... Mmmm, gyoza dolls. Don't be afraid to take a bite!

Name: Elementary School Student
Mnemonic: You know 学生 is student, so what is a small student? Think young. That would be an Elementary School Student.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Elephant
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the ぞう reading of the kanji. You're at the ぞう show. How exciting.

Name: End Of The Month
Mnemonic: You know how 月 can also mean month? If you add 末 on there you have the "month end" aka the end of the month.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 月 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: When it's the end of the month, everybody gets mats (げつまつ). We don't pay people in money at Tofugu, but everyone gets mats at the month end instead.

Name: Fish
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Imagine a fish. Now imagine the fish playing soccer, while wearing a nun's outfit. This is a soccer nun (さかな).

Name: Floor
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, but here’s a mnemonic in case you need a refresher: You look at the floor. It's disgusting. Dirtiest and nastiest floor you've ever seen. You say yucka (ゆか) because it's covered in yucca (ゆか). Plus, it's all rotten. Yucka!

Name: Frantic
Mnemonic: Your future consists of certain death. How would you feel in this situation? Probably very frantic and desperate.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the on'yomi readings, though 必 (ひつ) gets shortened to ひっ. In your desperate situation just imagine that you're trying to get out of it, and to do so you move the つ only to find a smaller っ blocking your way. It is certain death.

Name: Freedom
Mnemonic: When you have self reason, you are able to think for yourself. When you can think for yourself, you have freedom. Very philosophical, this vocab is.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Full Name
Mnemonic: Both of these kanji have to do with names. You have both family name and name. Both of those names together makes for a First And Last Name... a full name if you will.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Future
Mnemonic: What has not yet come? The future.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Geography
Mnemonic: The reason the earth is the way it is is because of the geography of it. Though it may seem kind of strange that geography is bringing reason to the earth, if you think of geography as a study, then you can think about how you try to get reason through that, as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Goldfish
Mnemonic: A gold fish is really just gold in color, but it's still called a goldfish.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Group
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. That's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this one too. If you need a refresher, here's a mnemonic to help you: You're part of a special group. It is the cumin group, and they deal with all things cumin (the spice or seed). Smell the cumin. Touch it. Taste it. You live and breathe the stuff, because you are the president of this cumin group. P.S. This can also be spelled 組み (same reading: くみ) when it's a counter for groups, like ひと組み or ふた組み.

Name: Handmade
Mnemonic: When something is hand made, it is handmade!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for these kanji are the kun'yomi readings. Just think of this word as two separate words put together (手 and 作る). The る in 作る gets changed to り because it's an adjective, and the つ in つくり gets changed to づ because of the way the words are combined with each other. You should know most of the reading that is in this word, though it will probably take a little bit of thinking to sort out the little changes in those readings.

Name: Heavens
Mnemonic: The big thing in the sky is the heavens. The heavens where birds and planes soar, not the one you go to after you die if you've been really good.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that そら becomes ぞら because of rendaku here.

Name: High School
Mnemonic: The tall school is for when your kids get about as tall as they're going to get. That's high school, when most people stop growing taller.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: How To Make
Mnemonic: This is the way to make something. This is how to make something. You'll see this for directions on building something.
ReadingMnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 作る and 方. So as long as you're okay with those, you can apply that knowledge over here.

Name: Hull
Mnemonic: A boat's body is called the hull.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Human Habitation
Mnemonic: A person's hometown is a human habitation, or a village. This word has a slightly old-fashioned feel, and it's usually used for small villages in the countryside.
ReadingMnemonic: This jukugo uses the kun'yomi of the kanji instead of the more usual on'yomi. You learned both of these readings when you learned the vocabulary 人 and 里. Just notice that さと becomes ざと, because of rendaku.

Name: In A Big Way
Mnemonic: This is the adverb version of the kanji big. It's a little thing you can put in front of things to say that they are "in a big way" or "on a grand scale."
ReadingMnemonic: Since you already know the reading of the vocab word 大きい, you should be able to read this word as well.

Name: Inside Pocket
Mnemonic: Your inside ポケット is your inside pocket.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi for the kanji. You learned that reading when you learned the word 内.

Name: In The Near Future
Mnemonic: When something is close close (the 々 character repeats the kanji that was before it) it will happen in the near future, or soon.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading twice; that's the one you learn with the vocab word 近い from the previous level. The second 近 gets converted to ぢか, though, so take note of that. To write the character ぢ, type "di" on your keyboard.

Name: Jupiter
Mnemonic: The tree star is the planet Jupiter. Imagine Jupiter covered in very strange trees — the kind that are able to take root in gas! It's a pretty weird image, but will hopefully help you to remember this word. Alternatively, think about how the clouds around Jupiter make patterns that look a lot like wood grain.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Last Week
Mnemonic: The previous week was last week.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Letter
Mnemonic: A hand paper is a letter because letters are generally written by hand on paper.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is double kun'yomi. Think of 手紙 as two words mashed together — a letter is a thing you write by hand (て) on paper (かみ). You've learned those readings already, so you should be able to read this! Just watch out for the rendaku on がみ.

Name: Low Voice
Mnemonic: A small voice is so small that you can hardly hear it. It's a low voice or a whisper.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because, like in 大声, the こえ becomes ごえ thanks to our old friend rendaku.

Name: Mars
Mnemonic: The fire star is Mars. This should be easy to remember, because Mars is the only planet in our solar system that's the color of fire.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mental State
Mnemonic: The reasoning of your heart decides what you do. Probably when kanji was being made people thought that the heart directed our actions, not our brains. So, if you think about it that way, the reasoning of your heart is your mental state. Nowadays that's known as psychology.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Middle School Student
Mnemonic: You've seen 学生 (means student). Now let's look at a student who's in the middle. Perhaps we can call this a middle school student or a junior high school student, depending on where you're from.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Minute
Mnemonic: What's part of an hour? A minute, or minutes! This word is the suffix version of 分, so it goes after numbers to say how many minutes, and is used for telling the time too.
ReadingMnemonic: This uses a different on'yomi than what you learned with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading: How many minutes of fun (ふん) will you have today? Lots and lots of minutes, I hope! Depending on the number before 分, its pronunciation can change to ぷん, because of rendaku. We're looking for the original reading ふん here though!

Name: Mister
Mnemonic: The kanji means family name because it goes after a family name in very formal situations. So, it's really closely tied to that. Because only men got the respect back in the day, we're calling this vocab word mister. You can call me Mr. Koichi if you'd like, too.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji.

Name: Movie
Mnemonic: It's a reflection of an image on a screen, and the image is moving! What is this? It's a movie.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Napoleon The Third
Mnemonic: Adding "third generation" to someone's name means that they are the third generation of people with that name. In this case, the person's name is ナポレオン (Napoleon), so this means Napoleon The Third, also written as Napoleon III.
ReadingMnemonic: The kanji here are pronounced exactly the same as in the standalone word 三世. That is, it's a jukugo word which uses the on'yomi for both kanji.

Name: Near
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji near. So it also means near, or in the neighborhood of something.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 近い, so you should be able to read this word as well.

Name: Neptune
Mnemonic: The ocean king's star is Neptune! If you know anything about Roman mythology this should be easy to remember!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: New Year
Mnemonic: You correct the moon because it's a New Year. It's the beginning of a fresh year, so you gotta have the moon in the correct position.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Both of these kanji have a couple of on'yomi readings, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to use: At New Year, you hate your Shougun's guts (しょうがつ). He doesn't celebrate New Year, you see, so none of you get any time off. He even started a war last New Year and ruined everyone's holidays. No wonder you hate that shougun's guts.

Name: Next Week
Mnemonic: The next week is the next week. It isn't last week or this week, it's the next one!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: No Less Than
Mnemonic: Start from something and then go above it. Now you have "no less than ___," or, in other words, "___ or more"!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: No More Than
Mnemonic: Start from something and then go below it. Now you have "no more than ___," or, in other words, "___ or less!"
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: O'Clock
Mnemonic: If there's a number before 時, it means o'clock. For example １時 is 1:00, and ２３時 is 23:00 or 11pm.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Older Brother
Mnemonic: This word starts with an お to make it more polite. Then it has the kanji 兄 which you already know. Lastly, it has さん which is an honorific to elevate people and be polite. This is basically the formal way of saying older brother (versus plain old 兄). It can also be used to refer to a guy that you don't know who has a youthful appearance.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this one is pretty tricky, and I'd consider it an exception. To remember it, you have to learn the 兄 part, and everything else will fall into place. Here's a mnemonic to help you: Your (kind) older brother pushes you down on the ground. You stand up and look at your knee (にい), which is all bloody. "Why'd you do that to my knee!?" you ask. "You're supposed to be a nice older brother, that's why I call you お兄さん!"

Name: One Loaf of Bread
Mnemonic: One bread loaf counter is counting one loaf of bread.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening though!

Name: One O'clock
Mnemonic: When it's one o'clock it's one o'clock. It's time to eat lunch, or take a nap, or something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Other Than
Mnemonic: Compared with this, it's outside what you wanted. You'll have anything other than that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Paper
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but lucky for you that's the reading you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this vocab too.

Name: Period
Mnemonic: You have a period of time and it's called a period or era! Simple!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Previously
Mnemonic: From before, just means previously or before now.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Psychology
Mnemonic: The reason your heart does what it does is all psychological. The study of that is psychology.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Really
Mnemonic: 本当 is reality or truth (level 5 vocab). If you add on に, this changes the word to an adverb, and we get really or truly. 本当に!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It shares the reading with the level 5 本当 as well, but just has a particle on the end. Really!

Name: Reason
Mnemonic: A reason reason is a reason! How could it not be? Do you have a reason why it shouldn't be? I thought not.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Room Number
Mnemonic: This is a counter that can be used after numbers to let you know what number room it is. It's a room number that you use in apartments and hotels to know exactly which room you're looking for.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rude
Mnemonic: When you do something that's your fault and then you say "thanks" after you do it, that's super-duper rude, wouldn't you say? Imagine doing something like this and then thinking to yourself after... wow, I was really rude.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Saltwater Fish
Mnemonic: You've got a sea water fish, or in other words, a saltwater fish.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Same Time
Mnemonic: The same time? Okay, let's say what we think this word means at the same time. Whoops, I just said it, sorry.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: School
Mnemonic: A study school is obviously a place where people study and learn. In English, that's simply a school.
ReadingMnemonic: This jukugo word consists of on'yomi readings, except 学 (がく) is shortened with a small っ to make it がっこう.

Name: Shape
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What shape do you cut a cheese (かたち) into? Stars, triangles, little cubes, hearts! Anything but the boring slices other people do. You're like a mozzarella Michelangelo, the way you cut a cheese into those beautifully sculpted forms.

Name: Shortcoming
Mnemonic: You have a lack of points. These are things about yourself you wish were better. These are your shortcomings.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out because けつ is being shortened to けっ here!

Name: Snow
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for this vocab word. Enjoy the snow!

Name: Society
Mnemonic: Not to be confused with 会社, which is a company, this is society. When a company meets together, it's like a bunch of people, who are in groups, who come together to live in one world. That is a society.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Strong
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of strong? It's also strong.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you wanna be strong, you need to be able to use two yo-yos (つよ) at a time. Like, as weapons. And I don't mean with two hands. I mean one hand wielding two yo-yos. Now that's strong.

Name: Strong
Mnemonic: You have strong power. You are strong and powerful. Feel your strength.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: Nothing is as strong and powerful as the きょうと lock (りょく). It's a legendary lock produced in ancient きょうと, rumored to be the strongest lock in existence. What magical powers do you think lie behind the strength of the きょうと lock?

Name: Summer
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for the vocab.

Name: Summer Vacation
Mnemonic: You know that 夏 means summer and 休 means rest. What is a "summer rest" though? It's a summer break or summer vacation.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are kun'yomi readings because this word is essentially two separate words put together into one word. You should know the reading for 夏 from the kanji and the reading for 休み from the vocab.

Name: Surely
Mnemonic: This word looks like a verb but it's not (sorry!). It's an adverb. The kanji itself means certain and the vocab version means all sorts of variations on that: surely, certainly, and without exception to name a few.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Ra, the Egyptian god asks you: "Can you do it? Are you certain you can build the pyramids?" "Yes I can ra (かなら). Yes I can," you reply.

Name: Swan
Mnemonic: There are many white birds out there, for sure, but one really stands out if you ask me. That bird is the swan. It's big, it's white, and it's majestic.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: System
Mnemonic: Doing something as a group requires a system. Without some sort of structure, everyone does their own thing, and you would never be able to get stuff done as a group, you know?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a word with an irregular combination of readings. 仕 uses its on'yomi reading, and 組 uses its kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember this unusual combination: To be more successful in doing group assignments, you came up with a system called "sheep cumin (しくみ). Why "sheep cumin"? Sheep are known to be good team players (or herd players, should I say?), so you just sticked it to the name of the group you lead, the cumin group, hoping everyone can work together better, like sheep!

Name: Tall
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of tall or expensive? It's the same: tall or expensive.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Being tall is really expensive because you have to buy a tall car (たか). If it's not a tall car then your tall body won't fit inside, and those tall cars are expensive!

Name: That
Mnemonic: Remember how それ means "that one"? その has a very similar meaning: that. It's used before a noun that's either close to the person you're talking to, or fairly close to both of you. For example, その本 is "that book", and the book in question might be in the hand of the person you're talking to, or it might be on a shelf not far from you both.

Name: That Over There
Mnemonic: Remember how あれ means "that one over there"? Well, あの means that, and goes before a noun to point out something that is far away from both you and the person you're talking to, such as あの本 (that book over there) or あの子犬 (that puppy over there).

Name: The End
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Throw a "the" in there if you'd like, as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You've reached the end of the universe. Nothing is there. You step out, and you're surprised because you get greeted by an old Canadian man. Sue, eh?(すえ) he asks you, over and over. The poor man is looking for his wife Sue, and he's searched to the end of the universe. That's true love. As he walks off into the distance, you hear him calling out, "Sue, eh? Sue, eh? Sue, eh?"

Name: The Heck
Mnemonic: Okay, so this one is really weird, sorry. Each of us only get one body in our lifetimes, right? Well what the heck! What if I want more than one body. Let's all be mad about this together.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because いち is shortened to いっ here!

Name: The People
Mnemonic: The country peoples are the people of your country. They are the people.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: This Week
Mnemonic: The now week is this week.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Thought
Mnemonic: This is a noun version of think. What is "a think"? It's a thought.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading with 考える, just cut off the る!

Name: Thousand Yen Bill
Mnemonic: You know what 千円 is (1000 yen). So if you add a bill to that you get a thousand yen bill. That's just the little rectangular piece of money that is worth 1000 yen.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Time
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: What time is it? It's time to key (とき) your enemy's car. Imagine yourself looking at your watch, waiting until the correct time to perform a synchronized keying of someone's car. Who do you hate the most? Whose car would you like to key?

Name: To Attach Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means attach so the verb version is to attach something.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is actually the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this one just fine.

Name: To Be Fixed
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fix, so the verb 直る is similar to that: to be fixed.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to learn the なお part. Think of it this way. Something needs to be fixed. It's urgent! It has to be fixed now! (なお).

Name: To Be Found
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Cut Off
Mnemonic: If you cut and take something, you are going to cut it right off. So, this verb is to cut off.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 切る and 取る. So, know those words separately and you can combine them into this word.

Name: To Divide Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う (in this case る) sound, you know this word is a verb. One of the kanji meanings is divide, which makes this to divide something or to separate something. Depending on the context, it can also mean to share or to classify.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already know this reading from 分かる, but here’s a mnemonic in case you forgot: Whenever you need to divide something, you can’t help screaming "WAAAAAAAAAHHHH" (わ). You hate having to divide things, or people, so you always end up screaming "WAAAAAAAAAHHHH" in agony.

Name: To Lose
Mnemonic: The kanji portion means fault, so you would think the verb version is "to fault." It's a little different, though. Think of it this way, if you "fault" something, you're messing up. What's a great way to mess up? By losing something. That's why this word means to lose.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: So how did you lose the wedding ring anyway? Well... it was eaten by a cow. The 牛 now (うし + なう) has to have it surgically removed. What a mess!

Name: To Pick Out
Mnemonic: To take something and then remove it, is when you reach in and grab something and choose it and pull it out. This is to pick out or to take out.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from the individual words 取る and 出す. Put them together and you should be able to read this word too.

Name: To Shine
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means light or shine, so the verb is to shine, to flash, or to glitter. Just imagine what happens when something emits light!
ReadingMnemonic: Remember how you learned the reading for 光? Well this is almost the same thing. Just change the り to る and you'll know this reading!

Name: To Substitute For
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means substitute, and the verb 代わる means to substitute for or to take over for. Use it when one player substitutes for another in sports, for example, or when someone takes over for you at work.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the か part: You need something to substitute for your car (か). It's getting repaired, so you can't use it now. I guess you can substitute your bike for your car?

Name: To Teach
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means teach so the verb vocab version means to teach. It's also used to mean to tell in a more general sense.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about your favorite teacher. Now think about them teaching you the following: "Today I'm going to teach you about the ocean (おし)." It is big. Really big. Inside it are krakens, space aliens, and lost cities. Here is where you continue the lesson in your head, making it the most ridiculous lesson about the ocean you've ever heard. Focus in on the ocean part, since that's the reading, always coming back to it.

Name: Townspeople
Mnemonic: Town peoples are the townspeople! This can also be singular, so a townsperson.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Traffic
Mnemonic: Even though it gets mixed up as it passes through itself, modern traffic and transport systems are pretty amazing. This word refers to traffic and transport for pedestrians, bikes, cars, buses, trains, planes... anything that gets us from A to B.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Triangle
Mnemonic: You already learned that 三角 means "triangle." Well this means triangle too, but it's the mathematical term. You should use it in math class.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Two Loaves of Bread
Mnemonic: Two bread loaf counters are counting two loaves of bread.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Two Thirty
Mnemonic: When it's two o'clock and a half what time do you think it is? That would be two thirty.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Typhoon
Mnemonic: A machine that pumps wind can malfunction and make too much, causing a typhoon. It's a really powerful machine to be able to move that much wind.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Instead of だい for 台 though, this uses the reading たい. Remember it like this: When a typhoon is coming you have to tie (たい) down all of your stuff. Or, you know, if you already know the word typhoon, that's fine too.

Name: University Student
Mnemonic: You know that 学生 means "student" and you know that 大学 means university/college. Combine the two and you have a university student / college student.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Unpopular
Mnemonic: You already know 人気 which means "popular." And you also know that 不 means "not." So what do you get when you combine the two? Something that's not popular or unpopular.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Way Of Saying
Mnemonic: Your saying way is… your way of saying! This refers to the words you use and how you phrase things, as well as how you say it.
ReadingMnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 言う and 方. You might be more used to the on'yomi for 方 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember the kun'yomi (かた). Your way of saying things is to catapult (かた) them right into people's ears. Just catapult those words like you're trying to break through their ear drums.

Name: Way Of Thinking
Mnemonic: The think way is really the way someone thinks. That's why this word means way of thinking.
ReadingMnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 考える and 方. You might be more used to the on'yomi for 方 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember the kun'yomi (かた). Your way of thinking is like a catapult (かた). You just launch ideas at the wall and see what sticks. Sure it's a bit inexact, but it's the best thought process for you. The catapult way of thinking just suits you!

Name: Weak
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of weak? It's also weak.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You just got beaten up because you're weak. Then the bully asks you: "Yo! Why (よわ) you so weak?"

Name: Weak Point
Mnemonic: The weak point is your weak point.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Weekend
Mnemonic: The end of the week is the weekend... that is, unless you work on the weekend, but we can't cater to everyone here.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: What Time
Mnemonic: This is a good word to know to ask for the time. What is the time? This is how you ask what time it is.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Wind
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Do you know the word "kamikaze" from WWII history? Well, it means "divine wind." The "kaze" part is the wind part, and this word uses the same reading, making it かぜas well.

Name: Year End
Mnemonic: The year end is the year end aka the end of the year.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Yellow
Mnemonic: The yellow color is just the color yellow.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the same as the readings you learned with the kanji meaning you should be able to read this word right off the bat.

Name: Above Ground
Mnemonic: Remember 地下, which is "below ground." Well, this is ground and above combined together, so I bet you can guess that this means above ground. But usually things above ground don't float (unless you're in space), so it's really on the ground.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Address
Mnemonic: If you dwell in a place, that place is your address.
ReadingMnemonic: This word is made up of the on'yomi readings that you've already learned with the kanji. Have at it!

Name: Advice
Mnemonic: When you help with what you say, you're giving advice.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: All America
Mnemonic: Do you remember how 米国 can mean "America?" That 米 means America sometimes. So, when you see all rice (I mean, America), you can think of this word as meaning All America (sort of like how 全日本 means "All Japan.").
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: A Memory
Mnemonic: Do you remember the word 思う? It means "to think." What you are thinking is exiting—it's coming out of your head! You're recalling a memory or multiple memories.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi, but based off of previous experience with the two separate words that make up this word, you should be able to read it. Just remember that it's kun'yomi. One hint is the hiragana sticking out of the 思.

Name: Amount Of Time
Mnemonic: When you stick this onto the end of another word that talks about an interval of time in some way, you're indicating the amount of time that has gone past. For example, 二年間 is "two years." 一時間 is "one hour." Any amount of time + 〜間 will make it an "amount of time" instead of just a specific time.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. This should save you at least 二分間.

Name: Another Place
Mnemonic: When you're talking about some other place you're talking about another place.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which you would normally expect to use the on'yomi readings from the kanji. With this word, however, the on'yomi readings are rarely used now, so they sound rather out of date. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember the more common reading in contemporary Japanese: Another place you saw (よそ) always seems better. In other words, the grass is greener somewhere else you saw!

Name: Answer
Mnemonic: You can guess this is a noun version of the kanji because the hiragana sticking out of it isn't an う-related sound or an い-related sound. So, what is the noun version of answer? It's also answer.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is kun'yomi, but this is also the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this and then give your 答え correctly.

Name: Area
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji for area. This makes it have the same meaning as the kanji: area, vicinity, or neighborhood.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you think about an area that you're in, it's the place you're at (あた).

Name: Author
Mnemonic: Someone who makes is someone who creates things. Back in the day, a creator like this may have been known as many things, but the big one that stands out is an author.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 作 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: Your favorite author is also a sack shaman (さくしゃ). They do all sorts of weird magic involving sacks, and you just love reading about it. Maybe one day, you can become a sack shaman and writer yourself.

Name: Battery
Mnemonic: A pond for electricity? May seem weird at first, but if you think of something that's gathering all the electricity into one pond... that thing is like a battery (and is a battery).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Body
Mnemonic: The kanji is somebody, but the word is body. I guess somebody is somebody's body, so they are similar at least. It also refers to animal flesh sometimes, meaning the non-bone edible parts of animals, including seafood. It's the "mi" in sashimi!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Who is that somebody? Who is that body? Why, of course it is me (み).

Name: Body And Mind
Mnemonic: Technically this kanji is heart and somebody, but think about it this way. Where does everything come from inside somebody? The heart! It keeps things going by pumping blood, providing the foundation for both a good mind and body.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Both People
Mnemonic: When you have both someones, you have both people. You'll notice over time that 者 is often used to indicate a person or type of person, so keep that in mind for future words as well!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Boy Name Ender
Mnemonic: Add this to the end of someone's name, it's like saying ______buddy. It's generally used as a name ender (like さん) for boys and young men. Don't use this on people who are higher ranked than you (socially or literally). As in, you wouldn't use it on your boss. Use it on your younger male subordinates as well as boys who aren't adults yet.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji (on'yomi), probably because it usually is attached to other words (aka names, like こういち君) making it act more like jukugo words do.

Name: Branch Office
Mnemonic: The support shop is the branch office. Presumably this is because the regular "shop" is the "shop" and anything that supports it is the local (branch) office.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Branch Office
Mnemonic: The support bureau is the group that supports a business. It is the branch office.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Breakfast
Mnemonic: ごはん is a food or meal (maybe you'll learn the kanji for it later, but it's not usually used, so you're learning it this way now). What is your morning meal? That is breakfast (not to be confused with second breakfast, you hobbit).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 朝 is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read everything here.

Name: Bureau
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The kanji and the vocab are exactly the same, even the reading. This one uses the on'yomi probably because it's often attached to other words (specifying a bureau, for example), so that's why it follows jukugo conventions despite being all alone.

Name: But
Mnemonic: I want to show you my demo (でも), but you don't want to see it. However, I'm going to show it to you anyway. So there.

Name: Cloud
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading because it's a single kanji on its own. Luckily, that's the reading you learned with the kanji already, so you should be able to read this.

Name: Comfort
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji you learned, too, making this one an ease to learn!

Name: Completely
Mnemonic: This is the adverb version of the kanji all. So, it's like you add an 'ly' to it. But, that doesn't work too well (allly? c'mon). So, instead think of this word as completely, entirely or truly.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The person who completely doesn't understand this vocab word is Matt (まった). Be sure to take note of the small っ, too.

Name: Conversation
Mnemonic: When you meet and talk with someone else, you're having a conversation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Doctor
Mnemonic: Someone who works in medicine is a doctor.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Duty
Mnemonic: If you have an eye for service, then you'll always think helping people is your duty! If you see someone in need of service, you’ll always offer your help, because that’s your duty.
ReadingMnemonic: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 役 and the kun'yomi reading for 目. You've learned them both so you should be able to read this word too!

Name: East Exit
Mnemonic: Remember 北口 from a few levels before, and how 入り口 means "entrance" and 出口 means "exit?" Combine that 口 meaning with the kanji for east, and you get east exit or east entrance.
ReadingMnemonic: Just like the other 口s, this also uses kun'yomi readings. And just like before, watch out for the rendaku that changes くち to ぐち!

Name: Electricity
Mnemonic: Electricity energy is just a fancy way to say electricity.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Electric Power
Mnemonic: The electricity power of something is its electric power.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: All the world's electric power is stored behind this lock (りょく). Go ahead. Open it up. What could possibly go wrong?

Name: Electron
Mnemonic: An electricity child. What is a really small part of electricity? What makes up electricity? That would be the electron. This word can also refer to things that are electronic as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Emoji
Mnemonic: When you use a picture to replace your letters to type, you're using emoji! Those are the faces you send when you text or email.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Engineer
Mnemonic: Do you remember 工学 from a couple levels ago? This is someone who is in 工学. If 工学 is "engineering" then 工学者 is an engineer.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are just the on'yomi readings of the kanji. All things you should know now.

Name: Entrance
Mnemonic: When you enter a location, that's your entrance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Every Morning
Mnemonic: Every morning is every morning!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

Name: Factory
Mnemonic: A construction location is a factory. A factory is a place where you or machines do a bunch of construction!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Famous Place
Mnemonic: A famous place is a famous place. When traveling around Japan, you should ask about the 名所 if you can.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Fun
Mnemonic: Ending with an い tells you that this word is an い-adjective. What's the adjective form of pleasure? Well, you could say it's "pleasurable," but I'm afraid that's not what we're going for here. In this case, this word is a little more innocent. It just means fun.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: How much fun did you have? You just had a ton o' (たの) fun!

Name: Hello
Mnemonic: Woah, this place is mossy, mossy (もしもし)! This moss needs clearing up, so you call up the person in charge. Hello, says the person on the phone.

Name: Here
Mnemonic: Remember how words beginning with こ are close to you? It ends with こ too, which is a clue that we’re talking about a place. So ここ means here.

Name: Hokkaido
Mnemonic: The north sea road is the road you take to get to the northern sea. That is an area of Japan, actually. That area is known as Hokkaido. It's a very nice place, be sure to visit it if you can for some of the freshest seafood around.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ほく does get shortened though, so be careful!

Name: Horse
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Imagine someone riding a horse. Who is that person? It's Uma (うま) Thurman, the famous actress.

Name: Horsepower
Mnemonic: This word was probably made pretty recently. A horse's power? That is horsepower.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two common on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: Cars with high horsepower are usually driven by Ricky (りき). Ricky is well-known for loving all cars with a lot of horsepower, so he's often seen driving around in fancy sports cars. Vroom vroom Ricky!

Name: Human
Mnemonic: The person interval. Just think of different intervals each with a different type of species. The raccoon interval... the dog interval... the person interval... they are the humans.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, and the reading of 間 is a bit of an oddball, here's a mnemonic to help you: Did you know that the humans who work for Nintendo are all called Genji (にんげん)? Yep, that's right, every single human ever hired by Nintendo is called Genji, without exception.

Name: Important Task
Mnemonic: A big duty is a great duty. It can also be an important task. Think about some kind of big duty you have. Then, think about what an important task it is too. Feel proud of your important task.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.
