ReadingMnemonic: Whenever something is about to become empty, you can't help saying "Ah…" (あ) to express your disappointment. Your glass of water is becoming empty? Ah… Your bag of chips is becoming empty? Ah… Exclaiming a little "Ah…" is the only thing that helps you cope with the sadness of your favorite things becoming empty.

Name: To Be Emotionally Moved
Mnemonic: You know this is a verb from the する. Your feelings have been moved. So, when your feelings have been moved, you are emotionally moved. This word is to be emotionally moved or simply to be moving. Just be sure to know this has to do with emotions.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Be Released
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means release and the verb vocab version means to be released. You can differentiate this one from 放す (to release) by thinking that it's pretty rare (れる) for you to be released by your arch nemesis. He just let you go, strangely. How rare.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 放す. As long as you know that word you can apply that reading over here as well.

Name: To Bring Up
Mnemonic: This is similar to 育つ, except now you're doing the raising of someone. This word means to bring up or to raise. You can remember this because of the てる. Your version of bringing a child up involves tearing (てる) all their clothes to make them look poor so they can get the cheaper lunch at school. You're rich because of all the tax breaks you get from all the children you're raising, but you could always use more money to fuel your StarCraft addiction (we've all been there).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 育つ. So long as you know that one, you know how to read this one as well.

Name: To Catch Up With
Mnemonic: To follow then attach yourself to the whoever you're following is to catch up with someone.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, but you can also just notice that this word includes 追う and 付く combined.

Name: To Chase
Mnemonic: 追う means "to follow" or “to chase” and かける in this case means “to run,” so this word means to chase, to pursue, or to run after someone or something.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 追う as well as the kanji reading you learned too.

Name: To Choose
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "choose", so the verb version is to choose.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have the opportunity to choose. You choose, and a bright sign lights up reading "error" (えら).

Name: To Feel
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means feeling so the verb vocab version is to feel.
ReadingMnemonic: Guess what? Even though this would use the vocab kun'yomi reading, usually, the readings for both on'yomi and kun'yomi on this kanji are the same, meaning you can read this word no matter what. Feeling better now?

Name: To Fight
Mnemonic: This is the verb version of the vocab word 戦い, which I'm hoping you learned earlier. The verb version of course means to fight or to battle.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 戦い a word you've hopefully seen by now. Associate these words together in your mind and you'll be able to read them so long as you know the other one.

Name: To Foster
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means foster so the verb vocab version is to foster or to raise. This can also refer to fostering a skill or ability, so can also mean to develop or to cultivate.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're offering to raise some girl as your own. After the paperwork is over, you can finally say: "Yah, she now (やしな) is my kid!"

Name: To Get Accepted
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 受 means accept and this verb is related. It means to get accepted, usually into something good like a university or a new job. It can also mean to pass, often in the context of a test or an exam.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Here's a little mnemonic to help ya remember: To get accepted into this program, you have to juggle unis (う)—yes, those spiky sea urchins! Handling uni is tough, but if you want to pass the test and get accepted, you've got to master the uni challenge.

Name: To Get Tired
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tired, so the verb version means to get tired.
ReadingMnemonic: For example, you're bound to get tired if you try to lift two cars (つか), right? So think about that as you learn this word's reading.

Name: To Heat Something Up
Mnemonic: You know that the kanji 温 means warm, and this verb is related. It means to heat something up or to warm something up. It's all about you doing something to another object to make it hot, like putting it in the microwave.
ReadingMnemonic: The kanji reading is the same as 温かい. As long as you know that reading, you should be able to associate it with this word. Just like you can say あったかい for 温かい, people often say あっためる in conversation. The "official" reading is still あたためる, so when typing out the kanji or taking a test, try to stick to あたためる.

Name: To Help
Mnemonic: When you transmit your hand to something or someone, you're putting out your hand to help them or to assist them.
ReadingMnemonic: Both of these are the kun'yomi readings that you've already learned! The thing is, the た from 伝's つた changes into だ for who knows what reason. Perhaps you can ask for someone to help you to understand this dumb reading change.

Name: To Imagine
Mnemonic: To imagine some sort of an image in your mind simply means to imagine.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Kill
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means kill so the verb vocab version is to kill.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You kill someone! Oh no, what are you going to do? Where will you put the body? You decide to stuff it into the core (ころ) of a nuclear silo. It will melt and disappear in there, right? At least, that's what you think. Imagine opening up the core of the nuclear silo and feel the burn of the radiation. You throw the body in and close the core, then run away. Unfortunately, this nuclear core will kill you too, eventually. Then, it will kill everyone in the area, because the body you threw in will overheat the core, causing a giant explosion.

Name: To Look Back At
Mnemonic: Your seeing is returning on something. This verb can be both transitive and intransitive. When it’s transitive, it means to look back at, in the sense of looking back at someone who’s behind you, or looking back at your past. When it’s intransitive, it simply means to look back, in the sense of looking over your shoulder.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are just 見 and the vocab word 返る, combined together. So long as you know both of those you should be able to combine them into the reading for this word.

Name: To Order
Mnemonic: You hopefully have seen the word 注文 (order, request). This is just the verb version: to order / to request.
ReadingMnemonic: If you know the reading of 注文 you should be able to read this one too. Also, it's just all jukugo on'yomi readings, so you should be able to read it anyways.

Name: Topic
Mnemonic: The topic that we are talking about is the topic that we are talking about. It's the subject of our conversation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Separate
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means separate, so you can guess the meaning is to separate or to be divided.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember the word 分ける? That word means "to separate" too. The reading is similar, though not the same, but we can at least use it as a jumping off point. We go from わける to わかれる. It's like we've "separated" the け and the る and combined them in the middle. け, making a かれ, which gets you to わかれる.

Name: To Share
Mnemonic: This is the same as 共有 but the verb version.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 共有 as well as the readings you learned via the kanji.

Name: To Solve
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means solve so the verb vocab version is to solve. You know this verb is for when you are doing the solving because you think it's super coo' (く) to solve things.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: There's something you've been trying to solve for your entire life: your toe (と). Why is it shaped like that? Why is it a little crooked? What's it scheming? Maybe one day you'll solve the mystery of your toe…

Name: Train Station Employee
Mnemonic: A train station member is someone who works at the train station. They are a train station employee. Feel free to ask them if you need help knowing which direction to train in.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Understanding
Mnemonic: When the reason is solved, you reach an understanding of something. You reach comprehension.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Uranus
Mnemonic: The heaven king star is the planet Uranus. Knowledge of Greek mythology will definitely help you here, because the English name is a reference to the Greek god of the skies, and the Japanese name is a direct translation of that!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word and uses the on'yomi, but over time the reading for 王 changed from おう to のう, to make it easier to pronounce. You'll still see that listed as an alternative reading in some dictionaries, but it's pretty much never used nowadays, so we'll only accept the てんのうせい reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember: Who predicted the discovery of Uranus? Nostradamus (のう), of course!

Name: We
Mnemonic: When たち is attached to a word referring to a person, it makes it plural. So, when you attach たち to 俺 (I), it means we or us.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Wheel
Mnemonic: What part of your car are car rings? The wheels, of course!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Ability
Mnemonic: Your ability power is what you can do. This is your ability. It is also your capability.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: About
Mnemonic: The kanji means promise, but the meaning of this word is about, which is a little different. Just think about promises. When you promise something you really need to follow through... but only about as much as you need to for the other person to be happy. Someone asks for a puppy for Christmas, and you get them a stuffed animal puppy. It's approximately the promise you made. Close enough. *wink*
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this is actually the same one that you learned with the kanji, so no need to memorize anything new!

Name: Acquaintance
Mnemonic: You've probably seen the words 知る and 合う by now. This is someone you "know" because you have "come together" before, but that's pretty much it. You don't really know them well, you just met them a couple times so you know who they are. This person is an acquaintance.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are that of 知る and 合う. So long as you know those words, you should be able to read this one too.

Name: -al
Mnemonic: This is a strange word, I'm afraid. You'll have to bear with it. This, when added onto a word, is like adding an -al or a -like to the end of it—or when something is typical of something else. For example, add it onto 日本 (Japan) and you have "Japanese-like", or "typically Japanese". It's a weird sort of modifying word that really depends on each situation it's in. For now, just know this word means these things. We'll start applying it to various words in the future, slowly but surely.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, probably because this is usually added onto other words, making it behave like a jukugo.

Name: Anniversary
Mnemonic: When you wrap around the entire  circumference of the year you've come back around to the start of it. This is the anniversary.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Association
Mnemonic: When you meet for cooperation, you're coming together to help each other. One form of this is when people form associations. They're all cooperating and coming together to help each other and themselves.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Atmosphere
Mnemonic: The surrounding energy in the atmosphere is what makes up the atmosphere. I love it when it takes three kanji to represent what one of the three kanji already represents.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note: You'll sometimes hear people say ふいんき, but if you wrote that on a test you'd be marked wrong, so we're sticking with the more standard ふんいき reading. If you need help remembering it, just look a little closer at the kanji — you'll know 雰 is ふん because it gets its reading from the little 分 inside it!

Name: Automatic
Mnemonic: Something that can move by its self is something that's automatic.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Bad Feeling
Mnemonic: The 気持ち (feeling) is bad. So, you can imagine how you feel isn't good, it's a bad feeling. You're feeling terrible, in fact.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from the words 気持ち and 悪い. Hopefully you've seen both and can combine them together to know the reading automatically. No bad feelings with this word, right?

Name: Bad-Mouthing
Mnemonic: Your bad mouth produces nothing but bad-mouthing and trash-talk.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings for these two kanji, probably because this word is just two words put together into one (bad + mouth). Use your knowledge of the vocab words 悪い and 口 to learn the reading of this word. Okay, I lied. You should actually do わるぐち instead. わるくち is possible, but the rendaku version is way more common. Sorry to say such bad things before.

Name: Bone
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Take a look at your own bones. They have been upgraded with special technology, allowing you to hone (ほね) in on targets, then shoot your bones at them. Go ahead and imagine yourself using this crazy new bone technology. Wolverine is jealous.

Name: Broken Bone
Mnemonic: When your bone breaks, you end up with, well, a broken bone or fracture.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out because こつ is shortened to こっ here.

Name: Bundle
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You are counting your bundles. There are a lot of them, so you have to create tabs (たば) in your notebook to properly categorize everything. Imagine yourself doing this (physically creating the tabs in your notebook, even though your notebook didn't come with tabs).

Name: Care
Mnemonic: Older generations mostly talk about one thing: care. Everybody wants to receive care once they're older, don't they?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that 世 is せ here, and not せい!

Name: Carrot
Mnemonic: What do you use to get a person to participate in something? A carrot, of course. You've heard of "the carrot and the stick," right? So next time you want a person to participate, offer them a carrot.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 参 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're craving a carrot, but you can't seem to find any. You look in your fridge, in your garden, and even in the trash. Finally you give up your carrot search and sit down when... ouch! The carrot was in your jeans (じん) the whole time!

Name: Case
Mnemonic: What location suits a situation the best? That always depends on the case or circumstance. You can't know the suitability of the location until you have all the facts about the circumstances.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You didn't learn these readings with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out: There are few cases where you want to baa (ば) while making eyes (あい) at someone. In the circumstance of a sheep looking for love, it may be acceptable, but in any other situation it's probably not appropriate behavior.

Name: Character
Mnemonic: Your person status is where you, yourself, are a person. This is more than skin deep, though, this is your status after all. This is your character and personality. What's the status of your character? Good? Bad? Getting there?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Circumference
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji circumference, so it means circumference too.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You really want to measure the circumference of something but there doesn't seem to be anything round around. That's when you remember, "Mah Walnuts! (まわ)." The walnuts in your pocket have an easy edge to measure.

Name: Comedian
Mnemonic: What is the greatest art a person can possess? It’s got to be the art of making people laugh. That’s why this means comedian, though it can also mean a performer or entertainer more generally.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Complete
Mnemonic: When something is all perfect it is complete. Not only that, but it's perfect (because it's ALL perfect, not just partially so).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Completion
Mnemonic: A perfect finish is when everything is at total completion. Nothing is left over and all is done.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Completion
Mnemonic: When something has become perfect it has reached completion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Compromise
Mnemonic: When you have gentle cooperation nobody has their way. You're very gently coming towards the middle, coming to a compromise. (Whether you like it or not.)
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Condition
Mnemonic: You have to find the right tool to suit your condition or state. If you have a health condition, the tool is a pill, or exercise, or real life friends. But it always depends on the condition you're in.
ReadingMnemonic: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 具 and the kun'yomi reading for 合. You've learned them both, so you should be able to read this word too!

Name: Contemporary
Mnemonic: Something that is near period like is very contemporary. But if it looks like it's from a period not near the one you're in... throw it away! It isn't modern enough to touch your hands!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cooking
Mnemonic: There is a reason for this fee that you have to pay to get in here. We are cooking cuisine for you to eat while you're watching the show. If we weren't cooking a dish for you, we probably wouldn't charge you this fee!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Cooperation
Mnemonic: Cooperation power is your level of cooperation. It's how much collaboration or assistance you provide.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Cycle
Mnemonic: If you follow the circumference of a period of time, you end up back at the beginning and it makes a full cycle. Events in history always repeat, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Day After Tomorrow
Mnemonic: Things will be bright after the next day. Or you can think of it as adding an 後 in between your 明日. And what comes after tomorrow? It's the day after tomorrow.
ReadingMnemonic: Unfortunately, the reading for this is a complete exception, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "What do you want to eat the day after tomorrow?", your mom asks you. You answer, "Ah, satay (あさって)?" You're not so confident because you never know what you want to eat the day after tomorrow, but you absolutely love satay, the Indonesian skewers. Ah, satay it is!

Name: Depth
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji deep, so it means depth.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 深い so you should be able to read this one too!

Name: Desire
Mnemonic: The hope you request is your desire. Just imagine yourself hoping and requesting some higher power for something you really want. What is this? It's your desire or wish.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Diction
Mnemonic: Remember how 言葉 means "language?" Well, the way you "attach" (付き) language to things is your diction. Everyone has their own 言葉つき when they speak. How would you describe your 言葉つき?
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Disappointment
Mnemonic: There is fault in your hope. It breaks, and everything falls apart. You feel massive disappointment and despair.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Eraser
Mnemonic: You've seen the word 消す, I hope. This comes from that. You're extinguishing something with ゴム. ゴム is a word for either gummy or rubbery things. So, this is a gummy thing that extinguishes something. This is an eraser that extinguishes pencil markings.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 消す, so make sure you know that word so you can read this one!

Name: Everyone
Mnemonic: Everyone (formal name ender). This is just a polite way to say everyone (and you want to be polite to everyone, because everyone > you).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for both kanji here are the same as the ones you learned with their kanji. Everyone can breathe easier now.

Name: Evil Intent
Mnemonic: Someone with bad energy is someone who has evil intent, malice, or ill will. Hopefully you don't have too much 悪気.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading itself has a lot of 悪気 with all the exceptions it has. The 悪 part is read like 悪い. Then, 気 is rendaku'd. What an evil reading. Just think "what's the most evil reading I can come up with?" when you see this word. Then you should hopefully be able to read it.

Name: Example Sentence
Mnemonic: Example writing is a piece of writing that is an example for maybe a word or a kanji or something like that. This is an example sentence.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Exception
Mnemonic: Something that's outside the example doesn't follow the rules. It's not what it's supposed to be (the example), it is the exception.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Female
Mnemonic: Someone who's of the woman gender is probably going to be female.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: For Example
Mnemonic: This has almost the same meaning as the kanji it comes from. Instead of just simply being "example," though, it's for example. It can also sometimes mean supposing that when talking about hypothetical scenarios. So, supposing that I start a sentence with this, I can be all like "例えば, I am using 例えば in a sentence."
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Using all kinds of "for examples" like this, you were taught (たと) many things throughout your life. For example, you were taught about...

Name: Foundation
Mnemonic: The origin of your foundation is where you have to work from when learning something new. For example, the 基本 portions of WaniKani are the earlier levels, especially the radicals. They are the foundation you need to learn your kanji and vocab later on.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Fur
Mnemonic: This word is pretty straightforward. You have fur and skin, making a word meaning fur or pelt, like the kind that can be used to make garments.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a special case because both kanji use kun'yomi readings in this word. Luckily, you already know the kun'yomi reading from learning the vocabulary 毛 and 皮 previously. Just be careful with the rendaku on the second kanji, 皮.

Name: Game
Mnemonic: An attempt to join together isn't just any get together. Imagine two people boxing. They attempt to knock each other out when they join together. That's why this word is game or match. Did you watch the 試合 today? No! Don't tell me what happened, I recorded it on the VHS.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi し for 試 and the kun'yomi あい for 合, which you learned with 場合. So you should be able to put them together!

Name: Geisha
Mnemonic: The arts are performed by someone. Who is that someone? Well, think about the reading for this kanji. Do you recognize the word? It's geisha.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Gender
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Good
Mnemonic: A good like is something you like really good, if that makes any sense. This thing is a good and favorable thing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

Name: Good Work
Meaning: Thank You For Your Hard Work
Mnemonic: You are a 疲れ (tired) 様 (honorific that kind of refers to whoever's being mentioned). You say this to people when they've done good work — at the end of a workday or after a hard practice, for example. I guess the idea is that if they're tired, they've done some good work. Tell your coworkers お疲れ様でした when they leave for the day, or just use お疲れ in more casual situations with friends!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 疲れ and 様, combined together into one word.

Name: Graduation
Mnemonic: The business of you graduating is your graduation. If you think about it, it's kind of a big business, getting you graduated from expensive schools. The graduation business focuses on graduations, and getting you there (hint: this business is a school, probably).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Hard
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of hard? It's hard, firm, or tough.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need something really hard to put in your catapult(かた). Look around you for something hard and imagine putting it in your catapult!

Name: Heart's Desire
Mnemonic: What your thoughts request inside your head, nonstop like a crazy person, are your heart's desires.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Hope
Mnemonic: Both your hopes and wishes are held within this vocab word. So, what is the meaning of this word? It is both hope and wish. Either will work.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Indigestion
Mnemonic: You've hopefully seen 消化 by now and know that it means "digestion." If you know that, then you can see that the "digestion" is not good. When your digestion is not good, what do you have? Indigestion. Excuse me, I have to run to the restroom...
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 消化 and 不良 will help as well.

Name: Ingredients
Mnemonic: You have to pay a fee for the material you use to make food. Those are the ingredients you're paying for! Imagine making a list of all of the materials you need to make a stew, then making sure you have enough to pay the fees, so you'll have all the ingredients you need to make it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Instance
Mnemonic: One example is just an instance of what you're describing. Just one example.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Instinct
Mnemonic: The abilities you originally start out with are instincts. Animals have lots of them because they aren't very good at learning. They have to start out knowing them from the start.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Intentional
Mnemonic: You wouldn't put your idea in a diagram ~like format if it wasn't intentional. Doing that takes a lot of work. So you can only make diagram like things on purpose!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 図 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You intentionally stub your toe (と) all the time! If you hurt your toe on purpose you can get out of class and work! It's a really simple injury, but you can't do other stuff while it's hurt, so you always do it on purpose to get out of things.

Name: Kimono
Mnemonic: The things you wear are your clothes. Oh, and Japanese clothes count too. We're talking kimonos. Way back when, these could just be called clothes because it's all people really wore, but nowadays we know they're specific to the stereotypical kimono you think of when you think "Japan."
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a bit strange using kun'yomi readings. Luckily, we taught you these already, so go put on that kimono of yours and relax at the 温泉 for a bit.

Name: Line of Text
Mnemonic: You write the word go on a line of text. See the word "go" on that line, and think about where you're going.
ReadingMnemonic: There are two on'yomi readings for this kanji, but when it's used to mean lines of text, it's pronounced as ぎょう. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember that: You write out another line of text asking for some gyoza (ぎょう). You write out that line of text slowly and carefully, in your very best handwriting. Turns out you were going to a gyoza restaurant and you want to make sure you impress the gyoza chef, so that they give you a ton of gyoza.

Name: Lumber
Mnemonic: Lumber trees are what you use to make lumber and timber.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Main Building
Mnemonic: One of the meanings of 本 is main (which is what we're using here). The main public building is the main building.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. For you advanced learners out there, you might want to know that saying that this word like Kyoko gets you the main building meaning, while saying it like Kenichi gets you the this building meaning! Isn't pitch accent fun? But you'll probably never have to worry about this — context clues will be enough to tell you which meaning is being used.

Name: Male
Mnemonic: A man's gender is known as "male."
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Malicious
Mnemonic: A person whose ideas are grounded in evil is a malicious, mean jerk!
ReadingMnemonic: This reading is a combination of the on'yomi readings for 意 and 地, and the kun'yomi reading for 悪. You've learned them all already, but since 地 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: Malicious, mean jerks get sent to Jesus (じ) to sort them out. If anyone can sort out those malicious jerks, it’s Jesus!

Name: Mountain Climbing
Mnemonic: You've hopefully seen how 登る means "to climb." So, if you're climbing a mountain what is that? It's mountain climbing.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from combining 山 and 登る together to form one word, 山登り. If you know the readings of those two words you know the reading of this word too.

Name: Movement
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji move. So it means movement.
ReadingMnemonic: This is the same reading you learned from the word 動く. If you know that word, you know how to read this word!

Name: Obvious
Mnemonic: When it's bright around, things become more obvious, clear and evident.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this is a word that consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it uses kun'yomi. Unfortunately, 明 is a little tricky and has a few of those. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember this one: It's obvious that all you need is a key (あき) to open this door. It's like, blatantly clear. The lock is right there. You really just need a key. Did you forget it? Of course you did…

Name: One Time Around
Mnemonic: One circumference is one time around, or in racetrack sports, one lap. How many times will you go around the moon? Just 一周?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the いち becomes いっ as it often does when being used in a counter (一階, 一回, etc.).

Name: Opening And Closing
Mnemonic: Opened and closed things are opening and closing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Overtime
Mnemonic: The remainder of time that you work at the ol' business is extra time that you're working (above the normal work hours). This is overtime!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Personality
Mnemonic: Your gender and status are part of your personality. Think about what gender you identify as, and what your current status is (in relationships, residency, employment...). Now think about how all that affects your personality!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Pine
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so no need to think too hard.

Name: Pine Needle
Mnemonic: The pine leaves are not really leaves, they're more like needles, thus making this word pine needle.
ReadingMnemonic: If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 葉 gets rendaku'd to ば though, so watch out for that.

Name: Please Help Me
Meaning: If You Would Be So Kind
Mnemonic: This is a tricky word that doesn't really have a good translation. The best ways I've seen it done in terms of getting a meaning across are please and please help me. When you say this word you're kind of saying "please help me out and I'm relying on you and you're kind of awesome too." Anyways, please is a pretty good way to do it. So, when you see this word you'll notice it has the request kanji in it. You can guess you're requesting something. What is that thing? It's help (please help me) and you're asking very nicely too (please).
ReadingMnemonic: You ask for help by saying please help me, and that person does try to help you... but the amount they do for you is so negligible that it hardly does anything to help you at all. Please try to help me again, this time better?

Name: Popular Phrase
Mnemonic: You know that 流行 means "trend", so "trend" language means a popular phrase. Yolo! It could also be a catchphrase, a popular word, or a buzzword.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Popular Song
Mnemonic: You know that 流行 refers to a "trend." So, a "trend" song is a popular song.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Promise
Mnemonic: A promise bundle is still a promise no matter how many you have wrapped up there. One promise is just another promise which is just another promise.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Purpose
Mnemonic: When your eye is on the target you know your purpose. You also have your eye on the goal (that's the target, after all!).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a reading for 目 that's abnormal. You've seen this reading with 目標 and 目次, though, so hopefully it won't be too hard at this point. Just imagine telling someone your 目的, only to have them laugh in your face and begin mocking もく you for it. Now you're not so sure if your goal is going to work.

Name: Reason
Mnemonic: If you have reason in your nature, you have reason, sense and intellect.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Remainder
Mnemonic: This has the same meaning as the kanji. The little り thrown on there is just a little remainder sticking off the end of the kanji. No need to pay attention to that.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're waiting inside. The remainder of your forces are out there, fighting. You don't know who will survive... or if they even will. You have a secret knock (のこ), though, that you use to find out if it's one of the remaining forces outside or the enemy, broken through. You hear a knock. What is it? Is it your men or theirs? Imagine it out, focusing on the knock conversation that happens between you and the remainder.

Name: Reservation
Mnemonic: A beforehand promise is a promise you've made beforehand. This is a reservation or appointment. Makes sense, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Rotating Sushi
Mnemonic: You know that 回転 is "rotation" and you probably know what すし is (gets rendaku'd in this word to ずし). So, what is "rotation sushi?" It's rotating sushi, also known as conveyor belt sushi. Look it up if you don't know what it is.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 回転, so be sure to know that to know this one. Also, it's just the readings of the kanji you learned too, so shouldn't be too hard.

Name: School Festival
Mnemonic: Remember how 文化 means "culture?" Well add festival to it and you end up with a culture festival! These happen all the time at Japanese schools, so sometimes they're called school festivals too.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned all of these readings already, good for you!

Name: Sexually Transmitted Disease
Mnemonic: A gender sickness is one you catch from *ahem* doing things with those of another or the same gender. You only catch these sicknesses this way, meaning they're sexually transmitted diseases (save yourself some typing and just answer with STD).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Shape
Mnemonic: You like the status of what's in front of you. It has an excellent shape and form to it. Imagine something that would be pleasing to you in terms of its shape.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to note the かく reading, which gets changed to かっ.

Name: Show Business
Mnemonic: The art ability world is the world of show business, or in other words, the entertainment industry. To get into show business, you need abilities in the arts, after all.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Signal
Mnemonic: A diagram everyone joins together to see is a signal or a sign.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 合 and the on'yomi reading for 図. You know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

Name: Skeleton
Mnemonic: The status of your bones (aka how they're all arranged and put together) equals your skeleton. That bone status is lookin' good on you!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that こつ changes to こっ.

Name: Sports Day
Mnemonic: Remember how 運動 means "exercise?" When you meet with a bunch of other people to exercise it's called Sports Day! This is a day at schools in Japan where everybody does physical stuff together! It's fun and also very tiring!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Stood Up
Mnemonic: With 待ち you know you're waiting, but what's a ぼうけ? Turns out it's the long version of ボケ which means idiot. Basically, in this case you're a waiting idiot. Why? because you were stood up.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 待ち comes right from 待つ. You know the drill by now.

Name: Store Closed
Mnemonic: A closed shop is when a store's status is store closed or closed store.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Strawberry
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. Go eat some strawberries to celebrate!

Name: Stubborn
Mnemonic: A hard stubborn person is very stubborn no matter how you look at them. Try to break through that hard stubbornness and all you'll find is more stubborn.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Surroundings
Mnemonic: The circumference that surrounds you is your surroundings.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Swimsuit
Mnemonic: Water wear is a swimsuit, bathing suit, or swimwear.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this one is all kun'yomi vocab reading, but you should know these by now. 着 uses the reading you learned with the vocab word 着る, but this word employs that pesky rendaku, so remember that き becomes ぎ here.

Name: Talent
Mnemonic: A person who has great talent and ability has quite the talent.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: The Four Seasons
Mnemonic: The four seasons are the four seasons. For some reason many Japanese people think that Japan's the only place with four distinct seasons. Obviously they haven't been to half the places on their latitude around the world.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that 四 is read using the on'yomi reading, which you've seen a few times over the course of WaniKani. Think of し meaning "death" (like 死), and how with the four seasons there comes death every Fall and Winter.

Name: To Arrange
Mnemonic: When you arrange something with reason you're arranging it. That's why this is to arrange.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Be In Time For
Mnemonic: There is an interval (of time) that you need "to suit" (合う). To suit that interval, you need to be there before the time in question. That's why this word means to be in time for, to make it on time or to be on time for.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading for 間 when you learned 間もなく. And the reading for 合う is just that of the word 合う. If you remember them both, you'll remember this word!

Name: To Calm Down
Mnemonic: Hey. Drop yourself down and arrive back to me. You're going nuts over there. Lower down. Come back. Arrive. You need to do these things to calm down.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 落ちる and 着く. Hopefully you know these words so you can read this word as well! If you don't, just 落ち着く and everything will be okay.

Name: To Come
Mnemonic: The kanji itself means participate, so you'd think this word would mean "to participate" but it's a little more complex than that. Think of it as "to participate" but where you have to come or to go in order to do it. This is the humble way to say those things, so you're going to these places with your tail between your legs, just happy you can participate more than anything. By extension, this is also a humble way to say to visit, often used if you're visiting something sacred like a shrine or a tomb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You get to come to participate! "It's my (まい) lucky day!" you exclaim.

Name: To Digest
Mnemonic: You know how 消化 is "digestion"? Well, The verb form of that is this word, which is to digest.
ReadingMnemonic: If you know 消化 you should be able to read this. Also, it uses the readings you learned with the kanji anyways, so no problemo there.

Name: To Disappear
Mnemonic: You've seen that 消す is "to extinguish." So, this is another verb version of that. This time, you're not doing the extinguishing, it's just happening. Something is going to disappear on its own. How can you differentiate this from 消す? Well, える allows you to notice how the object disappeared into thin air (える). You know you didn't do it, so it disappeared on its own, making it to disappear.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is different from 消す, unfortunately, so you can't use that. Just think about how after the object in front of you disappears you use a key (き) to open an invisible door. That's where everything's disappearing to! You see all your disappeared stuff on the other side of this invisible door which you opened with a magical key.

Name: To Expect
Mnemonic: Hopefully you know the word 期待 by now (expectation). This is the verb version, which makes it to expect.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the word 期待, so make sure you know that to know this one as well.

Name: To Fold Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fold or break, so the vocab verb version is to fold something or to break something
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You fold your obi (お) really carefully and put it away with the rest of your kimono.

Name: To Join Together
Mnemonic: You know that the alternative kanji meaning for 合 is join, which is what we're using here. The verb form of join is to join together, and it can also mean to unify and to match.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 合う, so if you know that reading you'll know this reading as well.

Name: To Make Someone Wait
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wait so this word has something to do with waiting. Use the たせ as a hint. Someone "tossed" a ball off into a ditch, and then they had to find it. They made you wait for them to get the ball too, even though it's a cheap piece of crap. Feel upset about this. That'll help you remember that this means to make someone wait and to keep someone waiting.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading from 待つ, congrats!

Name: To Move Something
Mnemonic: You've seen 動く hopefully, and know it means to move. This is similar to that, but now you're moving something else. You know this because as you go to move something the thing you're moving starts to cuss (かす) you out because it's angry.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this can come from 動く. If you know that word, you know how to read this word!

Name: To Pass A Test
Mnemonic: The status joins together. Think of this like a bunch of status messages on Facebook, all coming together at the same time. A big government test has just finished. Everyone's status' are joining on Facebook together to say they passed, showing to pass a test.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Put On
Mnemonic: Another verb for this kanji! Crazy! I know, I'm sorry. The previous ones were: 着る (to wear), 着く (to arrive), and now 着ける (to put on / to wear). At least it's similar to 着る, right? In this case, this word is like 付ける, which means "to attach." It's used for things you "attach" to your body to wear, like accessories, or a face mask. That's why this is to put on or to wear. Same sound, different kanji, similar ideas.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 着く's reading, but it might be easier to think it shares a reading with 付ける, which has a similar meaning. Put on clothes, attach on clothes, etc.

Name: To Remain Behind
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means remainder, so the verb vocab version is "to remainder." Let's make that sound better: to remain behind.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to remain behind. Everyone else leaves, and you think you're alone. Then, someone knocks (のこ) on the door. Your heart jumps in your throat. They knock again.

Name: To Rotate
Mnemonic: You know that 回転 means "rotation" or "revolution." So, what happens when you make it into a verb? It becomes to rotate and to revolve.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 回転 of level 10. Alternatively, you can just use the readings of the kanji as well. EZPZ.

Name: To Stream
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stream? It's to stream (though it's also to flow, a very similar word). You can differentiate this from 流す because with 流す you flush something down the toilet, which causes it to overflow so you sue (す) the toilet maker. With 流れる you find a rare (れる) jewel trying to flow down the river. You grab it, and see it's a rare diamond!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 流す. So long as you know that you should be able to read this one as well!

Name: To Study
Mnemonic: You've seen 勉強 (study) by now, right? Well, this is the verb version of that. This is to study.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 勉強. It's also the readings you learned with these kanji.

Name: To Surround
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surround so the verb vocab version is to surround or to enclose.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: People surround you. They circle around you, calling you a chicken. "Cacko! (かこ) Cacko! Cacko!" Wait, this isn't the sound a chicken makes, right? You laugh at them, thinking their way of making a chicken noise is weird. Go ahead and join in with them and say "Cacko" with them as well.

Name: To Travel
Mnemonic: You've hopefully seen 旅行 by this point. This is the verb version of that. Instead of "trip" it's to travel or to take a trip. These are fun to do. You should do them!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 旅行, but it also happens to use the reading you learned with the kanji anyways, so you should be able to read it.

Name: To Understand
Mnemonic: 理解 is "understanding," so the verb version would be...? How about to understand or to comprehend? Well, do you?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, if you know 理解 already this one is easy to comprehend.

Name: To Wake Someone Up
Mnemonic: You've seen 起きる which is "to wake up." This is similar, except you are waking someone else up, which makes the meaning of this word to wake someone up. How do you differentiate between this and 起きる? Because of the す on the end. You wake someone up violently, wrenching their neck. They turn around and sue (す) you, making you wish you never woke them up.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 起きる, so as long as you know that word you should be able to read this one. Of course, you can also imagine them yelling "OH!" when you shake them awake too, if that helps.

Name: To Warm Up
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends in an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 温 means warm. So the verb 温まる means to warm up or to get warm.
ReadingMnemonic: The kanji reading is the same as 温かい and 温める.

Name: To Wish
Mnemonic: If you have a hope and you turn it into a verb, you'd think it would be "to hope." But what is really behind a hope? It's a desire or wish, right? That's why this word means to wish or to desire.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your one wish that you have is to have a bigger nose (のぞ). Feel your nose, it's too small. You wish it was two or three inches longer. Of course, if it helps to imagine you want a smaller nose or a nose at all, that's fine too. Just make sure you wish you have something nose-related.

Name: Traveler
Mnemonic: You've seen that 旅行 is "trip." So who is someone who goes on trips? That is a tourist or traveler.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know the reading of 旅行 already.

Name: Underwear
Mnemonic: The things you wear below your other clothes. That is your underwear. You do wear underwear, right?
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this one is all kun'yomi vocab reading, but you should know these by now. 着 uses the reading you learned with 着る, but this word employs that pesky rendaku, so remember that き becomes ぎ here.

Name: Unfortunate
Mnemonic: You have remainder thoughts when your hear about something unfortunate. That's too bad, you think, I wish it could have been different. Those remainder thoughts are a kind of regret, right? That's why this can mean regrettable or disappointing too.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Very Japanese
Mnemonic: Things that are targeted as Japanese are more than just Japanese, they are very Japanese. This word may be hard to understand at first, but there are many things the Japanese consider to be Japanese-only. These theories range from reasonable to ridiculous, but either way, you'll see them described as 日本的.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know how to read 日本 as well.

Name: Waiting Room
Mnemonic: The place you wait to join other people is a waiting room or a meeting place.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings, but it's like the hiragana that normally sticks out is stuffed in. 待ち → 待, 合い → 合 and is pronounced the same too. I know it's confusing, but once you get it down you'll never forget!

Name: We
Mnemonic: I with a ら on it makes it plural. It's less formal than 俺たち (if you've seen that word yet), but has the same meaning. It's we.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji's reading.

Name: Well
Mnemonic: A well door is just a well. It's the door that goes into the well hole, making it a well.
ReadingMnemonic: This kanji uses the kun'yomi readings for each kanji, for some reason. You learned the kun'yomi reading for both of these kanji as their primary readings already, just watch out for 戸 getting rendaku'd so it becomes ど instead of と.

Name: Werewolf
Mnemonic: What’s another word for a wolf man? A werewolf, obviously.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned the reading for 狼 in both the kanji and the vocabulary word. The reading for 男 comes from the vocabulary 男. Put them together and you get おおかみおとこ. Awoooo.

Name: Wish
Mnemonic: A hope is really a wish that you have inside of you (though it can still be a hope too).
ReadingMnemonic: What's your one big wish? It's to have a different nose (のぞ). Alternatively, you could think "nose on me" for のぞみ.

Name: With Trouble
Mnemonic: When there's nothing but folds and angles, you have quite a mess. This word means with trouble because you certainly aren't traversing along a nice, flat piece of space-time, are you? Nah, it's all angled and folded.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Watch out for the せつ changing to せっ, though. Another thing you have to go through with trouble, I'm afraid.

Name: Wolf
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: Wood
Mnemonic: Wood that is lumber is lumber wood.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: All You Can Drink
Mnemonic: Drinking as much as you want is nice and all, but don't get sick. When you see this word, you know you're at an all you can drink place. Tip: Usually there's a time limit, so drink up!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the word 放題 (ほうだい) and 飲む (のむ). So long as you know those vocab words, you'll be able to read this one as well.

Name: All You Can Eat
Mnemonic: When you eat as much as you want, you are getting an all you can eat deal.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading consists of the readings of 食べる and 放題. If you know those you should be able to read this too.

Name: An Eccentric
Mnemonic: A strange person is an eccentric. They are also an oddball.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: A Request
Mnemonic: The noun form of request (don't be tricked by the い on the end, it's not an adjective). So, request goes to a request.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same like お願いします. Hopefully you're able to read that by now so you're able to read this too.

Name: Army
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Art
Mnemonic: You need art techniques to make art. Without art techniques, the arts and fine art simply wouldn’t exist.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Autumn
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, あき.

Name: Being Proportional
Mnemonic: You compare examples, trying to figure out in which way they're being proportional. You know these examples you're comparing are in proportion to one another, you just need to figure out how.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Boss
Mnemonic: The director who is above you is your boss or superior.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Boulder
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so you can read this one!

Name: Britain
Mnemonic: The England country is where England is. This word can refer to Britain, the United Kingdom and England!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Buddha
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You go up to Buddha. You want to rub his head for good luck, because that's what you hear is good to do. Right before you touch him, he backs off and says, "Whoa! I'm hot, okay?" (ほとけ). You touch him and it burns your hand clean off. Imagine saying "hot, okay?" in a strange accent to help you to remember.

Name: Buddhism
Mnemonic: The buddha teachings are what you have to learn when you're studying Buddhism.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that 仏 gets changed to ぶっ for this one.

Name: Calculation
Mnemonic: When you measure and then calculate something, you are making a calculation. For example, you measure the length of a frog, then you calculate how many frogs you'd need to reach the moon. What is that? A calculation, of course.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Cat
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Meow!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Neko neko neko! Kawaiiiii.

Name: Century
Mnemonic: The account of a generation... this covers a whole generation, and considering how long Japanese people live, this account totals a whole century.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Ceremony
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. In fact, this kanji's on'yomi AND kun'yomi are しき, so you can never go wrong.

Name: Change
Mnemonic: Change and change equals even more change.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Clear Weather
Mnemonic: If you say something is going to clear up, you're usually talking about the weather. That makes this clear weather or sunny.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Clumsy
Mnemonic: You know how 器用 means "dextrous" and "skillful"? Well, this is when you're not those things. When you're not dextrous, you're clumsy and when you're not skillful you're unskillful.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just keep in mind that the reading of 不 changes from ふ to ぶ. If you're clumsy you'll get a lot of boo-boos (ぶ), get it?

Name: Common Era
Mnemonic: What does the narrative origin have coming after it? Well, the way we've counted years for the past couple of millenia has a specific narrative at its origin, and everything that comes after it is the Common Era, aka AD, or anno Domini.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Confidence
Mnemonic: When you believe in your self you have plenty of confidence (or self confidence). This is a good thing to have!
ReadingMnemonic: How much 自信 do you have that you know how to read this word already? I bet you have some, at least! This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Courage
Mnemonic: That feeling of courage is courage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Deck Of Cards
Mnemonic: トランプ comes from the English word "trump", as in "a trump card", but it means deck of cards or playing cards in Japanese.

Name: District
Mnemonic: The earth district isn't our solar system or something like that. We're talking about a specific portion of earth, and naming it as a district. So, what is this patch of earth? It's a district, area, or zone.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: District
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

Name: Distrust
Mnemonic: When you can't (not) believe in someone, it's because you distrust them. Maybe someone discredited them and now you mistrust everything they say.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: English Conversation
Mnemonic: English meeting and talking with each other. This is English Conversation. This is used a lot when talking about "speaking in English" for studying English and whatnot.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: English Japanese
Mnemonic: This is seen on things like dictionaries. When you have an English and Japanese (style) dictionary, for example. You'll see it the other way around too, but this particular one is English Japanese.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: English Language
Mnemonic: The English language is the language you're reading right here and now. This is the English language. It is English.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: English Writing
Mnemonic: England writing is English Writing (or if you want to be fancy, English Composition).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Every Night
Mnemonic: Every night is simply every night. What do you do every night?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Faith
Mnemonic: What you believe in your heart, and not in your head, is your faith. This is something that doesn't follow logic, it's all heart belief, it's all faith.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that しん changes to じん.

Name: Fine Art
Mnemonic: When you create beauty with your techniques, that’s fine art, or simply art.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Food Poisoning
Mnemonic: If you eat and find yourself in the middle of poison, you've probably got food poisoning. No fun when you get this :(
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Four Small Animals
Mnemonic: Four small animals is four small animals. Use this to count four dogs, or cats, or whatever else.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fukushima
Mnemonic: The luck island wasn't actually too lucky. This is Fukushima where the nuclear meltdown happened after the 2011 earthquake. So, when you think of "luck island" this is where you should think.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. If one thing is lucky, it's probably that.

Name: Giant Buddha Statue
Mnemonic: A large Buddha doesn't make sense if you don't know the context. There are giant statues of Buddha, and these are called Daibutsu, making this word translate to the Great Buddha or Giant Buddha Statue.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Good Evening
Mnemonic: This word is made of now and night with the hiragana は at the end. The は here is pronounced as わ (the old pronunciation). When you say "now night!" you're really saying good evening.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be aware that the は at the end is actually the particle は so it's pronounced like わ.

Name: Grammar
Mnemonic: The method of writing is how you write. You can have vocabulary words, but you have to be able to put them together using some kind of method. This method happens to be grammar.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ほう changes to ぽう.

Name: Height
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word is usually used for clothing height and length.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is different from what you learned with the kanji. Remember the word 竹? It has the same reading as this. Just think of everyone measuring the heights of things with bamboo (たけ) poles with markers on them. Okay, this one is 5 bamboo poles high!

Name: Horseback Riding
Mnemonic: If you ride a horse, that's horseback riding or, in some parts of the world, simply horse riding.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 乗, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Know who loves horseback riding? That's right, Joe (じょう) the farmhand. It makes sense, with him being a farmhand and all.

Name: Husband
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Think about your husband even if you don't have one. What's his name? It's Otto (おっと), and he's always leaving you at home because he's working at the auto (おっと) shop.

Name: Illegal
Mnemonic: A not law is something that's against the law. It's illegal or unlawful.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Incident
Mnemonic: An occurrence that causes change somehow can also be called an incident.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Intermediary
