Mnemonic: When you get someone to transmit information, they're a type of intermediary, a go-between, if you will.
ReadingMnemonic: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it takes the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: When the go-between gets back and is about to tell you everything the other group said, it takes him two takes (つて) to get it all right. The other group had a lot to say and he had trouble getting it all on the first take, but he totally nailed it on the second. Little side note: this word is actually more common in katakana, as in ツテ, or hiragana, as in つて. Still, you might see it in kanji too, and it's good if you can read it!

Name: Kitten
Mnemonic: A child cat is an adorable kitten. D'awww!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the vocab word 子 (こ) and the reading for cat (ねこ).

Name: Last Year
Mnemonic: Yesterday's year was actually last year. Today must be New Years then!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Line
Mnemonic: When things are put in a row they end up forming a line. This can be a line of people waiting in a queue, a row of seats in a theater, or a column in Excel and other spreadsheets.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Lunch Break
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 休み means "break?" When you take a break at noon it's your lunch break! Or, if you aren't hungry, it's a noon break instead.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this too!

Name: Meal
Mnemonic: The ご just makes this word more polite and fancy. When it comes to food, it's nice to be those things. This has the same meaning as the kanji (meal) making it meal, but it also refers to cooked rice as well. So, "Come eat your ご飯" can be both "come eat your rice" and "come eat your meal." Really, since most Japanese meals come with rice, though, you can see how the overlap happens.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Now how about you "hand" me another bowl of rice?

Name: Meal
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It also refers to cooked rice, because you gotta eat cooked rice with every meal, so it's basically synonymous with "meal" itself.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're eating a meal... MMmm, delicious! What are you eating? Well, it's a Mesh (めし) net. Taste the mesh net. It tastes terrible. This is a bad meal. Feel it in your mouth. It's weird and meshy.

Name: Method
Mnemonic: The way method or the method way is the method or way. This is a good word for talking about how to do something. What's the 方法? Well, first you...
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Miserable
Mnemonic: You've seen how the word 情け means pity, so adding ない to that turns it into an adjective meaning pitiable and miserable.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: Murder
Mnemonic: When you kill a person that's murder.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, if you know 人's reading as a vocab word and 殺す's reading, you should be able to read this word. Just note that ころし goes to ごろし due to rendaku.

Name: Murderer
Mnemonic: You've hopefully seen 殺人 (murder) from level 13. So, someone who does murder is what? A murderer.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Navy
Mnemonic: The sea army are the branch of the military that has boats and does ocean/sea things. What's that? The navy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Night
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading here is the same as the kanji reading!

Name: Noon
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This can also mean lunch, especially when used with the honorific prefix お, as in お昼.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji it comes from, so you should be able to read it!

Name: Onomatopoeia
Mnemonic: オノマトペ comes from the French word “onomatopée” which, as you can probably guess, means onomatopoeia.

Name: Origin
Mnemonic: What's the reason that something comes into being? Its origin, of course. Nothing can come into the world without a source, because it's always coming from somewhere.
ReadingMnemonic: You didn't learn this reading for 由 so here's a mnemonic to help you: The best way to get close to the origin or source of something is to move into a yurt (ゆ). Yurts are easy to move around, so you can always get close to the source, wherever that may be.

Name: Partner
Mnemonic: Remember how 手 can mean a "doer"? Now, what do you think your mutual doer might be? It’s someone who shares the same activities or tasks with you. This person could be your partner, companion, or even an opponent in certain situations.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. For 手, that's no problem for you. For 相, that's more of an issue since you learned the on'yomi reading for it. Think of it this way: Your partner wouldn't be your partner without you. Your partner is: I (あい) and you. Remember that as you gaze into your partner's eyes. "I and you."

Name: Passenger
Mnemonic: If you take a ride as a guest (or a customer), that makes you a passenger.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You hopefully learned the on'yomi for 乗 with the word 乗馬, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case: You notice a passenger getting on at your stop. Who is it? The distinct smell of barn animals and manure gives it away immediately: it’s Joe (じょう), the farmhand!

Name: Plan
Mnemonic: You need measurements and images to make a plan. You can't follow a plan without measurements and images to refer to, right? Any good plan has measurements and drawings.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 画 is the secondary reading though (かく), so take note of that.

Name: Poison
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji's reading.

Name: Poison Gas
Mnemonic: Poison Gas is a nasty thing. It is poison gas.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji it comes from. The ガス is of course "gas."

Name: Poisoning
Mnemonic: You're in the middle of poison, meaning you have poisoning.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Poisonous
Mnemonic: When something has poison it is poisonous and toxic.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Reply
Mnemonic: You gotta believe it will return. What are you believing in returning? The reply. You made a request for something (come up with something you want really bad but have to ask for). Now you wait for the reply.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Ring
Mnemonic: A finger ring is the kind of ring you'd put on your finger. That's just simply a "ring" though, so you'll have to know what "ring" this is via context.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from the individual vocab readings, 指 and 輪. In English we don't distinguish some other ring from a "finger ring" but in Japanese, you can think of this as two separate words coming together to form one word, which is why it uses the kun'yomi vocab readings like this. So, if you know the individual words, you should be able to figure out this word is read as ゆびわ.

Name: Rubber Band
Mnemonic: A ring of gum (ゴム) (which is what Japanese people call rubber quite often) is a ring of rubber. What is a ring of rubber that people use often? It's a rubber band.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 輪 is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which is わ, making this word わゴム.

Name: Serious
Mnemonic: A big change is a really serious thing. And people don't like change, either, making it a terrible event.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Shallow
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of shallow? It's shallow.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, making this あさい.

Name: Simply
Mnemonic: If you're moving towards (に) simple, you're saying simply, merely, or only.
ReadingMnemonic: If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Skill
Mnemonic: Your skill and ability are kind of similar things. That's why this word means either or. Your skill ability is your skill and ability.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Slope
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as this one.

Name: Small Animal Counter
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Soldier
Mnemonic: An army person is someone in the army. What are those people called? They're soldiers.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Solid
Mnemonic: A stubborn height is a shorter, stockier height. It makes a person especially solid, firm, and stout.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Something Heard For The First Time
Meaning: Something Heard For The First Time
Mnemonic: The first time something reaches your ear, it's something heard for the first time. If it's never entered your ear before, it's news to you!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses kun'yomi instead of on'yomi readings, because 初 behaves more like a prefix here. You already know how to read 耳, but you haven't learned the kun'yomi for 初 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Whatever it is, this something heard for the first time, be sure to hold onto your hats (はつ)! It's going to be something big, and I'm pretty sure it's going to be news to me, too.

Name: Specialty
Mnemonic: Your special skill is your specialty. So, what is your 特技?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Spring
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Ah, the beauty of spring! Err... はる, I mean.

Name: Spring Break
Mnemonic: You've seen 夏休み and 冬休み. If that isn't enough, you can see that this is a spring rest of some kind. That would be a spring break or spring vacation.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 春 is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. The 休み part is the same as the vocab word 休み, which hopefully you can read! If you know those readings, you can read this too.

Name: Strange
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is more the "strange" meaning though, not the "change" one. As in, you 変な猫！
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. How strange! Or not.

Name: Sturdy
Mnemonic: With the height of my husband, he's very firm. Try to push him over. Impossible. He's so tall and sturdy due to his height.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Syncing
Mnemonic: You're making things in two different places be exactly the same for a period of time. You're in the middle of a process called syncing. You can see 同期中 a lot in computery contexts, or if you change your device language to Japanese. (Not that I recommend that...)
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Tasty
Mnemonic: Something with a beauty taste is something that is really tasty or delicious. Mmmm, yum!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this makes no sense at all. You'll have to learn it straight up, that is, unless you know the word おいしい already, which many people do as it's used in every other sentence in every Japanese variety show. If you don't know this word already, just think of yourself eating something delicious. It's so delicious it makes you mad, I have no idea why. You yell at the chef: "OI (おい). OI! WHY IS THIS SO DELICIOUS????"

Name: Technique
Mnemonic: What is a skill? It's something you can do, and do quite well. It is a technique that you can make happen with ease.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You do your technique on a bad guy, coming at you. You flip him over and knock him out. He was (わざ) a threat, but now he's not. You look closer at the bad guy. Turns out it's Woz, the Apple Co-founder. He was just trying to hand you an iPhone12, not grab your wrist. Whoops!

Name: Temple
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji too! You must have been praying to the kanji Gods at the local お寺.

Name: These Days
Mnemonic: Previous from now are the times around now. They're these days, nowadays, or recently.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that さく changes to さっ as many K-column sounds do in situations like this.

Name: To Accept Something
Mnemonic: Remember 受ける (to receive something) and 入れる (to put in)? This just combines those two. You receive something, and put it into your heart. You accept it. So this verb means to accept something or to take in.
ReadingMnemonic: You should know how to read both 受ける and 入れる, so you should be good to go!

Name: To Arrange
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means arrange, and the verb version also means to arrange or to put in order. This has to do with putting things in their rightful place, getting affairs in order, or even preparing equipment.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Everything in your room has finally been put in order. Just as you finish, you hear a crash and turn to see your dog has jumped up onto your desk. "Toto no (ととの)!" you yell as he knocks everything over. Guess you have  to arrange  it all over again. Dammit Toto.

Name: To Be Fond Of
Mnemonic: You know that 好き is "like." Although 好き is kind of like a verb already, this is definitely a verb. It can be to be fond of or to like.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a strange one, different from anything you've learned, kanji on'yomi or vocab kun'yomi. The reading is この, so think of this: What’s something easy to be fond of? 子? No (この), not for you. You’re always saying “子? No!” Most people are fond of kids, at least their own, but not you. Noisy, germy, needy 子? No, no thank you!

Name: To Believe
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means believe so the verb vocab version is to believe.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 信 is しん no matter what! See, if you believe, good things will happen. You should be able to read this.

Name: To Be Solved
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means solve and the verb vocab version is to be solved. In a similar vein, this can also mean to be cleared, like with misunderstandings or tension in a room.
ReadingMnemonic: You already learned how to read 解く, and this uses the same reading for the kanji. Lucky you!

Name: To Change Something
Mnemonic: The kanji is change, and this verb is to change something. If you change one thing for another thing, you are going to change it, after all. This word refers to changing one thing for a similar thing.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. You want to change something about your car (か) but you don't quite know what yet. Maybe your car should have a really cool feature, like a hot tub or a giant screen. Try to think of the silliest ways you could change your car.

Name: To Clear Up
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means clear up, so the verb vocab version is to clear up. It also means to become sunny as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here. One of those words where the kun'yomi's going to be more useful.

Name: To Cry
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cry so the verb vocab version is to cry.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. If you remember the kanji reading you'll have no problem with this word.

Name: To Disconnect Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be a kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're going to disconnect something, it has (はず) to be the right thing! Don't go disconnecting the wrong plug, you'll cause no end of trouble!

Name: To Doubt
Mnemonic: The kanji means doubt, so this is just that as a verb. So this means to doubt, to suspect, or to be suspicious of.
ReadingMnemonic: There's reason to doubt that you can teach an uni Tagalog (うたが), but once you try, it's actually not that hard. They're very good listeners after all.

Name: To Fire
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned the verbs 放す and 放れる but this one is a little different. This is a specific kind of releasing. It means to fire an arrow, to hit a baseball, or to emit light. It even works when you're releasing a fart. Yes, it means to break wind too. What a great word!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: To Go Down
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means below, which is a clue to the direction this movement verb takes: this is to go down or to descend. In some cases, this can also mean to be issued, mostly in situations where some sort of grant or allowance is issued by an authority.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji), you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You're stuck on a huge mountain, and the only way to go down is by using your obi (お). So you'll have to descend this entire mountain with nothing but your obi, acting as a rope. Good luck!

Name: To Memorize
Mnemonic: Hopefully you've seen 暗記 before now. It means "memorization." So, turn that into a verb and you have to memorize.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 暗記. It also is the reading you learned with the kanji too.

Name: To Pay
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pay so the verb vocab version is to pay.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Practice
Mnemonic: You've hopefully seen 練習, which means "practice." So, if you make it into a verb, you have to practice.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the kanji as well as from the vocab word 練習. You should be able to read this!

Name: To Return Home
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return home so the verb vocab version is to return home, to return, or to go home.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You can return home happily, knowing how to read this word! This word has a pair verb though, so you'll want to remember the る ending. Just imagine how rude (る) it is when someone goes home without saying goodbye. The nerve!

Name: To Show Someone What One Can Do
Meaning: To Show Someone What One Can Do
Mnemonic: When you see someone doubting you and return something successful instead, that is to show someone what one can do or more simply to show someone. In other words, you show someone who doubted you or treated you unfairly what you’re really capable of.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are from the words 見 and 返す put together.

Name: Total
Mnemonic: When you join all your measurements together you have yourself a total.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Traffic Light
Mnemonic: If you believe in the numbers, there will be no traffic because the traffic light will be functioning properly. Traffic lights are based all off of traffic data and numbers. You just have to believe and hope it all works out in terms of these traffic lights.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Trust
Mnemonic: When someone believes in your task, it means they have a lot of trust in what you do. You've clearly gained a great deal of credibility through your previous tasks.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Understanding
Mnemonic: When you've finished solving something, you've come to a point of understanding.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Unexpected Incident
Mnemonic: You know 変 means "change," but it can also mean "strange." So a strange occurrence is an incident that is unlikely. In other words, an unexpected incident or an unusual incident.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Unnatural Death
Mnemonic: A strange death is one that doesn't seem right. It's an unnatural death, and probably an accidental death (ie wasn't caused by natural causes).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Various
Mnemonic: This one's kinda tricky. You learned 様 is a "formal name ender," but it can also mean "manner," as in the manner you do something in. So if you've got multiple manners, you've got lots of various ways of doing things!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is just the reading you learned with the kanji. The second one is ざま however, which plays right into the "various" meaning of the word. There's even various ways to read さま in this word!

Name: Watch
Mnemonic: A thing that gives you time measurements is a watch or clock. Most people have these in their phones instead of on their wrists now.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this is pretty weird. 計 is all nice and normal, but 時 is と for some reason. It probably is coming from the vocab word 時 (とき), is my guess. But even if it is, it's shortened, making it a step more complicated. Maybe it's just better to imagine that your watch is a walky talky (とけい) and run with that?

Name: Word
Mnemonic: The simple bits of language are the individual words. If you think about it, this is true. First of all, there are a ton of them. Second, they're tiny. They're just little bits of language and the "word" for these little bits is word.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Writer
Mnemonic: This is a strange one, but only at first glance. You make a house. You'd think this would mean something like "building a house" or "construction" or something. Instead, it means writer. Think of it this way: A writer makes (writes and creates works) in their home. Writers don't make their word magic in a corporate office!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since the さく reading of 作 becomes さっ here, we've made a mnemonic for you to remember this reading: Writers love soccer (さっか). In fact, playing soccer is how they get their inspiration. Try playing some soccer, maybe you'll become a creator too!

Name: Yesterday
Mnemonic: The yesterday day is yesterday. What a blast from the past!
ReadingMnemonic: Oof. The reading for this word makes no sense. You'll have to forget everything you've learned about the readings of the kanji and just go straight up mnemonic for the word on its own. Okay. Think about what you did yesterday, all day. You played keno (きのう), gambling away your grandmother's money. Yesterday was the worst day ever because you lost everything playing Keno. Today is different, not like yesterday, right?

Name: Absence
Mnemonic: You have gotten a mission. You must go out and detain a dangerous criminal to protect your country. While you go do that, you will be away from home and have an absence from society.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: A Cook
Mnemonic: You've seen 料理 and probably know it means "cooking." So, what is a person who does cooking? That is a cook or chef.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Admission
Mnemonic: If you are able to enter the gate then you have gained admission and entrance to the facility.  Sometimes you do this to start an apprenticeship, where you get an introduction to some sweet new skills, like how to make an entrance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Adventure
Mnemonic: You dare to do something risky. It's adventure time! Imagine yourself daring yourself to do risky things. Is this an adventure? If not, make it so!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Anniversary
Mnemonic: You should write down all your thoughts on this day, because it's not just any day — it's an anniversary!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a combination of on'yomi for the first two and kun'yomi for the last one. That being said, all of the readings for all of the kanji are the readings you've learned already, so you should be able to read this word too. Just watch out because ひ is rendaku'd into び.

Name: Article
Mnemonic: This is the same as the kanji, at least in regards to the article or goods meaning, which means you can use this word to mean article or goods.
ReadingMnemonic: When this kanji is used as a single-character vocabulary word, it's usually read as しな. That's the case with this word too! You haven't seen the しな reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Think of the sheen (しな) that new goods have before you buy them. When you bring them home, that sheen is already gone. But then you go back to the store and, wow! All the goods you don't already own have that sheen! Gotta buy them!

Name: Artist
Mnemonic: You know that 芸術 is art so you'd think that 芸術家 would be something like "art house." Well, it's not. Think of it this way: Who is the person who works for "House Art"? It's the artist.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Automatic
Mnemonic: An automatical (自動 + 的) thing of course isn't "automatical." A better way to say it is to cut off the -al and call it automatic.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the reading of 自動 as well.

Name: Automobile
Mnemonic: You know that 自動 is automatic. So what is an automatic car? That is an automobile, or simply a car.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 自動 and the kanji 車's readings, combined.

Name: A Work
Mnemonic: If you make a product, it's not really a product anymore, but a work. It's your work of art or literature, or maybe a theater production.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Bento
Mnemonic: You know how 弁 means dialect and 当 means success? Well, this isn't going to help you much, because this means bento or box lunch. Chances are, though, you know the word "bento" from English. So, if you read this word (which you should be able to) you can figure out it's べんとう. If you do that, you can realize this word means bento too!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Box
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Brand New
Mnemonic: A new product is something that's brand new or a new item. I like looking around the store for the brand new stuff because it's interesting!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Notice though that ひん changes to ぴん. This is because you're buying some brand new pins?

Name: Buddhist Scriptures
Mnemonic: Buddha transcribed all of the rules of Buddhism in the Buddhist Scriptures and Buddhist Writings.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that ぶつ gets shortened to ぶっ.

Name: Ceiling
Mnemonic: The heaven well is the well that goes up into the heavens. This is above you, and it is a ceiling. Maybe the "well" part is referring to the chimney that goes up through the ceiling to the heavens when you look up in a super old house?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn that reading for 井, so we've got a mnemonic to help you out with that. Just note that the on'yomi for 井 isn't actually じょう, but rather しょう, it just ends up getting rendaku'd here! Fixing up ceilings is a tricky task, but you've got just the man for it: Joe (じょう). Your local farmhand that does it all, nothing is too tricky or out of reach for him, you're starting to think that this man can do just about anything. What a handy person to have around.

Name: Character Dictionary
Mnemonic: Letter rules can be found in a character dictionary. In Japanese, one kanji "letter" or "character" can hold a lot of information, so you have dictionaries dedicated to kanji meanings. That's what this is.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Classical
Mnemonic: When something is "old rules-like," it is not very modern. It is in the past. It is classical.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Complete Recovery
Mnemonic: All cured! That means you've made a complete recovery! You're completely healed!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Concern
Mnemonic: The things related to your heart are the things that concern and interest you the most.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Connection
Mnemonic: A connection related to another connection obviously has some kind of connection, at least between all those meanings.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Conservative
Mnemonic: Who are all like "I want to preserve and protect what I have, get out of my business, government!"? Conservative people, of course.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading doesn't match up for this word's 守. The reading is しゅ, but you can remember that because the conservatives want to protect and preserve their hoes (ほ) and their chutes (しゅ) from the government. For some reason those get taxed a lot.

Name: Covering An Event
Mnemonic: Your job is to take materials from a bunch of different people because you're covering an event. This data collection needs to be thorough, so you try to take all the materials you can from as many people as you can find.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi of 取 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're covering an event featuring all kinds of chutes (しゅ). They have the whole range, from laundry chutes and garbage chutes, to evacuation chutes and so much more. You'll be doing some data collection and interviews about all these chutes, and you can't wait!

Name: Crude
Mnemonic: Things that are below normal products are the cheap knockoffs and bad quality items. These items are incredibly crude and vulgar in their manufacturing and design. So much vulgarity!
ReadingMnemonic: You haven't seen this reading for 下 yet (sorry there's so many for this kanji!) so here's a mnemonic to help you: Those items are so crude that you can't even tell what they're supposed to be. Honestly they all just look like statues of lumpy geckos (げ). That says it's a lamp but it looks more like a gecko looking at the sky. That chair? Definitely a bunch of geckos having a pool party. Are you sure you didn't get this stuff from a weird gecko artist?

Name: Dangerous
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dangerous? It's dangerous.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone is in danger! It's poor old abe (あぶ) Lincoln. You try to save him, yelling out 危ないよ！！！！, but he gets shot in the back of the head anyways.

Name: Day Of The Week
Mnemonic: The weekday day is the day of the week, as in "Monday" or "Tuesday." You'll be learning those on level 18, but first you should learn 曜日 to get you prepared.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for 曜 and the kun'yomi reading for 日. You've learned both of these already, but be careful because ひ of 日 changes to び here.

Name: Deterioration
Mnemonic: A bad change is exactly what it sounds like: deterioration, aka getting worse .
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. The on'yomi readings of the kanji are あく and か, but here they become あっか, to make the word easier to pronounce. Try and say it out loud to see if you agree.

Name: Dialect
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. The 〜 is there to show this attaches onto things, like 東京弁, meaning "Tokyo Dialect."
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Because it's normally attached to other words it uses the on'yomi reading like a jukugo word normally would.

Name: Dictionary
Mnemonic: You need to know the word rules of the language you're learning, don't you? Then you need a good dictionary that can explain its lexicon!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dictionary
Mnemonic: Take all the words you use in writing, put them together and you have a dictionary!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Encyclopedia
Mnemonic: If you come across a matter in which the rules aren’t clear, you’ll need to have a look in an encyclopedia!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Evidence
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 
Your relentless search for evidence has finally uncovered the existence of a car sheep (あかし)! It's a bizarre hybrid, having a car's body but a sheep's head and legs. "Ah, car sheep! I've finally found the evidence proving you're real!"

Name: Excursion
Mnemonic: Far feet are feet that have gone on long excursions. These feet have been on some trips, man. They've seen some things.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Existence
Mnemonic: Existing life is in existence on this planet... What would that say about life and survival in such an unforgiving place?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Express
Mnemonic: Things that hurry and go faster than the other things are express. This is often used with trains or subways, so look out for it if you're looking to get somewhere in a hurry. Also be careful in case it doesn't stop at your stop, because 急行 trains don't stop at every station (which is what makes them express!).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: External Appearance
Mnemonic: The outside face to something is the external appearance of that thing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, so this is がいめん. But note that this can also use the kun’yomi readings, which makes it そとづら. While がいめん is neutral, そとづら is a bit negative, often implying that the person's outward appearance might be deceptive, hiding their true nature.

Name: Face Of A Person
Mnemonic: The face of a face is a face, but more specifically the face of a person. Probably because the most face-like thing you can ever have is a human's face... at least in our eyes (by "our" I mean the human race's eyes, because I am totally with you guys on that one).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 顔 isn't the one you learned with the kanji. But, we're going to learn that reading right now. The worst thing that can happen to a face is if a face disappears. If it becomes totally gone (がん). A man that is walking up to you with no face, is a man with a gone face. Those men are men who are a part of the gone men (がんめん). Faces, totally gone!

Name: Fail A Test
Mnemonic: You know that 合格する is "to pass a test," so what's the opposite of that? Fail a test or failure.
ReadingMnemonic: If you know the reading for 合格, all you have to do is add 不 to it! You've learned all these readings, yay!

Name: Far
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of far? It's also far (or it's far away).
ReadingMnemonic: You want to go far, far away when you see a toe... oh (とお)! You realize there is a zombie toe on the ground and it reminds you of where you can go that's far from here—where the zombie that once had this toe went! (Remember the kanji mnemonic? It's that scooter zombie's toe that makes you say oh and want to go.)

Name: Flattery
Mnemonic: When you quit your current generation to join an older one, you'll need to use all kinds of flattery. Older people love being flattered; so be nice and give them some compliments.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Just watch out, as the 世 gets shortened from せい to せ! You can memorize this by remembering to be short and sweet with your flattery, don't make it too long and overcomplicated!

Name: Fluffy
Mnemonic: Who are who are (ふわふわ) fluffy? I’m thinking puppies, but ask yourself, "who are the fluffiest creatures I know?"

Name: Fold
Mnemonic: A fold you can see with your eye is a fold or crease in something.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi vocab readings. You should have seen 折る by now which should help you to read 折り. Then there's 目, which I'm guessing you won't have a problem with.

Name: Front
Mnemonic: The front face of something is the front or the front side of it (kind of like how 外面 is the exterior because it's the outside face). This also means fore or forefront, especially when used metaphorically.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Fundamental
Mnemonic: The things that are basics (基本) like (的) are basic and fundamental.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing how to read the word 基本 will be helpful too.

Name: Garbage Can
Mnemonic: ゴミ means "garbage." Add a box to it and you have a garbage box aka a garbage can or garbage bin.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is just the kun'yomi reading, the one you learned with the kanji. Be sure to pay attention to the rendaku though. はこ changes to ばこ.

Name: Gate
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Good Luck
Mnemonic: When you carry happiness with you, you look at the good side of everything and end up having really good luck. Someone who carries happiness will be really lucky in life.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Government
Mnemonic: Politics and government. They are needed to keep the government rolling.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Graduation Ceremony
Mnemonic: You know that 卒業 is graduation so what about when you add ceremony to it? That makes it a graduation ceremony.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know how to read 卒業 already as a word, too.

Name: Groceries
Mnemonic: Products you're paying a fee to eat later are your groceries. Buy them now, eat them later, yum!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ground
Mnemonic: The ground/earth face is the surface that makes up the ground or the Earth's surface.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 面 is what you'd expect. 地 on the other hand is じ, which is a bit different (though close sounding) to what you learned previously. Thank the Chinese and their ever changing language for this one. Think of Jesus laying on the ground, telling you how comfortable the ground is. You say "Jesus, you have to get off the ground, you have a dinner to go to," but he doesn't want to leave.

Name: Guarantee
Mnemonic: Giving evidence (or a guarantee) that you will preserve something, is giving a guarantee, assurance, or warranty.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Hanshin
Mnemonic: The slopes of the gods! What could this be? Well, it's mainly just a company, known as Hanshin. They're based in the area between Osaka and Kobe. Think of it this way: 大阪 + 神戸 = 阪神! They're everywhere, though, and even have a baseball team (the Hanshin Tigers), so it's good to know.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Happiness
Mnemonic: With a little happiness and luck you can achieve happiness, though that goes without saying.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Happiness
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji 幸. The kanji means happiness and the vocab word means happiness.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: On your quest for true happiness, you meet a happiness guru. She always says (しあわせ), "just be happy!" She always says that, and you always listen. You can't believe how simple yet profound her approach is!

Name: Incomplete
Mnemonic: You know that 完全 means "complete" or "perfect." So, a not "complete" or "perfect" is something that is incomplete or imperfect.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It also will help if you can read 完全.

Name: Incurability
Mnemonic: When you can not cure something, this is a problem of incurability.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Insurance
Mnemonic: When you are able to guarantee against risk, it's probably because you bought some good insurance! What do you use? The gecko 保険?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Interesting
Mnemonic: The face of this object is so white! Why is it so white compared to everything else? This is so interesting...
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is unlike what you've learned before, at least with the 面 part (白い is just like the vocab word 白い). When you look at the white face of the object you say to your friend Moe: "Oh mo!" (おも) because you want him to come over and look at this. Try to imagine someone you know named Moe, or at least a celebrity or something named Moe.

Name: Joke
Mnemonic: When you have a superfluous talk you aren't being serious, you're telling a joke.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Kansai
Mnemonic: The Kansai region of Japan is the Southern Central part of Japan. It actually connects the East side of Japan (at least back in the day) to the West side, making it the "connection to the west." For our purposes, though, we should call it "Kansai."
ReadingMnemonic: Urgh, what a confusing reading! The 西 is さい instead of せい. Readings like this just make you want to sigh (さい), no?

Name: Library
Mnemonic: A public building where written things are all diagramed out in a way that lets you find said written things? That sounds like a library to me!
ReadingMnemonic: The 書館 part should be readable by you, but it's the 図 that's troublesome with an alternate reading from the one you learned. Imagine yourself at the library. You check out every single book you can about the human toe (と). You have a giant stack of books on it, then you drop it... ironically on your toe. You decide to show Khan (your buddy) your smashed toe.

Name: Limited Express Train
Mnemonic: Something that's special and in a hurry must be special indeed. This refers to limited express trains in Japan. They go fast, they stop at fewer stops (because they're special!) and they hurry. Look out for these if you want to get somewhere in a jiffy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the とく goes to とっ.

Name: Line
Mnemonic: You know the two words that make up this word, 行 and 列, and they both have similar meanings: a line and a row. Put them together and you have a line or a queue.
ReadingMnemonic: This word takes the readings of the two words that make it up, so you should be lining up to read it!

Name: Luggage
Mnemonic: A luggage thing is your luggage. It's also your baggage and load too.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You'll need to remember the 物 reading as もつ, though. Why? Because all your luggage just got thrown into various moats along the countryside. It's going to take you forever to collect your luggage from these moats and by then it'll be all soggy. Dangit...

Name: Mask
Mnemonic: A temporary face is something you put over your face to cover it. It's a mask.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Meiji Era
Mnemonic: It’s the era of Bright Rule! If this doesn't make sense, don't worry about it. Focus more on the reading, which is めいじ. Sound familiar? This is the famous Meiji Era or Meiji Emperor. If you don't know about it consider reading up, it's interesting history!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Merchandise
Mnemonic: Articles of merchandise are still merchandise.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Museum
Mnemonic: You know 美術 is fine art. So what is a public building that contains said fine art? It's a museum.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Origami
Mnemonic: You know that 折る is "to fold," so what about "to fold paper"? Ever heard of something that involves lots of folding of paper that is Japanese? Most likely you have. This is origami, aka the art of paper folding.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 折る and the vocab word 紙. As long as you know those you should be able to read this. Also, you probably already know this reading because it's an English word, too.

Name: Osaka
Mnemonic: The big heights. What a nice area to be, it's where everyone wants to live! This magical place is Osaka. Heard of it before? It's a city, and kind of the rival to Tokyo.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is pretty weird, but then again so are people from Osaka (just kidding, Osakazens!). The 大 reads like おお from おおきい. Then, 阪 uses the kun'yomi reading as well, which you didn't learn. That being said, doesn't this kanji look like 坂, which also means slope? Well, it shares a kun'yomi reading as well, so if you've seen 坂 you can apply that reading over to here, making おおさか. Then again, if you know this word means Osaka you probably can figure out how to write it too. Don't forget the double おお though!

Name: Outpatient
Mnemonic: From foreign lands, you have come to this hospital. That makes you an outpatient.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Payment
Mnemonic: The pay that supports you is made in payments. Whether you make payments to keep your house or your car, or you get payments from your boss, they keep you going.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of the on'yomi reading of 支 and the kun'yomi reading of 払. You've learned them both, so you know this too!

Name: Photo
Mnemonic: A copy of reality is a lot like magic. How do you make a copy of reality, though? You take a photo.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Pitch Black
Mnemonic: The reality is that it's black. Like, so black that it's beyond fake black, it's reality black. This is so black it's pitch black.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 真 is the kun'yomi reading, which you haven't learned yet. Think of what is pitch black. It's your poor Ma (ま). She is so dark that she sucks in light, like a black hole... wait, she is a black hole, it explains why your Ma is pitch black.

Name: Plan
Mnemonic: Take your plan and add some images to it. This is your plan.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 画 is the secondary reading though (かく), so take note of that.

Name: Politics
Mnemonic: If you want to cure the government, you have to get into politics. Gotta join 'em to fix them... but can you survive that long without being corrupted yourself?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Preservation
Mnemonic: We try to preserve anything we want to exist with preservation. Want a special sea creature or bird to exist? Up conservation efforts! And, if you want to save data (like on a computer), you can use this word for that kind of saving, as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Prime Minister
Mnemonic: The neck minister? This meaning prime minister makes sense if you think about the neck being the most important part of the body, kind of like the head!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. It also uses a reading for 相 that you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The first prime ministers of Japan were actually the shoguns (しょう)… kind of.

Name: Proof
Mnemonic: Is the evidence bright enough to convince me? Is this really proof enough to prove it?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Public Order
Mnemonic: If your people can relax because you rule over them so well, there is public order. You don't want the people you rule being upset or stressed out, you want public safety and public peace for all!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Public Park
Mnemonic: A public park is a park that is public. It's a public park.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Risky
Mnemonic: Something that is dangerous and risky is probably pretty risky, dangerous, and unsafe.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Scene
Mnemonic: Everything on a location's surface is really just a part of the scene before you. This is the kind of scene that would be set in a novel. It's the setting.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading for 場 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: A scene where everyone says "baa" (ば) isn't very common… Unless you're reading a novel where all the characters are sheep! You find this novel's animal-centric setting to be pretty unique and interesting, but, honestly, all the baaing makes the dialogue a little hard to follow.

Name: Screen
Mnemonic: The image surface is a screen. Just imagine your computer screen. There's an image on the surface, right? It just happens to move around all the time, like most images on screens these days.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Simple And Easy
Mnemonic: Your hands are light because it was a simple and easy task, so you didn't get your hands full. This word describes something that's hassle-free and doesn't take much effort, time, or sometimes cost to do.
ReadingMnemonic: Both kanji use kun'yomi readings in this word, which you've already learned. Just make sure you rendaku the 軽.

Name: Smile
Mnemonic: A laughing face is a  smiling face (or just a smile!). 笑顔s all around!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word won't make you smile, though. You were smiling, but then you heard about the reading of this kanji. It made you yell out "EH??" (え). Just watch out for the rendaku of かお to がお.

Name: Specialty
Mnemonic: Your specialty gate is the thing you open to let out your specialty. Imagine the thing you're best at (your specialty). Now imagine opening a gate in your chest that lets it out, allowing you to be good at it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Statue Of Buddha
Mnemonic: You have Buddha and 像, which you learned mainly as "image" but can also mean statue. So that makes this a statue of Buddha. 仏像 can also just mean an image of Buddha, of course.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Study Abroad
Mnemonic: You detain your study and take it away to a foreign place. That foreign place is having you study abroad.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 留 is the りゅう version. You can remember this because Ryu (りゅう) from street fighter is doing a study abroad program to learn more karate.

Name: Sudden
Mnemonic: This takes its meaning from the sudden part of the kanji, meaning it's sudden, urgent, or an emergency!
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Sudden Death
Mnemonic: A sudden death makes for just that, a sudden death.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Suddenly
Mnemonic: Something that happens in a sudden way happens suddenly, immediately, or abruptly.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Suddenly you can read a new word!

Name: Sunbathe
Mnemonic: You know that 日光 is "sunlight" so when you add bathe you get "sunlight bathe" ... but that sounds dumb, so let's call this word sunbathe instead!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tag
Mnemonic: A luggage tag is a tag you put on luggage. It's also a label you can put on a package before you send it, like a shipping label.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for both kanji. You've learned both of these readings already, so you should be able to read this word too.

Name: Technique
Mnemonic: You've seen 技 as a vocab word meaning "technique," and the kanji 術 means technique. So this means technique! Your technique is also your craft, and what’s needed for technology.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Testimony
Mnemonic: Evidence that you say is testimony. You could also say you're providing verbal evidence. Hopefully you won't have to give too much of this in your lifetime.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Textbook
Mnemonic: The thing you use to teach a course with writings is a textbook. It's a book of writings you use to teach your course!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Bathe In
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bathe so the verb vocab version is to bathe in.
ReadingMnemonic: You want to know the best way to bathe in something? With a bunch of aardvarks (あ) in the water. They use their sticky little tongues to clean all your cracks and crannies.

Name: To Be Related To
Mnemonic: You know that 関 means related. So, when you add する to it you make it a verb. Now it means to be related to.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Break
Mnemonic: You already learned how 折る means "to fold something" or "to break something". This is the intransitive version of that, which just means it has no object. You just folded something too far, and now it's starting to break.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 折る, so you should know this one too!

Name: To Close Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means closed so the verb vocab version is to close something.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you want to close something, use a sheep (し). Sheep are famously good closers. Doors, windows, curtains, you name it. Sure, they'll bleat on and on about how they're not your personal closer, they have their own doors to close, and bah bah blah, but they secretly love having the chance to shut something for you.

Name: To Compromise
Mnemonic: You know that 妥協 means compromise. So, what happens when you make it a verb? It becomes to compromise.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the vocab word 妥協, so if you know that you should be good (also, just the reading of the kanji works too).

Name: To Graduate
Mnemonic: You know that 卒業 is "graduation." Make it a verb, and you have to graduate.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is just the same as the vocab word 卒業.

Name: To Hurry
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hurry so the verb vocab version is to hurry.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone who is trying to hurry is someone who is not at ease (いそ).

Name: To Inquire
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The first kanji is question. And you learned 合わせる is "to join together." What's "to join questions together"? It's to inquire. When you inquire, you ask all your questions together, right?
ReadingMnemonic: You know how to read 合わせる already, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember the reading of 問: You love to inquire with your toes (と). By that, you mean you love to type on your keyboard with your toes. There's no particular reason for this besides that you like the feel on your toes when you type up an inquiry.

Name: To Know
Mnemonic: This is like a very formal and humble way of saying to know or to believe. Sure, the kanji means suppose, but think of it this way... When you say "I suppose" it's like a humble way of saying "I know" or "I believe." You're not being as direct about it this way, and in Japanese, that makes you more humble and polite. So, that's why 存じる means to know or to believe.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. If you remember the kanji reading, you'll have no problem remembering this vocabulary reading as well!

Name: Tokyo Dialect
Mnemonic: You know that 東京 is Tokyo, and you know that 弁 is dialect, so you have yourself Tokyo dialect.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know how to read 東京 already, which you should.

Name: To Laugh
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means laugh so the verb vocab version is to laugh.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You can laugh freely, now!

Name: To Leave Behind
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means remainder, but you can't really "to remainder." What is something that's similar that would make sense? How about to leave behind. This is when you're actually doing the leaving behind too. For example, you eat some food and you leave behind your rice because you're a bad child. You can remember this because of す. Every time you leave some food behind your mom would sue you, because she was a terrible mom. Imagine this.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word can come from level 14 item 残る. Associate the two in your mind and you'll be able to read both.

Name: To Make Something Hard
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hard so the verb vocab version? To make something hard. You need to differentiate this from 固まる, though, which means "to harden" (the hardening happens on its own). This word means "to make something hard," because you're doing the hardening. You can remember this because you want to make something hard. And to do that, you send special "mail" (める) to this thing you want to make hard, and this mail does that for you.
ReadingMnemonic: Since the reading for 固 (かた) is different than the one you learned with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you: Why would you want to make something hard? Obviously because you want to put it in a catapult (かた). There's no point putting soft things in catapults, after all.

Name: To Occur
Mnemonic: Remember how 生まれる means "to be born"? This word is similar, but it's used for when non-living things are "born". So as an intransitive verb, this means to occur or to arise. When used transitively, it means to cause something. You'll probably encounter the intransitive use much more, though.
ReadingMnemonic: You'd think this would use kun'yomi, but it actually doesn't! Like other verbs ending in じる, this takes the on'yomi reading of the kanji. 生 has two of those, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: If you wanted anything to occur in medieval Japan, you needed to talk to the Shougun. You always needed the Shougun's help to cause something. Without the Shougun, nothing would ever happen!

Name: To Promise
Mnemonic: 約束 is a “promise.” So when you add する to it you’re making it a verb, meaning to promise. Now promise you’ll remember!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 約束 with する added. Make sure you know 約束 and you'll know this word as well.

Name: To Protect
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means protect so the verb vocab version is to protect and also to defend. This can also mean to obey, in the sense of obeying the rules.
ReadingMnemonic: You need to protect against breast cancer, so you get yourself a mammogram (まも).

Name: To Quit
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means quit so the verb vocab version is to quit.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "Hey, you going to quit?" "Yah (や) man, I'm going to quit."

Name: To Send Someone Back
Mnemonic: The hiragana ends with an う sound, so you know this is a verb. The kanji itself means return, and this verb is transitive, meaning it takes a direct object. You send someone back. You send them home. And tell them to never come near you again. So this means to send someone back or to send someone home.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Yay! But since this word has a pair verb, let's think of a way to remember the ending: What's the most surefire way to send someone home? Threaten to sue (す) them if they don't!

Name: To Stack
Mnemonic: You've got lots of heavy things, so the only logical thing is to stack them all up.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: All the things you've stacked up were in preparation for your new casa (かさ). With everything inside boxes and neatly piled up, you're finally ready to move into your new casa. Hooray!

Name: To Wish
Mnemonic: You know that 希望 is a "wish." When you "do a wish," that means to wish, to request or to hope.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 希望. It's also the on'yomi jukugo reading as well, if that helps any.

Name: To Write
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means write so the verb version means to write.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the on'yomi one, but this word is read with the kun'yomi, か. So just be sure to remember the kun'yomi reading to read this word in the car (か) ... or to write it, or whatever.

Name: Truth
Mnemonic: The reality of the truth is nothing more than the truth and the reality. Doesn't get any more real than this.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Unhappiness
Mnemonic: When you do not have happiness, you have unhappiness, misfortune and misery. This can also mean death, usually of a family member.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Waiting Room
Mnemonic: A room where you join other people to wait. This is a waiting room.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember how you learned 待合 already? Well throw the on'yomi for 室 on the end of that and you have your reading!

Name: Witness
Mnemonic: An evidence person is a witness, because witnesses are people who provide evidence (you know, with their mouths or something).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Zoo
Mnemonic: Remember how 動物 means animal? Well when you add park it becomes a zoo. It's a park for animals. Except the animals can't leave. Ever.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Absence
Mnemonic: When a seat is lacking the person it's supposed to have in it, there is an absence. Where is Johnny? Another absence? Ugh. Johnny. C'mon.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the けつ is shortened to けっ as つs often are when in a situation like this.

Name: Absolutely
Mnemonic: Absolutely an injustice! We must absolutely punish the perpetrator, by all means. First, though, we should probably define right and wrong.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: After All
Mnemonic: If you tie the bureau up with your delays this may not get done this year after all.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note the けつ gets changed to けっ as つs in this situation often do.

Name: Aichi Prefecture
Mnemonic: The Love Know Prefecture! I want to live here, because people must know love! Of course, we don't call it that in English. You'll have to know the reading of the kanji to know the reading of this prefecture, which is Aichi Prefecture (jump to the reading to figure this out).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn 知's on'yomi when you learned the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know what they really love to know about in Aichi Prefecture? Cheese (ち). Those folks in Aichi, they're some real cheese know-it-alls. Don't ever bring one to a wine and cheese party, because, man — they will be rattling off cheese facts to you all evening.

Name: Always
Mnemonic: The particle に here is a clue that this word is an adverb. An adverb describes actions, so what's a normal action? It's one you're always, or constantly, doing. That's what makes it normal!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn. In order to learn it, think of this: I always tune (つね) my violin, but today I didn't tune it. So, now I sound terrible. Imagine how terrible my untuned violin sounds, compared to how it always sounds.

Name: Anonymous
Mnemonic: Someone with "nothing" for their name is either trying to remain anonymous or is simply unknown.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Arms
Mnemonic: The containers that soldiers use aren't just bowls and stuff, they're the things that hold their arms and weapons. Think spear and sword containers, full of weapons!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: As Usual
Mnemonic: A mutual change you make with other people will go so smoothly that it will seem like everything is working as usual. It will be like everything is the same as it was before because the change was mutual.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Atom
Mnemonic: The original child of everything is the atom. It is the child from which everything else is created, for it was the original child. Atoms are the building blocks of all things!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
