Name: Attendance
Mnemonic: The people who exit their seats at the end of the show are the number of people who showed up, not counting empty seats. This is the true attendance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note the しゅつ gets changed to しゅっ, as many つs do in this situation.

Name: Bad Tasting
Mnemonic: You've seen 美味しい by this point. This is the opposite of that. Instead of 美 you have 不 (not), so something that does not have flavor is something that doesn't taste good. i.e. something bad tasting. This can also refer to someone who's unskillful at something as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading doesn't follow any of the rules you've run into. It's まずい. Think about how you're going through this really long maze (まず) and how you're promised a really tasty wonderful treat at the end for getting through it (you're a lab rat or something). When you get to the end, there's your treat! What joy! You eat it and... oh man... it is so bad tasting you can't even believe it. Be sure to imagine the terrible taste and the terrible disappointment after going through that difficult maze only to get this... this... terribly unappetizing cheese.

Name: Before The Common Era
Mnemonic: Remember how 紀元後 is "Common Era", or "anno Domini"? Well, this is the opposite because it has before (前) instead of 後. It's Before the Common Era or Before Christ.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know how to read 紀元後 already, because then you'll just have to remember the 前.

Name: Both Sides
Mnemonic: Both sides is both sides. Which side? Both sides.
ReadingMnemonic: The first kanji takes the on'yomi reading and the second takes the kun'yomi reading. Luckily you know both of them already!

Name: Bottom
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This vocab uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. Well played!

Name: Bottom Of One's Heart
Mnemonic: The heart bottom is the bottom of one's heart. Do you want to learn kanji? Do you want to learn it from 心底? Okay, fine, you can move onto the reading then.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this too!

Name: Breakfast
Mnemonic: The morning meal is the meal you eat in the morning. That is breakfast.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. It's also like the vocab: 朝 is like the vocab version, あさ and ご飯 is like the word you learned, ごはん.

Name: Cafeteria
Mnemonic: An eating hall is a big room in which you eat. What big rooms do you eat in? How about a cafeteria, a dining hall, or a diner?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Cause
Mnemonic: The original cause is how you got into this mess. Forget all the things it caused, the first cause is the origin and source of what's going on right now. You can pinpoint one thing that caused all of this!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Comedy
Mnemonic: Rejoice drama isn't so much drama as it is comedy, since it makes you rejoice.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Common Sense
Mnemonic: Normal discerning is the discerning you do on a daily basis, without thinking. It is all the things that you do that are common sense.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Conclusion
Mnemonic: The perfect way to tie up a research paper is with a conclusion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Consciousness
Mnemonic: Your ideas while discerning things show your consciousness and an awareness of your surroundings. You not only know that you have ideas, but you think about them and discern them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Crybaby
Mnemonic: You've seen that 泣く is to cry, so you can probably guess that 泣き is just "cry." You've also seen how 虫 is rarely a nice thing to call someone. So what's a mean thing you can call someone who cries? How about a crybaby?
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 泣く and 虫. So long as you're okay with those two words you should be able to read this one too.

Name: Crying
Mnemonic: A cry voice is a sound of crying or a sob. Don't cry! Kanji will get easier someday!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the vocab words 泣く and 声. So long as you know those two words okay, you should be able to read this word too!

Name: Day Before Last
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 昨日 means "yesterday?" Well one day previous to that day is the day before last.
ReadingMnemonic: This reading is an exception. Let's use this mnemonic to remember it: The day before last you bought an "O" toe toy (おととい). It's a kid's toy in the shape of the letter O that you put on your toe. You know it was the day before last because you wore it all yesterday, and now today your toe is sore. If only you could go back to the day before yesterday to tell yourself not to buy that O toe toy! Or at least not to wear it for the whole next day!

Name: Detailed
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of detailed? It's also detailed.
ReadingMnemonic: When something is detailed it is made up of a huge quantity (くわ) of little things. And if you're an expert on something, you'll have a huge quantity of knowledge, too.

Name: Details
Mnemonic: Things that are detailed and... detailed are, well, the details.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dinner
Mnemonic: The night meal is the meal you eat at night. That is dinner.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Diplomat
Mnemonic: Someone from the outside who comes in to mix with the government is a diplomat. Really, that's what diplomats do, right? They come from the outside (country). They mix with the government, and they do what they're there to do!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Drama
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well (drama). Can also mean play or show as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji. No more drama from you, okay?

Name: Dramatic
Mnemonic: Something that is drama al is dramatic.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Drugs
Mnemonic: These medicine things are of the bad kind, they're drugs!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Dry Weather
Mnemonic: Remember how 天気 is weather (and how 天 often refers to sky things?). Well, when those sky things are dry, you have dry weather.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: East Side
Mnemonic: The East side is the East side.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember how 東口 read as ひがしぐち? This word is like that too, with 東 being read as ひがし. 側 is read like you learned it with the kanji.

Name: Emergency
Mnemonic: When an injustice to what's normal is being committed, that makes it an emergency!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Everyday Life
Mnemonic: Normal days are what you have in your regular everyday life. This is your normal life.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Explanation
Mnemonic: When you make your theory bright (and clear and easy to understand) you must have come up with a great explanation for it. Before, it was dark and murky in everyone's mind. But, when you gave your explanation, it became bright and easy to understand! Yay!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Failure
Mnemonic: A fault and a failure, all in one. This must have been one big failure and mistake you've made.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 失 gets shortened, and 敗 gets rendaku'd, though. Don't make that 失敗.

Name: Fantasy
Mnemonic: An illusion that you imagine is your big fantasy (it's also an illusion). This makes sense, though, right? An illusion is an illusion, sure. But, when you imagine it, it becomes your fantasy!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Fluent
Mnemonic: Parrot, parrot (ペラペラ), your speaking is so fluent!

Name: Foreign Word
Mnemonic: You know the word 外来 to mean "imported." So, combine that with the kanji for language and you have an imported word, aka a borrowed word. There are a lot of these in Japanese, which makes this word important. Almost everything in katakana is a 外来語, in fact.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Free
Mnemonic: When the fee is nothing it is free and without charge!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Fruit
Mnemonic: A fruit thing is just fruit.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this is an exception, at least for the 果 portion. To remember this part, imagine yourself asking for some fruit. Could I (くだ) have some fruit, please?

Name: Government Funds
Mnemonic: Government gold (aka money) is what makes up government funds.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Hallucination
Mnemonic: An illusion you have when you're awake is a hallucination.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Head
Mnemonic: Your head part, or the part of your body that's your head, is… well, your head!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 頭 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Need a checkup on your head? Then head to とうきょう! They have the best… head doctors in とうきょう, I've heard. So head on over to とうきょう for your next head checkup.

Name: Heartbreak
Mnemonic: The fault of romance isn't the romance itself, it's when everything falls apart. It's when you experience heartbreak or unrequited love. Have you ever felt the fault of romance? If so, remember back to that time, and think about how terrible of a fault it is.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Humming
Mnemonic: Try singing a nose song. How does it sound? Like humming perhaps?
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi vocab readings, probably because a 鼻 is a body part, and body parts do that to jukugo words. You know 鼻's reading from the kanji (はな) and you know 歌's reading from the vocabulary word 歌 (うた). Combine them together and you have a very nice humming tune and reading, はなうた.

Name: Hypothesis
Mnemonic: A temporary theory isn't one that's set in stone yet. In fact, it's not really a theory at all, it's more of a hypothesis.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Ignorance
Mnemonic: When you know nothing (Jon Snow), you know nothing. This is ignorance, it's being ignorant.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn 知's on'yomi when you learned the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What's the worst thing to live in ignorance of? Probably cheese (ち). Can you imagine not knowing cheddar from Swiss? Or gouda from brie? Imagine the sad, hollow life you would live if you were ignorant to the wonders of cheese.

Name: Illusion
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add phantom to the meanings as well, because phantoms are kind of like illusions.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look up to see a crazy illusion. You can't believe it's real. Master Roshi, from Dragonball, is standing in front of you (you thought he was a cartoon!). Then, he splits into a million versions of himself, creating a mob of Roshis (まぼろし). This mob goes on to train many people to fight.

Name: Illustration
Mnemonic: A diagram theory is an illustration that is used as an explanatory diagram. Just imagine a chalk board with all sorts of drawings of things, showing how they work, at least in theory.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Impossible
Mnemonic: If you can do nothing within reason, then what you're trying to do is unreasonable and probably downright impossible. If you still try, you're probably just overdoing it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

Name: Inference
Mnemonic: Okay, so you guess but you also kind of know. You can make an inference as to what the answer is... You're not 100% sure, but you think you know, even though you're guessing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You know the 察 part, although it gets shortened to さっ here. You didn't learn 知's on'yomi when you learned the kanji, though, so here's a mnemonic to help you with it: One inference everyone can make is that you probably want to eat some cheese (ち). Seriously, it's written all over your face. You can try to hide it, but everyone saw how hot and bothered you just got in the dairy section. It doesn't take a mind-reader to sense how bad you're jonesing for some cheese.

Name: Inside
Mnemonic: The inside side is the inside. A little redundant but makes a lot of sense.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. With 側 you've already learned it. With 内 you've also already learned the reading. Combine them together and you have うちがわ. In case you've forgotten, here's a mnemonic to help you remember that pesky うち portion. What is it that's drawn you inside? "Oo, cheese!" (うち) Cheese has drawn you inside. You're so excited that you exclaim, "Oo, cheese!"

Name: Interference
Mnemonic: When you're fording a stream, and you suddenly feel dry feelings around you, that doesn't make any sense for something wet. This dryness is an interference. It's an intervention trying to stop you from fording.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Irrational
Mnemonic: Imagine having nothing but tea for an entire week. Sounds completely irrational, right? Such a reckless diet plan seems excessive.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Knowledge
Mnemonic: You're discerning about what you know. You choose what to keep and what not to keep in your brain. This is the sum of your knowledge.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn 知's on'yomi when you learned the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What's something you have a ton of knowledge about? Cheese (ち)! You have a massive, encyclopedic knowledge of all the world's cheeses. As a true bleu expert, it really grates on you that most other people's cheese knowledge is so full of holes.

Name: Left Side
Mnemonic: The left side is the left side. Simple as that.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this is vocab kun'yomi readings. Just take the vocab 左 and add it to 側 to have yourself ひだりがわ.

Name: Legend
Mnemonic: When people transmit a theory through the ages, it can turn into a legend, or legendary story. Kind of like how the "theory" of King Arthur's sword turned into the legend of Excalibur.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You just have to remember that 伝 is read as でん in this case. Just imagine yourself sitting in your den (でん) as you get cozy and listen to this theory about a great legend.

Name: Loser
Mnemonic: The defeated someone is the loser or the defeated.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Love
Mnemonic: When you have romance and love all in the same package. Well, that is love! Ah, love! This is the word used when talking about love, though. You don't use this to say "I love you."
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Love
Mnemonic: Those love feelings you're having mean you're in love!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Love
Mnemonic: When you have romance you also have love! The romantic kind of mushy, gushy love. Be careful though. This word doesn't share its meaning with its kanji. But, that's how romance is. It gets all crazy and turns to love really fast.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Your love isn't toward a person, it's toward this giant Koi (こい) fish you met the other day. The fish is just so... so... handsome! You get hearts popping above your head every time you think about this koi!

Name: Love
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji. Now that is true kanji love.

Name: Lover
Mnemonic: The person you make love to is your lover. Woooh! Don't worry I won't tell. Have fun and be safe, kids.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lunch
Mnemonic: The noon meal is the meal you eat at noon. What meal is that? It's delicious, delicious lunch.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from the words 昼 and ご飯. If you know how to read those words you can read this word as well.

Name: Main Cause
Mnemonic: The main cause is the main cause or the primary cause.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Medicinal
Mnemonic: Something that's used for medicine is medicinal.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Medicine
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. If you're looking for medicine in Japan, look for this sign.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You need some medicine, stat! But, nobody wants to give you any medicine. You keep asking your pharmacist, Yuri, if he'll give you some medicine. He says no. You get pissed off, and you cuss yuri (くすり) out. He gives you the medicine after you cuss him out.

Name: Military Personnel
Mnemonic: A soldier member (or a member of the soldiers) is a person that is of the military personnel. It also shows the amount of military strength an army has. The more soldier members, the more military strength and military personnel it has!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Navy Sailor
Mnemonic: A water soldier is a soldier that is out to sea. In other words, a navy sailor.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Negotiation
Mnemonic: When you ford into the thick of things and mix everything up, you're getting involved in a negotiation. That's what negotiations are though, right? You gotta get right in there, fording through the muck. Then, you gotta mix things up and compromise between both parties.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: No Holidays
Mnemonic: If rest is nothing then there are no holidays. If there are no holidays, then that means a place is always open, nonstop.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Nose
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji. Smells nice, right?

Name: Nosebleed
Mnemonic: A nose with blood is a nose with a nosebleed. It is a bloody nose.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You already know 鼻's reading from the kanji and vocab, and you should know the vocab reading of 血 as well. Put them together and you have はなち, though you want to change the ち to ぢ. Alternatively, it's possible (though less common, but it doesn't matter if you're turning it to kanji via an IME anyways) to write it as はなじ. I guess that blood added a little tenten (it represents the blood coming out of that nose!). Spurt spurt spurt.

Name: Novel
Mnemonic: A small theory is some idea you have that you put on paper. Perhaps it's an idea about life, that you write in the form of a novel?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: One's Wish
Mnemonic: You know that お願い means "a request," and 事 can mean "thing." Well, a request for some specific thing can also be called one's wish or a prayer. Do you have any 願い事 in your heart right now? Of course you do! Don't worry, you can tell me.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from the words お願い and 事. If you know how to read those you should be able to read this word too. Just remember that 事 is rendaku'd, so it's read as ごと.

Name: Open Seat
Mnemonic: A sky seat is a seat full of sky (aka nothing!). This is an empty seat or open seat.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Opera
Mnemonic: A song drama. Ugh, I hate these. They sing so much and they're so dramatic. This is an opera.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Original Work
Mnemonic: The original thing you make is the original work. It's always better to have the original, rather than a copy, I think.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Outside
Mnemonic: The outside side is the outside.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from the kanji. Since you learned the kun'yomi reading for 外 with the vocabulary, you should be just fine here.

Name: Patriotism
Mnemonic: When you have love for your country deep within your heart, that is patriotism.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Police
Mnemonic: They warn you and they guess when you've done something wrong (with evidence, of course!). They are the police.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Powerless
Mnemonic: When your power is nothing you are powerless.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. There are a couple possibilities for 力 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember which to use: You know 力 uses its りょく reading here because you're totally powerless when they lock (りょく) you up. Who's "they"? I don't know, but did you hear the click of the lock behind you? That means you're powerless now.

Name: Result
Mnemonic: You tie up all the fruit because you're going to use them to make giant fruit letters. These giant fruit letters will show the result of the big monkey election.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the 結 gets shortened to けっ.

Name: Right Side
Mnemonic: The right side is the right side.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading. You should know the reading of the vocab word 右 by now. Also, the 側 reading happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji as well as with the word 側.

Name: Riverbed
Mnemonic: The river bottom is the river bottom, also known as the riverbed.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. Just don't forget the rendaku for 底!

Name: Safe And Sound
Mnemonic: A nothing occurrence is an occurrence where nothing happens to you, or at least nothing too bad — that means you're safe and sound. Phew!
ReadingMnemonic: One thing that's not safe and sound is the reading of the 無 in this word. Instead of む it's ぶ. Why? Because you thought it was safe and sound, but you were fooled. There are ghosts everywhere, all jumping out and screaming Boo! (ぶ) at you. Feel the surprise. You thought it was safe and sound!

Name: Salt
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, no extra salt needed.

Name: Salt Water
Mnemonic: Water with salt in it is salt water. Best not to drink 塩水.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You know 塩's from the kanji and you know 水's from the vocab word 水. Combine them together and you have しおみず.

Name: Salty Taste
Mnemonic: The taste of salt is a salty taste (it's also when something tastes salty).
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, take the readings of 塩 (you learned the reading with the kanji) and 味 and you have yourself しおあじ. If you happen to be a cooking show fan, you might also hear the on'yomi reading of this word - えんみ. This word can also be read as しおみ, which has more or less the same meaning as the primary reading you learned.

Name: Seat
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the on you learned with the kanji. Have a seat and relax.

Name: Self Love
Mnemonic: If you love your self that is self love. You’ll mostly see this word as part of the set phrase ご自愛下さい, which is used in emails and the like to remind the recipients to be good to themselves. Other variations include ご自愛くださいませ, ご自愛を, and ご自愛のほどを.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, you self lover you.

Name: Sense
Mnemonic: You know how we use feelings to memorize things here on WaniKani? I ask you to feel angry or sad or happy while imagining out the mnemonic stories. I also ask you to use your senses, because feelings are memorized best when you use the senses. This can also refer to any particular sensation or even somebody's sense of humor or fashion!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Side
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: You've learned the がわ as the reading for this kanji, but when its used on its own as a vocabulary word, it is read as そば. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember: Having a sober(そば) person by your side is important when you're drunk. Think of other vocabulary words that use がわ. In these words, 側 is a suffix, so it will have another kanji that comes before it.

Name: Signature
Mnemonic: When you write your name for a government office, they require you to write out your signature. Printing won't do for official government office business.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Silence
Mnemonic: When you have nothing to say you sit in silence.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 言 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Nothing cuts through silence like a gong (ごん). Once it's done gonging you really notice how silent the world around you is.

Name: Snot
Mnemonic: If you're like everyone else learning a new language, you learn the bad words first. This isn't a bad word, but it sort of contains one. くそ means "sh*t" (as in "poop") in Japanese. What is your nose sh*t, then? It's your snot and boogers. Eww, stop eating them!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is just like what you learned with the kanji. はなくそ.

Name: Soldier
Mnemonic: A soldier samurai is still just another soldier.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Soldier
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Study Of Pharmacy
Mnemonic: People who study about medicine are studying the study of pharmacy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Theater
Mnemonic: A drama location is where people do drama. This is a theater.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Thin
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of thin? It's also thin, though it can be slender as well.
ReadingMnemonic: If your garden is too thin, just get out the hose (ほそ)! How about if your hair is thin? Point the hose at your head! Hoses can cure any thin issues you may have.

Name: Tip Of The Nose
Mnemonic: You know the previous part of your nose? The part of your nose I just chopped off? Well, you were lucky, as that was only the tip of the nose. Time to cut off the rest, next!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. With 鼻 you learned that with the kanji. With 先 you learned that with the vocab. So, you should have all the pieces to be able to read this. Remember, body parts tend to change words into kun'yomi readings for some reason, no exception here.

Name: To Be Changed
Mnemonic: You've seen how 変える means "to change" something. This word means that something changed by itself, so it means to be changed or to be altered.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: To Be Defeated
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means defeat, so this means to be defeated, but also to be unsuccessful.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have been defeated. You lay there on the ground, and the fans around the stadium are disgusted with your performance. Some hipster walks up to you and says: "Yah, Boo" (やぶ) referring to how poorly you did. "No boo!", you reply back. "Yah boo", they say again.

Name: To Be Sad About
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sad and this verb is transitive, so it means to be sad about something. Boohoo.
ReadingMnemonic: If you're going to be sad about something right now, it will be kana (かな). Don't use kana when you're trying to learn kanji! You'll be sad forever if you're stuck using kana your whole life, so don't let that habit start now, friend.

Name: To Cure
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I need you to heal him, and I need you to heal him right now (なお). NOW NOW NOW! This also shares the reading for 直す, a very similar word you learned previously, which means "to fix." I'm guessing that the Japanese word なおす was only one word ("to fix" and "to cure" are pretty similar, right?). Then, there were two Chinese words for it (as you can see with the kanji), so the one Japanese word got split into two very similar words.

Name: To Dry Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dry and the verb vocab version is to dry something.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Why do you need to dry something? Because someone used a hose (ほす) and got everything all wet. Ugh, you shouldn't leave that hose out anymore...

Name: To End
Mnemonic: If you tear (てる) up a fruit, its life is going to end. In other words, the poor thing is going to die. Fruit can't go on when they've been beaten up so much.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The fruit's life is about to end and you laugh, "Hahahaha (は)!" And then you start tearing at it more! What's wrong with you? Weirdo...

Name: To Guess
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means guess so the verb vocab version is to guess. Alternatively, you can learn this as to sense or to presume.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this is actually the same as what you learned with the kanji, but the さつ is shortened to さっ. If you had to guess be sure to guess with the shorter つ.

Name: To Love
Mnemonic: You know that 愛 means love. So, when you add する to it you make it a verb. Now it means to love.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: To Rejoice
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rejoice so the verb vocab version is to rejoice. Though to become happy probably sounds a little more natural.
ReadingMnemonic: You start to rejoice by saying, "Yo, rock on (よろこ)!" Now you know how to rejoice from now on. At church or temple? "Yo, rock on!" Perfect.

Name: Tragedy
Mnemonic: A sad drama always ends in tragedy. That's what makes it sad.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ume
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. It's also the same as the meaning of the kanji / vocab, though you can think of this as  Japanese plum as well if you want.

Name: Ume Wine
Mnemonic: Alcohol that comes from ume is ume wine. It can also be called plum wine or plum liquor. If you're of age give it a taste, it's quite nice!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is just the readings of the kanji that you learned. How about a toast to easy to read words!

Name: Unknown
Mnemonic: Something is not detailed at all. I don't know anything about it. No details whatsoever. It's a totally unknown entity. It's unidentified.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: US Soldier
Mnemonic: Remember how 米国 is "America." Well, more of that again. With 米 representing "America" you can combine that with 兵 (soldier) to have yourself a US soldier / American soldier.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Victory Or Defeat
Mnemonic: You have win and you have defeat. When you are talking about both in one word, you have victory or defeat.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: West Side
Mnemonic: The West side of something is known as the West or the West side. Sorry, I have no story to go along with your West side.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You should know both of them, with 西 being にし and 側 being がわ (what you learned with the kanji).

Name: Without
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji nothing, so when you have nothing, you are without.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you are without you don't have anything to eat either, so you end up gnashing (なし) your teeth together instead.

Name: Youth
Mnemonic: The time of young spring for humans is really just their youth. Just like plants in spring, your adolescence is when you start growing to your full potential! You might even say it's the springtime of one's life.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for 春 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Don't let your youth go to waste, because it will be over soon (しゅん)!

Name: Advance Notice
Mnemonic: If you announce something beforehand you will have advance notice. Advance notice is always nice to give.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Advertisement
Mnemonic: When you announce something to a wide audience, you're just throwing your message out there for everyone to hear. This is just a big wide advertisement.
ReadingMnemonic: Sorry, you only learned the kun'yomi reading with 広. So, think of it this way when you need to remember this word's meaning: You're advertising something. It's a big advertisement to advertise how terrible a person こういち is. Come up with some terrible things he's done so that you can imagine this crazy Koichi advertisement you made and ran on national TV.

Name: A Laugh
Mnemonic: You know that 笑う is "to laugh." This is the noun version, because the う in 笑う turns to い (so don't confuse this as an adjective). What is the noun version of "to laugh"? It's a laugh.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 笑う, so just make sure you know that so you can know this as well.

Name: Amulet
Mnemonic: You know how 守る is "to protect," right? This is like that, but it's the noun version. It's not really "a protection," though it kind of is. What things can you wear to protect you from things like bad luck, demons, and ancient aliens? That would be an amulet or a charm. You'll see these kinds of things sold at temples and such.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is like that of 守る, so if you know the reading of that word you should be able to read this one as well.

Name: Archery
Mnemonic: The path of the bow. This is archery.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Black Smoke
Mnemonic: Black smoke is black smoke. It's also something you should avoid if you can.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Borrowing
Mnemonic: A borrowing task is just another way to say borrowing. This is also for when you take out a loan.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Bow
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: All we need to shoot a bow is you 'n' me (ゆみ). One person holds the bow, the other fires the arrows. Teamwork makes the dream work. Even for shooting bows. Just you 'n' me.

Name: Brain
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Don't have to use your brain for that.

Name: Brain Death
Mnemonic: If your brain is dead you have brain death.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Brains
Mnemonic: Do you know みそ Soup and how miso goes in it? This is that miso. It's soft and strange feeling. Now, your brain miso, that's your brains or your gray matter. Essentially, if someone cuts your head open with a katana, this is perhaps what would come out.
ReadingMnemonic: Reading is just what you learned with the kanji. Just use your 脳 a bit and it should be easy.

Name: Brainwashing
Mnemonic: Give your brain a nice wash. No! Wait! It's not as nice as it sounds. This is brainwashing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Buddhist Priest
Mnemonic: A Buddha priest is a Buddhist Priest.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Cafe
Mnemonic: If you consume tea in a shop, it could either be a cafe, a tea house, or slightly confusingly, a coffee shop. Welcome! Sit down. Relax. Have some tea (or coffee).
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are what you'd expect except for きつ getting shortened to きっ and 茶, which has this strange さ reading. To remember that it's さ instead of ちゃ, think of this tea house you're going in. You think it's nice and pleasant, and it is for a while... until someone starts working a saw (さ) outside, ruining the atmosphere. BEWWEEEEHHHEEEHHHHHE gatatatatatat BWEEEHEEE.

Name: Calm
Mnemonic: A place that is peace and quiet is a very calm and serene place. Ahh, so nice!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Candy
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. When we talk about this kind of candy, it's usually hard candy 🍬 or a lollipop 🍭 though.
ReadingMnemonic: This word is made up of a single kanji, and it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

Name: Caretaker
Mnemonic: You know how 留守 means "absence" or "away from home"? Well, now that you're absent from your home, it's someone else's  turn to come to your home and take care of it. This person is the caretaker, someone who's looking after one's house.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 留守 will be important as well.

Name: Car Wash
Mnemonic: A wash that washes cars is a car wash.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Don't confuse this with the same-sounding 戦車 though... unless you're washing your 戦車 in a 洗車...

Name: Certificate
Mnemonic: You hopefully know that 証明 means "proof." So, when the proof is written down, what kind of proof is it? It's a certificate of some kind. I'm going to need to see some 証明書 if you want to get in here, sir.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 証明's reading will also be helpful.

Name: Chest
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This vocab word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. At least I won't have to bring up the image of you mooning (むね) people with your breasts or whatnot. Oh dang, I just went and did it.

Name: Classification
Mnemonic: You divide something into different types. That's called classification or categorization.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Comedy
Mnemonic: You know that 笑う is "to laugh." This is a noun version of that, though it's not "a laugh," (that's 笑い). Add お to that and you have the thing that makes you laugh. It's comedy. It's the joke that's elevated with お because it made you laugh SOOOOO much. Haha!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same 笑う or 笑い. It's also the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Complaint
Mnemonic: A paragraph in writing is what you send someone when you want to submit a complaint. You want to make sure these are in writing, though, otherwise you don't have proof of your complaint. Also, don't make it longer than a paragraph, because that's too long and nobody cares about how you think the shop staff mistreated your dog Fluffy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Confession
Mnemonic: To announce something and make it white is to make a confession. Think of a completely blank sheet of paper - your confession clears all the announcements from the sheet of paper, making it white.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Cute
Mnemonic: It's possible to love this thing. It's so gosh darn cute! Any really cute thing is possible to love.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is screwed up, though if we're lucky, you already know the word for cute. It seems to have injected itself into American and English culture a decent amount, anyways. If you are one of the lucky ones, you'll know that this word is read as かわいい. If you're not, think of the cute thing being a cow. Then you say, "that cowはいい" (かわいい), or "that cow is good" because it's so cute.

Name: Debt
Mnemonic: The money (and gold) you borrow is your debt. Be sure to pay it back before the yakuza come for you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The しゃく gets shortened to しゃっ though, so beware. Just think of that like the little bit that you lost to the yakuza, because they weren't happy you didn't pay back your debt. *cut*

Name: Dictionary Form
Mnemonic: This is a combination of the word 辞書 "dictionary" and the suffix 〜形 or "form." Put them together and you get dictionary form!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Document
Mnemonic: If you put writing into a category, you'd have to write it down after you've chosen what category it is in. Where would you write that down? Into a document, probably.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Elegant
Mnemonic: Remember how 下品 is "crude" and "vulgar" - this is obviously the opposite. This is elegant.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Equal
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of equal? It's equal (and also similar or equivalent). That "similar" one is a bit weird, because "similar" is not equal, though I'd lean more towards equal.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What should be equal above all things? I think each 人 (ひと) should be equal!

Name: Equality
Mnemonic: It doesn't matter what you say versus equal rights. If you really want things to be equal, you have to support equality.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Equal Sign
Mnemonic: How do you represent an equal number? With an equal sign.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Exchange Student
Mnemonic: Remember 留学, which means "study abroad"? Do you also remember 学生, which is "student"? This word is like those two words mashed together (they share a 学), making it a "study abroad student." What's a better way to say that? How about exchange student!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Far Away
Mnemonic: This is the noun/no-adjective version of the kanji far, so it means far away or distant.
ReadingMnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi reading which you learned with 遠い. How convenient!

Name: First Class
Mnemonic: When you're equal to one you are the very top. You are first class and first rank. In fact, you are the best.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. いち gets shortened to いっ though, so watch out for that if you want to remain the best, yeah?

Name: First Love
Mnemonic: Your first love is your first love or your first crush. This usually refers to the first time you fall in love, but it can also refer to the person you fall in love with.
ReadingMnemonic: Similarly to 初耳, 初 behaves more like a prefix here, which means that this uses kun'yomi readings. You already know these for both 初 and 恋, so you should be good to go!

Name: Five Flat Objects
Mnemonic: You know that 枚 is a flat objects counter. So, now we're counting! You have five flat objects.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Flat Object Counter
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, so this is flat object counter.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Forbidden
Mnemonic: Stop! That's prohibition (prohibited)! When something is prohibited and you're forced to stop, that thing is obviously forbidden. If you see this you should probably not do the thing it's telling you not to do.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Forecast
Mnemonic: A news report that covers things beforehand (before they happen) is a forecast. For example, a weather forecast is a 天気予報.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Friday
Mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The gold day of the week is the greatest day. It's the day that makes you feel like gold because it's the end of the weekdays and the beginning of the weekend! This day is Friday.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

Name: Friend
Mnemonic: A friend that you attain is your friend. This is the most common way to say "friend," so learn it if you want to make any!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for both of these are readings you haven't learned yet, though maybe you already know this word since it's fairly common. Think of it this way. You have your friend Tom (とも) Cruise. You like him, and he likes you. You're close enough friends that you can touch (だち) each other too. Like, on the shoulder or on the hand or whatever, without it being awkward. So, you like to Tom touch (ともだち) when you can, because he has nice skin.

Name: Ginza
Mnemonic: The silver seat isn't some crazy kingdom where the king sits upon a silver seat. It is a famous place in Tokyo. Perhaps if you read the reading it will become more apparent what the meaning is (since they're the same). This silver seat place is Ginza.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Goods
Mnemonic: A product thing is any type of general goods. It's about as specific as you can get when you're talking about things like this.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You've seen those readings before, but the one for 品 (しな) is a little tricky, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: Think of the sheen (しな) that new goods have before you buy them. When you bring them home, that sheen is already gone. But then you go back to the store and, wow! All the goods you don't already own have that sheen! Gotta buy them!

Name: Graffiti
Mnemonic: When writing just happens to "fall" on the wall (whoops, wasn't me who did that, how strannnnge) it's writing that's not supposed to be where it is. This kind of writing is graffiti.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 書, however, is kun'yomi in this case and also has rendaku. So just remember that it's read as が for this vocab and you'll be fine.

Name: Grilled Chicken
Mnemonic: A nicely baked bird isn't just any bird, it's grilled chicken or roast chicken. You may also know it by its Japanese name: yakitori.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings. With 焼き, you can use the reading you learned with the kanji. With 鳥 just remember back to the vocab word, とり. Combine and eat.

Name: Grilled Meat
Mnemonic: Nicely baked meat is grilled meat or yakiniku. Mmm, yum! If you go to Japan look out for 焼肉 places (same meaning and reading). They're pretty tasty, if you're into meat at least.
ReadingMnemonic: 焼き uses the reading you learned with the kanji. 肉 does too. Put them on the grill and enjoy!

Name: Hand Baggage
Mnemonic: Remember 荷物 and how it means "baggage" or "luggage." Add a hand to it and you have hand baggage or hand luggage.
ReadingMnemonic: If you know 荷物 and you know 手, then you should be able to Voltron the two together into one mega reading.

Name: Happiness
Mnemonic: Happiness is happiness!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: If your life is filled with nothing but happiness, every time someone says something to you, all you can do is say, "Sigh, what (さいわ)?" You sigh and say what. Because you're too happy to really listen. You're just sighing all day and not paying attention.

Name: High Class
Mnemonic: When you are higher than equal, you are above the very top, you are above everyone. You are high class.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: How Many Flat Objects
Mnemonic: You have flat objects but what amount of flat objects? This word is asking that question: "how many flat objects are there?" If this doesn't make sense, think back to words like 何回 or 何年 which ask "how many ____" just like this one.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Indispensable
Mnemonic: It's not possible to lack. It is  indispensable and essential, so don't lack it!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Information
Mnemonic: The feeling of news is that it should give you information and data, not fluff.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Kansai Dialect
Mnemonic: Do you remember 関西, which is the Kansai region of Japan? Well, they have their own dialect, and it is Kansai Dialect.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the vocab 関西's reading and the kanji reading of 弁, combined.

Name: Kind
Mnemonic: The kind and type is the kind, type, or sort. Basically, if you know the meaning of either of these kanji you'll know the meaning of this word as well, since they all share nicely.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Kun'yomi
Mnemonic: The instruction reading may not make a lot of sense, but you've heard this word before. Jump to the reading and you'll know what the meaning of this word is.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the word 読み (like 読む) and the reading you learned for 訓 combined, making くんよみ. Sounds familiar? It's that kun'yomi reading you've heard so much about.

Name: Larynx
Mnemonic: The body part that lives between your throat and your head is your larynx. Otherwise known as the voice box, because your vocal cords live in there.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned 頭's on'yomi reading with 頭部, but here's a mnemonic in case you forgot: If you really want to get a larynx workout, go to とうきょう. It's loud, it's crowded, and you have to yell the entire time to get people to hear what you have to say. You also know 18 levels of kanji and you really want to shout them all out, which makes your voice box tired (but makes you happy).

Name: Lesson
Mnemonic: At least way back in the day, things that teach instructions to people are things that teach a lesson, moral, or teachings. Back in the day, lots of learning was done through storytelling, and storytelling taught lessons and morals, thus, this word.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Lullaby
Mnemonic: A song you sing to protect your child while they sleep is called a lullaby.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are all kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 守 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you finish singing a lullaby to your child they always ask for more (もり). It doesn't matter how many you sing, they always want at least one more before they will fall asleep.

Name: Mankind
Mnemonic: There's only one person type and that is mankind, otherwise known as humanity, or humankind.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Master
Mnemonic: A person who has "attained" is someone who knows much. They are a master or expert, obviously.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Monday
Mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The "moon" day of the week is monday. Why? Because "Moon" is pretty much just "Mon," right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

Name: News Report
Mnemonic: News travels down the road by way of a news report.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: No Smoking
Mnemonic: If smoke is prohibited you probably shouldn't smoke. Aka no smoking, okay?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Number Of Sheets
Mnemonic: You have flat objects. You have a number of them. These flat objects are flat things, right? Flat things like sheets of paper, perhaps (or other sheets of things). So, this word is number of sheets.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Osaka Dialect
Mnemonic: Remember 大阪 (Osaka)? This is the dialect they speak, making this word Osaka dialect.
ReadingMnemonic: If you know how to read 大阪 you can just add 弁 to it and be able to read the whole thing, though maybe not in Osaka dialect. Okay, fine, it's probably the same thing in Osaka dialect.

Name: Permission
Mnemonic: I permit that it is possible. So, go ahead, do it. I give you permission.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Pluralizing Suffix
Mnemonic: You'll see this attached to other words to make them plural. That's why it's called a pluralizing suffix.
ReadingMnemonic: This is almost the same reading you learned with the kanji. Remember たつ? Well this is read たち. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: If you want to pluralize something, touch (たち) it to something else. One friend touches another friend, well now they're friends. Plural friends! All thanks to the good ol' pluralizing suffix touch! Oh, and don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached in front of this word.

Name: Possible
Mnemonic: The ability is there, so it is possible... wait, there's enough ability to make this possible? Let's do it!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Postcard
Mnemonic: A writing that you put on a leaf is like something else. Instead of a leaf, think about writing you put on a leafish sized item. A postcard perhaps?
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is kind of weird, sorry. The reading for 葉 is the は you know and love. Then, 書 is かき despite not having a き on the end like you'd expect. So, it's weird. It's shortened like a postcard is a shortened letter, I suppose? Technically it is the 書き reading, but keep in mind that 書き gets rendaku'd.

Name: Quiet
Mnemonic: This is the な adjective form of quiet, which is kind of just like the noun, anyways. What is the adjective version of quiet? It's also quiet.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to be quiet. She's (しず) being nice and quiet, unlike you!

Name: Race Of People
Mnemonic: A kind or type of person is when you categorize a person into different types. How do we do that? Well, you categorize by race of people (or more simply by race).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Racing Heart
Mnemonic: Doc, Doc (ドキドキ), listen to my racing heart. I'm so excited, but I'm also a bit nervous.

Name: Refinement
Mnemonic: You take your practice and you wash it. Slowly chunks fall off and it becomes more and more simple. You are washing away the gunk on the outside to attain refinement and polish yourself, via practice.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Relatives
Mnemonic: These people are kind of like a type of parents. Not quite parents, but kind of, in a pinch anyways. These are your relatives.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Rented House
Mnemonic: When you borrow a house it's a rented house. This could also be a house for rent.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but in this case the second kanji can be read with either the on'yomi or kun'yomi. This uses a less common kun'yomi of 家, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you live in a rented house, someone has to give you the keys and let you in and stuff. You're only renting, after all. And when they let you in they'll say, "Here's a shack, yah (しゃくや) house renter! Enjoy!" By the way, in the secondary reading しゃっか, the しゃく changes to しゃっ. This reading is mostly used in legal contexts though, so しゃくや is more common.

Name: Report
Mnemonic: News that you announce becomes a report. When someone announces news on a topic, they are giving you a report on the information.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Rough Draft
Mnemonic: Something below your writing isn't what you want to necessarily publish to the world. It's below your writing, after all. This is merely a rough draft.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading, as you can maybe guess from the hiragana sticking out. If you know the readings of the words 下 and 書く separately, you should be able to combine them into one reading. Just don't forget the rendaku here!

Name: Safe
Mnemonic: The big height of your husband makes everything safe and all right. Nothing you need to worry about when you have your super giant husband around to protect you. This is a really useful word, and it is used all the time. If someone asks: "Are you alright?" you could say in response "大丈夫" to mean you're doing all right.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Saturday
Mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The earth day of the week is a day you find yourself close to the earth. Either you found you drank too much on Friday, so on this day's morning you're laying right on the ground of earth. Or, maybe you just want to sleep in after staying up late on Friday. Either way, this day you lay close to the earth is Saturday.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

Name: Seat
Mnemonic: A sit seat is probably going to be a seat.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Seiza
Mnemonic: The correct way to sit is this way: traditional Japanese sitting (this is when you sit on your legs and your feet, kneeling). You can also call it seiza. Learning the reading will help with the meaning.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Smoke
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're standing around a smoke machine. It's billowing up smoke. Strangely, your buddy Bill Murray is here too. For some reason, he loves the smoke, and he puts his head in it, breathing it in deeply until he goes into a coughing fit. You decide it's time to stop him. "Kay, Murray (けむり), it's time to stop that," you say.

Name: Smoking
Mnemonic: If you consume smoke you are smoking.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Steam Ship
Mnemonic: A steam ship is a steam ship or steam boat. So fancy back in their day!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Steam Train
Mnemonic: A steam car is a car that runs on steam. No regular car runs on steam, but what thing that has things called "cars" does run on steam? How about a steam train? You can also think about 電車s, which are electric cars (but means "train"). This is similar to that, but now it's run with steam, making it a steam train.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Still
Mnemonic: Everything is quiet and stopped. The world is still and everything is at rest.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Sugar Sculpture
Mnemonic: Candy made into a thin construction is a sugar sculpture or a candy sculpture. It's usually a sugar animal, but it can be anything, really.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for the first kanji and the on'yomi readings for the second two. You haven't learned this reading for 工 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want your sugar sculptures to be made into cookies (く)! Cookies are your other favorite snack, so having a cookie that's really just entirely made of sugar is the absolute best. Also, watch out for the rendaku on 細, it's easy to miss if you're focusing on remembering this new on'yomi reading.

Name: Sunburn
Mnemonic: When the sun burns something, and that something is you, it's giving you sunburn.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings here are the vocab kun'yomi readings. You have ひ for 日 and や for 焼け (which you learned with the vocab). Combine it with some sunscreen and hopefully you'll prevent the sunburn.

Name: Sunday
Mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The Sun day of the week is Sunday. Doesn't get much easier than that for you. Lucky!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

Name: Sunset
Mnemonic: When the evening is burning with sun, it is the sun going down, getting all close to the horizon and earth. This is the sunset, or more specifically, the evening glow you can see during a sunset.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. Combine 夕 and 焼け (you learned the reading via the kanji) and you'll have ゆうやけ.

Name: Taboo Word
Mnemonic: A paragraph that is under prohibition is under prohibition because it contains a taboo word or taboo phrase. Do not say this word, please!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Temple
Mnemonic: An monk’s institution is going to be a monastery or temple. What a nice place to live, I'm sure!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Throat
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji (and is a body part) it uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Remember the mnemonic from when you first learned this kanji? Well こういち is still in your throat and he doesn't want to get out. In fact, every time you tug on him, he shouts, "No Do- (のど)" but you gag and can't hear the rest. People around you think you're saying "No Do-" but it's really just the weirdo living in your throat now. What a pain...

Name: Thursday
Mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The tree day of the week is Thursday. Tree day comes after water day (which is Wednesday, for Water-Wednesday!). Trees need water to grow, which is why the tree comes right after the water.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

Name: To Announce
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means announce so the verb vocab version is to announce.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'd like to announce... we're not having one baby, we're having two (つ) babies!

Name: To Attain
Mnemonic: You know that 達 means attain. So, when you add する to it you make it a verb. Now it means to attain.
ReadingMnemonic: This reading for this is a bit of an exception. You know the reading for 達 is たつ, but here it's shortened, to just たっ. So make sure you remember.

Name: To Bake
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bake or burn. So, the verb vocab version is to bake, to burn something, or even to grill.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Be Connected
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this is a verb. The kanji itself means connect, which makes this to be connected to. In other situations, this can also mean to be tied together, or to lead to.
ReadingMnemonic: You already learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go!

Name: To Be Involved
