Mnemonic: You know that the kanji means related. As a verb, this often means to be involved, to be related, and to be connected. Basically, things that have to do with being related to something else.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Ever heard of the "Kaw Kaw (かか) Crow Gang"? They are bad news, always eating from garbage and squawking "kaw kaw" ... You don't want to be involved with them.

Name: To Borrow
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means borrow so the verb vocab version is to borrow.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Dude, can I borrow your car (か)? Please?

Name: To Bully
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means frustration. What do frustrated people do? They tend to bully, to pick on, to tease, and to torment other people.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Close
Mnemonic: If 閉める is "to close something" or "to shut something," then this is going to be the version where you don't do anything and something closes on its own. That's why this is to close or to shut. You remember this because the door keeps shutting on your hand, marring (まる) it over and over again. Ouch.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 閉める.

Name: To Deliver
Mnemonic: You distribute the goods, they attain the goods. You are going to deliver to everyone.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Forget
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means forget so the verb vocab version is to forget.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You don't want to forget anything, because forgetting always makes everything worse (わす). Forgot your car keys? Now you can't drive. Forgot someone's name? Now you have to ask again and it'll be awkward. All these situations make your day worse, and probably your life worse too.

Name: To Get Better
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out: When you get sick, your mom calls every day to ask, "Are you better now (なお)?" How about NOW!? How about NOW!? Jeez Mom, just let me rest!

Name: To Harden
Mnemonic: You've seen how 固める means "to make hard." This word means that something hardened by itself, it means to harden or to solidify.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: To Permit
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means permit so the verb vocab version is to permit. It also means to forgive, in that "I'll permit it this time... but only this time." Look out for 許さない in TV shows, too. It means "I won't permit this!" or "I won't forgive you!"
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going to allow it. You're (ゆる) allowed to do it this one time, okay?

Name: To Prohibit
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means prohibition so the verb version means to prohibit or to forbid.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: To Report On
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means news report so you could try to say "to news report" but that doesn't make sense. What does make sense is "to report on," however.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading doesn't seem like it's the kanji's on'yomi reading, but it is. What an oddity! Do you think it's worth doing a news report on it? Koichi, reporting in on this strange reading that is readable by you right now. Signing off.

Name: To Rewrite
Mnemonic: If you take your writing and fix it, you are taking your writing and rewriting it. This word means to rewrite, because the fixing is really heavy, so regular revisions won't do.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 書く and 直す. Know those and you'll know how to read this word too!

Name: To Sit
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sit so the verb vocab version is to sit.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is unlike the kanji reading, so let's use a separate mnemonic to remember this. Just imagine yourself going to sit down. You sit down, and the ground collapses below you and you fall. When you land, you find yourself in a nasty, stinking sewer (すわ). It is so gross. Taste the sewage in your mouth. Smell it. Feel gross. You shouldn't have sat down on that spot, it was looking awfully dangerous, now that you think about it.

Name: To Strike
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tap or strike, and the verb version is to strike, to tap, to hit, to knock, or to beat.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you already know this reading from when you learned the kanji!

Name: To Wash
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wash so the verb vocab version is to wash.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to wash a rock (あら) you found. It looks shiny, but you can't tell until you wash it.

Name: To Write In
Mnemonic: To insert what you write into something is to write in or to fill in.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 書く and 入れる. Combine those two words to get the reading of this word.

Name: Training
Mnemonic: You've got your instruction and you have your practice. Time to start your training, or simply your practice.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Train Station Bento
Mnemonic: Remember how 弁当 is "bento"? Well, the 弁 in this word comes from that, so pretend it means "bento." Then, when you have a train station to go along with the bento, you have a train station bento. As you might think, a train station bento is just a bento that's sold at a train station. Easy!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Transmission
Mnemonic: When you transmit something and you attain it on the other end, you've done a transmission.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Tuesday
Mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The fire day of the week is the day after the worst day of the week (monday). You set fire to everything because you're so pissed off about yesterday, which makes today Tuesday.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

Name: Warning
Mnemonic: When you announce something to warn somebody, you're warning them. Sometimes you're just trying to give them some helpful advice.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Way To Write
Mnemonic: This is the way of writing (kind of like how 見方 is the way of seeing). So this means way to write or how to write. How's your 書き方 for kanji? Mine is terrible.
ReadingMnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 書く and 方. So as long as you're okay with those, you can apply that knowledge over here.

Name: Wednesday
Mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The water day of the week is where the water flows from. Think of your entire week as a big hill, with Wednesday (hump day) being in the middle. This hump is a hill. What originates from hills? Water! That's why Water day is Wednesday.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

Name: Year End Party
Mnemonic: Time to get together and forget the year... what a terrible year, good thing a new one is coming. This get together is a year end party.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Zen Meditation
Mnemonic: When you sit and do zen you are probably doing zen meditation. Hummmmm.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Zen Priest
Mnemonic: A Zen priest is a zen priest.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Zen Temple
Mnemonic: A zen temple is just what it sounds like, a zen temple. Sounds nice.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the two words 禅 and 寺 put together. The てら gets changed to でら, though. In terms of when it's pronounced ぜんじ, if you put this word onto the end of the name of a 禅寺 the pronunciation changes to ぜんじ. It makes sense - it's more like a jukugo word that way (not that the original isn't, but you can see the separation of words coming together which gives the hint that it's a kun'yomi combo reading). Anyways, you may need a zen temple to keep your mind pure enough to remember this, but it's a good thing to keep in mind if you can.

Name: Academic History
Mnemonic: A continuation of studying is the time that passes that we study. This is academic history, so pay close attention!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Adjective
Mnemonic: A part of speech that creates the shape and form of a word is something that is descriptive (its shape and form are in there, after all!). This shape and form part of speech is an adjective. You are so beautiful!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Aiueo Order
Mnemonic: This is a little confusing for someone who didn't grow up with the Japanese language. You have fifty sounds. Then, they're in a certain order. So, these fifty sounds are the Japanese syllabary. That's hiragana / katakana, probably from back in the day when there were more sounds than there are now. So, the "fifty sounds in order" makes up aiueo order, where the "aiueo" is あいうえお representing the five columns.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: As Expected
Mnemonic: A stream containing stones is like… the most natural thing ever. It's just as expected.
ReadingMnemonic: Unfortunately, the reading for this is a total exception that you'll just have to memorize, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Just as expected, I saw Suga (さすが) at the bar again last night… Mr. Suga spends a little too much time at the bar, and we're starting to get worried for him. 流石に Mr. Suga…

Name: Aversion To Hot Foods
Mnemonic: A cat's tongue is for some reason associated with an aversion to hot foods. I guess I haven't seen a cat drinking up boiling milk, but whatever. Just imagine a cat licking up something super hot and freaking out. Cats don't like hot things, which is why this is an aversion to hot foods.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the two vocab words separately put together, just as you'd expect from a body-part related kanji. So, 猫 plus 舌 = ねこじた. Just remember that 舌 is read here as じた, and not した.

Name: Baked Sweet Potato
Mnemonic: Baked potato is actually baked sweet potato (or roasted sweet potato). Although it's literally just potato, most Japanese speakers will automatically think of sweet potato when they hear this word. Yum! 🍠
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the readings from 焼く and 芋 put together.

Name: Believer
Mnemonic: A junior believer is a believer or follower. They certainly aren't the leader or anything because of their junior status, but at least they're there, and at least they're believing. Oh, and excuse me, may I take a moment of your time? I'd like to tell you about the glory that is the Crabigator....
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Benefit
Mnemonic: When you are able to acquire whatever you want, you start to see the benefits of everything around you and begin to profit from them. Aren't you so amazing?
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this is the same as with the kanji you learned. とく!

Name: Blanket
Mnemonic: A fur cloth isn't something you'd just throw away. You'd probably turn this warm fur cloth into a nice blanket.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Book Counter
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as well. It's probably treated like on'yomi jukugo because it's attached to things (like numbers!).

Name: Buddhist
Mnemonic: You know 仏教 means “Buddhism” so a follower of Buddhism is a Buddhist.
ReadingMnemonic: Add the on’yomi reading for 徒 to the word you already know. Done!

Name: Busy
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with しい on the end, meaning it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of busy? It's also busy.
ReadingMnemonic: You're busy because you have to take care of your friend's ice ogres (いそが) this weekend. You don't know why you agreed to this, you were busy enough, but now you'll never get anything done running around taking care of these little ice ogres.

Name: Busy
Mnemonic: If you've had many busy days, then you're even more busy than you thought!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chronological Order
Mnemonic: You put years in order of the period they come in and you're really putting them in chronological order.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Cloth
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You take your cloth and put it on top of your head. It's there because right at noon (ぬの) the sun is in the middle of the sky and burns your scalp. So, you cover it with a cloth. Imagine yourself setting an alarm for noon to help you to focus on the noon part.

Name: Confusion
Mnemonic: There's a riot and everything's getting all mixed up! Within that, there is of course a ton of confusion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Contents
Mnemonic: Inside that form... there is something inside there. What are the contents?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Decreasing Order
Mnemonic: When the order is from big (to small), you are talking about decreasing order. That's largest first.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the word 大きい plus 順's reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: Detailed
Mnemonic: This is an adjective utilizing the second meaning of 細, detailed. So, this just means detailed or fine!
ReadingMnemonic: This word has a different reading from the ones you've learned so far, so here's a mnemonic to help you: After the coyote wrecks your model railroad, he bites you on the head, sending you into an indefinite coma (こま).

Name: Drama Troupe
Mnemonic: A drama group is a drama troupe or theatrical company.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Drinking Alcohol
Mnemonic: Drink alcohol is drinking alcohol, or just drinking. This always refers to alcohol though.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading of 飲 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Where's a good place for drinking alcohol? An inn (いん), of course!

Name: Ease
Mnemonic: The form in front of you is easy. Whatever it is, you'll be able to do it with ease.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Easy
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of easy? It's also easy.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Everything is so easy for you to do. Why? Because you don't do anything yourself. You ask others. You say things like "Hey, can you get me some water?" They say "yassah!" (やさ) very enthusiastically.

Name: Eight Books
Mnemonic: When you have eight books you have eight books. This is an example of how to count books, so if you have eight of them this is what you'd say.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はち part gets shortened as it often does when put into situations like this, making it はっ. The 冊 is all normal, and to the "book(s)." Har!

Name: Emergency Exit
Mnemonic: You know how 非常 means emergency and how 口 can be some kind of doorway (like in 入り口, for example)? Well, if that's the case, then you have an emergency doorway. Usually you run away from emergencies, though, making this an emergency exit.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the words 非常 and 口 combined together. The thing that makes this weird is that it's a mix of the kun and on'yomi readings. I guess things get all jostled up when you have yourself an emergency.

Name: Enrollment
Mnemonic: If you enter a group, it's called enrollment or enlistment. You're joining the group.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Every Day
Mnemonic: What happens when you take along a day? It becomes every day.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Flute
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Pretend you're trying to whistle, but you can't. All that comes out is air. You make a "Fuuuuuuueh" sound over and over, because you can't get the whole whistling thing down. Go ahead and pretend to do that (or do it for real).

Name: Forked Tongue
Mnemonic: You have two flat objects that make up your tongue. What kind of tongue is made up of two of anything? That's a tongue that's split, that's a forked tongue.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. That's the case for the first two kanji, but 舌 actually uses the kun'yomi. Not only that, it's read here as じた, and not した.

Name: Futon
Mnemonic: Put some cloth in a group and you get a futon. It’s just the kind of nice, soft bedding or sleeping mat you’d like to curl up on.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 団 is the secondary reading that went with the kanji, though, so watch out for that. If you can figure out the meaning of this word, chances are you already know how to spell it, so carry that over to Japanese.

Name: Good And Evil
Mnemonic: You have morally good and bad. This is the battle between good and evil.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Good At
Mnemonic: When you're able to acquire ideas at a fast rate, you must be familiar with whatever it is you're doing. If you acquire ideas in this way, there's a good chance you're good at or skilled at this action.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Grammar Particle
Mnemonic: A part of speech that's just meant to help your grammar out are the little things. They tie grammar and words together, and that's about it. These are grammar particles or just plain old particles.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Group
Mnemonic: A group that has collected together is a bunch of people. It is a group or crowd.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: History
Mnemonic: The continuation of history is history itself. This is the main word for "history" and you'll see it a lot if you're in school or something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Improvement
Mnemonic: When you renew something and it ends up morally good it's definitely an improvement.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Increasing Order
Mnemonic: When something goes from small and goes in order it's in increasing order, or smallest first.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the word 小さい plus the reading for 順.

Name: Insect
Mnemonic: An insect insect is... you guessed it! An insect.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi of the kanji. You learned this reading for 昆 when you learned the kanji, but you haven't learned the on'yomi for 虫 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Did you know that insects are Chewbacca's (ちゅう) favorite thing? He's fascinated by all types of insects, and keeps them in boxes as pets. There are a good few of them crawling around in his fur, too.

Name: Intransitive Verb
Mnemonic: Remember how 動詞 means "verb"? When the verb's action happens by itself or to the subject itself, it's an intransitive verb.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Irresponsible
Mnemonic: You add and you subtract. This brings you back to zero. There was absolutely no point in doing those actions. Completely pointless. In fact, I'd say that was downright irresponsible of you. The extra いい is there to mean "good," as in "good, you've figured out how pointless that was, now stop."
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Job Posting
Mnemonic: When you're requesting people, you put up a job posting because you’re seeking workers.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: As you're looking at job postings, you notice they're all looking for people with cucumbers and jeans (きゅうじん). That's the only qualification they're after, cucumbers and jeans.

Name: Joy
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji rejoice, so it means joy and delight. You rejoice because there are lots of reasons for your glee.
ReadingMnemonic: You already learned this reading when you learned 喜ぶ so you should be able to read this one too!

Name: Konbu
Mnemonic: Insect cloth is actually konbu. Konbu seaweed is very common in Japan, and it's delicious. And insects happen to love using it as cloth, too. They make all their clothes out of konbu.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 布 part gets changed to ぶ, probably because if a food doesn't have konbu you say boo (ぶ).

Name: Lover
Mnemonic: A person of romance is someone you do romancey things with. That person is your lover.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a bit strange. it's the two separate words 恋 and 人 put together, making the reading こいびと. Oooh lala. Two words coming together like two people coming together. Rawrs.

Name: Melee
Mnemonic: A riot of war is where things go nuts. This is a melee!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Midair
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Mixed Race
Mnemonic: If you have mixed blood, some people might say you're of mixed race. Own it!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Noun
Mnemonic: A name part of speech is when you are naming something. What part of speech has names in it? That would be the noun.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Nuclear Power
Mnemonic: The power of the atom (原子) is nuclear power.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Numeral
Mnemonic: A number part of speech is a numeral or number word.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: One After Another
Mnemonic: When you continue and then you continue again (that's the repeater kanji), you get things happening one after another. Continue continue continue!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: One Book
Mnemonic: When you have one books you really just have one book.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 一 portion gets shortened to いっ as it often is.

Name: One Small Animal
Mnemonic: One small animal is one small animal. Use this to count small animals like cats and dogs.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening and the rendaku.

Name: Order
Mnemonic: When you go in order of turns that's the order. It also represents one's turn in said order as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Outer Space
Mnemonic: The midair of outer space is the space that's in outer space which is outer space, space, and the universe!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Participation
Mnemonic: When you participate, adding yourself to the activity, that is participation. Well done, you earn a gold star for participating!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Part Of Speech
Mnemonic: A product of part of speech is more part of speech. Evil begets evil, so to speak.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Personal History
Mnemonic: Think about all the important places your footwear has touched, one place to the next in continuation, and write it all down. What you'd get is a personal history or a resume. I guess you can think of it as a history of the schools and jobs you've left your footprints at.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Persuasion
Mnemonic: You acquire theory after theory. In doing this, you have a lot of theories in your head. You use all these theories as tools for persuasion. These theories will allow you to convince anyone of anything.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 説 gets shortened to せっ.

Name: Pickled Plums
Mnemonic: You know 梅 is a Japanese plum, and 干す means "to dry something." So when you combine them as 梅干し, you get dried plums, right? Well, sort of. You have to pickle them before you dry them, so we can say 梅干し means pickled plum or pickled ume. And if you know the Japanese name, you can call it by that too: umeboshi.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this one, like the meaning, is kind of tricky. It uses two kun'yomi readings that you've learned before. So you have うめ plus ほし, which comes from 干す but gets rendaku'd to ぼし here. In other words, うめぼし. I guess the pickling process has mangled the reading of this word. But you'll just have to deal with it, because this food is as common as it is tasty! Also, you might often see this written as 梅干, where the し gets shy or something and hides, but the reading stays the same: うめぼし.

Name: Plutocrats
Mnemonic: A wealth clan is a group of people who do whatever they can to get their money. These are the plutocrats of the world, but you can also call them a financial clique.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Police Officer
Mnemonic: You know how 警察 is "police"? Well, this is kind of like that. This time you have someone from the government trying to warn you about the bad things you do. This person, like 警察 is a police officer. It's kind of informal, so you might also say this means cop.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Police Station
Mnemonic: A government office for police (警察) is a police station, because that's where they hang out, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Potato
Mnemonic: A じゃが potato is a potato. More specifically, a white potato.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Potato
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Private Funds
Mnemonic: Private wealth are private funds or your own funds.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Ranking
Mnemonic: The order that you are ranked in is your ranking or standing amongst others on a list. Beat that high score, Ryu!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Really
Mnemonic: So this doesn't really make much sense in terms of the kanji and word, but it is what it is. Let's remember it this way:
ReadingMnemonic: To remember the reading, just imagine yourself snorting out a sharp "HA!" (は) right before saying the phrase: "HA! Just as I thought."

Name: Relation
Mnemonic: If you take along some things that are related, you'll be able to understand their relation better.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Revision
Mnemonic: Renew and make something correct. When you do this, you are doing a revision, amendment or alteration. Ah, much better now.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Run Wild
Mnemonic: Violent running... sounds like a marathon gone wrong. No, this is when you run around and you're all violent. A better way to describe this would be to say "run wild" or "run out of control."
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Sad
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with しい on the end, so you know it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of sad? It's sad, sadly.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading with 悲しむ, hooray!

Name: Sadness
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji sad, so it means sadness.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading with 悲しむ, hooray!

Name: Season
Mnemonic: The seasons season is the season. Who likes winter? It's my favorite 季節.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Seasonal Festival
Mnemonic: Think of what a paragraph of a season would be. It's a small part of the season, but it's worth writing about. That's a seasonal festival. These are fun!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that せつ gets shortened to せっ just like many つs do in this situation.

Name: Seating Order
Mnemonic: The order of seats is the seating order. Everyone go sit in your proper positions, please.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Separate Volume
Mnemonic: Usually you call books "volumes" when they come in sets, right? This is like that, but separate, making this a separate volume.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The べつ gets shortened to べっ, though, probably because it's a つ and that's what つs do for a living in jukugo words.

Name: Serial
Mnemonic: If you take along and continue something, you are creating a serial version of it. Come along now. Okay, continue! Come along now. Okay, continue! This is how Lord of the Rings was made, probably. Come along now.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Song Lyrics
Mnemonic: A song's part of speech is the part of the song where you're talking (aka singing). These are the word parts of the song. These are the song lyrics. Anyone ready for some カラオケ?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Steam Whistle
Mnemonic: A steam flute is a flute that goes off using steam. The only time I can think of this happening is via a steam whistle. Choo choooo!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Student
Mnemonic: One who is junior in life is a student or pupil. It's kind of like how a 先生 is someone who came previous to you in life. Cool how that works, right? Okay 生徒, get back to work!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Subtraction
Mnemonic: What's a method to decrease something? Well, you take something away. You do subtraction.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the ほう changes to ぽう. This is because you're trying to subtract Polar (ぽう) bears from the area around you as they're very dangerous and you use a cologne made from meat.

Name: Suspicion
Mnemonic: You have the appearance of doubt about you. That's because you're under suspicion. There's a charge against you. Oh no!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Takeout
Mnemonic: When you're holding food and returning home with it, you're likely getting takeout.
ReadingMnemonic: You've already learned how to read both 持つ and 帰る, so you should be able to read this as well.

Name: The Gang
Mnemonic: People you want to take along to the middle of somewhere are probably people you know pretty well. They're your gang, they're the guys.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

Name: Three Books
Mnemonic: Three books equals three books.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Acquire
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means acquire so the verb vocab version is to acquire.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to acquire an elephant (え) for your elephant collection. If you don't acquire an elephant, you'll look like an idiot in front of your elephant collecting friends.

Name: To Act Violently
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means violence. "To violence" doesn't sound great, so instead this word is to act violently or to rage.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're about to rage all over the place. You're going nuts. You're going to act violently. Then, a calm wizard steps in front of you and mutters "abara kadabara," (あば) causing you to calm down immediately.

Name: To Add
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to add something and then to add something else, and you end up with quite a quantity (くわ) of things. Just keep adding and adding forever. What a huge QUANTITY you now have!

Name: To Be Disconnected
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: That rail has はず to be fixed, otherwise it's going to come off again, someone's going to get hurt.

Name: To Be In Disorder
Mnemonic: The kanji means riot, but this verb version word doesn't really mean "to riot." It's more like to be in disorder. But if you think about it, when things are rioting and crazy, they definitely are in disorder, so you can think of it that way. You can differentiate this from the future word 乱す because with れる you know it is rare for it to be like this. You aren't doing it, but it just happens on occasion (rarely) so you take advantage of it.
ReadingMnemonic: When everything is in disorder it's finally your chance! You run to the bar, break the windows, and grab all the mead (みだ) you can carry.

Name: To Be Involved With
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means entangle, but this verb version is usually used in a figurative sense, so it means to be involved with, as in 事件に絡む (to be involved with an incident).
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: There's an accident you happen to be involved with in からて class, where it's common to get tangled up during sparring. This time you and your partner's limbs are literally in a big entangled mess. Good luck getting out of that.

Name: To Be Piled Up
Mnemonic: If you remember 重ねる, then you'll recognize this as the intransitive version of that verb. Literally, this means to be piled up, but it's often used to mean to coincide, to overlap or to accumulate.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with 重ねる, but in case it's slipped your mind, here's a mnemonic to help you remember: All these boxes that are piled up are here because you've just moved into your new casa (かさ). Congratulations! Now it's time to unpack every single box you've accumulated. Have fun.

Name: To Bury
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bury so the verb vocab version is to bury as well.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading with the kanji, how nice for you! However, you might notice that in addition to うめる, there's another reading too: うずめる. うめる is used for the act of burying something or filling in a hole, while うずめる is used when describing the covering or concealment of something, or when burying one's face in something (like a fluffy cat!)

Name: To Change Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Usually when we want to change something, we want to make it 新た (あらた), right? Out with the old, in with the 新た, as they say.

Name: To Contact
Mnemonic: You take along a message and entangle it into the telephone. From there it buzzes off to the person in order for you to contact them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Continue
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means continue so the verb vocab version is to continue. Please continue.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Two dudes (つづ) get to continue on. I'm afraid you two ladies are going to have to stay here. This is a dudes only night club.

Name: To Decrease
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decrease so the verb vocab version is to decrease or to be decreased.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your status is to be decreased amongst the eyes of the Gods. They decide your punishment is to be decreased into hell (へる) where you will live the rest of your days.

Name: To Memorize
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means memorize so the verb version is to memorize. That shouldn't be too hard to remember, right?
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use one of the kun'yomi readings. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The best way to memorize and to remember something is to make up a song and play it on your oboe (おぼ). Something about playing it makes it so you can memorize anything. You're so talented.

Name: To Mix Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mix so the verb vocab version is to mix something, to stir something, or to blend something. This is when you're doing the mixing. You can remember this because "there (ぜる) is much mixing to be done so it's best if you just do it because nobody else will."
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're doing mixing like your ma (ま) taught you, which is why when you do the mixing things get done around here a lot faster. You can also use the level 5 vocab 交ぜる to help you remember as it has the same meaning and reading!

Name: Tongue
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Uses the same reading that you learned with the kanji. Go ahead and use your tongue and say the reading out loud... "した."

Name: To Pass Through
Mnemonic: You have pass through, so this is to pass through.
ReadingMnemonic: Like other verbs that end in じる, this actually uses the on'yomi of the kanji, not kun'yomi! You learned that reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go here.

Name: To Put On Shoes
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means footwear. And what do you do with footwear, usually? You put it on! That's why this word is to put on shoes or to put on pants or to put on a skirt.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to put on shoes, and then to put on pants. "Hahahaha!" (は) you laugh. What a ridiculous idea to put on shoes before you put on pants! But you do it every morning, and every morning it makes you laugh. You really crack yourself up.

Name: To Take Along
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means take along so the verb vocab version is  to take along.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What are you going to take along? Whoa. That much? Why in the world do you have two (つ) of everything?

Name: Total Failure
Mnemonic: You know how 失敗 is a mistake? Well, a large mistake is going to be a total failure or a huge mistake. So terrible!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 失敗 on its own as well.

Name: Unconsciousness
Mnemonic: Know how 意識 is "consciousness"? What about when this consciousness doesn't exist (aka it is nothing)? That's when it becomes unconsciousness.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know how to read 意識, though.

Name: Verb
Mnemonic: A part of speech that represents moving is a part of speech that describes actions. That is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Very
Mnemonic: When something is moving towards emergency (非常), it is something that is very, extremely bad. Like, exceedingly so. It's nuts.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes straight from the word 非常, which you hopefully know okay by now!

Name: Violence
Mnemonic: The power of violence is more violence, and it is a force to be reckoned with.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Violent
Mnemonic: Riot and violence. That sounds terrible! That sounds like a place full of violence, because rioting is violent and violence is violent too!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Wakame
Mnemonic: A young cloth for some reason is the seaweed wakame. If you've never heard of wakame before, go look it up. It's delicious and really good for you. Seaweed is kind of like cloth in the sea, right? Well, this young cloth is nice and soft and thin, like wakame. I imagine young people are soft and thin too, which is why the young cloth gets to be wakame.
ReadingMnemonic: 若い uses the same reading you learned with the kanji, but the reading for 布 is totally irregular. If you can figure out the meaning, you can use that to remember the reading (since they're the same), but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case: You're eating wakame and you suddenly spot a 目 (め) looking up at you. You didn't know seaweed had eyes!

Name: Wallet
Mnemonic: Your wealth cloth is your wallet. Really, a wallet is just a piece of cloth you keep in your pocket that has your wealth in it, right? This can also be your purse, especially if you live in the ol' UK.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: World
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: Since you have generations of people making up this world, think of the rapper generation. What do they say all the time (obviously I don't know anything about rap)? They say "Yo yo yo!" (よ).

Name: Written Explanation
Mnemonic: An explanation (説明) in writing is a written explanation. I guess sometimes you don't want to do your explanations in person, huh?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Year Before Last
Mnemonic: Remember how 一昨日 means "day before last"? Similarly, one year previous to that year is the year before last.
ReadingMnemonic: The last time you tossed something into a trash can was the year before last. Why? Because you got a trash can with an auto  tossing (おととし) feature. What amazing technology!

Name: Young
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of young? It's young.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Oh how nice it is to be young and to be able to remember that.

Name: Young Person
Mnemonic: A young someone is a young person.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this one is a pain. 若 is the same as what you learned with the kanji (わか), but 者 is もの, which isn't what you learned. Think of this: A young person does what they want. They don't follow tradition or do anything the way you'd want them to, just like the reading of this word. Also, their actions make you really want to moan (もの) because ugh, young people. Get off my lawn.

Name: Youthful
Mnemonic: A young young thing has youthfulness on their side. Oh to be youthful and young looking again!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. Same goes for the repeater kanji.

Name: Accomplice
Mnemonic: Someone who does crime together with you is your accomplice in crime. It's best to "take care of" these before the coppers get to them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Accurate
Mnemonic: It is correct and you're certain of it. When you've done this much checking and you're this sure, your measurements must be very accurate and precise.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Aftershock
Mnemonic: A surplus (that's an extra!) earthquake is a quake that  comes after the main (non-surplus) quake. That's an aftershock.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Airplane
Mnemonic: The fly and go machine is some machine you get into that flies and goes places. It's an airplane.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Answering Machine
Mnemonic: You hopefully know that this has something to do with housesitting (留守番). So, a telephone (電話) that does housesitting for you is what? It's your answering machine, or voicemail.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Anthropology
Mnemonic: The study of mankind (人類) is known as anthropology.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Argument
Mnemonic: There is much deliberation and theory exchanging when you are trying to present an argument. Of course, it's a very nice one. Lots of thinking and stuff, you know? That's why there's deliberation and theories instead of just screaming. That kind of "argument."
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Bankruptcy
Mnemonic: If someone overthrows your property, it'll end in bankruptcy. Without property you're sure to go bankrupt, unfortunately.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Blood Pressure
Mnemonic: Check the pressure of your blood. It's your blood pressure.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Borrower
Mnemonic: Remember how 手 can mean "doer" in some words? So here, you have borrow doer, or more simply borrower.
ReadingMnemonic: You'll want to know the words 借りる and 手 to be able to read this one. Combine them to know the reading.

Name: Bow And Arrow
Mnemonic: A bow and an arrow. Put them together and you have a bow and arrow.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the vocab readings, 弓 and 矢, put together. This is probably because this word is like two separate words put together, thus the "and" in the middle of the English translation.

Name: Butt
Mnemonic: The お is just there to be nice to your butt. This word simply means butt (or any other word for it, like buttocks or bottom).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Certainly
Mnemonic: This is an adverb, but it has the same meaning (basically) as the kanji. It means certainly, and it can also mean surely.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this one is certainly weird. To remember the reading for this word, just think how you're certain that if you stash the treasure, nobody will find it here.

Name: Chairman
Mnemonic: The person in charge of long discussions is the chairman, or the speaker. They also say who gets to talk and for how long.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Conference Room
Mnemonic: A room where you meet for discussions is known as a conference room.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Conger Eel
Mnemonic: A hole child isn't some kind of creepy hole child (not sure how else to describe it). It's a conger eel, a type of tasty eel eaten in Japan. It might be easier to learn the reading first, though, and use that, because the second meaning option is anago, the Japanese word for it (also used in English).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the two kun'yomi vocab readings combined. So, 穴 and 子 to combine make あなご. Just watch out for rendaku, which changes the reading of 子 from こ to ご.

Name: Cough Drop
Mnemonic: Throat candy is the kind of candy that should make your throat feel better. That's right, it's a cough drop or a throat lozenge. Don't just eat regular candy when your throat hurts! Use the right kind.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!

Name: Crazy About
Mnemonic: Even in the middle of your dream you're thinking about your body pillows. You're crazy about them, wrapped in absorption.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Crime
Mnemonic: You have crime and you have guilt. Sounds like you did the crime.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Crisis
Mnemonic: A dangerous machine is walking through your town, destroying everything. This is a huge crisis!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Criticism
Mnemonic: A difficult injustice to take from someone is a criticism. Ugh, what a pain to be criticized! So difficult, and besides, it's an injustice, because I'm perfect!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Culprit
Mnemonic: A crime  person is a culprit, or a criminal.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Damage
Mnemonic: Incuring damage creates damage,  harm and injury.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Diet
Mnemonic: The place you meet for deliberation in Japan is called the Diet. It's their version of congress.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Difficult
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of difficult? It's also difficult.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: It's awfully difficult to load a cow into your Moo-zooka (むずか). Click. Boom!

Name: Disaster
Mnemonic: This is the noun form of disaster, so it means disaster or misfortune.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about how, the last time disaster struck, it was a while (わざわ) before things got back to normal. Be careful of the い on the end, it can be tricky and make you think it's an adjective when it's a noun.

Name: Disgust
Mnemonic: You dislike someone so badly that it turns to disgust and hate.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 悪 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you feel disgust for someone all you can manage to say when you see them is, "Oh... (お), it's you." Feel the anger when you see their face, "Oh, you again. Bleh."

Name: Dishwashing
Mnemonic: You know the word 皿 (plate) and the word 洗う (to wash), right? You can probably guess dish washing is happening here, but this is a noun, so it's the idea of dishwashing, AKA doing dishes, or washing dishes.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the individual vocab words (you can tell because there's a bit of hiragana stuck on there). It's the reading for 皿 and 洗う combined.

Name: Dislike
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. The vocab has the added meanings of eww, gross, and even reluctant.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is pretty weird. It's different than the 嫌い word you will see in this level too. It is いや, so when you think of something you dislike, just think "iyah (いや), I dislike it." Also, think about that eww feeling it gives you when you think of the thing you dislike most.

Name: Dislike
Mnemonic: You know that 嫌 means dislike and this vocab word means the same thing: dislike or hate!
ReadingMnemonic: Of all the things out there to dislike the thing I dislike the most is the killer (きら) of people. People should never kill people.

Name: Do Not Enter
Mnemonic: Standing and entering are both 禁止 (prohibited). If you see this sign, it's essentially saying do not enter or no entry.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 立入 is a bit strange, but it might help you to know that it can also be written 立ち入り. The 立ち is the same one you learned with 立ち飲み and the 入り is the reading you learned with 入り口. In our version of the word, the hiragana isn't visible (it's sort of pushed into the kanji), but the word is still pronounced the same way: たちいり. And 禁止 doesn't have any weirdness going on, so at least you have that!

Name: Dream
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're having this crazy dream. The dream allows you to do anything you want. Every time you ask "hey, can I do this?" The answer is always "you may" (ゆめ). Think of some things you'd want to do if you could do anything. Ask permission and get this answer in your imagination.

Name: Earthquake
Mnemonic: An earth earthquake is just another way to say earthquake.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Notice that 地 is read as じ instead of ち. You've seen this happen a few times before, so just try to remember that this is the case here.

Name: Earthquake Disaster
Mnemonic: An earthquake disaster is just that, an earthquake disaster. These are no good.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Earthquake Intensity
Mnemonic: The earthquake degrees is how you measure an earthquake. The 震度 is the earthquake intensity, AKA earthquake magnitude, seismic intensity, or seismic scale.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Electronic Device
Mnemonic: You have an electronic (電子) container machine. This is just a machine that contains electricity and electric parts. So basically, an electronic device, or more generally, electronic equipment or electronics.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: End Of A Line
Mnemonic: You have 最, which means most, and 後尾, which means something like "back" or "rear" (behind + tail). When you're at the most back part of something, you might find yourself at the end of a line or end of a queue.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Be careful, because this is 最 + 後尾, and not 最後 + 尾, meaning that 後 is read こう, not ご! You learned the こう reading with the kanji, but this might be your first time seeing it in a word, so here's a mnemonic to help you out: Who's always waiting at the end of a line? It's こういち. The dude is always the last one to get to places, and he lines up after literally everybody else, which is why he's at the end of the queue. In middle school the bullies called him "End of the Queue こういち." Poor guy.

Name: Existence
Mnemonic: I exist, I suppose... this is the kind of existence I have. I'm not really sure either way, and I don't care. Existence is futile, I suppose.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Experience
Mnemonic: Through various tests over the passage of time, you have gained much experience. Time and testing is all it takes.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Fire Disaster
Mnemonic: A fire disaster is a fire disaster, or a conflagration.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Flood Damage
Mnemonic: Water damage is so bad they call it water damage. Doesn't get any clearer than this.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Forgotten Item
Mnemonic: Remember how 忘れる is "to forget"? Well, a thing you've forgotten is a forgotten item.
ReadingMnemonic: You didn't learn this reading with the kanji 忘, but you did learn it with the vocabulary 忘れる. What was that reading again? You can't remember! It's become a forgotten item in some dusty corner of your brain. And really, forgetting how to read 忘? That's worse (わす) than leaving your umbrella or keys behind! Come on! Try to hold onto the reading this time — you'll only be making things worse if you don't.

Name: Full Control
Mnemonic: When you're all by yourself and only your self exists, you probably have full control. You can do whatever you want freely and at will.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Guilty
Mnemonic: To have guilt is to be guilty. This can also simply mean guilt.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Hand Washing
Mnemonic: You remember how 洗う is "to wash"? Well, when you wash your hands you're doing hand washing.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the vocab readings 手 and 洗う put together.

Name: Hardship
Mnemonic: You're distressed and it's difficult. This is quite the hardship and difficulty you're feeling.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Harmless
Mnemonic: Psh, that guy's damage is nothing. He's what I'd call "mostly harmless."
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Heartburn
Mnemonic: When your chest is burning, you have what's known as heartburn.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings (hint is that there's hiragana sticking out there). So, just make sure you know the word 胸 and 焼く. If you do, you can combine that knowledge into this word, and hopefully not get any heartburn in the process.

Name: Hidden Gem
Mnemonic: Hey, this hole is a really nice place! But no one knows about it because they think it's just a hole. That makes it a hidden gem or a hidden spot, and you better hope the tourists don't hear about it.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for each kanji. You've seen both of these readings before, but here's a mnemonic in case you need it: Your town's hidden gem is a place where you can baa (ば) without shame. It's this great petting zoo no one knows about yet. It's never crowded, so you can baa at the sheep as much as you like without fear of society's judgment! (What's that? You didn't come here to baa? Okay, weirdo…)

Name: Husband And Wife
Mnemonic: You have a husband and a wife. Combine them together and they're husband and wife, or a married couple. This can also be added to a name to mean Mr. and Mrs..
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Indivisible
Mnemonic: When it's not possible to divide something, that makes it indivisible or inseparable.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Leeway
Mnemonic: When your surplus is abundant, you have leeway for a lot of things. You have plenty of room to spare.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Logic
Mnemonic: Using theory and reason, you are one who uses much logic. Imagine this type of person, I bet you know at least one.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Machine
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Machine
Mnemonic: A machine contraption is just a machine
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Meeting
Mnemonic: A place where people meet and do deliberation. Sounds boring, but also sounds like some kind of meeting or conference.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Member Of The Diet
Mnemonic: A discussion member talks about all the really important things that need to be discussed for the sake of the country. They are a member of the Diet. The Diet is Japan's version of congress. Diet members discuss really important matters.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Misfortune
Mnemonic: A disaster that is difficult is particularly difficult, making it more of a misfortune. Obviously a disaster that wasn't difficult wouldn't really be that bad, so a difficult one gets the "misfortune" or calamity label.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Mood
Mnemonic: Machines dislike everything. Their mood, or temper, is very sour. What about your mood?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. けん gets changed to げん, though, so don't let that ruin your mood.

Name: Natural Disaster
Mnemonic: A disaster that does damage. Usually these are natural disasters, though they could also just be regular disasters as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Nightmare
Mnemonic: A bad dream is also known as a nightmare. Ah! Noooooo!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Nostril
Mnemonic: What's your nose's hole? How about your nostril?
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the readings for 鼻 and 穴. Smell that fresh air through your nose hole.

Name: One Small Thing
Mnemonic: The counter 個, which means individual on its own, refers to "an individual thing." This is usually a small thing, so it's used to count small things. This word here talks about one individual. A better way to translate that would be to call it one small thing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The いち gets shortened, but I bet you knew that already.

Name: On'yomi And Kun'yomi
Mnemonic: You've seen (hopefully) 音読み and 訓読み. This is a combination of the two. This is on'yomi and kun'yomi, aka the Chinese and Japanese readings.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Overseas
Mnemonic: When you exist outside (outside of what? Japan, of course), you are overseas or abroad.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: People
Mnemonic: The kanji 達 pluralizes things sometimes. So, when you have a plural amount of a person you have more than one person, you have people.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi readings of the kanji. The readings come from the word 人 and the だち of 友達, though now it's たち because it hasn't been rendaku'd. You like to touch (たち) people, you perv.

Name: Personal
Mnemonic: In terms of an individual person... well, that's personal, and depends on the individual. Whatever it is, an individual person has personal tastes, so make sure to think of that.
