ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Pollution
Mnemonic: Public damage is something that affects everyone, the whole public. What is in the air and gets into everything no matter where you are? How about pollution?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Polygamy
Mnemonic: One husband, many wives. Sounds a bit sketchy. This is polygamy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the 一 gets changed to いっ and the 夫 gets changed to ぷ from ふう for some reason. You can imagine that this is because when you are the type that has many wives, you're probably the type who makes them clean up your poo for you as well.

Name: Possibility
Mnemonic: The possible (可能) range of gender extends beyond two options. It means there's a possibility to identify with many different gender identities.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to be able to read 可能 as well.

Name: Pressure
Mnemonic: The pressure power is the pressure. This can also be stress as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Prevention
Mnemonic: To prevent beforehand is still prevention.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Prevention
Mnemonic: To prevent and stop someone from doing something is prevention. It's good to have prevention instead of letting something bad happen.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Private Room
Mnemonic: An individual room just for you is your own private room. How nice!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Probability
Mnemonic: You're certain there is this percent chance it will happen? You know that this is the probability?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Quietly
Mnemonic: Quiet quiet! Do it quietly, please.
ReadingMnemonic: You know how 静か is しずか? Well, this is the same reading as that. Say it in a whisper with me: "しずしず." Shhh!

Name: Ratio
Mnemonic: You compare the percentage, figuring out the ratio or proportion of one thing to another. This can also be expressed as a percentage!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Reader
Mnemonic: The reading someone is someone who is reading. They are the reader (of a book, blog, article, etc).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 読 is the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. This reading is どく, and you can remember it by thinking about how you are the reader, and as the reader you choose where to read. For you, the best place to read is a peaceful dock (どく). Sit on the dock and relax. Be the reader.

Name: Reality
Mnemonic: The truth is that you exist in reality. This is your real existence. Well, that makes sense, I suppose.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Residence
Mnemonic: Where you exist is the place you're detained. As long as you're in this place, this will be your residence, even if you're staying in a foreign country.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Route
Mnemonic: If you pass through the roads, you are figuring out which roads to use, when to use them, and essentially coming up with the route and course to take to get to wherever you're going.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Seed
Mnemonic: What kinds of seeds are you going to sow? Think about all the different kinds of seeds, and the kinds of plants they'll grow into.
ReadingMnemonic: Choose your seeds carefully, because you love to have a tan eh? (たね). You love tanning, so you don't want to plant anything that will grow tall and create shade. Choose those seed types carefully, and don't forget about your tan, eh?

Name: Self-Awareness
Mnemonic: What does self and awake mean in combination? This refers to self-awareness, consciousness of yourself, or a realization.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Senior High School
Mnemonic: Remember when you learned that 高等 means "high class" and 学校 means "school?" Well put them together and you have senior high school! It's the most high class school you've got (unless you go to university, but that's considered to be separate).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Shiatsu
Mnemonic: When someone applies finger pressure, they're probably practicing shiatsu.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Sin
Mnemonic: If you have guilt then you have committed a sin or crime. Come here and confess to Father Koichi.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: When you come to confess your sin to me, you start claiming it wasn't you. You say it was some other version of you! What? How could this be? Well, you say "there are two mes (つみ) out there!" One is doing the bad stuff, and the other is you, and you haven't done any sins!

Name: Smoky
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of smoke? It's smoky.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You sort of did learn this reading with the vocabulary word 煙, but this one is just different enough where we thought we should make a mnemonic for this one: All this smokiness is from a terrible chemical (けむ) spill that happened nearby. It was acid, so it burned everything up real good, causing the air to get pretty smoky.

Name: Stinky
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of stinking? It's also stinking (or stinky).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji can be used here, too.

Name: Suspicion
Mnemonic: I dislike him and I have doubts about him. I therefore have much suspicion against him as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Tail
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You look down and you've sprouted a tail! You're so shocked that all you can say is "Oh. (お) Oh okay..." This your life now. A life with a tail.

Name: Theory
Mnemonic: You have reason behind your theory, making it a real theory (unlike those that don't have reason, I guess?).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Thesis
Mnemonic: A writing of your theory is usually a thesis. Remember how school teachers always wanted you to present theories in writing? And to make sure you have a thesis in that paper? I do.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Thick
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of thick? Also thick.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. No thick books needed to understand this reading, yeah?

Name: Three Small Things
Mnemonic: Three individuals is three small things. The kanji 個 can be used to count small objects, just like this! Try other numbers as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Bear Fruit
Mnemonic: You might remember 実 means "truth," but it can also mean fruit! That's why this verb vocab version means to bear fruit or to come to fruition.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a verb, so it uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out: Your experiments have finally started to bear fruit. You've fully turned yourself into a minotaur (みの)! Your long-term ambitions of turning yourself into a minotaur are finally beginning to come to fruition. All hail our new minotaur overlord!

Name: To Be Born
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You know another word that means "to be born" (生まれる), and they both have the same reading!

Name: To Be Distressed
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means distressed and troubled. The verb versions of those are to be distressed and to be troubled.
ReadingMnemonic: If someone seems to be distressed maybe someone they know is in a coma (こま). Not too many things are more distressing and troubling than that.

Name: To Be Gone
Mnemonic: Here we have nothing, followed by the verb なる. A verb that means "become nothing"? That'll be to be gone, to run out, to be lost, or to disappear.
ReadingMnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi reading, which you learned with 無し, so you should be good to go.

Name: To Be In Surplus
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surplus so the verb version would be to be in surplus, to remain left over, or to be in excess. Too much!
ReadingMnemonic: Something you don't want to be in surplus is armor (あま). Armor is heavy and it takes up a lot of space, so you need maybe one set at most. If you have enough for it to remain left over when you go off to battle, well, you probably have too much.

Name: To Be Renewed
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You might remember this reading from the transitive verb 改める, but here's a mnemonic just in case: To be renewed means to be changed into something 新た (あらた). Out with the old, in with the 新た, right? Picture yourself in a situation where there's been a lot of change. Try to remember how it feels when everything is 新た. Are you nervous, excited, or do you usually move on without noticing?

Name: To Close Something
Mnemonic: Another verb version of the kanji 閉! This is a special one that can be either transitive or intransitive, so 閉じる means to close something or to close.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is different from 閉める or 閉まる. Instead, 閉じる is read とじる. Why? Because to close something that's expanded or spread open, you always use your toe (と)! It's easy enough with books, but umbrellas are a real challenge… But you, you can do it! You have the toe-tal control and can close anything expanded to the way it was before.

Name: To Commit A Crime
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means crime and the verb vocab version can mean to commit a crime, to make a mistake, or to rape, depending on the context.
ReadingMnemonic: You go to commit a crime. How did it go, you think? Well, I thought it went okay (おか). Imagine yourself committing a crime and it going just okay. Not great, not bad... meh. Okay.

Name: To Connect Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means connect, and this verb means to connect something or to tie something to something else. Like connect people, hold hands, connect a cable to a charger, etc.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you already know from the kanji.

Name: To Defend Against
Mnemonic: You're doing a prevention. When you prevent something, what are you really doing? You're trying to defend against something from happening. That's why this verb is a little weird and means to defend or to protect against. It can also be to prevent, too, but just make sure you're thinking of it more like you're defending something with your prevention.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to defend against the enemy? You should probably put out that fuse (ふせ) attached to that giant bomb first then.

Name: To Fly
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fly, and the verb vocab version is also to fly. In addition to flying, the verb also means to jump. Just think of jumping as being some sort of... smaller version of flying, and this'll make sense.
ReadingMnemonic: When you try to fly, the main thing holding you back is your toe (と). It's like forty pounds and holds you down.

Name: To Get Baked
Mnemonic: Remember how 焼く is "to bake," "to burn something," or "to grill"? 焼ける is just the intransitive version. That means no direct object needed! So this verb means to get baked, to get burned, or to get grilled.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 焼く, so just use that knowledge and apply it here to be able to read this too.

Name: To Get Mixed
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mix so the verb vocab version is to get mixed or to be mixed. This is when something is just getting mixed and you're not directly doing the action of mixing anything. You can remember this because the Tzar (ざる) of Russia is very impressed that things mix on their own and you're not doing the mixing.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're not doing the mixing, in order for things to get mixed you call your ma (ま) up and ask her to mix it. What a terrible lazy child you are.

Name: To Knock Over
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to knock over something, you'll have to go to town (たお) on it. You'll never be able to knock down anything if all your efforts are perfunctory. You really gotta go to town on that thing!

Name: To Put On
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You learned this kanji as "incur," but it can also mean cover. So 被る means to put on, to wear, or to cover oneself with.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The hat you want to put on is way too heavy for you. It falls off your head and hits the ground with a loud KABOOM (かぶ). You try to wear the hat again and pull it down tight, but this time it pulls you to the ground with an even louder KABOOM!

Name: To Stab
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading you learned for this kanji is the kun'yomi one. Since this vocab word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Guess what? That means you already know it! But in case you've already forgot the reading, here's a mnemonic to refresh your memory: If you're going to stab someone, use a saw (さ). It may seem more difficult to stab them with a saw at first, but when you see the damage, plus how hard it is to get back out, you'll realize saws are the ideal stabbing tool.

Name: Trouble
Mnemonic: When you're looking straight into the face of a collapse it means trouble and difficulty coming soon.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The とう goes to どう, though. Agh, what a 面倒.

Name: Unneeded
Mnemonic: The surplus is measured and it's all unneeded. Yeah, it's definitely more than needed. Maybe we should get rid of all this surplus?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Via
Mnemonic: You pass through somewhere for a reason, so you're going via that place.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned this reading for 経 with the kanji, and you learned this reading for 由 with the word 由来. If you need an extra reminder for that one, here's a mnemonic just in case: If you're going via an unfamiliar place, I recommend you seek out a yurt (ゆ) to stay in. Wherever it is you're going via, you can't go wrong if you stay in a yurt.

Name: Wealthy
Mnemonic: You have such abundant luck! If you have abundant luck, you're probably also wealthy, because lots of wealth equals lots of luck, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Weather Forecast
Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 天気, meaning "weather," and 予報 meaning "forecast." Put them together and you get the weather forecast!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Wife
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is used to refer to your own wife, though, for the most part.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Your wife does everything for you. She feeds you, she bathes you, she cleans up after you and even wipes your butt when you poop. Really, she is doing too much (つま), and you should stop being a baby.

Name: Wife And Kids
Mnemonic: You have your wife and you have your child. These are your wife and kids.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Wonder
Mnemonic: This is not what you thought would happen during your deliberation. You thought it would be very normal. Instead, it's the opposite. It's full of wonder and mystery. It's marvelous
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Actually
Mnemonic: A truth occasion is reality. This word is also used a lot as an adverb (with or without the particle に) to mean actually or really.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The つ is shortened to っ.

Name: Alien
Mnemonic: You know how 宇宙 is space? Well, a person from space is an alien.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help to know how to read the word 宇宙 on its own, too.

Name: Arch Enemy
Mnemonic: Your big enemy is your worst enemy. Your arch enemy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Both kanji have a couple different on'yomi readings though, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to pick: Your arch enemy is the tie techie (たいてき). Who's the tie techie? He's the tech support guy at work who always wears the same tie and never helps you. He just says "try restarting your computer" to every problem, which isn't helpful. He's not just a great enemy, he's basically your nemesis. You hate that tie techie.

Name: A Right
Mnemonic: You have rights to profit! This is a right you have!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: As A Whole
Mnemonic: With the whole body. Do it as a whole instead of as a part, or something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Biker Gang
Mnemonic: A tribe that runs wild (暴走) is what the Japanese call a biker gang. Just imagine them riding around on their bikes, running wild. They're also close, like a family. How nice!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Capital
Mnemonic: To start a business, your main resource is your capital, which can be money and various other types of assets, like real estate properties.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Character
Mnemonic: With time your body will acquire a certain type of character. It shows your true nature as a person.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

Name: Checkup
Mnemonic: We're going to need to examine and inspect you for our annual checkup, mmk? Now drop your pants and cough, please.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Cloth
Mnemonic: Cloth from the earth is still cloth, just a little dirty.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, you've learned them both already!

Name: Condition
Mnemonic: A clause in the matter complicates things. It adds conditions, terms and requirements to an otherwise simple matter.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Confirmation
Mnemonic: Just be sure to make certain that you recognize him. We need confirmation and verification, so make certain again, please.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Construction
Mnemonic: You do the building to establish something. This whole process is called construction!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Crime Syndicate
Mnemonic: A group that has power using violence? Sounds like a crime syndicate to me, probably the Yakuza or some other gangster organization .
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Criticism
Mnemonic: A criticism is when you judge. It is still just a criticism.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Cut It Out
Mnemonic: You know how いい加減 is unfounded or pointless? Because if you add and then decrease you haven't really done anything? Well, this is like saying "do the pointless!" Okay, that doesn't make any sense. This is a phrase that means something similar to cut it out or cut the BS!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as いい加減, which you (hopefully) learned earlier.

Name: Definition
Mnemonic: Please determine what righteousness means. I want the definition for it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Drunk Driving
Mnemonic: You know that 飲酒 is "drinking alcohol" and 運転する is "to drive", so it makes sense that this word means drunk driving, or drinking and driving.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Duty
Mnemonic: You have a duty. You have a task. You have both a duty and a task to do.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Economy
Mnemonic: When a passage of time comes to an end, you look back on it and see how well you did. Did we make more money? Did we make less? That's all economics, baby (that's money, baby!).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The さい changes to ざい, though, so watch out for that.

Name: Election
Mnemonic: You have to choose someone and raise them up to office. This is an election.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Enemy
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The main reading is the same one you learned with the kanji. But there's also a secondary かたき reading you haven't seen yet, so here's a mnemonic for that: You love to call your enemy's car tacky (かたき). They're always driving around in some tacky sports car, you can't stand it. Every time they drive by you shout, "Your car is tacky, enemy!" Note: In terms of differences, the てき reading just means "enemy," whereas かたき typically refers to someone you hold a deep grudge against, often on behalf of another.

Name: Envy
Mnemonic: Envy consumes your hope turning it all to envy and jealousy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

Name: Explanation
Mnemonic: Once you've solved a theory, you should be able to give a pretty good explanation of it to somebody else. Makes sense, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Extremity
Mnemonic: The kanji 外 alone means "outside." This word means extremity. How can you remember this? Just think of the れ as a "ray of sunshine." Where you are, in the extremity of space, even the れs of the sun cannot be seen. So, when 外 is combined with れ just think of this.
ReadingMnemonic: Let's continue the previous story: You're off in the extremity of space and your friend is running low on Vitamin D. He has (はず) to get some sun れs on his skin! How's that supposed to happen with those spacesuits on, though?

Name: Footwear
Mnemonic: Remember how 履く is "to put on shoes" and 物 means "thing"? Well, combine them and you have a word for things you put on your feet, a.k.a. footwear or shoes.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is that of 履く and 物 put together. Just know those separately and you should be able to figure this one out as well.

Name: Forcing
Mnemonic: They have strong control over us. This means they never stop forcing us into compulsions or making all sorts of things compulsory.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Funds
Mnemonic: The resources of gold that we have are our current funds.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Harvest
Mnemonic: Remember how 実る means "to bear fruit"? This is just the noun version of that word, so it means harvest. (A nice harvest is what you get when your crops literally bear fruit!)
ReadingMnemonic: This is just the noun version of the verb 実る, which you've already learned how to read, so you should be good to go here!

Name: High Class
Mnemonic: The sect that stands the highest are those who are high class, splendid, and fine. 立派だ!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The りつ shortens to りっ though, so keep an eye on that you splendid frood you. Oh and は changes to ぱ too. Because rendaku and all that.

Name: Human Rights
Mnemonic: People Rights are human rights.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Incident
Mnemonic: An occurrence of some matter is really just something that happens. It's an incident or case.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Increase
Mnemonic: An increase will add to what you had before. This is an increase.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: International
Mnemonic: You have an  occasion to check out another country. Wow, so international!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Investment
Mnemonic: Go ahead and throw your resources at the project. It could use the investment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well!

Name: Ism
Mnemonic: The main cause behind someone's righteousness is usually what isms, principles or doctrines they believe in. Buddhism, Shintoism, socialism, communism, you name it. If you believe in one of those it's the main driving factor behind what you believe righteousness to be.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Judgment
Mnemonic: I judge to cut off your head. That is my judgment!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Justice
Mnemonic: The correct righteousness is always your righteousness. It is your form of justice.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Knowledge
Mnemonic: What does your heart want to acquire above all other things? Knowledge! That's why you're here, isn't it?
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Material
Mnemonic: If you use resources to make material, you'll have material. This is in the sense of material for a book, or data and documents for research.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Member Of A Committee
Mnemonic: A committee member is a member of a committee (or a committee member).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Ministry Of
Mnemonic: Let us conserve our tasks. We will give it to the Ministry Of Tasks!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Na Adjective
Mnemonic: A 形容詞 is an adjective. So what about an adjective with a 動詞 (verb) in there? How does that make sense? I'm not entirely sure either, but an adjective with movement in it is a na adjective. These are the adjectives that can end with な (便利な, for example). In fact, they're more like nouns than they are verbs, so what gives? Whatever it is, just decide you don't want to deal with this craziness. Just say nah, I don't care about this anymore.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 形容詞 and 動詞 as well, since they're both parts of this word.

Name: Obligation
Mnemonic: My righteousness task is my obligation to these people. I will go out and purge the world of evil, be righteous, and make things happen. It's my duty!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Office
Mnemonic: When the occurrence of your tasks is in the same place every day, that place is probably an office.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Okayama Prefecture
Mnemonic: Okayama (岡山) Prefecture is a prefecture in Japan. Learning the reading will help you to remember the meaning of this word since half of it is in Japanese.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the first two kanji. Luckily you learned them when you learned the kanji. Then, stick 県 on there and you should be good to go!

Name: One's Seal
Mnemonic: The child of a judge is the thing he puts on his judgements. What does he put on his judgments? His seal, you know, to make it all official and stuff.
ReadingMnemonic: 判 is the reading you learned. 子 is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which I bet you know pretty well by now as well. You just have to remember to use it here.

Name: Optional
Mnemonic: My idea of duty is that you don't really have to do it. It's optional, you know?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Overall
Mnemonic: When you take the whole and join it together, you get a synthesis, and probably a good overall picture of things.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Participant
Mnemonic: You know that 参加 is participation, so someone who does participation is a participant.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Police Officer
Mnemonic: The police (警察) government is full of police officers. This is the formal way to say "police officer." It is similar to 警官, but has a slightly more official feel to it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Prayer
Mnemonic: You pray and make a request, as a prayer to some deity at a shrine or temple.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Procedure
Mnemonic: Someone takes your hand and shows you how to continue. "This is the procedure," they say. Move your hand like this. Verrrryyy goood. Good procedure. Good!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of 手 and 続く put together into one. Darn these body parts making everything kun'yomi.

Name: Proper Noun
Mnemonic: A noun (名詞) that has hardness is a noun that can't be budged. It's a big noun, so big that you have to capitalize these kinds of nouns in English. It is a proper noun.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 名詞 as well.

Name: Public
Mnemonic: It's public establishment. It is public.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Qualifications
Mnemonic: The credible resources that determine your professional status are your qualifications. You need some good ones if you want to get into a good school or land a sweet job.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Raw Material
Mnemonic: When you want to use the most basic elements of a material, you end up with raw materials. Maybe it's the raw materials you're going to use to build a house. Maybe it's the raw materials you need to make a good soup. Either way, they haven't been touched much (yet).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 素 is the そ reading, so be careful. You can remember by thinking how you have to sew the building together using these raw materials.

Name: Reconsideration
Mnemonic: If you're anti conserve, I'm going to ask you to do some heavy reconsideration and reflection, and see if that's really the right way to be. If you change your thinking, you might even end up showing regret.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 反 is all good. The reading for 省 is an on'yomi reading you haven't seen yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm standing in front of you, forcing a reconsideration of your anti conserve stance, with my saber (せい) to your throat. I better see some reflection on your face or you won't have one in a second.

Name: Responsibility
Mnemonic: You can blame duty all you want, but you still have a responsibility as well, no matter what your duty dictates.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Sashimi
Mnemonic: Remember how 身 can mean "animal flesh"? Well, when you stab some animal flesh and eat it raw, you're having sashimi. Yum!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a little weird. It's double kun'yomi where the 刺す becomes stem form and gets pushed inside the kanji to become さし. The 身 is just the word 身's reading.

Name: Self Control
Mnemonic: Self control is self control and self restraint. Have some!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Sense Of Duty
Mnemonic: You have righteousness and then a reason behind it, at least in your own mind. This is your sense of duty. And it really is a "sense" in a way, too. You just feel it. It's not an actual thing that is tangible. It is your own personal reason for this righteousness.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Showy
Mnemonic: This is a weird one. Just think about the sect of hands. They are always doing jazz hands and things like that, trying to be all showy and flashy. Ugh, what a dumb sect, you think.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, though て goes to で.

Name: Side
Mnemonic: Even though the kanji mainly means  occasion, for some reason this word means side or edge. I suppose on occasion kanji takes you to the edge of what ought to make sense when it comes to kanji.
ReadingMnemonic: You're on the very edge of the world. You heard that at the edge of the world are the key words (きわ) written there in big fiery letters, telling you the meaning of life. Supposedly these are the words of God himself. They say: "We apologize for the inconvenience." WHAT? THESE ARE THE KEY WORDS??? Note that this word is often written in kana, as きわ or キワ.

Name: Society
Mnemonic: The middle of the world is the society. It's what holds everything together, for us humans. You can also call it the world.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. Why? Because this word is really two separate words connected together into one bigger word. You know the kun'yomi readings from vocab practice in previous levels.

Name: Spaceship
Mnemonic: You know how 宇宙 is outer space and how 船 is ship, right? Well, put those together and you have an outer space ship (better known as a space ship).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 宇宙 beforehand as well.

Name: Sudden Increase
Mnemonic: A sudden increase is just that, a sudden increase or surge!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Suspect
Mnemonic: I have a suspicion (容疑) about someone. That someone is my main suspect.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to be able to read 容疑 first, though.

Name: System
Mnemonic: You control every degree of this system. Think about a system. It's designed to create more control for you, degree by degree by degree. That's why they call it "The system," after all.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Tax
Mnemonic: The tax gold is what you have to pay when you have to pay a tax.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Tax Free
Mnemonic: When the tax is nothing things are tax free.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Tax Increase
Mnemonic: When you increase tax you're doing a tax increase.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Acknowledge
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means recognize or acknowledge, so the verb also means to acknowledge, to recognize, to perceive, or to admit, among others.
ReadingMnemonic: The only thing you could ever truly acknowledge is meat (みと). Meat is the only thing in your life that has any authority over you. That's how much you love meat.

Name: To Be Confused
Mnemonic: If 混乱 is confusion then making it into a verb would cause it to be confused.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 混乱 so no reason for you to be confused, right?

Name: To Be Raised
Mnemonic: When you raise something you are causing it to be raised. This verb can also mean things like to be listed, to be nominated, or to rise. For these additional meanings, you might want to imagine something rising up onto a list or someone rising up to a nomination, because lists and nominations are always high up.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The reading for this is the same as the other "to rise" word, 上がる. Nice how that works, right? So, just associate the two and you have yourself a reading.

Name: To Blame
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blame so this also means to blame. Additionally, this can also mean to criticize, to reproach, or to accuse.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Are you going to blame me for eating your celery (せ)? You should know I'm the wrong person to blame because I don't even like celery!

Name: To Come To An End
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means come to an end so the verb vocab version is to come to an end.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your romp finally has to come to an end when someone decides to sue (す) you for all your romping.

Name: To Come True
Mnemonic: The kanji means come true, and this is the intransitive verb version of that, making this to come true or to be fulfilled.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a verb, so it uses the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you already learned this with the kanji, so you should be good to go here!

Name: To Compensate For
Mnemonic: 埋める is "to bury." 合わせる is "to unify together." If you bury somebody in order to unify them with you, you're almost certainly trying to compensate for something.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 埋める and 合わせる. Combine them into one big happy word.

Name: To Continue Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means continue, so 続ける means to continue something. It's a transitive verb, so it takes a direct object. You can 続ける your work, for example, and you should 続ける your WaniKani lessons at a pace that works for you!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 続く, so be sure to know that so you can know this.

Name: To Decrease Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decrease so the verb vocab version is to decrease something. You can differentiate this from 減る because with this one, you are the one that is going to be doing the decreasing. The rush (らす) of decreasing something fills your veins.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 減る, so if you know that reading you should know this one.

Name: To Envy
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means envy so the verb version is to envy someone.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're really starting to envy those uranium Yankees (うらや). That's the new Yankees team hopped up on uranium that were created in a lab. Even though they're gross and hulk-ish, they're really good at baseball, so you're jealous of them.

Name: To Establish
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means establish so the verb vocab version is to establish, or to set up.
ReadingMnemonic: What are you going to establish? How about a system for mowing (もう) lawns? It's very important that lawns are mowed according to an established system, you know. How do you mow yours?

Name: To Get Irritated
Mnemonic: Double frustration would cause anyone to get irritated, to get annoyed, or to grow impatient.
ReadingMnemonic: This isn’t the reading you learned with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You don’t just get irritated, you get ira-ira-tated (いらいら). That's the next level up from irritated. This word is often written in katakana or hiragana, but you'll sometimes see it in kanji too, so it's worth knowing!

Name: To Get Rid Of Something
Mnemonic: This word ends with a う sound so you can guess it's a verb. The kanji means nothing, and you'll end up with nothing if you want to to get rid of something, to do away with something or to lose something.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi, which you already learned when you learned the word 無し.

Name: To Give Birth
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give birth so the verb vocab version is to give birth.
ReadingMnemonic: You know another "to give birth" word (生む). Guess what!? They share readings!

Name: To Increase
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means increase, so the vocabulary verb version means to increase. This is when something is just increasing on its own, and you're not doing the increasing. You know this because you like to err (える) on the side of caution and not touch anything when it's increasing, therefore you're not doing any of the increasing yourself (it's just happening).
ReadingMnemonic: It would be foolish (ふ) of you to touch anything while things are increasing anyways. You don't want to mess up a good thing, do you? Don't be a fool.

Name: To Inspect
Mnemonic: You examine the problem. In order to do this, you need to inspect it or to examine it. And if you're inspecting people like this, you're probably the police.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Leave
Mnemonic: You 立ち and then 去る. Makes sense, as in order to leave, you'll have to stand up first.
ReadingMnemonic: This combines the readings of two verbs you already know, so you should be good to go here!

Name: To Omit
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conserve... but why stop there when you could try to omit everything and to eliminate everything? Just take exactly what you need, conserve it, and omit everything else.
ReadingMnemonic: You have (はぶ) what you have, and omit what you don't need. Perfect life.

Name: To Participate
Mnemonic: You know how 参加 is participation? Well, make that a verb with する and you have yourself to participate.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also help to know the reading of 参加.

Name: To Persuade
Mnemonic: You know that 説得 is persuasion, so what is the verb version of that? To persuade.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also immensely help to know the reading of the word 説得.

Name: To Plan
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means plan so the verb vocab version is to plan.
ReadingMnemonic: You say you have something you need to plan? Cool, whaddaya (くわだ) gonna do?

Name: To Pray For
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pray and this verb is transitive, so it means to pray for.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You gotta pray for Christmas presents if you want Santa to bring you some!" "I know (いの), I know," you reply as you begin to pray for presents. You should say this out loud to remember it better.

Name: To Put In Disorder
Mnemonic: You know how 乱れる is "to be in disorder"? Well, now you're the one causing this. So, by doing this you are going to put in disorder, to throw out of order, or to disturb whatever it is. Just imagine all the people who will try to sue (す) you for your actions.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 乱れる, so hopefully you know it already.

Name: To Receive Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means receive, making this to receive something, or alternatively, to get something from someone or to be given something.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go here!

Name: To Refuse
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cut off. What happens when you do the action of cutting someone off? You're going to refuse them whatever it is they want.
ReadingMnemonic: Deciding to refuse something unfortunately starts a coat war (like a pillow fight, but everyone hits each other with coats instead of pillows). Coats to the ready, and let the coat war commence!

Name: To Set
Mnemonic: What do you establish and determine in your every day life? A setting. When you make that into a verb, you have the word to set, as in setting the temperature of the AC, setting your password, or setting your computer to dark mode.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Careful because the 設 gets shortened to せっ.

Name: To Wake Up
Mnemonic: If your eyes are awake then you're going to wake up. Your eyes are usually the first thing to awaken when you're waking up, you know?
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven’t learned this reading for 覚 yet, and in this case it also gets rendaku’d, so bear that in mind. Anyway, here’s a mnemonic to help you: If you start to wake up in the middle of the night, it’s because of the Czar (ざ) you met that had banned sitting. This cruel, ruthless Czar keeps appearing in your nightmares, causing you to wake up incessantly. Terrifying.

Name: To Work As
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means task so what's the verb vocab version? Well, when you do a task, you are going to work as or to serve as something to do that task.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To work as my secretary, you will have to complete a task. A task where you bring me two toes (つと)! Don't ask me why! You want to serve as my assistant, right? Just get me those two toes then!

Name: Transitive Verb
Mnemonic: Remember how 動詞 means "verb"? When the verb is done to some other thing, it's a transitive verb.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Treaty
Mnemonic: There are many clauses about the promises you make in this contract considering it's supposed to be a treaty.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Uniform
Mnemonic: If you control people, you make them wear the same clothes. That's a uniform.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Unrivaled
Mnemonic: You have nothing when it comes to enemies. Why? It's not because you're super kind and everyone likes you. No, it's that you've defeated anyone who's tried. You are unrivaled and invincible.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Whistling
Mnemonic: A mouth flute... Normal flutes you blow air through to make a sound. How do you blow air through your mouth to make a sound? By whistling.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings put together. Thank 口 for being a body part, which tends to cause this to happen. So, you have 口 (くち) and 笛 (ふえ) put together, though ふえ changes to ぶえ, maybe because you can't whistle properly? Buuuweeee. Buwwweee.

Name: Adverb
Mnemonic: This is like your side part of speech, as in, you add it to the side of a verb because it's an adverb.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: A Fine
Mnemonic: Penalty gold is the money you pay when you get a penalty. It's for a fine.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ばつ gets changed to ばっ though, so don't get it wrong (or you'll get a 罰金!).

Name: Alteration
Mnemonic: Things that change and renew are going through alterations and change. Pretty straightforward!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: A Plan
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Lucky for you, even though this word is a single kanji, it uses the same reading you learned, meaning you know how to read it already. Time to plan and scheme for your next vocab/kanji.

Name: Architecture
Mnemonic: When it comes to building and constructing, the thing that encompasses both of them is architecture.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: A Reaction

It's the spirit of the hot, icky oil from the deep friers at fast food chains, and nothing will stop that giant mass of icky oil from hurtling at its target.

Name: To Be Crowded
Mnemonic: This one is a little strange. You have 混じる (to get mixed up in), 混ぜる (to mix), 混ざる (to get mixed), and now this: 混む, to be crowded. It makes sense that when everyone's all mixed up it's going to be crowded, but how to differentiate between this and the other 混 words? Just think of how cows muuuuu (む) get all bunched up and crowded, which is why this word is to be crowded.
ReadingMnemonic: Hey, come (こむ) out of that crowd of cows. It's going to be crowded in there.

Name: To Be Pierced
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 刺す.

Name: To Criticize
Mnemonic: Know how 非難 is a criticism? Make it a verb and you have the word to criticize.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, it will be really helpful to know the word 非難 to start.

Name: To Examine
Mnemonic: You know that 検査 is inspection, so the verb version of that would be to inspect.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 検査 already as well.

Name: To Exist
Mnemonic: Know how 存在 is existence? Well, make it a verb and then you have to exist.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Get Knocked Over
Mnemonic: You've seen how 倒す is "to knock over." But this is when something gets knocked over by itself. You know that you're not doing anything here, because when you're not touching all these fine glass items, it's very rare (れる) that anything gets knocked over (because you're not touching anything, you clumsy dumsy). It's also when you or someone else collapses. You didn't push yourself over, you just kind of fell by yourself.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same like 倒す. If you knew 倒す you will know the reading of this one too.

Name: To Give Up
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give up or abandon so the verb version is to give up or to abandon.
ReadingMnemonic: You hopefully learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a reminder just in case: Just before you're ready to give up on something, you yell, "AKIRA (あきら)!". You don't know anyone named Akira, you just saw it in a movie once and it made sense, you know? So now when you've tried really hard on something, but you have to abandon it anyway, you shout AKIRA into the sky. I just did it while trying to write this mnemonic!

Name: Toilet
Mnemonic: You know that 手洗い is "handwashing" (and also a not as polite way to mention a bathroom). When you add お you're suddenly making it polite. Why? Because you're talking about something a little more crass than handwashing. You're talking about the toilet or restroom or bathroom. Ewww. Poop goes there.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 手洗い, so if you know that you'll know this too!

Name: To Indicate
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means indicate so the verb vocab version is to indicate or to show. This is used in contexts like "a study shows that learning Japanese is fun" and "I demonstrated my willingness to learn kanji".
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Studies seem to indicate and to show that sheep men (しめ) are better than regular men in every way. The sheep/man combo is a powerful thing. Or so studies indicate.

Name: To Judge
Mnemonic: 判断 is judgement. Make that into a verb and you have to judge, or to conclude.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 判断 before learning this, but if you don't I won't judge you (the Crabigator will).

Name: To Let Something Fly
Mnemonic: Remember how 飛ぶ is to fly? Well this word is for when you make some thing fly. So, this word is to let something fly or to send something flying. It also means to skip over something, such as someone's turn or a question on a test.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is just like 飛ぶ, so if you know that reading you're close. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember the second part: You can use your strength to let something fly, and that something is a bus (ばす). You're that buff!

Name: To Make Sure Of
Mnemonic: Like with 確か, which means certain, this is the verb version of that. So when you "do certain" you are going to make sure of something or you're going to verify something.
ReadingMnemonic: This one is kun'yomi followed by okurigana. If you remember the reading you learned with 確かに, you should know this one!

Name: To Overwhelm
Mnemonic: The pressure used easily collapses whatever it's pushing against. That's why this verb means to overwhelm.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the あつ goes to あっ, as you'd probably expect.

Name: To Pass
Mnemonic: You know how 経 means passage of time, right? Well, this is the verb form of that. What does time do when it passages? It passes. So, this verb means to pass or to elapse.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you say to time as it begins to pass you by? "Ta ta (た), Time!"

Name: To Pass
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surpass, but this verb is intransitive, meaning we’re not focussing on who did the action, but on the action itself. So this means to pass, as in “the storm passed”, to be over as in “winter’s over”, or to be too much.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In order for the storm to pass you’re going to have to sue (す) it. Sadly storms won’t pass unless you take legal action these days.

Name: To Punish
Mnemonic: When you do a  penalty to someone you are trying to punish or to penalize them.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Just remember that the つ becomes a small っ so I don't have to punish you.

Name: To Put Down
Mnemonic: When you put something you don't just put it, you have to put down this item or even (to) set down the item. Basically, you have to put something down with this verb. It's a little different from the kanji meaning you learned but not that different.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Just imagine you're putting down Oreos (お). One after another. Each oreo that you try to put down say in your head "Hello Mr. Oreo, I'm going to put you down.. ooh yes, you like that don't you?" REPEAT.

Name: To Reside
Mnemonic: If 在留 is residence, then the verb version of that would be to reside.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 在留 so you should be able to read this one already!

Name: To Respond
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means respond so the verb vocab version is to respond.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is actually the same as the one you learned with the kanji! Not too shabby.

Name: To Run A Business
Mnemonic: The kanji means manage, but when you manage something, what are you usually managing? How about a business? So this word means to run a business even though the kanji is manage.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to run a business. Your business is to make people eat who don't want to eat. "HEY, YOU EAT NOW!" (いとな).

Name: To Shake
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means earthquake so the verb means to shiver and to shake, like you would if there was an earthquake happening right now.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You start to shake in an earthquake because you're really full (ふる) from eating lunch. Now your full belly is shaking and quaking with the ground! Ahh it's awful! You never want to be full again!

Name: To Sleep
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sleep or lie down, so the verb vocab version is to sleep or to lie down—just like what you do when you decide to go to bed.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. So, you can go ahead and lie down for a moment before moving on to the next item.

Name: To Smoke
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means suck so the verb vocab version is to suck, but it's usually used to talk about what you do to cigarettes, so a better translation I think is to smoke.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You smoke too much, and that gives you cancer. You decide to sue (す) the cigarette makers.

Name: To View
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means view so what is the verb vocab version? It's to view or to watch.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading here is actually the same as 見る. This is easy to remember because the meanings are so similar too, not to mention it has a 見 right inside the kanji itself!

Name: Tradition
Mnemonic: When you transmit something that unites the people, you are probably pulling on tradition. Tradition is what unites us all and transmits who we are to everyone else. What is your 伝統?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Troublesome
Mnemonic: Something is a trouble (面倒) and it is smelly (臭い). So what is something that's smelly and a trouble? Well, something that's troublesome or a bother, I suppose. Basically you can ignore the smelly part. For some reason someone threw that back in, but smelly things are a bother, I suppose.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the words 面倒 plus 臭い added together, so it is めんどうくさい! Although the proper reading is めんどうくさい, be aware that people often just say めんどくさい when speaking. That extra う is just such a bother, you know?

Name: Undressing
Mnemonic: If you undress from clothes you are undressing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Unexpectedly
Mnemonic: Something that happens outside the plan is something that happens unexpectedly.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Unification
Mnemonic: When you unite and join things together, you get unification! This can also mean integration and consolidation, which are essentially other ways to describe things being united.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Unify them.

Name: Unpleasant Feelings
Mnemonic: Bad feelings that you dislike are unpleasant feelings. These unpleasant feelings include things like hatred, disgust, revulsion, and fear. All of those are considered to be a part of the term unpleasant feelings.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these readings already so you should be able to read this one too!

Name: Value
Mnemonic: A value and a value. Obviously this is something that has much value.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Value
Mnemonic: A value is a value, but only in the mathematical sense.
ReadingMnemonic: Imagine a numerical value written on a tie (あたい). Now imagine that it's the price of a neigh (ね) from your favorite horse. It's a pretty high price, but you'll do anything to hear that horse neigh. Generally, あたい refers to a numerical value in math, while ね is a formal word for "price."

Name: Victim
Mnemonic: The someones (people) who incur damage are the victims. WILL SOMEBODY THINK OF THE VICTIMS HERE???
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 被害 as well.

Name: Wisteria
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned! Now you just have to make sure you know what a Wisteria is... This word is often found in names, like a lot, so look out for it in that way.

Name: Zone
Mnemonic: When there's a district in a region, it's called a zone or district.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Absorption
Mnemonic: You suck something in and obtain it. Shhheewwwwww! When you suck something in and obtain it into your body, you have done absorption because it's been sucked inside of you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Acting
Mnemonic: Your performance skill allows you to be great at acting and doing awesome performances.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Actor
Mnemonic: A superior haiku requires someone really famous and well known to read it... it's just on that level. Who is super well known and who deserves to read this superior haiku? A great actor, perhaps?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Actor
Mnemonic: A man who is superior to us is an actor, or more specifically a male actor.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Actually
Mnemonic: The present time is the time you're actually in. You aren't really in any other time, because that's not how time works!
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: A Lot
Mnemonic: Swamps and mountains happen a lot in Japan. That's why we use this to mean many! Because there are many of them!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. This word is usually written in kana though, so keep that in mind when you're writing it to use kana and not these kanji!

Name: Architect
Mnemonic: You know that 建築 is architecture. So, someone of house architecture is someone who does architecture. They are an architect.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know how to read 建築 already.

Name: Attorney
Mnemonic: A samurai who uses speech to defend people. This samurai does their battle in the court of law. This "samurai" is an attorney or a lawyer.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Bookcase
Mnemonic: A book shelf is a bookcase or bookshelf.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the individual kanji. Be careful of the rendaku.

Name: Bullet Train
Mnemonic: This is one of those words that makes more sense when you look at the reading first. Technically this is the "New Tree Trunk Line" but you wouldn't realize this is the Japanese bullet train aka Shinkansen from that, would you? Maybe going to the reading will help you after all.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Read this to be able to remember the meaning, too, which is Shinkansen.

Name: Business Trip
Mnemonic: You exit the building and stretch in preparation for your business trip. This is the routine you always follow for your business trips: exit, and stretch.
