ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful about しゅつ becoming しゅっ here!

Name: Bus Stop
Mnemonic: This is where the bus (バス) halts. It's the bus stop.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Cabinet
Mnemonic: A door shelf is a shelf with a door on it. What kinds of shelves do you know of that have doors on them? How about cabinets? Or maybe cupboards?
ReadingMnemonic: These readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. Just keep in mind that 棚 gets rendaku'd to だな.

Name: Cape
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Castle
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Changing Room
Mnemonic: A renew clothes room is a changing room or a locker room.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Committee
Mnemonic: There are member(s) of a committee (委員) all getting together to meet. This is the committee itself.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course it will help to know 委員 as well, since it's 2/3rds of the word.

Name: Conservative
Mnemonic: You know that 主義 is "-ism." Add that ism to people who want to protect and conserve their country so it stays just the way it is (forever). That's conservatism and they're conservative people.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the reading of 保守的 for the first half and then the regular kanji readings for the second half. Combine those things and you'll be a master of righteousness and / or kanji.

Name: Demon
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Demons are mean. This particular demon bites you on the knee, creating an "O" shape on your knee. He tells you he has cursed you with the "O" knee (おに).

Name: Derailment
Mnemonic: When something escapes from the line it should be on, that's a derailment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Division
Mnemonic: Divide and calculate? Why, that's just division!
ReadingMnemonic: This is the kun'yomi reading for 割 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

Name: Doctor
Mnemonic: A medicine expert is someone who knows a lot about medicine. Those people are (I hope) generally doctors.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Dwelling
Mnemonic: If you dwell in a house, that house is your dwelling, or residence.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Economic
Mnemonic: 経済 is economics. So, something that has to do with economics is the economic or financial situation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 経済 as well.

Name: Economics
Mnemonic: You know how 経済 is economics, right? Well, add study to that and you have the study of economics, aka economics.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 経済 as well.

Name: Effect
Mnemonic: When you make a task you're looking for a certain effect or action. What task can you make right now to get the effect of learning more kanji?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 作 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: What's the effect of a saw on yogurt (さよう)? What will the action of the saw on the yogurt do? Seems futile, but you're going to try anyway. For science.

Name: Enforcement
Mnemonic: If you carry out something and go, the result is still enforcement, carrying out, or implementation of whatever it is. There’s no point hanging around after you’ve enforced something! So you always carry out and go.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. You might sometimes see せこう as an alternative reading, but しこう is the more common version.

Name: Envious
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with hiragana that ends in an い, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of envy? It's also envious!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 羨む, but here's a reminder just in case: Those uranium Yankees (うらや) are making you more envious and jealous by the day. They're the new Yankees team that was manufactured in a lab and fed uranium. Their skills are unparalleled because of their metallic strength. Go ahead and feel envious, they'll definitely be #1 this year.

Name: Expression
Mnemonic: When you express something that's of the present time, you are saying something that only people of the current time understand. These are expressions or figure of speech. You say these things during the present time, not the future, not the past, the present time. Otherwise nobody would understand.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Foul
Mnemonic: An anti rule is when you break the rules. It's when you do a foul.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Gentle
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of gentle? It's gentle (but also kind or warm hearted).
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do people who are gentle and kind say when someone asks of them a favor? Always "yessir" (やさ). Always, always "yessir"!

Name: Government-Run Company
Mnemonic: A public company is a government-run company or a government-owned company. In other words, it's a company that's run by national or local government in the interests of the public.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Guidance
Mnemonic: Take your finger and lead with it. Just point at things. Tell people where they need to go, what they need to do, all with your finger leading them. This is guidance you are providing.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should know them both already!

Name: Haiku
Mnemonic: A haiku paragraph is just a haiku. Haikus are little haiku paragraphs.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Having A Job
Mnemonic: To have employment just means having a job. Wow, congrats on being employed!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: House
Mnemonic: Just like its kanji, this word means house or home. By extension, it also sometimes means household. It can go after someone’s name to say whose house it is, as in 山田宅 (Yamada’s house), and after words that give more information about the house, such as 女性宅 (women’s homes).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go home now.

Name: Income
Mnemonic: Please enter what you've obtained in here. We'll divvy it all up later. But we have to enter it all here so we know our income.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Institution
Mnemonic: Go ahead and carry out the task and establish the institution. To carry out and establish something is to institute it too. What do you institute? An institution.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Itchy
Mnemonic: You can guess this is an adjective from the い at the end. The meaning for the kanji is itchy, and the adjective version is itchy too.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji: かゆ.

Name: Job Hunting
Mnemonic: Ugh, time to request employment again. Time to go job hunting.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Kawasaki
Mnemonic: This is one of those words that's easier to know if you jump to the reading first. Why? Because it's the name of a city. It's Kawasaki.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, making it Kawasaki.

Name: Law
Mnemonic: Though there's no law about two kanji with the same meaning producing the same meaning, a law law is probably a law.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Leather
Mnemonic: Skin leather is really just leather because leather is also skin. It's also hides.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should know them both already!

Name: Leather
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: Leather is the skin of a cow, right? How do you say "skin" in Japanese? Remember 皮 (かわ)? It has the same reading as that, and they're both skin, so hopefully that makes it easier to remember.

Name: Local Train
Mnemonic: At  each  station someone keeps  halting the  car . What is this, a local train?! Yes, yes it is. You’re on a local train. People use it when they get on (or off) at the smaller stations.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Luxury
Mnemonic: You live in the most extravagant of swamps, which means you’re completely surrounded by luxury and extravagant things.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Milk
Mnemonic: Cow milk is cow's milk, though most people just call cow's milk milk.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Nagasaki
Mnemonic: This word will be easier if you jump to the reading, since it's the name of a place, Nagasaki.
ReadingMnemonic: The 長 is the kun'yomi reading, which comes from 長い. The 崎 part is the same reading that you learned with the kanji (though also kun'yomi). Combine those together and you have ながさき. Sound familiar? It should. This is the city of Nagasaki, one of the cities in which the A-bombs fell.

Name: Nipple
Mnemonic: What is a milk neck? Think about where milk comes from. Now, think of what looks like a little neck on the thing that milk comes from. What is that thing? It's a nipple.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this one is an exception, you already know that 首 is read as くび, but 乳 in this case is read as ち. Here's a mnemonic to help you. You come across a nipple and decide to milk it so that you can make some cheese (ち). That's a little bit strange. You should probably find out who this nipple belongs to and ask them if you can do that first.

Name: Nurse
Mnemonic: An expert who watches over and defends people at all hours is the nurse. That's what nurses do, 24/7. They have to check up on people, defend their health, and watch over them, making sure they're okay. What a tough job.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Occupation
Mnemonic: Your employment business is your occupation or profession. What is your employment business?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: One's Home
Mnemonic: Your self home is your own home. It's one's home.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Optimism
Mnemonic: You know that 主義 is "-ism." If you add that to being comfortable like you're in heaven then you have lots of optimism. You're sure you'll be okay in any situation!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Outskirts Of Town
Mnemonic: You already know that 町 means "town" and that 外れ means "extremity" or "outskirts", and this is just a combination of the two. So this means the outskirts of town.
ReadingMnemonic: You've already learned both 町 and 外れ, so just combine the two and you get 町外れ not only in meaning, but also in reading!

Name: Performance
Mnemonic: What's above the stage and involves acting? A performance!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Performing Arts
Mnemonic: When you turn acting into art you get the performing arts. It is popular entertainment! Lights, action! Welcome to Broadway!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Personnel
Mnemonic: The employment members of a workplace are the personnel or staff. Pretty straightforward!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Physical Law
Mnemonic: It's both a law and a rule. This usually refers to something that is a physical law, but also can simply be a law, too. Anyways, lots of rules. Lots of laws. It's both, so the stronger one (law) takes precedence.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Place Of Work
Mnemonic: Your employment location is your place of work or place of employment. It's also your workplace.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading for 場 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: At your place of work, you "baa" (ば) to your coworkers as a greeting. Remember that town hall where you had to speak Sheepanese to the clerks? Well, it turns out your "baa" pronunciation was so good that they hired you. Now you can practice baaing all day, and get paid for it too!

Name: Power Outage
Mnemonic: When you halt electricity you experience a power outage. Makes sense. When the electricity stops you don't have any more power.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Preparation
Mnemonic: When you follow standard procedure to provide what's needed, you make the perfect preparation!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Present
Mnemonic: In the present time we exist. What time is it? It's present and now. It is the current time!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Priority
Mnemonic: It was superior previously, so we need to go back there. That, amongst all the other things, is our highest priority.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Purple
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading of 紫 when you learned the kanji, so you should be good to go!

Name: Purple
Mnemonic: A purple color is purple. Simple as that!
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of both kanji.

Name: Ratio
Mnemonic: When you divide something into parts and join them back together, you are better able to evaluate the ratio or percentage of these parts in relation to the whole. Think of all these parts, neatly separated and then placed next to one another. It's only because you divided them that you get to see them this way.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!

Name: Reality
Mnemonic: The present is the truth. It is what's going on right now. It is reality.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Receipt
Mnemonic: I obtain some territory, so I want a written record of it. How will I get a written record of my obtained territory? How about with a receipt? Emailing one will do just fine.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Reputation
Mnemonic: When people evaluate and judge you at every turn, it means you have quite a reputation, and indeed fame. Wouldn't this be terrible if people evaluated and judged you 24/7? Having that kind of reputation or fame would be difficult.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This uses a slightly different reading from what you learned for 判, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your reputation is incredibly important to you, so don't let anybody know that you've been banned (ばん) on the WaniKani forums before. Wouldn't want anyone to find out. What, this is going to be published as a reading mnemonic on WaniKani?! What are you talking about? Oh sh-...

Name: Resignation
Mnemonic: If you quit your place of employment, you are quitting, aka putting in your resignation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Revolution
Mnemonic: Leather's fate is in the hands of a revolution. It's the leather revolution! Off with these normal clothes and on with leather ones!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Role
Mnemonic: Let's divide the duty up amongst various people. Each person will have their own role in completing this duty.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. See how we divide up the duty of learning kanji into radicals and kanji and vocab? Makes it nice, right? Each piece is its own 役割.

Name: Scene
Mnemonic: Your present location is the scene of the crime! And you're on the scene to check out what's currently going on.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a combination of the on'yomi and kun'yomi readings. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading for 場 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: At this crime scene, a "baa" (ば) was apparently heard by witnesses. This can only mean one thing: that infamous arch-criminal, the Lamb-Chopper, has struck again! Baa!

Name: Sense Of Responsibility
Mnemonic: 責任 is responsibility. If you add 感 you get a "feeling of responsibility." That's not really a thing people say. What people do say, however, is sense of responsibility. Do you have one?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Shelf
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Shutter
Mnemonic: A rain door is really just a shutter. In Japan, having shutters for rain protection is very common. When there were no glass windows, the shutters were simply like exterior doors in Japan, so "rain door" kind of makes sense as "shutter"!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, but it actually uses kun'yomi for both 雨 and 戸. Additionally, the reading for 雨 is actually slightly different from what you've learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: A shutter is basically just armor (あま) for a window. They're both protective, and are often made from metal. Kind of makes sense, right?

Name: Speech
Mnemonic: A part of speech machine spits out speeches and words. It's all the machine is programmed to do.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you: The only font the machine can print speeches in is serif font (せりふ).

Name: Standard
Mnemonic: The foundation of your standard is where you place your standard. No more, no less. This foundation is where the standard is all based off of.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Stoppage
Mnemonic: Halt and stop. When something does this, it's in a stoppage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Suddenly
Mnemonic: When something happens with a sudden nature, it happens... suddenly.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Superior
Mnemonic: Something that's superior will excel. It is superior and excellent in every way.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Tax Evasion
Mnemonic: You're trying to escape from taxes? You scared of them? Huh? That's tax evasion, buddy. You're going to jail for that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Teacher
Mnemonic: A teaching expert/teacher is a teacher.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Ten Percent
Mnemonic: One division is ten percent. You'll just have to imagine this in terms of tens going by. Must be some old Japanese percentage system that carried over or something. Just remember that one wari is ten percent, two waris are twenty percent, and so on.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the same as what you learned with the kanji. You know much more than ten percent of this word's reading already.

Name: To Appear
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means appear, so this word means to appear or to emerge.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Some kind of paranormal entity starts to appear in front of you. "You… are a walrus (あらわ)!" you scream, terrified. Yes, it seems a ghostly walrus has appeared before you. It has come from beyond the grave to warn you that the Crabigator will get you if you don't do your reviews!

Name: To Be Added To
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 加える. To help you distinguish between the two, remember that most verbs ending in わる are intransitive.

Name: To Be Buried
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 埋める means "to bury?" Well this is something that is being buried, maybe even you! Either way, you're not the one doing the burying. It means to be buried.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

Name: To Build
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means build so the verb vocab version is to build.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about what happens when you build something. What are you doing? You're standing it up. How do you say "to stand" in Japanese? たてる. That's the reading of this word as well. If you think about it they're similar!

Name: To Call
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means call so the verb vocab version is to call or to call out. As in "HEY, YOU!"
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji, so you should be good here. Just imagine yourself  calling out to someone: "YO (よ)! You!"

Name: To Confirm
Mnemonic: 確認 is confirmation. When that's a verb, you have to confirm or to verify.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help immensely if you know the word 確認 already as well.

Name: To Conserve
Mnemonic: To preserve and defend something is to conserve and to protect. I won't let you destroy this land I'm trying to protect!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Criticize
Mnemonic: 批判 is criticism so the verb version of that would be to criticize.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will be much easier to read this if you know 批判, as well.

Name: To Cut Off
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cut off so the verb vocab version is to cut off.
ReadingMnemonic: URGH! The reading isn't even the same as 断る, how frustrating. to cut off is read as たつ. Instead of eating too many chocolates and getting cut off, maybe you're eating too many tater tots (たつ). Don't eat so many of those, it's unhealthy. You have to cut off tater tots from your diet so you don't get fat.

Name: To Divide
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means divide so the verb vocab version is to divide or to split something.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the one you'll use here. It's the わ one, though, making it わる.

Name: To Elect
Mnemonic: Election is 選挙 so when you make that word into a verb, you have to elect.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, the reading just comes from 選挙 so if you know that you know this as well.

Name: To Escape
Mnemonic: You escape and run the hell out of there. Basically, you're trying to escape, to flee, or to break out. Pretty simple.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The だつ changes to だっ, though, so be careful of that.

Name: To Excel
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means excel so the verb vocab version is to excel.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "He-e (ひい) is going to excel," you stutter. "He-e is!"

Name: To Finish Something
Mnemonic: Remember 済む and how it means "to come to an end." This is like that, but slightly different. This is to finish something or to settle something, because this is when you're doing the coming to an end action. You can remember this because you're coming in to finish the score uno mas (ます) time. This is the last time.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with 済む, so if you know that you'll be able to finish this vocab.

Name: To Fit Inside
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You don't fit inside your bed anymore. I guess you've grown? Better get out the trusty old saws (おさ) and chop off your footboard.

Name: To Get Mixed Up In
Mnemonic: This one is a little strange. You have 混む (To Be Crowded), 混ぜる (to mix), 混ざる (to get mixed), and now this: 混じる, To Get Mixed Up In. It makes sense because it has to do with mixing, but how to differentiate from the rest? Well, for this one just imagine Jesus (じ) getting mixed up in a pot of soup. He's getting mixed up in this giant pot of soup because someone thinks that if they eat him, they'll gain his powers.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as (almost) all the other 混 verbs. All about mamamamama!

Name: To Get Off
Mnemonic: The kanji is descend, but this verb vocab word is to get off, as in, to get off the train, or to get out of the car. If you think about trains back in the day, you had to descend down to the platform to get out of them, which is how this word became what it is. You know that this word is the "to get off" word because once you get off the train, you enter the real (りる) world, where hardships are real and not as comfy as the train.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is unlike anything you've seen with this kanji. Just think about how you have to get off at O-station. None of the other letters are your stop. Just O-Station (お).

Name: To Grant
Mnemonic: The kanji means "come true" or grant, and this is the transitive verb version of that, making this to grant or to fulfill.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a verb, so it uses the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you already learned this with the kanji, so you should be good to go here!

Name: To Increase Something
Mnemonic: Remember how 増える is "to increase" (as in, something just increases, you aren't doing the increasing yourself). This one is that one, where you're doing the increasing. So, this word means to increase something. You know you're doing the increasing because you said "yes" (やす) to increasing something, and did it yourself.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same like 増える. If you know that vocab word you probably can read this one as well.

Name: To Judge
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means judge so the verb version is to judge.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you go to judge people, there are different types. The one you truly hate the most, however, is the sobber (さば). "The Sobber" is the worst kind. They just sob and sob and sob and it's really hard to move on to your next judging.

Name: To Know
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 心得 means "knowledge"? Well the verb version of that is to know. (You know it deep in your heart.)
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Lead
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lead so the verb vocab version is to lead.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this one is a bit difficult, but there's a hint in the kanji. See the 道 in there on the top? What's the reading for the vocab version of that kanji? It's みち. That's the first part. Now, who are you leading? Let's say you're leading a bee back to its nest, via the road. It's a 道 Bee (みちび)!

Name: To Perform
Mnemonic: If 演 is performance then the verb version of this would be to perform.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading looks weird, but it's actually just the reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Provide
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means provide so the verb vocab version is to provide.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to provide your friends with their own sauna (そな) because they don't want to use your shower. This requires you to go out and buy a sauna for your house (very expensive) just so you can provide your needy friends with what they want (a sauna). Feel angry you have to provide this.

Name: To Raise Something
Mnemonic: The kanji means raise, and this verb is when you do that to something. It's transitive. So this means to raise something. It actually has a pretty wide meaning, and can also mean "raise" in the sense of to cite something, like an example. It can even mean to hold something, like an event.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 挙がる, so if you know that reading you should know this one as well.

Name: To Stretch Over Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stretch, and the verb version means to stretch over something, to spread out, or to be taut, not to be confused with the type of stretching you do after a workout.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine yourself trying to stretch your favorite toy figurine, seeing just how far you can stretch it. With every stretch, you start laughing uncontrollably, HA (は) HA HA HA HA HA. Seems a bit cruel. Are you okay?

Name: Tree Trunk
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: When you cut the tree down to produce a tree trunk, out jumps Mickey Mouse. "WHY YOU CUT DOWN MY TREE BRO?" he yells. I'm Mickey Mouse and I don't stand for this.

Name: Trial
Mnemonic: You're going to get judged times two. Judge and judge again. Once by the judge and another time by the jury. This is a whole trial here.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You hopefully learned this on'yomi for 判 with the word 評判, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case: After your ban (ばん) on the WaniKani forums, you now face trial before none other than Judge Koichi. He's going to decide whether your ban will be lifted or not. Good luck, there's a lot at stake.

Name: Turning Point
Mnemonic: What seasons should you keep an eye on? The seasons that are turning points in your life. Keep an eye on those seasons, because you don't want to miss the critical junctures and milestones.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi of both kanji. You haven't learned that yet for 節, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: The real turning point in your life was when you got yourself a few sheep (ふし). Owning a few sheep was a true milestone for you. Now you have all the wool sweaters and cheese you could ever want!

Name: Unemployed
Mnemonic: When the status of your employment is "nothing" then you're probably unemployed. You're experiencing unemployment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Vampire
Mnemonic: A demon that sucks blood? What mythological creature can you think of that sucks blood? How about a vampire? Them Sparklzzzz!
ReadingMnemonic: 吸血 should be easy for you to read. The 鬼 part uses the reading you already learned with the kanji, き. Easy, no?

Name: Victory
Mnemonic: The superior person wins. They will win the championship and be able to claim victory over all others.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Wonderful
Mnemonic: An element of clear up (like the sky clearing up!) is so wonderful and splendid. Sort of a weird word, but very useful. Just think of that wonderful feeling you get when the sun breaks and things clear up and it's awesome.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a bit weird, too. Luckily, you've learned both of them already. 晴れる is はれる. That's the reading you use here, though は goes to ば.

Name: Above Mentioned
Mnemonic: Above mentions are above mentioned. Look above to see where I mentioned it, okay?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Annual Amount
Mnemonic: The year amount is the yearly amount.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Antenna
Mnemonic: The angle of the touch is important with an antenna. Think about antennae. An ant's antennae wiggle around and move in different angles, touching things, to understand the world around them. Imagine their tiny bug antennae touching your arm to figure out who you are.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. しょく goes to しょっ.

Name: Arm
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Birthday
Mnemonic: Remember how 誕生 is birth? If you add day on there, you have a birthday. Happy birthday!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but with this word 日 uses the kun'yomi ひ, which is turned into び due to rendaku.

Name: Blood Transfusion
Mnemonic: Transport of blood. Only time you do this is during a blood transfusion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Blood Vessel
Mnemonic: The pipes that hold your blood are your blood vessels, or your veins.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The けつ goes to けっ.

Name: Both Arms
Mnemonic: Both arms are both arms!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of the on'yomi reading of 両 and the kun'yomi reading of 腕. You've learned them both, so you know this too!

Name: Boundary
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You walk up to the boundary. You're there to pick something up to take it across. This thing you're smuggling across the boundary is a sockeye (さかい) salmon. You take it across the boundary and sell it for a big profit.

Name: Boundary
Mnemonic: The boundary separates worlds. It is a boundary.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Building
Mnemonic: This is a build thing, or perhaps a building thing. In other words, a building or structure.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading might look a little strange, but makes sense once you get it. You already know that the verb 建てる means "to build", and that a もの is a "thing". Now just remove the る part from the verb to make it a noun, combine it with もの, and we get たてもの! Just remember that it’s all kun’yomi since it comes from the verb 建てる.

Name: Burden
Mnemonic: You lose. Because of that, you have to carry this burden and responsibility.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Burnable Garbage
Mnemonic: Possible to burn ゴミ (garbage). This is burnable garbage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Characteristic
Mnemonic: Your special quality is your characteristics or your traits.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Child
Mnemonic: A child often has to accompany someone else when they go places, because they're… a child. Can't have all those kids running around unaccompanied, can we?
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this one are the kun'yomi readings of each kanji. 子 is こ, like the individual vocab word. 供 is ども, however. Remember this by thinking how much children love domo-kun (ども). Also, 子ども is kind of more "politically correct" with the kana hanging off there. 子供 is still used in a lot of situations, usually stiff ones. The second kanji means servant, and some people don't like that. The second version pops up a decent amount, so it's good to be familiar with that as well.

Name: Confidential
Mnemonic: If intimacy expands to something, that thing is confidential. Try visualizing intimacy as a sort of gooey liquid, expanding and covering a letter, and making that letter confidential.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Counter Plan
Mnemonic: Your versus plan is to attack back. They've already attacked you once, so now it's time for your counter plan.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Difference
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you'd think it's probably an adjective. However in this case, it's a noun. What's the noun form of different? It's difference.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Not different at all.

Name: Discrimination
Mnemonic: You make a distinction between people and based off that you separate the people. This is terrible! Why so much discrimination?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Environment
Mnemonic: The loop that makes up the boundary of this area holds in the environment, at least this particular one.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Essence
Mnemonic: The real quality of something is its essence, or its true nature. Whether it's good or bad is a different story.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Examination
Mnemonic: I will judge and inspect you. This is an examination, so we'll see if you pass.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Export
Mnemonic: When you transport things and they exit from your country, you are exporting them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Farsightedness
Mnemonic: When you can look at far things, but not near things, you have farsightedness, longsightedness, or hyperopia.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji, which you'd know if it wasn't for your farsightedness (go get some glasses so you can read our lessons!).

Name: Fixed Amount
Mnemonic: A determined amount is an amount that is fixed, aka a fixed amount, a fixed sum, or flat rate.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Fixed Quantity
Mnemonic: A determined quantity is a fixed quantity.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Framed Picture
Mnemonic: You previously learned this kanji with three different meanings. In vocabulary form, it just has one of these meanings, framed picture! Similarly, it can just mean picture or frame too.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Fuel
Mnemonic: A material you can burn is called fuel!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Furthermore
Mnemonic: When you're renewing what you're saying, you're adding onto it, which makes this furthermore or further.
ReadingMnemonic: The kanji stands by itself with a particle, meaning that this uses the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You know a person that starts every other sentence by saying "Furthermore," and that's... Sarah (さら). Really feel yourself getting annoyed with this Sarah for starting every other sentence with "Furthermore, ...!" Just note that 更に is often written in kana, as さらに, especially in casual writing!

Name: Good Quality
Mnemonic: Good quality is always good quality. Don't skimp!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Government Office
Mnemonic: A government government office is a government office. Did I mention government?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Half Price
Mnemonic: A half amount sale is when things are half price. Cheap!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: High Price
Mnemonic: A tall value. If you paid for something that had a tall value, it would have a high price.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

Name: Homemade
Mnemonic: By my self at home I manufactured this. It is homemade.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: In Charge
Mnemonic: You carry everyone else and you are always right. With these traits, you are in charge.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Intersection
Mnemonic: You mix, but there's a distinction as to where you mix at this point. Where is this point? It can be found when two streets cross, at an intersection, also known as a crossing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Judgment
Mnemonic: This word has judge and judge in it, so it has something to do with judgment. It's usually used in sports, so it's the referee or umpire, depending on your sport of choice.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for rendaku turning はん into ぱん (as is so often the case after ん).

Name: Large Amount
Mnemonic: A many amount is a large amount or large sum.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Large Quantity
Mnemonic: A large quantity is a large quantity. Kind of like the large number of words you're learning here now. A huge amount. Well done you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Late Riser
Mnemonic: Remember 寝坊 and how it means oversleep? Someone who oversleeps in the morning is someone who's a late riser.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the vocab words 朝 and 寝坊 put together into one. So long as you know them separately you should know them together too!

Name: Layer Of
Mnemonic: This is a word that's attached to other things indicating the layer of something (or just layer). It has essentially the same meaning as the kanji it comes from, layer.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. It's treated like a jukugo reading because it's normally attached to things.

Name: Left Arm
Mnemonic: Your left arm is your left arm.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, but it uses kun'yomi instead of on'yomi, so watch out for that!

Name: Long Sleeves
Mnemonic: Long sleeves are long sleeves.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!

Name: Low Price
Mnemonic: A cheap valued item comes at a low price. What a good deal!
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

Name: Made In China
Mnemonic: China (中国) manufactured items are made in China.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know the word 中国 already.

Name: Made In Japan
Mnemonic: Things that are manufactured in Japan (日本) are made in Japan. Good quality stuff, that is.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know how to read 日本 already.

Name: Made In USA
Mnemonic: America manufactured is something that is made in USA or made in America.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Mail Order
Mnemonic: Things you sell that pass through the world to get to you are probably mail order. You order them and they get zoomed off to you, passing through all kinds of space to arrive at your door.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Management
Mnemonic: The pipe of reason. Imagine someone holding this pipe. It always leads to the correct decision because it is the pipe of reason. Those who have this pipe are in a higher rank than you. They are the management, and by using this pipe of reason they're able to make good management decisions.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Manufacturing
Mnemonic: A place where you manufacture and make is a place where manufacturing and production are done. So many things getting made.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Martial Arts
Mnemonic: If you take the road of the military you're going to have to fight a lot. Back in the day, this involved learning martial arts to fight with. Remember, just wax off.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Material Quality
Mnemonic: A product's quality is in its material quality. If the materials aren't any good then the product isn't either.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Metropolitan Government Building
Mnemonic: The metropolis agency is the government that controls the metropolitan area. Their office is in the metropolitan government building.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Metropolitan Police Department
Mnemonic: They warn, they look at crime, and they're an agency of the government. They are the metropolitan police department.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Model
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: What model catapult (かた) is this? Is it the trebuchet or the mangonel type? Only one model can aim at your ex's window with the right trajectory. Catapult model matters!

Name: Monthly Amount
Mnemonic: A month's amount is the monthly amount.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Much More
Mnemonic: One layer more? One whole layer? It must be much more important than we thought. Let's pay all the more attention, in that case.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. いち goes to いっ.

Name: Narrow
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of narrow? It's narrow.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji, so you're good to go here. It may be a narrow way of thinking about this kanji, but it will help you out the most.

Name: National Border
Mnemonic: A country boundary is that country's national border. Be careful about crossing it if you're carrying bananas. The border police seem to hate when you tell them you're carrying a banana in your pants when they ask you if you're bringing any fruits back. No idea why.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The こく gets shortened to a nice little こっ.

Name: National Holiday
Mnemonic: A celebrate day is a day you get off to celebrate something awesome. More specifically, this is known as a national holiday or a public holiday.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: National Police Agency
Mnemonic: Unlike the 警視庁, who look at things, this is just the police officer (警察) agency. Just the general police agency of the whole country, making them part of the National Police Agency.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Nearsightedness
Mnemonic: When you can look at things that are near well but you can't see things far away, you have nearsightedness, shortsightedness, or myopia. Good to get those eyes checked out occasionally.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Nonburnable Garbage
Mnemonic: These are not burnable garbages (ごみ). Pay attention to this on signs when you throw things away. You want to put the right things into nonburnable garbage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Offering
Mnemonic: When you present something and offer it to someone, you're kindly offering and providing it to them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Open For Business
Mnemonic: Remember how 営業 means "business"? Well, if you're in the middle of running a business, it means you're open for business.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 営業 first as well.

Name: Past Tense
Mnemonic: The past shape is how things were in the past. To describe those things (like you would with an adjective, aka 形容詞), you'd use past tense.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Phenomenon
Mnemonic: A present time phenomenon is a phenomenon whether it's in the present or in the future or in the past.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Pipe
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: "That's coo' だ," you like to say in response to pipes. You've never seen pipes before, which makes them pretty cool to you. You've been using an outhouse your whole life, so pipes are pretty neat.

Name: Place To Put Something
Mnemonic: 置く is to put down something. So a location where you put something down is a place to put something.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings. 置き comes from 置く, and you learned 場's reading with 場所, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case: You're looking for a place to put something that goes "baa" (ば). Your pet sheep won't stop baaing and it's getting annoying, so you want to put it somewhere. "Baa, baa," it bleats irritatingly as you search high and low for a good place to put it.

Name: Price Tag
Mnemonic: A price tag is... a price tag!
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You learned the kun'yomi reading for 値 in the vocabulary word 値 (ね). You learned the reading for 札 in the vocabulary 札 (ふだ). Put them together and you have ねふだ.

Name: Product
Mnemonic: Manufactured goods are manufactured goods. What does that end up being? A product.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Prototype
Mnemonic: The original model of something isn't usually very good. It's rough. It's a prototype.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Quality
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Quantity
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Question
Mnemonic: A quality problem is worth a question. A low quality problem however... don't ask the question. There are stupid questions, after all.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Record
Mnemonic: Please write down and put on paper the facts, so we have a record of them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Recorded
Mnemonic: When you give information its place, it's put on record. That means it has been recorded or published in a particular publication.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Remaining Amount
Mnemonic: The remainder amount is the remaining amount, aka the balance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Rooting Section

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 応援 is a word you've seen before, so if you know that this word will be easier.

Name: Rule
Mnemonic: A standard law is the rule or law you have to follow. With these standard laws comes discipline. If you don't have these it will be chaos!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Rule
Mnemonic: A standard rule is just one of the rules or regulations. Nothing weird about these rules.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Sales

Name: Samurai

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Sense Of Sight

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Short Sleeves
Mnemonic: Half sleeves is just another name for short sleeves.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for 半 and the kun'yomi reading for 袖. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this word.

Name: Shoulder
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Stock
Mnemonic: A stock ritual is the dance we do in the modern world around stocks and shares of different companies. Buy! Sell! Buy! Sell!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

Name: Stock
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji.

Name: Subjective
Mnemonic: 主観 is subjectivity. So when something moves towards subjectivity it is becoming subjective.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know 主観.

Name: Target
Mnemonic: The versus phenomenon is what you're going up against. It's your target because you're heading towards this phenomenon you're versusing against.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Time Difference
Mnemonic: The time distinction is how you tell apart time zones. It is the time difference.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
