Name: To Be Delivered
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deliver so the verb vocab version here is to be delivered or to arrive. You know this one is "to be delivered" (aka it's just getting delivered, you aren't doing the delivery) because when this item arrives at your house you say "coo'" (く), it arrived.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji: とど!

Name: To Be Different
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means different so the verb vocab version is to be different... and of course, to be different is also to be wrong in Japan. Don't be different!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. It's not different at all.

Name: To Be Placed On
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. It's also an intransitive verb, meaning the action happens on its own, you don't do it. The kanji itself means place on, and this means to be placed on.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: A reporter asks for your conversation to be placed on record, to which you respond "NO (の)!" Koichi doesn't want everyone to know that he didn’t notice a cactus had been placed on his seat until…

Name: To Build Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means construct and the verb version is to build something or to construct something.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to build something called a key zoo (きず). Which is a zoo for keys instead of animals. So it's a bunch of keys in cages, basically. Hmm, how artsy of you... Hopefully people get it. Isn't it a bit avant-garde to construct something like a key zoo?

Name: To Burn Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means burn and the verb vocab version is to burn something, or to set on fire.
ReadingMnemonic: This is when you're burning something. To remember this meaning, you have to remember the も part. So, just think of your friend Moe (も), and how you're going to burn him... uh... just a little bit.

Name: To Carry
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carry so the verb vocab version is to carry. This has to do with carrying something literal, unlike 担う which is not necessarily literal (you'll learn it later). And in this case, you carry it on your shoulder(s). You can remember that it's literal from the reading mnemonic, which has you carrying literal cats on your shoulders.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You love to carry things, especially cats (かつ). You hoist them up onto your shoulders and carry them all around town.

Name: To Celebrate
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means celebrate, so the verb vocab version is to celebrate. When you burn this word, you should 祝う!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Everyone's here to celebrate, and all you can say is "Eek, wha...!?" (いわ). All your friends and family have come to celebrate your birthday, but you had no idea. Still confused and processing the situation, you keep saying, "Eek... what?" The surprise was a complete success!

Name: To Develop
Mnemonic: Let's depart from this place and expand it out. To do that we'll have to develop it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はつ gets shortened to はっ, though.

Name: To Ignore
Mnemonic: I will look at nothing. I am going to ignore you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Make An Offering
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means offer, and this verb version means to make an offering.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. It shares its reading with the word 備える, which you learned a level ago, but in case you need a reminder, here it is: What's the best way for your servants to make an offering? When they offer up their sauna (そな)! You really value a warm and relaxing sauna session at the end of the day.

Name: To Measure
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means quantity, but you don't "to quantity." To figure out the quantity, however, you have to measure / to weigh whatever it is you want to get the quantity of.
ReadingMnemonic: You need to measure the quantity of something, but don't have a scale or anything. Luckily, you are quite the hacker (はか) and hack together a scale using only rubber bands and beans.

Name: To Mention
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mention so the verb vocab version is to mention.
ReadingMnemonic: I have to mention this thing... "NO," (の) you quickly respond. I don't want you mentioning that here and now.

Name: Too Much
Mnemonic: 過ぎる is to pass. When you pass what is needed, what are you left with? Just this word: too much. This can also mean after, as in "after 5pm", and past, as in "past sixty".
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 過ぎる. Know that and you know too much. Dial it down to get 過ぎ.

Name: To Oversleep
Mnemonic: 寝坊 is oversleep. Make that into a verb and you have to oversleep.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It also just takes the reading from 寝坊.

Name: To Point At
Mnemonic: When you want to use your finger to explain the distinction between more than one thing, you need to point at it. Otherwise the person you're talking to won't be able to tell which one you're talking about.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Propose
Mnemonic: You remember 提案, which means proposition? Make that into a verb and you have to propose.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Root For
Mnemonic: 応援 is aid and root for, but for this verb the "root for" one is going to be more on the money. You can call this to root for, to cheer on or to cheer for.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 応援. It's also just the on'yomi readings you learned.

Name: To Run A Business
Mnemonic: The word 営業 is business. The verb version of that (to do a business) becomes to run a business.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, it shares the reading with 営業.

Name: To Shine
Mnemonic: The kanji is distinction, and the verb version here means… a million things. Let's just focus on a few common meanings. Things with distinction tend to stick out from the others. They tend to shine, you know? And if you imagine shining a beam of light on something, that light tends to project or to extend outward. It sticks out, shines on something, then makes that thing more distinct too.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading of the kanji is actually the same as the reading for this word, making things easy (both on'yomi and kun'yomi are さ).

Name: To Stab
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stab so the verb vocab version must also be to stab.
ReadingMnemonic: If you're going to get stabbed, don't get stabbed two (つ) times. You can remember that this is the "two time stab" stab because it has a hole that's big. The hole is big because you got stabbed twice.

Name: To Support
Mnemonic: To support and aid is to support.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Total
Mnemonic: All of the amount is your total.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Touch Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means touch so the verb vocab version is to touch something.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You only like to touch things that are sour (さわ). Lemons, limes, grapefruits, you name it. There's something about sour things that just makes you want to touch them.

Name: Touch
Mnemonic: Your feeling of touch is your touch sense (or simply just touch).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Undress
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means undress and the verb is to undress.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you go to undress your goal is to become nude (ぬ).

Name: Tourist
Mnemonic: Sightseeing (観光) guests are tourists and sightseers.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 観光 as well.

Name: Trade Show
Mnemonic: I want to expand my business. I want to show my goods. I want to do this in a place where everyone meets up to do these things. You can do this in a trade show.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Traditional
Mnemonic: If 伝統 is "tradition," then adding a 的 (-al) to it would make it traditional.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Transportation
Mnemonic: You want to transport something by sending it? Well, that's transportation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Typical
Mnemonic: You learned that 的 on the end of a word means “-al” or “-like”. So what is rule model -like? It’s a model that follows all the rules. It's the normal model. It’s typical.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Unfolding
Mnemonic: To expand and open. Just imagine something happening like this. This is when something is unfolding or in development.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Values
Mnemonic: These views that have merit (価値) are your values.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Vending Machine
Mnemonic: Automatic (自動) sell sell machine. The machine sells things by itself, basically. This is a vending machine. There is a shorter version of this, but good to learn the long one first :)
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Remember those, and you'll be fine here.

Name: Vice President
Mnemonic: You know about 大統領 (president), right? Well, this is the vice version of the president, aka the vice president.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know the word 大統領 first, though.

Name: Waist
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Weapon
Mnemonic: A container used by the military is probably going to be used as a weapon. After all, that's what the military does... weapons.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Weather
Mnemonic: The energy phenomenon. That's when energy is doing stuff in the sky and nobody understands it. That's the weather for you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Wooden
Mnemonic: Tree manufactured items are wooden / made from wood.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Wristwatch
Mnemonic: Remember how 時計 is watch? An arm is now there too, making this a wristwatch.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the words 腕 (same reading as what you learned with the kanji) as well as the reading for 時計. Just don't forget that rendaku!

Name: Writing Down
Mnemonic: When you Write down and mention what happened, you're writing down a description and account of it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Absolutely
Mnemonic: Extinction will happen as you go versus extinction. It will happen absolutely. It will happen without fail. There's nothing you can do to stop extinction.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Be careful though, 絶 is normally read as ぜつ, but in this case it is shortened to ぜっ.

Name: Actively Working
Mnemonic: At the present time you're providing a service, so you're actively working. 現役 means you have a certain role (such as school teacher or a high school student, etc.) and you're still active in that role, as opposed to being retired or having graduated.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You learned the readings for both of these, but 役 uses a less common reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this: You're actively working at the 駅 (えき) and you plan to remain active there forever! You sure do love that 駅, it's like you're inseparable.

Name: Actress
Mnemonic: Remember how 男優 was "actor"? Well, I bet you can extrapolate what this one means because it now has woman in it. This is an actress.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Affiliation
Mnemonic: Your place of belonging describes your affiliation. It’s where you belong to.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: An Effect
Mnemonic: The fruit of something that's effective is an effect.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Arrest
Mnemonic: When you apprehend and catch someone, that leads to an arrest.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Ballot
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It can also be a vote, because that's what ballots tend to do.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Bonus
Mnemonic: It's a prize where you are given gold. In business, this is called a bonus. You didn't expect it (not your salary) and it is given to you (and is gold, if you're lucky).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Business Card
Mnemonic: Take your name and stab someone with it... using your business card. Your business card has your name on it. Also, you "stab" it at people who are willing to take it and read it. Not a real stab, but a metaphorical.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 刺 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: After doing business in Japan, you'll have so many business cards you can count them like sheep (し) when you're trying to get to sleep. One business card, two business cards… See them leaping over the sheep fence as you begin to nod off.

Name: Business Climate
Mnemonic: Take a look at this scene and the condition it’s in. This is the climate of the situation, but more specifically the business climate. This word is really only used to talk about the state of business and economic stuff, and tends to appear in technical writing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Candidate
Mnemonic: The candidate is someone who's a supplement to the entire political system. Despite being a supplement, they're still a candidate nonetheless, unless they can win!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Climate
Mnemonic: The energy of the climate is the climate. High energy? Climate. Low energy. Climate.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Clothes
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: What are clothes, really? Some people say clothes are the chromosomes (ころも) of your personal style — each garment carries information about your unique identity. Other people say clothes are simply the key to not being nude (きぬ). What do you think? Both ころも and きぬ mean "clothes," but these usages are old-fashioned. Also note that the more modern meaning of "coating" or "breading" uses only the ころも reading!

Name: Composition
Mnemonic: If you set up something so that it becomes a certain way, that's the composition of this thing. That's its structure.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Condition
Mnemonic: The condition condition is the condition. It's also the circumstances if you can remember that. It's like saying "What's the condition!??" which is similar to saying "What's the circumstances?"
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Cool
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cool? It's cool.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this one too. If you need a refresher, here's a mnemonic to help you: Looking for a place that's cool and refreshing? Go to the Sue Zoo (すず). Imagine swimming with Sue the penguin in the refreshing water of her pool. Feels good!

Name: Criminal Complaint
Mnemonic: I've announced I'm going to sue you. To do this, I need to file a criminal complaint against you. What's the nature of my complaint? Uh... You suck.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Criminal Investigation
Mnemonic: When you search and inspect things, you are probably part of a criminal investigation. You may even be subject to a manhunt.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Custom
Mnemonic: I've learned to be accustomed to this. It has become my custom and habit.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Deadline
Mnemonic: The period of time limit is the deadline for a certain thing. Alternatively, this can describe a term for something, like the repayment of debts, or some sort of due date.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Despair
Mnemonic: When hope has died out, you have no more hope, only despair.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Discount
Mnemonic: Divide that price and pull it apart. You only have to pay for one part! What a discount.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. き from ひき kind of just gets stuffed into the 引 and hidden away like that strange collection of fingernails you have hidden in your closet drawer inside of a 35mm film container. Also remember that the reading gets changed to びき here because of that pesky rendaku.

Name: Division
Mnemonic: Take a district and divide it and you'll end up with many smaller divisions and segments.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Earth
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Although this is a single kanji all alone, it uses the on'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck.

Name: Echo
Mnemonic: An anti echo is still an echo! It's just going back and forth with a normal echo. Together they get a weird reverberation going.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Efficiency
Mnemonic: Your effective percent shows how effective you are. If you're at an effective percent of 80%, that's your efficiency.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Elderly
Mnemonic: As the years get distributed, you slowly turn into an elderly senior, proud of your old age.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はい goes to a ぱい, because… elderly persons love pie (ぱい), right?

Name: Fine
Mnemonic: Bind and set up everything so it is fine and fairly  sufficient.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The けつ shortens to けっ.

Name: Fire Prevention
Mnemonic: Trying to prevent fire? Better get into fire prevention.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: First Volume
Mnemonic: The above scroll is the top scroll, the one you read first. It's the first volume. Many Japanese books come in parts, so look for this if you want to get the first one.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Fluke
Mnemonic: Somebody tried to mug Remi (まぐれ), your friend, but by chance they managed to escape! Their escape was a fluke, but what a relief they didn't get mugged.

Name: For Every
Mnemonic: Add a に to every and you get for every. This means something happens at intervals of a certain time frame or milestone, like once every year, month, day, etc.!
ReadingMnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi reading of 毎, which you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: For every kanji you burn, you go to (ごと) Tokyo Disneyland as a reward. It's a bit of an expensive habit, but I think you deserve it.

Name: Fresh
Mnemonic: New and fresh is fresh (has to be new if you want it to be fresh, after all).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Fresh Fish
Mnemonic: Fresh fish is fresh fish (and the best fish, nom nom nom).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Full House
Mnemonic: Full of members, so sorry, no more room. This place is a full house. That means there is no vacancy here.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Full Moon
Mnemonic: The full moon is a full moon.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Government Business
Mnemonic: A public task is going to be government business. You have to think of this public as government to know the meaning of this word easily.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Honest
Mnemonic: All your dishonest elements are fixed, making you more honest than ever.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this is a bit of a weird one. It uses on'yomi for 素, then it uses the kun'yomi for 直. You know both readings, but it's all a little strange, so here's a mnemonic help you: To present yourself as an honest person, you should hurry up and change into a suit now (すなお). We all know that people in suits look more honest and upfront, so go get suited up now!

Name: Honor
Mnemonic: When a light shines on how much you've prospered, it's a great honor. You don't feel like you did anything so special, but it's really a privilege for the light to come down on you like this.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Huge
Mnemonic: Something that is endlessly big isn't just big, but huge and enormous.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Implication
Mnemonic: Include your ideas here, but think about the implications they will result in too, especially considering you're just including them now. They have implications!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Infinite
Mnemonic: The limit is nothing. What? No limit? That means it will never stop! It is infinite!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Influence
Mnemonic: In the shadows you still echo. Your echo leaves the shadows and hits people, creating an influence on them. You're like the shadow person pulling the strings, making things do what you want... influencing them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Irregularity
Mnemonic: You know that 規則 means "rule" or "regulation." So a not "rule" or "regulation" is an irregularity.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Junior
Mnemonic: The comrade who's behind you is your junior.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 後 is the long こう reading, though. Just think of your junior being こういち.

Name: Last Volume
Mnemonic: The scroll that's below is the last scroll you read, making it the last volume.
ReadingMnemonic: The 下 uses the alternative reading of げ but 巻 is all good and normal.

Name: Lawsuit
Mnemonic: If you sue and bring about a lawsuit, you are bringing about a lawsuit.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Leather Jacket
Mnemonic: 革 is leather and ジャン is short for ジャンパー (Jumper, like a jacket). So, put those together and you have a leather jacket.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the vocab word 革, because this word is like two separate words put together (so it's treated as single words too, giving it that reading).

Name: Limit
Mnemonic: As you reach the limit of your world, you face your limit and confront your limitations.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Manure
Mnemonic: Your fee for being obese is lots of manure coming out of your butt. If you eat a lot you'll poop a lot of manure.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Metal
Mnemonic: Even gold belongs to a family... the family of metals!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Multiplication
Mnemonic: If you try to calculate something, but instead you feel the urge to hang your teacher, you know you're doing multiplication. It's hard, guys. Like really hard. The hardest kind of math of them all. But you can do it! No one needs to get hanged. And don't hang your head in defeat either. Multiply those numbers like a boss! Hang the numbers instead!!
ReadingMnemonic: This is the kun'yomi reading for 掛 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

Name: Murder By Strangling
Mnemonic: A strangle kill is murder by strangling, or strangling to death.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Nagasaki Prefecture
Mnemonic: Long Cape Prefecture. This will make more sense when you look at the reading. Hint: It's Nagasaki Prefecture.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are 長 from 長い, normal 崎 and normal 県.

Name: Obesity
Mnemonic: Does being obese mean you're always full? Of course not. But clearly that's what the people who coined the Japanese word for obesity thought... You can see there are some implicit biases in these kanji!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Okayama Castle
Mnemonic: This is the same 岡山 that you learned with 岡山県. So what's Okayama castle? Yep, Okayama Castle!
ReadingMnemonic: When 城 is added to a place name like this, it takes the on'yomi. You haven't learned this yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The lord of Okayama Castle is none other than Joe (じょう), your local farmhand friend. How a farmhand like Joe managed to become the lord of a Japanese castle is beyond even us, but it's Lord Joe to you now.

Name: One Volume
Mnemonic: One scroll is one scroll back in the day, but now it refers to books and means one volume.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. いち goes to いっ.

Name: Pattern
Mnemonic: 様 uses its alternative meaning "manner" here, so we have an imitation manner. An imitation of the same manner over and over creates a pattern.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 様 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. You see a pattern in your yogurt (よう). The yogurt is an imitation of life. So deep, man. So deep.

Name: Pay Cut
Mnemonic: A decrease in salary is a pay cut.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Perfect Score
Mnemonic: Full points are when you get a perfect score.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Plastic Model
Mnemonic: An imitation model is obviously not the real thing. It's (usually) a plastic model or just a model figure or something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Plump
Mnemonic: If you're plentiful and full, you could say you're plump or full-figured... in other words, you're not a snack, you're the Whole. Damn. Meal.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Receipt
Mnemonic: Please accept this territory. Oh, you want some writing to make the deal official? Okay, here's a receipt.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Recession
Mnemonic: A "not condition" is where nothing is going well. How are things going? Not well. The condition is bad. We're in a recession.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Regular
Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 規則 and 正しい, that you learned already. If you follow the rules in the correct order, everything will stay regular and orderly.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of the words 規則 and 正しい, which you learned already, so you should be able to read this word too.

Name: Retirement
Mnemonic: You hide away but you're alive. You've lived your life, so now it's time to hide and enjoy your retirement by making your retreat from working life.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Revolutionary
Mnemonic: A person who lives in a revolution (革命) house is a revolutionary. They want government change! They want to take down the people in power!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course it will help to know 革命 already as well.

Name: Rich
Mnemonic: This is the same as the kanji 豊, making it plentiful and abundant. It can also mean rich or wealthy.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You discovered plentiful yurt tacos (ゆた) inside the yurt you’re staying in. Picture yourself savoring the richly flavored yurt tacos beside your yurt while being immersed in the abundant nature around you.

Name: Salary
Mnemonic: Your salary fee are the moneys you get for your salary. These are your wages and pay.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Satisfied
Mnemonic: I am full and sufficient. I am satisfied.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that the reading for 足 in this one is ぞく because of that pesky rendaku.

Name: Scene
Mnemonic: When light shines on a scene, it's still a scene. The light is here to create some drama, also making this a sight or a spectacle.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Scenery
Mnemonic: The scene's color is the scenery, landscape, and view. Looking good, scenery!
ReadingMnemonic: You haven't learned either of these readings yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember them: You're admiring the scenery and you notice key marks all over everything. You realize it's that girl who keys everything and you say to yourself kay she keyed (けしき) that, kay she keyed (けしき) this.

Name: Seasonal Climate
Mnemonic: The time's climate is the seasonal climate, or seasonal weather.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Second Volume
Mnemonic: The number two scroll is the second volume. With Japanese books, they often come in pieces with groups of three being common. This represents the second volume.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Senior
Mnemonic: My comrade who came before me is my senior, my senpai (せんぱい).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well, but just remember that the second kanji is read as ぱい because of the rendaku on はい.

Name: Shadow
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Just imagine the shadow of a cage (かげ). Lots of long bars. Looks good.

Name: Shoulder Stiffness
Mnemonic: When your shoulders get a little こり, it means you've got shoulder stiffness or a stiff neck.
ReadingMnemonic: You already know the reading of 肩, and this is just that with some hiragana added on!

Name: The Weather
Mnemonic: Heaven's climate is the weather.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Absorb
Mnemonic: If 吸収 is "absorption" the verb version is to absorb.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Be Built
Mnemonic: You know that 建てる is "to build." This is similar to that, but it's the version where you're not doing the building. Something is just getting built. That's why this word means to be built. You can remember that by thinking about how two (つ) buildings were built without you noticing. These two buildings just seemed to pop up out of nowhere and, unfortunately, they're now blocking your view.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is shared with 建てる, so if you know 建てる then you should be able to read this word as well.

Name: To Be Called
Mnemonic: If 呼ぶ is "to call" then this is something similar. This is when you are called by someone (and you're not doing the calling). This word is to be called.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is shared with 呼ぶ, so remember that and you'll be able to read this too.

Name: To Be Caught
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means catch, so this intransitive verb version is to be caught.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is つか, so to remember that with to be caught, think about how you're a police officer chasing some criminals. Unfortunately, they split up into two cars (つか), meaning they can't both be caught. Guess you should have called for backup...

Name: To Become Accustomed To
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accustomed so the verb vocab version is to become accustomed.
ReadingMnemonic: What have you become accustomed to? All the Narwhals (な) you hang out with. They take some getting used to.

Name: To Be Divided
Mnemonic: Remember how 割る is "to divide"? Now you're learning the intransitive version. Instead of you doing the dividing, something just gets divided or split up. So this is to be divided or to be split.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is shared with 割る.

Name: To Be Effective
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means effective. The verb vocab version is to be effective or to work effectively (since "to effective" doesn't make sense).
ReadingMnemonic: What is particularly effective? It's your key (き). It's effective at opening your house door.

Name: To Be Involved
Mnemonic: You know that the kanji means connection. This is a verb, so one meaning is to be connected. It can also mean to be involved and to be related. Basically things that have to do with being connected with something else.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. It's exactly the same as the reading for 関わる, so here's a reminder of that mnemonic to help you: Remember the "Kaw Kaw (かか) Crow Gang"? They are bad news, always eating from garbage and squawking "kaw kaw"... You don't want to be involved with them.

Name: To Care About
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means care so the verb vocab version is to care about.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Do you care a lot about grammar? I don't care, unless it has to do with commas (かま). Then I do flip out.

Name: To Catch
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means catch so the verb version is to catch.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

Name: To Cross
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transit, which is just another word for crossing through or crossing over. That's why this word is to cross or to cross over.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Echo
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means echo so the verb is to echo.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing...

Name: To Exist
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means alive and the verb version means to exist or to be, for anything that is alive and moving, like people and animals.
ReadingMnemonic: Do you know the word いる? This is the kanji version! If you've been studying Japanese up to this point you probably already know that word. You can associate these two things together into one and remember the reading at the same time!

Name: To Hang Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hang so the verb vocab version is to hang something or to hang up something (as in to hang it up by a hook).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Hide Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hide and the verb vocab version is to hide something or to conceal something.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Hide your cock (かく)! You have a ton of roosters but you don't want people to know about them, so you gotta hide your cocks. What did you think I was talking about?

Name: To Include
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means include so the verb vocab version is to include or to contain.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: They don't want to include you in their game? Well, "F*** (ふく) you!" you yell at them, because they wouldn't include you.

Name: To Increase
Mnemonic: It's another verb with the kanji 増! This one means to increase too! But!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: What increases with time? Your love for your mama (ま)! Your love for her will grow and grow the older you get! I love you, mama!

Name: To Limit
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means limit so the verb vocab version is to limit. It is often used in the passive form 限られる, which means to be limited, implying that the limiting is being done by someone else.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: to limit things, you have something called a car (か) guillotine (ぎ) which you drive around limiting everything with.

Name: To Look Out Over
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji mean see and transit, but the vocab isn't quite the same. You are going to transit your eyes over an area to take in what you see. So you're really going to look out over everything. This word is usually used when you're looking at landscapes or a really large area.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Too Late
Mnemonic: Now isn’t good enough for renewal. It’s already too late. The time has passed now.
ReadingMnemonic: You might be tempted to read this with on’yomi, but this is actually 今 and 更に put together, just without the に particle at the end. Try to remember it in this way, or just make a mental note to use kun’yomi here!

Name: To Persevere
Mnemonic: 張る is to stretch. You're stubborn and want to stretch out what you're doing right now. Although you're stubborn, you keep doing it. You persevere. That's why this word is to persevere or to do one's best.
ReadingMnemonic: This word gets its reading from the kanji 頑 and the verb 張る put together, but the 張る part gets rendaku'd to ばる. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember that rendaku: When you have to persevere, you always scream baa (ば)! Not sure why, you just think when someone has to do one's best, screaming "baa!" is a great motivator. Kinda like how weightlifters and tennis players grunt when they're doing their best, you know? Baa!

Name: To Prepare
Mnemonic: You've seen that 準備 is preparations. This is the verb version, so you get yourself to prepare.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 準備.

Name: To Pull Something Out
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pull out so the verb vocab version is to pull something out.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Just go ahead and extract it out of your memory so you can use it here.

Name: To Question Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means problem and this verb means to question something. That's because when you want to get to the bottom of a problem, you question things.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading: It's okay to question something, but you should be careful not to step on someone else's toes (と) by doing so. Questioning certain things can offend people, especially when they have strong feelings about it! So be careful about those toes.

Name: To Replace
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means replace so the verb vocab version is to replace. You know that you're doing the replacing because of the air (える). You're replacing the air as quickly as you can because if you don't you wouldn't be able to breathe in this small room.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Roll
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scroll. But, you don't "to scroll." What do you do to scrolls, though? You roll them up, making this word "to roll."
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you are rolling up is your ma (ま). She's going wild again, so you throw her into a blanket and roll her up to hold her down.

Name: To Search For
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means search so the verb vocab version is to search for or to seek.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're searching all around for a "sagger" (さが) on your body. This is a flap of skin that is sagging on your body really far, and you probably should get it removed.

Name: To Show
Mnemonic: This is the transitive version of 現れる (to appear), so rather than something appearing on its own, you’re making it appear. So this word means to show or to reveal, but it’s usually used in set phrases like 姿を現す (to show up) or 正体を現す (to reveal one's true nature).
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with 現れる, but here's a mnemonic to help you: The monster under your bed decides to show you its true form. "You… are a walrus (あらわ)?" you ask, shocked. Evidently, the monster under your bed was actually just a walrus who got in one day when you left the window open. You feel silly for being scared of it for so long, but you're glad it finally showed itself to you.

Name: To Store
Mnemonic: When you obtain something you need to keep it safe, so you decide to store it somewhere. Then you can always go back and look at the thing you managed to achieve or  to score, and no one can take it from you.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with 収まる, but here's a mnemonic to remind you just in case: You need to store all of the old saws (おさ). You were able to finish and to achieve everything you wanted with them, so it's time to put them away so they'll be safe.

Name: To Strangle
Mnemonic: The kanji means strangle and this vocab is the verb version of that: to strangle. It’s usually used in the phrase 首を絞める, which also means “to strangle.”
ReadingMnemonic: The thing that is threatening to strangle you is actually a sheep (し)! The sheep comes to your house and says, "here's the sheep mail!" and then tries to strangle you. It puts its hard feet on your neck though it's pretty ineffective.

Name: To Sue
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sue so the verb vocab version is to sue.
ReadingMnemonic: YOU TAKE (うった) MY THINGS, I AM GOING TO SUE YOU!

Name: To Supplement
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means supplement so the verb vocab version is to supplement.
ReadingMnemonic: Oh, gee, now (おぎな) you're going to supplement it? That would have been helpful earlier. Might help to say "oh gee now" with a ぎ sound instead of "ji" sound out loud, too. This is a tricky reading, won't be learned too easily, so think about it a bit now.

Name: To Surpass
Mnemonic: This is the verb version of the kanji superior, so it means to surpass. Someone who is superior is always going to surpass and to excel beyond others. That's what makes them so superior in the first place!
ReadingMnemonic: If you want to surpass everyone, you have to be super good (すぐ) at stuff. Like, super good at everything. Not pretty good, not really good — super good. Only then can you surpass all the others.

Name: To Take Down
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned that 降りる means "to get off." This is when you're helping something else descend down from something, not when you yourself are getting down. So it means to take down or to lower.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you already learned. Go you!

Name: To Vote
Mnemonic: Throw a ballot in the ballot box to vote.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. You may have to think back to some other words using 投 to remember the on'yomi reading, 投資 for example.

Name: To Wring Out
Mnemonic: You've learned that the kanji 絞 means strangle. 絞る, on the other hand, means to wring out or to squeeze something like a towel, or to narrow down ideas.
ReadingMnemonic: Your friend wants to wring out a towel, but before she does so she bows (しぼ) to the towel to show her respect for it.

Name: Tutor
Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 家庭 and 教師. A "teacher" who only teaches when you're with your "family" is known as a tutor. They don't teach you at school, they're a private teacher that comes to your home to help you learn.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Vivid
Mnemonic: Alright, so it's not quite the same, but something that is fresh is also vivid and splendid. I know those are a couple things I'd associate with freshness. Try to make the connection here before moving on.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: This vivid and splendid fresh fish is MINE! You grab the other (あざ) one that's not as vivid and splendid. This one is mine.

Name: Waterproof
Mnemonic: Something that prevents water is waterproof and watertight. Time to take a bath with my 防水 cell phone...
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Werewolf
Mnemonic: A person wolf  is a werewolf. This word is less common than 狼男, but it's used more and more thanks to the card game of the same name!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for 狼 (wolf) yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember that, as well as which on'yomi to use for 人: There's a werewolf in front of you wearing  jeans and eating roe (じんろう). This is typical behavior for werewolves, as I'm sure you know.

Name: Accident
Mnemonic: An occurrence that only results because of circumstances is also called an accident. You didn't want this bad thing to happen, it was just an occurrence of circumstance! Everything aligned in the worst way.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Again
Mnemonic: Again with that occurrence? That occurrence has now happened again.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that there's a い hiding in there!

Name: Alone
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is different from the one you learned (this is kun'yomi). There's an easy way to remember it, though. 一人 and 独り share the same readings and mean almost the same thing. Just try to remember that this ひとり is used to emphasize solitude.

Name: A Mistake
Mnemonic: We waited an interval of time, and at each interval it was different. They're all supposed to be the same. Is there some kind of mistake?
ReadingMnemonic: Take the reading of 間 (ま from 間に合う) and 違う and you'll have the reading for this word too.

Name: Beast
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: A beast... what do you think of when you think of a beast? How about a thing (物, もの) full of fur (毛, け), aka a けもの (fur thing)? A beast is a fur thing, and in Japanese that's けもの. Punnnns.

Name: Beasts
Mnemonic: Things that are of the beast type or animal type are within the beasts and animals category.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Big Difference
Mnemonic: 違い is difference, so a big one of those is a big difference.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 違い plus 大 of 大きい (おお) put together. You can remember this because when you see the difference (the BIG difference), you say "oohhhhh" (お), because you were surprised you didn't see it before.

Name: Brewing
Mnemonic: The act of alcohol creation is done via brewing and distilling.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Canal

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The か goes to が, probably while floating down said canal.

Name: Celebration
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji celebrate, so it means celebration!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: Characteristic
Mnemonic: A special indication on something or yourself is a special characteristic. It's a distinctive feature that exists.

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Corporation

Name: Crazy
Mnemonic: Your energy is ... well ... different. That's the nice way to put it. You're crazy, actually.

Name: Creation

Name: Direct

Name: Disability

Name: First Impression

ReadingMnemonic: I'm going to do some fortune telling on you... hmmm... I see... ohhhh... Looks like you'll be living on Uranus (うらな) in your near future, that will be $50. What a dumb fortune telling for $50, you definitely won't be living there, unless he meant your butt, then maybe.

Name: Fountain Pen
Mnemonic: The only kind of writing brush you can use for ten thousand years is a fountain pen! All other pens run out of ink and then you're out of luck. But fountain pens can be refilled, making them work for pretty much exactly ten thousand years.

Name: Fugu
Mnemonic: The river pig is what's known as fugu or blowfish. You may know it from our mascot and best friend, the Tofugu!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading makes no sense, really. Neither kanji readings work. But, if you remember that a river pig is a fugu, you can know the reading is ふぐas well! YOU ARE A BLOWFISH, JESSE!

Name: Ghost Story
Mnemonic: If you have a suspicious talk, you're talking about something that may or may not be real. One of those things you could be discussing is a ghost story.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Giant Monster

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Glacier
Mnemonic: An ice river is some ice that moves (very slowly) like a river. That is a glacier. In fact, many inlets and sounds were created with glaciers, because glaciers moved through them like rivers... not very quickly, though.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 氷 is the one you didn't learn. Think of the glacier coming slowly to your door. It rings your doorbell and says heyo (ひょう). Note that the か becomes が here.

Name: Happy Birthday
Mnemonic: 誕生日 is birthday. おめでとう is like "congratulations." So, congratulations for your birthday is like happy birthday!
Reading: おたんじょうびおめでとう
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 誕生日, so if you know that you know this!

Name: I
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: It is I! Due to my ego, I love the Wii and no other gaming device. I love playing all the Wii-ware (われ) that's available, and everything else sucks.

Name: Import
Mnemonic: The transport of things that enter your country are imports.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Independence
Mnemonic: Alone I stand. I have independence!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Indirect
Mnemonic: After an interval of time it will adjoin, but not right away. That is because it was being indirect.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Intense

ReadingMnemonic: What is fierce and violent? That old hag (はげ). Imagine her coming at you attacking you violently!

Name: Intentional
Mnemonic: The circumstance was caused by the idea I had. Because I had this idea before the circumstance, it shows I was intentional in doing it. I did it on purpose.

Name: Kappa
Mnemonic: A river juvenile... not what you think. It's a kappa, a mythological Japanese creature. That being said, it lives in / around rivers and is about the size of a juvenile, so maybe this makes sense.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 河 makes sense. The reading for 童 however is weird. Since the meaning is "kappa" though you can use that to remember the reading as well. If you don't know what a kappa is do some research on the internets and figure out about them. It's interesting, and it will help you to remember this word.

Name: Landscape Gardening

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Mail

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. The reading for 便 here (びん) isn't the on'yomi you learned with the kanji though, so here's a mnemonic to help you out: You get a lot of junk mail, so you throw it in the waste bin (びん). The waste bin is where that mail goes.

Name: Malfunction
Mnemonic: By some circumstance, the thing you're using is hindering you. Usually it works, but now it's out of order and has a malfunction.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Misreading

ReadingMnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 読む and 違い. As long as you remember those, you can apply that knowledge here as well.

Name: Mistaken Identity

Name: Monopoly

Name: Monster

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Needle
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: As a standalone vocab, this uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: This needle is… incredibly hairy (はり). And you're about to receive an injection. About the only thing worse than a normal needle is probably a hairy needle. Eww.

Name: Obedient
Mnemonic: When you obey orders people consider you to be an obedient person.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pencil

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful because the ひつ gets rendaku'd to ぴつ. In case you need help with this rendaku reading, here's a mnemonic: You know how some people put a pencil behind their ear? Well, you keep yours between your pits (ぴつ). Why? So your friends will stop mooching pencils off you in class. No one wants a gross sweaty pencil you've been keeping between your pits.

Name: Reason
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When thinking about the circumstance of your current situation and the reason you're there (which is studying kanji and vocab). Whose fault is it? It's WaniKani's fault! But, your brain has been beaten to a mush from all the studying, so when you say "it's your fault" it comes out as "it's yue fault!" Go ahead and say it out loud that way.

Name: Recovery

Name: Single
