ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Burn
Mnemonic: Remember how 燃やす means "to burn something" or "to set on fire”? Well, 燃える is the version that means to burn or to be on fire. You might say that paper and wood 燃える easily, for example. And if your house is 燃えている, you're in trouble.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the word 燃やす.

Name: To Catch Fire
Mnemonic: When something attaches a burn to something that something is about to catch fire.
ReadingMnemonic: This is the readings of 燃える and 付く put together.

Name: To Construct
Mnemonic: The kanji means create, and this word is for the creation of big things. So it means to construct or to build or to make, and it's usually used with ships, bridges, buildings, and other large-scale work.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is like 作る, which means "to make." They have very similar meanings, but different kanji. Use 作る to help you to remember the reading of this word.

Name: To Cool Oneself
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cool (temperature-wise) and the verb vocab version is to cool oneself or to cool off. Whoo, that feels much cooler now.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this one too. If you need a refresher, remember that the Sue Zoo (すず) was made for the penguin Sue to cool off in, even when it's hot outside.

Name: To Deliver
Mnemonic: 届く is "to be delivered." This word is when you're doing the actual delivering, making it to deliver. You can remember this because you care (ける) about the package so much that you deliver it yourself, thus doing the action of delivering it!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 届く and you can use that to deliver the memory to your brain.

Name: To Discriminate
Mnemonic: 差別 is discrimination. This is the verb version, to discriminate.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Encourage Someone
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means encourage and the verb vocab version is to encourage someone (or to encourage).
ReadingMnemonic: Think about encouraging a hag (はげ). She needs encouragement because she's a hag, and nobody likes her much because of that.

Name: To Entrust Something
Mnemonic: If you pass a duty on to someone, that means you're going to entrust something to that person, or you're going to delegate something. In other words, you're going to leave something to them, so that they do it for you.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi of the kanji. You haven't learned that reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In order to entrust something to someone, you need to make a (まか) list. It's no good delegating tasks if the person has no idea what to do, so be sure to make a list, okay?

Name: To Examine
Mnemonic: You examine it but you also chastise it, because you want to make sure this examining is correct. This is to examine or to study. All require chastising things to be sure for sure.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Export
Mnemonic: Remember how 輸出 is an export? This is the verb, so this is to export.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also help to know the word 輸出.

Name: To Flourish
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means flourish or prosper, so the verb vocab versions of these would be to flourish or to prosper.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you flourish at? You're an amazing soccer (さか) player who flourishes and prospers no matter where you go to play this wonderful (but not as good as baseball) sport.

Name: To Give
Mnemonic: This is a really humble and polite way to say "to give," probably because you're lowering yourself down and raising the item above your head so far that you have to point at it because if you were touching it you'd be defiling it anyways so, you know, point at it and raise it way up, you little worm on the ground.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 差す and 上げる put together, both hopefully words you know okay by now.

Name: To Hand Over
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transit. It's also in the verb 渡る, which means "to cross." But with 渡す, it's more like you're sending something across instead, usually to another person. So 渡す means to hand over.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Irritate
Mnemonic: This is the verb version of hinder, but it's what happens when you hinder someone else enough. You'll start to irritate and to annoy them.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to irritate me, all you have to do is make what I'm eating sour (さわ). Did you know sour food is known to be bad for you, too? Don't make that sour face, stop eating sour things!

Name: To Narrow Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means narrow, so the verb version is to narrow something or to narrow down something.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to narrow the width of something. The only way you can do that is to sever (せば) off each end. Maybe you're trying to get a sofa up a tight stairway. The only way to do that is by severing off each arm to narrow it.

Name: To Obey
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means obey so the verb vocab version is to obey.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I am going to obey you. I think your order is a bit of shit が (したが), I'll do it and obey you. (Little side note, did you know が in the middle of a sentence can mean "but" in Japanese? Think of it as that meaning here.)

Name: To Occupy
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means occupy so the verb version is to occupy.
ReadingMnemonic: What is it you want to occupy most in the whole, entire world? Your own flock of sheep (し). Also, a fortune teller (this kanji also means fortune, remember) told you that if you occupy her sheep, you'll have good luck! Gotta do as she says!

Name: To Pass Time
Mnemonic: 過ぎる means "to pass," and 過ごす is to pass time.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as  過ぎる. If you know it, it's OK to pass time relaxing for a bit! If you don’t know it, maybe it's good to spend time reviewing…

Name: To Place On Something
Mnemonic: Remember how 載る is "to be placed on"? This one is to place on something, like a mug on a table. 載せる is transitive, and you know this because you do it yourself (せる). Like 載る, 載せる also often refers to putting something in a written document or publication, so it can mean to put on record.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is shared with 載る, so as long as you remember that you can remember this.

Name: To Shake Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shake and this verb is transitive, meaning that you're shaking something. So this verb means to shake something, to wave something, or to swing something. You'll often see it paired with 手, as in 手を振る, meaning "to wave one's hand" or, as we'd usually say in English, simply "to wave".
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone is trying to shake something. And unfortunately, that something is you. The most unfortunate thing here is that you're totally full (ふる), and you throw up because of the shaking (and you're full, gross!).

Name: To Take Responsibility
Mnemonic: 担ぐ is more like when you're carrying something physical. 担う is when you carry a responsibility, which is why this word means to assume responsibility. You can remember this because YOU (う) are responsible for this. You assume this responsibility.
ReadingMnemonic: What is your responsibility? To raise this girl named Nina (にな).

Name: To Touch
Mnemonic: 触る means "to touch," and 触れる also means to touch. The word also means to touch on, as in touching on some subject. Just think of a subject that is rare (れる) for you to want to touch on.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is totally different from 触る so don't let that fool you. In this case, you feel some fur (ふれ).

Name: To Wipe
Mnemonic: The kanji means wipe, and this is the verb version of that, making this to wipe.
ReadingMnemonic: Like verbs usually do, this uses the kun'yomi, which you already learned with the kanji. Lucky you!

Name: Unique
Mnemonic: It is alone and special. Nothing is like it. It is very unique and peculiar.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Up To Now
Mnemonic: You've obeyed all that has come up to now. That's because it's the conventional way of doing things, and it's what's conventionally expected of you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Vending Machine
Mnemonic: Remember the super long vending machine that is 自動販売機? This is a shorter easier to remember and say version. Basically every other kanji is removed, making it 自販機.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know 自動販売機 already.

Name: Veterinarian
Mnemonic: One who does beast medicine is a veterinarian, taking care of all them animals.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Vibration
Mnemonic: The movement that has to do with shakes is vibration and oscillation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Violation
Mnemonic: If you're anti- something in a way that's different from the norm then you'll be in violation of the law! The laws that the "not" different people made. Either way, those people will give you a hard time for your anti-stance against the thing they like, and say it's a transgression.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 違 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you find yourself in violation of the law just pull out your pet eagle (い). Eagles are so majestic, they'll forget all about your transgression and let you go. If you're going to go be anti-something make sure you bring that eagle. People seem to care more about animals than other people like that.

Name: Weather Agency
Mnemonic: The energy phenomenon agency sounds like something that could be really cool but it's really just the weather agency or meteorological agency. Nothing shady going on here.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Why
Mnemonic: When you want to know what the circumstances are around you, you have to ask why. Why do things happen around you? Asking why is very important if you want to understand the world.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this is an exception. The reading for 何 is just the first な from なに. You can remember the second part this way: No one knows quite how or why that big zeppelin (ぜ) crashed in the 1930s. People are still asking today and no one has any answers. We have to keep asking until we get some.

Name: Wild Beast
Mnemonic: A field beast/animal is one that lives outside and not under human care. It is a wild beast / wild animal.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Writing Brush
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: For as long as you can remember, your family and another family has had a bloody feud (ふで) over this one writing brush. Just think of all the people killed over this brush. This feud has to end.

Name: Amnesia
Mnemonic: A healthy bit of forgetting symptoms means you might have amnesia.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Antarctica
Mnemonic: The southern extreme is Antarctica. It's about as south as you can go.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Arrangement
Mnemonic: You've taken a decision from someone. By doing this, you've created a kind of arrangement with them. Imagine yourself pulling this decision out of the person. They don't want to necessarily give it to you, but they're letting you pull it out of them, kind of. When you've pulled it out, you've come to an arrangement, though they've pulled some of your decision out too.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for both kanji, which you might have guessed already since there's hiragana sticking out of both of them. The 取り comes from 取る and the 決め comes from 決める. Put them together and what have you got? Bibbidi bobbidi とりきめ!

Name: A Visit
Mnemonic: A visit problem is when someone makes a visit, because you're the type of person who doesn't like visitors, since they're usually so inconsiderate and you have to feed them. That's why a visit is a visit problem.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: A Worry
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of worry, making it a worry, or a trouble.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. Nicely done, no need to have a worry about it.

Name: Bad Influence
Mnemonic: 影響 is "influence," so an evil influence is a bad influence.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Bastard
Mnemonic: Ugh, that field guy. He's the worst. Always in the fields, making us look bad, quite the bastard. Really though, he's just this guy, but for some reason I sometimes don't like him.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Belly
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: If anyone tries to touch your belly, that's harassment (はら). Unless you're cool with it, obviously. But if you're not, make sure to yell "harassment!" when they touch your belly. You should also shout what kind of harassment it is: 腹ハラ (腹 harassment). Note: This word will often get rendaku'd when it's combined with other vocab, like in ビールばら (beer belly) or 別ばら (separate stomach for dessert).

Name: Boring
Mnemonic: I retreat! I yield! I can't take it anymore, it's so boring. Just imagine yourself giving up on whatever you're doing because you're so darn bored. You can't stand it. You have to retreat. You are ready to yield. Booooooring.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Breakdown
Mnemonic: When you divide and untie things, you're unraveling the connections between them. In other words, you're doing a breakdown or dismantling of something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Change Money
Mnemonic: Coins? Bills? Both can be replaced if you want to change money at this money exchange. Just don’t do your currency exchange at the airport — the rates aren’t so great.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading here is a bit weird. Instead of just being か (it changes to が for the rendaku), it is がえ. Just think that if you want change exchanged, I'm your guy (がえ).

Name: Change Of Clothes
Mnemonic: You know how 替える is "to replace"? Well, you're replacing what you wear. That's a change of clothes, or spare clothes.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 着る and 替える put together. The か goes to が.

Name: Clue
Mnemonic: You learned that 掛かる can mean "to be hooked." If you're doing something physical like climbing and your hand hooks onto something, that thing is called a handhold.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 手 plus 掛かる put together. Just watch out for that rendaku.

Name: Coward
Mnemonic: You learned that 抜ける is "to fall out." If your waist falls out, you can't remain standing. You have to curl up on the ground, like a coward.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you've learned already. Go you!

Name: Dense
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning it's probably an adjective. The kanji means dense, and this can also mean dense or thick in some contexts, like if you’re describing fog, or body hair! More generally, it can be used for anything that’s highly concentrated, so you can use it for things like deep colors, or strong coffee too!
ReadingMnemonic: What’s the most dense thing you can think of? A 子 (こ). Children are so full of joy, you can practically see how dense, thick and concentrated the joy is.

Name: Density
Mnemonic: When something is dense to a certain degree, you’re talking about the density or concentration of something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Don't Mind Me
Mnemonic: Remember how 構う is "to care about"? You can convert it into お構いなく to politely tell someone not to care about you. So this means, don't mind me.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 構う, so if you know that you know this!

Name: Do Your Best
Mnemonic: Remember 頑張る means “to persevere” or “to do one’s best”? This time you're telling someone to 頑張る, so this word means something like do your best, hang in there, or good luck! Speaking of which, 頑張れ, you!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 頑張る. Just watch out for that rendaku on 張る! You've seen it before, but here's a mnemonic in case you need a refresher: Remember how when it's time to 頑張る (to persevere), you always scream "baa"? Not sure why, but it's a great motivator for you. So you do the same when you cheer for others. When you tell them Do your best, you also scream baa (ば) at them. When you tell them Hang in there, you scream "baa!" If it makes you persevere, it must work the same for others, right? Baa!

Name: Edge
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This refers to a literal edge, not a figurative one.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you're on edge, just eat some hash (はし) browns to feel better! And if you're going to the edge of the world, hash browns will probably help you make it there too. Hash browns are so useful!

Name: Effective
Mnemonic: Remember how 効果 means "effect"? Add ~like to that and it's effective!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Elderly Person
Mnemonic: For years and years, your comrades have been with you, but now they're all elderly.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As this vocab is identical to 年配, it's also read the same. Just remember that the はい turns into ぱい!

Name: Exclusive Sale
Mnemonic: When a 限定 (limit) is applied to 販売 (selling), it’s a sort of exclusive sale or limited offer.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Extreme
Mnemonic: At the extreme edge, which is just the extreme.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Finding Employment
Mnemonic: Getting a position of employment means finding employment, or getting a job.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Glory
Mnemonic: You have prospered so much that light seems to shine forth from your every pore in a golden aura. With the wealth, fame, and admiration you have achieved, you are the walking embodiment of glory.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Gradually
Mnemonic: Step by step. If you take things step by step, you're moving up gradually, taking steps.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Half Finished
Mnemonic: Take the middle route, half to the edge. You don't do anything the full way. Just to the middle. Just to the half. Not to the edge. This was really half finished and half assed of you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ぱ at the end is the only tricky part here since that isn't a common reading (or the one you learned before) for the kanji. Just think of your ol' Pa (ぱ), who is the biggest half-asser you know.

Name: Hand Wipe
Mnemonic: You have hand and the noun version of 拭く (to wipe). Put the two together and you get a hand wipe!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this uses all kun'yomi. So just put together the kun'yomis of 手 and 拭き (from the verb 拭く) with an honorary お and you're good to go!

Name: Headache
Mnemonic: Head pain is when you have a headache.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 痛 should be okay. The reading for 頭 isn't one you've learned before, however. Just think, every time you go to the zoo (ず) you get a terrible headache. Must be the animal feces floating around in the air.

Name: Health
Mnemonic: You're so healthy it puts you at ease. That's your health! So healthful, go you!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Idiot
Mnemonic: You learned that 抜ける is "to fall out." If an interval of time falls out of you, you're totally spaced out. You won't learn anything and you'll become an idiot.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from the ま reading of 間 and from 抜く.

Name: Insomnia
Mnemonic: The not sleep symptom shows you have a disorder that involves not sleeping. That is insomnia.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Izakaya
Mnemonic: An alive alcohol shop is a place that serves a lot of alcohol. In Japan, these places are often izakaya. If you don't already know what an izakaya is, you can consider it to be a casual Japanese Style Bar.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings here are all kun'yomi, but this is the first time you've seen the さか reading for 酒, which rendaku then turns into ざか here. If you know what an izakaya is already, you can probably remember the reading, but if not here's a mnemonic to help: When you need recommendations for a good izakaya (a Japanese style bar), you ask your friend Zachary (ざか). He knows all the best spots. You even call him Izakaya Zachary. He doesn't like that, but too bad. In your mind, Zachary will always be tied to Japanese style bars.

Name: Job Promotion
Mnemonic: Ascend and advance! Congratulations, you ascend and advance by getting a new job promotion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Landscape
Mnemonic: Quite the scene, this view is. So what you're looking at is a landscape. This often refers to a cityscape or the general scenery of an area.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Large Scale
Mnemonic: Remember how 規模 is scale? Well, this is a big scale, which is on a large scale.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Leave Early
Mnemonic: An early retreat means that you leave early.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Leaving Decisions To Someone Else
Mnemonic: This word comes from 任せる, but without the る on the end it's a noun. You also have the honorific お on the beginning, which is a clue that you're addressing someone else. So you're entrusting something to the person you're talking to, and this means leaving decisions to someone else. This is used a lot in restaurants, where it means chef's choice or simply omakase. In other words, you're leaving the choice of food to the chef.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading with the word 任せる, so I'll leave this one to you.

Name: Living Room
Mnemonic: A room that comes alive in intervals is your living room, or sitting room. You don't spend all your time in there, so it can only be alive sometimes.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Logic
Mnemonic: Reason yields to logic and more reasoning.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lost Child
Mnemonic: After going astray, the child becomes a lost child. Let's help them find their way home.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 迷 is an exceptional reading. The ご comes from こ. Think of the まい as the child asking: "Where is my (まい) mommy???"

Name: Maze
Mnemonic: A road where you're astray is a road that goes all around in different ways, tricking you and making you lost. This is a maze.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Month After Next
Mnemonic: The next month (来月) isn't enough... one more next month, please. Let's do it again. That month is the month after next.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: No Thank You
Mnemonic: 結構 is something like "fine" or "alright." This is just a little more polite. You can use this to say no thank you or I'm fine to someone trying to offer you something.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 結構.

Name: Objective
Mnemonic: Remember 主観的 meaning "subjective"? This is the counterpart to that. And since guests' and customers' views are always objectively right, this means objective.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: On The Way
Mnemonic: If you're on a route, right in the middle, you're on the way or en route.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Organization
Mnemonic: A group that's weaved together so tightly with hierarchy and everything else is a little more complicated than a group. It's an organization.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn that reading for 組, so here's a mnemonic to help: You start an organization for soap (そ). You're all about soap and making it more effective through your organization. So you call it the Soap Organization for Antiseptic Progress, or S.O.A.P. for short.

Name: Painful
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of pain? It's painful.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: An eater (いた) is someone who eats. But, the eater hurt his mouth. So now it's painful to eat.

Name: Pay Raise
Mnemonic: When you ascend in salary you get a pay raise at work.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Persecution
Mnemonic: Someone has an urge to damage things. If that person wants to harm you, you might be facing persecution.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Preparation
Mnemonic: To support yourself to some degree, you need preparation. Doing your hair and makeup in the morning supports your presentation to some extent, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 度 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember them together: In preparation for getting sheared, a sheep will sit on a tack (したく). This sheep tacking makes it so that the shearing part is nothing! Imagine watching some sheep getting ready by sitting on tacks. Yikes. You want to tell them being sheared doesn't hurt and that sheep tacking is worse, but something makes you think they won't listen to you.

Name: Pressure
Mnemonic: The pressure is urged upon you. It's the pressure, so much pressure!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The あつ turns into a small っ, and はく goes to ぱく.

Name: Price
Mnemonic: The value is in various steps. Each step is a different amount, and each amount is a price or cost.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading for 値 plus the on'yomi reading for 段. Combine them together to get the reading here. You've learned both of these readings already, so just remember 値 is ね because you neigh (ね) when you see a good price.

Name: Private Reservation
Mnemonic: The lending gets cut right away when you make a private reservation.
ReadingMnemonic: It's the reading of 貸す and 切る put together. Know those two readings and you know this one as well. Sometimes you'll see this word as 貸切り or 貸切 as well.

Name: Public Behavior
Mnemonic: We all build up something in front of ourselves. It's the front we present to the world, the public behavior, public stance and social niceties that maintain harmony.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is pretty strange. It's a lot like 建物 in that it's read as たて, which is like the word 建てる even though the て isn't showing here. So, you'll have to remember it's read like 建てる but the て gets pushed into the kanji.

Name: Rain Boots
Mnemonic: Long shoes aren't long in that the feet part are long (that wouldn't make sense). Instead, the top part is long to keep you dry when it's raining. Yes, these are rain boots.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a bit weird. Double kun'yomi, so think along the lines of 長い and 靴 getting added together. 靴 is the reading you learned with the kanji, however. It also gets rendaku'd.

Name: Retiring
Mnemonic: When you pull yourself back and retreat, you're retiring. At some point in everyone's lives you just can't do it anymore and it's time to take your retirement.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 引 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Now that you're retiring, you decide to go and spend your retirement at an inn (いん). Inns are great places to spend your retirement because everything is done for you, and you can just sit back and relax!

Name: Rolled Sushi
Mnemonic: 巻く is "to roll." ずし is すし. This is rolled sushi.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 巻く.

Name: Seduction
Mnemonic: You're being invited, but you're also being misguided. This is seduction that's talking. A misguided invitation is never a good thing!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Seppuku
Mnemonic: When you cut your abdomen you are committing seppuku. It will help if you already know the word "seppuku" from English, since it's also the reading here.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. But it's got shortening and rendaku going on, so you have to remember those if you want to get it right. Or just know the word seppuku already since it's pretty popular. That works too.

Name: Shoes
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Huzzah!

Name: Shoe Store
Mnemonic: A shoes shop is one that sells shoes. It's a shoe store or shoe shop.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

Name: Sleep
Mnemonic: Feeling drowsy and like I want to sleep. I just want to sleep so bad.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Sleepy
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of sleep? It's sleepy.
ReadingMnemonic: You're so sleepy you can't even remember your own name (ねむ).

Name: Small Scale
Mnemonic: 規模 is "scale." This is a small one, making this small scale.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Socks
Mnemonic: What's below your shoes? Your socks.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this word too!

Name: Spare Time
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: In your spare time you like to drink hima (ひま), an off brand version of Zima.

Name: Spring Rolls
Mnemonic: 巻く is "to roll up." If you roll up spring, you get a roll that's spring flavored. These are known as spring rolls.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 春 and 巻く.

Name: Stage
Mnemonic: Each time you take a step up, you reach a new floor… a new stage! We're talking metaphorical stages. You're making all kinds of progress. The first stage, the second stage. The third phase. Man, you're blowing through all the stages and phases of Japanese learning. Keep it up!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Stairs
Mnemonic: To get to another floor you have to go up one step, then another, and another… These are stairs. The word you're looking for is stairs! Do you have any 階段 in your house?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Stomach
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Stomachache
Mnemonic: When your stomach hurts you have yourself a little stomachache.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Superstition
Mnemonic: Led astray in what you believe by all these superstitions. These superstitions will lead you astray, don't believe them!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Supply
Mnemonic: If you can offer a salary to someone, it means you've got plenty of supply. The bigger the salary you can offer, the bigger your supply is, probably. That's why those big tech companies can pay so well — they have an endless supply of paying customers or ad revenue, I guess.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Symptom
Mnemonic: Your symptom condition is your symptoms that you have.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Syndrome
Mnemonic: Multiple symptoms combine to make a syndrome. If you see this at the end of a word, you know it means "______ syndrome," or else indicates some kind of health condition.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this is attached to things, it's treated like a jukugo word, so the on'yomi reading is used here.

Name: The First Step
Mnemonic: 第一 means "the first," and 段 is a step. So, this is the first step.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Tip
Mnemonic: The previous (or ahead) edge is the tip of something, like your finger or your chopsticks. It's also a word used to describe the latest (technology, etc), because it's on the cutting edge. The tip!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Arrest
Mnemonic: Remember how 逮捕 is an "arrest" or "capture"? This is the verb version, and it is to arrest or to capture.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also be helpful to know the word 逮捕 already as well.

Name: To Be Accompanied By
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading with 従う. Remember it?

Name: To Be Discharged
Mnemonic: Time to retreat from the institution. Basically, you are leaving an institution, particularly institutions like hospitals, asylums, etc. When you are leaving one of these places, it means you are to be discharged.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Be Hung
Mnemonic: Remember how 掛ける is "to hang something"? Well, 掛かる focuses on the fact that something is hanging, without specifying who did it. So it means to be hung. Use it to say a picture is hung on the wall, for example.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 掛ける, so as long as you know that you know this too.

Name: To Belong To
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means belong so the verb vocab version is to belong to.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. This kanji is going to belong to you.

Name: To Bend Down
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means yield, and 屈む means to bend down or to crouch. After all, bending down and crouching are sort of like yielding to gravity, don’t you think?
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You always have to bend down to get into your car garage (かが) because you’re just too tall. You have to crouch just to get inside your car garage! Let’s hope you can find a bigger one someday.

Name: To Capture Something
Mnemonic: The kanji itself means catch, and 捕える means to capture something or to catch something.
ReadingMnemonic: You recently learned 捕まる, which uses the same kanji, but this word has a totally different reading. To remember it, just think about how the meaning of 捕える kind of resembles the verb 捉える that you learned a while ago. 捕える is mostly for capturing things, and 捉える is mostly for grasping ideas. So it kinda makes sense that they'd have the same とらえる reading, right?

Name: To Come Out
Mnemonic: Remember how 抜く means "to pull something out"? 抜ける describes something coming out of where it was, so it means to come out or to fall out.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Also, it is the same as 抜く.

Name: To Compare
Mnemonic: 比較 is comparison. So, verb version of that? It's to compare.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help a lot to know the word 比較 as well.

Name: To Conclude
Mnemonic: When you tighten things up and bind things together, it's hard to separate them again. That's why this word is used to conclude or to enter into important agreements, like treaties and contracts.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Get Angry
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means angry, the verb vocab version is to get angry.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're starting to get angry about something. It's mostly this okra (おこ). It tastes terrible.

Name: To Get Lost
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means astray and the verb vocab version is to go astray (because you don't just "to astray" now do you?). You can use it if you ever happen to get lost.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you are going to go astray, one way to do it would be to eat wayyyy too much mayo (まよ). I can't think of a worse way to go astray, personally.

Name: To Give
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give so the verb vocab version is to give or to grant.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go to give a bone to your dog. Atta (あた) boy, Sparky! Atta boy.

Name: To Hand Over
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 渡す means "to hand over?" Well you can use your actual hand to hand over something too!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Hide Oneself
Mnemonic: 隠す is "to hide something." 隠れる is to hide oneself or just to hide. You know this because when someone is hiding, it's rare (れる) for anyone else to find them. They take this hide-and-seek thing pretty seriously, you know!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 隠す. So as long as you know that you know this as well.

Name: To Invite
Mnemonic: You beckon someone to come to you, but then you wait. This is because they aren't really near you, so your beckon is more like an invitation. That's why this word means to invite .
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Lend
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lend so the verb vocab version is to lend.
ReadingMnemonic: Allow me to lend you some advice. The reading you learned from the kanji can be used here.

Name: To Long For
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means long for, so the verb version is to long for and to yearn after.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: To Pull Something Out
Mnemonic: You know 抜く means "to pull something out" and 出す means "to remove," so this word also means to pull something out, or to extract.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are from 抜く and 出す, combined together. Know those two and you'll be able to read this word as well.

Name: To Replace
Mnemonic: Take and replace something. That is to replace something with something else.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are 取る and 替える put together into one. If you know those words you'll be able to read and understand this one as well.

Name: To Respond To
Mnemonic: The kanji means respond, and this is also to respond to, but often in the sense of trying to meet or to live up to some expectation, need, or other feelings.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, but it shares a reading (and some similarities in meaning) with 答える, so just try to think of that vocab in relation to this one!

Name: To Retire
Mnemonic: 隠居 is "retirement". Make that a verb and you have to retire, to be retired, or to go into retirement.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To See Something's True Nature
Mnemonic: You know 抜く means "to pull something out." Whenever you see something and pull something out of it, you're able to see something's true nature. You're able to see through things like situations, lies, and people.
ReadingMnemonic: This is the reading for 見る and 抜く put together.

Name: To Spend
Mnemonic: Turn expense into a verb and you get to spend or to expend. Or, in some cases, to waste.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Just as you're about to spend some money, a familiar sound comes from inside your wallet: "TWEET (つい)!" It's the little bird that lives inside your wallet and angrily tweets at you whenever you're about to waste money on something you don't need. Maybe you should listen to the bird tweeting from inside your wallet a little more.

Name: To Tighten
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tighten so the verb vocab version means to tighten, like a screw, or to tie, like a necktie or towel.
ReadingMnemonic: You go to tighten and to tie your captive up, and you realize you don't have anything to do it with. Then you see a sheep standing nearby. Okay. You take the sheep (し), pull its wool, and tie the sheep and your captive up together around a tree. Problem solved!

Name: To Urge
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means urge so the verb vocab version is to urge.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Do you prefer to urge people to do something, or to press them to do it? It depends on how you want to approach them. But it's all semantics (せま) because they're basically the same.

Name: To Visit
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means visit so the verb vocab version is to visit.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to visit your friend Taz (たず), the Tasmanian Devil. He's your best bro, so imagine visiting him and having a good time and saying you're going to visit him again.

Name: To Weave
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means weave so the verb vocab version is to weave.
ReadingMnemonic: When you have to weave the only thing you can weave is an O (お) shape. That's it. Just O's.

Name: To Worry
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means worry so the verb vocab version is to worry.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, so no need to worry about it.

Name: To Yell
Mnemonic: An angry chirp is a type of shout. The verb version is to yell or to shout.
ReadingMnemonic: This one is a bit tricky, as it uses the on'yomi reading you learned for 怒 and the kun'yomi reading for 鳴る, so try to keep that in mind!

Name: Trouble
Mnemonic: You've been led astray and you've been misguided. What a trouble, and indeed a troublesome inconvenience all this is.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Ultimate
Mnemonic: You are trying to research the extremes. If you do that, you'll be able to figure out the ultimate weapon. Just researching the safe middle-ground stuff won't get you ultimate. Extreme research, however, will.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Unity
Mnemonic: To unite as one is to achieve total unity and uniformity.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. However, it uses a reading for 一 that you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You dream about unity so often that it eats (いつ) away at you. Thoughts of uniting your country occupy you day and night, but you can't let them consume you.

Name: Unsold Merchandise
Mnemonic: The remainder products are the things that haven't been sold. They're the unsold merchandise. They're the remaining stock.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that ひん changes to ぴん.

Name: Urgency
Mnemonic: We're cut right down to the end, reaching that urge position where urgency is so strong.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The せつ of 切 gets shortened to a small っ. The はく becomes ぱく.

Name: Vacation
Mnemonic: The spare time is your vacation. It is your holiday.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Working
Mnemonic: When you get a position in some business, you’re considered working.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Year After Next
Mnemonic: You have next year (来年), but then you do a year again. That's the year after next.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Yukata
Mnemonic: The bathe clothes are clothes you wear to and from the bath. They're your yukata.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is totally an exception. The reading comes from the meaning, though. Yukata = ゆかた.

Name: Advance
Mnemonic: You advance and attack! This is a charge on someone or something, though it can also be an advance on them. Yep, this is the 進撃 from 進撃の巨人, the popular anime and manga. Don't say you never learned anything useful here.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the ones you learned with the kanji. Advance! Charge! Move on to the next item!

Name: Advance Ticket
Mnemonic: A ticket you sell beforehand are advance tickets. This is a ticket sold in advance. Buy your tickets early, or how else will you get in on a Conan audience?
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are 前, 売る and 券 combined into one awkward word.

Name: Again
Mnemonic: This is the adverb version of 再, so it shares the meaning again and also has the meaning once again.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Once again, you have to say "Who? Ta-ta!" (ふたた). That's because people you don't know keep trying to talk to you, again and again. Whenever this happens you say "Who? Ta-ta!" again and run away.

Name: A Giant
Mnemonic: A giant person is a giant.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Army
Mnemonic: The army squad is an army. It's also just the army. It refers more to "an" army rather than "the" army. Just a group of people who do army things.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Arrow
Mnemonic: 矢印 combines the kanji arrow and the vocab word 印 (mark), giving us the type of arrow you use for pointing at things, like these: →↑↓←. It could be an arrow on a sign, or on a piece of paper, or a document. We can just call it an arrow, or an arrow symbol.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 矢 and 印 put together into one. The 印 is like the actual vocab word 印, but watch out for rendaku changing it from しるし to じるし.

Name: A Safe
Mnemonic: Gold storage is where you put your gold. You want it to be safe, so you put it in a safe or a vault.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Astrology
Mnemonic: 占い is "fortune telling." Star fortune telling is when you use the stars for fortune telling. That's known as astrology or horoscope.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the words 星 and 占い put together into one. Did you foresee that one coming?

Name: Attack
Mnemonic: With aggression you attack the enemy. This is an attack.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Beach
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It's worth mentioning that a more common way to say beach is ビーチ, and many people actually say 海 even though this literally means "sea."
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Beach
Mnemonic: A beach area is just a beach!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 辺 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Beach starts with be. Be is べ! (I mean, it's pronounced differently, but they're spelled the same!) When you think of the beach, think of べ!

Name: Because
Mnemonic: This is like saying "when it comes to the 何故," which means you're giving a reason, making this because or the reason is, followed by… whatever you wanna say!
ReadingMnemonic: This reading is an exception but you learned them already because they're the same as the word 何故, which you learned a few levels ago. It just has some kana attached to it!

Name: Beneficial

Name: Body Language

Name: Bog

Name: Book Of Tickets

Although they’re not official readings, people sometimes distinguish 基準 and 規準 by calling them もとじゅん and のりじゅん respectively when speaking.

Name: Filthy

Name: Furigana
Mnemonic: 振る is "to shake." 仮名 is kana. This word refers to furigana, which is the little kana that's put next to kanji for the people who don't use WaniKani and can't read anything. As to why it's called "shake kana"? I have no clue. Just imagine putting little kana next to kanji and watching them shake around, though, and you should be good to go.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are 振る and 仮名 put together into one. If you know those words, you won't need no furigana to help you with this word.

Name: Gambling
Mnemonic: A gambling hit can be multiple things. One type of gambling in Japan that was popular in the day involved betting these awesome wooden block things. You'd gamble by hitting them down on the ground, making a nice thunk sound. Another way to think about it is like blackjack. You want a card? You hit! Either way, it's gambling.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is weird on this one, but gambling is weird, I guess. はく goes to ばく, maybe because you're playing some gambling backgammon. The ち can be cheating, where you cheat at this gambling backgammon. So, you're backgammon cheating (ばくち), you big cheater.

Name: Garage
Mnemonic: Car storage is where you store your car. It's your garage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Honorable
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. The kanji means pure, but this is an adjective that often describes behavior or character, so it means honorable, dignified, or gracious.
ReadingMnemonic: Oh man, the reading for this is... like... crazy. First part can be something like it's soggy (いさぎ)... then the second part is like the word 良い (good). So, you can think of a honorableperson eating soggy cereal. They're so gracious that it doesn't matter to them how soggy it is. In fact, they accept it with dignity! They keep saying "it's soggy... 良い!" over and over again while eating the terribly soggy food.

Name: Housekeeper
Mnemonic: The person who governs your house like a wife is your housekeeper.

Name: Not Yet

ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn it with this kanji, so here a mnemonic to help you: Someone's telling you "not yet... not yet.... not yet...". You have some food on your nose, but you're not allowed to eat it 今 (いま). Note that this word can also be read まだ. However, いまだ is often written in kanji, while まだ is almost always written in kana. So when you see 未だ, it's a safe bet to read it as いまだ!

Nothing exceptional about those waves.

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Soldier
Mnemonic: A soldier in a squad is a real soldier or sailor, unlike those "soldier" who are not in a squad. They don't have jobs, and can't be called real soldiers.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Sound Recording
Mnemonic: A record of sound is a sound recording of some kind. Might be minidisk, might be CD, might be digital. Whatever it is, it's still the record of sound.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Spirit
Mnemonic: Your spirit spirit is… your spirit. This word is for the human mind and can refer to your mental state, thinking, attitude, mindset, or even willpower.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Squad
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned, probably because this is stuck onto things, describing various squads.

Name: Storehouse
Mnemonic: The kanji means storehouse, and the vocab is also storehouse! Specifically, this usually refers to a traditional Japanese storehouse, which is typically a two story building used to store personal property or merchandise.
ReadingMnemonic: What do you put in your storehouse? Nothing that nice. Just your totally crashed (くら) car. So sad, it was a nice car, too and now it's all crashed and stored in your warehouse.

Name: Talking To Yourself
Mnemonic: 独り is when you're alone. 言 is when you say something. So, when you say something and you're alone, you're just talking to yourself.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 独り is just the reading for 独り. The reading for 言 is an exception, though. It's ごと, which comes from こと. Just think that as you're talking to yourself you're telling yourself over and over to go to hell. You're mean to yourself, and you're also insane, which is why you keep saying that out loud to nobody but you.

Name: Thawing
Mnemonic: If you untie something that's frozen, you're thawing it. The best way to go about defrosting anything is always to untie it first.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji, so you should be able to read this one on your own.

Name: Therefore
Mnemonic: You learned that 故 means reason. Basically, whatever comes before 故に in a statement is going to be the reason for something that comes after. So 故に works like therefore or consequently. It can also be translated as "because" or other similar conjunctions depending on the context.
ReadingMnemonic: By knowing the word 故 you'll know the reading for this word too! Here's a mnemonic in case you need a reminder, though: You're using WaniKani, therefore you're studying kanji and vocab. Whose fault is it? It's WaniKani's fault! But, your brain has been beaten to a mush from all the studying, so when you say "it's your fault" it comes out as "it's yue fault!" Go ahead and say it out loud that way.

Name: Ticket
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Usually it's attached to things, because it tells you what kind of ticket something is.

Name: To Attack
Mnemonic: You don't say "to aggression." When you do aggression on someone, you're probably doing something to hurt them in some way. This is an attack, making this word to attack.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To attack someone, use a celery (せ) stick. Celery is not a deadly weapon but most people hate it, so it's perfect to casually attack someone, especially those who hate celery.

Name: To Beckon
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means beckon so the verb vocab version is to beckon.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You move to beckon your friend over. You can't see him well, so that's why you invite him to come closer. He is hiding something, and it turns out to be his long, luxurious horse mane (まね). Why does he have a mane!? Horse steroids?

Name: To Be Complete
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned the kun'yomi reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this!

Name: To Be Painful
Mnemonic: 痛い is "painful." The verb version of that is to hurt or to be painful.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you learned already!

Name: To Break Off Contact
Mnemonic: The kanji means extinction or die out, but the verb version here means to break off contact, to sever, or to end. Just think about how when you’re breaking off contact with somebody, you’re essentially making them go extinct or die out from your life completely. It’s such a complete severance, they basically stop existing to you.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In terms of things you need to sever, tacos (た) are #1 on your list. No more tacos for you, going to cut those off from my diet.

Name: Toddler
Mnemonic: An infancy child is a toddler. The kanji are kind of deceptive since this isn't really used for infants. It's more for small children, from toddlers on up to preschoolers.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Fall
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means descend, but this word means something closer to to fall or to come down.
ReadingMnemonic: The rain is to fall and you're outside anyway with your mouth open so you'll get a mouth full (ふる) of rainwater! All the ponds, wells, and your yard will be full of water too!

Name: To Freeze
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means frozen, so the vocab version is to freeze.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading actually comes from the word 氷, which means "ice." You can kind of see where the origins of these words come from, now... really cold frozen things. So, think back to こおり, then change the り to a る and put it outside the kanji. That makes the reading for this こおる, in all (or most) of 氷's glory.

Name: To Go Against
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means opposite so the verb version is to oppose or to go against.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Just like when you play soccer (さか). You never play right, causing you to go against all things you're supposed to do and shoot goals into your own goalie's net.

Name: To Import
Mnemonic: 輸入 is import. Now let's make it a verb. To import.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 輸入 as well.

Name: To Interview With
Mnemonic: 面接 is an interview. Make that into a verb and you have to interview with.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 面接 as well.

Name: To Line Up
Mnemonic: The kanji itself means line up, and this is the intransitive verb version of that, which makes this to line up or to be lined up. You can remember this because you keep saying boo (ぶ), why is everyone already lined up? If you were the one in charge of lining things up, you wouldn't have to stand in line yourself…
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Only for you, when you visit Nara (なら), the deer there are to be lined up for you to inspect, as you are the deer inspector. If you don't know about Nara and its deer, you should look it up, they're pretty awesome.

Name: To Make A Mistake
Mnemonic: Remember how 間違い means "a mistake?" Well this is the verb version. It means to make a mistake or to mistake.
ReadingMnemonic: It's read the same as 間違い! Nice and easy!

Name: To Reach The Peak Of Something
Meaning: To Reach The Peak Of Something
Mnemonic: The kanji itself means extreme. The verb vocab version isn't "to extreme" because that wouldn't make sense. Instead, you bring something to extremes, making this to reach the peak of something, to perfect, or to reach the extreme.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you go to reach the peak of something or to perfect something, you tend to go a little overboard, so there has to be a key word (きわ) that other people can say to remind you to calm down a little. “PINEAPPLE! PINEAPPLE!”

Name: To Recover
Mnemonic: 回復 is recovery. Make it into a verb and you have to recover.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 回復, but you can also figure it out via the readings of the kanji as well.

Name: To Retreat
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means retreat, and the verb vocab version means to retreat or to withdraw.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to retreat because she re-zoned (しりぞ) where you are standing. Now this is a no standing zone. Who is she? The re-zoner, duh.

Name: To Seduce
Mnemonic: If 誘惑 is seduction or temptation, then the verb version would be to seduce or to tempt.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 誘惑 first, though.

Name: To Shift
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shift so the verb vocab version is to shift.
ReadingMnemonic: All that dubstep (うつうつうつうつうつ) playing downstairs is causing all of your glassware to shift off the shelf and onto the floor. Damn that dubstep. うつうつうつうつうつ♪

Name: To Shoot
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means to attack, but 撃つ means to shoot.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What are you going to shoot at? Uni (う)! Why? Because this area is overrun with those black, spiky sea urchins. You need to cull them by shooting them down.

Name: Total Absorption
Mnemonic: You already know that 無我 is "selflessness" and 夢中 is "crazy about." So this means something like total absorption. You're so into something that you’ve started losing your sense of self. Just like 夢中, this can also describe doing something frantically, like running away from somebody or something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Training
Mnemonic: You sharpen your mastering of a specific skill. One could say that you're training. Additionally, when you sharpen someone else's mastering, you give training.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Umbrella
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Umbrella Stand
Mnemonic: This is when you take your umbrella and you stand it up. Wait, how is an umbrella standing up? Good question, my dear Crabling, you are putting your umbrella in an umbrella stand.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the readings for 傘 (learned with the kanji) and 立つ (to stand).

Name: Very Young
Mnemonic: The kanji means infancy. The adjective version describes someone who is very young, like little kids in their early childhood or babyhood!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you were very young and childish you were sent off to do prayers to ask for forgiveness. One of the things you had to do was sing "hosanna (おさな) in the highest."

Name: We
Mnemonic: 我 is me, so two of me makes we! Or us!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 我, twice.

Name: Week After Next
Mnemonic: You know how 来週 is next week? Well, if you do next week again, you have the week after next.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Wire
Mnemonic: A needle made of gold is a wire. Perhaps wires were made from gold mostly back in the day? And they were thin like needles? That's my guess.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading of both. You already know both of these, just watch out for the rendaku on 金!

Name: Wonder Drug
Mnemonic: A peculiar drug that seems too good to be true? That's what we call a wonder drug or a miracle cure.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Yearning
Mnemonic: If you long for something you'll get feelings of yearning and longing. Don't worry, some day you'll get whatever it is.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: Yokohama
Mnemonic: It's the side of the beach! Well, wait, what is it? This will make better sense when you look at the reading for the word, since it's a place: Yokohama.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 横 and 浜 put together into one nice word, よこはま.

Name: Abbreviation
Mnemonic: Abbreviation in language is an abbreviation or an acronym.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Anger
Mnemonic: This word looks a lot like 怒る, doesn't it? But this word isn't a verb, so you can think of it as referring to anger or wrath itself.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I have a lot of anger because I carry (いか) all of my own things (books, luggage, drinks) and no one will ever carry them for me. Plus, the more things I carry, the more anger I carry inside. Ahh!

Name: Anger
Mnemonic: An angry energy comes out of you when you have anger.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: A Pain
Mnemonic: 痛い is "painful." This is the noun version, it is a pain or pain.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 痛い. No pain here.

Name: Application
Mnemonic: When you say humbly that you're requesting something, you're putting forward an application.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which means on'yomi readings from the kanji.
