You already know this reading for 請, but not for 申, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Today you finally submitted your application for a new shin (しん). Your old one had to be painstakingly removed after you banged it against a table. Anyway, congrats on the application for your new shin!

Name: Area
Mnemonic: The surface that accumulates into one area is a particular area. This has to do with math. When you add all the surfaces together by accumulating them into one calculation, you get yourself the area!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Attachment
Mnemonic: Append and attach this document to your email. That’s called attachment.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 添 is what you'd expect. The reading for 付 is the on'yomi reading ふ, which you've learned with 付近. But for this word it becomes ぷ from the rendaku fairies. Just think of an attachment where instead of a document or something, you get an attachment of poop (ぷ). What a gross attachment. Your friend who likes to send poop attachments is dumb.

Name: Aviation
Mnemonic: Navigation in the sky is aviation and flight. Vroom vroom sky flying!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Banquet
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: At a banquet or party, you don't only get food, you also 歌 GET (うたげ), which is you getting a song from a singer. After all, entertainment is just as important as the food when you're at a wild bacchanal such as this!

Name: Banquet
Mnemonic: A banquet meeting is when you meet together for a banquet or dinner party.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Beckoning Cat
Mnemonic: A beckoning cat is a beckoning cat or maneki neko.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you know already!

Name: Belly
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is an exception, but it isn't too hard to remember. It's the same as 中 (なか), so if you think about it it makes sense. It's your insides, just like your belly is your insides!

Name: Bizarre
Mnemonic: That's very odd and strange, making it bizarre and peculiar.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Blackboard
Mnemonic: A black board is a blackboard.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Board
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who can make good use of various boards? An avid eater (いた)! If you’re an avid eater, you’ll need lots of (cutting) boards to prepare all the delicious food you’re going to eat. This makes boards and eaters the perfect match.

Name: Broad Outline
Mnemonic: The big abbreviation is where you take everything and abbreviate it down to show the big picture. This abbreviation is the broad outline of something bigger.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Bureaucrat
Mnemonic: A government colleague is a bureaucrat, or a government official. The one who works for and is part of the bureaucracy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Cabinet Meeting
Mnemonic: When the cabinet meets for deliberation they are having a cabinet meeting. So governmenty.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Cabinet Ministers
Mnemonic: The cabinet colleagues are the cabinet ministers or cabinet secretaries. They're the people in the Cabinet who are all colleagues with each other, making them cabinet members. Depending on the country, they're also called ministers or secretaries.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Central Europe
Mnemonic: The middle part of Europe is Central Europe, wherever that is.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Collapse
Mnemonic: When something collapses and breaks, it is when a collapse happens. Something big collapsing or falling down will probably result in its destruction.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Colleague
Mnemonic: We work at the same place and are colleagues, making us colleagues or coworkers.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Complete Destruction
Mnemonic: When all of something breaks, every last bit of it is broken. It's complete destruction!!!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Contribution
Mnemonic: When you draw near to give something, you are probably giving a contribution.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Curiosity
Mnemonic: You like it because it gives you an odd feeling in your heart. You don't quite know what it is you like, but that's because it's curiosity that you have.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Daughter
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Deadline
Mnemonic: Things 締める (tighten), and eventually 切る (cut off), meaning you’ve reached the deadline! You can associate this with the feeling of your chest tightening once you approach the due date for something.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this is the stem form of both verbs, so 締め (しめ) and 切り (きり), put together!

Name: Demand
Mnemonic: You request then you request again. This is starting to turn into more of a demand if you ask me. Also can refer to a claim or a charge as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Diagnosis
Mnemonic: To diagnose is to (metaphorically) cut off all the possibilities you don't believe to be likely. That's how you get a diagnosis!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Donation
Mnemonic: If you draw near someone and attach some stuff to them, you're making a donation. They get to keep it, after all.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dozing Off
Mnemonic: Sometimes even though you think you're very much awake and alive, you can't help fall into a sleep and start dozing off. But you're not dead! You're totally alive, so let's hope no one thinks you're doing anything other than nodding off.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dry Season
Mnemonic: The dry seasons is the dry season.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Edo
Mnemonic: The bay door isn't what you might think, it refers to Edo, which is what Tokyo was called back in the day. You'll still see references to it everywhere, though, so it's good to learn. You can also call this Tokyo if you want, but I'd prefer if you answered "Edo," instead.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. Just watch out for that rendaku on 戸, which changes the reading to ど. Of course, it will be easy if you already know the word Edo!

Name: Effectiveness
Mnemonic: Something's effective power is its effectiveness. If it has effective power, it remains in effect.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Entranceway
Mnemonic: The most mysterious thing that's connected to a house is the entranceway. When you're walking into one you never know what's coming next. You just take off your shoes and hope the rest of the house isn't really weird or something. If it is, the entryway is then your only way out.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Europe And America
Mnemonic: You have Europe and America. This word refers to Europe and America.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Extremely
Mnemonic: 極める is "to carry to extremes." So, 極めて is something similar. It's used to refer to something that's extremely _______.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 極める.

Name: Fervent
Mnemonic: Your fever turns violent when you express your fervent feelings.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Fierce
Mnemonic: If you're fierce and violent then you are fierce and violent.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Fierce
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can put this on other words to say that it's a "Fierce ____" or "Intense _____," or something along those lines. If you see this, you know that something is being done really fiercely or intensely.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because it's stuck onto things making it all jukugo and such.

Name: Harakiri
Mnemonic: If your abdomen is getting cut, and you're the one doing the cutting, there's a good chance you're committing harakiri, a form of ritual suicide.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 腹 and 切る. If you're lucky, you already know the word harakiri as it's made its way into English as well.

Name: Hero
Mnemonic: You've learned 英 means "England," but it can also mean excel. So what kind of person excels at being brave? A hero!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Hesitation
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 迷う means "to go astray" or "to get lost?" Well when you feel like you're about to go astray or get lost it causes hesitation. You end up with a lot of doubt about where to go or what to do. It's a natural progression.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading already when you learned 迷う! Just swap the う for an い.

Name: Host
Mnemonic: The master sponsor for an event is the host who's hosting (and possibly sponsoring) it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Hungry
Mnemonic: When your belly has decreased in the amount of stuff inside it, you become hungry.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 腹 plus 減る put together. With these two combined, you have はらがへった. In casual speech, you might hear 腹減った without the が more often. The version with が is more common in writing or fixed expressions like 腹が減っては戦ができぬ (you can't fight on an empty stomach).

Name: Index
Mnemonic: You search then pull items from the index — you know, that list of keywords in alphabetical order at the end of a nonfiction book. Or in 五十音順 order, if you're fancy enough to be reading Japanese!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just think of the first part of the word index (いん). Where do you search? In the index.

Name: Inlet
Mnemonic: When you enter an inlet, you've gone into the inlet. It's also where water goes inside of the inlet (it's entering the inlet from the ocean, or whatever), so that's another way to think about it.
ReadingMnemonic: For this reading, just imagine this as 入り with 江 pushed on at the end! Also note this is commonly written as 入江, but the reading stays the same!

Name: Japan And Europe
Mnemonic: The 日 refers to "Japan" (It's the 日 of 日本). So, you have Japan and Europe, which makes this Japan and Europe or Japanese-European.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Japan And South Korea
Mnemonic: With the 日 of 日本, the 日 means Japan. Then, you add Korea into the mix and you have Japan + Korea. This word means Japan and South Korea or Japan and Korea.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Kanpai
Mnemonic: You dry out your cup of liquid after saying Kanpai, or cheers!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for the はい turning into ぱい!

Name: Lookup
Mnemonic: You examine then search. These are the steps you take in order to perform a lookup of some kind (or, as the case may be in modern times, do an internet search).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Main Road
Mnemonic: A street road is as wide as a street and a road combined together. So cool! So wide! It must be a main road or a highroad!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. One thing to note though: This word uses the かい reading for 街 (not がい). And even when 街道 is a suffix, it never gets rendaku'd! Remember this by imagining every main road being full of kayaks (かい) for some reason. Just a traffic jam of kayaks up and down the 街道.

Name: Medical Exam
Mnemonic: I'm going to diagnose you and then make a guess as to what's wrong with you during this medical exam.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Minister
Mnemonic: A big servant is a really important servant — you know, one who serves a king or some other political leader. What do we call a big, highfalutin servant who prances around doing jobs for the leader? A minister.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Navigation
Mnemonic: The navigation methods are the methods used for navigation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Nervousness
Mnemonic: Your tense body begins to stretch tighter and tighter as nervousness takes over.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Nonstop Flight
Mnemonic: Remember how 直行 is "nonstop"? Well, with 直航 it's the same thing, but it's only used for flights and boat trips, making this a nonstop flight or direct voyage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Notice
Mnemonic: When you sponsor an announcement, you're allowing those you're sponsoring to create some kind of notice for all those they want to get in contact with.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Odd Number
Mnemonic: Odd numbers are odd numbers (as in, 1, 3, 5, 7, though they are a bit strange as well).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Omitting
Mnemonic: Conserve those letters with abbreviation and now you're omitting all the extra fluff!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: One Cup
Mnemonic: One cup of liquid is equal to one cup. It could just be a drink, but if you're measuring exactly one cup, it needs to be full to the brim. That's a lot of liquid—so be careful not to spill!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that 一 becomes いっ, and 杯 becomes ぱい.

Name: Only Daughter
Mnemonic: An "alone" (一人) daughter is a daughter with no other daughter siblings, making her the only daughter.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are 一人 plus 娘 put together into one, single (daughter) word.

Name: Painkiller
Mnemonic: 痛み is "pain." 止める is "to stop." What stops pain if you use it? How about a painkiller.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 痛み and 止める put together into one word. Not too painful, right? Just remember the rendaku on the ど.

Name: Passenger Ticket
Mnemonic: If you want to ride in a car, the ticket you'll need is a passenger ticket.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Phobia
Mnemonic: You learned 恐怖 means "terror," and 〜症 can mean "disease." So what's a terror disease? Well, it's a phobia.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Rage
Mnemonic: Being fierce and angry means you're filled with rage, or for you to be enraged.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Rebuilding
Mnemonic: Again you build it. This is rebuilding.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just don't forget that extra い!

Name: Religion
Mnemonic: The religion teachings are what makes up a religion. If you don't have the teachings of the religion, nobody will learn about it, and it will stop being a religion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Rental
Mnemonic: To lend or to rent is 貸す. This is the noun version of that, used as a prefix. It is something that has been rented, a "rental ____," like a 貸しビル (rental office building) or 貸しボート (rental boat).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 貸す.

Name: Rough Diagram
Mnemonic: An abbreviation version of a diagram doesn't include all the details. It's more like a rough diagram that shows only the essentials.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Scary
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of scary? It's also scary.
ReadingMnemonic: You know what's really scary, like double scary (because kanji and vocab both mean scary)? How about your coworkers (こわ). They are all insane, and you know it. Absolute nutjobs they are.

Name: Search
Mnemonic: A search search is a more intense search, like the official investigation for a missing person.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sect
Mnemonic: A religion sect is a sect within religion, most likely, but it can be simply referred to as a sect or denomination.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Shopping Street
Mnemonic: A merchandise shop street is a street with all kinds of shops and merchandise on it. Sounds like a lot of shopping goes on here in this shopping street!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Signboard
Mnemonic: A watch over board is a board that's put up and watches over everything. What kind of board watches over everything from up high? One that gets the most visibility, so probably a signboard or billboard.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Sleeping Pills
Mnemonic: Drowsy sleep medicine is sleeping pills. Don't take too many or you might get addicted.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Sleeping Potion
Mnemonic: Some kind of sleeping medicine? That's a sleeping potion!
ReadingMnemonic:
The reading is 眠い plus 薬 put together in one ... zz zzzzzZZZzz
Just remember that くすり turns into ぐすり here because of rendaku.

Name: Solicitation
Mnemonic: I recommend this to you, so I'd like to invite you to try it. This is a solicitation or invitation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: South Korea
Mnemonic: The Korea Country is Korea, of course... well, South Korea that is.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Spam
Mnemonic: When you have "troublesome" (迷惑) mail, you have mail you don't want. This is known as spam, spam mail, or junk mail. On a more technical level it's unsolicited mail.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 迷惑, so if you know that you know this (and then this vocab word won't be unsolicited as well!)

Name: Supervision
Mnemonic: The one who oversees and directs is the one who gives supervision.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Surveillance
Mnemonic: You oversee and look at all that is in your domain. You are conducting surveillance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Terrifying
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of fear? When you really feel fear, you think something is terrifying or frightening or even dreadful.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: How terrifying is it? It's Oh so (おそ) terrifying!

Name: Terror
Mnemonic: I fear it. It is scary. It is pure terror.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Textile
Mnemonic: The things that are weaved are, essentially, just textile or fabric.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. With 織 you can pull the reading from 織る. With 物 you've probably seen it enough to know that it's often もの and not ぶつ. Just think of a piece of cloth that is monochrome.

Name: Three Cups
Mnemonic: Three cups of liquid is equals to three cups or three drinks. It can also mean three glasses depending on what your drink is in!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for 杯, which becomes ばい thanks to our old friend rendaku.

Name: To Abbreviate
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means abbreviation, so the verb vocab version is to abbreviate or to shorten. In some cases, it can also mean to omit something for the sake of simplicity.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is, strangely, the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. りゃくす.

Name: To Accumulate
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accumulate and the verb version is to accumulate.
ReadingMnemonic: If something accumulates, you can start with one, but you need at least two (つ) things to say it has accumulated. If you don't, then there's nothing accumulating at all.

Name: To Add Something To
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. When appending something, you basically want to add something to something, or to include something with it.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: One way to add something to something else is to just sew (そ) it on!

Name: To Anger Someone
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 怒る means "to get angry?" Well this is when someone else gets angry and it's because YOU made them angry. It means to anger someone.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 怒る, so you should know this one too!

Name: To Ascend
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ascend so the verb vocab version must be to ascend, or to rise.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but it's pretty easy. How do you read all the other "to climb" words? 登る is one example. 上る is another. They're all のぼる, and so is this. Unlike the other climbing words, though, this suggests there's no effort involved. That's why you're "ascending" and not climbing, because climbing is a bit of work.

Name: To Break Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means break so the verb vocab version is to break something, because you're doing the breaking. You know this because someone is trying to sue (す) you for the things you broke of theirs.
ReadingMnemonic: The thing you broke? A beautiful ceramic koala (こわ). Watch it shatter to the ground, because you threw it there. What a jerk you are.

Name: To Draw Near
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're too shy to draw near to people, just learn how to use a yo-yo (よ)! Then people will draw near to YOU to compliment you on your sick skills. You won't have to do it yourself!

Name: To Entrust Something
Mnemonic: The meaning of this word is the same as 任せる. Both words are pretty common, but 任す is slightly less common than 任せる.
ReadingMnemonic: This uses the same reading you learned with 任せる.

Name: To Examine A Patient
Mnemonic: In order to diagnose a patient, you must first go to examine a patient. When you examine them you know what's wrong with them and then you can diagnose them, which is why this verb is to examine.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 見る, which you have to do when you are examining a patient. So, you look and see all you can about the patient while you examine them, making this reading みる as well.

Name: To Get A Position
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means get a position. The verb vocab version is to get a position, or to get a job.
ReadingMnemonic: If you want to get a position, there are two (つ) interviews. Just pass the two interviews to get a job!

Name: To Get Dry
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dry, so this verb vocab version means to get dry. You're not doing the drying here — it's happening on its own. To remember this, just think about how cool (く) it is that something can become dry all by itself. It's just, like, the magic of nature — how cool is that?
ReadingMnemonic: The 川 (かわ) has started to get dry. Need to use less water around here otherwise it'll become completely dry.

Name: To Get Lost
Mnemonic: Remember 迷う? It means "to get lost." If you get lost on a road, you are still lost, wandering around looking for the correct turn. This word means to be lost or to get lost.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the words 道 and 迷う.

Name: To Get Mad
Mnemonic: What's that feeling when your belly stands up? It's that feeling where something jumps up into your throat (in this case your belly) and you get all pissed off. This word means to get mad.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are 腹 plus 立つ put together. The たつ becomes だつ as a standard reading though. While はらだつ is the standard reading for 腹立つ, it's usually found in more formal settings or writing. You'll probably hear はらたつ more often in everyday conversations, as it’s a shorter, more colloquial way of expressing 腹が立つ!

Name: To Get To The Bottom Of
Meaning: To Get To The Bottom Of
Mnemonic: 極める is "to carry to extremes." If you take the action of seeing something to the extremes, you're going to get to the bottom of whatever it is. You'll be able to identify something, like the truth.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from the words 見る and 極める put together. Get to the bottom of this word and learn it.

Name: To Happen Successively
Mnemonic: Things that happen mutually right next to each other are said to happen successively. In other words, to happen one after another.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi readings. You've learned this reading for 相, but not for 次. Instead of giving you a mnemonic, we think it's easier to remember that 次ぐ being read つぐ comes from the 次 reading つぎ. Not too hard! All in all, that makes this あいつぐ.

Name: To Invite
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means invite. The verb vocab version is to invite.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You saw so (さそ) much in this person that you decided to invite them to dinner.

Name: Tonkatsu
Mnemonic: 豚 comes from 豚肉 (pork), and カツ comes from the word "cutlet" and means just that. And a pork カツ is what any Japanese food fan will probably know as simply tonkatsu, a.k.a. breaded pork cutlet.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi of 豚. You haven't learned that yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You really like tonkatsu so you just ate a whole ton (とん) of it. Imagine how you feel after eating a ton of breaded pork cutlet.

Name: To Recommend
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means recommend so the verb vocab version is to recommend.
ReadingMnemonic: To remember the reading think about how you are going to recommend this restaurant to your friends, Sue and Sue (すす). You refer to them as "Sue Sue" to make things easier on yourself, and they're always looking for recommendations.

Name: To Set Up
Mnemonic: The kanji itself means set up, so this means to set up, as in establishing something in an orderly manner.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is like 構う, so as long as you know that you know this too.

Name: To Sleep
Mnemonic: 眠い is "sleepy." The verb version of this is to sleep, or to fall asleep. yawn
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 眠い.

Name: To Stuff In
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stuffed, this word means to stuff in, as in you're doing the stuffing. You know this because you're a mail (める) carrier, and you always have to stuff mail into people's packed mailboxes. Why don't these people check their mail more? It’s hard work trying to cram in all this junk mail!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the kanji, so you should have no troubles here.

Name: To Take On
Mnemonic: Someone requests something, and you're the one to take on their request. Wow, how nice of you to accept that request!
ReadingMnemonic: What's another word for "to accept" or "to receive"? How about 受ける? They share a reading!

Name: To Tighten
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tighten, so the verb vocab version is to tighten.
ReadingMnemonic: What can you do if you want something to tighten or to become tight? You need to hug your sheep (し) really close until... The sheep tightens into a tiny little ball. Cute!

Name: To Urge
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means urge so the verb vocab version is to urge.
ReadingMnemonic: Someone with a weird accent is trying to urge you to eat "Unagah" (うなが). This person really means "unagi," and this person also doesn't realize how delicious unagi is (and thinks he's tricking you). You ask him what "Unagah" is. Go ahead and say it out loud.

Name: To Visit
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means visit and the verb vocab version is also to visit.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading isn't the same as 訪ねる, though, I'm afraid. It's おとず. Remember how this means just visiting a place? Unfortunately, you completely forgot what you were visiting. When you finally remember, it's because you were looking down to think. It's to look at the toes of the giant Buddha statue. "Oh Toes!" (おとず), you exclaim.

Name: Two Cups
Mnemonic: Two cups of liquid is equals to two cups or two drinks. It can also mean two glasses, depending on what your drink is in!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Unhealthy
Mnemonic: If 健康 is "health," then something that is not this is unhealthy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 健康 first.

Name: Unpolished Rice
Mnemonic: Mysterious rice is unpolished rice, or brown rice. You're used to seeing nice white rice, so seeing rice look any other way is really strange for you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 米 so here's a mnemonic to help you: The biggest problem when you buy unpolished rice is the mice (まい)! Mice like to eat and sleep in unpolished rice, so you have to be careful when you buy a bag that you get rid of all the sleeping mice before you try to cook it.

Name: Urge
Mnemonic: I'm so for this I'm willing to sponsor you. I am going to urge you to do this until you do it, so much so I'll give you money. This is one great urge and press for you to do this!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Urgent
Mnemonic: Things are tense and we have to hurry! This is quite the urgent emergency!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Very Strong
Mnemonic: Things that are strong and intense are very strong and intense.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Volume
Mnemonic: In the body, liquids accumulate. It can be the body of a cup, a body of a bucket, or the body of your body. Whatever it is, this body accumulation represents the volume of liquid in your body.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Zen Sect
Mnemonic: The zen religion is a part of Buddhism. It is the Zen sect of Buddhism.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Affair
Mnemonic: You are floating above everything, at least that's how your spirit feels. You're having an affair, and feel like nothing will catch you but... wait, what's that? Is that your wife? Oh no... not floating anymore, you're not.
ReadingMnemonic: This kanji uses the kun'yomi read for the first kanji, and the on'yomi reading for the second. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this too.

Name: A List
Mnemonic: With just one look at something you're able to take in all the info you need, because that something is a list. A nice list that gives you an overview at a glance. Perfect for all that looking over you have to do. You busy consumer of information, you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: A Little While Ago
Mnemonic: The previous extent of time was a little while ago. Just think to a previous extent of time that was indeed a little while ago. Now, associate!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the words 先 and 程, put together.

Name: Allure
Mnemonic: The alluring power is the power of allure.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Amusement Park
Mnemonic: The play park ground is where you go play. It's fun. It's an amusement park!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Appropriate
Mnemonic: Everything is suitable and right. Therefore it is appropriate, proper, and suitable. Strangely enough, this also means irresponsible. Maybe it's because when everything is suitable and right for you, you're taking too much and not leaving enough for everyone else, making you irresponsible?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Attire
Mnemonic: The clothes with which I decorate myself with is my attire or my fashion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Background
Mnemonic: The back scene is the scene going on in the back. You don't really notice it, because it's the background.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Background
Mnemonic: Something that's behind your back is in the background. It's also probably plotting against you, behind the scenes. Sneaky, sneaky.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

Name: Bank Deposit
Mnemonic: Deposit your gold here in the bank. When you do that, it is a bank deposit.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Buffet
Mnemonic: バイキング comes from the English word Viking, but in Japanese, it often refers to a buffet.

Name: Bureaucratic
Mnemonic: If 官僚 is "bureaucracy," then adding a 的 to it would make it bureaucratic.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 官僚 will help a lot too.

Name: Burglary
Mnemonic: You are strong so you break into someone's home, hold them up, then steal from them. Ha ha! Take that, next door neighbor! This is a burglary or robbery, depending on how crazy you get after you use that strength to break down that door.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. But 強  has two on'yomi readings, and you haven't really seen this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you out: Think about how when you commit a robbery, you go (ごう) into someone's house, then you go to jail as well, if you're caught.

Name: Copyright
Mnemonic: You have edition rights over this. This edition is yours, and if anyone copies this edition, they get in trouble. You have copyright.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Decorative Lighting
Mnemonic: The 電 is what powers electric things. Many times, these electric things light up (especially back in the day, when electricity did this a lot more than other things). So, you have "lighting." Then, you have decorate. So, if you decorate with lighting, you have decorative lighting.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Delicate
Mnemonic: The kanji means delicate, and so does this word. Something that's delicate is probably also faint and indistinct. So use 微か to describe things like faint sounds, delicate breezes, and indistinct memories.
ReadingMnemonic: You should speak in a delicate and faint voice when you cuss (かす). So delicate that the cuss words are indistinct to other people, even. It's the only acceptable way to cuss.

Name: Electric Fence
Mnemonic: If you combine 電気 (electricity) with 柵 (fence) you have an electric fence. Shocking, I know.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Emigrant
Mnemonic: If you shift the place you dwell, you’re someone that we call an emigrant, an immigrant, or a migrant. Welcome, friend!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Exposition
Mnemonic: An exhibition that you look at and all the people come meet together. Well, that just sounds like the description of an exposition.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Fence
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Isn't that fencetastic?
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi, which you learned with the kanji. Just think about the sack (さく) hanging on the fence.

Name: First Edition
Mnemonic: The first edition is the first edition.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Flag
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The one with the flag is the Mad Hatter (はた). Just imagine looking through a group of people. You have to find the Mad Hatter, and he has to find you. That's why he offered to wear a flag on his hat.

Name: Height
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Where you're from, everyone measures their height in celery (せ). No inches or centimeters for you, it's celery sticks only. How many celery sticks tall are you?

Name: High Speed
Mnemonic: It's pleasant but also fast. When getting on a train, it's nice to find a train that's both of these things. What makes it pleasant? That would be the high speed. What makes it fast? Also the high speed. Really, if you're on a train you'd rather get to your destination sooner than later, so a high speed 快速 train is the way to go.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Honeymoon
Mnemonic: You know that 旅行 is a trip. The other part is new marriage. What's the trip you go on after a new marriage? The honeymoon!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Illumination
Mnemonic: Illuminate and make things bright, my illumination!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Iron Fence
Mnemonic: Ready for this one? An iron fence  is an iron fence. Don't you love it when it's straightforward?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful though, 鉄 is normally read as てつ, but in this case it is shortened to てっ.

Name: Iron Plate
Mnemonic: Well, you've got iron and you've got a board. You'd probably just call it an iron plate, though. But this often isn't just any iron plate. If you could guess from the reading, it's often used in cooking as an iron griddle, or a teppan grill. Ever heard of Teppanyaki?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Watch out for the rendaku and you should be good!

Name: I See
Mnemonic: If you become aware of something to an extent you'll end up saying I see or That's right! But you won't see if you didn't become aware enough. So it's that extent of understanding you're trying to reach before you can chime in with an "Ahh, indeed."
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. The reading for 成 is from 成る and it keeps the る part. It's just hidden in the kanji. If you can remember that, you'll know this reading!

Name: Japanese Descent
Mnemonic: The 日 stands for 日本 here, making it mean "Japanese." So what's a more common way of saying Japanese lineage? That would be Japanese descent or Japanese origin.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Kindergarten
Mnemonic: If 幼稚 is childish, then a garden for childish people would be a place full of lots of children, probably growing in some way. When you're growing little children in a garden, you're putting them into some kind of school. In this case, it's a kindergarten.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 幼稚 as well.

Name: Lack
Mnemonic: We are lacking and things are scarce. We have a lack and scarcity of resources.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Leak
Mnemonic: Something is leaking and whatever is leaking is exiting what it was in before. This is when a leak occurs.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Looking At
Mnemonic: ご覧 is the polite noun form of 見る and means looking at, seeing, or watching. It's often paired with 〜になる, as in ご覧になる, which is a respectful way to describe someone else's 見る action.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Go look at the next lesson, now.

Name: Marriage
Mnemonic: Let's bind this marriage up with a marriage. No better way to make a marriage happen than a marriage, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Marriage Proposal
Mnemonic: When you request marriage with someone else, you are doing a marriage proposal. Will you marry me, Brad Pitt?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Mental
Mnemonic: Your 精神 is your spirit or your mind. If you add 的 to it, you get mental. It can mean spiritual too, but it more often shows up in reference to a person's mental or emotional state.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Mental Illness
Mnemonic: 精神 is your spirit or mind, the non-physical part of you. When it's sick, it's a mental illness or mental disorder.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know 精神 already, though.

Name: National Flag
Mnemonic: A country's flag is the flag they use for their nation. It's the national flag.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The こく gets shortened to こっ, though, so look out for that.

Name: Niece
Mnemonic: This is just the kanji niece as a vocab, so this also means niece!
ReadingMnemonic: As a standalone vocab, this uses the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, that's what you learned with the kanji, so no new reading here!

Name: Noise
Mnemonic: Boisterous sound is when there's a lot of noise around you. It's the din of the crowd or environment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Nostalgic
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of nostalgia? It's nostalgic.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. Do you remember doing that? Oh man, those were the days. How 懐かしい.

Name: Our
Mnemonic: Here we have I followed by the particle が, giving us a somewhat old-fashioned and stylized way of say our, one's own, or my.
ReadingMnemonic: You haven't learned this reading for 我 so here's a mnemonic to help you: Let us present you with our walrus (わ). Well it's my walrus really, but I'm happy to share.

Name: Overstepping Your Authority
Mnemonic: If you go beyond your rights, you are going too far. You're doing what you're not supposed to do, and you're overstepping your authority.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Owner
Mnemonic: The master is the owner who has dominance or control over something.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is of course different from what you learned with the kanji. Think of this: The owner of those nude sheep (ぬし) doesn’t even need their wool, he just likes owning nude sheep. So he keeps them as pets and shaves them every day. He’s not interested in sheep with fur. Only nude sheep for this owner!

Name: Photography
Mnemonic: If you photograph a shadow, you're obviously doing some kind of photography. (In the old days photography meant using light to burn shadows onto special paper, but now it's all fancy and digital.) This isn't just still photography though; it also means filming (as in a video or movie). Basically, if it has to do with taking photos or video, 撮影 is your dude.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Pillow
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, huzzah!

Name: Plagiarism
Mnemonic: Steal what other people make? Wow. Way to go. That is plagiarism.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Pleasant
Mnemonic: Something that is both pleasant and suitable is still really pleasant.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pleasant
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of pleasant? It is also pleasant.
ReadingMnemonic: This word's reading is pretty weird. We're going to think back to a couple different words to put this one together. The word for heart (心), is こころ. The word for good is よい (or いい, but for this word's sake, よい). A "good heart (feeling)" is one where your heart feels nice and warm and fuzzy (figuratively, not literally. If it's literal, go to the hospital please). That is a pleasant feeling. A こころよい feeling.

Name: Pleasure
Mnemonic: When you have the feeling of pleasantness, you are experiencing pleasure.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Pleasure
Mnemonic: Pleasant comfort brings you a lot of pleasure.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Poor
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of poor? It's poor.
ReadingMnemonic: You know the word 先ず (まず)? It means something along the lines of "first of all." So, if you're poor, first of all (まず), you're going to want to get some help. Second of all, learn how to play the guitar and make funny jokes.

Name: Poor
Mnemonic: You are poor and money / food is very scarce for you, making you poor.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Prime Minister
Mnemonic: The whole reason our country is still running is because of our "minister" (大臣). Which minister? The prime minister, of course. Without our prime minister, we'd all be doomed I say. DOOMED!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It also contains a vocab word you've learned recently, 大臣!

Name: Prime Minister
Mnemonic: This is an abbreviation of 総理大臣 (prime minister), so this means prime minister.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It'll also help if you remember the longer version of this word, 総理大臣.

Name: Prolonging
Mnemonic: Prolong it for a long while. We need more time. We need a prolonging or  extension of some kind.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Properly
Mnemonic: If the extent you go to do something is properly (よく) done, then you did it properly and well!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You learned this reading already! Nice!

Name: Publishing
Mnemonic: If you exit that edition out of your hands and into the world, you've gotten something published! That is publishing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Purchase
Mnemonic: When your purchase enters into effect, you have made your purchase.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Purchasing
Mnemonic: You purchase and buy something? That's some serious purchasing.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is on'yomi, which is great for 購 but not as great for 買. Luckily, the reading for 買 is buy (ばい), which is the same as the meaning, which is a pretty awesome coincidence.

Name: Push
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Rehabilitation
Mnemonic: Experiencing a renewal of life means going through a process of rehabilitation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Scarce
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of scarce? It's also scarce.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When things are scarce, you have to boat (とぼ) all the way across the lake to find any resources or food, as your side of the lake is picked dry.

Name: Secret Photography
Mnemonic: Stealing photographs of you. Wait, you didn't know you were being photographed / filmed? That's secret photography or secret filming Creeeeeepy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Solar System
Mnemonic: You know 太陽 means "sun," so hopefully you can guess what a sun system is. That's right — it's the solar system!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 太陽.

Name: Stance
Mnemonic: You know 構える, which can mean to assume a stance? This is the noun version, making it stance.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is like 構える, so as long as you know that you know this too.

Name: Stolen Goods
Mnemonic: These are stolen (steal) goods. So, I'll give you a deal, because, you know, they're stolen goods.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Subscription
Mnemonic: This is a purchased read — especially one that comes regularly. In other words, a subscription.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The on'yomi for 読 (どく) is the same as the reading in 読者. In case you forgot, think about how you just got a subscription to dock (どく) magazine. It's all about docks and dock related things. How exciting.

Name: Systematic
Mnemonic: Give a body to a system to make it a real, structured system, you know? Then add 的 to it to make it systematic.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: The Next Day
Mnemonic: The next day is just that, the next day.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: The Next Month
Mnemonic: The next month is the next month.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: The Next Morning
Mnemonic: The next morning is the next morning.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading can be what you've learned with the kanji, よくあさ, or it can be the on'yomi reading across the board, よくちょう. Both are good to remember because よくちょう is more formal (you'll use that reading in writing more often) and よくあさ is more informal - you'll use that in speaking more often.

Name: The Next Year
Mnemonic: The next year is the next year.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading can be the on'yomi for 年 or the kun'yomi. So, you can do either よくねん or よくとし, or preferably both.

Name: Ticket
Mnemonic: A cut token is a token you cut out from a sheet of paper into smaller sheets, and each of these pieces is a ticket.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 切る cut short to きっ, then ふ rendaku'd to ぷ. It's a bit of a troublesome word, so concentrate on this now a bit so you can get it in the reviews.

Name: To Arrange Something
Mnemonic: Remember 揃う, "to be complete"? This is the transitive version of that, and it means things like to arrange something, to gather something, and to align something.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You already know this, so you're all good here!

Name: To Attack
Mnemonic: 攻撃 is an attack. Make that into a verb and you have to attack.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 攻撃 as well.

Name: To Become Thirsty
Mnemonic: When you have a thirst, you tend to become thirsty.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go grab a cup of water so you don't become dehydrated, okay?

Name: To Be Scared
Mnemonic: 怖い is "scary." This is a verb version, making it to be scared or to be afraid of.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 怖い.

Name: To Be Shifted
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shift and the verb vocab version is to be shifted. You know that this is the one where something is shifted (and you're not doing the shifting), because it's really rude (る) to be shifted, and you don't like it when people do it to you (because it happens quite a lot, strangely).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 移す, so use that to remember this!

Name: To Be Stuffed
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stuffed. The vocab word is to be stuffed, as in something is stuffed and you're not doing the stuffing. You know this because when it comes to まる the cat, he stuffs himself into boxes on his own, so you don't have to stuff him into boxes for him. It just happens, and you can watch and be entertained (obviously you need to go watch some Maru videos if you haven't on YouTube, just saying).
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the reading you learned with the kanji!

Name: To Chill Something
Mnemonic: 冷たい is "cold." This is the verb version, so you're making something cold. This word is to chill something or to cool something.
ReadingMnemonic: To chill something, you need to apply cold, not heat (ひ).

Name: To Decorate
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decorate. The verb vocab version is to decorate.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To decorate something, you don't really need a cause (かざ). You should just do it, just because.

Name: To Deposit
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deposit so the verb vocab version is to deposit or to entrust.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In terms of places where you want to deposit your money, the last place on your list should be a zoo (あず). I mean seriously, you know the animals are just gonna munch up all your dolla bills.

Name: To Diagnose
Mnemonic: 診断 is a diagnosis. Make this into a verb, and you have to diagnose.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Die Out
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means die out so the verb vocab version is to die out or to come to an end.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading can come from 絶つ, so as long as you know that word you know this one as well.

Name: To Feel Shy
Mnemonic: Your feel as if your cheeks are illuminated when you start to feel shy. Probably illuminated in red, which is why this also means to blush.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you feel the most embarrassed about is your 手 (て). It's all blue and scary looking.

Name: To Float
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means float so the verb vocab version is to float.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji. う!

Name: To Get Buried
Mnemonic: You know that 埋まる is "to be buried." This verb is also to be buried or to get buried.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 埋める.

Name: To Go Beyond
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means go beyond, the verb vocab version is to go beyond.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To go beyond child (こ) years in order to become an adult, you have to be 18 years old in both the USA and Japan.

Name: To Hold Something Down
Mnemonic: The kanji means push, and this verb means things like to hold something down and to grasp something. This verb is pretty versatile, and you can use it if you're holding down a piece of paper, holding a cloth to a wound, or grasping a concept.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, so hopefully you can read this on your own.

Name: To Injure Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the word 痛い.

Name: To Leak
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means leak so the verb vocab version is to leak.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Causing you to leak all over the floor (we're talking blood, here) is your friend Moe (も). If you know someone named Moe, imagine them doing this. If you don't, think of a famous Moe.

Name: To Line Something Up
Mnemonic: 並ぶ is when something is lining up. 並べる is when you're lining something up. In other words, 並べる is transitive. It means to line something up or to put something in order. You know this because when it comes to bears (べる), you have to line them up yourself, because they won't be doing it for you, that's for sure.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading of the kanji is same as for 並ぶ, so if you know that you can figure out the reading for this one as well.

Name: To Make Noise
Mnemonic: The kanji is boisterous. The verb version is to make noise or to be boisterous. Basically, you're being boisterous when you make a lot of noise, so that's where it comes from.
ReadingMnemonic: You're always going to make noise and be boisterous when you eat something sour (さわ). Imagine stuffing lemon slices, sour candy, and umeboshi into your mouth. All at once. See how much noise you make? They're so sour, and they make you so boisterous.

Name: To Move Something Close To
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: You want to move something close to you, but it's out of reach. The solution, of course, is to take out your trusty yo-yo (よ) and lasso that thing and pull it closer!

Name: Tonkotsu Ramen
Mnemonic: Pig bone ramen is tonkotsu ramen or, very logically indeed, pork bone ramen.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You know both of these readings, but in case you need a reminder, here's a mnemonic to help you out: You really like tonkotsu ramen so you just ate a whole ton (とん) of it. Imagine how you feel after eating a ton of pork bone ramen.

Name: To Play
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means play and the verb vocab version is to play.
ReadingMnemonic: You want to play with everyone, but every once in a while someone doesn't want to play with you. You know what? That's okay. If someone doesn't want to play with you, they're the a**hole (あそ), not you.

Name: To Postpone
Mnemonic: Can we prolong this period of time to a later date? I want to postpone, if possible.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Prolong Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means prolong and this verb means to prolong something.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Do you mind if I go to prolong things? The answer? "No (の), I don't mind."

Name: To Push
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means push so the verb vocab version is to push.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, actually!

Name: To Register
Mnemonic: 登録 is registration. Make that into a verb and you have to register.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Repel Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this with its intransitive pair verb 退く, but here's a mnemonic just in case: Remember the re-zoner? Well, to repel bad luck, she, re-zoned (しりぞ) the whole place. No bad luck allowed inside the zone.

Name: To Smell
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means smell so the verb version is to smell.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

Name: To Steal
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means steal, so the verb vocab version is to steal.
ReadingMnemonic: What are you going to steal? How about a noose (ぬす)? Wait, why are you stealing a noose? That sounds like trouble to me...

Name: To Take A Picture
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means photograph. When you make that into a verb, it becomes to take a picture. It can also mean to take a video. Basically, it's for any form of shooting you do with a camera!
ReadingMnemonic: To take a picture, to take a video… You "take" all these things. And how do you say "to take" in Japanese? It's 取る (とる), which happens to share a reading with this word. Different kanji but related meanings, and exactly the same reading!

Name: To Wet
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wet or damp, so the verb version is to wet or to dampen something.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

Name: Trainee
Mnemonic: 研修 is a training or study of some kind. If it's in your current life (生) that you are doing the training, then you are a trainee. This is a lot like how a student is in the status of "study life."
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading from 研修 should also help you too.

Name: Treatment
Mnemonic: We're going to deal with it by putting this up your butt and giving you the treatment you need. Kancho!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Type
Mnemonic: Trace something back through its lineage to determine what type of thing it is.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because this word gets stuck onto other things to describe tribes and groups.

Name: Ukiyo-e
Mnemonic: A floating world painting is what you call an ukiyo-e woodblock print in Japan. The "floating world" refers to an evanescent world that is impermanent (floating), just as beauty and entertainment are. Back in the day, this type of art was made into woodblock prints and paintings. Unfortunately, we don't have a name for these in English because they're so unique and special, but they come up more than you'd think, so get used to ukiyo-e!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings don't really line up perfectly, but they're close (although mixed in terms of what has what reading). Take a look at the word and break everything down. 浮 takes the kun'yomi うき (from 浮く), 世 also takes the kun'yomi よ, and then 絵 takes the on'yomi え. Put that all together and you have うきよえ! Or if you already know the word ukiyo-e, that works too!

Name: Unmarried
Mnemonic: Not yet marriage? You haven't been married. You're unmarried.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Unpleasant
Mnemonic: Things that are not pleasant are unpleasant or uncomfortable.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Unsuitable
Mnemonic: Something that is not suitable is unsuitable and inappropriate.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Upside Down
Mnemonic: Something is reverse, that much you know. The さま comes from 様, which could mean manner. So, something that is in a "reverse manner," is something that is upside down.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 逆らう and 様, put together. A bit of an upside down reading if I do say so myself, but you do what you gotta do.

Name: Various Joints
