Mnemonic: Your joint joints are your various joints, or even every joint in your body, or a specific body part. When we're not talking about the joints in your body, this means something like various parts, referring to various parts of a whole.
ReadingMnemonic: This is just the kun'yomi of 節, which you learned with 節目, repeated twice. Keep in mind that the second ふし gets rendaku'd to ぶし!

Name: Viewing
Mnemonic: If you view and look at something, you are viewing that thing, or watching it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Water Leakage
Mnemonic: A leak of water is a water leakage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: With All One's Might
Mnemonic: You put one cup of liquid... no, one full cup of liquid spirit into what you're doing. None of this half-cup garbage. A full one. That means you're going at it with all one's might.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you've seen 一杯 before.

Name: Abundant
Mnemonic: Something that's plentiful and rich is abundant, plentiful and rich.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi of both kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Academic Inquiry
Mnemonic: Look for something. Research answers. This is an academic inquiry, or in other words, research.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Admiration
Mnemonic: I'm so surprised it caused me to sigh. This is like when you run into a movie star, and you go in surprise shock. Then, you breathe out in a sigh because of your great amount of admiration and wonder for this person.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Airplane Ticket
Mnemonic: An aviation (航空) ticket is the kind of ticket you need to fly on an airplane. That's an airplane ticket.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Already
Mnemonic: One of the meanings is the same as the kanji, previously, but it can also mean already.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is different from what you learned with the kanji. But as I told you already, I'll be there on Su-day (すで). It's like Sunday, but not quite the same. Imagine your confusion when someone says this over and over, but you don't know what Suday is.

Name: Ambulance
Mnemonic: Rescue in a hurry using this car. What kinds of cars can do this? How about an ambulance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Appraisal
Mnemonic: When a model human determines something, that's an appraisal you should probably pay attention to. This isn't just some random nobody off the street — they're a model determiner, so they're really giving you an expert judgment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: A Stroll
Mnemonic: Scatter around the ground and walk. When you walk in a scatter all around, you're going for a walk or a stroll.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ほ goes to ぽ, though.

Name: Average
Mnemonic: Something that's flat and equal to everything around it, all those flat things around it, are average. They're the mean (same as average).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Beehive
Mnemonic: ハチ is a bee. Buzz buzz. Just imagine "eight bees" combining into one bee, making it a "hachi." Then, there's a nest. What is a nest for bees? A beehive.
ReadingMnemonic: 巣 is a standalone word here, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary.

Name: Bodyguard
Mnemonic: "Use your heart and this pole when you guard me," you tell your bodyguard. A good bodyguard needs both — the heart of a lion, and a nice sturdy pole to smack fools with.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cemetery
Mnemonic: A grave ground is an area with lots of graves in the ground. This is a cemetery, or graveyard.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chinese
Mnemonic: 中国 is China, right? That's what this 中 represents. And, of course the Chinese are known for being super showy, which is why you have showy there.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Cleaning
Mnemonic: Sweep and exclude all that dirt from the floor, please. When you do this a lot, it becomes cleaning.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. For this one though, you have to remember to read the 除 part as じ. Just keep in mind that cleaning (cleanliness) is next to godliness and so is Jesus (じ). So, Jesus is like cleaning. Easy.

Name: Continent
Mnemonic: A big land is the biggest types of land on this earth that there are. That is a continent.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Corridor
Mnemonic: A corridor is below. What do you call a corridor that's below? Well, really it's still just a corridor or hallway.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Currency

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Decided
Mnemonic: It was previously decided, which means it's been decided and settled.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Descendant

Name: Diameter

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Dissolution
Mnemonic: Untie and scatter everything. This will cause the dissolution the breakup, and indeed the breaking up of whatever is being untied then scattered.

Name: Divorce

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Edit

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Editor
Mnemonic: A knit someone is one who knits words together and makes them better. This someone is an editor.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Equality
Mnemonic: This is equal and that is equal. They're both the same, amazing! They carry equality, uniformity,  and evenness.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Exception

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Exclamation Mark
Mnemonic: A feeling where you sigh is one in which you're surprised by something, and can't believe it, so you sigh. Ugh, *sigh*. What token represents this in writing? An exclamation mark!!!!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Existing
Mnemonic: Something that previously existed is probably still existing now.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Fear
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji fear, so it means fear too.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: Financing
Mnemonic: Someone dissolves their resources in order to more easily give them to you, because they are financing you with a loan. This someone is an investor, and they want to see your business succeed!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Flower Arrangement
Mnemonic: The way of the flower is flower arrangement.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fragile Thing
Mnemonic: A thing that could break easily, is a fragile thing. Be careful with things like this.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 壊れる and 物 put together.

Name: Freight
Mnemonic: Freight things is freight or cargo.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the 物 reading that's もつ. You can know this because you have to carry the freight and cargo (持つ it!).

Name: Fusion
Mnemonic: Dissolve and then join together again to create a reaction, a fusion reaction.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Gaudy
Mnemonic: If something has showy beauty then it's going a little overboard and is going to come across as gaudy. Too much is too much.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Geometry
Mnemonic: How many? What? In this area of study, you ask these questions a lot. This area of study is geometry, because you have to ask how many sides and how much the area is or something (can you tell I don't remember any maths?).
ReadingMnemonic: The 学 is read correctly, in terms of what you learned. The 幾 and 何 is weird, though. Just think how when you're asking a question in Japanese, you end the sentence with か. So, it's like, "何か????" and that's why it becomes か. Then, for 幾 think about how the key (き) to answering geometry questions correctly is figuring out "how many" sides something has. So, "do you have the keyか?"

Name: Grandchild
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are the grandchild of your grandfather. His favorite thing is to call you a maggot (まご). Your grandfather was in the military and is very hard on you, maggot.

Name: Grave
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: You went to your grave because you were a hacker (はか). You made a lot of powerful enemies with all your hacker exploits, and before you knew it, you were six feet deep.

Name: Hay Fever
Mnemonic: The flower powder symptoms are when you start sneezing from flower powder, aka pollen that comes from all sorts of flowers, which is pretty much all plants. This word, however, refers to the most common version of this sickness, which is hay fever.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is all on'yomi readings, which you learned for all but 花. Instead, 花 is か, and to remember that you can think about how the only way to escape the hay fever is to jump in your car and turn on the filter. Sweet, sweet relief.

Name: How Many
Mnemonic: This has the same meaning as the kanji, specifically the how many meaning. You know this because you ask "how many" and they answer "つ." This can also be used to ask how old someone is, but generally only for children's ages.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from what you learned in the kanji, nice job.

Name: How Many Times
Mnemonic: How many occurences is just another way of asking how many times.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

Name: How Much
Mnemonic: This has the same meaning as the kanji, specifically the how much meaning. To remember this, just think about how Ra, the Egyptian God, is always asking "How much will it cost to build this pyramid?" Ugh, too much, let's hire some slaves.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: Interrogation
Mnemonic: When you inquire about a problem, you tend to do interrogation-style questioning to get to the bottom of it. Why is it like this? What happened? Is it bigger than a breadbox?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Land Army
Mnemonic: The land army is the land army, also known as the plain old army.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Leave The Nest
Mnemonic: When you stand up out of the nest, you're getting ready to leave it. Your mother may be sad about this, but this means it's time to leave the nest and become independent.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are from the words 巣 and 立つ put together. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes たつ to だつ!

Name: Luxurious
Mnemonic: Oh wow, that is exceptionally showy! Whatever that thing is, it is luxurious and splendid and I want one.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Male
Mnemonic: The kanji means male and this also means male. It's mostly used for animals.
ReadingMnemonic: Male animals can be kind of pushy, always trying to push (押す) other animals around, trying to be the alpha and all.

Name: Male Dog
Mnemonic: A male dog is a male dog.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings, which is probably A-Okay for 犬, but for 雄 you'll want to think about how a male dog is probably pretty pushy, always trying to push (押す) other dogs around, being male and moody and all that.

Name: Minister Of Foreign Affairs
Mnemonic: An outside tasks minister (大臣) is someone who is tasked with dealing with things that are outside the country. This is the minister of foreign affairs.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Morals

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mountain Range

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mt Fuji

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mud
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a mnemonic in case you need a refresher: You may know of Dora the Explorer. But have you heard about her dirty, muddy brother, Doro (どろ)? They're like a team. And because of all the exploring he does, Doro is always covered in mud.

Name: Muddy Water
Mnemonic: Mud water is muddy water. Don't step in it, if you can help it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. There's another way to read this word that uses both on'yomi readings (でいすい). It's mostly used in more formal or technical situations though, so we're focusing on the どろみず reading here!

Name: Nest
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Normal
Mnemonic: You pass through like completely normal. You are normal. You do things normally, normally.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Obi
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are the same, except that this isn't just any type of belt. It's an obi, a wide cloth belt worn with traditional clothes like kimono and yukata.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is obi (おび), so if you know the meaning, you know the reading as well! If you need an extra reminder, ask yourself "What is the first letter in belt?" Hmm, I can't remember. OH! "B" (おび)! I remember now.

Name: Obstruction
Mnemonic: Something that obstructs and also does damage is an obstruction. No obstruction is ever good and if left too long it really will cause damage and interference as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Our Country
Mnemonic: You learned that 我が means "our", so our country is simply our country.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading for 我 when you learned 我が. Just watch out for 国, which you might expect to rendaku here, but doesn't!

Name: Picture Gallery
Mnemonic: An image corridor is a corridor in which there are images hanging on the wall. This is a picture gallery.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pole
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Powder
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also mean flour.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Just imagine there’s powder all over Conan’s (こな) hands and face. Detective Conan, that is. Conan has been investigating some kind of bakery murder. He had to dig through sacks of flour to find the hidden murder weapon (rolling pin, naturally) and now Conan is just covered in the white, starchy powder.

Name: Powdered
Mnemonic: Something that is in a powder condition is something that has been powdered. Puff!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Private Detective
Mnemonic: You look for things and you spy on people. Your job isn't as glamorous as it sounds. You're a private detective.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Probably
Mnemonic: The kanji in this word means fear, but the word itself means probably. I guess you only have to fear something if it's probably going to happen, you know?
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: Radius
Mnemonic: Half a diameter is a radius.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Scouting
Mnemonic: Inside spying is when you get inside enemy territory and spy on them. This is scouting and reconnaissance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Seal
Mnemonic: A seal that's modeled after you is a useful seal indeed — it's your very own personal seal!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Separation
Mnemonic: When you divide and detach things from each other, you're creating separation between them. Makes sense, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Showy
Mnemonic: Something that is showy is showy.
ReadingMnemonic: For the reading, think about something that's showy... in particular, 花s (はな). Flowers are super showy, always showing off their colors and stuff.

Name: Sigh
Mnemonic: A sigh breath is a sigh.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Spiderweb
Mnemonic: クモ is a spider. Add a nest to it, and you have a spider nest. What do spiders call their nests? They call it a spiderweb (that is, if they can talk).
ReadingMnemonic: 巣 is a standalone word here, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary.

Name: Storehouse
Mnemonic: The kanji means storehouse, and the vocab is also storehouse!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the other storehouse reading you learned earlier with 庫. They're basically the same thing, and lucky for you they share the same reading too (くら).

Name: Stuffy Nose
Mnemonic: 詰まる is "to be stuffed." So, if your nose is stuffed, then you have a stuffy nose.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 鼻 and 詰まる put together. the 詰まり is rendaku'd, probably because you're trying to say this word with a stuffy nose.

Name: Symmetry
Mnemonic: Things are equal in how they're arranged. They have perfect symmetry and balance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Be Broken
Mnemonic: 壊す is "to break something." 壊れる is when something just gets broken or is broken, and you're not doing the breaking. This is to be broken.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 壊す, so try not to break any of your memories and remember this.

Name: To Be Extended
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 延ばす.

Name: To Be Rich In
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rich so the verb vocab version would be to be rich in.
ReadingMnemonic: Think about the richest person you know. That person is Tom (とむ). Imagine Tom as being super rich. If you don't know a Tom, think of a famous Tom, like Tom Cruise, who definitely is pretty rich.

Name: To Be Scattered
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scatter so the verb vocab version is to be scattered or to get scattered.
ReadingMnemonic: Think about something scattering. That something is cheese (ち), scattering all over the floor, going everywhere, getting in everything. Ugh, you hate how cheese scatters, don't you?

Name: To Be Surprised
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surprised, so the verb vocab version is to be surprised.
ReadingMnemonic: What are you so surprised by? Your friend's odor (おどろ). Think of a friend that you wouldn't expect to be so smelly. Then, be surprised by the odor. Eww, bro, you have to take a shower.

Name: To Brood
Mnemonic: 詰める is "to stuff in." If you're really stuffing in your thoughts (think), you're thinking very deeply and seriously. So this is to brood, to dwell on, or to take something to heart.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 思い and 詰める put together into one reading.

Name: To Exclude
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means exclude so the verb vocab version is to exclude.
ReadingMnemonic: You would like to exclude your nose (のぞ) because you don't like your nose. Imagine your strong feelings about your nose as you decide to exclude it.

Name: To Fear
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fear so the verb version is to fear.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is shared with 恐ろしい, which is "scary." Use that, and don't be afraid. You'll be able to learn this reading yet.

Name: To Feel Nervous
Mnemonic: 緊張 means "nervousness" or "tension." So, the verb version is to feel nervous or to get tense.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Host
Mnemonic: If 主催 means "host" or "hosting," the verb version of that would be to host.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 主催 already as well.

Name: To Illuminate
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means illuminate, so this means to illuminate or to shine light on something.
ReadingMnemonic: Speaking of things that illuminate, your hands (手) illuminate all the time for some reason.

Name: To Inquire
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means inquire so the verb vocab version is to inquire.
ReadingMnemonic: You want to inquire about some serious matters, but Taz (たず), your Tasmanian Devil friend, keeps interrupting to ask silly questions instead.

Name: To Knit
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means knit so the verb vocab version is to knit.
ReadingMnemonic: When you start to knit, you always end up with the same thing every time when you're done, no matter what you're trying to make: The letter "A" (あ). It's so frustrating that you can't knit anything else.

Name: Tokugawa
Mnemonic: This is one of those words that makes more sense when you look at the reading. The "Virtue River" isn't some virtuous river, it's in fact the Tokugawa family name, made famous by the Tokugawa shogunate. They ran Japan for a while, you know?
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are 徳 and the vocab 川 put together into one word. Once you can read this, you'll know the meaning too, so focus on the reading for this one. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes かわ to がわ!

Name: Tokushima Prefecture
Mnemonic: The virtue island prefecture is Tokushima prefecture. The reading will give away the meaning of this one, so long as you knew "prefecture."
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the individual kanji. Put them together and you'll know this is Tokushima Prefecture.

Name: To Lament
Mnemonic: When you sigh, you feel a certain type of emotion. A type that makes you feel sad and causes you to lament and to grieve.
ReadingMnemonic: For the reading, just think about this feeling you're having (this lamenting grieving one). Then, decide you're done with it. 投げる (throw) it out the window. You don't want these feels anymore!

Name: To Lead Someone Astray
Mnemonic: You learned 迷う means "to go astray," and 迷わす is its transitive version, meaning it takes a direct object. So it means to lead someone astray, to perplex someone, or to mislead someone.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 迷う, so use that so you aren't lead astray too.

Name: To Let Something Die Out
Mnemonic: Remember how 絶える means "to die out?" Well 絶やす is its transitive version, meaning to let something die out or to put an end to something.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 絶える.

Name: To Look For
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means look for and the verb version of the kanji is to look for.
ReadingMnemonic: You are looking for a sagger (さが) amongst the products you're shipping off overseas. The saggers are the boxes that have weird lumps sagging out of them, which means they broke and are getting things wet. So, find the saggers. Go to search for them, because they could ruin the whole shipment.

Name: To Pile Something Up
Mnemonic: You learned that 積もる (to accumulate) is used when something like snow or dust piles up over time. 積む is the transitive version, so it means to pile something up, to stack up, or to load. You know this because you are the one moving (む) things to pile them up!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 積もる, so pile up your knowledge and remember it that way.

Name: To Rescue
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rescue so the verb vocab version is to rescue.
ReadingMnemonic: The すく in the reading is a lot like the scue (すくう) part of to rescue, don't you think? Hopefully you do, so you can make the connection.

Name: To Resemble
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means resemble so the verb vocab version is to resemble or to look like.
ReadingMnemonic: You should have learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a mnemonic to help you, just in case: What are you trying to resemble?? Is that... oh no. A knee (に) face resemble surgery, where you make your face look like your knee and vice versa? Do you know how dangerous that surgery is?

Name: To Separate
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means detach, but what happens when something detaches? It causes it to separate and to leave. This refers to when something separates on its own. You aren't doing the separating. You know this because it's rare (れる) to see things separate, but sometimes you do see them. Also, whenever you see れる usually it's a safe bet that you're not the one doing the action, right? Think about it.
ReadingMnemonic: For the reading, think about what is separating. It's quite sad, because all of the 花s (はな) are separating from their stems and falling on the ground, and nobody knows why. Just falling off and being sad.

Name: To Stare At
Mnemonic: When you really stuff in (詰める) what you are seeing, you're really looking at something, causing you to stare at whatever it is you're stuffing your seeing into.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 見 and 詰める.

Name: To Sweep
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sweep so the verb version is to sweep.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: While you sweep you laugh. "HA (は) HA HA!" Just imagine yourself doing this, or do it for real if you want to clean up a bit.

Name: To Urge
Mnemonic: If 催促 is urge, then the verb version would be to urge.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 催促 first.

Name: Underground Shopping Mall
Mnemonic: An "underground" (地下) street isn't as underground streety as it sounds. A lot of the underground streets and areas in Japan tend to be underground shopping malls.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Usual
Mnemonic: The normal steps are the ones that are totally usual. They're the ones you usually do, unlike those weird not usual steps.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Vegetable
Mnemonic: A field vegetable is still a vegetable, whether it comes from the field or not.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Vegetarian Diet
Mnemonic: If you eat vegetable food you are on a vegetarian diet.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Warehouse
Mnemonic: A storage warehouse is some kind of warehouse, or some kind of storehouse.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Wealth
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. Someone who is rich has wealth and riches, right?
ReadingMnemonic: For the reading, think about the person you know with the most wealth. It is Tommy (とみ) Hilfiger.

Name: Wealthy
Mnemonic: If you're rich and abundant, you are super wealthy, affluent, and rich.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Zone
Mnemonic: This earth belt is the area within the belt, which holds this area of earth in. It is separate from the rest of the earth, making it its own zone or district.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Achievement
Mnemonic: One achievement plus another achievement is an even bigger achievement. Wow, what an accomplishment!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Agreement
Mnemonic: It has become that we agree. We have agreement!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ambition
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: When you have the ambition to do something, it feels like you're pointing at it with your heart. To say "heart pointing" in Japanese, you could say 心ざし (こころざし), which is how this word was written in classical Japanese. In modern Japanese it's always 志, but the reading is exactly the same. Now get out there and heart point to your dreams!

Name: Ancestors
Mnemonic: Your previous ancestors are your ancestors. All ancestors are previous to you, after all, unless you want to talk time travel, then who knows.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember there is a rendaku that changes そ to ぞ！

Name: Appetite
Mnemonic: I have a food want. When I want food (or when I don't want food), it has to do with your appetite.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Benefactor
Mnemonic: A kindness person is a very kind person. This person is a benefactor.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Blood
Mnemonic: Your blood fluid is your blood.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Boiled Egg
Mnemonic: The ゆで comes from the verb ゆでる, which means "to boil." So this word means boiled egg.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the kanji.

Name: Burn
Mnemonic: A fire wound is a burn or scald you got from fire (or other hot things). Ouch!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this is unlike anything you've seen with these kanji. Try to think about a burn (on your arm) being caused by a yakky dodo (やけど) bird (which is a dodo bird that has yak-like features). Take a look at how weird it is, and wonder why it is burning you. Feel the pain.

Name: Business Suit
Mnemonic: If your back is wide, you need a nice business suit to cover it up when you go to work. Otherwise you'll look completely out of place sitting at a desk like a giant, wide-backed wrestler. Is that what you want to look like? Of course not! You need to go out and buy a fancy suit to cover your wide back up right now!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both already so you should be able to read this too! Just watch out for the weird rendaku here making it び not ひ.

Name: Carnal Desires
Mnemonic: Your meat wants are your deepest desires, your carnal desires.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cherry
Mnemonic: A cherry tree can create a cherry. This is what this word is.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the kanji.

Name: Clamor
Mnemonic: If 騒ぐ is "to make noise," then a big version of this is even louder. It's a clamor and an uproar.
ReadingMnemonic: This is word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, which you should know already because 大 is pretty familiar to you by now (I hope) and you just learned 騒ぐ as well! Put them together, with a little tweaking at the end, and you have your reading. Ta-da!

Name: Closet
Mnemonic: You push things to make them enter the closet or cupboard.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 押し (push the し inside the 押) plus 入れる's reading.

Name: Coin
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It can also mean money more generally.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for the kanji is せん, the reading for this vocab word is ぜに. They're pretty similar, but only ぜに rhymes with "penny."

Name: Communist Party
Mnemonic: The idea of everyone together sharing property between them comes from which party? That's the Communist Party.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Complicated
Mnemonic: There are duplicates of everything, not to mention the duplicates are random. Nothing makes sense, and everything is super complicated.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Constipation
Mnemonic: For this word, the 便 comes from 便所, which you know as "toilet." A toilet secret is one you take with you to the bathroom, one that you don't want people to know about. This is constipation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ひ changes to ぴ because "P" stands for "Poop."

Name: Contagious Disease
Mnemonic: A sickness that can transmit and then dye into you (aka get inside you and infect you, via transmission) is a contagious disease. Everyone cover their mouths when they cough and sneeze, and please wash your hands, okay?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Copying
Mnemonic: When you make a duplicate copy you are copying things. Especially if you're making a photocopy or a carbon copy. It's like a copy of a copy!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Decoration
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji decorate, so it means decoration.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: Desire
Mnemonic: Your intention for your hope is what you want. It's not just a hope. You have intention behind it. This is your desire. This is your ambition.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Desk
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Dirty Water
Mnemonic: Dirty water is dirty water. Gross. Could also be sewage. Even grosser.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Egg
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: English Translation
Mnemonic: English translate is an English translation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Eye
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is just a little more technical than 目.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the word "eye" (目), so use that to remember this!

Name: Eyeball
Mnemonic: An eyeball sphere is an eyeball. Eww.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Farsightedness
Mnemonic: An elderly eyeball is one that can't see things close up. That's why this word means farsightedness. But this is the kind of farsightedness that only comes with age. So you have to be an elderly oldey to have 老眼.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Forever
Mnemonic: Eternity is a long time... as in forever. This word has to do with an actual forever. So, like, forever. Not like an "oh man I haven't done that in forever," because if you've done something before, it's not forever. This is forever for realsies.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Forever
Mnemonic: An eternity that is far away is not really an eternity, it just feels like it. It's forever, but not the real kind of forever that's actually forever. That's 永久, which is a real forever, this is more like "whoa, I haven't eaten sushi in forever" (actually, you have).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Grades
Mnemonic: What kind of things become your achievements? Your grades. At least when you're in school, that is. Your grades become your main achievements, right? So let's take a look at those grades… Oof, some of those "achievements" weren't all that amazing. Don't worry, grades aren't everything.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Grandfather
Mnemonic: Your ancestor father isn't your father, it's the father that came before your father's generation, your grandfather.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is all on'yomi, which is great for 祖 but not as great for 父. To remember that this 父 is ふ, just think about how much of a fool (ふ) your grandfather was, even if he wasn't.

Name: Grandmother
Mnemonic: Your ancestor mother isn't your mother, it's the mother before your mother, your grandmother.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 祖 is known to you, but the 母 part is not. To remember the on'yomi reading for 母 in 祖母, just think about how your grandmother had a boat (ぼ), even if she didn't... and what an amazing boat it was. If you want, you can imagine your grandma is a boat too, but that might not be very nice.

Name: Heartbreak
Mnemonic: A wound of your heart. That could be many things, but in this case it's heartbreak.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Horse Meat
Mnemonic: Strangely, cherry tree meat isn't just some kind of cherry steak... it's horse meat. Hopefully you'll just remember that due to the strangeness of this word's kanji.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the words 桜 and 肉 put together into one horse steak of a word.

Name: Hygiene
Mnemonic: In defense of life, you have to remain clean. If you are dirty, you will die earlier (think: plagues). So, to defend said life, you must have good hygiene.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Infection
Mnemonic: The feeling of dye, covering your body, is the feeling of nasty germs and diseases penetrating your skin, getting inside of you. This is an infection, and it's gross.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Injured Person
Mnemonic: Someone who has a wound is someone who is wounded. They are an injured person.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Interest
Mnemonic: I have an interest in the flavor... You do? Yes, I have a very deep interest in it.
ReadingMnemonic: As a jukugo kanji, you can guess the reading is the on'yomi kanji readings, which it is, so you should be able to read it.

Name: Interpreting
Mnemonic: If you let words pass through you, and as they do you translate them, you are doing interpreting.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Japanese Translation
Mnemonic: Remember how 和 represents Japan? Now, take that and add translate to it. With that, you have Japanese translation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Liberal Democratic Party
Mnemonic: The individual peoples party is the political group that believes in each individual of the people (or something?). The translation doesn't really get hinted at in this meaning, but this group is the Liberal Democratic Party, aka the LDP.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Liquid
Mnemonic: Things that have a fluid body are made of liquid.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Long Ago
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with しい on the end, meaning it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of long time? Well, it's long ago, or can mean for a long time.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Long ago, in a galaxy far away, a bunch of prequel movies were ruined by a single character. "Heesa (ひさ) the best character!" you hear. Oh no. Heesa here. Get out before Jar Jar Binks gets you! Keep him in the past!

Name: Marriage Ceremony
Mnemonic: If 結婚 is marriage, then a marriage ceremony is a marriage ceremony or wedding.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Miscellaneous Expenses
Mnemonic: Random expenses are miscellaneous expenses. Not actually random, but they feel that way.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ざつ goes to ざっ and the ひ goes to ぴ, making it into a dumb sounding word, like "zappy" (ざっぴ), so you can think about how some of your miscellaneous expenses were on zappy items.

Name: Multiple
Mnemonic: The duplicate numbers are when you duplicate the numbers into more numbers, representing multiple.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Noise
Mnemonic: Random noise is still noise, though more specifically it is random noise, like static.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: No Photos
Mnemonic: 撮影 is photography. 禁止 is prohibition. So if photography is prohibited, then we can assume there's a no photos or no photos allowed rule in place.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the words 撮影 and 禁止.

Name: One's Back
Mnemonic: The middle of your back is one's back (or your back).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings, put together, making it the words 背 and 中 combined.

Name: Oxygen
Mnemonic: The acid element is oxygen. In German it’s the same as in Japanese - it’s called “Sauerstoff”, including “sauer”, the word for “sour”. The noun version is “Säure” which means both “sourness” and “acid” (which again is the same in Japanese, the same kanji is used in both words). The word “oxygenium” in Greek/Latin literally means “acid maker”. Long ago chemists thought oxygen was a defining characteristic of acids, later they found out there are also acids without oxygen like hydrochloric/muriatic/salt acid and the defining characteristic actually is hydrogen. But the name stuck.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Party Member
Mnemonic: A party member is party member of a political party.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Personal Connections
Mnemonic: Your person veins are all the veins you have going out to all the different people you know. These are your personal connections, your network.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pink
Mnemonic: A cherry blossom color is what color? Kind of a pink, wouldn't you say? Also, pink can be ピンク, if you want it to be.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the readings for 桜 and 色 combined.

Name: Play
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji play, so it means play or playing!
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned 遊ぶ. It's the same one!

Name: Political Party
Mnemonic: A politics party is a political party.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pollution
Mnemonic: A dirty dye that's all throughout the sky and makes things gross when it touches them is pollution. If it's bad enough it really is like a dye, too, making your white clothes brown, yuck.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Poor Person
Mnemonic: 貧乏 is poor, so a poor person is a poor person.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 貧乏 already.

Name: Preface
Mnemonic: Preface writing is the preface.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Profit
Mnemonic: Gather the money and then calculate how much of it you have. Oh, nice, looks like you have a profit.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Public Bath
Mnemonic: Give a coin and get hot water. So you hand over a coin and then you get hot water in the form of a bath. It's a bath for anyone willing to pay, making it a public bath.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You don't know the on'yomi reading of 湯, though, so just think about how when you get in the public bath, you're in Tokyo (とう), because there are a lot of public baths in Japan, and Tokyo is the most well known city there.

Name: Publishing Company
Mnemonic: If 出版 means publishing, then a company that does said publishing is a publishing company.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 出版 as well, though.

Name: Push Button
Mnemonic: If 押し is push, and a ボタン is a button, then you have yourself a push button.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 押す.

Name: Raw Egg
Mnemonic: Remember how 生 can mean raw? Well, it does now. So, a raw egg? First of all, delicious. Second of all, it means raw egg.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the vocab 生 and 卵 combined into one なまたまご.

Name: Reason
Mnemonic: This word takes the reason meaning of the kanji, making it reason. What's the reason for it having two meanings? I have no clue, but there must be a reason.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What's your reason to wake (わけ) up this morning? Think about it. Now think of your reason to wake up tomorrow. What is it?

Name: Reward
Mnemonic: A kindness prize is one that someone gives you out of kindness. Perhaps you've done something nice, which is why they are giving you a reward.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sakura
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Satellite
Mnemonic: A defense star isn't really a star, but it is something shiny in the sky that can look like a star if it's bright enough. This is a satellite, and while it's not always defensive, satellites can have defensive properties. Think ion cannons and deflector shields and things like that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You know them both already, so you should be able to read this word!

Name: Scary
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of fear? Scary or frightening. It can also mean I'm afraid or I'm scared  too.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know what's really scary? Koalas (こわ). Have you ever heard one of those things? They're super scary, don't go near them.

Name: Secret
Mnemonic: Secret and secrecy. Combine the two and you have quite the secret.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Secret
Mnemonic: Something that has secrecy is secret and private.
ReadingMnemonic: Think about that really secret and private dude. He so (ひそ) secret...

Name: Secret Information
Mnemonic: In secrecy you must announce this information. It's not for anyone to hear, it's secret information.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The みつ goes to みっ.

Name: Secret Meeting
Mnemonic: A secrecy meet is a secret meeting. You know the password?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note that みつ changes to みっ.

Name: Self Defense
Mnemonic: Self defense is when you protect yourself. It's self defense.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sequence
Mnemonic: The order of things is the preface to the entire sequence and steps we're planning on taking. So, just remember. The order is just the preface. It is what allows us to come up with a sequence.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Showing Off
Mnemonic: If you decorate your spirit with a bunch of pretty things like streamers and balloons, people will think you're just showing off. Yes, you know your spirit is awesome, but everyone else doesn't want it pushed in their face with your over the top decorations.
ReadingMnemonic: Since the first part of this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned how to read the かざ part already with the 飾る vocabulary. The second kanji uses the on'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading for 気 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: At the height of showing off, you bend one arm to your hip and the other out in the air. You pretend to be a kettle (け). You show off your spirit to all your friends singing "I'm a little ke-ttle, short and stout. Here is my handle, here is my spout. EVERYONE LOOK HOW GREAT I AM!" Your kettle dance is sure to impress them.

Name: Smell
Mnemonic: This the noun version of the kanji for smell. It also means smell, or scent!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

Name: Smuggling
Mnemonic: A secrecy transport is when you transport something in secrecy. If you don't want people to know what you're transporting, you'll have to resort to smuggling.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Socialist Party
Mnemonic: The society (社会) party is the socialist party.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sour
Mnemonic: The taste of something with acid is... well... you'd think it'd be acidic, but it's a sour taste. Some acidic things are pretty sour, though. Lemons are pretty acidic, and they're super sour too, so think about that when you need to remember this word.
ReadingMnemonic: Something was so sour that it broke your mouth. You were so upset about this, that you decided to sue (す) the maker of this nasty sour thing.

Name: Stain
Mnemonic: A dirty point is a little point of dirtiness on something. This is a stain or smudge.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Stature
Mnemonic: Someone's back height is their height. It also refers to their stature.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the vocab readings of 背 and 丈, combined together.

Name: Strict
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of strict? It is also strict.
ReadingMnemonic: The most strict creature in Japan is the key bee (きび). Little key bees have to be very strict about locking the doors to their hive. If they aren't strict enough, the scary Japanese hornets will get in and kill them all. Have you seen those things? They're terrifying!

Name: Strictly Forbidden
Mnemonic: Something with strict prohibition is strictly forbidden / strictly prohibited.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tall
Mnemonic: This is the words 背 and 高い put together to make one adjective. When your height is tall it means you are a tall person. This word is only used for tall people though, not anything else that's tall like a building or a tree.
ReadingMnemonic: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). You've learned both of these readings before now, so you should be able to read this word already!

Name: Teriyaki
Mnemonic: You illuminate some food, then bake it. To illuminate it, you put on some shiny sauce. Sound familiar, in terms of a type of food? This is teriyaki, though I have to warn you it's quite different from the teriyaki you get in the west.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 照る and 焼く. Put them together and you have something delicious.

Name: To Be Chilled
Mnemonic: If 冷やす is "to chill something," then this would be the version where something is just chilled. You're not doing the action of chilling anything, it's just that way. You know this because if you get involved, there's always some kind of chilling error (える). So, you step back and let the fridge do its job without messing.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 冷やす. Know that and you know this as well.

Name: To Be Happy
Mnemonic: 浮く means "to float," and 浮かれる draws on that metaphor of "floating" to mean to be happy, to be in high spirits, or to be elated. We have the same metaphor in English — think of being "on cloud nine."
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 浮く, so if you know that you' are going to be happy and you won't have a care (かれる) in the world!

Name: To Conceal
Mnemonic: If you secret something, you are trying to keep secret something. That, or you're trying to conceal it.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, strangely enough. Nothing to conceal about this reading, you gots it.

Name: To Dye
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dye so the verb vocab version is to dye.
ReadingMnemonic: You need to dye something that you just sewed (そ) together. It's all sewed and looks like a shirt, but it's colorless. That's where the dying comes in.

Name: To Feel Hot
Mnemonic: If fire illuminates your face, you're going to feel hot. Sometimes you start to flush when you're embarrassed and it just feels like there is fire making your face light up.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 火 yet, but it's easier to remember this with a mnemonic for the whole thing: When are you going to feel hot? When is your face going to flush? When I ask you to go to a hotel (ほてる) with me!

Name: To Gather
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gather so the verb vocab version is to gather.
ReadingMnemonic: When you gather things, you go around and take things from their original location to put them together in your gathering spot. In Japanese, when you take something, you could say 取る, right? This word has the same reading: とる.

Name: To Get Dirty
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dirty so the verb vocab version is to get dirty. You know you're not doing the dirtying, because it's rare (れる) for you to get anything dirty, though things do get dirty on their own.
ReadingMnemonic: Things seem to get dirty easily around here, which is why you go (よご) to great lengths to keep things clean. Note that the reading よごれる is generally used for getting physically dirty, whereas けがれる is more figurative, so more like “to be defiled”.

Name: To Get Wet
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wet, so the verb version is to get wet.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

Name: To Go Beyond
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means go beyond so the verb vocab version is also to go beyond.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 越える. So if you know that you know this too! In case you need a reminder, here's the mnemonic: To go beyond child (こ) years in order to become an adult, you have to be 18 years old in the USA, and 20 years old in Japan.

Name: To Keep A Pet
Mnemonic: The kanji is domesticate. When you domesticate an animal, you get to keep a pet of some kind. You'd use this to describe when you are keeping a dog or cat or something.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. The か of cat!

Name: To Let Something Leak
Mnemonic: You learned 漏れる means "to leak." 漏らす is the transitive version, which means it takes a direct object. So this means to let something leak or to leak something. The reason you let something leak is because you rushed (らす) the job (because you did it yourself)!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 漏れる, so if you know that, you know this! Don't let that memory leak from your head.

Name: To Look After
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deposit, and this word is for when someone is depositing something (or someone) with you, because they want you to look after, to take care of, or to hold on to it.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this before with the pair verb 預ける, but here's a mnemonic to remind you just in case: You need someone to look after your kids for the day. Hey, I have an idea! Leave them with the monkeys at a zoo (あず)! Monkeys love kids, and kids love monkeys. Now you can zoom off in your cars (か) for the day!

Name: To Marry
Mnemonic: 結婚 is marriage, so the verb version of that would be to marry or to get married.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 結婚 first, though.

Name: To Pick Someone Up
Mnemonic: The kanji means welcome, but the verb version is to pick someone up or to meet someone. That's weird. But, think of it this way: When you go to welcome someone, you are going to meet someone too. You have to go somewhere to wait and welcome them, which is why you are going to pick someone up or going to meet them. Something like that anyways.
ReadingMnemonic: To pick someone up you are going to drive your moo car. It's a car that's designed to look like a cow, but you think it will be a nice way to welcome your friend.

Name: To Prolong
Mnemonic: If 延長 is prolonging, then the verb version is to prolong.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Publish
Mnemonic: If 出版 is publishing, then the verb vocab version is to publish.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 出版, so if you know that you know this. Also, it's just the kanji readings too, so no problemo for a person like you, I'm sure.

Name: To Subscribe
Mnemonic: If 購読 is a "subscription", then the verb vocab version would be to subscribe.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Suit
Mnemonic: It resembles you! It suits you! Wow, your good looks really cause this scarf to suit you, you know?
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is from 似る and 合う, put together.

Name: To Throw Away
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means throw away so the verb version is to throw away.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, so no need to throw away that bit of knowledge just yet!

Name: To Translate
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means translate so the verb version would be to translate.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for the kanji part is surprisingly the やく you learned with it, even you wouldn't expect that. I suppose that's the kind of thing you have to look forward to if you were to go into translating.

Name: Translated Term
Mnemonic: A translated bit of language is a translated term.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Translator
Mnemonic: Someone who translates things is a translator.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Use
Mnemonic: I gather things and use them. The things I've gathered, are the things I use.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Voting
Mnemonic: When people gather and decide things, they decide together, usually by voting.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Wanted
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of want? It's also wanted.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want? A hoe (ほ), like a garden hoe, you sicko.

Name: Wants
Mnemonic: What you want and request are your wants, your desires, perhaps your craving. You want these things so you request them. I wants them!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. よく goes to よっ, so be careful not to want the wrong reading.

Name: Warm
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of warm? It's warm as well! Though this is for a warm weather or temperature, not some warm food or something like that, that would be 温かい, a different あたたかい. Confusing, right?
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 温かい, which also means warm. But while that 温かい refers to a warm thing, this 暖かい refers to a warm temperature or place. Just like with 温かい, people often pronounce this as あったかい in conversation. But when it comes to kanji exams or typing out the kanji, remember to use あたたかい!

Name: Warm
Mnemonic: Warm warm is warm.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: White Flag
Mnemonic: A white flag is a white flag. It's one for surrender. I give up! Too many kanji!
ReadingMnemonic: You'll have to be careful about this one, as it's actually read with the two kanji's kun'yomi readings put together, making this しろはた.

Name: Will
Mnemonic: If you have an idea of what you want already, then that's good! You have will, desire, and ambition. Those who don't know what they want can't have any of these.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Will
Mnemonic: You have an idea and you have intent to carry it out. This is your will and volition.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Wound
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: "How did you end up with that wound?" "I went to the key zoo (きず) and all the keys had escape their enclosure and were running wild. They can really inflict a lot of damage if you're not careful".

Name: Abnormal
Mnemonic: When something differs from normal it's called abnormal or strange.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Abnormality
Mnemonic: It differs from the normal condition of things, making it weird. It is an abnormality. There is something wrong.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Advice
Mnemonic: A loyalty announcement is the kind of announcement you give to someone who you're loyal to. To this type of person, your announcement would come in the form of advice or maybe admonishment, if you're upset with what they've done.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Alley
Mnemonic: A backside street (or "avenue") is a street that's not a main street... it's hidden and behind everything, making it an alley.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 裏 and 通り put together into one word.

Name: Annual
Mnemonic: The year that is next is coming up. What will you do in the year that is next that you did this year too? What do you do that is annual?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Arms
Mnemonic: The most important part of your military attire are your arms (not the ones attached to your body, your guns and stuff). Arms are what make you a real military person.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ash
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Ashtray
Mnemonic: An ash plate is a plate you use for ashes. That's an ashtray.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the two vocab words, 灰 and 皿, put together. Just keep in mind that 皿 gets rendaku'd to ざら.

Name: A Slump
Mnemonic: If something does not shake, it’s probably in a slump. If nothing’s shaking, things must be sluggish.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Attire
Mnemonic: This looks like it's an adjective, but it's just a tricky word. It's a noun, and it means the same thing as the kanji, making it attire.
ReadingMnemonic: "Yo, so, oh, you gonna wear that attire today or what?"

Name: Attire
Mnemonic: Your clothes which attire you is your attire. It's how you dress.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Author
Mnemonic: Someone who is an author is an author.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Back Door
Mnemonic: The backside mouth (think: entrance) is the back door or rear entrance.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 裏 and 口 put together into one word.

Name: Backside
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji as well.

Name: Betrayal
Mnemonic: From the backside you cut someone. Wow. What a jerk. What betrayal and treachery.
ReadingMnemonic: This word is 裏 and 切る's readings, put together.

Name: Calisthenics
Mnemonic: Take your body and manipulate it around for exercise. This is Calisthenics or gymnastics.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chastity
Mnemonic: This takes the second meaning of the kanji you learned, chastity.
ReadingMnemonic: Who is doing the chastity thing? That missa, oh (みさお), yes she is.

Name: Compound Word
Mnemonic: Ripened languages are words that have taken some time to come into their form. They ripened up, starting with just one kanji, but then became two, or three, or more. That is a compound word or compound kanji. You know that "jukugo" thing I talk about so much? That's this!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Crotch
Mnemonic: The groin interval is simply the groin or crotch.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Crown Prince
Mnemonic: The emperor's fat child is the crown prince, not because he's fat, but because he's the emperor's child.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Denial
Mnemonic: No! I will not determine that. In fact, I deny it. This is my denial.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Different Gender
Mnemonic: Someone who differs in gender from you is of a different gender. This is often used to mean the opposite sex in the sense of men as viewed by women and vice versa.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Different Meaning
Mnemonic: My idea of righteousness is different from yours. Really, it's just a different meaning.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Disguise
Mnemonic: Change your attire to look like someone else. This is a disguise.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Editor
Mnemonic: An edit is 編集. Someone who does those edits is an editor!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the readings from 編集 should help you.

Name: Emperor Of Japan
Mnemonic: The Japanese emperor is supposed to have come from the heavens, so that just makes this heaven emperor the emperor of Japan.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just have to remember that 皇 is read as のう here. You just found out you can never be the Emperor of Japan because you aren't Japanese. NOOOOOOOOOOOOO~ (のう).

Name: Enlargement
Mnemonic: Go ahead and extend it and stretch it. That's how we'll do this enlargement, expansion and extension.
