ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Of course, just to be dirty, the people who made up this word decided to use a kanji that read as かく. Dirty old monks that could see the future and speak English, ugh.

Name: Equipment
Mnemonic: This attire is put inside this equipment, where it's changed into something else. This attire device is strange and interesting. Imagine something that it does to your attire.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Except
Mnemonic: 除く is "to exclude." This is the te-form, and it means "except." So, something like "please get everything except broccoli," because who wants broccoli?
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 除く. It's just the te-form of it.

Name: Faithful
Mnemonic: I have loyalty to you, so I always tell you the truth. I am very faithful and devoted to you!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Flatulence
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: You already learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go!

Name: Freeloader
Mnemonic: To stay alive in some climates, some have no choice but to be a freeloader. That is, a lodger who pays nothing. If you live somewhere with an inhospitable climate but you can't afford to pay rent, your only option is to live with someone for free.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a slightly unusual case because both kanji use the kun'yomi. You haven't learned that reading for 候 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What? You've become a freeloader? I can't believe you've gone so low (そうろう)!

Name: Freighter
Mnemonic: A freight things ship is a boat that freights things. It's a freighter.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The 物 takes its もつ reading, which makes sense since it sounds like 持つ, which is "to hold." What is this freighter doing? It's holding freight! So, that's how you can remember that bit.

Name: Fructose
Mnemonic: A fruit sugar is the type of sugar that's more commonly known as fructose. Mmm, delicious fructose.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Garden
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Which garden is the Garden of Eden? その garden! That garden right next to you is the Garden of Eden! It can also use the on'yomi, though, which you've already learned. When it takes the on'yomi and is used as a standalone word, it usually refers to some kind of institution, like a 幼稚園.

Name: Gentlemen
Mnemonic: My various buddies! Wait, that didn't come out right. Gentlemen! My friends! There we go, much better.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Gorgeous
Mnemonic: 華やか is "showy." Now we're doubling it, making it doubly showy. If you make something showy enough, it becomes gorgeous, but it also becomes pretty flamboyant. So, so, so flamboyant.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 華やか. Note the second はな becomes ばな, to be はなばなしい.

Name: Graveyard
Mnemonic: A grave location is a place where there are graves. It is a graveyard.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi for both kanji, which is fairly unusual, but then graveyards are unusual and special places. You've learned both of these readings before, so you should be able to read this on your own, but here's a reminder just in case: This graveyard is only for hackers (はか) who say "baa" (ば). In other words, dead hacker sheep. Many were anti-establishment types who leaked classified info to the public, then died in mysterious circumstances. Today, hackers the world over visit this graveyard and baa before the graves to pay their respects. Rest in fleece, comrades! Baa!

Name: Gray
Mnemonic: Ash color tends to be a kind of gray color, wouldn't you say? That makes this word gray (or grey, depending on where you're from).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hip Joint
Mnemonic: Did you know that your crotch is connected via various joints? That makes this word your hip joints or, more generally, just your hip.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Honorific
Mnemonic: Respect language is what you speak to someone you respect and want to elevate. You can do this using this type of Japanese, which is known as honorific language.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: House Rent
Mnemonic: Your house rent is your house rent, though it can be your apartment rent too.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 家 is an exceptional one. It is や, because when your landlord asks if you paid your rent, you always say yah (や), whether you did or not.

Name: Illogical Argument
Mnemonic: You already know 理屈 means "logic" or "argument." So what's flatulence logic? It's an illogical argument, a far-fetched argument, or sometimes a lame excuse. It's all just hot air!
ReadingMnemonic: You've already learned all these readings. You should be able to read this on your own. And no, that's not a far-fetched argument, or a lame excuse for not writing a mnemonic.

Name: Imitation
Mnemonic: You're taking reality and trying to resemble it. To do this, you have to do an imitation, mimicry, or an impersonation.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 真 and an irregular reading for 似. You've already learned the reading for 真, but here's a mnemonic to help you with 似: What are you doing an imitation of? A horse! You gallop around neighing (ね) at the top of your lungs! That's a pretty good imitation.

Name: Imperial Family
Mnemonic: The emperor's tribe is his family. This family is known as the imperial family.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Imperial Family
Mnemonic: The emperor's room is where the Imperial Family gathers.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Jizo
Mnemonic: The ground storehouse refers to a person's name. It may be easier to learn this one reading first because of that. Anyways, this person is Jizo(u), a Bodhisattva, and protector of children.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Leaflet
Mnemonic: What do people usually scatter in a rush (らし)? Leaflets and flyers. Handing them out takes way too much time, so if you just scatter them all over the place your job will be done so much faster!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the 散る, so you should be able to read it already! Note that this word is almost always written in kana, and チラシ is much more common than ちらし.

Name: Lung
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. OH HAI THERE LUNG. OH HAI THERE YOU.

Name: Lung Cancer
Mnemonic: 肺 is lung, がん is "cancer," I suppose because you want it gone (がん) from you. That makes this word lung cancer, which, with all the smoking in Japan, happens a decent amount.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Lung Disease
Mnemonic: A lung sickness is bad for those lungs of yours. It means you have lung disease.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Magazine
Mnemonic: Random magazine is pretty much all magazines. Just a bunch of random stuff inside, making it a magazine.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mild-Mannered
Mnemonic: When a warm temper is applied extra thick, it leads to a person having a mild-mannered or gentle personality.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You already know the on'yomi for 温, but not for 厚, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: The most mild-mannered Tofugu staff has to be onion こういち. It's an onion that jumps in for こういち whenever he's not at the office. He's the most gentle soul you could imagine, never yelling at anyone. The ideal boss, really.

Name: Mountain Stream
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word share the meaning of swamp, but this word is primarily used to mean mountain stream. Think of it this way, the water for a swamp has to come from somewhere right? It starts out up in the mountains and drains out into a swamp in the valley. The life cycle of a mountain stream into a swamp!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: The beginning of the word swamp is actually pretty similar to this word's reading. さわ = "swa"? I'd say it's close enough to make a mnemonic out of in your head.

Name: Muscle
Mnemonic: Your muscle meat is your muscle.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Natural
Mnemonic: Something of heaven's nature is indeed natural, with no human intervention involved.
ReadingMnemonic: You know the reading for 天, but 然 uses a different reading from what you learned. So here's a mnemonic to help you: One thing that definitely isn't natural are nendoroids (ねん). Remember, the little plastic figurines? Have you ever seen an anime figurine growing naturally in a field before? Yup, me neither. Not very natural.

Name: No
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Instead of saying "no" you say "na," and instead of saying "na" you say いな. Note that 否 can also be read いや, which is a common way to say “no” in modern Japanese, but that reading is almost always written in kana.

Name: Operation
Mnemonic: If you manipulate the things you make, you are in operation of said things.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Payment
Mnemonic: When you enter your supply into the machine, that is your payment for the day. Every day you have to enter your supply, otherwise they crack down on you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Proclamation
Mnemonic: You proclaim things by saying them. This is a proclamation or declaration.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Propaganda
Mnemonic: All the things the leader proclaims are transmitted to the people. It's all propaganda, which is why you transmit it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Quagmire
Mnemonic: A muddy bog is a way of describing a quagmire. It’s a bog with almost no water left, having become all muddy and sticky. Gross (and dangerous)!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the vocab readings of the two words, 泥 and 沼.

Name: Refrigerator
Mnemonic: A cool storehouse storage is a place you put things (like food) to keep them cool. This is a refrigerator.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rejection
Mnemonic: "No" is the decision I've made. Sorry, but this is rejection.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Remarkable
Mnemonic: The kanji means author, but if you think about it, what do authors do? They write about remarkable or marked things, whether it's fiction or nonfiction.
ReadingMnemonic: Something is so remarkable you let out one jeer (いちじる) at the opposing team. Just one, because you're not that mean.

Name: Rental
Mnemonic: Rent it and I will lend it to you. This thing that is being lent and rented? It's a rental.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just have to remember that 貸 is read as たい for this one. What is your rental? It is a tie (たい) fighter. Sweet.

Name: Respect
Mnemonic: You are revered and you have my respect. This is respect.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Revered
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of revered? It's also revered!
ReadingMnemonic: You are revered because of your Toe toe (とうと), which is a toe on your toe. It's weird, but people seem to like it.

Name: Ripen
Mnemonic: To become ripe(n) is to ripen and mature.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Robber
Mnemonic: I don't know why a mud pole is a robber, but for some reason it is. Just imagine a robber covering himself in mud and standing behind a pole to hide, then jump out, then rob you of everything you've got.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 泥 plus the reading for 棒 put together.

Name: Rumor
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

Name: Simple
Mnemonic: Simplicity is simple, making this simple as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Simple
Mnemonic: It has simplicity and is easy. Whatever it is, it is simple and easy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Steam
Mnemonic: Steam energy is steam or vapor.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Storage
Mnemonic: When you obtain supply, you have to put it all together somewhere. You have to put it in storage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Storehouse
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the other storehouse reading you learned earlier with 倉 and 庫. They're all basically the same thing, and lucky for you they share the same reading too (くら).

Name: Sugar
Mnemonic: A sand sugar is just sugar.  Nom nom nom, sugar.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sugar Free
Mnemonic: Something with not sugar is something that is sugar free or unsweetened.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Taro
Mnemonic: A hometown potato is a taro. In Japan, taro is the kind of potato that everyone has in their hometown, because it's been around for such a long time and it'll grow anywhere.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji.

Name: Tendon
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, at least on the tendon side of things.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You get a horrible tendon injury, making it so you can't walk anymore. You're so upset that you blame it on Jesus. So, you go and sue Jesus for this tendon injury, and win in court, amazingly.

Name: Ticket Window
Mnemonic: A window mouth is where you go to buy tickets out of the window. You know how there's those windows with holes in them, or the window is the hole itself? That's the kind of ticket window I'm talking about.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the readings for 窓 and the reading for 口.

Name: To Backstab
Mnemonic: If you cut someone from the backside you're doing a backstabbing, making this word to backstab or to betray.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 裏 plus 切る put together into one word.

Name: To Clean
Mnemonic: 掃除 is cleaning, so the verb version would be to clean.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, it'll help to know the word 掃除 as well.

Name: To Dangle Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dangle so the verb vocab version is to dangle or to dangle something. You're doing the dangling.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What are you trying to dangle? You're dangling a taco (た) in front of a hungry person. He just wants the taco, and you keep dangling it like that.

Name: To Differ
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means differ so the verb vocab version is to differ.
ReadingMnemonic: Look at your coat (こと), now look at mine. They are different. If you look at them, they are going to differ.

Name: To Dry Something
Mnemonic: 乾く is "to be dried." This is the version where you're doing the drying, making this to dry something. You know this because it's annoying to have to dry something yourself, so you cuss (かす) endlessly as you do it. "#$@%! Why do I have to waste my time drying this %$# thing?!"
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 乾く.

Name: To Edit
Mnemonic: 編集 is edit, so the verb version is to edit.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Extend
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means extend so the verb vocab version is to extend.
ReadingMnemonic: This word shares the same reading as 広い. That means 拡がる is read as ひろがる.

Name: To Get Hot And Sticky
Mnemonic: Anywhere with lots of steam is going to get hot and sticky, so this word means... to get hot and sticky!
ReadingMnemonic: What is making things get hot and sticky? Not many people know this, but it’s actually all of the cows going moo (む). With how much they moo, they create so much steam that everything is turning hot and sticky. Who could’ve known?!

Name: To Go For A Walk
Mnemonic: 散歩 is "a walk." Make that into a verb and you have to go for a walk or to go for a stroll.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 散歩 as well.

Name: To Heap Up
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means heaps, so the verb vocab version is to heap up. It can also mean to serve food, as in you're heaping on food onto someone's plate.
ReadingMnemonic: Please keep heaping up the food. I want more (もる), more, more.

Name: To Live
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means livelihood. The verb version is to live. It's not really "to live" literally, though. It's more like to live one's life, rather than just to live.
ReadingMnemonic: If anyone is going to live one's life, it's gotta be the great Kublai Khan (く). He conquered most of the world and was super badass.

Name: To Manipulate
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means manipulate, so the verb vocab version is to manipulate.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: A guy using eye arts (あやつ) isn't a great guy, it's the type of guy who might try to manipulate you via hypnosis of the eyes.

Name: To Obstruct
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means obstruct, so what is the verb vocab version? It's to obstruct.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You try to obstruct a woman coming your way (see kanji). As she gets close, she roars, "I am Sama(n)tha!" (さまた) You shall let me pass!" You don't argue with Samanthas. Get out of her way!

Name: To Ripen
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ripen so the verb vocab version is to ripen.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If something starts to ripen too much, it gets all gross, and you're all like, "ew (う), that's gross."

Name: To Scatter
Mnemonic: 散る is "to be scattered." 散らかす on the other hand is when you're doing the scattering. So it means to scatter or to make a mess.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading of the 散 comes from 散る. So, go ahead and scatter more memories around your brain, you got this already.

Name: To Separate
Mnemonic: Remember how 離れる is "to separate," where something is just separating and you're not doing the separating? Well, this one has the same meaning, but now you're doing the separating. This word is 離す, and you know that you're doing the separating because if you don't, that person will sue (す) you for grabbing onto them and not letting go.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 離れる.

Name: To Supply
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means supply so the verb version is to supply.
ReadingMnemonic: So you're supplying something... let's say nuclear warheads... to Osama Bin Laden. You gonna be in soooo much trouble, especially since it's zombie Osama Bin Laden.

Name: To Surprise
Mnemonic: Remember how 驚く is "to be surprised"? This is when you are surprising someone else, doing the surprising, making this word to surprise or to shock.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 驚く. Don't be surprised if you remember the reading of this word because of your past knowledge.

Name: To Wipe
Mnemonic: You have the kanji for wipe, and this is the verb version of that, which makes this to wipe or to mop up.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a verb, so it uses the kun'yomi. However, to differentiate this verb from 拭く, it uses a different reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this: What are you trying to wipe? Some nude goo (ぬぐ)! You spilled nude goo all over your floor, and now you have to mop it all up… pesky nude goo.

Name: Unrefined
Mnemonic: A field of livelihood is so lively! Look at everything jumping around. It is so fresh and new and awesome! That being said, being so lively and fresh and new, it's pretty unrefined and rustic.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Unripe
Mnemonic: Something that has not yet ripened, is, well, unripe. This is often used figuratively to say that someone is either immature or inexperienced, so you'll often encounter those usages!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Vacuum Cleaner
Mnemonic: A cleaning (掃除) machine is a vacuum cleaner. Suck that dirt up!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Various
Mnemonic: This has the same meaning as the kanji. Stick this onto another word and you have "various _____."
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji as well.

Name: Vertical
Mnemonic: Something is dangling in front of you, so you fix it so it's straight and not moving. It becomes perfectly vertical, perpendicular to the floor.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Wheat Flour
Mnemonic: Small wheat powder is wheat flour, or flour.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of all three kanji. The 小 and the 粉 both use kun'yomi that you haven't learned yet, but luckily they are both the same! Just think about how "small" things are like 子 (こ), and "powder" is also small. So both 小 and 粉 are read こ.

Name: Window
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.

Name: Writing
Mnemonic: An author makes writing in an activity known as authorship.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Zoom
Mnemonic: Extend the lens nice and big to zoom in on the subject, please. That's magnification, enlargement, and expansion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: All Wool
Mnemonic: Something that is pure fur is pure fur... but what kind of fur? In this case it's wool, making this mean all wool.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Along The Train Line
Mnemonic: To run alongside the line (referring to the train line) means along the train line. What's along the train line? All kinds of things if you look carefully.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Approval
Mnemonic: I recognize your consent. It is an approval and recognition of what I'm doing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Autumn Leaves
Mnemonic: You've got some deep red leaves. You'll usually see those during autumn, which makes this autumn leaves. Just red leaves is fine too, though.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. As you haven't learned this reading for 葉 yet, here's a mnemonic to help you: Your favorite pastime during autumn is sitting there admiring the autumn leaves while eating some yogurt (よう). There's no better combination than autumn leaves and yogurt. Note that there's also an additional reading, もみじ, used to refer to the Japanese maple tree, or its leaves, but we'd like you to focus on こうよう for this one.

Name: Azuki Beans
Mnemonic: Small beans refer to a type of bean known as azuki beans. It will help if you've heard of this delicious popular bean, because there's not really anything effective we can do with the meaning mnemonic from this point on. Just know that small beans are azuki beans.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading doesn't make sense either. If you know that small beans are azuki beans, then you know that this is referring to a thing known as azuki (あずき). Other than that, there's not much else to do.

Name: Bakufu
Mnemonic: A government behind a curtain is the bakufu. They didn't let anyone know their government secrets so they would hide behind that curtain and keep everything to themselves.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 幕 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you try to peek through the bakufu's curtain you'll only see someone's back (ばく). They all huddle together to discuss things so a row of hunched backs is all you'll get out of the shogunate. That's not helpful.

Name: Beans
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: You want your beans, but you're also super lazy, so you call for your mom, yelling: "MAMEYYYYY, MAMMMEEYYY!" (まめ).

Name: Beef Bowl
Mnemonic: A cow rice bowl is a bowl of rice covered in beef, making it a beef bowl. Go get some Yoshinoya.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the same readings that you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bible
Mnemonic: The holy writing is the Bible.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Black Tea
Mnemonic: A deep red tea isn't a deep red tea... it's a black tea. If you think about it, a lot of black tea is really deep red, which is why a deep red tea is a black tea instead.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Blood Type
Mnemonic: Your blood fluid type is your blood type. This is a very important thing to know in Japan for some reason.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, at least the 血液 part. The 型 uses the kun'yomi reading, probably because it's an add-on word.

Name: Branch
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this is a word made up of a single kanji and nothing else, you can assume that this word will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading you learned for this kanji happens to be the kun'yomi reading as well. So if you know the kanji you know the reading.

Name: Claw
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though it adds a few more meanings as well, like nail or talon or hoof or really any hard thing on the ends of fingers or feet.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Coast
Mnemonic: The run alongside coast basically just describes the coast.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Coastal Waters
Mnemonic: The run alongside sea is the sea that runs alongside the land, making it the coastal waters aka the coast.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Command
Mnemonic: Take your finger and brandish it to command the troops.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the on'yomi readings, so if you know those you may take command of this vocab word.

Name: Commute
Mnemonic: The things you pass through on your way to work are the things you see and run into during your commute.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Consent
Mnemonic: You consent and know everything that's going on. You consent and know about all this. You're aware of it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn 知's on'yomi when you learned the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need someone's consent before you give them cheese (ち). Cheese has the power to enrapture a person and leave them in a state of total ecstasy, so you better make sure they consent and know what's about to happen before you feed them any cheese.

Name: Corrosion
Mnemonic: When something rots and eats away at something, that is corrosion. Not a good thing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cough
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: Crotch
Mnemonic: The kanji means crotch and the vocabulary also means crotch or groin.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned the on'yomi for this kanji, but like many kanji it takes the kun'yomi when used by itself. You haven't learned the kun'yomi yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You've spilled something on your crotch again, but your pants are so stained at this point that it doesn't even matter (また).

Name: Crowd Of People
Mnemonic: When a person goes into a place (then another person goes into the place, and then another person and another person), that place eventually gets filled with a crowd of people.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the word 人 and the kanji 込. Just keep in mind that the こ changes to ご and you'll be fine.

Name: Curtain
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck.

Name: Damage
Mnemonic: Your loss comes from damage done to you. This is damage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Decomposition
Mnemonic: Rot and failure lead to decomposition and rotting. This word also has the related meaning of  corruption, similar to how "rotten" can mean "corrupt" in English.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Disadvantage
Mnemonic: A loss will give you a disadvantage. So, try not to get any losses... or you'll be at a disadvantage.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the kanji, so you aren't at a disadvantage... this time.

Name: Disposable
Mnemonic: After you use it you throw away it, making whatever it is you used a disposable item.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 使う and 捨てる, combined into one.

Name: Diving In
Mnemonic: You’re doing a 飛ぶ and 込む at the same time, or you jump into, meaning you're diving in. Picture yourself standing somewhere up high, and then jumping to dive into a deep body of water.
ReadingMnemonic: As long as you remember that we're combining the kun'yomi readings of the verbs and then turning them into a noun, you should know how to read this.

Name: Dude
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Some dude... he did it two times. Yah, two (やつ) times. This can seem kind of derogatory, if you say it the wrong way. But as long as you're duding to your dude friends and not your no-dude boss, you should be a-okay to dude-bro it up!

Name: Epicenter
Mnemonic: The earthquake origin ground is where the earthquake started from. It is the epicenter.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Estimation
Mnemonic: You’re doing a bit of inferring while you determine something, which means you’re not 100% sure, making this an estimation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Excuse
Mnemonic: You say a reason for your actions, but really it's just an excuse.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 言う and 訳 combined.

Name: Full Time Employment
Mnemonic: Normal work is work you do all day long, 8-hours a day, 5 days a week. That is full time employment or full time.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Genji
Mnemonic: The origin family name is the original dude. The original dude comes from the original and first novel ever written, the Tale of Genji. These kanji represent Genji, good ol' Genji. Perhaps hopping over to the reading will help you to know the meaning of this kanji.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Glasses
Mnemonic: An eyeball mirror is something that refracts and focuses light into your eyeball in a different way so you can see better. Really, these things are glasses, not eye mirrors, but same sort of things when you get down to it. Just imagine someone wearing mirrors on their eyes, and when you ask them what those are for, they just say they're glasses.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 眼 is the same as the vocab 眼. The reading for 鏡 is an exception, totally different. It shares a reading with 金 (gold), though, so think of the mirrors on the person's eyes being made of gold. What nice glasses! This word can also be read as がんきょう, but usually only on official/written documents. If you're speaking and not reading a government document, you should say めがね!

Name: Grandparents
Mnemonic: You know that 祖父 is grandfather and 祖母 is grandmother. This is both combined. Is it some hybrid grandmapa monster you've created in your lab? Hardly, it just refers to your grandparents.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 祖父 and 祖母, which are exceptional readings on their own, so you'll need them in order to be able to read this one too.

Name: Hand Towel
Mnemonic: You have the kanji for hand and the noun version of the verb for wipe. With a bit of imagination, that makes this a hand towel, or just a towel. They're a very specific kind of cloth towel, which is why you'll also often encounter them with their Japanese name tenugui.
ReadingMnemonic: You have a standalone vocab (手) combined with the noun version of a verb (拭い from 拭う), which means that this uses kun'yomi readings. You've already learned these, so you should be good to go!

Name: Heart
Mnemonic: The heart internal organs is the heart, of course.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Heavy Loss
Mnemonic: A big loss is a heavy loss.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the おお reading of 大 coupled with the on'yomi reading for 損. Just keep in mind that the そん changes to ぞん and you'll be good here.

Name: Hereafter
Mnemonic: Everything that happened since you descended some stairs, is hereafter. It's all after the stairs thing you did, since you did it already.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Holiness
Mnemonic: God is holy. Everything about a holy god is full of holiness.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Holy Land
Mnemonic: Holy ground is holy land.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Impersonation
Mnemonic: 真似 is "impersonation." Actually, this word is too. It's also impersonation.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 物 plus 真似 put together.

Name: Impure
Mnemonic: Not pure things are impure.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Internal Organ
Mnemonic: Inside internal organs are your internal organs, though you'd think the second kanji would give a hint to that without the 内.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lean
Mnemonic: A thin body type is called lean or slim. These days this is usually used in the context of slimming salons and massages you can get that may or may not work.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

Name: Length And Width
Mnemonic: Vertical and side (horizontal). That means you have the length and width and the vertical and horizontal.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that usually uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note however, that there is a less-common on'yomi reading,  じゅうおう, which is used in some idioms. It's good to know this reading exists, but you probably won't come across it very often.

Name: Long Time No See
Mnemonic: This is kind of a "set phrase" in Japanese, though we're going to treat it like a vocab word here (because it's so common and useful!). You know that 久 means "long time" - so now let's pay attention to the kana: しぶり. Just imagine that she buried you alive, then a few days later came back to dig you up. The first thing she says is "LONG TIME NO SEE!"
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned 久しい. It's the same one!

Name: Lung
Mnemonic: The lung internal organ is the lung.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Magnet
Mnemonic: A magnet stone is a magnet. Magnets look like little stones, right?
ReadingMnemonic: The 磁 reading makes sense. The しゃく reading for 石 is an exception. To remember this, just think how you are using a magnet to find this shack (しゃく) full of other magnets. It pulls you towards the shack, and when you find it and open it, all the magnets fly out and crush you because of magnety reasons.

Name: Magnetic Field
Mnemonic: A magnet location is an area with a magnetic field.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading for 場 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Do magnetic fields say "baa" (ば)? No, but some studies suggest that sheep like to align themselves to Earth's magnetic field lines when they're standing around. Just a bit of weird baa-rnyard trivia for you!

Name: Magnetism
Mnemonic: Magnetic energy is when magnetism occurs.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Meeting
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji welcome, so it means a welcome or a greeting, but it's usually used for someone who's coming and meeting you!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: Miscalculation
Mnemonic: A mistake in what you calculate is a miscalculation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Misunderstanding
Mnemonic: A mistake in what you solve... wow, sorry, I thought I was supposed to solve this, not that. What a terrible misunderstanding.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Misuse
Mnemonic: A mistake in use is a misuse.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Nail Clipper
Mnemonic: When you cut your claw you use a nail clipper.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned for the kanji 爪 and the word for the reading 切る.

Name: Natto
Mnemonic: A supply of beans is when you take a bunch of beans, mash them up into a supply, and then ferment them all together to make them into natto (also known as fermented soybeans).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is an exceptional one. 豆 is okay, and is the on'yomi reading from the kanji. The 納 part is weird though. Instead of being のう it's なっ. But, if you can remember the meaning of this word, you can just think about how you do not (なっとう) want to eat natto. At least a lot of people don't want to eat it. It's quite the acquired taste.

Name: No Interest
Mnemonic: 興味 is interest in something. If you do not have (がない) that interest, then you have no interest or you're not interested.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned that the word 興味 uses the on'yomi readings for both kanji, so all you have to do is add が + ない and you've got a new expression!

Name: Older Brother
Mnemonic: The older brother is valuable to you. But, no matter how valuable he is to you, he's still just your older brother.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 兄 on its own plus the reading for 貴. ANIKIIIII.

Name: Origin
Mnemonic: The origin is the origin, but it also refers to the ground springs, where the origin of water comes from.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Think of how this ground spring is everyone's (皆) origin (元). Everyone can use it, it's the 皆元!

Name: Pet Owner
Mnemonic: You know that to 飼う is "to keep a pet." If you're the master that is keeping a pet (飼う), then you are the pet owner.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings for both. You'll need to remember the words 飼う and 主 to be able to remember the reading of this word.

Name: Pleasure Quarter
Mnemonic: The delight and comfort street. Sounds nice. Sounds like the "pleasure quarter." You'll see these most often in samurai films, or in sketchier areas.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Plural
Mnemonic: If 複数 is multiple, and 形 is shape, then when something is in a "multiple shape," it has more than one version of itself. It's the plural, or the plural form.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 複数 as well.

Name: Power Source
Mnemonic: The electricity origin is where the electricity comes from. It is the power source.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Precious
Mnemonic: Something that's valuable and heavy is extremely precious and probably even more valuable than your less heavy things.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 重 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Keep things precious to you very close, because the evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will come and steal it away if you don't. She'll take every valuable you have and destroy them.

Name: Pure
Mnemonic: You're pure and that's stylish, which makes you even more pure, somehow. But your purity also makes you genuine, unlike all the people who aren't pure trying to be stylish.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Radiation
Mnemonic: It releases and shoots out of the bomb. It's not fire. It's radiation, and it sticks around a long time once it has been released.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Reasoning
Mnemonic: To infer reason is to have reasoning.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Recommendation
Mnemonic: To infer and recommend something is to give a recommendation. What do you recommend?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Reduction
Mnemonic: Shrink what you have into something small. It was big, now it's small. This is a reduction.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Reflection
Mnemonic: You shoot yourself at a mirror, and it is the anti-you. It is your reflection.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rice Bowl
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned the どん reading for this kanji, and this reading is just an extension of that, coming out to どんぶり. This change might be a little tricky to remember, so here's a mnemonic to help you out: Rice bowls keep disappearing, and everyone's terrified. Who's behind it? Don Brie (どんぶり), the feared cheese-loving mafia boss. He wants those rice bowls to eat all his brie out of, because I guess plates aren't good enough. That's why they call him Don Brie.

Name: Self-Recommendation
Mnemonic: As for myself? I recommend this product. It is a self-recommendation. You make it of yourself!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Serious
Mnemonic: A deep carve is very serious and grave. Just imagine getting cut with a sword. If the carve is deep, well, that's serious.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Shot
Mnemonic: When you shoot something into someone that you actually have to pour (aka a liquid), you're shooting them up with a needle, giving them a shot / injection.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Simple
Mnemonic: Simple and pure. This is simple.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Slave
Mnemonic: Some dude who is a slave is just a slave.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Stain
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of 染. A dye would seem like the right answer, but what else is a dye? If you get it on you when you don't want to get it on you, it becomes a stain.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is unlike what you learned with this kanji before. Just think about how you have this stain on your shirt, all because you were trying to dye some sheep (し) and they didn't like it. So now you have a big dye and sheep poo stain. How were you supposed to know sheep don't like being dyed?!

Name: Stylish
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are stylish. Since you're stylish, you avoid icky (いき) clothing at all costs. You won't even be seen in the same room, that's how stylish you are.

Name: Subtitles
Mnemonic: A curtain of letters that goes on your screen are subtitles. Sometimes they have black bar backgrounds too, which are like curtains!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Surrender
Mnemonic: I am going to descend my participation in this conflict. I am going to descend all my weapons to the ground. I am going to surrender.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: The Nobility
Mnemonic: People of a valuable tribe are part of the nobility. Unlike our tribes, they are valuable.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Timetable
Mnemonic: If you take the time and carve it onto a surface, then you've made a timetable or schedule.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Agree
Mnemonic: The 賛成 portion means "agreement", "approval", or "support", so the verb version would also be to agree, to approve, or to support!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Apply
Mnemonic: I must say humbly that I want to get into this position, so I'm planning to apply for it and to submit an application.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from the word 申す and the kanji 込, stuck together... humbly.

Name: To Be Damaged
Mnemonic: The kanji means wound, and this verb is intransitive, so it means to be damaged or to go bad. After all, fruit with a wound on it is going bad, isn't it?
ReadingMnemonic: This shares the same reading as 痛む. The meanings are similar too, so that should be easy to remember, unless your brain was damaged by these mnemonics or something.

Name: To Be Dyed
Mnemonic: If 染める is "to dye," then this is to be dyed. You aren't doing the dying, because you know that if you did it you would have done things right, unlike the other person who dyed your hair. This person marred (まる) it up really bad.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 染める.

Name: To Be Employed At
Mnemonic: The kanji is work which means this verb has something to do with working. It's not straight up "to work," instead it's "to work for" or "to be employed at."
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the other word that means "to work as" (務める). Remember this and you'll be able to remember the reading for this word too.

Name: To Carve
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carve so the verb version is to carve.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You don't have a knife for your steak, so you have to carve it using the key zag (きざ) technique. You take a key and zag it through the steak repeatedly until you're able to cut up some zaggy bite-sized pieces.

Name: To Exhibit
Mnemonic: Departure and brandish this thing. This means you're sending something out to show to everyone. That's why this is to exhibit or to demonstrate (because when you brandish, and send it out to show, you're demonstrating it!).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The はつ becomes はっ, though.

Name: To Get Thin
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means thin so the verb version is to get thin.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to get thin, just join the Yankees (や). They run their players around those four bases so much they all get thin quicker than you can throw a ball.

Name: To Harm
Mnemonic: To do loss to something means you are doing something to make something have loss. This is to harm or to injure.
ReadingMnemonic: In order to harm your opponent, you go way overboard. You soak (そこ) them in acid. Soaked head to toe. Too far man, too far.

Name: To Have A Look At
Mnemonic: You worship only the things you see. So, in order to see if something is worth worshiping, you'll go to have a look at that thing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Humbly Hear
Mnemonic: Giving consent to someone is similar to humbly listening to and accepting their words. So this word means to humbly hear and to accept.
ReadingMnemonic: You received (受けた) some information. Now, you are going to take that information that you received and then revolve it (回る) around in your head to think about it. Hmmm... hmm... Ok, I like what I'm hearing. I am going to accept what you said. Thank you.

Name: To Hurt Someone
Mnemonic: You つける (attach) a wound to someone or something. In other words, this means to hurt someone, or to scratch or to damage something.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 傷. If you remember the reading for that you got this too.

Name: To Launch
Mnemonic: Departure and shoot something off. If you do that to something, you are going to launch it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Make Dirty
Mnemonic: 汚れる is "to get dirty." This is when you make something dirty, aka "to make dirty." You know that this is the version where you make things dirty yourself because when you make someone dirty with all that poop you're flinging, they sue (す) you immediately. This happens a lot.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 汚れる, so if you know that you can read this. Note that the reading よごす  is generally used for making things physically dirty, whereas けがす means making someone or something impure in a figurative way.

Name: To Move
Mnemonic: 越す is "to go beyond." Now you're going beyond your home and pulling everything with you to go to another home. You are trying to move / to move homes.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 引く and 越す put together. Careful of that っ.

Name: To Overtake
Mnemonic: 越す means "to go beyond." 追 is follow. If you are following someone, and then you go beyond them, you have overtaken them. That's why this word means to overtake or to surpass.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 追う and 越す put together into one. You can overtake this word now that you know that.

Name: To Puke
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means throw up so the verb version is to throw up or to puke or to spit.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is from the reading you learned with the kanji. HA HA HA! Barf.

Name: To Put In
Mnemonic: You know the kanji 込 means into. This verb is transitive, meaning you are doing the action. If you “do something into something” you are putting it into that thing. So this means to put in or to load something.
ReadingMnemonic: Lucky for you, the reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here. In case you need a hand with the okurigana, here’s a mnemonic for you: You always try to put in your emotions into the mail (める) you send. You don't just load your mail with words, but also with emotions, to make it truly heartfelt mail.

Name: To Recommend
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means recommend so the verb vocab version is to recommend. This word is often used in a positive context for recommending things, actions, and people by implying or pointing out their charms, merits, or both.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as 勧める, since they mean almost the same thing.

Name: To Rot
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rot so the verb vocab version is to rot.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember the word 臭い, which means "stinky"? When something rots, it becomes stinky, and all くさい.

Name: To Run Alongside
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means run alongside so the verb vocab version is to run alongside.
ReadingMnemonic: Imagine yourself on a path designed to run alongside an endless array of soap (そ) bars. As you walk alongside the soap bars, you enjoy their delightful scents. It's a "scent-sational" promenade with soap bars that leaves you feeling squeaky clean!

Name: To Shrink
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shrink so the verb vocab version means to shrink.
ReadingMnemonic: Jesus couldn't cause the monster to shrink. He had to transform into cheese jesus (ちぢ), a more powerful version of himself, in order to shrink the monster down to size.

Name: To Stuff
Mnemonic: You know that 詰める is "to stuff in" and the kanji 込 is into. When you’re stuffing something into something else, you are going to stuff or to cram it in.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. If you remember your kanji readings, you'll be fine here.

Name: Total Loss
Mnemonic: An all loss is when you lose it all. It is a total loss.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Throw Away
Mnemonic: You throw and throw away something. That's why this means to throw away.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 投げる and 捨てる, combined into one garbage inducing dump of a word.

Name: To Worship
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means worship so the verb vocab version is to worship.
ReadingMnemonic: You have to worship the ogre (おが), because if you don't it'll eat your face off.

Name: To Write In
Mnemonic: You know that 書く is "to write" and the kanji 込 is into, so this means to write in, to fill out, or to jot down.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the word 書く and the kanji 込 combined into one.

Name: Typo
Mnemonic: A mistake in letters is a typo.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Valuable
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of valuable? It's valuable.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What is most valuable to you? Of course it's your toe toe (とうと). It's your big toe (the long とう) with another small toe growing out of it (short と). Imagine your toe toe, and then imagine how valuable it is to you. So valuable! You can also think about 尊い, a similar word which means "revered." It's a similar idea, and it has the same reading.

Name: Vertical
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

Name: Vertical Writing
Mnemonic: Vertical writing is vertical writing. That's when you see Japanese and it's written top to bottom instead of sideways.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the reading you learned with the kanji 縦 and かき (changes to がき), though the き gets smushed inside the kanji, because it wants to be confusing like that.

Name: Welcome
Mnemonic: It's my delight to welcome you, so I give you a big, warm welcome.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Wirepuller
Mnemonic: Just imagine a black curtain off in the background. You don't know what's behind it, but you know what's in front of it. Thing is, the thing in front of the curtain is controlled by whoever is behind the black curtain. This person is the wirepuller or mastermind of the situation. Like the Wizard of Oz, or something.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the vocab readings for 黒 and 幕, though the vocab reading for 幕 is the same as the on'yomi reading, making things easy for you.

Name: You
Mnemonic: A valuable formal name ender. It's like saying something like "the valuable great you"... or something. Anyways, this means you, but it isn't as nice as it sounds. Probably a lot of irony and sarcasm going into this word, because if you use きさま to say "you" to someone, you're probably not pleased with that person, or you're just trying to be rude.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the reading you learned with 貴 plus the vocab reading for 様.

Name: Alternately
Mnemonic: You mix, then you go mutual, then you mix, and then you go mutual. Alternately, you could go mix again?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Amateur
Mnemonic: You've got a very elemental person. They're so elementary that they're quite an amateur, really. Maybe a little too elemental.
ReadingMnemonic: Unfortunately, the reading for this is a complete exception, so you'll just have to memorize it. Here's a mnemonic to help you: "You're an amateur!", she wrote (しろうと). A little harsh, isn't it? But that's what she wrote. Gotta do a little better to impress her, pal.

Name: Bankruptcy
Mnemonic: If someone tears all your property it'll lead to bankruptcy. With all your property torn, you're going to go bankrupt. What mean person did that?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Barracks
Mnemonic: A soldier cottage is a place where the soldiers stay. This is the barracks.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bear
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Being Convinced
Mnemonic: I will supply and you will acquire. Does that sound good? Do I have your consent? I can see that you're understanding and being convinced. You're planning on accepting my proposition, aren't you?
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a bit weird for 納. Just imagine asking the consent question from the meaning, then have the other person say "Nahh! (なっ), no consent!"

Name: Be Late
Mnemonic: A slow carve is so slow. If you carve something slowly, it will take you a long time. You will be late with a slow carve like that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Braided Hair
Mnemonic: 編む is "to knit." When you knit in threes, you are knitting in a braid style. What do you braid? Hair. That makes this braided hair.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the み from 三つ and つ and 編む combined into one (or should I say three?) braids. Just watch out because this isn't みっつあみ, it's just みつあみ. Listen to the audio a few times to make sure you remember how it's spelled and pronounced!

Name: Bronze
Mnemonic: Blue copper is bronze. Bronze gets a bluish tint to it, which is why it's a blue copper.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cedar
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. This will be particularly useful for names, as there's a lot of names with 杉.

Name: Conjecture
Mnemonic: When you infer and measure, it’ll lead to some sort of conjecture, speculation, or guess about something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cooking Pot
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as you learned with the kanji.

Name: Copper Mine
Mnemonic: In a copper mountain you go in and make a copper mine.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. The 山 reading is ざん instead of さん because of rendaku.

Name: Copper Statue
Mnemonic: A copper statue is a copper statue.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Copyright
Mnemonic: 著作 is "writing" or "authorship." The rights that writing has is what's known as copyright.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 著作 first, too.

Name: Countryside
Mnemonic: A rice paddy and a cottage. This is the image of the countryside to me. This is rural. Just cottages and rice paddies...
ReadingMnemonic: The reading doesn't really make sense for the kanji, and is an exception for sure. Just think about how when you're in the countryside you're in 中 (いなか) of nowhere.

Name: Crude Oil
Mnemonic: The original oil is oil in its original state. That is crude oil.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dead Drunk
Mnemonic: If you're mud drunk, you're so drunk you're rolling around on the ground. You are dead drunk.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't seen the on'yomi reading for 泥 yet (でい), so here's a mnemonic to help you out: You'll probably get dead drunk if you start drinking in the middle of the day (でい). Just try to wait until the day is over, like maybe after work, you know?

Name: Deed
Mnemonic: You go for the sake of others. You are constantly doing deeds like this for others.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Delay
Mnemonic: I am too slow so things have really begun to stagnate. What a delay.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Delay
Mnemonic: I was too slow, so we'll have to prolong the time in which this product will come out. This is a delay :(
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Desert
Mnemonic: A sand desert is just a desert.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Destruction
Mnemonic: Tear and break everything, taking it all down. Destruction! Demolition!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Embarrassing
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of shame? It could be ashamed or even  embarrassing.
ReadingMnemonic: When you're ashamed it's even worse when someone laughs at you: ha (は) ha ha!"

Name: Escape From Prison
Mnemonic: You're making your escape from prison . So this means... escape from prison. Or jailbreak if you're feeling a little fancy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Flame
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same!
ReadingMnemonic: Ho nooooo (ほのお), there are flames everywhere!

Name: For
Mnemonic: You move towards the sake. When you move towards it, you are doing something for the sake of. But why use fancy language like that? Let's just leave it as for.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: For the sake of public safety, you will need to tame (ため) the wild beasts loose in our city. Now go, tame them!

Name: Fruit Juice
Mnemonic: Fruit soup isn't really a soup, it's more of a fruit juice.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fueling
Mnemonic: You take your salary and buy oil. When you are doing this, you are fueling something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Government Office Building
Mnemonic: A government office cottage is the place where the government office is stored. That's the government office building.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Happiness And Longevity
Mnemonic: Luck for your whole lifespan, that's a life of happiness and longevity.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hell
Mnemonic: The earth prison is a prison down inside the earth. What prison is under the earth? That would be hell.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Homonym
Mnemonic: You have the same sound with a different meaning (異義), and it's a part of language. Same sounds... different meanings... that sounds like a homophone, or a homonym.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. All I know is there's probably not a homonym for this word, for it is huge.

Name: Honorific Japanese
Mnemonic: 尊敬 is respect. A respect language is honorific Japanese (or honorific language, though usually this refers to Japanese).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 尊敬 plus 語 put together.

Name: Hot And Humid
Mnemonic: If it’s a steaming hot day, it means the weather is hot and humid (or you can just say humid, because that usually implies hotness too). This is a useful word for summers in Japan, since you'll complain about this all the time.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 蒸れる and 暑い. Know those and you know this too.

Name: House Counter
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Imprisonment
Mnemonic: When you enter prison that's imprisonment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Inattentiveness
Mnemonic: If you let someone cut off your oil supply, it's probably because of your inattentiveness. You let your guard down.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Inflammation
Mnemonic: When you have flame symptoms that's when you feel like you're filled with fire, which is  inflammation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: In Prison
Mnemonic: If you're inside prison you're in prison.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Inseam
Mnemonic: Your crotch and what's below it is called your inseam. It's that line that goes down the inside of your pants. Depending on your variety of English, you might call this your inside leg instead!
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun’yomi reading of both kanji. You learned また from the word 股, and you learned した from the word 下 a lonnnng time ago. If you didn't remember either of these, hang your head in shame and look at your またした!

Name: Intervention
Mnemonic: I jammed in myself and entered your personal life. Because I care, you know? I don't want you to be addicted to My Little Pony anymore, so this is an intervention.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Introduction
Mnemonic: My introduce was jammed in there for you to hear. That is my introduction. Jammin' it in.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Kendo
Mnemonic: The path of the sword is known as kendo. You could also say Japanese fencing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Kumamoto Prefecture
Mnemonic: Bear origin prefecture is Kumamoto Prefecture. Probably best to learn this meaning via the reading. Also, you should look up Kumamon of Kumamoto-ken.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 熊's reading, the alternate "origin" 本 reading, and the reading for 県.

Name: Lake
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is crazy long, but also crazy easy! You know みず means "water," and うみ means "sea." So, you have a "water sea" which is a lake, which is a みずうみ.

Name: Lake Yamanaka
Mnemonic: The mountain middle lake is lake Yamanaka, a famous and very nice lake in Japan. It's also a lake that will help you to learn the lake kanji reading better.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of 山 and 中, then the on'yomi reading of 湖.

Name: Lecture
Mnemonic: Perform your lecture. This is your lecture. This is your address to the people.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lecture
Mnemonic: Lecture of righteousness is still a lecture.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lecturer
Mnemonic: A lecture expert is a lecturer or instructor.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Life
Mnemonic: If 暮らす is "to live" or "to live one's life" then the noun version would be simply life.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 暮らす.

Name: Lifespan
Mnemonic: Your lifespan is your fate and will show you how long your lifespan is.
ReadingMnemonic: You did learn the reading of 寿, but the reading for 命 is an exception. When you think of a lifespan, think of how that affects everyone. Me, you... well, just those things. Combine them both into myou (みょう). That is who the lifespan affects. Myou!

Name: Long Life
Mnemonic: A long lifespan is a long life.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Miso
Mnemonic: A flavor that makes foods boisterous is a great flavor. In this case, it's the flavor of miso, which goes in a lot of Japanese dishes, and certainly does make the flavor of things boisterous.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mutual
