Mnemonic: Mutual and mutual is mutual.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mutual
Mnemonic: Despite it looking like an adjective, this is the noun version of the kanji, making it mutual. It also means each other and reciprocal and together, too.
ReadingMnemonic: Let's help each other. Maybe if we work together we can get rid of this tagger (たが) tagging graffiti all over our neighborhood.

Name: Negative Form
Mnemonic: 否定 is denial. Remember how 形 sometimes refers to grammar tense / type? Well, with a denial type grammar, you have a negative form, making it a negative sentence.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Observation
Mnemonic: View and measure what you are watching. This is observation. It is no mere viewing, it is more than that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Oil
Mnemonic: Oil that has stones in it is from the ground. It's not olive oil, it's petroleum!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Oil
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: You need to apply oil to a bra (あぶら) because it's stuck on you. You can't get it unhooked, so you have to slide it off. Problem is, it's too tight, which is why a bra needs oil to slide off.

Name: Oil Field
Mnemonic: An oil rice paddy is really more like an oil field.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 田 yet. Just think about how you walk into the oil field and you see a bear den (でん), filled with oil.

Name: Oneself
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It also means myself and I.
ReadingMnemonic: As for myself? I'm not Bob. oh no, Ray (おのれ), Ray is my name.

Name: Polar Bear
Mnemonic: A white bear is a polar bear! They're the only white bears in the whole world!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this too!

Name: Prediction
Mnemonic: A beforehand measure is when you make a prediction or estimation about something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Prime Minister's Office
Mnemonic: The prime minister's (総理) government is where he does all his governmenting. It's where the Japanese Prime Minister's Office (aka the Cabinet Office) is located as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 総理 beforehand as well.

Name: Rainy Weather
Mnemonic: You see the kanji for rain being followed by the 天 kanji from 天気 (weather). This word means rainy weather.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, so you use on'yomi readings. You should be familiar with the on'yomi reading for 天 already, but not for 雨. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember: The rainy weather won't stop you to go catch some uni (う). You would get wet anyway diving into the ocean to collect uni, the rainy weather doesn't affect you. You can also sell them for ten (てん) bucks a piece! The rainy weather isn't at all a problem for a uni hunting if you're making ten dollars for each, you know?

Name: Relatives
Mnemonic: What exactly are your parent relatives? Your own relatives! You're all kin, after all.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Release From Prison
Mnemonic: If you exit from prison you are getting your release from prison. But, before you move on, let me tell you one thing: Hope is a dangerous thing. Hope can drive a man insane.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rising
Mnemonic: Wake up from your bed and get up. You are rising or getting out of bed.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned these readings yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Just remember that rising and getting out of bed early is the key (き) to the Shogun's (しょう) heart. He doesn't like lazybones, so make sure to get out of bed at a reasonable time.

Name: Sculpture
Mnemonic: You carve then you carve again. So much carving until, wait, wow, it looks like something! All that carving became a sculpture!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sea Turtle
Mnemonic: A sea turtle is a sea turtle. Cowabunga!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of these kanji, put together. I suppose it's because it's like two separate words put together into one. That makes this word read as うみがめ, where the かめ gets rendaku'd.

Name: Self
Mnemonic: Your self oneself, is your oneself or self.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Selfie
Mnemonic: A self photograph is exactly that: a selfie.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi of 自, which you learned with the kanji, and the kun'yomi of 撮, which you learned with the word 撮る. Though it's a bit of an unusual combo, you can probably guess the first one since it's such a common reading, and the second one because of the り on the end. Just watch out for rendaku, which turns とり into どり.

Name: Serious
Mnemonic: The reality of the sword is that it will cut you right in half and kill you, easily. The fact that this is true is a very serious thing. Very serious.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Seventy Seventh Birthday
Mnemonic: You can rejoice because your lifespan has reached this special point. That special point is your seventy seventh birthday. So many sevens, lucky!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the on'yomi reading. You've seen the on'yomi reading of 喜 before, though it may be hard to remember at this point. Maybe you can think about how when you reach this seventy seventh birthday, all you want is a key (き) to the city so you can do whatever you want.

Name: Shame
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is also the reading you learned. How nice! But if you don't remember it, what a shame. What an embarrassment this must be for you.

Name: Shipwreck
Mnemonic: A tear in your ship will cause it to wreck, making it a shipwreck.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Shoyu
Mnemonic: Soy sauce oil is soy sauce, or as it's called in Japanese, shoyu.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Significance
Mnemonic: If you have an idea, it means you are important. You have significance. Those without ideas are just big jokes and can't do anything at all.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Single Mindedly
Mnemonic: You have one muscle, therefore it only does one thing. That's it. It is single mindedly doing that one thing. It is intently and earnestly doing that one thing.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a bit weird. It's the kun'yomi readings, where 一 is ひと and 筋 is すじ. Look back on the vocab words that use these readings to remember this one.

Name: Soup
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are given some soup. You take a bite and your mouth is cut clean off. That is because you're eating sheer (しる) soup.

Name: Sushi
Mnemonic: The lifespan of a director depends on how much sushi they eat.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It might also help to know the kanji in 寿司 are 当て字 (remember those?). They have nothing to do with sushi, so they're just being used here for their sound.

Name: Sword
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word covers all types of swords and sabres, though it was originally used mostly for double-edged swords.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading! This word can also be read つるぎ, but in that case its meaning is limited to Western-style swords only. Because of the meaning difference, we only accept the けん reading (but you'll get another try if you enter つるぎ).

Name: Tears
Mnemonic: Your teardrops are also known as your tears.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a mnemonic in case you need a refresher: Your teardrops are like little waves. What are they? They're 波だ (なみだ).

Name: To Be Drunk
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drunk so the verb vocab version is to be drunk.
ReadingMnemonic: I'm not drunk, yo (よ). YO. I'm not drunk, yo. YO. Yo, I'm not drunk. Yo.

Name: To Be In High Spirits
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means courage so the verb version is what happens when you have lots of it. Someone with courage is probably the kind of person who is able to be in high spirits in the face of something!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who is the one person who always seems to be in high spirits? Isabel (いさ)! She's so positive and eager, even in the face of a challenge.

Name: To Be Late
Mnemonic: If something or someone is slow, and they "do slow" they are going to be late.
ReadingMnemonic: What is slow and probably going to be late all the time? A big oak (おく). Oaks have trouble moving, and are slow, and therefore are always late, too.

Name: To Be Overdue
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stagnate, and the verb vocab version is to be overdue. After all, if something stagnates, it's not advancing, which causes it to be delayed.
ReadingMnemonic: Your work tends to be overdue, so you get a lot of to-do calls (とどこおる) from your boss, reminding you to do your work. These calls are pretty annoying, but at least your work is less delayed.

Name: To Calculate
Mnemonic: When you calculate and determine (the calculation), you are determining the calculation. That's why this word is to calculate.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Chat
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means chat or talk so the verb version is to chat or to talk.
ReadingMnemonic: This vocabulary word uses the same reading you learned with the kanji, plus the hiragana attached at the end.

Name: To Dangle
Mnemonic: If 垂らす is "to dangle something" then 垂れる is to dangle or to drip on its own. So you can use 垂れる to describe your dog's floppy ears hanging down or your ice cream’s melty goodness dripping away. You know this because it's rare (れる) to witness the moment something starts dangling or dripping down.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 垂らす.

Name: To Deny
Mnemonic: If 否定 is "denial," then the verb version would be to deny.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 否定 as well.

Name: To Feign
Mnemonic: If you go to attire yourself, you're covering up who you are and trying to be someone else. You are trying to feign. You are trying to wear a lie. You are trying to pretend.
ReadingMnemonic: While you go to feign that you're someone or something else, someone calls you out on it: "you so (よそお) much a liar!"

Name: To Get Dark
Mnemonic: You've been so busy with your livelihood, you didn't even notice it's started to get dark outside. When you're doing lots of living, days and seasons just seem to end rather quickly like that.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 暮らす, so if you can remember that, you should be able to remember this one too!

Name: To Get Hurt
Mnemonic: Remember how 傷 is "wound"? Now a wound is つくing to you, or in other words, is getting attached to you. If you get a wound attached to your body, you are probably going to get hurt.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the word 傷.

Name: To Heap Up
Mnemonic: 盛る is "to heap up." If you "raise" (上げる) what you heap up, well, that comes with heaping something up, making this word to heap up or to pile up. This word is also used when you want to liven up some things. Heap up that energy and stir things up!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 盛る and 上げる. Know those words and you'll be able to read this one too.

Name: To Measure
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means measure so the verb vocab means to measure. This word generally has to do with scientific or medical measurements.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember another word that means "to measure?" It is 量る, and has the same reading as this word. That should make things easier to remember.

Name: To Proclaim
Mnemonic: If 宣言 is a "proclamation," then the verb version will be to proclaim.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Rehash
Mnemonic: You steam something to return it to its previously warm state. This is when you go to reheat something. But we usually use it to talk about bringing something up again and again in conversations or arguments. That's why it means to rehash or to bring up again. You're bringing up memories from the past and steaming them up again.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 蒸れる and 返す. Combine this knowledge to reheat your memories.

Name: To Respect
Mnemonic: If 尊敬 is "respect" then the verb version would be to respect.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Settle Into
Mnemonic: If 納める is "to supply" or "to deliver," then this word is when things have been delivered: so it's to settle into or to be satisfied.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 納める.

Name: To Take Something Into Account
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You learned this kanji means "model," but it can also mean "take into account," so the verb version means to take something into account or to be in light of.
ReadingMnemonic: This verb uses the kun'yomi of the kanji. You haven't learned that yet, so here's mnemonic to help you: If you want to take something into account, you'll need to 考える (かんが) about it really hard first. And when you do that thinking, it has to be in light of lots of other factors. Taking all those factors into account will help guide your next move, you know?

Name: To Tear
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tear so the verb version is to tear.
ReadingMnemonic: You start to tear the cloth. You don't know if you're supposed to or not. The crowd isn't sure either. You hear kind of a yah boo (やぶ) reaction going on, making you unsure if you should continue or stop. Yah! Boo. Yah! Boo!

Name: Traitor
Mnemonic: Someone who backstabs (裏切り) someone is a traitor.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 裏切り and an exception reading for 者. Just think about how you'd think of a traitor as a "thing" (物) and not a person.

Name: Troublesome
Mnemonic: The misfortune is just getting jammed in there. So much misfortune leads to very troublesome trouble.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The やく gets changed to やっ.

Name: Turtle
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. BURN BURN BURN.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Vague
Mnemonic: Something with a vague nature is also quite vague.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Various
Mnemonic: You have various various things. They are various. You have all kinds of them.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a bit weird. Just think about how when you have various things, you probably have a lot of things. What do you want? You want more (もろ) of those things. More more more!

Name: Vinegar
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji!

Name: Vinegared Food
Mnemonic: A vinegar thing is a thing that has been vinegared. This is a vinegared food or a pickled food.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the readings for 酢 and the kun'yomi reading for 物 which you've seen quite a bit by now.

Name: Abolition
Mnemonic: It is obsolete so we must stop it. No more of it anymore. This is abolition.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Acceptance
Mnemonic: I will accept and I have agreement in the matter. I have come to acceptance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Alliance
Mnemonic: We are of the same alliance. We are in an alliance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Aunt
Mnemonic: An aunt feels like a mother sometimes, but she's still an aunt after all.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for the 母 part is just the first は in はは, rendaku'd. You can also think of your aunt as a sheep, too, if you'd like. Baaaah!

Name: Bad Example
Mnemonic: A bad example is a bad example and is something you don't want.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Blood Donation
Mnemonic: I would like to offer my blood to someone else in the form of a blood donation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bond
Mnemonic: A debt ticket is a bond. You buy it from the government and then they pay it back to you with interest... in theory.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chicken And Egg Rice Bowl
Mnemonic: This very common food is parent and child rice bowl, aka a parent and child rice bowl. The parent is a chicken. The child is an egg. This can also be called chicken and egg rice bowl, or simply oyako-don.
ReadingMnemonic: This is 親子 (おやこ) plus 丼, and all three kanji use their kun'yomi readings. The full name is おやこどんぶり, but people usually say おやこどん for short. You learned the full どんぶり reading with the vocab word 丼, but here's a refresher: When you want to make a chicken and egg rice bowl, you have to ask Don Brie (どんぶり) for the rice bowl. He's the mafia boss who hoards all the rice bowls to eat his cheese out of — remember him? Don't get on Don Brie's bad side, or no oyako-don for you!

Name: Class Reunion
Mnemonic: A same window meeting is a meeting with people who spent a long time gazing out of the same classroom window as you. Who are those people? They're your former classmates, and this is a class reunion. It can also mean alumni association, which is still something you do with former classmates, so it makes sense.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 窓, so here's mnemonic to help you: If you have a class reunion coming up, you'd better work on your soul (そう). You want to make a good impression on all your old classmates, right? Well get to work on your soul right now, otherwise they might not be impressed.

Name: Commander
Mnemonic: The master commander is the commander of all commanders, the commander in chief if you will... or, even the team captain.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Conductor
Mnemonic: If 指揮 is "command" or "lead" then someone who does those things is a commander, or conductor. Usually the kind that conducts an orchestra!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this is the reading of 指揮 plus the on'yomi reading of 者.

Name: Consent
Mnemonic: You have my consent and agreement. This is my consent, agreement, or acceptance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Consent Or Refusal
Mnemonic: Do we have agreement or no? Which is it? consent or refusal? Yes or no? Choose!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Conversion
Mnemonic: If you change something then exchange it, you are making a conversion or a change.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Corpse
Mnemonic: You leave behind your body to join the spirit realm. This body remainder is your corpse or remains.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Credit
Mnemonic: Your debt rights state that you have a certain amount of credit with your bank. And if they try to say you don't have that credit you can file a claim against them!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dancing
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: People think you're dancing, but you're really jumping from the mice (まい) running on your floor. You don't want the mice running up your legs so you have to hop from one to the other, making it look like you're dancing.

Name: Dancing
Mnemonic: You dance, you step, you dance, you step. Good job! Now you're doing dancing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Deer
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You're staring really closely at this deer, but something looks off. You get closer, slowly, and you realize it's a sheep in a car (しか) shaped like a deer. The sheep car deer suddenly turns toward you rushing forward, legs raised. Ahh, get outta there! (The lesson here is to never get too close to a deer. You never know its true form until it's too late.)

Name: Dentistry
Mnemonic: Tooth science gives you the science of dentistry, simple as that!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 歯 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know who benefits from great dentistry? Sheep (し)! Have you seen one smile? Their wool makes a great, endless source of dental floss. That's their secret. Just think of the sheep and their perfect teeth and you'll never forget this reading!

Name: Dependence
Mnemonic: Being reliant on something in order to exist is dependence or reliance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Diffusion
Mnemonic: When something reaches normal, it has finished diffusion. Normal things aren't all bunched up and concentrated. Normal things are spread out nice and evenly, via diffusion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dirty
Mnemonic: This is the adjective form of 汚, which is dirty. This word is the adjective dirty, but you can also use it to say things like filthy, foul, or unclean.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is different from the other kun'yomi readings you've learned so far with this word. It is きたない. Think of it like you're saying "来た、な", as in "it came, huh?" What came? A really dirty looking monster, and it's coming for you.

Name: Donation
Mnemonic: I'd like to offer money, no strings attached. It's free. It's a donation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Edamame
Mnemonic: A branch bean doesn't mean a whole lot this way, but you probably know the food that this describes anyways. This is edamame, a food made from steamed soybeans, usually with a bit of salt added for flavor.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of the two kanji, unfortunately. That's the vocab words 枝 and 豆 combined into one.

Name: Eel Bowl
Mnemonic: うなぎ means "eel," so うなぎ丼 is an eel rice bowl, aka an eel bowl. And yes, it's very good.
ReadingMnemonic: This is うなぎ plus 丼. The full name is うなぎどんぶり, but people usually call it うなぎどん for short. You learned the full どんぶり reading with the vocab word 丼, but here's a refresher: When you want to eat an eel bowl, you have to ask Don Brie (どんぶり) for the rice bowl. He's the mafia boss who hoards all the rice bowls to eat his cheese out of — remember him? Don't get on Don Brie's bad side, or no eel bowl for you! Note that sometimes people even shorten this to うなどん. But since the ぎ is included here, make sure to type it out when reviewing!

Name: Electromagnetic Field
Mnemonic: A 磁場 is a "magnetic field." An electricity version of this is an electromagnetic field.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings for the first two kanji and the kun'yomi reading of the third. You should be able to read this on your own. Will of course help to know 磁場 as well.

Name: Fang
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Using your animal fang you are able to eat kibble (きば).

Name: Former Surname
Mnemonic: Your former surname is just that: your former surname! This is often your maiden name, as in the name you had before getting married.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Full Name
Mnemonic: Your surname and your name put together create your full name.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Future
Mnemonic: The commander will come in the future. Not anytime soon, but in the future.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: General
Mnemonic: One generally does things... in general. It's more common this way.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that the はん changes to ぱん for 般.

Name: General
Mnemonic: The big commander is the general or admiral (or head or leader). Basically, they're big stuff.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Heredity
Mnemonic: What I leave behind and transmit to you is your heredity. You have my genes, even after I'm gone.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, which you've already learned.

Name: Idiot
Mnemonic: A horse deer is a stupid idea. You're an idiot for thinking about it, really. It's quite dumb.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned both of these readings when you learned the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Inheritance
Mnemonic: If you leave behind property it's known as your inheritance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Injury
Mnemonic: Do you know how suspicious I get if I have an injury? I start suspecting everyone around me of having given me the injury. It was you, wasn't it?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. It also uses the less common reading け, which you learned with 怪, so here's a mnemonic to help you recall this reading: Remember the suspicious soul and its kettle (け)? Yup, turns out this exact kettle is responsible for the injury. Suspicious souls and their kettles...

Name: Ivory
Mnemonic: An elephant tusk is the material known as ivory (or just an elephant tusk).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Jomon
Mnemonic: Rope writing was used during the Jomon period, a time in ancient Japanese history when people decorated pottery with rope.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Kabuki
Mnemonic: A song dance deed is a deed you do that involves singing and dancing. This is the traditional form of stage deeds, known as kabuki. Watch it on YouTube if you want a taste.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Kagoshima Prefecture
Mnemonic: The deer child island prefecture is Kagoshima Prefecture.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are part on'yomi, part kun'yomi, but you should know them all if you look at them one by one. Just remember that 児 is read as ご here. Go, Kagoshima Prefecture! Go!

Name: Kanagawa Prefecture
Mnemonic: The god Nara river Prefecture is Kanagawa Prefecture.
ReadingMnemonic: The か of 神 is used here (losing the み). Then, everything else should be self explanatory.

Name: Large
Mnemonic: Something big in width is large. In fact, it's of a pretty substantial size. This word is used to describe a large magnitude or degree of change, increase, decrease, or difference in a given situation.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: League
Mnemonic: If we take along our alliance and move it forward to something better, we have a league or federation. It's like we're one group now!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lipstick
Mnemonic: A mouth deep red is a deep red you put on your mouth. This is lipstick.
ReadingMnemonic: This uses kun'yomi readings for both of the kanji. You already know this for 口, but you haven't learned either of the kun'yomi readings for 紅 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you memorize the one you'll need for this vocab: Your favorite lipstick is one called Benny  (べに) by... Benny. There's a guy called Benny that makes really pretty lipstick, he's just not great at naming things, so it's all just Benny.

Name: Loss
Mnemonic: The thing we leave behind at a fault is a loss.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Maintenance
Mnemonic: Maintain what we have and put it on hold. We need to keep it up to date and fixed, so we need maintenance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Make The Grade
Mnemonic: I reached the ordinal number prefix that represents a passing score on my test. This means I was able to make the grade! Wow, passing an exam feels great.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Medical Therapy
Mnemonic: Cure and heal me. That is medical therapy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Medical Treatment
Mnemonic: A medicine can heal. This is medical treatment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mistake
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji mistake, so it means a mistake or if it's on a computer, an error.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you make a mistake, you need to admit to it. When someone asks, "Who's responsible for this mistake?" You say, "I am (あやま)."

Name: Nara
Mnemonic: Nara is good and it is Nara (the place, we're talking about).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 奈 is good, the reading for 良 is pretty off in terms of what you've learned. But, if you know that the meaning is Nara, you know the reading is なら as well.

Name: National Debt
Mnemonic: A country's debt is the national debt. It can also be bonds, like the ones you buy from your country.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Nausea
Mnemonic: This throw up energy you feel inside of you… could it be… nausea?!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 吐く and the (irregular) reading of 気 put together.

Name: Nuclear Test
Mnemonic: A nucleus experiment (実験) is a nuclear test.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Nuclear Weapons
Mnemonic: Nucleus arms (兵器), aka weapons, are nuclear weapons.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Nucleus
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word can also mean core because that's where the nucleus is in a cell, and nuclear because we like to blow ourselves up nowadays...
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.

Name: Open Sea
Mnemonic: The open sea is where the sea joins together to be the open sea.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings that you learned when you learned the kanji. Just remember that this time 合 takes the あい reading.

Name: Orderly
Mnemonic: Something with an arranged nature must be very orderly. Nicely arranged, very tidy and orderly!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Permission
Mnemonic: I will permit this, and you have my agreement. Both of these things combine to be my permission and my consent.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pledge
Mnemonic: An alliance promise is one that's made with a pledge or pact. Imagine making an alliance with someone, pledging your support.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pointing Out
Mnemonic: Take your finger and pluck out the one thing out of all the things that needs pointing out or identification. Yep, that's the one. Pluck that one.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Radioactivity
Mnemonic: 放射 is "radiation." Add the ability of radiation and you have radioactivity, for some reason. I guess things don't have radioactivity until you have given them the ability of radiation, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Recommendation
Mnemonic: If 薦める is "to recommend," then the noun version would be a recommendation or some advice. This generally refers to a recommendation of a person or thing, not an action.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 薦める. Might I make the recommendation to learn that word first?

Name: Reliance
Mnemonic: I believe I can trust you. That's why I put so much reliance and trust on you to do well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Request
Mnemonic: I am reliant on you and I trust you. Therefore, I have a request for you that I'd like to entrust you with.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Restoration
Mnemonic: We must maintain the new and get rid of the old. It's time for a restoration of policy! This also refers to the Meiji Restoration too. In fact, it probably mostly refers to this, though you'll learn a more full version of this later.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Restoration
Mnemonic: Restore to the former self. This is restoration.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rope
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Please hand me the rope, right now (なわ), otherwise I will fall to my death!

Name: Salmon
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. But! Some explanation about when to use さけ versus しゃけ. They're both technically right. But, typically when you refer to the living animal, you use さけ, and when you refer to salmon as a food, it's more likely to be しゃけ (but it can go either way). There might be some generational and regional differences, though.

Name: Sand
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you walk around on the beach, you'll get sand in your shoes sooner (すな) or later.

Name: Shogun
Mnemonic: The commander of the army is the shogun. Do you know the shogun? He ran Japan, and was like the ruling general over the states. You can also call him the general or commander, if you like.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sickbed
Mnemonic: A sick bed is a sickbed. If you're in that bed, you're probably sick.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Spring Water
Mnemonic: Well up water is spring water. Kind of makes sense, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Stage
Mnemonic: A dance machine isn't really a machine... a 台 is a large machine thing counter, so in this case it's talking about a stage. A dancing stage is a stage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that 台 is read as たい here, not だい.

Name: Succession
Mnemonic: I will inherit at your consent. It's not just given straight to me at birth, though it kind of is. I get succession, but only if people say it's okay.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Supernatural
Mnemonic: Something that is ultra natural (自然的) is supernatural. Too natural! Super!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sweet
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of sweet? It's sweet.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Sweet Tooth
Mnemonic: The sweet group is a group of people who love sweet things. They really have quite the sweet tooth.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the readings you learned with the kanji.

Name: Tale Of Genji
Mnemonic: Remember 源氏? He has his own 物語. This is the very first novel ever written (that we know about). This is the Tale of Genji.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the combination of 源氏 and 物語 which you have learned before so you should have no problems with this one.

Name: Those Dudes
Mnemonic: If a 奴 is just some dude or some guy, adding a ら on there makes it plural. Now it's those dudes or those guys.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 奴.

Name: To Ask For
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means trust, but the verb vocab version is to ask for or to rely on or to request. When you trust someone you can 頼む them, but only when you trust them. You put it in their hands. You trust them, after all.
ReadingMnemonic: But, you're entrusting this task to your friend not because you are busy, but because you want to go have a 楽しい (fun) time at the waterpark. Sucker!

Name: To Become Obsolete
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means obsolete and this word means to become obsolete.
ReadingMnemonic: Everything has to become obsolete. Even the biggest most fiery things, like a star, for example, will go obsolete at some point.

Name: To Damage Something
Mnemonic: The kanji means wound, and this verb is transitive, so it means to damage something or to injure something.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned 傷む. Yay!

Name: To Dance
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dance and the verb vocab version means to dance, as well as to flutter.
ReadingMnemonic: Who is the greatest dancer of them all? China's previous ruler, Mao (まう).

Name: To Exchange
Mnemonic: The kanji is exchange, so this verb is to exchange. If you exchange one thing for another thing, you are going to exchange it, after all. This word refers to exchanging one thing for something different.
ReadingMnemonic: I don't like this car. I would like to exchange it for another car (か).

Name: To Fry
Mnemonic: This is the verb version of the kanji fry, so it means to fry, more specifically to stir-fry or to sauté.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go!

Name: Tofu
Mnemonic: Bean rot is when you take soy beans, let them ferment, and then you make tofu out of them! Yep, that's what tofu is. Rotten beans.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Grow Longer
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stretch and the verb vocab version is to grow longer or to be stretched. You know that this is the version where you aren't doing the stretching, because you're letting someone stretch you on a torture rack in order to win a beer (びる). You're that desperate.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck!

Name: To Inherit
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means inherit and the verb vocab version is to inherit.
ReadingMnemonic: You not only inherit one fortune, but two! You're lucky both sides of your family "accidentally" died at the same time. TWO (つ) fortunes! TWO! HAHAHAHA. Also, you can think of it like the つ of 次, because you are the "next" successor when you inherit something.

Name: To Not Take Seriously
Mnemonic: When you see something as sweet, you're just looking at it like it's some little sweet kid with sweet flavoring. You are not taking it seriously, or you are taking it lightly. So sweet! That's why this word is to not take seriously or to take lightly.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 甘い and 見る. Don't take this word lightly and you should be able to learn it no problem.

Name: To Pickle Something
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pickle, so the verb version is to pickle something or to marinate something.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You learned this reading with the kanji. Good for you!

Name: To Pluck
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pluck so the verb vocab version is to pluck or to pick or to prune, like with plants.
ReadingMnemonic: You are going outside to pluck two (つ) of your favorite flowers.

Name: To Reach
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means reach and the verb version is to reach or to amount to . This is like "x reached y" or "x amounted to y."
ReadingMnemonic: Oh, yo, if you want to reach that number, you'll have to try harder.

Name: To Spit Out
Mnemonic: If 吐く is to throw up, and if 出す is to remove or hand over, then if you throw up and hand that throw up over to someone via your throwing up, you are going to spit out at them, or to spew out, or something gross along those lines. Then again, this word can be used to be like "spit the info out already!" too, so it's not all spitting for reals.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 吐く and 出す.

Name: To Step On
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means step and the verb vocab version is to step on. So, not quite "to step" like you might expect, but at least you're stepping still, though it's on something.
ReadingMnemonic: You want to step on that bug? You fool (ふ)! That's a killer shoe stabbing bug, it will cut right through your sole and poison you via your foot! Fool!

Name: To Surrender
Mnemonic: 降参 is "surrender" so the verb version would be to surrender.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading is the same as 降参 as well, of course.

Name: To Unmask
Mnemonic: To pluck off someone's mask and departure it off somewhere away from their face, that is to unmask or to expose someone.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Well Up
Mnemonic: The kanji itself means well up, and this is also to well up or to gush out.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're fishing in a hole in the ice when suddenly the water starts to well up and to gush out of it. A huge walrus (わ) splashes out and jumps on you. No wonder there weren't any fish! This is a walrus hole.

Name: Trade
Mnemonic: Trade is easy if you like trade and commerce.
ReadingMnemonic: The 貿 reading is okay, but the 易 reading is different from what you're used to. Just think about how a lot of the trade that comes in will come into the train station (駅). So if you want good trade, you'll want to be at the えき.

Name: Tsunami
Mnemonic: A harbor wave is a wave big enough, it could easily submerge an entire harbor. What could you call such a wave? Perhaps a tsunami, or a tidal wave.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the 津 and 波 kun'yomi readings, combined together.

Name: Ultra
Mnemonic: This has the same meaning as the kanji. Stick this onto another word and you have "ultra _____."
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Ultrasonic Wave
Mnemonic: An ultra sound wave is an ultrasonic wave.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that the は changes to ぱ for 波.

Name: Uncle
Mnemonic: An uncle feels like a father sometimes, but he's still an uncle after all.
ReadingMnemonic: You already know the お reading for 叔, but じ for 父 is new, so here's a mnemonic to help you: One thing nobody knows is that your uncle is none other than Jesus (じ)! That technically makes God your grandfather. Don't tell anybody about this, though.

Name: Valuables
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 貴重 means "valuable?" Well valuable products are your valuables!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ventilation
Mnemonic: Something that will exchange energy is something that pulls in air, takes out the bad stuff, and then outputs good air, exchanging it for the bad. That is ventilation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Width
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Work
Mnemonic: If 勤める is "to be employed at," then the noun version of this is work. I mean, I really hope you're doing work at the place that employed you... if not you'll probably be fired.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 勤める.

Name: X-ray
Mnemonic: レントゲン comes from the German word "Röntgen" meaning X-ray, named after their inventor Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen.

Name: Aim
Mnemonic: Your aim is your aim. What are you aiming for? Despite looking like an adjective, this is a noun, so be careful!
ReadingMnemonic: My aim is near (ねら) to here. Right there, in fact.

Name: Antibody
Mnemonic: Confront your body? Sounds like it's something that's against bodies... perhaps, something that's antibody?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: A Patient
Mnemonic: An afflicted someone is someone who is a patient / medical patient. They are afflicted with some disease which is why they need medical attention.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji and you should be able to read this on your own. Just remember there's rendaku on the second kanji so it turns to じゃ.

Name: Application
Mnemonic: I respond to your recruitment with this application to try and join your group.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Army Camp
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Attachment To
Mnemonic: You tenaciously wear something. You have some kind of attachment to it. You can't let go. It's an obsession, after all, and you just can't stop clinging to it!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Baseball Base
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Baseball Umpire
Mnemonic: A baseball base judge is one who judges things on a baseball field. This is a baseball umpire, or more simply, an umpire.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Base Hit
Mnemonic: A baseball base hit is a base hit or single in baseball terms. A 二塁打 is a double, a 三塁打 is a triple, and a homerun is something you'll learn here on WaniKani at some point if you haven't already.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned the readings for both of these kanji, so you should be able to read this word already!

Name: Battle
Mnemonic: A war fight isn't just any old fight — it's a battle.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bomb
Mnemonic: An explode bullet is when an explode shoots out of something like a bullet, but much bigger, like from a bomb.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bombing
Mnemonic: An explode attack is when someone attacks with exploding things, like bombs. This is a bombing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Brow
Mnemonic: Your eyebrows interval is that place between your eyebrows called the brow. The technical term for this interval between your brows is the glabella, but I bet you never use that word. Unless you're... an eyebrow doctor?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, but it uses the slightly less common けん reading for 間. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember: You stare at the beautiful brow on your Ken (けん) doll, completely mesmerized. You wish your brow looked as perfectly groomed as his... le sigh~

Name: Bullet
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Bullets used to be round, so maybe that's why this vocab shares a たま reading with other words you've learned for round things, like 玉 and 球. Remember those? If not, just imagine a bullet being grabbed out of the air by Tamara (たま), the local ball girl. She heard there was a たま and mistook it for a ball, and now her hand is kinda messed up. Try not to repeat her mistake.

Name: Bullet
Mnemonic: Back in the day, a bullet was a circle shape. So, this word is bullet.
ReadingMnemonic: The 弾 part is okay, but you never learned the on'yomi reading of 丸, which is がん. When you shoot a bullet, you are using a gun (がん). Bang!

Name: Camp
Mnemonic: An army base is managed from the camp. This is where all the bigwigs get together, talk, and manage things, right over the open fire.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chance
Mnemonic: I pledge myself to the machines. It is my only chance to survive the upcoming machine apocalypse.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Collapse
Mnemonic: When something begins to crumble and break, it will certainly collapse at some point. It just can't hold up under the pressure.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Contract
Mnemonic: I pledge and promise to do that thing... so much so, I'm willing to sign a contract about it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cremation
Mnemonic: A fire burial is when you burn the body. You call this cremation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Death Penalty
Mnemonic: A death punishment is the death penalty.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Deletion
Mnemonic: Whittle down and exclude this item from the list. Time to remove it. It's deletion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dispatch
Mnemonic: The sect of dispatch helps with all the dispatch and deployment duties.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Drunk Person
Mnemonic: If you're so drunk that you'll be paying for it later, it's safe to say you're a drunk person. You're way past being tipsy at this point, and you're definitely going to pay for it… with a hangover in the morning.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of 酔う and 払い, put together with some small っ and a rendaku added in because you're drunk.

Name: Elasticity
Mnemonic: If you want the power to stop a bullet you need to have just the right amount of elasticity. Bullets go right through rigid things, but if the material is strong and has the right amount of flexibility, the bullet will bounce right off!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Emergency Patient
Mnemonic: Someone who is so afflicted that you have to hurry and help is an emergency patient.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Evidence
Mnemonic: Evidence traces are little bits of evidence, or proof, left behind. They're the traces that show that something happened.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Exam Hell
Mnemonic: An "examination hell" is the nickname given to the exams you have to take in Japan all at once. That's why this is exam hell.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that smooshes two previous vocabulary words together into a new one. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Explosion
Mnemonic: Explode departure is when an explode departures from a certain point, causing an explosion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Explosive Laughter
Mnemonic: Explode with laughs, what explosive laughter.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 笑 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic. Who has come down with explosive laughter? It's the shogun (しょう)! The shogun just can't stop laughing.

Name: Eyebrows
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. This also includes the place where your eyebrows live: your brow.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're staring lovingly at your own eyebrows in the mirror when your mom walks in and you gasp, "Ma! You... (まゆ)" but you're in so much shock you can't finish the sentence, "Ma, you shaved off your eyebrows?!"

Name: Fighting Spirit
Mnemonic: You have fight in you, and you have the intention to win. You have fighting spirit. Right? Right?! Show me your fighting spirit!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: First Ten Days Of The Month
Meaning: First Ten Days Of The Month
Mnemonic: What are the above ten days of the month? They're the first ten days of the month, of course, or even just the beginning of the month.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fisherman
Mnemonic: A fishing expert is a fisherman.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading is the りょう reading, because you gotta get in your row boat to be a fisherman.

Name: Fishing Boat
Mnemonic: A fishing boat is a fishing boat.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fishing Industry
Mnemonic: The fishing industry is the fishing industry or a fishery.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fundraising
Mnemonic: If you recruit gold you are trying to raise money, aka you are fundraising.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Funeral
Mnemonic: A burial ceremony is a funeral.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Gas Station
Mnemonic: A fueling (給油) place is a place where you get things fueled. This can either be a gas station or a filling station.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Generally
Mnemonic: A big resist is something he generally and usually does... at least in most cases. He's usually a big resistor, that one.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Grilled Skewers
Mnemonic: Skewers you grill (焼く) turn into grilled skewers.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of the kun'yomi readings you already learned. You should be able to read it already!

Name: Gulf
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though it contains some extra similar meanings as well, like a bay or inlet.
ReadingMnemonic: Same reading as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Hangover
Mnemonic: On the second day, you experience your drunkenness a different way... in the form of a hangover.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 二日 and 酔い put together (the reading for that comes from 酔う).

Name: Hearing Ability
Mnemonic: Your listen power is your hearing ability.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Holding In One's Arms
Mnemonic: You know that the kanji means hug and the verb 抱く means "to hug". This noun is similar, but it usually means carrying by hugging, so holding in one's arms or carrying. This is one that children use a lot!
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.

Name: Hotbed
Mnemonic: A warm bed is a "hotbed."
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hotpot
Mnemonic: Remember how 鍋 means "cooking pot"? This is the suffix version of that, so it means ____hotpot or ____stew.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: In Season
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.

Name: Jail
Mnemonic: The punish task facility is the place you go to do your punishment tasks. It is a jail or prison.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Last Ten Days Of The Month
Meaning: Last Ten Days Of The Month
Mnemonic: These are the below ten days of the month. In other words, the last ten days of the month, or even just the end of the month.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Letter Of Introduction
Mnemonic: Remember how a 年賀状 is a new year's card? This is another kind of card/letter, but this time it's for an introduction (紹介), making it a letter of introduction.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 紹介 as well.

Name: Life Sentence
Mnemonic: Until the end of somebody, you will be punished. If you are punished to your end, you are being given a life sentence.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Listener
Mnemonic: A listen someone, is someone who listens. This is a listener.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. For this word, most often you'll hear the word リスナー but this is a kanji learning site, so you're going to be learning yourself some kanji, you hear?

Name: Living Alone
Mnemonic: If 暮らす is "to live" or "to live one's life," then to live one's life as 一人, means you are living alone.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the vocab readings from 一人 and 暮らす, so you should be able to read this on your own. Just note that くらし changes to ぐらし due to rendaku.

Name: Middle Ten Days Of The Month
Meaning: Middle Ten Days Of The Month
Mnemonic: The middle ten days is the middle ten days of the month. You could also call this the middle of the month.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Miracle
Mnemonic: Some odd traces are left over here. We don't really understand what happened, because it was a miracle, but it certainly left some odd traces behind.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Miso Soup
Mnemonic: You know that 味噌 is "miso," and that 汁 is "soup." So, combine them together and you have Miso Soup.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 味噌 plus the vocab 汁 put together.

Name: Notice
Mnemonic: To display and indicate something is to put up a notice or bulletin.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Oil Painting
Mnemonic: An oil painting is an oil painting.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi for 油 (which you learned with the vocabulary) and the on'yomi for 絵 (which you learned with the kanji).

Name: Omen
Mnemonic: A before omen is something that tells you about something that will happen before it happens. Really this is just an omen or sign.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Payment
Mnemonic: If 払う is "to pay" or "to brush off," then the noun version is payment or brushing off.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 払う, so know that and it will pay forward your knowledge to this one. Note that when 払い is added to the end of a compound, it becomes ばらい.

Name: Perfume
Mnemonic: A fragrance of water is a perfume.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Police Detective
Mnemonic: You know 事 means "occurrence," but it can also mean "matter." And someone who handles punishment matters is someone like a police detective (or detective) trying to find and punish the bad guys.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Prison Term
Mnemonic: A punish period of time is the time in which you are being punished in prison. This is your prison term.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Publication
Mnemonic: To display your writing so it's put on public record, it needs to go into publication. You're getting it printed in a magazine, newspaper, etc., and this can refer to Internet publications as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Punishment
Mnemonic: A punish penalty is a punishment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Recruiting
Mnemonic: I want to recruit some people, so let's gather them up and do some recruiting and solicitation to get them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Reduction
Mnemonic: Whittle down and decrease something. This is a reduction or cutback, since you're whittling down and decreasing it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Reimbursement
Mnemonic: My dialect has offended you? I will make reparation by giving you a reimbursement and some compensation. I'm sorry my dialect was so bad you couldn't understand the speech. Here's your money back.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Resistance
Mnemonic: We are ready to confront war, if we have to. We are going to start the resistance against your regime, confront you, and even make war.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ruins
Mnemonic: All you leave behind are traces of the past. These are the ruins of what happened before. The historic remains...
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Seasickness
Mnemonic: When you're boat drunk you have sea sickness.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 船 goes to ふな (probably because you're sick and can't spell). The 酔い comes from 酔う.

Name: Seaside
Mnemonic: If you look to the sea, you are seaside or coastal.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Self Introduction
Mnemonic: A one's self (自己) introduction (紹介) is a self introduction.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Shameless Person
Mnemonic: 恥 is a "disgrace." If you 知らず then you don't know something. In this case, you don't know disgrace, and a person who doesn't know disgrace is a shameless person, because they don't care what disgraces them and what doesn't.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 恥 and 知る put together.

Name: Shooting
Mnemonic: If you have to aim with your attack, you're probably shooting or sniping something with a projectile (like a gun, or something).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Showa Era
Mnemonic: The shining peace time was a time known as the Showa Era. This can also refer to the Showa Emperor or just Showa itself. Everything Showa is here.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sign
Mnemonic: An omen for the climate of things is a sign or indication of change. If there's an omen, there's going to be a sign as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Silk
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a mnemonic in case you need to refresh your memory: Wearing silk is the key (き) to not being nude (ぬ). Wear it!

Name: Skewer
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

Name: Slow
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of slow? It's slow (or, if you're slow, you're probably late, too).
ReadingMnemonic: How slow are you? You are oh so slow (おそ).

Name: Soups
Mnemonic: A soup thing is what you use to refer to soups.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is both the kun'yomi readings combined to form one word. So, you'll want to make sure you know the word 汁.

Name: Suicide Bomb
Mnemonic: If you self explode, it means you're blowing up yourself, and probably taking others with you. This is a suicide bomb.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sweet Vinegar
Mnemonic: Sweet vinegar is sweet vinegar. Them Japanese love their sweet things.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 甘い plus 酢, combined together. It's the kun'yomi readings, but that's probably because we're combing two words into one. It also changes the す to ず so, remember that.

Name: Taiwan
Mnemonic: The machine gulf isn't what you'd expect. In fact, looking at the reading will probably help the most first, since this word represents Taiwan.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is たい for 台, which is a little different from what you learned, but not the end of the world (especially if you can get the meaning down). The わん is however what you learned, so even if you arrive to だいわん, you'll probably realize that this is たいわん.

Name: Temporary
Mnemonic: Look to time to see how much longer this will last. It's not forever, it's temporary, which is why we must look to time to figure out how much longer it'll be around.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Appeal For Something
Mnemonic: The kanji is recruit, so this verb vocab version can also mean to recruit. However, its primary meaning is to appeal for something, like a job position or donations.
ReadingMnemonic: You'd like to appeal for two, no (つの), three things! Three!

Name: To Be Afflicted With
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means afflicted and the verb vocab version is to be afflicted with or to suffer from.
ReadingMnemonic: I was afflicted with an ancient Egyptian disease that turned me into sun god Ra, but now I'm okay. I was a Ra (わずら), but now I'm just me again.

Name: To Be Oncoming
Mnemonic: Being in the versus yonder (the opposite side) means you are in one yonder and someone is in the other yonder, and you are coming towards each other. So this means to be oncoming or to come towards.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Be Shy
Mnemonic: 恥ずかしい is "embarrassing." This is the verb version. What happens when someone is embarrassed? They become shy and bashful. That's why this word is to be shy or to be bashful.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 恥ずかしい.

Name: To Bounce
Mnemonic: Weird that this kanji means bullet but the verb vocab version means to bounce. Just imagine someone shooting a bullet. What does it do when it hits the right materials? It's going to bounce.
ReadingMnemonic: If you're going to bounce something off that wall, it has (はず) to be made of rubber, otherwise it will just go right through. It has to.

Name: To Bury
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means burial, so the verb version would be to bury or to inter.
ReadingMnemonic: We're going to bury you, so this is your new home (ほうむ) now, friend.

Name: To Compensate For
Mnemonic: To make reparations is to compensate for or to make up for something. You're going to atone for your sins.
ReadingMnemonic: When you try to compensate for everything you've ever done wrong, you become too good for your own britches. You are too good now (つぐなう).

Name: To Demolish
Mnemonic: The kanji is crumble, so what happens when you crumble something? You are going to demolish it. You are going to break it. You know you're doing the crumbling / demolishing because someone's going to sue (す) you for what you've done here today.
ReadingMnemonic: You are Zeus, and you demolish everything in your path. Your friend Hercules watches and is all like "That's coo' Zeus (くず), that's so cool."

Name: To Do A Favor
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means favor and the verb vocab version is to do a favor for.
ReadingMnemonic: If you are going to do a favor for anyone, it's going to be for your good buddy meg (めぐ). Imagine a Meg you know (or know of) and imagine yourself doing a favor for her. Meg Ryan is so happy you're in her life.

Name: To Embrace
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hug and the verb vocab version is to embrace or to hold (in one's arms, that is). It can also mean to hug, especially in the form of 抱きしめる.
