ReadingMnemonic: What are you going to embrace? How about your dad (だ)? Or if he's not around, maybe an e-dad (いだ)? You know, like a digital version of a dad. The two readings for this word have different nuances. だく is more for physical holding and hugging, as in 赤ちゃんを抱く (to hold a baby). But when it's something you hold in your heart, like an emotion or feeling, use the いだく reading: 疑問を抱く (to hold doubts) or 夢を抱く (to have a dream), for example.

Name: To Face
Mnemonic: If you look to something, you are facing it, taking it head on. That's why this verb vocab is to face, as in "to face terrorism," etc.
ReadingMnemonic: The reason you must (to) face terrorism is because the terrorists have threatened to take everyone's noses (のぞ) away. We must face them head on if we are to save our noses!

Name: To Fight
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fight so the verb version is to fight or to struggle.
ReadingMnemonic: Your neighborhood is fighting a struggle against car theft. Sadly, your car was stolen. So, you say: "ta-ta, car (たたか). Ta-ta."

Name: To Get Torn
Mnemonic: If 破る is "to tear" or "to rip," then this is to get torn or to get broken or to get ripped.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 破る.

Name: To Introduce
Mnemonic: A 紹介 is an introduction. So the verb version is to introduce.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Helps that I introduced introduction to you earlier.

Name: To Jump
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hop and the verb vocab version is to hop or to jump or to leap. Basically anything that gets both feet off the ground via your own foot propulsion.
ReadingMnemonic: Know how 飛ぶ means "to fly"? This is a similar idea, though this time you're not flying nearly as much, because you're just hopping or jumping. Anyways, the readings are the same.

Name: To Listen To
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means listen and the verb vocab version is to listen to or to hear.
ReadingMnemonic: The meaning is really similar to 聞く, right? The reading is the same.

Name: To Put Up A Sign
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means display, so if you're doing the action of displaying something, you're going to put up something, or, sometimes more specifically, to put up a sign.
ReadingMnemonic: You have to put up a sign for your newest invention, the car car (かか). It is a car made so that other cars can drive the car. Nobody wants to buy it, which is why you have to put up a sign.

Name: To Rebel
Mnemonic: If you're anti something and you confront the government about it, in some cases you are going to rebel against the government... that is, if you're crazy enough about it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Resist
Mnemonic: Resist and confront those who pressure or attack you. This is to resist or to withstand.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Return
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return and the verb vocab version is to return or to be returned. This is when something does this on its own. You aren't doing the returning of something in this case.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Swell
Mnemonic: 盛り上げる is "to heap up" - this has a similar idea, except now this is more like an excitement or swelling. As excitement heaps up in you, you are going to get excited. Note how 上がる is in here. This means something is happening to you (or something else), but you're not doing the action. When you get all sorts of excitement building up in you, you aren't really doing it, it's just happening on its own in reaction to something else.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 盛り and 上がる. Let the excitement build as you realize you know the reading already.

Name: To Take Up
Mnemonic: You learned that 執 means "tenacious," but it can also mean "carry out." The verb version here means to take up, like taking up a task or responsibility, or to carry out.
ReadingMnemonic: Notice how the word "take" is in this verb. If you take something, you might say 取る. This word shares take's reading.

Name: To Use
Mnemonic: The kanji means dispatch, but the word 遣う itself simply means to use because it's basically just a more formal version of 使う. Still, the kanji adds a subtle nuance: it suggests you're sending out some care or intention when using something, usually things like time, money, language, or feelings.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this is an alternate version of 使う, it has the same reading too. If you remember that, you can remember this word's reading.

Name: To Whittle Something Down
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means whittle down and the verb vocab version is to whittle something down, to shave something down, and to reduce something.
ReadingMnemonic: To whittle something down or not to whittle something down. Will have to take it on a case (けず) by case basis.

Name: Traces
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When something leaves traces or marks behind, it's because they were there, but now they're gone, and you've come 後 (あと) they left.

Name: Tsukemono
Mnemonic: In Japanese, pickled things refer to  Japanese pickled vegetables!
ReadingMnemonic: You already learned 漬ける (to pickle something), so just take the る off and shove the け into the kanji. You still read it, but it's hiding. It probably shrank in the pickling process. Stick some things (もの) on there and you know the reading! Not bad! By the way, sometimes you'll see this word spelled like 漬け物 too.

Name: Wiretapping
Mnemonic: I steal by listening to what people say. I do this by wiretapping their phone and bugging their homes.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Wisdom
Mnemonic: You are favored with knowing things. You have wisdom and intelligence.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn 知's on'yomi when you learned the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your wisdom tells you people should eat cheese (ち) on a regular basis. Yes, in your infinite wisdom, you know that a calcium-rich food like cheese is just what humanity needs. It is your duty, O wise one, to share this wisdom with others. Go forth! Spread the wisdom of cheese consumption with all mankind!

Name: Writing
Mnemonic: You learned that 執 means "tenacious," but it can also mean "carry out." So what do you carry out with a writing brush? You carry out writing! But not just any writing — this is professional writing, so you better get it right!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi reading of the kanji, but both readings are slightly altered: しつ gets shorted to しっ, and ひつ gets rendaku'd to ぴつ. If you're having trouble with the rendaku, just imagine fervently writing page after page until your pits (ぴつ) start to reek. Mmm, smell those musky pits. That's the smell of someone who's just poured their heart and sweat out onto the page!

Name: Absurd
Mnemonic: 馬鹿 is "stupid" so if you hear a rumor about something (らしい) that's stupid, you'll just respond by saying "that's absurd."
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 馬鹿.

Name: Absurd
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 馬鹿 means "idiot?" Well put two idiots together and everything they say and do is absolutely absurd. Remember how ridiculous that "Dumb and Dumber" movie was? Yeah. Like that.
ReadingMnemonic: You already learned 馬鹿, so as long as you can remember it twice in a row, you should be able to read this too!

Name: A Favor
Mnemonic: To 頼む is "to ask for" or "to request." The noun version of that is a favor or a request.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 頼む.

Name: Air Conditioning
Mnemonic: A cool cluster is something that has a cluster of cool-creating coolant. This device is air conditioning.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Annexation
Mnemonic: Join and join with each other. This is an annexation, or a merger.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that 合 is read as ごう here. Who orchestrated this annexation? Good ol' grandpa ごういち.

Name: As Well As
Mnemonic: 及ぶ means "to reach" or "to amount to." The noun version is more like a grammar thing, as it means "as well as." Perhaps if you are reaching a certain point or certain amount, then you are adding things on. That's why this means "as well as".
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 及ぶ, so if you know that one you know that one as well as this one.

Name: Ball
Mnemonic: A dancing (舞踏) meet is when you all get together to do dancing, the kind that's like "step step swing" (or whatever). This is a ball or dance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Base
Mnemonic: A foundation tray is a flat thing that is your foundation. It holds everything up. It is the base of everything that goes above it. It is the foundation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Be Entrusted With
Mnemonic: You accept and consign the job. You are going to be entrusted with this property for the winter. Don't go into room 237.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Birth Control
Mnemonic: I dodged being pregnant. Whew. Good thing I was taking my birth control.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Boiled Tofu
Mnemonic: 豆腐 is tofu, and 湯 means hot water, making it tofu you've put in hot water, aka boiled tofu.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of 豆腐 and the kun'yomi reading of 湯. You should be able to read this on your own. Will of course help to know 豆腐 as well.

Name: Bribe
Mnemonic: A bribe bribe is a bribe.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bribery
Mnemonic: The presents you acquire are a bribe. What? That is bribery!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Client
Mnemonic: You already know that 依頼 means "request." What's a "request" person? It's someone who requests things from you. In other words, your client!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cluster
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: "How many things are in this cluster?" asks your boss. "Just a few sah," (ふさ) you reply.

Name: Consideration
Mnemonic: I'll think and consider this. I'll give it consideration.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Consideration
Mnemonic: If you distribute your considers, you will be giving consideration and care to whatever you're distributing these cares to.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Consign
Mnemonic: To the committee I would like to consign these things. This is what I consign.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Control
Mnemonic: Try to suppress and control the enemy. We must control them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Daily Edition
Mnemonic: The day's edition is the daily edition.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The にち goes to にっ.

Name: Demand
Mnemonic: You demand and need this thing, which is why you must make this demand.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Depiction
Mnemonic: Draw a copy of the world and you are making a depiction of the world.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Depths
Mnemonic: Something is in the interior AND the bottom? Why, it's in the very depths! And if it's in the interior and bottom of you, then it's at the bottom of your heart!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Deterrent
Mnemonic: This is going to suppress and stop what's coming at you. It's a deterrent.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Disk
Mnemonic: A round tray is a disk, though if it goes through the air it becomes a flying saucer.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Drawing
Mnemonic: If you draw an image, you end up with a drawing (or a painting).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Eager
Mnemonic: Go ahead and suspend fate, let's get this done before the time we are fated to do it. We are that eager to get started.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Elderly Person
Mnemonic: Someone of tall age is going to be an elderly person or an old person.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Escape
Mnemonic: If you escape death you have, well, an escape.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Evacuation
Mnemonic: Dodge a difficult situation by getting away from it. Do an evacuation to get out of there!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Evening Edition
Mnemonic: The evening edition is the evening edition.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for the first kanji and the on'yomi reading for the second. You've learned both of the readings, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Far Back
Mnemonic: Something that is in the interior of something else is inside of it, deep, and far back / in the back. Just imagine something interior to something else, it's probably in the back.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Fatal
Mnemonic: Somebody doing you fate -al would... probably be pretty fatal!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: First Installment
Mnemonic: The ordinal number prefix one bullet is actually the first installment of something. Picture someone firing a gun to let everyone know that, yes, this is indeed the first round of… whatever you're doing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: First Person
Mnemonic: The one person title is the title one person gives themselves. They are speaking in the first person.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Foreign
Mnemonic: Something is versus the outside. Back in the day, everything was a battle with the outside. You had the Mongols... the rebels... and the foreigners. So, when you say something is "versus the outside" you're just saying it's something compared to where you are right now. It's something that's foreign or external.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: General
Mnemonic: All general-al! It's super general. It's general and overall and across the board. Nothing specific going on here.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Genes
Mnemonic: If 遺伝 is heredity and you pass your heredity to your child, how is it being passed? Via genes, of course.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Give Something Back
Mnemonic: Send back to the origin means you are going to give something back. This word is commonly used to mean "giving benefits back to the consumers.” For example, if a company makes more money than usual, they can thank consumers with a 利益還元 sale, lowering prices to "give back" some of the profits.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Good
Mnemonic: You send your best regards to everyone. Is this good? Is it okay? Is it all right? Yes, of course, how nice of you.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: Heating
Mnemonic: A warm cluster is when you get a bunch of warmth together, and then use it to warm your home. This is indoor heating, kind of like the same way how an air conditioner is a "cool cluster."
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Knee
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

Name: Kneecap
Mnemonic: Your knee's head is the kneecap. It's also called the patella, if you want to get fancy and talk about bone names.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 頭 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're walking around in your mom's house, minding your own business, when you slam your kneecap right into that gargoyle she loves (がしら). It hurts so bad, you can't even think out that phrase and instead you shout out, "GA SHE RA" and fall to the floor, clutching your searing kneecap (which has probably broken in half).

Name: Lineage
Mnemonic: The main reason behind your connection to some people is your lineage or history. Lineage and history tie people (especially families) together.
ReadingMnemonic: You didn't learn this reading for 由 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you had good lineage you'd never make a U-ey (ゆい) on the highway. That's dangerous, and people with good lineage and a long history would simply never do such a thing.

Name: Loose
Mnemonic: This is the na-adjective version of loose, so that means this word means loose or mild or gentle.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Loose
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of loose? It's loose.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, so feel nice and loose and move on to the next item.

Name: Meiji Restoration
Mnemonic: You know Meiji, (明治), and you know restoration (維新). Combine them together and you have the Meiji Restoration.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Milky Way
Mnemonic: You're looking at heaven's river, or the river of heaven. There's only one river in heaven (i.e., the sky), and that's the Milky Way!
ReadingMnemonic: This is two individual words connected with a の, so it uses kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 天 yet, so we've got a mnemonic to help you. Also watch out for the rendaku on 川, turning it into がわ! What does the Milky Way remind you of? It kind of looks like a shining piece of armor (あま). Look at it in the sky, shimmering like a piece of silver armor. Uncanny, no? To summarize: The 天 is read あま here, and the 川 gets rendaku'd to がわ. Add a の inbetween and the full reading for this vocab is あまのがわ!

Name: Monthly Edition
Mnemonic: The moon edition is the monthly edition, since 月 also means "month."
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Morning Edition
Mnemonic: The morning edition is the morning edition.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You may have seen this reading for 朝 before, but here's a mnemonic to help you: You pick up your copy of the morning edition and Mrs. Chou (ちょう) is on the front cover. Oh no, what has she done now? Before you can find out, the morning edition is ripped from your hands. You look up and see Mrs. Chou running away, cackling, with other copies stuffed into her arms.

Name: Musical Performance
Mnemonic: If you perform and play music you are doing a musical performance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Musical Performance
Mnemonic: Play music that will give me comfort, why then I should go see a musical performance to keep me nice and calm.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Nara Prefecture
Mnemonic: Remember Nara (奈良)? This is the prefecture of it, making it Nara Prefecture.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Necessities
Mnemonic: I have certain demands for goods to take on this trip. Don't worry, it's just the necessities and essentials.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Okinawa
Mnemonic: The open sea rope is the rope that attaches Okinawa to the mainland.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, put together.

Name: Old Age
Mnemonic: If you are at an elderly age you are at an old age.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: On The Contrary
Mnemonic: Something that is contrary... this is the te-form version of contrary, meaning you're starting to say something, making this on the contrary.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is like 変える, which is to change. So, if you change what the other person is saying to another way, then you're saying you're changing things. It has the same reading, so remember it that way.

Name: Oppression
Mnemonic: I want to suppress and pressure you! Muahaha! This is oppression.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ordinary
Mnemonic: 一般 is "general" and "common", and adding 的 just gives you ordinary or general or common.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 一般 plus 的.

Name: Patience
Mnemonic: A spicy hug is a hug that feels not so great. But, it's not really painful all at once, either. As you're receiving a spicy hug, you just have to show patience and endurance while it lasts.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, but you haven't learned this for either 辛 or 抱 yet, so let's use a mnemonic to remember it: Think about how much patience and endurance your shins (しん) need to have to be good at bowling (ぼう). You won't get any strikes with weak shins! Note that the ぼう reading is the rendaku'd reading for 抱.

Name: Perfect
Mnemonic: A perfect disc is flawless. It's just perfect.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that rendaku turns へき into ぺき.

Name: Pickled In
Mnemonic: You already learned that 漬ける means "to pickle something," so if you add that to the end of a food word (and leave off the る) it means that food has been pickled in something, like  酢漬け  (pickled in vinegar).
ReadingMnemonic: You've already learned 漬ける (to pickle something), so just take the る off and you've pickled whatever comes before 〜漬け. Just look out for つ changing to づ — think of the rendaku here as a side effect of the pickling process!

Name: Pregnant Woman
Mnemonic: A pregnant wife is a pregnant woman.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own — just watch out for ふ turning into ぷ due to rendaku here.

Name: Profound
Mnemonic: If your interior is deep, then you're a really profound person.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned おく when you learned the kanji, and ふかい from 深い, so you should be able to read this on your own. Most of the time the ふ is rendaku'd into ぶ, but it can be read the other way too.

Name: Reaching Home Plate
Mnemonic: We got life by sending back our runner to home plate. That run allowed us more life in this game. Now, maybe we'll win! It was all by reaching home plate. Outside of baseball, this means returning alive from somewhere.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rejection
Mnemonic: It is contrary to what I think is good. It is below my standards. Thus, rejection.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Release From Prison
Mnemonic: You exit a facility. It's your release from prison!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading follows on'yomi protocols, but you just have to be careful of the shortened しゅつ which becomes しゅっ. Note: There is also the reading でどころ for the meanings origin and source. This version is generally used in spoken language, often to emphasize the significance or curiosity about where something came from.

Name: Restraint
Mnemonic: A far consider is when you let your considerations go far from you so you don't think about how angry you are about what's going on in front of you. It allows you to have some restraint, since your considerations are far from here. It also allows you to decline things, since you're not considering the other person's feelings.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Return
Mnemonic: If we return and send back things, we will have done a return or restoration.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rope Off
Mnemonic: Take your rope and stretch it out to show where the cutoff is. This is when you rope off something. It shows your territory and turf. Don't cross this rope I've stretched out, it's my domain.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 縄 and 張る put together into one word. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes the 張り reading to ばり. Here's a little mnemonic in case you need it: In order to rope off your turf you go around screaming baa (ば), basically at anyone who gets near your territory. You walk around the perimeter of your house or yard and shout, "This is my domain! Baa!" Yeah, that'll show 'em.

Name: Secret
Mnemonic: Keep information inside a cord that cordons off just you and a few others (or maybe no one else). Only the people you let inside the cord can know, because it's a secret and confidential.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Selection
Mnemonic: Choose and select your choice. This is your selection.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Spices
Mnemonic: The fee for fragrance and spicy in your food is the fee of spices. If you don't pay your spices fee, you aren't going to have any spice or fragrance in your food. If you do, you'll have those things and your food will be awesome!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them for 香 and 料, but not for 辛, so here's a mnemonic to help: The cabinet you keep your spices in is in a terrible place on the floor, and you keep banging your shin (しん) on it. Ouch!

Name: Symmetry
Mnemonic: If you versus (compare) the title of these two things, you'll notice that they're the same as each other. They have symmetry.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sympathy Visit
Mnemonic: The dance of going to see someone. It's a sympathy visit. Because, you know, you gotta dance the dance of sympathy.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. 舞い comes from 舞う.

Name: Tendency
Mnemonic: If you usually lean yonder, in that direction, that will be your tendency.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Time Limit
Mnemonic: A time limit is a time limit, but not any old time limit. This is usually used at the beginning of compound words, especially 時限爆弾 (time bomb).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: To Abolish
Mnemonic: 廃止 is abolition, so the verb version of that would be to abolish.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 廃止 as well.

Name: To Accompany
Mnemonic: The same accompany means you are in the same place as someone, and you are accompanying them. This word means to accompany. This is only used for accompanying people.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Accompany
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accompany and the verb vocab version is to accompany. This can be used both literally and figuratively.
ReadingMnemonic: You need to accompany your friend, so to call out to them you yell "友, NOW!" (ともなう) to command them to come near you to accompany you to somewhere else.

Name: To Avoid
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means avoid or dodge and the verb vocab version is to avoid or to dodge!
ReadingMnemonic: Each reading has a slightly different meaning. Here's some mnemonics to help you remember them: You need to avoid people who drink sake (さけ) all the time. Why? Because when they get drunk you'll have to dodge the yo-yos (よ) they spin at you. Sake makes you want to toss the ol' yo-yo around. Avoid them or you'll have to get good at dodging!

Name: To Be Leaned
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lean, and the verb vocab version means to be leaned or to be tilted. You aren't doing the leaning or the tilting, though, you're just watching, which is why you say "cool" (く) when you see it, because it's already done.
ReadingMnemonic: When you need a moon to be leaned, your best option is to cut a moon (かたむ) in half. It's impossible for a full moon to be tilted, but a split moon can lean one way or the other.

Name: To Be Pregnant
Mnemonic: To do pregnant pregnant is to be pregnant.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Bite
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bite or chew so the verb version is to bite or to chew.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the same reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Do
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means do and the verb vocab version is to do. This is a polite way to say "to do."
ReadingMnemonic: What are you going to do? You're going to become a professional eater (いた), because you like to do eating a lot, and you are very polite about your eating despite how fast you eat in these competitions.

Name: To Draw
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means draw and the verb vocab refers to creating visual art, like drawings or paintings, making this to draw or to paint. It can also be used figuratively to illustrate ideas or dreams, or to depict scenes in one's mind.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 書く, which is similar to drawing something (you use a writing instrument on a piece of paper, which you can do with drawing). Another reading is えがく, which is like saying 絵を書く, but combined and rendaku'd.

Name: To Eat
Mnemonic: You know the kanji means eat, and you also already know 食べる. So what's the deal with this also meaning to eat?
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You do know that reading, but this uses a different one, so here's a mnemonic to help you: There's nothing you love to eat more than cookies (く). You could eat them day and night, but watch out, as that might get a little… time-consuming.

Name: To Entrust
Mnemonic: If you consign something to someone, you are going to entrust them with that item. Here you go, I entrust you.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this one is unusual, but I will entrust you with the knowledge of why to help you remember it! This uses the on'yomi reading and not the kun'yomi, as you might expect, because the す here is the old-fashioned version of the verb する. Luckily, you learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so it's unusual but hopefully not too hard!

Name: To Escape
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means escape so the verb vocab version is to escape. Also, it can be to flee or to run away. Basically, if you're trying to get away from someone or something, you could be doing this.
ReadingMnemonic: You are trying to escape from something chasing you, but you can't run fast because of your knee (に). You try to run, but it keeps holding you back. Feel the fear and pain of running with a hurt knee, and curse that knee of yours for holding you back.

Name: To Exceed
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ultra or super so the verb version is what happens when you do something ultra or super much. You start to exceed the amount you were meant to do it. If you ultra drive a car, you exceed the speed limit. If you ultra study, you exceed your brain capacity. Get it?
ReadingMnemonic: Who likes to exceed everything? Your 子 (こ)! Or you, when you were a 子. No bedtimes, parents, or other limitations could stop you! You were able to go over them all!

Name: To Exert
Mnemonic: If you have reach, that means you're able to exert a great influence on people. Watch out, though, because it also means you're able to cause great harm.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 及ぶ, so if you know that, you'll be able to read this one too.

Name: Together
Mnemonic: One cord is enough to tie you together with someone. Imagine an invisible cord stretching between you and the people you do things together with. That one cord is like a symbol of your togetherness. Very poetic (or very Death Stranding), right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The 一 becomes いっ.

Name: To Give A Present
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means presents so if you do presents, you're giving them, making this to give a present or to gift.
ReadingMnemonic: If you want to give someone a present, maybe you would think about sending/送る (おくる) it to them?

Name: To Handle
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means handle so the verb vocab version is to handle.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, actually! Can you handle that?

Name: To Loosen
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means loose, so the verb version is to loosen. This is when something loosens on its own, and not via your actions. You know this because a cow is loosening things, moo (む)...
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

Name: To Maintain
Mnemonic: To "do maintenance (維持)" is keeping something in that maintained position, which is to maintain.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the reading from the vocabulary you learned earlier. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Match
Mnemonic: You do one do and I'll do another do. I'll do the same thing to match it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The いち is shortened to いっ.

Name: To Pay
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bribe, but when you pay a bribe, you are going to pay something or to cover something, like a meal, or something like that.
ReadingMnemonic: You need to make a payment, make a payment now (まかなう) to cover the cost of this room.

Name: To Point Out
Mnemonic: If 指摘 is "pointing out" then the verb version is to point out.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading comes from 指摘.

Name: To Publish
Mnemonic: The edition will go out to the public if we were to publish it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Rely On
Mnemonic: 頼む is "to ask for" or "to request." This word is to rely on or to trust or to depend on. You know it is this word because it is rude to rely on your friends, but you are anyways.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a bit different from 頼む, however. It's たよ, because you go to rely on your friends so much they become tiyored (たよ). They say "tired" like that, for some reason.

Name: To Return
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return and the verb vocab version is to return or to return something. You know you're doing the action of returning someone or something because when you do, they just sue (す) you because you broke the thing you were supposed to return before returning it.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Roast
Mnemonic: The kanji is fry. You already know the verb for "to fry" (炒める), so this verb is for a slightly different cooking technique — to roast.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to use the kun'yomi reading. The tricky part is where this doesn't use the same kun'yomi as 炒める, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this: Now that you know the difference between frying and roasting, we're going to roast our first dish: Eagle (い)! I heard it's your favorite food, so I just had to prepare this for you. What do you mean, "eww"?!

Name: To Spin
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means spin so the verb vocab version is to spin.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is used here.

Name: To Stake
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means suspend, but in this case, you're going to suspend your win or loss and try to stake it all on one, big bet. You're going to risk it all!
ReadingMnemonic: You decide to risk it all and bet everything on your car (か). If you lose, you lose the car, but if you win, then you were right to stake it all on this.

Name: To Step Into
Mnemonic: 踏む is "to step on" and the kanji 込 means into, so this means to step into.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from the word 踏む and the kanji 込, put together.

Name: To Stretch Something
Mnemonic: If 伸びる is "to be stretched" then 伸ばす is to stretch something, where you're doing the stretching. You know this because you took a bus and you stretched it out to be an even longer bus.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 伸びる, so if you know that you should know this.

Name: To Transfer
Mnemonic: You have ride and exchange, so you take your ride (bus, train, whatever) and exchange to another bus, train, or whatever. That's why this word means to transfer, and most commonly to change trains.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 乗る and 換える.

Name: Trading Firm
Mnemonic: A trade (貿易) company (会社) is a company that makes a lot of trades, because it's easy for them, making this word a trading firm.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for the 易 portion is a bit weird. Just think about how this one trade firm only trades in train stations (えき).

Name: Tray
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are the same! This word also means board and disc, which makes sense if you think about it. Boards you play games on are basically just trays for the pieces, and discs go inside boards (like records) for storage.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

Name: Trust
Mnemonic: If you believe you can consign your trust to someone, then you can trust them, or you are being entrusting.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Wife
Mnemonic: The interior person (the honorific さん shows it's a person) is the person who stands in the interior of the house and doesn't leave, making that person your wife. Ouch. Sexist kanji strikes again.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from what you learned in the kanji.

Name: Working Name
Mnemonic: A temporary title is what you give something when you don't have a final title for it. it's a working name or a tentative name.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Yawn
Mnemonic: When you lack stretching, your body has to get that energy out somehow, so you end up yawning.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You've never seen more yawning than when you performed acupuncture (あく) on a bee (び). It was so relaxed from being the one poked for once that it just couldn't stop yawning.

Name: Years Old
Mnemonic: Your year age is the number of years old you are.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Active Participation
Mnemonic: A lively leap is what you do when you have active participation in an activity and often find success and do great.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Addressee
Mnemonic: The address name is the name that's on the address, making it the addressee. This can also mean name and address.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 宛 is the same one you learned for the kanji. The reading for 名 comes from the kun'yomi reading, which you learned in the vocabulary word 名 and 名前. So, the reading for this word is あてな.

Name: Allowance
Mnemonic: 遣う means "to use," so a "small use" refers to what you can do with your spending money. You're not rolling in dough over here, so you can only use your spending money on small things. Think of it like a little allowance you can use to buy baseball cards and bubblegum and stuff.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the alternate reading of 小 and 遣う's reading. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Antarctic Circle
Mnemonic: If 南極 is Antarctica, then the Antarctica Range is the area that makes up Antarctica. That's the Antarctic Circle.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Atomic Bomb
Mnemonic: 原子 is atom and 爆弾 is bomb. What is an atom bomb? An atomic bomb.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Backup
Mnemonic: Something that can abstain until it's needed makes for good backup. Think about it — you don't want backup rushing in too early, right? It should abstain until the backup is actually needed.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You learned this reading already! Good for you!

Name: Bitter Flavor
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. The adjective form of bitter is bitter, or more specifically, a bitter flavor.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: She gives you some food, and it's terribly bitter. You look at the lady who gave you this bitter food. You say, "She boooo" as in, she's no good, and she serves bitter food.

Name: Broken Language
Mnemonic: One sided saying things means you don't know both sides of the language, causing you to speak in broken language, for example speaking a few words in broken Japanese or broken English.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned for 片 and the こと of 言葉.

Name: Bulletin Board
Mnemonic: A 掲示 is a notice or sign. Put this on a board, and it becomes a bulletin board.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Certificate
Mnemonic: Your excuse for the current condition is surprising, especially considering your diploma and license on the issue.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Choice Of Words
Mnemonic: You may remember 言葉 means "word" and 遣う means "to use." That makes this your choice of words or, more simply, your word use.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 言葉 and 遣う combined together.

Name: Commonwealth
Mnemonic: Take along your home country to all the other spaces you want to add to your group. Put them together to form the commonwealth or federation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Condemned Criminal
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 死刑 means "death penalty?" Well a criminal who has been sentenced to it is a condemned criminal or a death row convict. They're condemned to death.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cooked Rice
Mnemonic: The honorable meal is cooked rice. It's the meal of Japan.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Crowd
Mnemonic: A flock that has gathered is a crowd and multitude. Because, well, lots of things gathering.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Daffodil
Mnemonic: A water hermit, for some reason, is a daffodil. Just imagine a water hermit dancing around picking daffodils, because he loves 'em! Yayyy daffodils!!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Death By Shooting
Mnemonic: A gun kill is a death by shooting.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Deep Red
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same, so this also means deep red, or crimson. Additionally, it can also mean rouge, usually in reference to the cosmetic.
ReadingMnemonic: This is where things get a little complicated. You already learned べに as a reading with 口紅. 紅 can also be read べに just by itself, and in that case, it means rouge. However, there’s a different reading that’s used for deep red, which we’d like to focus on here, so here’s a mnemonic to help you remember it: There's so much deep red blood everywhere, there's no way of helping this person bleeding out. One might say, cure ない (くれない).  Just remember: when there's deep red everywhere, cure ない.

Name: Discreet
Mnemonic: Humility is heavy, so it's best nobody knows your secret. You should be discreet instead.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember the alternative reading for 重. If you aren't discreet or careful, the evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう)will find you and kill you!

Name: Doorbell
Mnemonic: A buzzer that will call you to the door is a doorbell.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 呼ぶ and 鈴's reading, put together.

Name: Double Play
Mnemonic: A join kill is when in one play you get two kills (outs) in baseball, making it a double play.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Effect
Mnemonic: A turtle shell that is patterned has much more effect and result and worth than a non-patterned turtle shell.
ReadingMnemonic: You haven't learned this reading for 甲 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to know how much you're worth, just take a look at your car (か). Cars are the result of money and hard work. So basically, they say how much you're worth!

Name: Employment
Mnemonic: The employ task is employment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: English Speaking World
Mnemonic: The English range is the areas where people speak English, aka the English Speaking World.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Exemption
Mnemonic: To excuse and to exclude, that's exemption.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Eyebrow
Mnemonic: An eyebrow's hair is the individual eyebrow hair that makes them up.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!

Name: Fellow Countryman
Mnemonic: A home country person is a fellow countryman or compatriot (only for Japanese people though). In Japan, you're a Japanese national.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Flock
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji, making it flock.
ReadingMnemonic: A flock? A flock of cows (む)! Imagine a flock of cows, probably flying like birds, because flocks usually have something to do with birds.

Name: Footprint
Mnemonic: Foot traces are footprints.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of the kanji, put together.

Name: Fragment
Mnemonic: Something that is one-sided has only one side and not the whole. That's just one of a pair or a fragment of the whole. Stick this onto another word and you have one of a pair or an "incomplete_____."
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Fragrance
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of 香, making it have the same meaning, fragrance.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The fragrance you smell is somebody's 顔 (かお). Just imagine smelling the fragrance of a bunch of people's faces. Yum!

Name: Frame
Mnemonic: The frame group is a frame or a framework.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the reading of 枠 and the reading of the vocab word 組み. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Frame
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Fullness
Mnemonic: Allocate the truth more and more to make things better. The truth is, we need to allocate even more, until we've reached fullness.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Gifu
Mnemonic: The branch off mound is the area of Japan known as Gifu.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Go Hall
Mnemonic: A chess piece institution is where you go to play chess... or, in Japan, it's not chess, it's a Go hall or a Go club (it's a very interesting game you should look it up!).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Gun
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Gunma Prefecture
Mnemonic: The flock of horses prefecture is the part of Japan known as Gunma Prefecture.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for 群 and 県 are okay, but you haven't learned this reading for 馬 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Gunma Prefecture is where your mama (ま) lives! Imagine going back to your mama's house, and finding it's now in Gunma Prefecture. It's a bit of a surprise, but very handy for practicing your Japanese. Thanks mama!

Name: Heir
Mnemonic: The traces are the people that inherit what you have. They are your heirs or heiresses. Your successor.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the vocab words 跡 and 継ぐ put together.

Name: Hermit
Mnemonic: A hermit person is a hermit or mountain man.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Home Run
Mnemonic: A hit you get in baseball that takes you to the origin plate is a home run. HOOOMMEERUNNNN!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Humble Japanese
Mnemonic: Language when you defer to modesty is humble Japanese. Of course, this doesn't have to refer to Japanese, though it usually does, meaning this could mean humble language as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Important Points
Mnemonic: A needed paragraph contains the important points of what you want to say.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Item
Mnemonic: You need to go through a paragraph in chunks that you can easily see with your eye so you break it up by item.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you out with 目. If you can't see this item in the paragraph with your eye, someone will mock (もく) you for sure.

Name: Jump
Mnemonic: If you hop and leap into the air, you probably are doing a jump and leap into the air.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Jump Rope
Mnemonic: A rope that you hop over is a jump rope.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the vocab words 縄 and 跳ぶ, put together.

Name: Katakana
Mnemonic: One-sided kana is katakana. Might be easier to do the reading first on this one.
ReadingMnemonic: 片 is かた, and 仮名 is かな. Put them together to get katakana.

Name: License
Mnemonic: You have an excuse that permits you to do what you want. It is a license and certificate allowing you to do this.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Matter
Mnemonic: You know 事 means "occurrence," but it can also mean "matter." So a matter paragraph shows the matters, items, or subjects that make up a larger issue or discussion at hand.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Modesty
Mnemonic: The modesty void is that big pit you go into when you are showing modesty or humility.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Now Hiring
Mnemonic: Recruit and gather everyone to the middle. They're all here gathering for this recruitment because we're now hiring / now recruiting.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Of Honorable Lineage
Mnemonic: Someone or something whose 由緒 (lineage) is 正しい (correct) is of honorable lineage, and venerable indeed.
ReadingMnemonic: You already know the readings for 由緒 and 正しい so you just need to put them together to read this word.

Name: One Handed
Mnemonic: A one sided hand is one of your hands, that means you're doing something one handed.
ReadingMnemonic: These readings are the ones you learned with both of these kanji.

Name: One Way
Mnemonic: A one sided street is for one way only, because everything just goes in one direction.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. You learned the reading from 片 already, and 道 is the vocab reading みち.

Name: Out Of Range
Mnemonic: The range is outside of the range, meaning you're out of range.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pistol
Mnemonic: A short gun is a pistol, because it's not long like a rifle, it's a short gun!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Prayer
Mnemonic: You pray with your thoughts, making this a prayer.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Prisoner
Mnemonic: A criminal person will end up as a prisoner or an inmate if they get caught!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Prosperity
Mnemonic: Prosperity in piles is a lot of prosperity!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Protuberance
Mnemonic: When prosperity wakes up it will push through whatever it's in and create a protuberance or bulge. Just imagine it pushing out of the wall, trying to get out, making a bulge. So prosperous!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Here's a mnemonic for the reading of 起. To get out of this bulge, you use a key (き). The key lets you get out.

Name: Rainy Season
Mnemonic: In the ume season, it rains a lot in Japan (and some other East Asian countries). That's why ume rain means rainy season. It usually happens from the end of May to mid-July, when ume get ready to be harvested.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses an exceptional reading, so don't try to read this with the kanji readings you already learned. Here's a mnemonic to help you: Rainy season is a special season to you (つゆ). All of your favorite things in the year happen during rainy season, like… staying inside all day because all it does is rain! But to you, there's nothing better than rainy season.

Name: Recharge
Mnemonic: Allocate electricity back to the battery with a recharge.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Recommendation
Mnemonic: If you take what you recommend and announce it to the world, you are making a recommendation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Refusal
Mnemonic: I refuse. I am saying "no." That is my refusal.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Resupply
Mnemonic: To take a supplement and allocate it to where it needs to be is to resupply or refill something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rice Cultivation
Mnemonic: If you make a rice plant then you are doing rice cultivation, since you're making it from the seed to the harvest and doing it all!
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses a kun'yomi reading for 稲 (いな) and the usual on'yomi reading for 作. You may not be familiar with the いな reading yet, but it appears in a lot of compounds that use 稲, so it's good to know. Here's a mnemonic to help: When you do rice cultivation, you should eat nachos (いな). You need all the calories and carbs from some loaded-up nachos to get ready for the hard work of rice cultivation, you know? Mmm, you'd happily do rice cultivation every day if it meant you could eat nachos.

Name: Rice Field
Mnemonic: A rice plant rice paddy is a rice field or rice paddy.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses kun'yomi readings for 稲 (いな) and 田 with rendaku (だ). You may not be familiar with the いな reading yet, but it appears in a lot of compounds that use 稲, so it's good to know. Here's a mnemonic to help: There's a popular road trip game in Japan where every time you pass a rice field, you have to eat nachos (いな). See a rice field? Eat nachos. And if you've ever driven through rural Japan, you know how many rice fields (and eaten nachos) that adds up to. I once gained five pounds in two hours on a drive through Niigata… It wasn't pretty. But the rice fields were.

Name: Rice Plant
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the いね reading of this kanji. You can think of it like you're saying "いいね!" at the rice plant you're looking at (just shorten the い).

Name: Rifle Bullet
Mnemonic: A gun's bullet is a bullet, though this word can specifically refer to a rifle bullet as well (probably because it was mostly rifles that people had way back in the day).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Saitama Prefecture
Mnemonic: The cape ball prefecture is Saitama Prefecture.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of 埼 and 玉, and the regular reading for 県.

Name: Sendai
Mnemonic: The hermit machine is a giant machine that lives in the Sendai area of Japan.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Shogi
Mnemonic: Commander chess piece is a game known as shogi (or Japanese chess, but shogi is better). It's similar to chess in a lot of ways and it's pretty interesting. Check it out if you already like chess.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own — just watch out for き turning into ぎ due to rendaku here.

Name: Shogi Player
Mnemonic: A chess piece samurai is someone who plays chess or go, making this word a shogi player or go player.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Small Bell
Mnemonic: The meaning for this word comes from the kanji. It's a small bell!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone is ringing a small bell, over and over. It's Ichiro Suzuki (すず) being obnoxious, ringing that small bell. I think he's trying to get practice started.

Name: Sorry
Mnemonic: An honorable excuse is all I have, and that is no good. I'm sorry and I beg your pardon.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Steel
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You take a look at the steel. It's shaped like a person. Turns out you turned that hag into a steel statue. You say, "huh, that's the hag ね?" (はがね). Whoops, sorry hag lady.

Name: Steel Manufacture
Mnemonic: If you manufacture steel that is steel manufacture.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Steel Material
Mnemonic: Steel material is steel material. Boom!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Still
Mnemonic: If you have a dependent nature, then even if you go off on your own, you're still going to ask for help. Dependent people still need help because that's just how they are.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tax Exemption
Mnemonic: An excuse from taxes? That's a tax exemption.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Aim At
Mnemonic: Remember 狙い and how it means "aim"? Make that into a verb, and you have to aim at.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 狙い, so if you know that you'll be able to aim at knowing this word's reading as well.

Name: To Apply For
Mnemonic: If 応募 is "application" then the verb version is to apply for or to enlist.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 応募's reading, though knowing the readings of the kanji will take care of things too.

Name: To Be At A Loss
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means misguided, but the verb version is usually used to describe how you feel after being misguided — to be at a loss!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you are going to be at a loss you're going to be mad (まど) about it, most likely. Nobody likes to feel at a loss, so imagine how mad you feel when you are.

Name: To Be Discreet
Mnemonic: If you have humility you will try to be discreet.
ReadingMnemonic: Why are you going to be discreet? Because that tutu she (つつし) wears is really embarrassing.

Name: To Concede
Mnemonic: If you are going to defer to someone, you are going to concede something. I concede / defer this to you.
ReadingMnemonic: What are you conceding? Some delicious yuzu (ゆず). You are sad, because they're so much better than lemons and now you don't have them.

Name: To Crumble
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means crumble and the verb vocab version means to crumble, like, something is crumbling or collapsing.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 崩す, so if you know that you know this reading as well!

Name: To Delete
Mnemonic: If 削除 is "deletion," then the verb version would be to delete.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Employ
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means employ so the verb vocab version is to employ.
ReadingMnemonic: You are going to employ more people to your business so you can make more money and eventually buy a yacht (やと). That's the dream life, it is.

Name: To Escape Something
Mnemonic: You are going to excuse yourself from the situation, and in order to do that, you have to escape from the person / thing trying to hold you there in order to avoid them.
ReadingMnemonic: In order to do that, you jump inside your man(u) car (まぬか) which is a car for a tough man(u) that needs to drive fast, just like you.

Name: To Fire Someone
Mnemonic: You are going to untie the person who is in your employ from being employed with you. They are free. This means you fired them, which is why this verb means to fire someone.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Jump
Mnemonic: Not to be confused with 跳ぶ, this word has the same meaning. The reading is different, however.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this one is は because you're laughing (HAHAHA!!) at the person who put Nair (ねる) on their legs, then only finding it to be really painful, so they have to jump around to get the pain to go away.

Name: To Leap
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means leap so the verb vocab version means to leap. It also means to jump or to bounce.
ReadingMnemonic: You go to leap and leap again. You do it so much that you start sweating, which is causing a foul odor (おど) to come from your body.

Name: To Look
Mnemonic: Add an honorable little 御 for someone to look at when you want to show respect to them. 御覧になる is the honorific form of 見る, so it still means to look, to see, or to watch, but with a more respectful tone.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Play A Stringed Instrument
Mnemonic: You'd think that this means "to bullet" but it does not. It means to play a stringed instrument. It's actually used for all stringed instruments, and all instruments with a keyboard, like pianos and electric keyboards. Just imagine taking a bullet and using it as a pick for a guitar, then using it to press down the keys of a piano and play a tune.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 引く, which is "to pull." When you play a stringed instrument, you are pulling the string in a direction to make it vibrate and create a sound. So, "to pull" and "to play a stringed instrument" share a reading. It's a bit more of a stretch for instruments with keyboards, but pianos do at least have strings...

Name: To Publish
Mnemonic: 掲載 is publication so the verb version of that is to publish or to print.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will also help to know 掲載 as well.

Name: To Refuse
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means refuse and the verb vocab version is to refuse.
ReadingMnemonic: What are you refusing? You are refusing a child, because children are all bad. You say "子 bad, 子 bad" over and over again.

Name: To Repay
Mnemonic: 払い is a "payment" and 戻す is "to return." If you return a payment, you are going to repay, to refund, or to reimburse someone for their payment.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 払い and 戻す.

Name: To Rob
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rob so the verb vocab version is to rob.
ReadingMnemonic: This reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Take Back
Mnemonic: To take and return something to yourself is to take back something. Give it back!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 取る and 戻す. Combine them to get this.

Name: Traffic Jam
Mnemonic: A bitter stagnate is when you're stagnated in traffic. It feels bitter, doesn't it? Why can't people drive faster? Why are people looking at the accident instead of driving? I'm so bitter about it! That's why this word is traffic jam and traffic congestion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Transfer
Mnemonic: Shift something and defer it somewhere else. This is a transfer or assignment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Translation Into Japanese
Mnemonic: A home country translation is a translation to your home country's language. Since this is a Japanese word, this translation would be a translation into Japanese.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Turtle Shell
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This word is made up of a single kanji, but it uses the on'yomi reading, not the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you've learned this reading already. Yay!

Name: Vanity
Mnemonic: When how much you prosper goes into your heart and just enters a void, it will rarely mean anything to you. A person who has this trait is going to have extreme vanity because he/she just needs to suck more and more prosperity into their bottomless pit of a heart. It's like a black hole. They need more and more and more so then they have to become vain.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Wall
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji!

Name: Wallpaper
Mnemonic: A wall's paper is wallpaper.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. It's what you learned with 壁 and the vocab reading of 紙, rendaku'd.

Name: Way Back
Mnemonic: If 戻る is "to return" then you return on the street you came from, you are taking the way back.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of everything. Think 戻る for the 戻り portion.

Name: Welfare
Mnemonic: You have much luck in your welfare, making you have good welfare and well being.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Abduction
Mnemonic: If someone abducts what do they do? That's abduction, kidnapping, or taking captive. This word comes up fairly frequently in Japanese newspapers, and is often used to refer to kidnappings carried out by North Korea in the seventies and eighties.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Acquisition
Mnemonic: If you seize and acquire you're making an acquisition or possession of something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Admonition
Mnemonic: A commandment is announced to you, but you should take it more as an admonition or warning. You're an adult after all, so people don't get to command you around.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Advisor
Mnemonic: The people who will review a problem are those who know more about the problems. They are the advisors.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Advocate
Mnemonic: The master chanter is the one who is the loudest. He makes sure everyone hears his chants. He's the main advocate.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: A Present
Mnemonic: Remember 贈る, which means "to give a present"? A thing that you give as a present is a present.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 贈る and 物.

Name: Artistry
Mnemonic: If everything you do is elegant you have artistry and good taste. So much elegance!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Best Regards
Mnemonic: The kanji is best regards and this can be best regards as well. It can also mean well, properly and suitably as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Best Regards
Mnemonic: A 宜しい (good, okay, all right) request is when you send your best regards to someone. This is a set phrase you say when someone is going to help you out and you're all like "thank you for your help" or "I'm counting on you" or some combination of the two. It's a word you'll see a lot to varying degrees of kanji and length.
Reading: よろしくおねがいします
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 宜しい and お願いします.

Name: Breeding
Mnemonic: Something that is overgrown and will multiply is obviously breeding and multiplying a ton.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
