Name: Bribery
Mnemonic: Presents that you give as a bribe is a form of bribery.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Capture
Mnemonic: To catch and seize is capture and seizure.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chinese Noodles
Mnemonic: You already know that 中華 means Chinese, and 麺 means noodles. Put them together and what have you got? That's right, Chinese noodles! Yum!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chorus
Mnemonic: People who join in a chant group are people who are in a chorus or choir.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 合 is pretty weird. It's a がっ instead of a ごう. Just imagine a bunch of people in a chorus singing "ga ga ga ga gaaaa!"

Name: Cold Hearted
Mnemonic: If you dilute feeling from someone, they have no feelings. They become cold hearted.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Collision
Mnemonic: When things collide and thrust into each other, you have a collision, or at least a strong impact.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Combined Use
Mnemonic: If you concurrently use one thing for multiple purposes, you're using something with a combined use. Something that is serving two purposes.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Confidential Talk
Mnemonic: Remember how 内緒 means "secret" or "confidential"? Well, that makes this is a secret talk, aka a confidential talk — like the kind often done by whispering.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi of 内緒 and kun'yomi of 話, only rendakued.

Name: Cutting Edge
Mnemonic: Something that is new and sharp (presumably because it's so new) is on the cutting edge. It's up-and-coming, the next big thing!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Detergent
Mnemonic: Wash your clothes with a dose of detergent.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Disobedience To Parents
Mnemonic: Not filial piety is when you don't listen to your parents. This is disobedience to parents.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ditch
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Drainage
Mnemonic: Emitted water is what we call drainage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Elegance
Mnemonic: Something that is superior and elegant has much elegance and grace.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Emission
Mnemonic: Things that are emitted and then exit are, well, emissions.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Empty
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of void? It's empty or vacant. Just think of what has to happen to make a void in the first place.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If everything in life seems empty and futile, even cows will be affected. Listen to them say, "Moo, nah (むな), never mind. What's the point?" Nothing makes life seem empty like a cow saying "Moo, nah."

Name: Enchanting
Mnemonic: You can guess this is an adjective by looking at the い it ends with. One of the meanings of the kanji, enchanting, is already an adjective. That's the meaning of this word, too: enchanting. What is enchanting? It's basically charming in a mysterious way.
ReadingMnemonic: So this enchanting and charming feeling is mysterious... some would say 怪しい (suspicious). It actually shares the same reading as 怪しい. They're kind of similar, too. Here's the difference: 怪しい usually has a negative feel to it whereas 妖しい generally has a positive feel. 妖しい also feels more mysterious or has a magical edge.

Name: Exclusion
Mnemonic: When you expel others, you're practicing exclusion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Exclusion
Mnemonic: If you expel or exclude something or someone, that's called exclusion. Alternatively, you could also call this removal or elimination.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Exhaust
Mnemonic: The emitted energy of some machine is exhaust. This can also refer to ventilation. Think of it as air (energy) being emitted so new, fresh air can take its place!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fairy
Mnemonic: A supernatural spirit flutters up to you. It's a fairy!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Feudal Lord
Mnemonic: Milord (you say very formally with a formal name ender). You say it very formally because this person is a lord, or more specifically, a feudal lord.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 殿 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Feudal Lords were pretty brutal back in the day. If you did something wrong he'd get to punish you. What kind of punishment? Well, he'd cut off your toe! That left most people yelling, "My toe?! NO!" (との). Imagine screaming "Toe no!" over and over as the feudal lord got closer and closer. Holding a pair of hedge clippers or something. Maybe if you yell "toe no" enough times, he'll change his mind.

Name: Filial Piety
Mnemonic: If you go towards filial piety, you are going to be doing filial piety. Do this for your parents.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Frequency
Mnemonic: The frequentness of something, measured in occurrences is measured in frequency.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Frequent
Mnemonic: Something that is frequently overgrown is something that is super frequent. It never stops attacking, never stops coming, and is honestly getting incessant in how often it overgrows. Those darn [put plant name here].
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Frequently
Mnemonic: Something that goes towards being frequent is something that is frequently happening.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Something that happens frequently is something that has really caught on. People want to do this thing frequently, because it is so chic (しき).

Name: Frequent Occurrence
Mnemonic: Something that frequently departures has much frequency and is a frequent occurrence. Oh, that? Yeah, it departures with much frequency.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fugitive
Mnemonic: Someone who has escaped death by running away is a fugitive or a runaway. I think there was a movie about that once!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Genius
Mnemonic: A person with genius and talent is a genius, or a person of exceptional talent. So smart!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Glad
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of glad? It's also glad!
ReadingMnemonic: Whenever you're really glad to be alive, you look up at the sun's rays and sing, "Ooh, rays (うれ), I'm so glad you're here!" Then your Uncle Ray comes dancing into the room and sings back, "Ooh, Ray is happy you're happy!" The sun's rays and Uncle Ray both make you really happy.

Name: Handling
Mnemonic: If 扱う is "to handle," the noun version of that is handling or treatment.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 扱う, so if you know that you'll have a good handling of this one.

Name: Honor
Mnemonic: You have a prosperity of honor, therefore you have honor.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Honor
Mnemonic: A famous honor is still an honor, but it is also a prestige to have, since you are famously honorable. So prestigious!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Inner Moat
Mnemonic: The inside ditch is the inner ditch, or, if you make it awesome enough, the inner moat. If they get through the outer moat, we have the inner one, at least!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi / vocab readings of these kanji. 内 + 堀 added into one word.

Name: Japanese Court Music
Mnemonic: It's so elegant and so comforting. This is Japanese court music, and it's what fancy court people listened to in Japan back in the day. You can also call it gagaku if you'd like.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Kagawa Prefecture
Mnemonic: The fragrance river prefecture is Kagawa Prefecture. Might help to look at the reading first.
ReadingMnemonic: This reading is made up of the kun'yomi readings for 香 and 川 (rendaku'd) and the on'yomi reading for 県. You haven't learned this reading for 香 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help: If you want to get to Kagawa Prefecture you're going to need a car (か). It's all the way over on Shikoku island, and you won't be able to cross the big bridge without a proper car!

Name: Kneecap
Mnemonic: In your knee there is a small priest named Kneecap.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for 膝 and 小, but the on'yomi reading for 僧, which gets rendaku'd from そう to ぞう, so watch out for that! You've learned all these reading before, so you should be able to read this as well.

Name: Leaping
Mnemonic: To fly and leap is leaping.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Luxuriant Growth
Mnemonic: Something that is overgrown and luxuriant must have quite the luxuriant growth. Lots and lots of growth.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Medal
Mnemonic: I praise you for what you did, so here's your prize to go along with my praise, a medal!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Medicine
Mnemonic: If you take a dose of something, you are taking a dose of medicine. Take your cough syrup, child!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same one you learned with the kanji, probably because it's attached to things usually, so it's treated like on'yomi.

Name: Medicine
Mnemonic: A medicine dose is medicine or drugs you're taking.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Memoirs
Mnemonic: You revolve to review the record of the past. These records are memoirs or reminiscences.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mentsuyu
Mnemonic: You know that 麺 means "noodles", and つゆ is another word for "soup" or "broth". Put the two together and you have the delicious mentsuyu , or noodle soup base. It's usually made of dashi, soy sauce, mirin and sugar​. Yum!
ReadingMnemonic: You learned the reading for 麺 when you learned the kanji.

Name: Monster
Mnemonic: What's supernatural and suspicious? A monster, or, if you know the Japanese term, a yokai.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mr.
Mnemonic: The kanji means Milord, and this word used to be a name ender similar to the English title Lord, but nowadays it's closer to Mr. or Ms.. It's rarely used in speaking or even written correspondence these days, but is still used in official documents, and you'll probably see it most on certificates. If in doubt, you're better off choosing the name ender 様 because it's much more widely used, and also more polite than 殿.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Do you know a Lord? Imagine it being someone named Mr. or Ms. Don (どの). If you know a Don, that's great, imagine that person. If you don't, think of a famous Don that's out there.

Name: Neighbor
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember the movie "Tonari (となり) no Totoro"? That is the Tonari.

Name: Neighbor
Mnemonic: A neighbor person is a neighbor.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Neighborhood
Mnemonic: All the near neighbors are the people who live around you and near you. They're a part of the neighborhood.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Neighboring Country
Mnemonic: A neighbor country is a neighboring country. For us, our 隣国 in America are those sneaky Canadians... always waiting to strike, I can tell...
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Neighboring House
Mnemonic: A neighbor house is a neighboring house. That house is right next to ours!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Noodles
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. Go eat some noodles to celebrate!

Name: Okinawa Prefecture
Mnemonic: Remember how 沖縄 is "Okinawa"? This is the prefecture, Okinawa Prefecture.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 沖縄 and 県 put together.

Name: Outer Moat
Mnemonic: The outside ditch is the ditch around our town that's on the outside (not the inside ditch, which is the inner moat). This is the outer moat.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the same readings from the previous vocabulary except that 堀 gets rendakued - don't forget!

Name: Oversensitivity
Mnemonic: You've surpassed what is normal alertness. You are too alert. You notice everything. This is oversensitivity.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Palace
Mnemonic: Milord's hall is a nice place. It's where a lord would live. A palace. By extension, this can also mean a sanctuary, and even a hall of fame.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Parking Lot
Mnemonic: A location where cars can be a resident is a parking lot.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these readings already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

Name: Patrol
Mnemonic: You patrol and revolve around the block to make your patrol. You're going around patrolling.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pharmacist
Mnemonic: A medicine dose expert is someone who knows exactly how much dose of each medicine you should be getting. The person who specializes in this is a pharmacist.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pilgrimage
Mnemonic: A patrol of thanks is a patrol you make to something you're thanking. Sounds religious. Sounds like a pilgrimage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pillar
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: You'll have to imagine a pillar standing tall, and made entirely of the Egyptian god Ra and hashbrowns. It is a hash-ra (はしら) pillar, made by the Egyptians who love breakfast.

Name: Police Officer
Mnemonic: Those who patrol and inspect are police officers or patrol officers.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Portable
Mnemonic: A portable belt is something so portable you can put it on your belt. It is portable. Note, this is also a very common term for a cell phone or mobile phone. You'll learn more about that in the coming levels.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Preservative
Mnemonic: A prevent rot dose is a dose of something you put on your cut or wound that prevents it from rotting (or you put it on something else to prevent it from rotting). This is an antiseptic or preservative.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Prospering
Mnemonic: If you're overgrown with prosperity you are probably really prospering.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Quick
Mnemonic: A machine alert is an alert that is timed by a machine, not by a human. It's pretty quick. It's also quick-witted. Machines can move and think so much faster than us, after all.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Reproduction
Mnemonic: Life, when it multiplies (multiply), is doing reproduction.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Residence
Mnemonic: Your roofs are spread out around your property. Put these roofs and areas all together and you have your residence or estate.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Residence
Mnemonic: You're a resident and you exist in the place you're residing in. That means you have residence.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Reward
Mnemonic: I praise you for your beauty. I'm so into your beauty, I hand you a reward... a prize, basically.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rolling Pin
Mnemonic: Grab your noodle pole and let's make some noodles. What's a noodle pole? It's a rolling pin!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. So just keep rolling.

Name: Sacrifice Fly
Mnemonic: A sacrifice hit is one you do in baseball, when you hit the ball in the air, and then the person on third tags up and scores. In baseball, this can either be a sacrifice bunt or sacrifice fly.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned the readings for both of these kanji, so you should be able to read this word already!

Name: Section
Mnemonic: Remember when you learned 房? Well it can be used as a counter for clusters of fruit. Like a section of an orange or a bunch of grapes! Yum!
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading already when you learned 房!

Name: Security Deposit
Mnemonic: Spread the gold around. First part, I want you to put in a security deposit.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sensitivity
Mnemonic: If you have an alert feeling, you are sensitive to things going on around you. That means you have a lot of sensitivity!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sharp
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of sharp? It's sharp.
ReadingMnemonic: Something that is sharp will stab someone, but they will sue you for your rude behaviors. They sue rude (するど) behaviors...

Name: Sharpness
Mnemonic: Someone on sharp alert has a sharpness about them. They are quick witted and have a strong keenness to them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sharpness
Mnemonic: Something that is sharp will benefit from its sharpness, since that's all it has, really.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Shock
Mnemonic: If you collide and attack what you're colliding into, you're going to not only cause a large shock but also crash and impact into them. Blamo!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Side Business
Mnemonic: Concurrently with my current business I have a side business. It's really a second job, actually.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Singing
Mnemonic: You're chanting and you're singing and you're having a gay ol' time. You're singing all your songs and even the chanting sounds like singing. It's so fun.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Singing
Mnemonic: You're singing and you're chanting. It's a gay ol' time. You're singing and singing and singing!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Solo
Mnemonic: An alone chant is one you do alone. It's a solo!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Spoils
Mnemonic: A seized thing is something you've seized from your victory. It's your spoils. It's your trophy!
ReadingMnemonic: Since you didn't learn the kun'yomi for 獲 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. Eh (え)? We won the game? Ehhhh?! No way! To the victor belong the spoils! Yay!

Name: State Of Enjoyment
Mnemonic: You're so glad, you get glad again. No matter what you're doing, it's undoubtedly in a state of enjoyment.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses on'yomi readings of the kanji you learned... twice! You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Stationed In Japan
Mnemonic: Something or someone resident in 日本 (Japan) is stationed in Japan.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Stationed Troops
Mnemonic: A resident detained in a location who is in the army is a member of the stationed troops at this location. They could also be the occupying troops as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tatami Room
Mnemonic: A sitting spread is a spread of tatami mats, making up the tatami room in a Japanese house.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Telephone Pole
Mnemonic: An electricity pillar is a telephone pole. All those wires and telephone wires going to and from those telephone poles.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Thin
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dilute? It's dilute. And something that's been diluted is now thin.
ReadingMnemonic: This drink is way too diluted. You sue (うす) the makers for their thin drink.

Name: To Be Diluted
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means dilute, and this is an intransitive verb, as you can guess from the まる ending. So this verb means to be diluted, to be diminished, or to become weak.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. The reading comes from 薄い, so if you know that you'll be able to read this too. If not, here's a mnemonic to help you: You don't want your drink to be diluted, so you sue (うす) anyone who dares pour you a weak drink.

Name: To Be Luxuriant
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means luxuriant and the verb vocab version is to be luxuriant or to grow thickly.
ReadingMnemonic: She gave (しげ) me a razor because my beard was starting to grow thickly... too thickly. But, I won't shave my awesome beard no matter what she gave me.

Name: To Be Transparent
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transparent and the verb vocab version is to be transparent (since usually people can't "to transparent" something).
ReadingMnemonic: To remember the reading, just think about something that is supposed to not be transparent, but is transparent after you give it to someone for a while. You're so upset that your dog, cat, plant, car, etc. is transparent that you sue the guy who was supposed to not make it transparent.

Name: To Blow
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blow so the verb vocab version is to blow.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Chant
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means chant so the verb vocab version is to chant.
ReadingMnemonic: Really, when you are going to chant, the most important thing to do is to figure out your tone (とな). If you get the tone down, the rest  comes naturally.

Name: To Combine
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means concurrently, but since you can't "to concurrently", we're going to have to come up with another word to use: "to combine" or "to double as." Since this kanji has to do with something having a dual purpose, we can say that something can combine as being another thing, or double as being another thing, which is where these words come from.
ReadingMnemonic: For example, a car (か) can double as a place to sleep at night when not enough people become members of WaniKani.

Name: To Decline
Mnemonic: If 遠慮 is "decline" or "restrain" then the verb vocab version is to decline or to restrain.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the reading comes from 遠慮.

Name: To Engage In
Mnemonic: Somehow the kanji portable turns into the verb to engage in or to participate or to take part in. I suppose if you are portable, you're able to engage in all kinds of things, since you can move all over the place, participating everywhere you can (rather than being not portable and being stuck in one place).
ReadingMnemonic: You've been asked to engage in various activities, so you bring your Taz saw (たずさ), a Tasmanian-made saw. You never know what kind of carpentry or lumberjacking you'll be asked to take part in, and Taz saws are known for their versatility.

Name: To Evacuate
Mnemonic: If you know that 避難 is "evacuation" then you know that this is the verb form of that: to evacuate.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will also help to know the reading of the word 避難.

Name: To Gallop
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gallop and the verb vocab version is to gallop.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Go Around
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means patrol, but what do you do when you patrol? You go around, which is to go around.
ReadingMnemonic: You're going around patrolling to protect the house of Meg (めぐ) Ryan. Just imagine Meg Ryan's house, and you walking around it. Imagine Meg Ryan looking out at you.

Name: To Go Out Into The World
Meaning: To Go Out Into The World
To Be Released To The Public
Mnemonic: Here we have world with the particle に, following by the verb 出る (to go out). Put that together and this means to go out into the world, to be published or to be released to the public in some way or another. Once it's out there in the world, there's even a chance for it to become renowned.
ReadingMnemonic: This uses kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you should already know by now, so I think you're good to go!

Name: To Hang
Mnemonic: If something is suspended, it is going to hang or to depend on your actions. We need you to make sure it goes right! Your actions are what we're suspended on!
ReadingMnemonic: We're depending on you to help us to get this car (か), okay?

Name: To Lean Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lean and the verb vocab version means to lean something.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading already with 傾く, so remember that and you'll know this one too!

Name: To Look Back On Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means review. What do you do when you review something? You look back on it. Meaning to look back on something or to reflect on something. This can also mean to be attentive to someone, for example your family.
ReadingMnemonic: For the reading, think about another word that is similar: 帰る. With 帰る you are returning to somewhere. With this word, you're returning to look back on something. They share the same first part reading, so you should take advantage of that. 帰る → かえり.

Name: To Loosen
Mnemonic: 緩む is "to loosen," but has to do with loosening on its own. This word is when you loosen or relax something, meaning to loosen or to relax.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 緩む, so you can use that!

Name: To Manage
Mnemonic: To take and then handle means you're taking it and handling it, causing you to manage or to handle something. You got it because you took it.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 取る and 扱う.

Name: To Miss
Mnemonic: You already learned that 逃げる means "to escape," and this verb is when you let something escape, or slip through your fingers. So this means to miss or to lose a good chance, or to let go of a good opportunity.
ReadingMnemonic: Here's a mnemonic to remember the kun'yomi for this word: You missed a huge opportunity. Why? Because there was no gas (のが) in your car! Think about what opportunity you missed out on because you forgot to fill up your car.

Name: To Multiply
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means multiply and the verb vocab version means to multiply or to increase.
ReadingMnemonic: What is multiplying? Your use of the word "fu" (ふ) for when you laugh. You used to say just "ha ha ha" like everyone else. Now the occurrences of you saying fufufu is really multiplying. You might also notice that this is similar to the word 増える, which means "to increase." This has a similar meaning and the same reading, use that to your advantage!

Name: To Praise
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means title, so just think about when someone gives you an awesome title. They are doing this to praise or to give praise to you.
ReadingMnemonic: After they go to praise you, you're all like "I don't need praise! Ta-ta (たた)! I'm outa here."

Name: To Praise
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means praise and the verb vocab version is to praise.
ReadingMnemonic: If you are going to praise this guy in front of you, it would have to be for his amazing hoe-using (ほ) abilities. Look at him go with that hoe.

Name: To Repeat
Mnemonic: 繰る is "to spin" (so spinning) and 返す is "to return" (so returning). Put them together and you have something that's spinning and returning to the same spot over and over. Something that does that is repeating itself, making this to repeat or to repeat over and over.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 繰る and 返す. Combine them together to get the reading.

Name: To Select
Mnemonic: 選択 is "selection" or "choice." If you do the verb version of this, you are going to select or to choose.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading also comes from 選択.

Name: To Spread Out
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means spread and the verb vocab version is to spread out or to lay out.
ReadingMnemonic: What is getting spread out? Sheep (し)! Someone's been hunting sheep, because you're looking at a bunch of empty (dead) sheep bodies spread out on the ground.

Name: To Warn
Mnemonic: I say my commandment in order to warn and to caution the people not to do bad things.
ReadingMnemonic: The first commandment I say to warn them of not doing bad things is I mash (いまし) my own potatoes. Nobody else mashes my potatoes. Got it?

Name: Transparent
Mnemonic: Something that is transparent and bright so that you can see through it is transparent.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Vigilance
Mnemonic: My warning commandment is there to make sure you take precaution and show vigilance when it comes to that precaution. It's only a warning commandment, though, which is why it has to do with prevention and precaution.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Warning
Mnemonic: My instruction is my commandment. You must do what I say in my instructions/commandments. This is my warning. This is my admonition.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Weakness
Mnemonic: Something is diluted to the point of weakness. It has much weakness and feebleness.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: With All One's Might
Mnemonic: You have only one life so do everything with lots of eagerness (懸命). Do everything with all one's might. Go all out.
ReadingMnemonic: Everything except the 生 uses the readings you learned with the kanji, and you learned this reading of 生 when you learned 一生. You've really been going all out to learn these readings!

Name: Your Wife
Mnemonic: Your interior formal name ender (person) is the person who's waiting internal, out of the picture (remember, kanji was made forever ago and is pretty sexist). This person is your wife.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

Name: Abandonment
Mnemonic: You release and abandon something. This is abandonment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Aircraft Carrier
Mnemonic: An aviation (航空) mother warship is a warship that is like mother to all the aviation things (the airplanes). They come home to their mother warship, which is an aircraft carrier.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: All Night
Mnemonic: Penetrate the night and go on through to the morning. You were up all night and had a sleepless night aka all nighter.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Amazing
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of amazing? It's also amazing! Or terrible. This word can be both good and bad, it really depends on the context, because what is amazing is usually also a little awful. You know?
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The most amazing and terrible thing you've ever seen is Suit Godzilla (すご). Godzilla was wearing a nice suit (amazing!) but also destroying your home, your friends, and your family (terrible!).

Name: A Mine
Mnemonic: A mineral mountain is one that you should build a mine in, to get all those minerals.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Atomic Bomb
Mnemonic: 原 is often tied to atomic things, as atoms are the origin of all things. If an atom explodes, you have yourself an atomic bomb.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Back Of One's Hand
Mnemonic: Your hand's turtle shell is the back of it (see you can make it shaped like a turtle shell if you try hard!). That's why this is the back of one's hand.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the respective vocab readings of 手 and 甲.

Name: Basis
Mnemonic: The root that this is based on is the basis and grounds for my argument. Look, it goes all the way down to the root problem!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Battleship
Mnemonic: An army warship is a battleship. Did you sink it? Oh oh! You sunk my 軍艦!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bee
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Camouflage
Mnemonic: Some fake attire doesn't make you look fake, it makes you disappear. This fake attire is fake surroundings. So, if you're in a shrub, it's shrub attire. If you're in the darkness, it's dark attire. This is camouflage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Capability
Mnemonic: Remember how 甲斐 can mean "worth"? If worth is in your nature, you're probably a person of some capability. You're worth knowing and people appreciate your dependability.
ReadingMnemonic: This word combines the word 甲斐 (which you've already learned) with the secondary on'yomi reading for 性. You haven't learned this reading of 性 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help: Who embodies capability and dependability? The Shogun (しょう), of course! He feeds his entire clan and army, makes battle plans, and rules a nation — all without breaking a sweat. A true leader, dependable and strong, the Shogun gets a lot of love for his 甲斐性.

Name: Carbon
Mnemonic: Things of the charcoal element are made up of much carbon. Just look deep into the charcoal to see all the carbon in there.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ceremony
Mnemonic: A ceremony ceremony is a ceremony.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Charcoal
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: I'm gonna put charcoal in your mouth. Whatchoo gonna do? Sue me (すみ)?

Name: Clenched Fist
Mnemonic: A fist that's like a bone (hard) is a fist that's clenched and ready to punch, making this a clenched fist or knuckles, if you want to get even bonier about it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. But 拳 doesn't use the one you learned, it uses げん instead. Just imagine someone clenching their fist at you. You gulp and say げん instead of けん out of fear.

Name: Coal
Mnemonic: A stone charcoal is charcoal shaped like a little stone. Or, maybe it's often found in stone. That's coal.
ReadingMnemonic: This uses the on'yomi for both kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Coal Mine
Mnemonic: Charcoal mineral has been found! Time to dig a coal mine or coal pit to retrieve it!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Congratulatory Gift
Mnemonic: To celebrate a ceremony, you offer a congratulatory gift.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember that 祝 is read as しゅう for this one and you'll be fine.

Name: Consideration
Mnemonic: If you dispatch what you think to the other person, you're thinking about them, and you're being nice. You're showing consideration, sympathy, and compassion for the other person.
ReadingMnemonic: One reading comes from 思う, so that's all good. 遣り has a weird alternate reading, though (やり). To remember it, just think about how much consideration you're always showing. You're always like "Yah (や), yah, no, I totally understand. SOOO sad." /end sympathy/

Name: Disposal
Mnemonic: It's obsolete, so you’re going to abandon it. This is the act of disposal. Whatever it is, you’re disposing of or scrapping it because it’s no longer needed.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Diving
Mnemonic: To conceal yourself in water, you'd better start diving and get under the water where it can conceal you!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Employer
Mnemonic: An employment (雇用) someone is someone who gives you employment, aka an employer.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Extremely Gruesome
Mnemonic: Something really terrible causing mass extinction will be extremely gruesome. It will also probably be extremely violent, so don't look.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

Name: Fake
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: It turns out she is a fake. Your niece (にせ) was a robot this whole time, just pretending to be your niece. What is wrong with this world, where your niece can be an imitation niece. A 偽niece, if you will.

Name: Field
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. Note when you stick this onto a type of crop to mean a ____ field, this gets rendaku'd to ばたけ.

Name: Fields
Mnemonic: We're talking about both a rice paddy and the other fields where farmers grow crops. So, this means fields, or more precisely rice and crop fields. It's all about farmland.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from what you learned with the kanji. 畑 uses the shorter はた reading that you learned.

Name: Fight
Mnemonic: When things get noisy and rowdy there's a good chance things will end in a fight.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Firefly
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Fist
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You make a fist. Why? Because she stole your corn on the cob. "Cob! She (こぶし) stole my cob!"

Name: Forgery
Mnemonic: Let's create a fake. This fake we've created? It's a forgery.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fragment
Mnemonic: Tear off a one-sided piece. It's only one part, not all the parts. It's a fragment.
ReadingMnemonic: The 破 reading is the one you learned, the 片 reading isn't one you've learned. Just think about how you're tearing off pieces of a hen (へん), one fragment at a time. Here little chicken, I want another feather from you please. *CAW*

Name: Fruit Tree
Mnemonic: A fruit wood is what a fruit grows on (the wood of a fruit is a tree, dummy). That makes this word a fruit tree.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Funeral
Mnemonic: A burial ceremony is known as a funeral.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Gifu Prefecture
Mnemonic: You've seen how 岐阜 is "Gifu." Now make it a prefecture to make Gifu prefecture.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hometown
Mnemonic: By circumstance this is your hometown. Not much to say other than it's your hometown and birthplace.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. While こきょう is the more common reading for this word, it can also be read as ふるさと, which is a native Japanese word that originally didn't have kanji. ふるさと is also common in hiragana.

Name: Hometown
Mnemonic: Your hometown home village is the one that's your hometown. It's also your birthplace, where you were born.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 郷 is the one you learned, but the reading for 里 isn't the one you learned. To remember this reading, just think about how your birthplace is the place you were reared (り), and you really (り) miss the place.

Name: Honey
Mnemonic: A bee's honey is its honey, honey.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

Name: Honey
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That's honey, baby!

Name: Hong Kong
Mnemonic: The fragrance harbor, perhaps this is where the perfumes came from back in the day. This place is Hong Kong.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading doesn't follow any of the rules you might expect. Try to use the meaning mnemonic to get the meaning, then know that it sounds something similar to the reading. "Hon(g) Kon(g)" goes to ほんこん. Almost the same, right?

Name: Humanity
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

Name: Humanity And Justice
Mnemonic: Humanity and righteousness. This is your duty. This is humanity and justice.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Humble
Mnemonic: If you have modesty and are humble, then you are probably humble and have humility (and have modesty too, I guess).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Inevitable
Mnemonic: If it's certain that you will attain it, then it is inevitable. It is a foregone conclusion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Infringement
Mnemonic: You invaded and damaged me. You are doing infringement on my territory. This is a violation of me.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Intrusion
Mnemonic: If you invade and enter that is an intrusion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Invasion
Mnemonic: If you invade with aggression that's an invasion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Iron Ore
Mnemonic: The iron mineral is iron ore.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Jumping
Mnemonic: If 躍る is "to leap" or "to jump," then this noun version will be jumping or leaping.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 躍る.

Name: Kitchen Knife
Mnemonic: Something you have to wrap up when you go into the street is your kitchen knife. Why would you wrap up your kitchen knife? Well, both to keep it from getting damaged and to keep it from accidentally cutting people, obviously.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Liar
Mnemonic: If lies puke (吐く) out of your mouth, you're a liar.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of the kun'yomi readings, one of which you haven't seen yet. You'll usually see this word without the 吐 kanji, as in 嘘つき, but for now let's learn its kanji reading! You can't just tell one lie, it always turns into two (つ). Kind of like a chip or pretzel, you can't just have one. With lies, you have to open your mouth for two more. And then two more.... and... well you get it.

Name: Lie
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. A lie is a lie!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned with reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

Name: Loyalty
Mnemonic: I have sincerity about my loyalty. That shows loyalty, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Manners
Mnemonic: The thanks ceremony is the dance you do in life when it comes to your manners and courtesy to others. Also means etiquette.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Measures
Mnemonic: Set aside and put what you'll need to get the job done over there. These are the measures and steps we're taking to make sure things get done properly.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mineral
Mnemonic: A mineral thing is a mineral.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mining Industry
Mnemonic: The mineral business is the mining industry.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Naval Fleet
Mnemonic: A warship squad is a naval fleet or an armada.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Noisy
Mnemonic: You can guess this is an adjective from the い at the end. The meaning for the kanji is noisy and picky, so the adjective version is also noisy and picky.
ReadingMnemonic: My noisy mom has earned the nickname yak-a-Ma (やかま). "Yakka yakka yakka," is what my mom says about my life choices.

Name: Ore
Mnemonic: A mineral stone is an ore / mineral.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of the kanji, you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Physical Evidence
Mnemonic: The evidence is based on something. What is it based on? This physical evidence. Ha ha! Guilty!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember that 拠 is using the こ reading you learned, not the きょ one. Just remember that you can never trust the word of a 子 (こ), so you always require them to provide physical evidence.

Name: Position
Mnemonic: Something based on points has a ranking, meaning you'll know where your position or location is, compared to everyone else.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rapids
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, actually!

Name: Reason For Living
Mnemonic: You know that 甲斐 is "effect" or "worth." So, the "worth for being alive" is your reason for living. It gives life worth. It's your reason for living.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 甲斐 and 生き, so if you know those you may have a reason for living, or at least a reason for doing your kanji study.

Name: Reluctantly
Mnemonic: If you bite into something bitter (twice!) you'll take your next bite reluctantly. Because who would want that much of something bitter? Not you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is the kun'yomi reading twice. You learned this reading when you learned 渋い. If you remember that, you know this too!

Name: Restroom
Mnemonic: You know 手洗い, right? This is like that, but way more polite sounding. The meaning is still the same though: restroom, bathroom, toilet.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for the 御 is お, the rest is てあらい, even though the い isn't showing on the end. It gets pushed into the 洗い.

Name: Revolver
Mnemonic: A fist gun is a small fistish sized gun that has some punch (because, you know, fist!). The gun I'm describing is a revolver, or a handgun.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ruins
Mnemonic: Obsolete ruins are places that are abandoned because nobody can run them anymore (due to being obsolete, or due to not having money, or due to whatever else). These things are ruins or abandoned buildings. People like to explore these, a lot.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Seto
Mnemonic: The rapids door is actually Seto, which is the name of a few different places in Japan. One of those places is where the famous earthenware Seto ware comes from 🍶
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Shallows
Mnemonic: The high rapids are the shallows. How does that make sense?! I guess this means geographically high. So higher up the river, near the source, the water tends to be pretty shallow.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 高い and the reading you learned for 瀬.

Name: Shibuya
Mnemonic: The bitter valley is a place known as Shibuya. This is a very famous area in Tokyo. Very busy too.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 渋 comes from 渋い. The reading for 谷 is one that shows up mostly in place names and surnames, so maybe you haven't seen it yet. To remember it, just imagine someone asking you if Shibuya is cool. Your answer of course is "yah" (や).

Name: Shochu
Mnemonic: Baked hard liquor is slightly higher in alcohol content. This is shochu, which I'm guessing is heated in some way during its production.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 焼 and 酎 are the on'yomi readings, but you didn't learn the reading for 焼 yet. That's okay, because if you know the (also English) word Shochu, you'll be able to remember the reading for this one as well too.

Name: Siege
Mnemonic: Wrap and surround them. We are going to siege the enemy. This is encirclement around their base!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sincere
Mnemonic: You have sincerity and you have truth. You are so sincere and honest and faithful, good friend.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sincerity
Mnemonic: The idea of sincerity is sincerity. It's also to have good faith in others.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sincerity
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Sincerity and truth are so important to me that I always keep them inside my coat (まこと). That's where I keep everything that's dearest to me, and what could be more important that sincerity and truth? Where do you keep sincerity and truth? I bet your answer is "my coat" too.

Name: Social Welfare
Mnemonic: 福祉 is welfare, 社会 is society. So, a society's welfare is social welfare.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sorry
Mnemonic: Remember 御免? This is a polite way to say it. It means sorry and I beg your pardon.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 御免. The addition is all kana.

Name: Subconscious
Mnemonic: If 意識 is consciously, then what exists concealed in your mind is your subconscious.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Submarine
Mnemonic: A conceal in the water warship is a submarine.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Summer Solstice
Mnemonic: If you have attained summer, that must mean you finished out with the previous season and are going into summer. This is the summer solstice.
ReadingMnemonic: You didn't learn this reading of 夏 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help: Just think about how cute little geckos (げ) start to come out into the open during the summer solstice. It's too cold for them to be out in the open before that, so if you look outside at the right time, you'll see geckos popping out of the ground all over the place!

Name: Supremacy
Mnemonic: If you attain above it means you're up above everyone, and you're looking down on them. You have supremacy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Swift Currents
Mnemonic: A quick rapids is going to have swift currents.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 早い and the reading you learned for 瀬.

Name: Thoroughness
Mnemonic: Penetrate to the bottom. ALL the way to the bottom. Don't stop half way. This is thoroughness. This is completeness.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 底 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Thoroughness is important when you're making tater (てい) tots. Each tater has to be cut carefully into little pieces then smashed back together again. Don't even get me started on the completeness I feel when I finish and eat them. Mm.

Name: Tiger
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Abstain
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means abstain and the verb vocab version is to abstain as well!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, good for you!

Name: To Arrive At
Mnemonic: The kanji means attain but the meaning of this verb is to arrive at. I suppose that's because if you attain something like enlightenment, you also arrive at that enlightenment as well. Thus, to arrive at.
ReadingMnemonic: What’s the key to arrive at enlightenment? Being an avid eater (いた)! Being an eater of all things delicious will truly let your body and mind arrive at new levels. Give it a shot. Become an eater.

Name: To Be Based On
Mnemonic: The kanji means based on, and the verb means to be based on.
ReadingMnemonic: From now on, everything is going to be based on your yo-yo (よ) skills. You want a raise at work? It's going to depend on your yo-yo performance. Your partner left you? Has to be due to your yo-yoing failures. Better get used to this new yo-yo meritocracy we're living in!

Name: To Bow
Mnemonic: The quit ceremony is when you quit and are ready to go somewhere, so you bow and then get going. That's why this verb is to bow.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Charge A Battery
Mnemonic: If 充電 is a recharge then the verb version is going to be to recharge or to charge a battery.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 充電.

Name: To Devote Oneself
Mnemonic: If you do penetrate, sure, you can to penetrate. But, if you penetrate something you really get into it, like, you are going to devote oneself.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the one you learned with the kanji. Look out for the shortening on this one.

Name: To Flock
Mnemonic: Remember how 群れ is a flock? This is the verb version, and means to flock or to crowd together with a bunch of other people.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 群れ, so if you know that you can flock together the two memories in your brain.

Name: To Inquire
Mnemonic: The kanji means inquire, and the verb version means the same — to inquire. Depending on the context it can also mean to hear or to visit. Basically it's a humble word for any of these verbs. It's often used in a professional context.
ReadingMnemonic: Excuse me, I'd like to inquire about Chairman Kaga. Ooh! Kaga (うかが). How exciting! You're asking questions about Chairman Kaga, the ruler over the Iron Chef kingdom.

Name: To Invade
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means invade and the verb vocab version means to invade as well!
ReadingMnemonic: I'm going to invade your country, okay (おか)? Sorry about that, but everything will be okay when I'm done.

Name: To Lie
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fake and the verb vocab version is similar, it means to lie or to cheat or to deceive.
ReadingMnemonic: Someone tries to lie to you. You can't believe it. It's what (いつわ)??? You can't believe it.

Name: To Lurk
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conceal, so if you conceal yourself and walk around you are going to lurk or you are going to lie dormant.
ReadingMnemonic: He so (ひそ) hidden. Where you at?

Name: To Return To One's Hometown
Mnemonic: If you return to the hometown you are going to return to one's hometown.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 帰 is the on'yomi reading, which you haven't learned. Just think about how when you return to your hometown, you're going to need a key (き) to get into your old home, which you haven't been to in a long time.

Name: To Wrap
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wrap so the verb vocab version is to wrap.
ReadingMnemonic: You never wrap things once, you always wrap them twice. And then you double that. It's a two two (つつ) wrapping technique. つつむ is the reading we want you to focus on, but it's good to know that 包む can be read as くるむ as well. くるむ is used when you wrap something up carefully and protectively, like a baby in a blanket. つつむ on the other hand, has broader use and is commonly used for wrapping things like presents.

Name: Tree Bark
Mnemonic: A wood skin is tree bark. It's the wooden skin around trees.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tree Planting
Mnemonic: If you plant wood you are doing tree planting, since only trees are made of wood.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Warship
Mnemonic: A warship ship is a warship.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Weak
Mnemonic: You have yourself a void of weakness. This means you are weak and feeble.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Wheat Field
Mnemonic: A wheat field is a wheat field or barley field
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings, but they're also the readings you learned with the kanji. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Winter Solstice
Mnemonic: If you are about to attain winter, then it's the winter solstice. Happy winter, everyone!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 冬 is the on'yomi reading, and one you haven't learned before. You're going to want to think about how you are celebrating the winter solstice in one particular place, that place being とうきょう. See the Tokyo landmarks around you, think that you are there on the winter solstice, and also think about the things you are doing to celebrate, here in Tokyo. Also, watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Withdrawal
Mnemonic: A withdrawal is something you do to remove something from the past. It is a withdrawal or removal of what you did or submitted before.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Look out for the shortened てつ.

Name: Withdrawal
Mnemonic: If you do a withdrawal of something it's like you're revolving back to how things originally were. This is a withdrawal or repeal. It's taking back something you said previously.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Look out for the shortened てつ.

Name: Withdrawal Of Troops
Mnemonic: A withdrawal of soldiers is a withdrawal of troops.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Look out for the shortened てっ spot.

Name: Wording
Mnemonic: You set aside these words specifically so you could get the wording right. Wording is important sometimes, like when you're trying to communicate something sensitive, or when you're writing a poem. Sometimes only certain words will do.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Worth Doing
Mnemonic: The やり part is from やる which is "to do." So, if the effect (甲斐) is good to do, then it is worth doing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: A Challenge
Mnemonic: A challenge for war? I accept this challenge. A challenge is always worth accepting!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: All People
Mnemonic: If we're talking about ten thousand persons, then we might as well be talking about all people and everybody, because that's a lot of people, you know?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 万 and 人 both have two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to use: All people have been banned from Nintendo (ばんにん). Apparently they're working on something super secret, so now everybody is banned. What could it be?!

Name: All Together
Mnemonic: Fasten everything into one. All together in one batch or lump.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortened いち.

Name: Analysis
Mnemonic: If you untie the analysis, you are really just doing analysis to the analysis, if you catch my drift.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Analysis
Mnemonic: You divide things to then do analysis on them. We can just call this analysis or analyzing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Arc
Mnemonic: A round arc is, well, the shape of an arc. It has that round shape to it, you know?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Arrival
Mnemonic: At the arrival time you will arrive. This is your arrival.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Axis
Mnemonic: The hinge axis of something is the axis or pivot where things hinge.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Axis
Mnemonic: The middle of the axis is where the axis is, of course, but it's also where the pivot is too.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Axis
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Binoculars
Mnemonic: A pair of eyeball mirrors - that's binoculars. Binoculars have mirrors in them to allow you to see through the pair of eye holes, which is how this word makes sense.
ReadingMnemonic: The 鏡 part uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn. To remember this, just think about how when you look down binoculars, you see something strange (like a strange reading for 鏡). That strange thing you see through these fantastic binoculars is... tomorrow. Your binoculars are so strong that you can already see tomorrow, today (きょう)!

Name: Blame
Mnemonic: I'm going to twist this bullet and turn it around on you. You're the one I'm going to blame, which is why my blame bullet is twisted back at you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Both Parties
Mnemonic: You've got a pair of directions, so this is something that concerns both parties or both sides. Things are going in two directions, not just one!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Center
Mnemonic: The middle hinge is the center pivot point.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Clothing
Mnemonic: Clothes and attire makes this clothing at its core, but these days, it often refers to special costumes or outfits.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. While you've learned these for both of the kanji, 装 actually uses one you haven't learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know whose wardrobe was definitely full of special clothing, costumes and outfits? The shogun's (しょう)! Know all those old-timey looking paintings of shoguns in their regal attire? Just think of that when you have to remember this reading for 装!

Name: Communications Network
Mnemonic: When you pass through, you find out what everyone believes via a great net connecting everyone. What is this net? It's a communication network! When you think about it, things like telephone networks or the internet are really just big invisible nets that allow beliefs and information to pass through from one person to another.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Complication
Mnemonic: Distract me with a twist in what we're doing. Just imagine you're working on something. Then, you get distracted by a twist in whatever it is that you're working on. This little twist doesn't destroy everything, but it does cause a complication and confusion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Conquest
Mnemonic: Time to overcome the clothes of our enemies. They all wear the same kind of clothes (let's say blue clothes) so we know that if we overcome the blue coated people, we will have won. It will be a conquest!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Demand
Mnemonic: You need something so you request it. But, since it's such a strong need, it's not really a request, it's more of a demand.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Detailed
Mnemonic: If you're overcome with brightness, you'll be able to see all the little fine detailed things.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Disobedient Child
Mnemonic: Remember how 不孝 is "disobedience to parents"? Well, someone who shows disobedience to parents is a disobedient child or an unfilial child.
ReadingMnemonic: 不孝 is a reading you should know already. Add the もの reading for 者 and you have yourself a reading. Now go be obedient to your parents and keep studying your kanji.

Name: Dumping
Mnemonic: When you throw out something and abandon it, you are essentially dumping it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi for 投 when you learned 投資 a long time ago.

Name: Effortless
Mnemonic: Something that is round and slippery just moves around with no trouble at all. It is so effortless in how it slides around. It is also super smooth.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Emotional Turmoil
Mnemonic: When your heart moves then shakes, you’re in a state of emotional turmoil or unrest.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Example
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned as well!

Name: Excavation
Mnemonic: Let's departure on our digging up of this site. It is more than just digging, we're going somewhere and learning new things with this dig. This is an excavation!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the 発 getting shortened.

Name: Exemplification
Mnemonic: An imitation of an example is the exemplification of something. It is also a model of the example of what you're making.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Extent
Mnemonic: Let's take a look at this example and surround it. This example shows the extent or scope of what we're doing, and the line that surrounds it shows how far that scope goes.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Filial Piety
Mnemonic: You know how 孝行 is "filial piety," right? Well, this is basically the same thing. You're just showing said filial piety to your parents, which, of course, is what filial piety means. That makes this word mean filial piety.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 孝行 plus the kun'yomi of 親. Put them together and you'll become a good filial child.

Name: Focal Point
Mnemonic: The char point is the part you're looking at so hard it burns a little hole in it. Just imagine yourself looking at a single point so hard that it begins to smolder. This is the focal point or the focus.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: For A Little While
Mnemonic: Please temporarily wait. Please wait for a little while. In a little while something will happen, but for a moment you'll have to sit still.
