ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You've been waiting for a little while and nothing has happened yet so you start singing a sheep ballad (しばら). This ballad helps you sleep by counting sheep. If you manage to doze off for a moment, time will surely pass faster, and then something might happen!

Name: Fried Rice
Mnemonic: What's your favorite fry meal? Surely it's fried rice, aka chahan! Who doesn't love fried rice?
ReadingMnemonic: You know the reading for 飯, but 炒 uses an exceptional reading that you didn't learn. Here's a mnemonic to help you: Do you know what would bring your fried rice to the next level? Some charcoal (ちゃー)! Next time, just add a little charcoal to your fried rice, and it'll taste so much better. Trust me on this one.

Name: Funeral Hall
Mnemonic: A purification location is the place where you perform purification on people. Who needs the most purification? The dead. Where do you purify them? In a funeral hall.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi for 場 when you learned 入場 ages ago.

Name: Garbage Bag
Mnemonic: A garbage (ゴミ) sack is a garbage sack or garbage bag.
ReadingMnemonic: The word for sack (ふくろ) is rendaku'd, so be careful of that.

Name: Grip
Mnemonic: Your grip power is your grip, or more specifically your grip strength or handgrip.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Handshake
Mnemonic: A grip with your hand (onto another hand) is a handshake.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. With 手 just think back to other vocab words that use the on'yomi reading.

Name: Hanging Scroll
Mnemonic: It hangs on an axis point. The axis opens up, and reveals a hanging scroll. This might take a little extra imagination, but I believe in you.
ReadingMnemonic: For 掛 you'll want to think back to the word 掛ける, then shorten it and shove it into the kanji half way (the かけ part at least). For 軸 that's the reading you learned with the kanji, so at least you have that to work off of.

Name: Hepatitis
Mnemonic: If you have the ol' liver flame then you probably have hepatitis. AUGH! MY LIVER IS ON FIRE.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Insecticide
Mnemonic: What kills insects with one dose? That's an insecticide or a pesticide.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lack Of Filial Piety
Mnemonic: You know that 不孝 means "disobedience to parents. So, if you add parents to it, it just means the same thing. Just a longer version of the word, basically. This means lack of filial piety or disobedience to parents.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 不孝 is the one you learned. Then, add 親's reading (vocab) to it.

Name: Lagoon
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Lawn
Mnemonic: The lawn grass is the lawn or the turf.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings, which you learned already!

Name: Lawn
Mnemonic: Your lawn of life is just your lawn. Of course it's alive, otherwise it wouldn't be a very good lawn.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 芝 is the one you learned with the kanji. The reading for 生 is one you haven't seen before (exception). It's ふ, and you can remember it by thinking how you were such a fool (ふ) for putting all that poison on it. Now it's dying, and now it's becoming less of a lawn.

Name: Lawn
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Liver
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Though, it also means chutzpah or courage (besides just being liver). Maybe your liver is where your courage is.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Your liver isn't doing great. You have cancer in your liver, so now they're giving you chemo (きも) to help get rid of that cancer.

Name: Liver
Mnemonic: The liver internal organ is your liver.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lodging
Mnemonic: A lodge where you will stay overnight is lodging. It is where you will stay the night.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Loss
Mnemonic: You are mourning your fault. Because of your fault, you have gotten a loss and forfeit.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mochi
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. Mochi is mochi.
ReadingMnemonic: If you know the meaning, you should be able to read this too. After all, mochi is mochi (もち)!

Name: Mourning
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What's the first two letters of the word mourning? It's mo (も). You can use that to remember.

Name: Mystery Bag
Mnemonic: The luck sack is a mystery bag. These are bags that are sold during the New Year's holiday. They contain various goods that are sold for a certain price. You don't know what's in them, but you know the minimum value of it at least. These are known as mystery sacks as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 福 and 袋, put together. Also, watch out for the rendaku.

Name: National Character

ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of both kanji. 国 is くに and 柄 is the reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: Net
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When it comes to nets, you gotta go talk to Amy (あみ) if you want a good one. Only Amy makes good nets.

Name: One Night's Stay
Mnemonic: One overnight is a one night's stay.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortened 一 and the rendaku in this one.

Name: Opacity
Mnemonic: You know that 透明 is "transparency" or "transparent" - so, if something is not transparent, then it is opaque, making this word opacity.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Parentheses
Mnemonic: The fasten arcs are arcs that go around something to fasten these things all together. What are these things? They are (parentheses) and [brackets].
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, watch out from the shortening.

Name: Pattern

Name: Personal Character

ReadingMnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi readings, combined. For 人 you'll just have to remember this. With 柄 that's the reading you learned anyways, so that makes things easier. Just keep it consistent!

Name: Philosophy
Mnemonic: The philosophy study is the study of philosophy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Portable Phone

This is basically just the longer version of simply saying 携帯, making this a portable phone or cell phone or mobile phone. It's sort of like the difference between saying "my cell" and "my cell phone," you dig?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the readings of 携帯 and 電話 for this one.

Name: Provocation
Mnemonic: My challenge has made a departure and is being sent to the enemy. This challenge that I'm sending is a provocation to see if they'll take me up on my challenge.

The other meaning of the first kanji actually makes more sense here though, because you pull the dough to stretch it when you make ramen noodles. Choose whichever meaning helps you remember it best!

Name: Rapid Progress
Mnemonic: When you leap and advance, you make rapid progress and great advancement.

Name: Sack
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Name: Sacrifice Fly

Name: Small Build

Name: Solid

ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Somen

Name: State Of The Art

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Study
Mnemonic: I write for purification. I do this purification writing in my study and den.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tentative
Mnemonic: Temporarily determine something. That makes it tentative and temporary.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tidal Flat
Mnemonic: A dry lagoon is a tidal flat.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 干 is an exceptional one. Just think to why the lagoon is dry. It's because of the heat (ひ) of the sun. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: To Be Burned
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means char, but the verb version is to be burned or to get burned. You're not doing the burning, of course, but you're getting burned (owch!).
ReadingMnemonic: The times where you were burned were mostly when you were a 子 (こ). That's because kids aren't good at working with hot things.

Name: To Begin To Blow
Mnemonic: If 吹く is "to blow" and 出す is "to remove," then you are removing your blowing. You need to begin to blow to do that!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 吹く and 出す.

Name: To Be Stormy
Mnemonic: The kanji is wild and the verb is to be stormy or to be rough. If something is wild, like a storm or something, then it will be stormy and rough, after all.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Be Transparent
Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 透ける and 通る. Something that is transparent enough for things (like light) to pass through it is still going to be transparent, aka to be see-through.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Be Well Pickled
Mnemonic: You already learned that 漬ける means "to pickle something." When it becomes 漬かる, it means the food has reached a state where the pickling or marinating process is complete, and it's ready to eat. So this word means to be well pickled or to be well marinated.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned 漬ける, so you should be able to read this one too.

Name: To Blow Away
Mnemonic: You know that 吹く is "to blow" and that 飛ばす is "To let fly." So, if you use your blowing to let something fly, you are going to blow away it.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 吹く and 飛ばす, put together.

Name: To Blow In
Mnemonic: You know that 吹く is "to blow" and the kanji 込 means into. So this word means to blow in or to breathe into, and it can be used both transitively and intransitively.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the word 吹く and the kanji 込む.

Name: To Challenge Someone
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with a う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means challenge, and the verb form means to challenge someone or to take on something difficult.
ReadingMnemonic: I don't (いど) just challenge anyone, but when I challenge someone, it's for real. My challenging reflexes come from my Id (いど), after all.

Name: To Deep Fry
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hoist. But most commonly (and most importantly), this word means to deep fry. I guess you can think of it as hoisting that delicious deep-fried food out of the oil.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember the other "to raise" vocabs? They are all あげる as well. For example, 上げる is あげる and 挙げる is あげる as well.

Name: To Dig
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dig and the verb vocab version is to dig.
ReadingMnemonic: If you are going to dig you are going to end up making a hole (ほ).

Name: To Dilute
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dilute and the verb vocab version means to dilute or to water down.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 薄い, so if you know that you'll be able to read this too.

Name: To Divert
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means distract and the verb vocab version of this word is to distract and to divert.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to divert and to distract Maggie (まぎ).

Name: To Escape
Mnemonic: You've seen 逃げる and 逃す. This one is 逃れる. This one simply means to escape. So that's not too bad. The difference between this one and the other escapes is that it has to do more with luck.
ReadingMnemonic: This is the same reading you learned for 逃す, so you should be able to read this word as well.

Name: To Grasp
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grip and the verb vocab version is to grasp.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go to grasp someone. You really need them. You are soooo needy (にぎ). Except, you can't really pronounce "d" sounds very well, so you say にぎ.

Name: To Let Someone Escape
Mnemonic: You know how 逃げる means "to escape"? This is the transitive version, so it means to let someone escape, to let someone go, or to set someone free. You know this because you'd want to let everyone escape when the place is filled with gas (がす).
ReadingMnemonic: You learned the に reading for this kanji when you learned 逃げる but here’s another mnemonic to help you remember: You decided to let someone escape because they were on their knees (に) begging you to set them free.

Name: To Run Around
Mnemonic: To 駆ける is "to gallop." 回る is "to revolve." So if you're galloping around in a revolving fashion, you are going to run around.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 駆ける and 回る.

Name: To Rush Into
Mnemonic: 駆ける is "to gallop" and the kanji 込 means into. To gallop into a place is to rush into it. You can’t gallop slowly, after all.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 駆ける and 込む.

Name: To Rush Out
Mnemonic: 駆ける is "to gallop" and 出す is "to remove." So if you gallop out to remove yourself you are probably going to rush out a little fast. Calm down and slow down, man!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 駆ける and 出す.

Name: To Shake
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shake and the verb vocab is to shake.
ReadingMnemonic: If everything starts to shake what else will shake along with it? You (ゆ), of course.

Name: Toshiba
Mnemonic: The east lawn isn't some eastern lawn, it's in reference to the company Toshiba. Might be better to look at the reading first for this one.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from the readings you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Slide
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means slippery and the verb vocab version is to slide or to slip.
ReadingMnemonic: You're about to slip, and notice the floor is covered entirely in souvenirs (すべ)! Souvenirs of all shapes and sizes are scattered all over the floor, making it extremely easy to slide and slip.

Name: To Stay The Night
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means overnight and the verb vocab version is to stay the night.
ReadingMnemonic: We are just going to stay tonight (と) and maybe tomorrow (と) night.

Name: To Tie Up
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fasten and the verb vocab version is to fasten or to tie up or to tie together.
ReadingMnemonic: You are fastening up the coocoo (くく) clock, so the coocoo bird doesn't come out anymore. That annoying coocoo bird.

Name: To Whistle
Mnemonic: You know that 口笛 is "whistling." So, if you're blowing your whistle you're going to whistle.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are of 口笛 and the reading you learned from 吹.

Name: Traffic Network
Mnemonic: You learned a while ago that 交通 means "traffic." So what would a traffic net be? A traffic network, or even a transportation network!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tug Of War
Mnemonic: The rope pull. Both sides are pulling on the rope. That is a tug of war.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are from 綱 and 引く.

Name: Twins
Mnemonic: The pair of children are the same as each other. They're twins.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is like 二人, (the ふた part) plus 子, combined together. A little weird, but makes sense. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Two Night's Stay
Mnemonic: Two overnights is a two night's stay.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Unification
Mnemonic: Unite something together and fasten it and you have unification or generalization. Nowadays this word is used to mean management in some contexts too.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Vibrancy
Mnemonic: Every leap you take is a move filled with vibrancy. Your dynamic movement captures the essence of lively motion, captivating all who witness it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Wild
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of wild? It's wild or rough.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is one of the readings you've learned from the kanji. The あら one.

Name: Yokozuna
Mnemonic: The "side rope." This doesn't make much sense. What this is, though (you'll want to look at the reading), is the Yokozuna. This is the Sumo Grand Champion.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

Name: Air Raid
Mnemonic: A sky attack is an air raid / air attack. Tora tora tora!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Amulet
Mnemonic: You learned another vocabulary word 札 as "amulet," but this is a special honorable amulet. It's a talisman.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for the 御 is お because ふだ uses the kun'yomi reading. Kun'yomi + kun'yomi = yes.

Name: A Pitcher's Stuff
Mnemonic: Your sphere might is the force you command over a sphere or ball… in this case, a baseball, making this a pitcher’s stuff.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Atomic Reactor
Mnemonic: If a 原子 is an atom and a 炉 is a furnace, what is a furnace that has atoms? It is an atomic reactor or nuclear reactor.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Attack
Mnemonic: An attack attack is an attack or assault.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Authority
Mnemonic: You have rights and might over this area. That gives you authority.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Awfully
Mnemonic: This may look like a verb at first, but it's actually the adverb version of the adjective 凄い. When something is awful it's usually awfully awful.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned this reading already, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Battleship Island
Mnemonic: A 軍艦 is a battleship, and 島 is an island. Welcome to... Battleship Island (go Jurassic Park music).
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi readings for 軍 and 艦, and the kun'yomi reading for 島. You learned all of them, so you should know the reading already! Oh, but watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Blast Furnace
Mnemonic: A high furnace is one that's particularly hot and blasty. This is a blast furnace.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Breakdown
Mnemonic: The decision is split, causing a breakdown in all we've decided. A big ol' rupture.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bright
Mnemonic: A bright bright is something that's bright.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bright
Mnemonic: This is the na-adjective version of bright. The word is bright or cheerful.
ReadingMnemonic: Of all the people who are bright and cheerful, one man comes to mind. The cheerful Hulk Hogan (ほが).

Name: Bundle
Mnemonic: Something that you wrap is a bundle or package.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned it when you learned 包む, but here's a reminder of the mnemonic just in case: Remember how you wrap your bundles? That's right, with the two two technique. Your packages are always double wrapped.

Name: Charm
Mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. 
This word covers a lot of meanings so it can be charm, taste, vibe, or even gist.
ReadingMnemonic: If something has charm, your thought/思 (おも) goes in that direction/向き (むき).  You feel the vibe? Do you get the gist?

Name: Compensation
Mnemonic: Remember how 慰謝 means "consolation?" Add fee to that and you get compensation. Or consolation money, depending on the situation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Consolation
Mnemonic: I show my consolation by apologizing. This is consolation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Contribution
Mnemonic: The tribute I offer is my contribution.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Counterattack
Mnemonic: A reverse attack is a counterattack.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Crystal
Mnemonic: A water crystal is just a crystal. I guess crystals are clear and look kind of like water, yeah? That's why it's being referred to as a water crystal, making it really just a crystal.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Delicacy
Mnemonic: A rare taste is a taste you can't have very often, because it's rare. This is a delicacy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Delicious
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of delicious? It's delicious. It also means "skillful" and "clever" as well, because delicious things are skillfully delicious, right?
ReadingMnemonic: What's especially delicious? Horse (うま) is delicious. Mmm, that delicious horse.

Name: Destruction
Mnemonic: If you break and destroy something, that is destruction. That is annihilation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dew
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading of the kanji, but you haven't learned it yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you: Dew is just the earth's way of giving water to you (つゆ). Rain is too forceful, you may not go to the ocean or a lake, so the earth gives dew to you by putting it on the grass outside your house everyday!

Name: Dignity
Mnemonic: Dignity is a strict thing. If you’re too lenient, you’ll lose all your dignity and majesty.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Discipline
Mnemonic: I will chastise you and give you penalty. I do this as a discipline. A punishment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Disclosure
Mnemonic: Using violence I'm going to expose the truth! This is disclosure. This is exposure.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 暴 is strange and new, not what you learned with the kanji. Just think about how when there is disclosure or exposure of something, you are surprised. You can't believe that's the truth. You have to take a step back (ばく) to deal with the new information.

Name: Disillusionment
Mnemonic: The illusion is destroyed. If your illusion is destroyed, that is disillusionment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Distance
Mnemonic: The distance that is detached from the distance is the distance and range. Just think of one part of the distance, stretch it out, and then look at it. It shows the distance and range!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Downfall
Mnemonic: Destroy to death. If you are destroyed to this point, this will be your downfall and ruin.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Eaves
Mnemonic: In order to use a house counter in the first place, you need to have something to count. That's why you have to find eaves. And all those eaves together stand in a row.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: These houses that stand in a row are neat and fun to count, but you can't go in because you have no key (のき). With no key, those eaves are just there for you to look at.

Name: Envelope
Mnemonic: Seal in the cylinder. This cylinder that is sealed in is an envelope. You just have to think back to the day, when things were more like in scroll form. So, a scroll's envelope would have been shaped like a cylinder, making this an envelope.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Exposure
Mnemonic: When what you expose is exited out of hiding, exposed for everything to see... that is exposure. It can also refer to photographic exposure too, in case you were wondering.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Extermination
Mnemonic: Slap that bug and destroy it. Haha! I slapped all the bugs away. This is extermination.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Extinction
Mnemonic: Extinction where everything is destroyed is extinction.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fake
Mnemonic: A fake thing is fake or counterfeit.
ReadingMnemonic: You've learned both of these readings already. No fakes there.

Name: False Accusations
Mnemonic: Ah yes, wet clothes must be wet clothes-NOT! This used to mean "wet clothes" a long, long time ago, but these days it's used for false accusations. Think of it this way: if you make false, baseless accusations, it's like you're dumping water all over someone for no reason.
ReadingMnemonic: This word is made up of the reading from 濡れる and the rendaku version of the きぬ reading of 衣. You learned this reading in the 衣 vocabulary, but here's a mnemonic to remember it. Imagine someone's dumped water on you and you're all wet. You might say "give new (ぎぬ) clothes to me!"

Name: Family Register
Mnemonic: A door register? Well, a register of people who live behind the same door. In other words, a family register. (Think of "door" as shorthand for a house in this case.) Family registers are actually pretty interesting. Look up "koseki" on Google and you're sure to find many fascinating histories.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 戸 is an exception. Instead of と it's こ. Just think about how the person who runs this census doesn't care about number of toes. They care about number of 子 (こ).

Name: Fence
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Feudalism
Mnemonic: You've learned that 主義 is "-ism." So what happens when you seal up everything you build and keep it for yourself, and make that your -ism? You get feudalism. Why? Because feudalism is a system built on the idea that power should be sealed within one group or family. Anyone outside of this sealed system is a vassal to the lord — that's feudalism for you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't seen the ほう reading for 封 yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you out: Everything belonged to a feudal lord under feudalism, even your home (ほう). People didn't have private property in those days, so you could only live in a home if a feudal lord gave you permission to. I guess, in a way, that means under feudalism you were always sharing your home. With a feudal lord. Aww, how nice!

Name: Fireplace
Mnemonic: A warm furnace is a furnace for warming you and other things. This is a fireplace or hearth or even a stove.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Frank
Mnemonic: I'm going to expose my bones for a second here and be blunt with you... this makes sense, because if you're exposing your bones at someone, you're not hiding anything. You're being frank and blunt.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Friction
Mnemonic: Things that chafe and rub have lots of friction.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Friendly
Mnemonic: Being courteous is the right idea if you want to be on friendly terms with others. The more courteous you are to someone (and vice versa), the more a sense of closeness grows between you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Friendly Talk
Mnemonic: A courteous talk is a friendly talk. We all know that "friendly talks" are never what they seem, though... right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Friendship
Mnemonic: If you treat someone with courteous intimacy, you're probably trying to build a friendship with them. Or… maybe something more? No, stop, it's not that kind of intimacy! This word is all about polite friendship and camaraderie. Yay for friendship!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Gentle
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of gentle? It's gentle... but in this word's case, it's also flexible, soft, and tender.
ReadingMnemonic: You find something that is so gentle and soft to the touch. You touch it. You can't stop. The monkey you're touching tells you to stop. It doesn't like to be touched. But, you won't stop. "Yah what (やわ) you gonna do about it, monkey?" "Yah, what can I do, I guess," replies the monkey.

Name: Gentle
Mnemonic: A gentle and peaceful person is gentle and tender.
ReadingMnemonic: You didn't learn this reading of 柔 with the kanji, so let's remember it a different way. You have to be gentle and tender if you want to touch something that's new (にゅう) to this world... a puppy, a kitty, a baby, etc. Anything new needs that gentleness.

Name: Gist
Mnemonic: The point of something is the gist and principle of it. So, what's the gist of this vocab word? It's gist as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the word 胸 (chest). So, the gist of your body is your chest (it's at the center, and holds everything together, right?). That's why these words are both read as むね.

Name: Good News
Mnemonic: A bright news report is going to be one full of good news. A dark news report is probably bad news, but we only care about good news right now, don't we?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hedge
Mnemonic: A hedge (or fence) root is where the hedge and fence grow from. What grows from this? Well, it's simply a hedge or a fence.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. With 垣 that's the one you learned and with 根 that's the vocab version of the kanji.

Name: High Tide
Mnemonic: A full tide is a high tide or full tide. That's when the water comes up.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hobby
Mnemonic: If something's got charm and is to your taste, then it's your hobby. Hobbies are activities that you find charming and develop a taste for.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Immediate
Mnemonic: An instant sit is immediate. It's also instantaneous. Just imagine yourself sitting instantly. No time passes between when you were standing and sitting. The instantaneous nature of your sit is definitely... troubling.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Immediate
Mnemonic: If you see 即 before a word, you know that it's probably something that happens really fast or instantaneously. That's why this is immediate or instant.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Immediate Effect
Mnemonic: It's instantly effective! Sounds like something out of Pokemon. This word means immediate effect or instant effect.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening.

Name: Improvisation
Mnemonic: An instant interest in something you didn't have interest in before? Well, time for some improvisation, because you're going to have to pretend you have interest in it (since you don't actually).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening of そく.

Name: Indeed
Mnemonic: The に on the end of this word turns sincerity into an adverb. What's the adverb version of sincerity? It's sincerely, or indeed. It really is.
ReadingMnemonic: This shares the same reading as the vocabulary word 誠, but here's a reminder just in case: My coat (まこと) really is a coat! Indeed, it is.

Name: Informal Talk
Mnemonic: A courteous talk is an informal talk where people gather and discuss something in a friendly way.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Inquiry
Mnemonic: If 伺う is "to inquire" or "to visit" then the noun version would be a polite way to say inquiry or enquiry. In other words, a question. It can also mean a visit.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 伺う.

Name: Instant Death
Mnemonic: An instant death is an instant death.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Judo
Mnemonic: The gentle path is, surprisingly, judo. Yep, the sport / art based on throwing people around.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Koto
Mnemonic: The harp, at least in Japan, is the koto, also known (to us) as the Japanese harp or Japanese zither.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Liquid Crystal
Mnemonic: A fluid crystal is a liquid crystal.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Livestock Farm
Mnemonic: A pasture place is a livestock farm. It's also a ranch. The place where things pasture is this place.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Main Point
Mnemonic: The parts we need. The point of that. That is the main point. That is the essentials. It's what we need and it's to the point, you know?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Marshy Rice Field
Mnemonic: A bog rice paddy is a marshy rice field. This is just a rice paddy in marshy form.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Nationality
Mnemonic: If you're on a country's register, you probably have nationality or citizenship there. What's your 国籍?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Nourishment
Mnemonic: Nourishing and fostering. The thing that gives you this is nourishment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Nuclear Reactor Core
Mnemonic: The furnace heart is the heart of the furnace. The heart of this particular furnace, the one we're talking about here, is the nuclear reactor core.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pastor
Mnemonic: A pasture teacher is one who leads his flock around through life. This is a pastor, minister, or clergyman.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pasture
Mnemonic: The pasture grass is the pasture and grass.
ReadingMnemonic: With 草 you learned a different reading from the one here. Just think about how with this pasture you have to constantly sew (そう) it together to make it come together, otherwise it comes apart and moves all around, and that's no good for any pasture.

Name: Pasture Land
Mnemonic: A pasture field is pasture land. It's also a ranch.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The secondary reading is a bit different. That's a family name, and uses the kun'yomi readings of both kanji. We'll consider this secondary for now, but you may have to come back to this when you see this as a name and are all like "what's going on here??"

Name: Paying A Sympathy Call
Mnemonic: The best consolation for someone's problem is paying a sympathy call. It is consolation through a sympathy visit.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Peace
Mnemonic: Relax in peace. Wherever you are that's allowing you to do this, it is certainly peace. You feel security too.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pipe
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You'll see this used to mean pipe more often than cylinder, though.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: When it comes to pipes, you always want to have two sets of two of them, just in case. So, that's a two two (つつ) set of pipes, lined up next to each other for backup.

Name: Point Of An Argument
Mnemonic: The point to my theory is the point of an argument. That's what I'm trying to say in my theory / argument, man!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Printing
Mnemonic: With a seal we're printing everything out. The seal is what prints the words on the paper, making this printing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rare
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of rare? It's rare. But, this can also mean unusual or curious (as in "odd" curious, not that you're curious about something).
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know what's unusual and rare? This maze is rare (めずら). I don't think there's a way out of it. We've been walking around for days now, and we haven't gotten any closer to the exit!

Name: Same Day
Mnemonic: The instant day is the day that's going on this instant. It's the same day as now.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 即 is the normal one. For 日 you're going to want to use the じつ reading, because, the truth (じつ) is that it's the same day today.

Name: Seal
Mnemonic: The kanji is seal in, but the vocab noun version is seal. This is simply a seal (not the water kind, the kind you use to seal something with).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as one of the readings you learned: ふう. Don't be a fool, make sure you seal your envelopes.

Name: Sealed Letter
Mnemonic: A seal in writing is writing that has been sealed into an envelope. This is a sealed letter.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Simultaneous
Mnemonic: At one moment it happened simultaneously. It was simultaneous. It was all at once.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening of 一.

Name: Solace
Mnemonic: You have consolation so now you can relax. What a great feeling this is. You now have solace and relaxation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Split
Mnemonic: Things get divided and split. We can just call this a split or division.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Stagnation
Mnemonic: Sink and stagnate. Imagine something is doing just that. It is in the state of stagnation and inactivity.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Stone Wall
Mnemonic: A stone hedge is a wall (hedges are nice walls), but it's made of stone. It's a stone wall.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the readings for 石 and 垣 combined into one word. Be careful of the rendakus.

Name: Street Stall
Mnemonic: An exposed shop is one that's not inside. It's outside, and exposed. It's a street stall.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sumo Wrestling
Mnemonic: A mutual slap is when two big guys run at each other and slap each other. This is sumo wrestling.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is pretty weird, and not one you've learned. But, you know what sumo is, right? It's just the same as that. It's すもう.

Name: Surprise Attack
Mnemonic: An odd attack is an attack you don't expect. This is a surprise attack.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Swamp
Mnemonic: A bog swamp is a swamp or marsh.
ReadingMnemonic: Oddly, this is the one word that uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. To remember this particular swamp, note how there are two kanji in here that make this area particularly swampy. Because it's the swampiest, boggiest place in all of Japan, of course the Shogun (しょう) wants it for himself. Even though it's useless land, he wants the best of everything, being the Shogun and all.

Name: Tide
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you think of the tide, you think of the ocean. If you think of the ocean and what it's filled with (besides water) you think of salt (しお).

Name: Tide
Mnemonic: The wind tide is the direction in which the tide is blowing. Is it blowing in? Is it blowing out? It is the tide and current. These days, we usually use this word for the current trends that come in like the tide.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tide
Mnemonic: A tides stream is the stream going through the tide. It's the tide or the tidal current.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Act Big
Mnemonic: Take your dignity and stretch it. Your dignity is so stretched! That makes you feel big! That's why this word is to act big or to be arrogant.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is from 威 and 張る. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes the 張る reading to ばる. Here's a little mnemonic to help with that: If you're trying to act big, you should shout baa (ば) at people like a sheep. Why? Because sheep are known to be arrogant. Their "baa" is like an arrogant little laugh, don't you think? Baa, baa! That's why it's good to copy them and say "baa" when you want to act big and push people around.

Name: To Attack
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means attack and the verb vocab version is to attack.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You going to attack me or something? Oh so scary you are. Oh so scary. Ho ho ho."

Name: To Be Fried Up
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 揚げる.

Name: To Console
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means consolation and the verb vocab version is to console.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going to console you for what happened to you. The nag saw (なぐさ) was turned on and buzzed through your leg. What a nagging feeling. You need some consoling.

Name: To Destroy
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means destroy and the verb vocab version is to destroy and to annihilate.
ReadingMnemonic: You are going to destroy the hoe roe. This is the roe that comes from the hoe tools. If they create too much roe, they will create too many hoes. And if there are too many hoes, bad things will happen.

Name: To Flock
Mnemonic: Remember 群れる, which means "to flock" or "to crowd."? This also means that!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a little different from 群れる, though. There's an extra ら in there. That being said, it's pretty similar, so you should be able to use one to remember the other after a few reps. You can also think about it this way: Everyone is flocking together in one place. Strange thing is, it's to a small 村 (むら). There's a 村 reunion going on, that's why.

Name: To Go Under
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conceal, but as a verb, this word means to go under or to pass through. Most commonly, this word means to dive underwater or to go underground. Can you see why the kanji for conceal kind of makes sense in these cases? If you're underwater or underground, no one can see you!
ReadingMnemonic: 潜る has two possible readings: もぐる and くぐる. The first is used when you mean to dive underwater or go underground.  The second is used when you pass through or under something, sometimes with difficulty, such as crawling under a fence. We want you to focus on もぐる, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Why are you trying to dive underwater again and again? It's to get mo' goo (もぐ) to sell on the black goo market. Who knew that sea goo was such a commodity?

Name: To Learn By Experience
Mnemonic: The kanji means chastise but the verb vocab version is to learn by experience. I guess these are kind of similar. When you make a mistake, someone will chastise you, and then you will learn by experience (either via the experience or via the chastising).
ReadingMnemonic: As a child (こ) you got a lot of chastising, I bet. A lot of learning by experience (of chastising).

Name: To Print
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means printing so the verb vocab version is to print.
ReadingMnemonic: When you print something out, it's usually the paperwork needed in order to sue (す) someone. You're just that kind of person, always looking to sue.

Name: To Sink
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sink so the verb vocab version is to sink.
ReadingMnemonic: You look at the cow. Poor cow. She's (しず) sinking.

Name: To Tear
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means split, but if you split something, you are going to tear it or to rip up it.
ReadingMnemonic: In order to get it open, you need to tear and rip up a sack (さく). Sacks don't have tabs or zippers or any of those fancy things. If you want to get at the stuff in a sack you have to tear the top right off!

Name: Unsealing
Mnemonic: When you open something sealed, you're unsealing it or breaking a seal.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Unusual
Mnemonic: Something rare is often unusual. This word could also mean rare (of course) and peculiar depending on the context.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this kanji is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That in itself isn't too rare, wouldn't you say?

Name: A Challenger
Mnemonic: A challenge (挑戦) someone is someone who is going to challenge you. They are a challenger.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Across The Board
Mnemonic: Line up house counters and you'll see that all the houses you've counted are the same across the board. It also turns them into a row of houses.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of the words 軒 and 並 that you've already learned, so you should be able to read this word too. Just note that for 並, the み in なみ is sticking out! While you might sometimes see this written 軒並, 軒並み is way more common.

Name: A Part
Mnemonic: One wing is just a part of the bird or plane it's attached to. But that one wing plays a role that's very important!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Assistance
Mnemonic: When you help with your power, you are providing assistance and support.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: You really need some assistance with this lock (りょく). You are certain that world peace and eternal happiness lie behind this one lock. But no one is willing to support you in opening it. What a cruel world.

Name: Bed
Mnemonic: A sleep bed is where you sleep. Where do you sleep? In a bed or a crib. Side note, if you're a baby sleeping in a crib, you must really want to learn kanji.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn the second kun'yomi reading for 床. You take とこ and rendaku it into どこ. How do you remember this? Just think about your bed. Then wonder, "where (どこ) is it?"

Name: Blade
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. But it also has a secondary reading you haven't learned, so here’s a mnemonic for it: Blade in hand, you charge at your foes hollering "Yah! Eee! Baa!" (やいば). As the blade cuts through them, you cry "Yah! Eee! Baa!" even louder. This battle cry always fuels your fury and doubles the force of your swinging blade. "Yah! Eee! Baa!" While both readings relate to blades, they have slightly different uses. は is used for any cutting tool's blade or edge, whereas やいば is a little old-fashioned and specifically refers to the blades of swords or knives, often in literary contexts.

Name: Blonde
Mnemonic: Gold hair is blonde hair. Makes sense!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 髪 isn't the one you learned. It's actually はつ, but it's getting rendaku'd here. So, to remember the reading of it for this word, just think about how if you were blonde, you'd wear many hats (はつ) to hide it. I have no idea why you'd hide it, but you can come up with a compelling reason that makes sense to you.

Name: Both Wings
Mnemonic: Both wings are both wings! There are two and you have them all!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Canned Coffee
Mnemonic: A can coffee (コーヒー) is coffee that's in a can. That's canned coffee or can coffee.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cannon
Mnemonic: A big cannon is... wait for it... just a cannon. I guess all cannons are big, right? At least when you compare them to guns.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cell Phone Strap
Mnemonic: You know how 携帯 refers to a mobile phone? This is a strap (ストラップ) for a mobile phone, making this a cell phone strap or mobile phone strap.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the reading of 携帯.

Name: Choices
Mnemonic: You're free to choose and select any of these limbs, leaving you many choices. With all these options and alternatives, which one will you go for?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Confusing
Mnemonic: The kanji is distract and the adjective version is confusing or misleading.
ReadingMnemonic: You know who is particularly confusing? That maggie (まぎ) girl. She's confusing because she uses magic (まぎ). Think of a Maggie you know, if possible.

Name: Conical Hat
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Control Tower
Mnemonic: The pipe control tower is the tower that controls all the pipes... think of the pipes not as pipes, but as directions things are moving in. You're controlling all of that on a map, and the pipe shows where everything is going and you're changing it to be where it needs to go. You are in the control tower.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Currency Exchange
Mnemonic: For the sake of exchange! What sounds so glorious is really just currency exchange.
ReadingMnemonic: You need to do a bunch of currency exchange for your newest investment: car wash celery (かわせ)! Why of course, it's celery that's stored, cleaned, and… smoked inside of a car wash. So go get all the currency you have, we have some exchanging to do.

Name: Deep-Fried
Mnemonic: Remember how 揚げる means "to deep fry"? This is the prefix or suffix version of that word, making it deep-fried...
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 揚げる as well.

Name: Dinosaur
Mnemonic: A fear dragon is a dinosaur. Dinosaurs are much, much scarier than dragons, and that's why dinosaurs are called fear dragons in Japanese.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dragon
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Name: Edge
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The edge of the cheese is what we call the fool (ふ) cheese (ち) because nobody wants that part.

Name: Edged Tool
Mnemonic: A blade thing is an edged tool or cutlery.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned 刃's reading with the kanji, and you probably remember 物 from so many other words.

Name: Edge Of Blade
Mnemonic: The blade's ahead is the farthest part of the blade away from you (since it's ahead of you). This is the edge of the blade or blade edge.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. For 刃 you learned that with the kanji. For 先 that's the vocab version of the kanji.

Name: Eiffel Tower
Mnemonic: The Eiffel (エッフェル) tower is the Eiffel Tower.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Eighteen-Liter Container
Mnemonic: A one ladle can is a eighteen-liter container, which is also a five-gallon container. That must be one big ladle!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Just watch out for the 一, which gets shortened to いっ.

Name: Exclamation
Mnemonic: Extinction caused by a shout. You are making everyone else's voices go extinct, and you scream and shout over them. You are making an exclamation, gosh darn it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the shortening.

Name: Fishing
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

Name: Fox
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Gloves
Mnemonic: A hand sack is a sack for your hands... better put, these are gloves.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are both the kun'yomi vocab readings, so think of 手 and 袋 as individual words, put together to make hand sacks. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Good Omen
Mnemonic: Having good luck is a good omen to have. Good luck means more good luck, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the きち reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: Grain
Mnemonic: Grains are made of single grains. You can also use this to refer to a bead or use it as a counter for grains.
ReadingMnemonic: You take all the grain and put it in a tube (つぶ). Just imagine doing this, grain by grain.

Name: Greeting
Mnemonic: Push open the door to the conversation that is going to be imminent by saying the proper greeting or salutation. This word might also refer to a short speech you give at an event or ceremony.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

Name: Grip
Mnemonic: Remember how 握る is "to grasp"? This is the noun version, making it a grip.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 握る, so get a grip on that!

Name: Hair
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Just be sure to know that this is the hair on your head.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Hairstyle
Mnemonic: Your hair model is how you model your hair. It's your hairstyle or hairdo.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the vocab readings of the individual kanji. For 髪 that's no problem. For 型 just remember that it's the individual vocab reading. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Head Hair
Mnemonic: Your hair fur is the hair fur that's specifically on your head. It's your head hair.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings, 髪 and 毛, put together.

Name: Hill
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for the vocab version of this word is the same as 岡 which has the same meaning and the same reading. Lucky!

Name: Ladle
Mnemonic: How much can you hold in this ladle? Why, exactly eighteen liters of course! Eighteen is your favorite number, how convenient.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Left Wing
Mnemonic: The left wing is the left wing, as in the "left wing party" or "left wing politics" or something like that.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 左 is the on'yomi reading, さ. You can remember this because the left wing uses saws (さ) to cut down their right wing enemies. Imagine left wing hippies sawing down old right wing conservatives. BBrrrrbbbbbbzzzzz!

Name: Marriage Proposal
Mnemonic: Let's take the edge and discuss it. That edge is the edge of getting married. But, when you reach that edge, before you jump over, you have to do a marriage proposal.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Measurement
Mnemonic: One of the easiest methods of measurement is to just check the size and dimensions, and there you go, you've got the measurement.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that the ほう changes to ぽう.

Name: Mourning Dress
Mnemonic: Your mourning clothes is your mourning dress or mourning clothes.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the on'yomi for 服 and the kun'yomi for 喪, which you learned with the word 喪. You should know how to read this word!

Name: Mystery
Mnemonic: A riddle is a riddle, but in this case, more of a mystery.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. No mystery there, I suppose.

Name: Ninja
Mnemonic: An endure someone is someone who can endure. Who endures everything better than anyone? A ninja.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Omen
Mnemonic: The edge of wake up is right before you wake up. And, by wake up I mean you're about to wake up to the truth. But, you're only at the edge, so for now what you see is an omen... an omen that will show the truth.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that 起 is rendaku'd and becomes ぎ here.

Name: Ominous
Mnemonic: Something that is not good luck is ominous and sinister. It's also bad luck and an ill omen.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: On The Brink
Mnemonic: Before you take the last measurement, you know you're on the brink of something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

Name: Original Creation
Mnemonic: You are alone in what you are able to create. Nobody else can create like you. So what you create is your own original creation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Overnight Stay
Mnemonic: You know that 泊まる is "to stay the night." The noun version is a overnight stay or sleepover.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 泊まる, so pull from that and you shall know this.

Name: Particle
Mnemonic: A grain's child is even smaller than a grain. It's a particle, sometimes even an atomic particle.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Peach
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Peach Color
Mnemonic: A peach color is a peach color, or pink.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from the vocab readings (and kanji readings, actually) of the two kanji.

Name: Pear
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Philosopher
Mnemonic: A philosophy scholar (学者) is someone who studies philosophy. They're known as a philosopher.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Playground Slide
Mnemonic: Remember how 滑る is "to slide"? Then, how 台 is a counter for machines? In this case, this slippery machine is a slide, more specifically a playground slide.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 滑る and 台.

Name: Pleasure
Mnemonic: Recreation and comfort are things you do for pleasure and amusement. So nice!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Princess
Mnemonic: The princess (formal name ender) is the princess, and you're talking to her politely. She is the princess.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the reading of 姫 and 様 combined together.

Name: Princess
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be used to refer to a noble girl as well, as in a girl of the noble family.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Red Seal
Mnemonic: A vermilion colored seal is a red seal. Just look up the (Japanese) word in Google Image search and you'll see what this is.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Riddle
Mnemonic: A riddle riddle is a riddle, and it's also a puzzle or an enigma.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Right Wing
Mnemonic: The right wing is the right wing. As in, "right wing politics" or "right wing beliefs."
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 右, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Those in the right wing love eating uni (う), not because they like the taste, but because uni is expensive. Picture some right-wing people in your mind right now and watch as they try really hard to pretend they like eating uni as they shovel buckets of it down their throats.

Name: Samurai
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the meaning and the reading of the kanji: さむらい.

Name: Sand Dune
Mnemonic: A sand hill is a sand dune.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Screen Door
Mnemonic: A net door is a screen door. Makes sense, right? Screen doors are like little meshy nets made into a door shape.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned the kun'yomi for 網 when you learned it as a vocabulary word. Take that reading, add the 戸 reading with rendaku, and you have yourself あみど.

Name: Sediment
Mnemonic: Earth and sand is earth and sand, or sediment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word and it uses the on'yomi for both kanji. This on'yomi for 砂 is a bit less common, and you haven't learnt it yet, so here's a mnemnonic to help you: If there's too much sediment, you need to speak to a shaman (しゃ) about it. Only a shaman has the power to get rid of all that earth and sand and get the river flowing again.

Name: Solid
Mnemonic: You know that 堅い is "solid" or "tough." When your hand is solid and tough, it's solid and steady. If your hand is shaky, it's the opposite, or something.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the two words 手 and 堅い combined together. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Sprout
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Storm
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: Stormy Seas
Mnemonic: A wild wave will make for some stormy seas or raging waves. Don't go out in these kinds of waves.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, 荒 (the secondary reading you learned with this kanji) and 波 (just the vocab version).

Name: Sun
Mnemonic: This measurement also refers to a specific measurement, a "sun", which is about 3.03 centimeters. You'll hear it brought up from time to time to measure things, though usually with more traditional Japanese items.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji! Congrats! Now to remember it's three point zero three centimeters.

Name: Tears Of Gratitude
Mnemonic: The feeling of teardrops is a feeling that makes you cry. But it's not a bad feeling because these are tears of gratitude, or because you're being moved to tears.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 涙 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your excessive tears of gratitude have ruined (るい) your life. Your friends didn't like being cried at for the smallest compliment or favor, so now they don't even return your calls. No one else you know is being moved to tears on a daily basis like this. It's ruining your life!

Name: The Big Dipper
Mnemonic: What can you see in the north that looks like a ladle and is made up of seven stars? That's the group of stars we call the Big Dipper or, depending on where you are in the world, perhaps the Plough.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.

Name: Thunder
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: To remember the reading think about thunder. Back in the day, it was probably terrifyingly loud. Like the cry of the gods! Wait a sec, the "cry of the gods" would be 神鳴り (かみなり).

Name: Thunderbolt
Mnemonic: Thunder that falls from the sky is a thunderbolt.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Thunderstorm
Mnemonic: A thunder rain is a rain that's coming with thunder. For all intents and purposes, if you see this, you'll think thunderstorm.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi readings. For 雨, you learned it with 雨天. So you should be able to put them together!

Name: Tin Can
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. It also just sounds like can.

Name: To Be Diverted
Mnemonic: You know that 紛らす means "to divert" or "to distract." This is when you're not doing the action, now, making this word to be diverted or to be distracted.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 紛らす.

Name: To Be Shaken
Mnemonic: Remember 揺る which means "to shake" or "to jolt"? This is like that, but now you're not doing the shaking and jolting, making it to be shaken or to be jolted. You know this because it's really rare (れる) for you to be shaken like this.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 揺る.

Name: To Be Split
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means split, so this verb has to do with something splitting.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 裂く.

Name: To Burn
Mnemonic: You know that 焦げる is "to be burned" or "to get burned." This word however is when you're doing the burning, making it to burn or to scorch. You know this because when it comes to burning, you pull out all the stops. You use lots of gas (がす) to burn whatever it is you burn.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 焦げる, so if you know that you know this word as well.

Name: To Conquer
Mnemonic: 克服 is "conquest" so the verb version of that is to conquer.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Endure
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure so the verb vocab version is to endure.
ReadingMnemonic: Those who are able to endure are those who have had a lot of training. Who has had the most training of anyone? Ninjas. What group are they part of? The shinobi (しの).

Name: To Fail To Catch
Mnemonic: The thing you want to take has escaped. Meaning you failed to catch this thing. This word is to fail to catch.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 取る and 逃がす.

Name: To Fish
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fishing so the verb vocab version is to fish.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Lay Waste
Mnemonic: 荒れる is "to be stormy" or "to be rough." This is when you do the stormy rough things. You go wild on everyone, trying to lay waste and to devastate everything around you.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 荒れる.

Name: To Overlook
Mnemonic: 逃す is "to let go" or "to let escape." If something escapes your seeing, then you are going to overlook it.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 見 and 逃す.

Name: Tornado
Mnemonic: A dragon scroll is a dragon that's shaped kind of like a scroll, spinning around. This is a tornado.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. For 竜 just think about how it's a standing (立つ) dragon, because it would have to be if it's a tornado. Your まき reading comes from 巻く, but the kana is pushed into the kanji.

Name: Torpedo
Mnemonic: Fish thunder is underwater thunder that shoots at things and are kind of shaped like fish. That's a torpedo. Load the fish thunder!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Scold
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scold and the verb vocab version also means to scold.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Shake
