Mnemonic: Shake plus "to do" is the verb version of shake. That's to shake or to rock slowly.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 揺る.

Name: To Shake
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shake so the verb vocab version is to shake.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 揺る.

Name: To Shout
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shout so the verb vocab version is to shout. Can also be to scream.
ReadingMnemonic: To remember the reading of this, just think about how you start to shout and to scream when you drink way too much sake (さけ).

Name: To Sink Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sink so the verb vocab version is to sink something or to submerge something.
ReadingMnemonic: When you sink something, like a battleship, you go on and say: "she's (しず) sunk, I sunk her." That's like your tagline, or something. You say it for some reason because you think it's cool.

Name: Tower
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be a pagoda. If you think about it, pagodas were the towers of the olden days.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tower Of Babel
Mnemonic: バベル's 塔 is Babel's tower. That's the Tower of Babel.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the reading of the kanji.

Name: Unrelated
Mnemonic: If something has a nothing edge, it's probably unrelated to what you're doing. There's no edge, your stuff always has edges.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Vermilion
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading can be either the on'yomi or kun'yomi reading, so you have a choice there. Since you learned the on'yomi しゅ with the kanji already, let's learn the あけ reading now. あけ sounds like the beginning of 開ける (to open). So imagine you 開ける (あけ) a person up, to see what color they are inside. Turns out it's vermilion! Uh… you shouldn't open people up like that. 朱 is mostly read しゅ, but it can also be read あけ in certain phrases, like 朱に染まる, which means "to be covered in blood" (literally, "to be dyed in vermilion").

Name: Wild
Mnemonic: 荒い is rough. Double that to 荒々しい and you have the same thing: wild or rough.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 荒い. Since you already know that 々 means it repeats, you already know this reading!

Name: Wing
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: In each political  wing there are two bosses (つばさ). It's a weird system, but that's how they're doing it these days. Imagine your favorite / least favorite political wings, all with two bosses, arguing with each other.

Name: Abolition
Mnemonic: Something that is obsolete will end in extinction. Join in the calls for its abolition, elimination and extinction, whatever it is.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: About When
Mnemonic: いつ is "when" and 頃 is "about." Combine those together and you have "about when?" or "how soon?"
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, just rendaku'd.

Name: Alarm Bell
Mnemonic: A warn bell is a bell that goes off when you need to be warned about something. This is usually an alarm bell or a fire bell.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Approximate Age
Mnemonic: The year approximate is your approximate age. This is also an indirect way to refer to adolescence, and when people reach marriageable age!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the reading of the vocab version of 年 plus 頃, put together. Note: You will also sometimes see this written partially in kana like 年ごろ.

Name: Approximate Time
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. When used as a suffix, it means approximate time and around (as in "around 3:00").
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Bear in mind that it's pronounced ころ when it's a noun, but it's usually ごろ when it's a suffix, though some people say ころ in both cases.

Name: Atrocious
Mnemonic: A villain who is bad is the most atrocious and fiendish villain of them all.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bacteria
Mnemonic: A thin bacteria is... well... a bacteria. I guess all bacteria are really thin. So thin you can't see them with your naked eye, in fact.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

Name: Bad Taste
Mnemonic: Remember how 趣味 means "hobby"? Well, if you have bad hobbies, it probably means you have bad taste.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bell
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Seeing the bell, you decide you need to ring it. You take your cane (かね) and hit the bell as hard as you can, making it chime.

Name: Betting
Mnemonic: The noun version of gamble is gambling or betting or a gamble or a bet. Whatever you do, put it all on black 13. Trust me.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: Boat
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that this word isn't usually used by itself (that would be 船). It's usually attached to things that are boat-related, but I wanted you to learn it individually so you can use it that way.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Also the same as 船.

Name: Boat
Mnemonic: A small boat is a boat or small craft. If something is a "big boat" it's better to call it a "ship" I think, which is why this is just a boat.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are all ones you've seen before. 小 uses its こ reading, so just think of this like a "child boat." This makes sense because it's small. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Bride
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Calculator
Mnemonic: An electricity table is a calculator. Why is this? You can think about it in a couple of different ways. Maybe in the past, a calculator (aka abacus) would take up a whole table, making this "electric" version a calculator. Or, maybe it can be used to solve tables. Wrong kind of table, but should help you to remember the meaning of this word.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Calendar
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: When looking at a calendar, the 子読み (こよみ) of it is to... well... not be able to read it at all. Because, children can't really read. So, when you look at a calendar you have to explain it to a child, since they cannot read it.

Name: Cemetery
Mnemonic: A ghost garden is where many ghosts are harvested and where many ghosts grow. This is a cemetery.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Christian Era
Mnemonic: The West's calendar shows the history and time period of "The West." To the Japanese and Chinese, this era is known as the Christian Era. It also used to be used as a way to refer to the Western Calendar, though we usually just say カレンダー nowadays.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cloudy Weather
Mnemonic: The noun version of cloudy is cloudy weather or cloudiness. In some cases, this can also refer to the type of fog you'd find on a window or your glasses.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Coin
Mnemonic: Stiff freight always has to be paid for in coins, because coins are also stiff. You can't go paying for something stiff with something not stiff, that would make no sense at all.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Completely Naked
Mnemonic: You're all naked, which makes you completely naked or totally naked.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Considerably
Mnemonic: It's possible that it's considerably considerable. It's considerably, fairly, and quite... something. Also please note that this is almost always written in kana and not kanji. But, we're learning kanji here, so gosh darn it we're going to learn some kanji.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: Cram School
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned in the kanji.

Name: Cram School Student
Mnemonic: Remember how 学生 is "student"? This plays off that. A cram school "student" is a student of a cram school, a cram school student.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Curse
Mnemonic: Despite looking like an adjective this is a noun. It means the same thing as the kanji: curse.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: Dangerous Weapon
Mnemonic: A villain vessel is a vessel used by a villain. This vessel holds bullets, and is a dangerous weapon.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dining Table
Mnemonic: An eating table is a dining table.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Drainage
Mnemonic: You already know that emitted water means "drainage." Add gutter to that and this becomes a drainage in the sense of a drainage ditch or gutter.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Entry In Family Register
Mnemonic: Remember how 戸籍 is the family register? This is referring to that, and that makes this word entry in family register. In most cases, that specifically means a registration of marriage in that family register.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Evil Spirit
Mnemonic: An evil ghost isn't so much a ghost as it is an evil spirit.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note this uses the secondary 霊 reading of りょう, so imagine an evil spirit rowing a boat.

Name: Germ
Mnemonic: A "ばい" bacteria is a germ. In case you're wondering, the ばい is referring to the kanji 黴, but people don't usually write that part.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Ghost
Mnemonic: A deceased ghost is a ghost (all ghosts are deceased). Can also refer to "the dead."
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Gloom
Mnemonic: A shade energy is a shady feeling. It's a feeling of gloom and melancholy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Goosebumps
Mnemonic: Bird skin is goosebumps. Makes sense, since a goose is a bird and a bird's skin is bumpy.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the individual vocab readings of the two kanji, 鳥 and 肌.

Name: Gutter
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you step in that gutter you'll catch measles (みぞ). A gutter or ditch has all kinds of dirt and germs in it, including measles, so don't go stepping in it or drinking from it!

Name: Half Naked
Mnemonic: If you're half naked you're half nude or half naked.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Human Skin
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though you'll want to know that this refers most specifically to human skin.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Humidifier
Mnemonic: An "add dampness container" is a container that adds dampness to the air. That's a humidifier.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hunter
Mnemonic: A hunt person is a person who hunts. A hunter.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned the reading of 狩 when you learned the kanji, but the reading for 人 is totally irregular. Just imagine that you're hunting a reindeer named Rudolph (りゅうど). He has an unusually red nose, which makes him easy to spot and puts him at a bit of a disadvantage.

Name: Hunting
Mnemonic: You have the noun version of hunt. That is hunting.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading uses the reading from the kanji.

Name: Inspiration
Mnemonic: A ghost feeling is inspiration. For some reason, the feeling of ghosts is the feeling of inspiration. I guess a ghost goes inside you and makes you feel this inspiration? Oh, wait, you can feel that because you have the sixth sense.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Japan Current
Mnemonic: The black tide isn't what you think, most likely. This is the Japan current, aka the Kuroshio Current. It's a Northern flowing  current on the West side of the Pacific Ocean. Have you heard of the Gulf Stream? It's kind of like that.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the two kanji, put together. 黒 and 潮.

Name: Lately
Mnemonic: The near approximate is the approximate time that was near to you. This period of time is the lately period of time. It's recently.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 近い and 頃 put together.

Name: Leg
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 足!

Name: Light-year
Mnemonic: What happens when light travels a year? You have a light-year.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Long Distance
Mnemonic: A far distance detachment is a distance that is far. It is long distance. Also remember that 距離 is a "distance" so a far distance is a long distance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lump
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are the same, so this can mean lump, mass, or bundle. Additionally, this can also refer to being the embodiment of something. When somebody or something is a mass or bundle of some attribute or trait, they might as well be the embodiment of it!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Recognize this word?

Name: Lunisolar Calendar
Mnemonic: The former calendar is the calendar from before. It's the lunisolar calendar and the traditional Japanese calendar. Certainly not the current calendar, anyways.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Madness
Mnemonic: Lunatic energy is madness and insanity.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Menu
Mnemonic: I'm offering to stand up and announce what's on the menu for today. I'll tell everyone about today's meal plan.
ReadingMnemonic: You didn't learn this reading for 献 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm actually announcing the menu for condors (こん). You thought I was going to tell you what's on the menu for humans? No no, that's a surprise. Condors need a heads-up for these things, because meals are extremely important to condors, given their size and everything.

Name: Moderate
Mnemonic: When you control your hand an approximate amount, you are going to be a very moderate and reasonable person.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Moisture
Mnemonic: A damp energy is a feeling of dampness. It is moisture and humidity.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful of the shortening, and the irregular reading for 気.

Name: Mountains
Mnemonic: The mountain peaks are just the mountains. Just because you can only see the peaks doesn't mean the rest of the mountain doesn't exist.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Naked
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: You are naked now. You used to wear a car, but you don't have it anymore (and you're not wearing it). You had a car (はだか), but now you don't have a car. That's what you'll explain when someone asks you why you're naked.

Name: Nuclear Fission
Mnemonic: 分裂 means "split" or "division." The nucleus version of this split is nuclear fission.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ocean Trench
Mnemonic: An ocean gutter is an ocean trench.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: One's Youth
Mnemonic: The young approximate is the approximate age of when you were young. This, approximately, is one's youth or early life.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 若い and 頃 combined into one.

Name: Package
Mnemonic: A small bundle is merely a package. Something big would be a big package, I guess.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 小 (which is a reading you've seen a couple times now, I'm sure) and 包み, with the み pushed inside the package. Beware of the somewhat weird rendaku. You don't see づ too often.

Name: Polish
Mnemonic: A polish is a polish or even a shine.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: Private School
Mnemonic: A righteousness cram school is, for some reason, a private school. Maybe because they don't think the public cram schools are any good, so they take their righteousness somewhere else to start a private one? I'm not sure.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Prospect
Mnemonic: You stare at hope. It looks good. That is your prospect and view, as you stare at hope.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rapids
Mnemonic: A waterfall river is a river that's moving like a waterfall! Fast and furious! Water that moves like this are rapids.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of each kanji: 滝 and 川. Careful of the rendaku.

Name: Recently
Mnemonic: The previous approximate was the previous approximate time, which is recently or the other day.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of the two kanji. That's 先 and 頃 (the reading you learned) put together. The 頃 is the rendaku'd version, ごろ so be careful.

Name: Recently
Mnemonic: This (この) approximate is this approximate time. It is recently or nowadays or these days.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the 頃 reading from the kanji reading. Be careful, it's the rendaku'd form.

Name: Ringleader
Mnemonic: The origin villain is the villain who's running everything. They're the mastermind behind the villainy going on. They're the ringleader or main culprit.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these, but since 元 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you out: The ringleader of all these problems is Genji (げん). He's the main culprit behind this mess. Remember all that trouble he stirred up by flirting with too many women in "The Tale of Genji"? Everyone admired his beauty, but there's no doubt he was the root cause of a lot of chaos.

Name: Script
Mnemonic: A leg book is just the legs of a book. Not a whole book. It only contains the parts that walk around and move, not so much the descriptions (things that don't move). This kind of book is a script or screenplay. These "books" are focused on actions and things people say, which is why it's just the legs.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Shadow
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also means shadow.
ReadingMnemonic: Look at a shadow. It's long, surprisingly long. It's in the shape of a cage (かげ), because that's what is producing the long shadow. Check out each bar of the cage. Maybe you're inside the cage? Whatever is going on, a long shadow is being created by the cage and shade.

Name: Short Distance
Mnemonic: A 距離 is a distance and 近 is near. A near distance is a short distance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Short Distance
Mnemonic: A 距離 (distance) that is short is a short distance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Simultaneously
Mnemonic: 一斉 is simultaneous or all at once. Add the に in there and you're heading towards those things. For "simultaneous" that becomes simultaneously. For "all at once" it stays at all at once.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 一斉.

Name: Skin Color
Mnemonic: Skin color is skin color, or skin tone.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings of each kanji, 肌 and 色 combined into one.

Name: Soul
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Look inside your soul. You see all the bits and bobs that make up your soul rolling around and around, being pushed by the Katamari Tamashii (たましい). He keeps your soul nice and big and safe!

Name: Spear
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The person who's holding the spear is a little hoe 子. It's a child who learned to fight with a hoe, and he's turned the hoe into a spear to fight with. Imagine him swinging his hoe spear around like a little dork.

Name: Spirit
Mnemonic: When attached to a word, this refers to a ____ spirit. It's  the same meaning as the kanji, too.
ReadingMnemonic: This word is made up of a single kanji, but it uses the on'yomi reading, not the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you've learned this reading already. Yay!

Name: Sterilization
Mnemonic: If you kill bacteria you are performing sterilization. You're killing those bacteria.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening.

Name: Sterilized
Mnemonic: Someplace with nothing amounts of bacteria is sterilized and aseptic.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Stiff
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of stiff? It's stiff, hard, or firm.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as a very similar word, 固い. So, if you can use that word to help you to remember, you'll remember the reading of this word in no time as well!

Name: Stiffness
Mnemonic: A stiff fix is when you fix something to be stiff, which leads to stiffness or stiffening.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Table
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: Table Tennis
Mnemonic: Table sphere is a sport where you have a table and then you use a sphere on it. That's table tennis or ping pong. Makes sense, right? You use a ping pong ball and you play on a table.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of たく's shortening.

Name: The Touch Of
Mnemonic: The skin touch is  the feeling of touching with your skin. That is the touch of, feel of, or texture of something. It's what you feel when you touch your skin to something!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 肌 plus 触る's reading, combined. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Tidal Hour
Mnemonic: The tide time is the tidal hour.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the individual words, 潮 and 時. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: To Attack
Mnemonic: Remember how 襲撃 is an assault or attack? This is the verb form, so it's to attack or to assault.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Become Clear
Mnemonic: Something with lucidity is clear. That's why this word is to become clear or to become transparent.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.

Name: To Be Damp
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means damp so the verb vocab version is to be damp or to be moist. Ewww.
ReadingMnemonic: You know what's really damp and moist? Sheep men (しめ) are. They've been hanging out in a greenhouse and now their wool is all damp. They're going to need a towel to dry off.

Name: To Be Destroyed
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means destroy so the verb vocab version is to be destroyed. You know you're not destroying things because of the beer (びる). You'd never destroy beer... but someone else might. Grrr.
ReadingMnemonic: "THE HORROR!" (ほろ) you cry, as your beer is about to be destroyed.

Name: To Be In A Hurry
Mnemonic: This is a bit of a weird word. The kanji is char, and a previous word you learned (焦げる) is "to be burned." This, on the other hand, is "to be in a hurry" or "to be impatient." I guess if you're getting burned or have that feeling, you're going to be in a hurry and you're going to be impatient. You can tell that this is that word because it only has one kana, る, which stands for rude. You're feeling someone is being rude (or maybe you are), which is why you have this feeling of impatience and hurrying.
ReadingMnemonic: You're being rude, but you're also being a big ass (あせ) with your impatience.

Name: To Curse
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means curse, and the verb version is to curse or to put a curse on.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Earn Income
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means earnings and the verb vocab version is to earn income, because you can't "to income" something. Can also be to make money.
ReadingMnemonic: To earn income, you decided to start a car sale. (かせ) "Every car sale, a step to richness!" was your quirky business mantra.

Name: To Fly
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means fly, so the verb version means to fly.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading already! You should be able to read this too!

Name: To Gamble
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gamble and the verb vocab version is to gamble.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Get Cloudy
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cloudy and the verb vocab version means to get cloudy or to become cloudy.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. It also happens to be the same as 雲, which has a very similar meaning (clouds).

Name: To Go Mad
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lunatic or crazy. The verb version of this is to go mad (you don't really "go lunatic" now, do you?) or to go crazy.
ReadingMnemonic: To remember the reading, just think about how when you go crazy, you are coming (来る) to crazy town. Just imagine some voice beckoning you to come. Come here! Please come here! Come to crazy town! Give in to the voices!

Name: To Let Someone Stay Over
Mnemonic: 泊まる is "to stay the night." Now you're letting someone else stay the night, which makes this to let someone stay over or to let someone stay the night.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 泊まる.

Name: To Marry
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bride and the verb vocab version is to marry, because you can't really "to bride" someone.
ReadingMnemonic: Imagine you're getting married to a valley girl. You're all like. Hey, I'm gonna marry you! And she's all like Tots (とつ), we gonna get, like, married! Imagine her saying more "tots" things (tots = short for totally in valley girl speak, at least in my imagination).

Name: To Polish
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means polish and the verb vocab version is to polish or, strangely specifically (and we'll learn an even more specific word for this later) to brush your teeth.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Rub
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rub and this verb means to rub or to scrub.
ReadingMnemonic:
If you're going to rub me like that, I'm going to sue (す) you. It's making me very uncomfortable. The cost  (こす) of your rubbing actions will be high.
    
So this word has two readings and both mean “to rub.” But you usually use する for a single action, such as lighting a match or grazing your knee, while こする means doing it repeatedly, like when you’re cleaning or polishing something.

Name: To Serve
Mnemonic: Everything we're doing is to serve you, you know.
ReadingMnemonic: To serve you well, we've gotten ourselves two cars (つか). If one breaks down, we can still serve you with the other car.

Name: To Stare At
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stare and the verb vocab version is to stare at (or to look at in a very staringish way).
ReadingMnemonic: To learn the reading, just think about how you're looking at something for a lonnnnng time if you're staring at it. In Japanese the word "long" is 長い, and guess what the reading of the kanji part is? It's なが, just like ながめる's kanji-part reading.

Name: To Tear Up
Mnemonic: You know that 裂く is "to tear" or "to rip up." So, if you're trying to tear or rip up something, and you're pulling it at the same time, you are going to tear up that thing, or more accurately perhaps to tear off something, since you're pulling.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 引く and 裂く.

Name: To Torment
Mnemonic: As usual, you can guess this is a verb thanks to the う sound on the end. The kanji means frustration, and unfortunately frustration tends to torment people. This verb is pretty advanced, but still useful to know!
ReadingMnemonic: We all know it's not okay to to torment each other. So how about we all sign a (さいな) contract saying that we'll never torment anyone ever again?

Name: Waterfall
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Wetlands
Mnemonic: The damp earth is where water seems to congregate, but not so much that there's a lake or ocean or anything like that. Just damp. This is a wetlands.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Wrapping Paper
Mnemonic: A 包み is a bundle or package, and 紙 is paper. What paper goes around bundles and packages? That would be wrapping paper.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 包み and 紙 combined together. Be careful of rendaku.

Name: A Blink
Mnemonic: A blink is a blink and a wink as well, depending on how many eyes you use.
ReadingMnemonic: A wink is all it takes to get the "Ma butter" (まばた) from the store. It's hidden, and they only bring it out if you do the wink.

Name: Air Bubble
Mnemonic: Energy bubbles are bubbles filled with the "energy" that's all around us (air). That's why this is an air bubble.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Alchemy
Mnemonic: Tempering gold is a technique so magical that we can consider it to be alchemy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: An Instant
Mnemonic: A blink interval of time is a very short period of time. It's an instant or a moment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: An Instant
Mnemonic: One blink is one instant. That is an instant or a moment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Annual Revenue
Mnemonic: Every time a government is years older, it calculates the money that has entered its coffers. This is the annual revenue received by national and local governments.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bad Habit
Mnemonic: The kanji itself means habit but it usually refers to a bad habit, so try to remember that meaning if you could.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Banzai
Mnemonic: Ten thousand years old! That's a lot of time. This is the word for the turned-English Japanese phrase, banzai!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading isn't the same as 万's normal reading. It's ばん instead of まん. But, since the word "banzai" is so well known, you probably can remember this reading.

Name: Below Zero
Mnemonic: Zero below is below zero. Sub zero.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Black Magic
Mnemonic: The devil’s techniques are black magic and sorcery. The kind of things that devils do.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Blunt Weapon
Mnemonic: You're using a dull container as a blunt weapon. It's all you have to hand.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Boarding Student
Mnemonic: A dormitory student (comes from 学生) is a boarding student or a boarder. This is a student who lives in a dormitory.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bookshelf
Mnemonic: A write shelf is a shelf with writing on it. That's a bookshelf or bookcase.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bubble
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: It's a bubble! A Wha---? (あわ) A BUBBLE. A WHA???

Name: Calm
Mnemonic: This is a な adjective version of the kanji which means calm. The vocab version here is calm as well, though you can use it to mean mild as well.
ReadingMnemonic: What is calm? "Ode (おだ) to Joy" is nice and calm and mild, as far as music goes.

Name: Calm
Mnemonic: A flat calm is a calm and tranquil place.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chair
Mnemonic: A chair child is for some reason just a chair. Not sure why it's a child, but it is.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. But the す reading for 子 here is less common and you haven't really seen it yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you out: Think about how you broke this chair when you sat on it, so you sue (す) the person who made the chair. (Who happened to be a child, I guess).

Name: Confinement
Mnemonic: Secluded and closed off, putting you in confinement and imprisonment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Construction
Mnemonic: If you have a shelf to establish on your wall, you'll need to do some construction and installation work.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cool Breeze
Mnemonic: A cool wind is a cool breeze.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is all on'yomi, and you know how to read 風. You didn't learn 涼's on'yomi (りょう) with the kanji though, so here's a mnemonic to help: Imagine that a cool breeze is pushing your little row (りょう) boat along, so that you don't need to do any rowing. Ahh, what a nice cool breeze…

Name: Cotton
Mnemonic: Cotton that comes off a tree is still cotton!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own as long as you watch out for 木. It drops the く from もく making this reading just もめん.

Name: Cotton Cloth
Mnemonic: A cotton cloth is a cotton cloth of cotton material.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Cotton Plant
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading can be either the kun'yomi or on'yomi reading, so you have a choice there. Let's learn the わた reading, though. Just think what (わた) is cotton? What is it? What does it mean? Ask a lot of "what" questions about cotton to yourself.

Name: Decision
Mnemonic: Noun version of decide? It's a decision.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji!

Name: Deep Fried
Mnemonic: Remember how 揚げる can mean "to deep fry"? 揚げ出し is a Japanese cooking technique where you deep fry something (usually tofu) and serve it in broth. This word might be easy to remember if you know that "dashi" soup stock is often used to make the agedashi broth.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 揚げる and 出す's reading.

Name: Devil
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Devil
Mnemonic: A bad devil is a devil (because they're all bad), or a demon or satan.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dormitory
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also refer to a hostel.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dull
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dull? It's dull.
ReadingMnemonic: To remember the reading, think about how when you're inebriated (にぶ) you need to use a dull knife. The にぶい reading talks about a thing that is dull. For のろい, which refers to a dull mind (someone who's thickheaded). Think about a Norse (のろ) God, the God of dullbrains.

Name: Elementary Particle
Mnemonic: A particle (粒子) that is the element version of it is an elementary particle.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Emperor
Mnemonic: The sovereign emperor of Japan is also the emperor of other places too!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Empire
Mnemonic: A sovereign country is one that is part of its own empire.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: End Of The Year
Mnemonic: Years old of livelihood. This is each year of livelihood that you have, and at the end of each year you've reached the end of the year. This may also refer to a year end gift.
ReadingMnemonic: You've learned this reading, but it might not be the one you were expecting. It's せい, like the saber you use to cut down the old year before starting the new one.

Name: Exaggeration
Mnemonic: Your pride is too big. You make it bigger than it is, in fact. You do this with exaggeration and hyperbole.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Exaggeration
Mnemonic: Take your pride and stretch it out. It's an exaggeration, because you've stretched your pride out pretty thin.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Foam

Name: Foreign Concession

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ghost
Mnemonic: A secluded ghost is someone who's secluded and a ghost, because everyone's forgotten about him (thus the "ghostness" of him). This thing is a ghost or specter.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Go
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Name: Go Board
Mnemonic: A go tray is a tray for playing the game "go." This tray is a go board.

Name: Go Parlor

Name: Head Of Plant

Name: Head Of Rice
Mnemonic: A head of plant of a rice plant is the head of rice or ear of rice.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses kun'yomi readings for 稲 (いな) and 穂 (ほ). You may not be familiar with the いな reading yet, but it appears in a lot of compounds that use 稲, so it's good to know. Here's a mnemonic to help: To get a big head of rice on your rice plant, have it eat nachos (いな). Not literally, of course, but like… give it some nacho fertilizer. If you let rice plants eat nacho (fertilizer), you'll have the biggest, most high-yielding heads of rice ever.

Name: Hospital Ward
Mnemonic: A sick building is a building (or part of a building) for sick people. In other words, a hospital ward.

Name: I

ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the readings you learned with the kanji readings.

Name: Ignoring
Mnemonic: Shut up and kill your talking or I'll kill it for you. I'm not listening to this. I'm ignoring it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Impatience
Mnemonic: Remember 焦る, which means "to be in a hurry" or "to be impatient"? This is the noun version, which is impatience.

Name: Imperial Government
Mnemonic: Sovereign government and Politics are those who are part of the imperial government. This type of government is imperialism. Of course, back in the day there weren't as many sovereign governments out there, so imperialism is the one that fits the bill in this word's case.

Name: Ink
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Name: Ink Painting
Mnemonic: An ink painting is an ink painting.

Name: Insensitive
Mnemonic: If you’re too dull to have feeling, you’re insensitive, or thickheaded.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Japanese Emperor
Mnemonic: The one true sovereign is the Japanese emperor, a.k.a. the emperor of Japan. On its own, 帝 only refers to him, not to other emperors around the world.
ReadingMnemonic: To remember the reading, think about how the Japanese Emperor, can always pull out his "me card" (みかど) when he's in trouble. It's kind of like how a "trump card" is the one that's above all the others, but with the emperor he's always up there, so it's a "me card" to him. And who's gonna argue with the emperor? Not me.

Name: Key
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Killing With A Sword
Mnemonic: A slice kill is a killing with a sword. You don't want to hear this, if at all possible.

Name: Magic
Mnemonic: The devil's method is magic and witchcraft. That's their method of doing things, after all.

Name: Manor
Mnemonic: A manor park is just a manor. That's what a manor is, though. It's a big house that has an awesome garden/park around it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Midnight
Mnemonic: Zero o'clock is 0:00. That's midnight or twelve o'clock.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Moment
Mnemonic: A blink of time is a mere moment or instant.

Name: Moment's Leisure
Mnemonic: You have a measurement (3.03 cm!) of spare time. This isn't much free time, but it's a free minute that you have.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Monkey
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Monkey See Monkey Do
Mnemonic: If 真似 is imitation and if a monkey is doing said imitation, that's summed up by the saying: monkey see monkey do.

Name: Novel Idea
Mnemonic: Something that has sliced newness into the world is a novel idea. It is original and novel. Just imagine the world as a place of things that are already done. If you want to get something new and novel in there, you have to slice that oldness open to make space for the new.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Obstruction
Mnemonic: If you thwart and stop something, you are an obstruction or hindrance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Obstruction
Mnemonic: Thwart and damage the advancement of something. That's an obstruction and inhibition.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Onigiri
Mnemonic: 握り is a "grip." When you add お it's elevated a bit. For some reason it becomes a rice ball (aka onigiri). To make a rice ball, you use your grip to make them into a ball shape, which is probably where it comes from.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 握り. Note that this is usually written in hiragana as おにぎり.

Name: Pending
Mnemonic: Something that is not yet decided... it is pending!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Pigeon
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Polite
Mnemonic: A street rather than a not-street. That's what I'm offering you to walk on. It's much nicer this way. I am being polite and courteous by offering you this street.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 丁 is an unexpected one. It's てい instead of ちょう, so think about how the street is lined with tater (てい) tots, and how you can eat from them as you walk along on your trek. How polite of someone to leave them there for you!

Name: Proper
Mnemonic: Everything is calm and right. It is proper and reasonable.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pupil
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Remember, this is the eyeball pupil.
ReadingMnemonic: What part of the eye lets a person see? The pupil! The pupil lets a 人 見る (ひとみ). That's how you can remember ひとみ.

Name: Pupil
Mnemonic: Your pupil hole is still your pupil. It can also be called your pupillary.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the same as the ones you learned with the kanji!

Name: Rather
Mnemonic: This is the same as the kanji, rather. Can also mean better or instead.
ReadingMnemonic: Just think: rather than a bug (むし), how about an animal?

Name: Refreshing
Mnemonic: A pure cool is refreshing and cool, isn't it.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is all on'yomi, and you know how to read 清. You didn't learn 涼's on'yomi (りょう) with the kanji though, so here's a mnemonic to help: You want a refreshing and cool drink really badly. Why? You just had to row (りょう) across a huge lake. With the wind in your face. Imagine how refreshing a cool soda would be after rowing all day!

Name: Ring
Mnemonic: On the soil we put sacks in a circle to mark the ring or arena in sumo. Go look up some pictures of this word in Japanese and you'll see exactly what we mean. Better yet, go see some live sumo!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sack
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: A bunch of sacks or straw bags are stacked upon each other to make a tower (たわら). Imagine walking into this sack tower and wonder how it's all held together. Such poor architecture.

Name: Shout
Mnemonic: A shout voice is a shout or a yell.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 叫ぶ and 声, put together. Careful of the rendaku.

Name: Shout
Mnemonic: 叫ぶ is "to shout" and "to scream." This is the noun version. This is a shout or scream.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 叫ぶ.

Name: Silence
Mnemonic: You sink down and shut up. You go into a silence and hush. This tends to be an awkward silence or hush.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sprout
Mnemonic: A new sprout is a sprout or bud or shoot. All sprouts are new, after all.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji, combined.

Name: Stretcher
Mnemonic: It will carry or bear people like a shelf. This thing that carries people is a stretcher or litter.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tattoo
Mnemonic: If you enter ink into (your body), you are getting yourself a tattoo.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 入れる and 墨 combined together. Careful of the rendaku.

Name: Taxes
Mnemonic: A tariff tax is a form of taxes or taxation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tempering
Mnemonic: Forging and tempering of things is tempering and forging of things. When you do this to your body, to get ready for the big race, it's called training. (Though body tempering sounds way cooler, don't you think?)
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Time
Mnemonic: Years old in months shows time in years. Just imagine counting time by months and years... You kind of do anyways, right? How old are you? 5 years old. Or, 5 and a half years old (that's five years six months). So, it makes some sense.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Be Proud Of
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pride and the verb version is to be proud of or to boast of.
ReadingMnemonic: The hoe 子 (ほこ) is the kid who is carrying around a hoe all the time, swinging it around, doing dumb things with it. He's so proud of it, though, and it shows on his face. He's always boasting about his hoe skillz too.

Name: To Blink
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blink and the verb vocab version is to blink.
ReadingMnemonic: Mah ta-ta (またた) is showing, causing you to blink. I don't know what a "ta-ta" is, but I bet you could come up with something that's blink-worthy.

Name: To Cut Down
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means slice and the verb vocab version means to cut down or to slice off or to lop off.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 切る, which means "to cut." Similar meaning, same reading.

Name: To Forge
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means forge and the verb vocab version is to forge and to temper.
ReadingMnemonic: To forge something, you need to have your kit (きた) with you. Without it, you won't be doing any forging at all.

Name: To Shake
Mnemonic: Hey look! If you weren't sick of them yet, it's another verb that goes with shake! This one means to shake too!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 揺る, 揺する, and 揺れる so I reeeeally hope you can remember it by now!

Name: To Shut Up
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shut up so the verb vocab version is to shut up.
ReadingMnemonic: You need to dam (だま) your mouth shut and shut up.

Name: To Thwart
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means thwart and the verb vocab version is to thwart or to hamper.
ReadingMnemonic: Someone walks up to you, saying "habbah habbah habbah" (kind of like hubbah hubbah). He's trying to flash you or something. So, you go to thwart him with your taser.

Name: Tray
Mnemonic: The kanji 盆 means tray or ancestral festival. The お just adds politeness or respect. So お盆 also means tray, or refers to the ancestral festival also known as Obon.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Twenty Years Old
Mnemonic: Two time ten years old is twenty years old.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for twenty years old, specifically, is a really weird reading. It's はたち. When you turn twenty years old you become a hater of cheese. A hater cheese (はたち) kinda person.

Name: Unmistakable
Mnemonic: 紛らわしい is "confusing" or "misleading." This is the negative of that (you can tell by the ない), meaning it's kind of the opposite of those things. This word is unmistakable,  indisputable , and obvious.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 紛らわしい.

Name: Unrest
Mnemonic: Something that's not calm is in a state of unrest. When things are unsettled, it's disquieting for people.

Name: White Chrysanthemum

ReadingMnemonic: The reading of 白 is a bit different from normal. It's しら instead of しろ, so do your best to keep that in mind. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Witch
Mnemonic: A devil woman is a witch. She uses magic, so she must be a witch! Also, does she float like wood / a very small rock?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Years Old
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is put on the end of numbers to show how old someone is.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Zero
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That's 零 extra things for you to learn.

Name: Zero Points
Mnemonic: Zero points means you got zero points. Could also refer to getting zero marks on your test.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Adhesion
Mnemonic: If something sticky wears something else on it, it will stick together because there's adhesion between them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Aid
Mnemonic: A supplement of help is an aid or help or assistance. Not a full on help, but an aid of sorts.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Barefoot
Mnemonic: If you have a naked foot, it means you're not wearing anything on your foot, making you barefoot.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading here is a bit weird. It's like the words 裸 (はだか) and 足 (あし) were smushed together into one word. The 裸 becomes はだ and the 足 becomes し. You can think of it this way: You were barefoot too long, and because of this, you don't have feet anymore, though you had ashi (はだし) at one point in the past.

Name: Body
Mnemonic: Your torso body is the body area that's your torso. It's your body and trunk and torso, depending on what kind of body you have.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Book Illustration
Mnemonic: If you insert a picture into a book, it becomes a book illustration.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading used for 挿絵 is an exceptional one. Instead of そう it's さし. When you think of a book illustration, think of an illustration of a sash. Just picture after picture of a sash. Purple sashes. Green sashes. Flashy sashes. What a weird book, that only has illustrations of sashes. 絵, however, is the reading you learned with the kanji, so at least you have that.

Name: Chopsticks
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Clarity
Mnemonic: Something that is bright and clear has great clarity and clearness. Just look at something with such brightness and such clearness! It has so much clarity!

Name: Clay
Mnemonic: Sticky earth is clay. Just think about feeling the clay. It's sticky especially when fresh and kind of wet, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cliff
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this is a word made up of a single kanji and nothing else, you can assume that this word will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading you learned for this kanji happens to be the kun'yomi reading as well. So if you know the kanji you know the reading.

Name: Colonel
Mnemonic: A big help is a colonel or navy captain. They go around the seas, helping people in need by fighting the bad guys.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Comic Haiku

Name: Cooking
Mnemonic: A cooking occurrence is just the act of cooking. It's the kitchen work.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cooking For Oneself
