Name: Counter For Tatami Mats
Mnemonic: The 〜 shows the number of tatami mats, and the 畳 part is "tatami" of course. So, this is a counter for tatami mats. It is generally used to show how big an apartment or something is. Oh, your apartment is 12 tatami mats? Nice and big!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Crashing
Mnemonic: If you crash and fall then you're crashing or falling, or maybe both.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dish Cloth
Mnemonic: A cloth towel is just a cloth towel. Essentially it's known as a dish cloth or tea towel.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Doors Of A Gate
Mnemonic: A gate's front door is the doors of a gate or gate doors.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Drop Of Water
Mnemonic: A water drip is a drop of water or a water drop.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dust Cloth
Mnemonic: A miscellaneous cloth is a dust cloth or house cloth. It's just a cloth that you use on random things.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading of 雑 is different from what you've learned. Instead of ざつ it's ぞう. Just imagine using this dust cloth to wipe down a 象 (ぞう). Its trunk is particularly dusty.

Name: Earnings
Mnemonic: 稼ぐ is "to earn income." This is the noun version. It's just earnings, the things you earn.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 稼ぐ.

Name: Electric Fan
Mnemonic: A folding fan wind machine is a machine that blows wind like a folding fan. That's an electric fan or an electronic fan.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the rendaku.

Name: Especially
Mnemonic: You 取り (take) and then 分け (divide) something. But you'll want to be especially careful not to give anyone an unequal share. This is especially important because we’re dealing with money, and people will flip out and shoot you under the table if you aren't especially accurate.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from the words 取る and 分ける. So long as you know those words you should be able to read this one as well.

Name: Flamboyance
Mnemonic: What does Italy attain like no other? Flamboyance! They redefine chic and stylishness, dazzling everyone with their unabashed display.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for both kanji are ones you haven't seen before. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember: So how does Italy attain its flamboyance? Because it embodies Dante’s (だて) bold essence—vibrant, captivating, and chic in every way. In Italy, Dante's influence is a living testament to flamboyant elegance.

Name: Fog
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading of the vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Folding Fan
Mnemonic: A folding fan's child is, for some reason, a folding fan. I'm guessing there are different sizes of folding fans, and this is the smaller more manageable kind you can carry around easily and make it smaller by folding it up, which is why it's the "child" version of the folding fan. Still a folding fan, though.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've seen the す reading for 子 before, but here's a mnemonic just in case: Think about how you accidentally fanned some sweat droplets into a dude's face when you fanned yourself a little too hard with a folding fan, causing him to sue (す). Sued for a folding fan faux pas?! Americans really are litigious...

Name: Fraud
Mnemonic: If there are lies and deceit in your interactions with people, you're committing fraud, you're carrying out a scam, you're swindling.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Front Door
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Out of the front door jumps 飛び Ra (とびら). They call him 飛び Ra because he's always flying (飛び) out the front door like that. Every morning 飛び Ra bursts forth from the front door to soak up the sun. He is the Egyptian sun god, after all.

Name: Grandmother
Mnemonic: An old woman, even with an honorific and an お is still an old woman. She might be your grandmother as well, though, so be nice!
ReadingMnemonic: Even if she is your grandmother, something is wrong. You look closely at her face. She's a sheep! Baa! (ばあ).

Name: Grasping
Mnemonic: Put something in your palm and grip it. Now it's in your grasp — you're grasping it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Gravel
Mnemonic: If sand makes a lot of profit, it swells up and becomes gravel. They're like the fat cats of the beach.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned the reading for 利 with the kanji, but the reading for 砂 is irregular, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're walking through that big fat gravel, when a pile of it starts moving, and something suddenly leaps out at you. It's a... jaguar (じゃ)! Run!

Name: Green Tea
Mnemonic: When you roast tea, you get green tea, also known as green leaf teaor sencha.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hat
Mnemonic: A hat child is a hat or cap. Sadly, it's not made from children, unless you're crazy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Heartfelt Desire
Mnemonic: The thing your heart requests is what your heart wants. This is your heartfelt desire.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Hunting
Mnemonic: You know that 狩り is hunting already. This is the same thing (hunting). Difference is this one is attached to other words to specify what kind of hunting you're doing.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 狩り, but since it follows another word, it gets rendaku-ed. Here is a mnemonic to help with remembering the rendaku. Hunting can be girly (がり), if you dress up like a girly hunter.

Name: Insertion
Mnemonic: If you insert and enter something, you are doing insertion to it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Intravenous Drip
Mnemonic: Point drips are drips coming down little by little. These are the drips of an intravenous drip.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ise
Mnemonic: The place with Italy force is a place known as Ise. It's a region of Japan that has a nice peninsula, I think. Going straight to the reading for this one may be your best bet.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out, because this uses the せ, not the せい you're used to seeing.

Name: Katamari Damacy
Mnemonic: A lump spirit is the lump of spirit that's used in the famous game Katamari Damacy.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 塊 and 魂 put together. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Lack
Mnemonic: You lack likeness to anything out there. You totally lack something that gives you likeness. It's a deficiency, or something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lieutenant Colonel
Mnemonic: The middle help in the army or navy is the lieutenant colonel or the navy commander. I'm guessing these ranks are kind of in the middle or middle high end of the ranking scales?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lips
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Love And Hate
Mnemonic: If you have love and hate then you have love and hate.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lower Lip
Mnemonic: The bottom lip is your lower lip or bottom lip.
ReadingMnemonic: したくちびる just combines the kun'yomi vocab reading for 下 and the kun'yomi reading you learned with the kanji for 唇.

Name: Major
Mnemonic: The few who help are the majors or lieutenant commanders. They are the few who step up to the plate to help out in the army, according to this word's kanji.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Makeup
Mnemonic: Change your face with cosmetics! This is via makeup or, of course, cosmetics.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 化 is a new reading, け. To remember this, think about someone putting on makeup. They finish putting it on, and then you say "K, show (けしょう) me!"

Name: Misrepresentation
Mnemonic: If you lie about your title, the title which represents who you are, then that is a misrepresentation. A false statement.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Money
Mnemonic: The freight of cash comes in. What is a freight of cash? It's just money, currency, or coinage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Morning Fog
Mnemonic: Morning fog is morning fog, because it's fog in the morning. This is the best kind of fog, I think.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the readings you learned with both kanji. Be careful of the rendaku.

Name: Mud Wall
Mnemonic: A soil fence is a fence made from soil. Usually this is in the form of a mud wall or an earthen wall.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Old Woman
Mnemonic: An elderly old woman is just an old woman.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: One's Father
Mnemonic: One's parent father is simply just one's father.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this is unfortunately a bit of an exception. 親 uses the kun'yomi おや, and 父 uses the じ reading which you learned with 叔父. You've learned all these readings before, so as long as you remember them, you're good to go. If you don't, check out the mnemonics for these readings on their vocabularies' pages!

Name: Palm
Mnemonic: The kanji means palm, and so does the vocab! This is your palm, as in the palm of one's hand.
ReadingMnemonic: Where is your palm? It's on your 手のhere (てのひら). Right here. I point to your palm and say, "your hand here, that's where your palm is." Another noteworthy thing about this kanji is it can be read as たなごころ. You won't see it read this way as often though so we're only teaching you the main reading.

Name: Paper Money
Mnemonic: Paper cash is paper money.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for 紙 even though you went through all that trouble to learn the kun'yomi reading. Did you know paper money is made of sheep (し)? Well, part sheep, but there's sheep in there for sure. That's why you can wash your paper money with your t-shirts in the washing machine.

Name: Peak
Mnemonic: The peak of the mountain is a peak or mountain.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you climb to the top of the peak, you're so amazed to find vegetation at this altitude. The only thing that grows here, and in thick amounts, is 竹 (たけ). It is impeding your progress to the very top of the peak, in fact, which is a bother. It's as if it's guarding something...

Name: Pitiful
Mnemonic: A possible pathetic scenario you might imagine is probably not just possibly pathetic. It's downright pitiful and pathetic, for sure.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Well, at least most of it does. To remember the reading for 哀 imagine some pathetic person who lost their home. They may be pitiful but at some point after losing their home they decided that the hood of your car would make a fine place to live. You can't help but ask them, "Why (わい) my car?" There are so many other cars this pathetic person could be camping out on, but they chose yours.

Name: Pity
Mnemonic: If something is pathetic then you should have pity on it. You should also feel a little sorrow and grief for it, because seriously, so pathetic!
ReadingMnemonic: You look at the thing you're feeling is so pathetic that you feel pity for and just think... aww (あわ), that's really pathetic.

Name: Point Of Spear
Mnemonic: The spear ahead is the most ahead part of the halberd. That's the point of spear or spearpoint.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the vocab versions of 矛 and 先 combined together.

Name: Pulverization
Mnemonic: To powder I will smash it! If I do that, it's pulverization and smashing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rainbow
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Rainbow Colored
Mnemonic: Rainbow colored things are rainbow colored.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the kanji readings for both 虹 and 色.

Name: Red Light District
Mnemonic: The flower willow for some reason is a red light district. Just imagine a shady red light district, and right in the middle is a flowering willow.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Refreshing
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji, making it refreshing as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same reading you learned with the kanji!

Name: Regret
Mnemonic: A pain grudge is pain you feel from the grudge. I wish I could change my grudge. It is my regret.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rest
Mnemonic: A rest rest is a rest. A break. A recess.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rice Cooker
Mnemonic: A cook food container is a container used to cook the main food staple in Japan. In this case it's a rice cooker.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rubble
Mnemonic: Smashed stone is smashed stone. It's rubble and broken stone.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Senbei
Mnemonic: What do you get when you roast mochi? Senbei, a crispy Japanese rice cracker!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for the second kanji, but if you remember the meaning of the word, that will get you to the reading. In case you're having trouble, here's a mnemonic to help: You sit eating senbei next to a bay (べい), looking out over the water as you crunch.

Name: Shaku
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Shooting Down
Mnemonic: An attack that causes a crash is when you're shooting down something, usually an aircraft.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Side Story
Mnemonic: Insert some extra talking into a story, and you have a side story!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sorrow
Mnemonic: I am sad and pathetic in how I feel. Such a deep sorrow! Such grief from my sad pathetic feelings.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Splittable Chopsticks
Mnemonic: Divideable chopsticks are chopsticks you can split apart. They are splittable chopsticks, almost always made from wood of some kind.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 割る and 箸 put together. Be careful of the rendaku.

Name: Stickiness
Mnemonic: Sticky sticky things are really sticky and covered with stickiness.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 粘る. I suppose you never never want to touch something sticky.

Name: Suddenly
Mnemonic: When something bears a sudden likeness, we say it happens suddenly, or all of a sudden.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Swindle
Mnemonic: You use your lie to take what you want. That's when you swindle or defraud someone to get their stuff. How dare you!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tape Measure
Mnemonic: A scroll of shaku. So, a scroll is all rolled up, right? And a shaku is an older form of Japanese measurement. If you roll up a measuring thing into a scroll-like container... what does it become? A tape measure!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 巻 is the 巻く reading, pushed into the kanji. The 尺 reading is the normal reading of 尺. Careful of the rendaku.

Name: Tatami Mat
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes right from the vocab meaning, which is tatami mat. The たたみ part, specifically.

Name: Thanks To
Mnemonic: 陰 is a shadow, and adding お to it and makes it honorific. It becomes the shadow of someone very important, and means thanks to, as in "thanks to you, I was able to pass the test." This originally comes from the idea of being in the shadow of the gods, who are protecting you and helping you out!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the word 陰. Thanks to that other vocab word, you can read this one!

Name: Thick Fog
Mnemonic: A black fog is going to be a really thick fog or black veil that covers suspicious acts or crimes. It's not a literal cloud of fog or a physical veil, it's what you hide your bad deeds in, metaphorically speaking.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 黒い and 霧.

Name: To Be Rubbed
Mnemonic: This is an intransitive version of 擦る, so it means to be rubbed. It often implies damage, in which case it can mean to be grazed or to be scraped, like when your knee gets grazed against a rough wall.
ReadingMnemonic: You really don’t want your knee to be grazed. If it happens, you are gonna sue (す). But the cost (こす) of suing is pretty high, so be careful not to get grazed in the first place! Depending on which reading you use, the nuance changes slightly. For example, すれる is the usual choice when you’re talking about your grazed knees or worn out jeans. For other uses, they are often interchangeable.

Name: To Be Sticky
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sticky and the verb vocab version is to be sticky. It can also mean to persevere, because if you're being sticky towards the situation, not giving up and not letting go. You're totally persevering by sticking around.
ReadingMnemonic: Will I give up? I'll never (ねば) give up! I'll also never unstick from you.

Name: To Brush One's Teeth
Mnemonic: 磨く is "to polish" or "to shine." If you're doing that to your teeth you are brushing them. That's why this is to brush one's teeth.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 歯 and 磨く, put together.

Name: To Carve Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carve and the verb version is to carve something, or to engrave something.
ReadingMnemonic: Imagine trying to carve something using a hoe (ほ). Its long handle makes it a pretty impractical tool for carving. Now imagine all the trouble you have carving with it.

Name: To Deceive
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deceit, so when you're doing deceit, you are going to deceive someone.
ReadingMnemonic: As a human everyone would know who you are. You can't deceive anyone like that. But, as a moo (あざむ)... a cow is what I mean... nobody would know who you are.

Name: To Drip
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drip and the verb vocab version is to drip.
ReadingMnemonic: To drip drip drip on your head... what's dripping on your head? You're standing below a toilet that's leaking. The dripping sounds like "sh*t, ta-ta (したた), with each drip making a "ta" sound because it's kind of thick and poopy.

Name: To Fan
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means folding fan and since you don't "to folding fan" something, this word means to fan instead.
ReadingMnemonic: Imagine yourself trying to fan yourself with an 青 (あお) fan. For some reason blue fans feel cooler. Maybe it's because they're the color of ice/water?

Name: To Hate
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hate and the verb vocab version is to hate or to detest.
ReadingMnemonic: What do you hate and detest more than anything? 肉 (にく). That stuff is gross, and you detest it.

Name: To Hold A Grudge
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grudge and the verb vocab version is to hold a grudge.
ReadingMnemonic: Who do you hold a grudge against the most? That would be you, Ra (うら). You and your dumb sun.

Name: To Make Something Clear
Mnemonic: 澄む is "to become clear" - this is when you make something clear, because you must (ます) make it clear. You have to. That's why this is or to make something clear or to clear something.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji, so if you know that, that'll make this answer clear too.

Name: To Moisten
Mnemonic: Remember how 湿る is "to be moist"? This is the version where you're doing the moistening, making it to moisten or to dampen.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 湿る.

Name: To Rest
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rest and the verb vocab version is to rest or to relax.
ReadingMnemonic: I'm going to rest and play some Ico (いこ) on the ol' PlayStation.

Name: Torso
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Spill Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means zero, but the verb vocab version means to spill something or to drop something. Think of it this way, if you spill something, eventually it will reach zero.
ReadingMnemonic: Imagine you're co-boiling (こぼ) water with someone. With the two of you co-boiling, the water is boiling pretty hard. Watch out, though — you're about to spill the hot water everywhere!

Name: Train Conductor
Mnemonic: Who drives a car with their palm? The 車 here actually comes from 電車, which is a train, making this person a train conductor. If you think about it, conducting a train involves a lot more palm action because of all those levers and knobs and big buttons, right? Yeah, let's go with that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Upper Lip
Mnemonic: The above lip is the upper lip.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 上 is a bit weird, it's うわ instead of うえ. It's almost like うえ, just a little different.

Name: View
Mnemonic: 眺める is "to stare at." The noun version is view or scene. It's what you're staring at.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 眺める.

Name: Wall
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Willow
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The willow you have outside is a naggy willow, always asking for more water. That's yah naggy weeping willow.

Name: Women's Rights
Mnemonic: A woman's rights consist of women's rights.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Young Lady
Mnemonic: Adding an お in front and a さん behind miss makes for a very respectful way of addressing ayoung lady. It can also be used to refer to somebody’s daughter in a polite manner.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading of 嬢 is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it!

Name: Accomplishment
Mnemonic: Accomplish and go forth! These are your accomplishments. This is your execution of actions.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ancestral Festival Dance
Mnemonic: The ancestral festival dance is the ancestral festival dance, or bon festival dance.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 盆 plus 躍り put together into one word.

Name: And Yet
Mnemonic: Even though you have this habit you're still able to win. That's why this is And yet, though, and in spite of. Because, in spite of your bad habit, you still won. Frustrating.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the word 癖.

Name: Anesthesia
Mnemonic: A hemp drunkness is when you take some "hemp" and put it into your body so you don't really feel anything anymore. This is anesthesia.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Animal Husbandry
Mnemonic: Livestock will give birth to more livestock. You're in the biz of raising livestock, that's why. This is animal husbandry.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Application
Mnemonic: Let's paint a cloth's worth of paint on the wall. This is one application or coating of paint.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Armpit
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Now isn't that a bit wacky (わき)?

Name: Attempt
Mnemonic: I have not yet accomplished anything yet. This is only an attempt, so we'll see how it goes.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Backing
Mnemonic: The rear shield is the shield that protects your back. This is your backing or support. So, not a literal shield, but the kind of protection that you want to have anyways.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 後ろ and 盾 put together. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Brazier
Mnemonic: Start a fire in your flower pot to make a brazier. A nice, homemade brazier. It might ruin the aesthetics of your garden, but at least you'll be warm. (Or you might just burn down your house.)
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the vocab reading for 火 and the reading you learned for 鉢, rendaku'd.

Name: Brightness
Mnemonic: The light's radiance is that of brightness and splendor.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Camouflage
Mnemonic: Astray coloring is coloring that's all over the place. It's astray all over your clothes. This astray coloring is camouflage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cannabis
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, but it also means cannabis as well.
ReadingMnemonic: You always smoke your cannabis in the 朝 (あさ). No other time. Just the 朝.

Name: Clever
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of clever? It's clever or intelligent.
ReadingMnemonic: If you're clever enough, you can start up an awesome company that makes tons of cash. A cash co (かしこ).

Name: Coating
Mnemonic: With paint I want to attire the wall. Let's put a coating of painting up on the wall.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Color
Mnemonic: The color coloring is the color of something.
ReadingMnemonic: 色 uses the しき reading (remember 景色?). Use that here with the 彩 kanji reading.

Name: Comeback
Mnemonic: The return blossom is when the blossoms return. A second bloom. This is another word for a comeback.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the readings from 返る and the kanji 咲. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Contradiction
Mnemonic: A spear and a shield. Totally different things. Not at all like each other. A complete contradiction.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Crevice
Mnemonic: A crevice interval is an area with a crevice or crack.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 隙 is the one you learned with the kanji and the 間 is the 間に合う reading.

Name: Crevice
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Cultivation
Mnemonic: Cultivate and foster something. That's cultivation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Damn It
Mnemonic: The livestock life. The life of a beast! Arghhh, damnit, I hate the life of a beast. Damnit.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dance
Mnemonic: A dance is a dance.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Darkness
Mnemonic: A dark darkness is a darkness. It's the dark.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading of both kanji. The reading from 暗い and the reading of the kanji 闇.

Name: Darkness
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Death From Starvation
Mnemonic: Starve to death is death from starvation... Starving to death.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Diagonal
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: A diagonal is anything that's not a right angle. Even if something is at a 七 (なな) percent angle is a diagonal, slanting, tilted angle.

Name: Disgrace
Mnemonic: If you shame and humiliate me, I will have a sense of disgrace, shame.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading from 恥 is the ち reading, a reading you haven't learned yet. To remember this, just think about how the cheese jock is the biggest disgrace to this sports team. He is cheese, after all. He falls apart and smells funny.

Name: Disgrace
Mnemonic: Yield a humiliation onto your life. What a disgrace. What a humiliation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Domestic Animals
Mnemonic: House broken livestock are domestic animals / livestock. They're made to live with us in or near our homes.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Durability
Mnemonic: I have the nature of being resistant for a long time. Things that are resistant for a long time have good durability.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Edge Of A Sumo Ring
Mnemonic: A soil sack on the edge. Pretend the sacks are lined up around in a circle. It's the edge of a sumo ring. It can also refer to a last moment or critical moment in time, like the moment before getting pushed out of the ring.
ReadingMnemonic: The first two kanji (土俵) use the on'yomi reading you learned. The last kanji 際 uses the kun'yomi reading, which you should know via the vocabulary. Just think of these two parts as somewhat separate bits of the word, which is why one part is on'yomi and another (the addition) is kun'yomi.

Name: Efforts
Mnemonic: If you exhaust power you are putting out efforts.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Electric Light
Mnemonic: An electricity lamp is an electric lamp. Nowadays they're all electricity, though, which means it's a lamp.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Emergency Stores
Mnemonic: I need something to provide to me in an emergency, so I'm amassing emergency stores. I'm building up a stockpile of reserves, just in case.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Endurance
Mnemonic: I'm resistant and I endure. I have much endurance and perseverance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fire Resistant
Mnemonic: If something is resistant to fire then it is fire resistant or fireproof. Turtles are not this.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Flower Pot
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Fluke
Mnemonic: When you're distracted, everything you do is a fluke. You're not focusing, so it all comes down to chance.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. This uses a different reading than the one you've already learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Somebody was trying to mug (まぐ) you, but you managed to escape by pure chance! Your escape might have just been a fluke, but at least you didn't get mugged!

Name: Frost
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Guess
Mnemonic: A recollection and measurement of the situation is what I use to make a guess and speculation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Harvest
Mnemonic: Obtain a harvest. When you do this you have a harvest or crop.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Headband
Mnemonic: Above your flower pot hangs a scroll, but it's not just there for decoration — you can also use it as a headband when you're gardening! Planting flowers is sweaty work, after all, and a good headband can make all the difference.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the reading of 鉢 and 巻く, put together into one word. The reading's pretty weird, but hopefully you can wrap it around your head.

Name: Heat Resistant
Mnemonic: If something is resistant to heat then it is heat resistant or heatproof.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hit
Mnemonic: An punch hit is a hit or strike or blow. Not a friendly hit, that's for sure.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji.

Name: Imperialism
Mnemonic: The Empire (帝国) ism (主義) is when you are doing imperialism. Long live the emperor!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the two words this word is made up of, 帝国 and 主義.

Name: Italics
Mnemonic: When text has a diagonal body to it, it is leaning. It is in italics or the italic font style.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Jockey
Mnemonic: 手 takes its alternative meaning "doer" here, so that gives us horse riding doer. Who does horse riding? It’s a jockey.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Knight
Mnemonic: A horse riding samurai is also known as a knight. Onward, knights of the round! Off to find the holy grail!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lamp
Mnemonic: The meaning of this noun is the same as the kanji, lamp. Can also mean light and torch as well, depending on where you herald from.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is like that of 明るい, which means "bright." At least the あか part is the same. What is a lamp if not 明るい (あか)? Another way to think of it is "what is a bright color?" The color 赤 (あか) is a bright color and would make a sexy lamp.

Name: Landing
Mnemonic: While a dance location can be a location in which you dance, this word actually means landing (as in, a landing between two flights of stairs on a staircase) or plateau (as in, for example, a plateauing economy) most of the time.
ReadingMnemonic: You know all the readings for this vocab already, just make sure to use the kun'yomi ones!

Name: Late Flower
Mnemonic: A slow bloom is a bloom that happens late. It's a late flower or late blooming. Important to know if you're going to go do 花見.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 遅い and 咲く put together (the same reading you learned from the 咲 kanji). Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Lava
Mnemonic: It can melt a boulder? What is this stuff that's so hot? It's lava. It's also probably made from melted boulders too, come to think of it.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the kanji, but you haven't learned the on'yomi reading for 岩, which is がん. When you think of lava, think about Gandhi, coming out of the lava. He's immune, because he's a robot.

Name: Looking Away
Mnemonic: If you look to your armpit to see you're looking away from where you should be looking. If you're too busy staring at your armpit while you drive, for example, you'll probably get in an accident. So don't look away like this!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned with 脇 and the reading for 見る.

Name: Luminance
Mnemonic: The radiance degrees show the luminance and brightness of something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Marijuana
Mnemonic: Big hemp is marijuana or cannabis.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Memo Book
Mnemonic: A memo (メモ) notebook is a memo book or memo pad that you use to write notes in.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, plus メモ.

Name: Memory
Mnemonic: When you record recollections in your mind, that concept is the concept of memory. This word is not a specific memory, instead it's the idea of memory itself. So, uh, try to memorize that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mosquito
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Mosquito Net
Mnemonic: A mosquito notebook, for some reason, is a mosquito net. Think of a notebook with graph paper lines on it, perhaps. These lines are shaped like a net. Surround yourself with it to make your own mosquito net.
ReadingMnemonic: The first kanji, 蚊, uses the reading you learned. The second kanji has an exceptional reading, や. To remember や, think about how you had to take a giant mosquito net and cover all of Yankee (や) Stadium. They have a rough mosquito problem.

Name: Notebook
Mnemonic: A hand notebook is a notebook you can hold in your hand. This could simply be a notebook, but it could also be a planner.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.

Name: Oil Painting
Mnemonic: Oil coloring is better known as oil painting. What fine strokes! What fine lines!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Paint
Mnemonic: Paint material is paint, or painting material.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Quick
Mnemonic: Things that are swift and fast are going to be quick and fast and rapid and swift. So many quick things.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Registry
Mnemonic: Please record it in the notebook. This will be the registry.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Regret
Mnemonic: My behind regret is the regret from before, which is all regret. So this means regret, or repentance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Regrettable
Mnemonic: The kanji is regret and this is regrettable. And something regrettable is likely to be frustrating, vexing, or disappointing.
ReadingMnemonic: It's regrettable if you're not cool, yah (くや)? Yah, that would be pretty vexing.

Name: Sage
Mnemonic: A wise person is a sage! Or you can just be straightforward and call them a wise person.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Savings
Mnemonic: Take your savings and amass them. That is your savings.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Shield
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Think of a big ol' shield. It's so big it will stand (立て) tall right in front of you.

Name: Slant
Mnemonic: A diagonal surface is a slant. A slope.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Snake
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Squad
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Squad Leader
Mnemonic: The squad leader is the squad leader. Can also be the honcho (ever wonder where this word came from?).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Stapler
Mnemonic: This word means stapler. It comes from the name of the company that first imported staplers into Japan: Hotchkiss! Here’s a mnemonic to help you remember it:

Name: Starvation
Mnemonic: One person starves and another person starves. Then more people. So much starve that there's starvation going on. It's famine and hunger, everywhere.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Streetlight
Mnemonic: A street lamp is a streetlight. Brightening up my street!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Supporting Actor
Mnemonic: If you're on armpit duty you're definitely not the lead. You're standing next to the lead's armpit, because you're the supporting actor. You're in a supporting role.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 脇's reading and 役's reading, put together.

Name: Telephone Book
Mnemonic: A telephone (電話) notebook is a book you use with your telephone. It's a telephone book or telephone directory.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Thoughtlessly
Mnemonic: "Darkness is nothing to worry about," I said thoughtlessly and unreasonably. Of course darkness is worth worrying about. It's darkness! Who knows what is in there!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

Name: Threat
Mnemonic: The thing that will threaten and then urge you to do something else is the threat and menace.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Amass
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means amass and the verb vocab version is to amass.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to amass things, so you take one (たくわ) and put it aside, then take one more and put it aside again. Repeat this process of taking one over and over and you’ll quickly store up lots of things.

Name: To Be Used Up
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means use up or exhaust, and this verb is to be used up, to be exhausted, or to run out.
ReadingMnemonic: If something is exhausted it's because you used up too (つ) much of it, and now it's all gone.

Name: To Bloom
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blossom or bloom and the verb version is to bloom.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Color Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means coloring so the verb vocab version is to color something, because you're doing coloring.
ReadingMnemonic: You go to color something, painting the coloring all over the wall. Problem is, the coloring is made of ACID. This causes the wall to erode (いろど).

Name: To Cook
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cook and the verb vocab version is to cook or to boil. Often it has to do with cooking grains (to cook grains).
ReadingMnemonic: When you cook something, it's like you're attacking (たく) the food with boiling water or fire or whatever. Attack the food by cooking it!

Name: To Cultivate
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cultivate and the verb vocab version means to cultivate.
ReadingMnemonic: You want to cultivate new friendships, so you decide to foster connection with two chicas (つちか), hoping to bring more people into your life. Now, no matter what you want to cultivate, you'll always have two chicas there to help you out.

Name: To Dance
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dance and the verb vocab version means to dance.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Endure
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means resistant. If you're resisting things, then you're enduring and withstanding them. That's why this is to endure and to withstand.
ReadingMnemonic: What is it that you have to endure? A barrage of tacos (た), coming at you.

Name: To Get Spilled
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 零す.

Name: To Humiliate
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means humiliate so the verb vocab version is to humiliate or to disgrace.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember the word 恥ずかしい? It has the same reading as this one, and a similar meaning as well.

Name: To Melt Something
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means melt and this word means to melt something or to melt. You're doing the melting, and you know it because you are the cause (かす) of the melting.
ReadingMnemonic: The thing that you melted in this situation is your toe (と). Feel your toe getting melted away. Augghh it hurts.

Name: To Paint
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means paint and the verb vocab version is to paint and to plaster and to lacquer.
ReadingMnemonic: Let's put a new (ぬ) layer of paint on the wall. Then we'll plaster it.

Name: To Paste
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means paste so the verb vocab is to paste (or to stick).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: To Punch
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means punch, so the verb means to punch, to strike, or to hit.
ReadingMnemonic: Someone is nagging (なぐ) you and nagging you about something. You can't take it any more, so you turn around to punch them in the face.

Name: To Shine
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means radiance. Imagine if something is radiating on something else. That would cause it to shine or to glitter or to sparkle.
ReadingMnemonic: The cog yak is so shiny. It's so shiny that it starts to shine and glitter. I don't know what a cog yak is, but imagine it in your head and imagine it being super shiny, shining off shines and glitter.

Name: To Smash
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means smash and the verb vocab version of the kanji is to smash or to break.
ReadingMnemonic: You want to smash my stuff? That's coo' だ (くだ). Whatever you wanna do.

Name: To Starve
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means starve and the verb vocab version is to starve.
ReadingMnemonic: When you're about to starve, what do you yearn for? Uni (う), of course! As your hunger intensifies, all you can think of is uni!

Name: Unreasonable
Mnemonic: Reason is not exhausted... but what you're asking is unreasonable. Soon my reason will be exhausted, though.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Watercolor Painting
Mnemonic: A water coloring painting is a watercolor painting.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Water Soluble
Mnemonic: With water it will melt. It is naturally like this. It is water soluble.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Wheelchair
Mnemonic: You know that 椅子 is a "chair." What about a car chair? It's a chair with wheels. A wheelchair.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 車 is the vocab reading, くるま. Then, 椅子 is いす.

Name: Wise
Mnemonic: You're wise and bright so obviously you're going to make wise decisions too — sensible in every regard. In fact, when you make these very wise choices and judgment calls, your brain glows brightly.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Wizard
Mnemonic: You know that 魔法 is "magic" so what about someone who uses magic? What are they called? How about a wizard, witch, or sorcerer?
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 魔法 is what you learned with the kanji. The reading for 使い is the same as 使う.

Name: Abstraction
Mnemonic: The thing you extract from a phenomenon is an abstraction. Extracting abstraction out of a phenomenon may not sound like a very concrete or vivid mnemonic, but I guess that makes it an appropriate abstraction…
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Approximation
Mnemonic: An approximation of the calculation is an approximation or rough estimate.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Associate Professor
Mnemonic: Remember 教授 meaning "professor"? That makes this a semi professor, or in other words, an associate professor.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Boiled Foods
Mnemonic: Boiled things turn into boiled foods or stewed foods. You can eat anything, if it's boiled long enough.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji.

Name: Buddhist Altar
Mnemonic: A buddha podium is the podium on which you put Buddha. This is a Buddhist altar.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Calculation With Abacus
Mnemonic: A pearl calculation is calculations you do with pearls. If you think about using pearls to calculate something, it's going to look a lot like using an abacus. That's why this calculation is calculation with abacus.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Capsizing
Mnemonic: It revolves then capsizes. When a ship revolves onto its back and then capsizes, this causes capsizing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Ceramic Art
Mnemonic: The pottery art is making pottery. That is the ceramic arts or simply ceramics.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chess Piece
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that this can also refer to a shogi piece or any other board game piece as well!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Conquest
Mnemonic: I will subjugate everyone to wear the clothes I want them to wear. They will wear my uniform, for they will be under my subjugation. I will conquest them!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Conspiracy
Mnemonic: Under the shade people conspire. When people do this, conspiracy appears.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Crane
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the vocab.

Name: Crown Princess
Mnemonic: Remember how 皇太子 is "crown prince"? Turn this crown prince into a "crown prince princess." So, this is the crown princess.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Currency Value
Mnemonic: 貨幣 is "currency" and 価値 is "value." This shows the currency value. Hopefully it's good for you when you visit Japan!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Decline
Mnemonic: Something that declines and retreats from decline is something that's on a decline. It's also decay.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Detention
Mnemonic: Arrest and put the criminal in detention and confinement. Get in there, criminal!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Deterioration
Mnemonic: Your inferiority has changed. In fact, it's getting worse and worse, changing by the minute. Each minute that goes by is another minute where you're getting worse. This is deterioration.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dimness
Mnemonic: 明瞭 is "clarity." If there is not any of this clarity, then you have dimness or obscurity.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Erosion
Mnemonic: Something that invades and eats away at something is something that causes erosion and corrosion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Every Other Month
Mnemonic: If you isolate this month from next month, and then do that over and over again, you'll be looking at every other month isolated from the other months.

Name: To Be Cooked
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb, so it means to be cooked, to be boiled, or to be done cooking. Also a little cultural note — this word is used for both rice, and other foods in western Japan, while it's only used for rice in eastern Japan.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 炊く.

Unfortunately, you get lost down there, and it takes you fifty years to get back to the pit you came in from. But your auto rope is gone! This is the last time you buy an organic rope, made to decay and to wither away when left in the wild.

Name: To Kick

And since you haven't learned the on'yomi for the kanji 蹴 (kick) yet, here's a mnemonic to help you: When you're planning to flatly reject someone, one kick is all you need. Before you do that, be absolutely sure to put your shoe (しゅう) on first.

ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Whenever you start to panic you can't help but blurt out, "A wha- (あわ)?" to everything people say and ask. For example, "Would you like a mint?" "A WHA?!" Yeah, you really do sound upset.
