ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a reading you've known your whole life. It's like you were born with the reading, whispering in your ear, ready to emerge at just the right moment... and that moment is now.

Name: Ancient Tomb
Mnemonic: An old tomb is an ancient tomb. They're mostly from the Kofun period, and indeed that's where the period gets its name.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Aunt
Mnemonic: Who is the chief mother? That's your aunt. And this aunt is the older sister of your mom or dad because she is the chief mother. An aunt who is a younger sister of your parent is 叔母, which is another word for "aunt" you already know!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the 叔母 which means aunt too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one aunt, you know them all.

Name: Brand
Mnemonic: The inscription's pattern shows what brand or make this item is. If the pattern of the inscription is an apple, you'll know the brand is Apple. If it's a Window, you know it's Microsoft. Etc.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second. Luckily, you've learned them both already so you should be able to slap them together and know the reading of this word!

Name: By Chance
Mnemonic: Something that happened accidentally by nature probably happened by chance or unexpectedly. It was just a coincidence!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Carry Out
Mnemonic: Transport and exit these goods from here (by transporting them). Take it away. It's time to carry out.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cavalry
Mnemonic: A horse riding soldier is a member of the cavalry.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cave
Mnemonic: A cave hole is a cave or den.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading of 洞 is one you've learned. The reading of 穴 isn't one you've learned, though. So, think about how you go inside this cave, only to find yourself covered by some red goopy liquid. You think it's blood, but luckily it just turns out to be ketsup (けつ). If you want to be less formal, you can also use the kun'yomi and say ほらあな, but then you'd never learn that reading for 穴, and where's the fun in that?

Name: Cave
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Hoe Ra (ほら), the version of Ra who carries a hoe around, is using said hoe to dig out a cave for himself, to provide shade from the sun (despite being the god of sun). He digs digs digs and then sits in his nice cave, hoe in hand.

Name: Change One's Mind
Mnemonic: When you flip your idea of something, you're changing how you think about it. That's why this word is change one's mind.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chief
Mnemonic: The chief of this district is that guy, the count. He's also the earl of another district, and the chief of yet another.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the はく reading you learned with the kanji.

Name: Clever
Mnemonic: Something that is adept but peculiar in how adept it is would have to be something truly clever and ingenious. Like a clever scam or trick.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cold
Mnemonic: A wind that is wicked comes and blows on you. It's so cold, and ends up getting you sick. You now have a cold.
ReadingMnemonic: Strangely, the reading for this word is the same as the vocab reading of 風 (かぜ). That's probably going to be the easiest way to remember this, especially since otherwise the reading would be one big horrible exception.

Name: Coloring
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji and has the same meaning as well: coloring.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading has いろ (like 色) in it, then a ど, so think about an 色 dog, running around coloring things, because that's what an 色 dog does.

Name: Comic Dialogue
Mnemonic: A comic talent! And not just one, but two comic talents, because this means a comic dialogue or a comedy double act.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Correction
Mnemonic: When you revise something to make it correct you are doing a correction and revision.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Counter For Bundles
Mnemonic: The kanji refers to a bundle, but this refers to a counter for bundles. Put this on a number, and you have "1 bundle" or "2 bundles" or even three, oh my!
ReadingMnemonic: Saying "1 bundle" and "2 bundle" takes too long, so you decide to call these bundles what they look like: わ for walrus (わ)!

Name: Court
Mnemonic: The law courts are the courts you visit to get law distributed. The room in which you do this in is a courtroom.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Crab
Mnemonic: The meaning is the same as the kanji's meaning, crab. If you know this word, and you know the word 鰐 as well... then, well, you know something, though I'm not sure what that something is.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. But you knew that already, didn't you?

Name: Dam
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Deep Impression
Mnemonic: A feeling of inscription is the feeling one gets when something so strong happens that it's like the feeling gets inscribed into your soul. This is something that left a very deep impression.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Devious
Mnemonic: Someone who is bad but also clever (賢い) is someone who is using their cleverness for evil. When you refer to clever evil people, usually you describe them not as "clever" but as devious, cunning, or other things.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 悪い and 賢い combined together into one word. Be careful of the rendaku.

Name: Drifting
Mnemonic: Drifting down the stream. Something that is doing this is drifting. It could also be the drift of something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Drifting Ashore
Mnemonic: Something has drifted to the point where it has arrived. Where do drifting things arrive? They arrive on shore (as they drift on top of water). That makes this word drifting ashore.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Each
Mnemonic: You look at this inscription then you look at that inscription and you notice that each one is an individual inscription.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Embankment
Mnemonic: The embankment prevents the water from going over the edge. It's an embankment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Embankment
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is like the reading of 包み, which means "bundle" or "package." Try to think of an embankment that's made purely from bundles and packages. These 包み(つつみ) are the only thing holding the water in!

Name: Excitement
Mnemonic: My interest is stirred up! I'm feeling excitement and stimulation from all this stirring up, in fact!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 興奮 is one you didn't learn with the kanji, though it's similar. Instead of きょう it's こう, so just think of how whenever you feel excitement, it's thanks to こういち. So just think of こういち exciting you in some way to remember this vocab's reading.

Name: Fistfight
Mnemonic: Remember 殴る, which means "to punch"? Well, add on 合う and you've got punches that have come together with other punches. By "come together" I mean your fist is coming in contact with someone's face, and their fist is coming in contact with your kidneys. In other words, this is a fistfight.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings come from 殴る and 合う, punched together.

Name: Futility
Mnemonic: Nothing but burdensome. That's all you get out of doing this task. The futility of it is ridiculous. The uselessness is huge.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Geta
Mnemonic: Look below you. These things carry your burdensome weight. All of it. These are the shoes you wear, though in this case they are specifically geta, or Japanese wooden clogs. The clogs themselves are kind of burdensome and hard to wear too, actually, so you can think of it that way as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 駄 is the secondary kanji reading. Instead of だ it's た. Hopefully you've heard of "geta" before. This will make it really easy for you to remember the reading of this vocab word.

Name: Gloomy
Mnemonic: Gloom pottery is... well, it's gloomy and depressing!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening, and don't be tricked by the hiragana sticking out. The readings of the kanji don't change.

Name: Gloomy Mood
Mnemonic: A gloomy energy has filled the room. This puts you in a gloomy mood. You are now feeling downcast.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the shortening of 鬱 or you'll feel gloomy.

Name: Grasp
Mnemonic: Using the grasp meaning of 把 and combining it with grip, you can tell you're grasping at something and then gripping it. I usually grasp then grip at things flying at me, which makes this word mean grasp or understand.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Grave
Mnemonic: A tomb grave is a grave... or it could be a tomb. Or maybe both.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hemp Cloth
Mnemonic: A hemp cloth is a hemp cloth.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the individual vocab readings of 麻 and 布 combined together.

Name: Hindrance
Mnemonic: A wicked devil! Ugh, I hate those things. They're always a hindrance and intrusion. Just imagine a wicked devil hanging out in your house, eating your food, and sleeping on your bed. What a hindrance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hollow
Mnemonic: A sky cave is a cave with sky (open space) in it. This is a hollow, but can also refer to a cavity.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hunger
Mnemonic: You've seen that 飢える is "to starve." The noun version is hunger or starvation.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 飢える.

Name: Immunity
Mnemonic: To excuse yourself from the epidemic, you'll have to have immunity or immunization from the disease.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Imperial Court
Mnemonic: Shinto shrine courts are the courts of the Shinto shrines. Shinto is often associated with the emperor, which is why this the imperial court. Royal court will do as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 宮 is one you haven't seen before. Just think about how cute (きゅう) this imperial court is. It's a My Little Pony imperial court, or something.

Name: Infectious Disease
Mnemonic: An epidemic of sickness is going to come from an infectious disease. Perhaps a plague or epidemic of some kind?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Innocence
Mnemonic: If there is nothing wicked about your spirit at all, you are a going to be an innocent and simple minded person.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Japanese Empress
Mnemonic: The emperor empress is the emperor's wife. That's the Japanese Empress, specifically, since 皇 usually refers to the Japanese emperor.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the rendaku.

Name: Magnificent
Mnemonic: It's so robust and big! Things like this are magnificent, grand, and epic!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Manga
Mnemonic: Comic drawings are manga, a.k.a. Japanese comics.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mountain Range
Mnemonic: Take along this summit and move it across a range, visiting more summits. One summit after another you take the summit along to. By covering this many summits, you notice there's a string of mountains. This is a mountain range!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Mulberry Field
Mnemonic: A mulberry field is a mulberry field.
ReadingMnemonic: These are both the kun'yomi readings, but you haven't learned this for 原 yet. It's actually the rendaku'd version, so let's just use a mnemonic to remember it instead: You know you're in a mulberry field when you see a bunch of capybaras (ばら) rolling around in there with you. Capybaras love mulberries! Picture a whole family of capybaras munching on mulberries. Mm Mmm!

Name: Not Good
Mnemonic: If something is burdensome to the eye (when you look at it), you know that that thing is not good or hopeless. Just look at that burdensome thing with your eye. This can also mean not allowed. Parents say this to their kids all the time.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.

Name: Occasionally
Mnemonic: Something you do accidentally is hopefully something you do occasionally or once in a while.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Occasionally Tamara (たま), the local ball girl, will take a break from her duties. But it's really only once in a while, because Tamara is such a hard worker.

Name: One's Lifetime
Mnemonic: A life horizon is your life, which you're looking out over, all the way to the very end. This is one's lifetime, though it could also refer to one's career. Basically, at the end of it something dies.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Orbit
Mnemonic: A rut in the road is for some reason an orbit or trajectory. Maybe imagine a big ol' rut in the road. You drive at it at very high speeds, hit it, and fly into the sky at a trajectory that will send you into orbit. Now you're up in space, circling the earth, wishing you didn't drive so fast.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pompous
Mnemonic: Someone tries to make you look up to them... twice. That's too many times to look up to someone. When this happens, this person must be pompous.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, x2 with a しい added on for good measure.

Name: Prime Of Life
Mnemonic: Your robust years are the best years of your life! This is the prime of life.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Public Acknowledgement
Mnemonic: You want people to express how they feel about you in a clear manner, so you demand they give you public acknowledgement. You want clear, concise public recognition for all of your amazing talents, skills, and for reaching level 50 of WaniKani. Maybe they'll throw you a parade!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Public Notice
Mnemonic: A public announcement is a public notice.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Quarantine
Mnemonic: We have to examine you during this epidemic... soooo, if you could come over here and just stay here for a long time, that'd be great. Yeah, it's kind of a quarantine, sorry about that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Question
Mnemonic: I need to consult you on this problem, if I could. I have a question / enquiry I'd like to ask you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Radiance
Mnemonic: If 輝く is "to shine" or "to glitter" think about the noun version of this. This would be radiance. Radiance can come in the form of shining and glittering.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 輝く.

Name: Raid
Mnemonic: Punch your way into a place, and you're launching a raid.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from the word 殴る and the kanji 込.

Name: Register Of Names
Mnemonic: A name record book is a book that contains names. That is a register of names or a list of names. Is your name on the list?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Religious Faith
Mnemonic: I believe and look up to a higher power, for I have religious faith.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for the 仰 portion is an exceptional one. Instead of ぎょう it's こう. Just remember, when it comes to religious faith, all you need to believe in is こういち.

Name: Restaurant
Mnemonic: If you see the kanji restaurant attached to a place name, there's a good chance that it's a restaurant, especially a traditional Japanese restaurant. It also crops up on the end of other places where you can rest, like inns, those traditional pavilions you see in Japanese parks and temple grounds, and tea houses.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Name: Revised Edition
Mnemonic: The renewed and revised edition of something is the revised edition.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Rhythm
Mnemonic: The law of movement is governed by rhythm. Imagine moving around to a boss beat. As you move, you start to feel the rhythm in your step. Go ahead and walk around your room and feel this rhythm.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Riding A Horse
Mnemonic: A horse riding horse is what you need for riding a horse.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Send-Off
Mnemonic: You want to make someone feel robust when they go away somewhere, so you give them a send-off. It's just a nice way to say farewell!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Spouse
Mnemonic: Distribute yourself accidentally to someone. That person ended up becoming your spouse. You distributed yourself to one person a little too much, it seems.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Stirring
Mnemonic: I'm stirred up causing me to wake up. I'm stirring and rousing oneself.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Summit
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be peak or ridge.
ReadingMnemonic: Look up at the summit. It's such a mean (みね) summit. So big, so stormy, so mean.

Name: Taken Aback
Mnemonic: I look up to heaven, and I am taken aback and amazed by it. It's just so amazing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Accomplish
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accomplish and the verb vocab version is to accomplish.
ReadingMnemonic: Everything you've accomplished can be stored in your single little pinky toe (と)... you haven't accomplished that much, apparently.

Name: To Be Boiled
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji. Good for you!

Name: To Billow
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. While the kanji means flip, the verb vocab version is to billow or to flutter, as in some kind of material (maybe a dress or a flag) billowing or fluttering in the wind. It can also mean to suddenly change your mind, or your attitude, etc.
ReadingMnemonic: For something to billow and to flutter, you'll need to ask the here guy (ひるがえ) - that's guy who's here right now - to open the window and let in the breeze.

Name: To Burn
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lamp, so the verb version is to burn or to be lit. Just like what you'd do with a lamp.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who wanted the candle to be lit? Tom (とも) Cruise. He's afraid of the dark so he always wants all the lights and candles in the house to be burning at all times.

Name: To Consult With
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means consult and the verb vocab version is to consult with or to discuss.
ReadingMnemonic: You need to consult with a hacker (はか) to solve your hacking problem. Imagine consulting with a hacker, whatever a hacker looks like in your mind.

Name: To Drift
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drift and the verb vocab version is to drift or to waft.
ReadingMnemonic: You're going to drift away. Drifting drifting drifting. Then, you turn into a yo-yo and yell "ta-da yo-yo (ただよ)! Not sure why drifting turns you into a yo-yo, but imagine it and don't question it.

Name: To Exhaust Something
Mnemonic: 尽きる is "to be exhausted". 尽くす is when you're doing the exhausting of something, which makes it to exhaust something or to run out. It can also mean to devote oneself to a certain cause.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 尽きる.

Name: To Look Up At
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means look up to and the verb vocab version is to look up at or to look up to.
ReadingMnemonic: Personally, I look up to the color 青 (あお). Literally and figuratively. I love the color blue, so I look up to it and respect it. Also, I look up at the sky and it's blue.

Name: To Melt
Mnemonic: 溶かす is "to melt something" and that makes 溶ける to melt (where something just melts, and you're not doing the melting).
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 溶かす.

Name: To Regret
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means regret and the verb vocab version is to regret or to mourn.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading comes from 悔しい.

Name: To Save
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means savings, so the verb vocab version would become to save or to save up.
ReadingMnemonic: This shares a reading with 蓄える, which makes sense, as the meanings of them are very close to each other! If you’re not sure you remember the reading, here’s the mnemonic once more to help you remember it: You need to save up things, so you take one (たくわ) and put it aside, then take one more and put it aside again. Repeat this process of taking one over and over and you’ll quickly save up lots of things.

Name: To Threaten
Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means threaten and the verb vocab version is to threaten.
ReadingMnemonic: I'm going to threaten you with your life if you have a bad odor (おど). Imagine someone with a bad odor, then threaten them.

Name: Track
Mnemonic: Rut traces left in the road are tracks that mark the trajectory of a vehicle’s wheels.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Translation
Mnemonic: Flip the translation of a word from one language to another. That is the translation of that word (or phrase, etc.).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Transport
Mnemonic: To carry you and transport you. That's a form of transport. Could also be a carriage, which is also a form of transport.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Name: Transportation
Mnemonic: Things that transport and send you places are forms of transportation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Uncle
Mnemonic: Who is the chief father? That's your uncle. And this uncle is the older brother of your mom or dad because he is the chief father. An uncle who is a younger brother of your parent is 叔父, which is another word for "uncle" you already know!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the 叔父 which means uncle too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one uncle, you know them all.

Name: Wicked
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a long reading for such a short word! Think of something being wicked. Evil, even! But what is wicked? It's the side of the island... but only the side. It's the 横島 (よこしま).

Name: Yodogawa
Mnemonic: The eddy river isn't so much a thing as it is a famous place. We're talking about Yodogawa. It might be better to look at the reading to learn the meaning. Look up this Osaka Prefecture river if you'd like more info.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is 淀 plus 川. Be careful of the rendaku.

Name: Affection
Mnemonic: When you have mercy upon those you love it's called affection. You end up doing things out of the kindness of your heart because they mean a lot to you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Again
Mnemonic: The meaning of this word and the meaning of the kanji are the same: Again!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading you learned for the kanji is the same as the reading for this word. You hopefully won't have to learn it... again.

Name: Arable Land
Mnemonic: Plowed land is called arable land. This is the kind of land you use for growing crops or for pastures.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Awaken
Mnemonic: If you scream wake up! at someone you can bet they're going to awaken. Screaming anything at a sleeping person would probably rouse them. They'll probably be mad at you though.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bay
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Blood Relative
Mnemonic: Those sharing blood within a tribe are blood relatives.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Boiling Point
Mnemonic: The point at which something starts to boil is the boiling point.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bottle
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Bottling
Mnemonic: What's stuffed in the bottle? Jam you bottled for later! How could you forget?
ReadingMnemonic: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 瓶 and the kun'yomi reading for 詰 that you learned when you learned 詰める. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too! Just remember that 詰 is taking the め from 詰める with it in this word too. You can't see it, but it's there.

Name: Calculation
Mnemonic: When you use your intuition to determine the amount of something, you'll end up doing the calculations in your head. You do the same thing when it's time to pay your bill at dinner too: just determine the amount in your head, go with your intuition, and all should be good.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. However, 定 uses a reading you didn’t learn, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're having trouble with the calculation of your bill, just call Joe (じょう)! He’s surprisingly good with numbers, so whenever you’re lost at the restaurant table, just give him a quick call.

Name: Charity
Mnemonic: A morally good person who has mercy upon people gives to charity. These people prove they're good by mercifully giving all their money away to the poor and needy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chastity
Mnemonic: Chastity is always in season so it's always cool to try to keep your chastity. Spring, summer? Doesn't matter. Your decision to stay that way is fine no matter what time of year it is.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chastity
Mnemonic: You are a strong, independent person and you are the only one who can manipulate your chastity. Nobody else can. So if you want to keep your chastity that's completely up to you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Collar
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Compassion
Mnemonic: If you have mercy for people who are sad you have a lot of compassion. You just can't help but go easy on sad people.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Corner
Mnemonic: A one sided corner is still a corner, just a really small one.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Corner
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Cultivation
Mnemonic: Plow the earth to make it ready for cultivation and farming.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dehydration
Mnemonic: Even something dry will dry up more if it's got dehydration. There's a lot of dryness going on here.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Detergent
Mnemonic: Wash wash powder is the detergent you put in the wash you make sure your clothes are washed well. Detergent used to only be available in powder form back in the old days, and it still can be, so this is for that good powdery stuff.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a mix of the on'yomi readings for 洗濯 and the kun'yomi reading for 粉. You already learned this reading for 粉 when you learned the word 小麦粉. If you can remember that, you should know the readings for this one too!

Name: District
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Dry Cleaners
Mnemonic: The wash wash shop is where you go to get your clothes washed extra well. It's the dry cleaners! They wash your clothes way better than you can because they wash them twice.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a mix of the on'yomi readings for 洗濯 and the kun'yomi reading for 屋. You've learned all of these readings by now, so you should be able to read this word too!

Name: Drying Up
Mnemonic: Something that will wither and dry up ends up doing exactly that, drying up. And as it dries up, there's less and less of it until there's nothing left. This is called depletion!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 渇 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If all of your plants are drying up you should just give them to your cats (かつ). Cats love to play with dried up plants. At least they won't go to waste.

Name: Ehime Prefecture
Mnemonic: The prefecture in Japan where they love princesses is Ehime Prefecture.
ReadingMnemonic: This reading is a little messy. This reading for 愛 is an exception, 媛 uses the kun'yomi reading ひめ, and 県 uses the on'yomi reading けん. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading for 愛: If you ask anyone outside of Ehime Prefecture what they think of princesses they'll respond with, "Eh" (え). They don't really care either way. If someone from Ehime heard that they'd says, "EH? EH?! Princesses are the BEST!"

Name: Empty Bottle
Mnemonic: A sky bottle is a bottle that has nothing but sky in it. It's an empty bottle.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. You learned this reading for 空 when you learned 空き缶. If you can remember that, you can remember this too!

Name: Engaging In Work
Mnemonic: You must obey your business. When you're in this situation, you’re engaging in work.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Explanation
Mnemonic: Even if you untie an explanation it's still a pretty good explanation anyway.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Explanation
Mnemonic: An explanation that's bright is just a really clear and well developed explanation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Farming
Mnemonic: Farming with a plow is still farming.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fat
Mnemonic: If you add fat to fat, what do you get? You get fat, obviously. Come on now, this isn't rocket science.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Faucet
Mnemonic: This isn't a literal snake's mouth, but rather a faucet. They do kind of have a resemblance though, just think about how the shape of a faucet kind of resembles that of a snake, with water coming out of its mouth.
ReadingMnemonic: This one's a little unique, as it uses on'yomi for 蛇, and kun'yomi (which gets rendaku'd) for 口. You didn't learn this reading for 蛇, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Every time you try to drink from the faucet, you get viciously attacked by a jaguar (じゃ). Trying to drink from the faucet has become a fight for life and death. You just know the jaguar is hiding right there behind the faucet, guarding it.

Name: Flexible
Mnemonic: A gentle and soft thing will be really flexible and pliable. Soft things are really easy to bend, like towels and flower petals.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Four Corners
Mnemonic: Four corners are four corners!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both by now, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Great
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of greatness? Great!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The only thing a great person doesn't do is make errors (えら). That's what makes them so great. They can always sense when an error is about to happen and they correct it before it even has a chance!

Name: Greatness
Mnemonic: Big greatness is still greatness, just a lot of it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Great Person
Mnemonic: A person with a lot of greatness is a great person.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Grounds
Mnemonic: The land inside of a residence is called the grounds or the premises. Only really big residences have land inside them big enough to be called the "grounds" though.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: House Arrest
Mnemonic: Soft prohibition isn't going to be as bad as jail or prison. They went soft on you, so you're only under house arrest. That's not so bad, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hurried
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い all the way at the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. Confused is already an adjective and this word is a little different. Usually when you get confused it's because you were already hurried, busy, and things were hectic. So this adjective is what causes your confusion.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned this reading, so you should be able to read this already!

Name: Impatience
Mnemonic: If you want to char fish for dinner it will dry up because of your own impatience. Charring fish takes time and if you're too uneasy and shove it too far in the fire it will dry out, burn, and get gross.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Internal Cause
Mnemonic: The inside cause is an internal cause. Internal causes are usually the nastiest causes, if you ask me.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Laws
Mnemonic: Laws are standard in society. You must have laws and regulations in society.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Lotus Flower
Mnemonic: A lotus flower originally means lotus flower, but these days 蓮花 often refers to a small flower that looks like a lotus, called a Chinese milk vetch. It can also mean a ramen spoon, because those spoons you get with ramen have a unique shape resembling a lotus petal.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 花 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Something is on the lotus flower... something little and kinda shiny. It's a little gecko (げ). It's hiding in the lotus and trying to catch flies. How cute!

Name: Mansion
Mnemonic: If you have a residence that's also your house, it's still your residence. But you probably have a lot of money if you can own your own house, so it's probably a nice, big mansion too.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Moisture
Mnemonic: This may look like an adjective, but it's actually the noun version of the kanji watered. Watered things, like plants, hold a lot of moisture in them.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 潤う, so you should know this one too.

Name: Molotov Cocktail
Mnemonic: A fire in a bottle that makes a big fire when thrown is called a Molotov Cocktail. Don't throw them in the house please.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mound
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Usually these types of mounds are burial mounds. (There's bodies under there!)
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Nod
Mnemonic: Before you can give an explanation of who you are to someone you're about to meet, you have to nod or bow as a greeting first. It's rude to start explaining who you are before you greet them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 会 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When someone bows to you, you always feel a little uncomfortable, so you say, "Eh" (え) and try to get them to stop. You're so uncomfortable that you can't think of words and "eh" is all you can manage to get out.

Name: Nooks
Mnemonic: Corner corners are still corners. Sometimes they're the corners TO corners, so they're the little nooks and crannies that are hard to get at.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice, with the second one rendaku'd. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Notes
Mnemonic: If your brain can't stop pouring out all the explanations your teacher gives you, you'll need to keep notes. That way when the information pours out of your head, you'll still have your comments and annotations to help you remember the teacher's explanations later.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Official Residence
Mnemonic: A government residence is one that is assigned to government officials. That means it's their official residence, and it goes on all their official paperwork.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Official Residence
Mnemonic: A public residence is the one you tell everyone for things like documents and loans and stuff. That means it's your official residence and it's in everyone's books.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Petition
Mnemonic: I request and then I request again. So many requests, but nobody will listen to me. My last hope is to get a bunch of people who have the same ideas together and make a petition.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Positive
Mnemonic: You are determined to get an agreement out of people so you decide to be really positive with them. As long as you make it seem like everything is super great, and totally good for them, they'll end up agreeing with everything you say.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Prescription
Mnemonic: When medicine is sent to your direction it's going to you. That's your  prescription.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Private Residence
Mnemonic: A private residence is a private residence!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Remainder
Mnemonic: The remaining surplus is the remainder or residual left over.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Resin
Mnemonic: The fat that comes out of the wood from trees is used to make resin. Trees don't have fat, you say? Well you're wrong, look it up. Trees are super fat and we use the resin from them to do all sorts of stuff.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rhythmical
Mnemonic: Rhythm is 律動, but by adding a 的 in there we get the adjective version of that word, making it rhythmical or rhythmic.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 律動. The 的 part you should also be able to read by now.

Name: Ryohei
Mnemonic: Clear flat is one way to write the Japanese given name Ryohei.
ReadingMnemonic: Unlike most Japanese names, this one actually uses the on'yomi of both kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Yay for easy names!

Name: Sacred Lotus
Mnemonic: This isn't just any lotus. It's THE lotus. The Sacred Lotus. When you see it blooming all alone in a murky pond, you'll know.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The sacred lotus has (はす) a strong significance (and probably some powers). It has something at least, just remember it has something special going on, and you'll be fine.

Name: Seedling
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The best time to plant seedlings is at night (なえ). If you plant them at night they'll sleep through the whole transplanting process and they'll wake up happy and ready to grow.

Name: Ship Counter
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Skin
Mnemonic: The skin under your skin is still skin. The extra layer is there to make sure when you get little cuts they don't bleed all over the place.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Smart
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's another way of saying wise? Smart or discerning.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What did you do to get so smart? You sat (さと) in class all day. You didn't even get up after class was over. You planted your butt down and sat in your desk until class started again the next morning. You absorb knowledge through your behind, so as long as you sat down all day, you sucked up all the knowledge in the world!

Name: Suburb
Mnemonic: Suburbs on the outside of town are still suburbs. They're sometimes called the outskirts of town too.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Suburbs
Mnemonic: Suburbs near you are still suburbs. They're all pretty much the same.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Summit
Mnemonic: The mountain summit is still called the summit.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Summon
Mnemonic: If you try to call upon someone by screaming for them, you're probably trying to summon them. It's a little bit more serious than just calling them over casually. Maybe you're summoning someone to court, or summoning a magical creature in a video game. Pretty serious stuff.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Surname
Mnemonic: A seedling letter is the very first letter you learn when you're little. What's the first thing you learn to spell when you're little? Your surname! You need to know who your family is, otherwise if you get lost or something happens, you won't know how to get home! Or even who you are!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: The Great Depression
Mnemonic: 世界 means "world" and 恐慌 means "panic" or "scare," so when you put them together you get a scare that made the entire world panic. This is how we refer to The Great Depression. It was caused by and subsequently resulted in everybody in the whole world panicking together about money.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

Name: Threat
Mnemonic: The kanji is threat and the noun version (here) is threat or a threat.
ReadingMnemonic: Think about a threat being sent to you. It's in the form of bad odor (おど). Yuck, what a nasty way to send a threat.

Name: To Boil
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means boil, so the verb version is to boil. It can also be used to mean to get excited, because you're boiling with that excitement.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want to boil for dinner tonight? Walrus (わ). Boiled walrus is a delicacy where you're from, and the only way to be able to eat its yummy walrus flesh is to boil it for a long time until it's soft. Mmm smells good.

Name: To Call
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means call, so the verb version is to call, as in calling someone over.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If a noble decides to call you over, don’t look them in the 目 (め). That's super rude! To show respect when you're called, turn away your 目.

Name: To Cover
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cover, so the verb version is to cover or to hide.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to cover yourself with a sheet because you want to pretend to be a ghost. But covering yourself isn't enough. If you really want people to believe in your disguise you have to say, "おお!" Otherwise they'll think you're a covered chair or a bush. If you おお at them they'll definitely know you're a ghost covered in that sheet.

Name: To Humbly Receive
Mnemonic: If you humbly do something you are going to humbly receive, to humbly accept, or eat or drink it. Basically you're humbly doing a lot of things. And you can use this word for all of them!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You technically already know this reading! You know how people say いただきます? Well that's the same as this! You're humbly receiving your meal. So to humbly receive is いただく!

Name: To Put Between
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means between, so the verb version is to put between or to sandwich.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: To Roast
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means roast, and the verb version is to roast or to toast. This verb is most commonly used when referring to dry roasting things like coffee, tea, or beans.
ReadingMnemonic: Do you know what animal likes to roast and to toast things? Eagles (い)! They're always roasting coffee beans and the like. That's how they stay so alert.

Name: To Shout
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scream, so the verb version is to scream or to shout.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to shout at someone you should pick a word that will really hit them. Give them a big whammy (わめ) to the face! Hey, that word works. Shout WHAMMY!

Name: To Soak
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means immersed, so the verb version is what happens when you immerse something in a liquid. It's to soak or to dip.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 浸る, so you should know this one too.

Name: To Till
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means plow, so the verb version is to plow or to till.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to till your land because you want to have a tiger yard (たがや). That's either when you have a yard full of live tigers, or you plant bushes and shape them into tigers. I hope it's the second kind of tiger yard. Either way, you have to plow the land to get it ready.

Name: To Wash
Mnemonic: Wash wash to wash your clothes. You wash wash your laundry. Hmm wash wash sounds like the sound my laundry machine makes when it's washing my underpants.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Wither
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wither, so the verb version is to wither or to die.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: How do you get plants to wither? You hit them with your car (か). It isn't very good for your car either, but the plants will definitely die, so problem solved!

Name: Unfaithful
Mnemonic: When you do not have chastity, it's probably because you were unfaithful to your promise to whoever you told you'd stay chaste to.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Vase
Mnemonic: A bottle for flowers is a vase. You should get some flowers and put them in a vase for someone special right now.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Vortex
Mnemonic: In the middle of a whirlpool you'll find a spinning vortex of water. You really don't want to get sucked in there.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Washing Machine
Mnemonic: A wash wash machine is just another way of saying washing machine. It does extra washing that you can't do by hand so there are two washes here.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note that although せんたくき is the official reading, this word is commonly pronounced せんたっき when spoken.

Name: Whirlpool
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: There are lots of whirlpools at the uni zoo (うず). Unis really like being spun around in whirlpools, so when you go to the zoo to see them look out for the tank full of them!

Name: Wise
Mnemonic: A wise and bright person is wise and intelligent. In fact, they have so much wisdom that it's showing up as brightness on their skin. Sparkle sparkle goes the wise old woman.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Admirable
Mnemonic: When you win especially well everyone will find you admirable. So get out there and win!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Adultery
Mnemonic: If you do not have any ethics you'll probably do something crappy, like commit adultery. Usually only unethical people would cheat on their spouse, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: After Death
Mnemonic: All the art, music, or books that come out after a person dies are considered to be released after death or posthumously.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ambition
Mnemonic: If you have the leadership spirit it means you have a lot of ambition to go after the things you want. And you'll be able to lead others because of it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Appearing Frequently
Mnemonic: Animals exit the mountains into your land and never seem to die! They end up appearing frequently in your garden, eating all your yummy carrots and watermelons, and then make their exit back into the hills. They're infesting your home now and you don't know what to do!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ayano
Mnemonic: This is a design from Ayano. Do you know an Ayano who's good at designing things? A couple creative Ayanos include traditional Okinawan folk singer and sanshin player Uema Ayano (上間 綾乃), and author Takeda Ayano (武田 綾乃) who won the Yoshikawa Eiji Literary Newcomer Award in 2021.
ReadingMnemonic: This name uses the readings that you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Backing
Mnemonic: Stand behind someone and embrace them. That's how you show them you're backing and supporting them. Do this to your local politicians.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bath
Mnemonic: Let the wind in from the window above your bath so the water is cool enough for you to take a bath! If the water is too hot, you'll get all dizzy and that's dangerous!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. This isn't the same on'yomi reading you learned for 風, though. It's a little different: ふ. If you're taking a bath you'd be a fool (ふ) to bring food in there. Drop the う or you'll end up as soup!

Name: Blockade
Mnemonic: A sealed chain won't break or open so it gets in the way of everyone, forming a blockade. This can happen at banks too and it will result in them freezing your account!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cat's Cradle
Mnemonic: One design that you can take anywhere with you is cat's cradle, the game where you loop string around your hands and fingers to create patterns.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi for both kanji.

Name: Cave In
Mnemonic: A cave in where everyone dies is still a cave in, just a really sad one.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chain
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The best way to break out of the chains life puts on you is to put on a cool sari (くさり). A cool sari will remind you where you come from. Who your family is. And how beautiful you look. Cast off those chains and put on a cool sari!

Name: Chain
Mnemonic: If you take along a chain with you it's still a chain, it's just moving somewhere new.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chronic
Mnemonic: If it's in your nature to ridicule people, it will become a chronic problem. You can't change something that's so embedded in who you are, which is a shame, since you're a jerk.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cliched
Mnemonic: If you keep exhibiting the same actions and emotions and phrases eventually they're going to rot and sound cliched to everyone. You have to mix things up once in a while. You don't want to get stale, do you?!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for ふ becoming ぷ.

Name: Closing
Mnemonic: A closed chain lets everyone know that a building or store is closing for good. It's got to lockout everyone so they won't try to get in anymore.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cold Reception
Mnemonic: When you are given cool treatment it's called a cold reception or inhospitality. This sucks.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Conquest
Mnemonic: Those with leadership who want control will set out on missions of conquest and strive for world domination!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Constancy
Mnemonic: Keeping things constant and normal ensures constancy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Daisuke
Mnemonic: Who's a big help? That'll be Daisuke!
ReadingMnemonic: This name uses the on'yomi for 大 and the nanori for 輔. You learned both of these with the kanji, so that should be a big help. Note: Historically, this name can be read たいふ or おおすけ, as is the case for Heian period poet 伊勢大輔, whose name can be read either いせのたいふ or いせのおおすけ. In modern contexts, you'll only need to know だいすけ though, not to worry!

Name: Defect
Mnemonic: If there is a cave in because it was lacking something that means there was a defect or a fault in there somewhere.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Disaster
Mnemonic: If you encounter something difficult it's going to result in disaster. Especially if you're in a boat. Encountering really difficult water will result in a shipwreck! Ick!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Discard
Mnemonic: When a plant or an animal dies you have to discard it. You can't just keep it sitting around the house after death, that's weird.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Embrace
Mnemonic: An embrace and a hug are pretty much the same thing. So you're still going to embrace and hug people!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 抱 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who gives the best hugs in the world? Harry Houdini (ほう)! He knows what it's like to be hugged too tightly because he's always in straight jackets. So his hugs are nice and gentle. Just the way you like them!

Name: Encounter
Mnemonic: The kanji here are encounter and encounter, which makes this… encounter!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Endurance
Mnemonic: I get ridiculed a lot, but it makes me have really strong endurance. If you get picked on a lot, just say, "I have patience and self control, and I can make it through this."
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Environment
Mnemonic: The treatment of your boundary of your neighborhood is something you should be concerned about, because it's your environment and if you don't take care of it, who will?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Eruption
Mnemonic: When a volcano erupts with fire it makes a really big eruption. You should probably start running.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Established Practice

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ethics
Mnemonic: Ethics and reason together in a person make them have very strong ethics and morals.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Exhibition
Mnemonic: An exhibit of things in a row only happens at an exhibition. Everything will be neatly lined up on display for you there.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Expansion
Mnemonic: You need to swell and stretch if you want to see any kind of expansion of your company. Growth can't happen without a little wiggle room.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Falcon
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Fall
Mnemonic: If you fall during a cave in you'll fall along with everything around you. And that sinking feeling in your stomach is because... I mean, well you ARE sinking into the ground.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Forfeiture

Name: Hegemony
Mnemonic: Those with the rights to leadership have complete hegemony over the country. And they will reign until the end of time.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Huge
Mnemonic: A thing that swells big ends up being huge or at least really bulky.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hunter
Mnemonic: If you can teach hunting then you must be a really accomplished hunter yourself.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hunting
Mnemonic: Hunting where you hunt is still hunting.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 狩 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When hunting make sure you know where the water chutes (しゅ) are located. You'll need to use those chutes to move quickly during the hunt.

Name: Hunting
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Hunting Dog
Mnemonic: A hunting dog is a hunting dog!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 犬 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who has the best hunting dog in the world? Ken (けん) from Street Fighter! His dog is also named Ken, because that's how Ken and Ken do things.

Name: Immersing Oneself

You didn't learn this reading for 埋 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Wait that's not a person you're embedding things into. It's a bunch of mice (まい). I guess that's okay. Just don't go putting the mice into people. That's... don't cross that line.

Name: Indispensable
Mnemonic: Something that's certainly necessary is something you can't live without. It's indispensable. And it's required by you to keep on living.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Inertia
Mnemonic: If you have the nature of being lazy it will become a habit. The momentum created by your natural laziness will make it so you can't break out of your lazy cycle.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Isolation
Mnemonic: An orphan is standing alone in the streets. Orphans don't have any parents and most of the time they're friendless too. It's really sad.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Isolation

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Killed In Action

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Laziness

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Narrow Minded

You didn't learn this reading for 狭 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The only place narrow minded people will go in Japan is Kyoto (きょう). It's where all the tour guides say to go, and they're too narrow minded to listen to anyone else. So they see Kyoto and head back home right away without seeing anywhere else.

Name: National Isolation

Name: Negligence

Name: One Piece Of Sushi

Linked to this, it can also mean integration, because integration is easier if there's consistency, after all.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Order

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Origin
Mnemonic: Your auspicious departure from another world is your origin story. You originally came from another place, and you had to leave there gloriously before you could enter this world.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Orphan
Mnemonic: An orphan child is sadly still an orphan.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Perfume
Mnemonic: Perfume fragrance is what you'll smell if you spray a bottle of perfume.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Permanent

Name: Poaching

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Preferential Treatment

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Reparations
Mnemonic: Compensation reparations are still compensation and reparations! That's convenient.

Name: Resuscitation

Name: Scandal

Name: Sinking

Name: Slow

Name: Statement

Mnemonic: Someone prone to indicate and instigate will have lots of suggestions for other people. By dropping hints, they can indicate problems and instigate fights among people. Their implications do a lot of harm.

You didn't learn this reading for 示 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone keeps coming up to you making suggestions and dropping hints that you should buy a sheep (し). It happens so much that you finally decide to grab the hint-droppers arm and... oh my gosh, that's a hoof. They're a sheep!

Name: Sunset
Mnemonic: At night the sun dies at sunset. Don't worry, it will be reborn tomorrow morning at sunrise and everything will be okay.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Supreme Ruler
