Name: Sushi Counter
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Sweet
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of perfume? Sweet or fragrant.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to smell a sweet fragrance, just open some potpourri. But be careful if it's a can. Fragrant cans will baa (かんば) like a sheep at you when you open them. That can baa is just a sweet smell side effect.

Name: Thorn
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: To Be Biased
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means biased, so the verb version is to be biased or to be prejudiced.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You meet someone who claims to be biased about everything. You ask them why and they say, "I'm a cutter, yo (かたよ)! I cut everything in half and only like one of 'em. But I guess if you wanna call that biased go ahead, man." Huh, okay.

Name: To Be Negligent
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means neglect, so the verb version is to be negligent or to neglect something.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you always seem to be negligent to your kids you'll end up with this situation. It's winter and your kid comes home from school covered in snow and sneezing. "Oh, coat... (おこた)" you say. You didn't give them a coat when they went out today. Maybe if you weren't so negligent that wouldn't have happened.

Name: To Fall Into
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cave in, and the verb version takes that feeling further. It means to fall into or to be thrown into something negative, like a trap, trouble, or even a bad emotional state.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Whenever you're about to fall into a physical or emotional pit of doom, you just mutter, "Oh cheese eatery (おちい)..." Because that's where it always starts. You can never resist the temptations of their mysterious fondue. Oh, that cheese eatery is like a trap for people with no self-control. Get ahold of yourself! Your life is falling into cheesy ruin!!

Name: To Go Through
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pierce, so the verb version is to go through or to pierce.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The best way to go through someone's mind or a college campus is to run nude (つらぬ). So if you really want to pierce someone's mind and soul remember this!

Name: To Have
Mnemonic: To do an embrace is to have that person or animal in your arms. You hug it and then run away with it. It's yours now.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: To Meet
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means encounter, so the verb version is to encounter or to meet.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember how 会う also means to meet? Well they're both read あう too! So if you know that one, you know this one too!

Name: To Swell
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means swell, so the verb version is to swell or to expand.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone comes up to you and asks, "Hey, do you want your stomach to swell like that?" How dare they ask you about your stomach. You respond with, "F@#$ (ふく) you!" It's none of their business how much you want your stomach to expand.

Name: Treatment
Mnemonic: Just because you have to wait for special treatment doesn't mean it's not still good treatment. And just because everyone didn't cheer when you arrived, doesn't mean you're getting a cold reception, you know? Maybe they're planning a surprise party for you or something... yeah.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Treatment

Name: Unbalanced Diet

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ReadingMnemonic: You should be able to read this on your own. And seriously... if you ever get this one wrong we're gonna show up at your house and look down at you with really, really disappointed looks on our faces. Don't let us down, kids.

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for は becoming ぱ.

Name: Abuse

People will pay more attention when you're in a row boat because it's kind of weird. Especially since you're in a row boat on a stage.

Meaning: Woman Of The Red Light District

Imagine this fast horse zooming past you over and over, but all you ever see are its white 目.

Think about fatty meat on your own body. If you have a lot of fatty meat, then you need a way to support said fatty meat. To do that, you would use a bra (あぶら).

Name: Fiber

ReadingMnemonic: You learned all the readings in this name with the kanji. What could be easier to comprehend?

Name: Scarf
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 巻く means "to roll?" Well the thing you roll up around your collar is a scarf!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Seedling
Mnemonic: A seedling tree is still a seedling.

Name: Self Purification
Mnemonic: If you purify your self you are performing self purification.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Shop
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Shop
Mnemonic: A shop shop is still a shop.

Name: Sitting Cross Legged

ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: If you're sitting cross legged lots of people will think you're a grouch (あぐら). Back in the day sitting like this was thought to be really manly, and if you were a woman who did it they'd call you a grouch too.

Name: Skin Disease
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 皮膚 is "skin?" Well when your skin is sick, you have a skin disease. You should probably go to a dermatologist right away.

Name: Soil
Mnemonic: Soil soil is still soil.

Name: Southern Latitude
Mnemonic: South latitude is south latitude or southern latitude.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Submission

Name: Sudden Price Jump

Name: Sudden Rise

Name: Summit

Name: Supreme Command

Name: Surplus
Mnemonic: Surplus of surplus money is still a surplus. There's just too much money everywhere!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Synthetic Fiber
Mnemonic: Fibers you join together to make more, stronger fibers, they turn into synthetic fibers.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Synthetic Fibers
Mnemonic: Fibers that have been changed from other materials are synthetic fibers. They aren't natural because they were something else once. Like plastic, or kittens.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Teacher
Mnemonic: Who admonishes and teaches you? A Teacher. Probably not the nicest one though...
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Admonish
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means admonish, so the verb version is to admonish or to warn.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your mom started to admonish you so you instantly sat (さと) down. Maybe if she sees you sat down right in front of her, looking guilty and feeling remorseful, she won't yell as hard.

Name: To Boil
Mnemonic: You already learned the word 沸く which means "to boil" or "to grow hot" but this is when you are the one heating the water. It still means to boil or to heat. But remember that you're the one who is doing the heating.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 沸く, so you should be able to read this word as well.

Name: To Eat
Mnemonic: You've learned that 召す can mean "to take" when a social higher-up takes a meal or a drink. Now you're adding 上がる (to go up), so you've got the added image of the food or drink rising up to their mouth. In other words, this is a respectful way of saying to eat or to drink.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of the words 召す and 上がる that you've learned already.召す becomes 召し and then you add 上がる to it. Pretty straightforward, right?

Name: To Get Between
Mnemonic: You already learned the word 挟む which means "to put between." Well this is when something is between two things and you're not putting it there. It's just kinda doing it by itself. It means to get between or to be caught in.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 挟む, so you should be able to read this word as well.

Name: To Install
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means install, so the verb version is to install or to fix.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: Tolerance
Mnemonic: It doesn't matter how big your tolerance is because it's still tolerance.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tolerance
Mnemonic: All forms of tolerance are still tolerance. Usually people like this are really open minded and generous too.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Let Dry
Mnemonic: You already learned the word 枯れる which means "to wither," but this is when you are the one making a plant wither. It means to let dry or to kill your plants. They didn't just die on their own, you did it.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 枯れる, so you should be able to read this word as well.

Name: To Nod
Mnemonic: If you want to show your agreement with someone you need to nod at them so they know.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: You seem to nod your head a lot when you're at the unagi zoo (うなず). Unagi zoos are really rare and hard to get into. So while you're there, keep nodding to everyone because you're so honored to be there! 肯く also has two readings. うなずく is the standard, but うなづく is more and more acceptable these days too. Luckily they sound pretty similar (if not the same), so they should be easy to remember!

Name: To Oppress
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means oppress, so the verb version is to oppress or to persecute.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The best way to oppress someone is to make it so they can't use the sh*tter (しいた). Just imagine any kind of oppressive monarch from history. They know your weakness. They know you need to poop at some point. What would it be like 48 hours from now if you didn't have a place to poop. If you didn't have your "sh*tter." To help you to remember that there's an い in there, think about an eagle, as we often do for い. This eagle represents "American Freedom." If you had this freedom you'd be pooping all you want and nobody would take your sh*tter away from you.

Name: To Relax
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tolerance, so the verb version is what happens when you're a really tolerant person. You're able to relax and to feel at home because nothing really gets to you.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to relax so you go down to old coots road (くつろ). It's a road with a bunch of old coots who don't bother nobody. They just kinda sit around and complain. That's where you like to relax. Something about being surrounded by a bunch of old coots on old coots road makes you feel at home.

Name: Tyranny
Mnemonic: Violence and oppression are all signs of tyranny and that someone is being really cruel.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Uncleanliness
Mnemonic: If you have not cleansed yourself you're going to be covered in uncleanliness and dirtiness. Eww.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Very
Mnemonic: If you manage to make all parts of something work together you worked very, extremely, considerably hard to do it. Doing all of anything is hard so lots of work had to happen.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Washing
Mnemonic: You wash something to cleanse it by doing the washing and cleaning. You have to do the washing if you really want to get all the dirt out and make your things clean.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Watermelon
Mnemonic: Melons that grow in the west are round and striped and green and wait a second. That's a watermelon. I guess they come from the western part of Japan.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for 西 here is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Watermelons taste best after you swing (すい) them around. Whether you tie a rope to them or swing them on an actual swing, it mixes up the yummy watermelon insides and they end up tasting the best this way. So always remember to swing your watermelon before you crack it open.

Name: Whirlpool
Mnemonic: This is a combination of the word 渦 meaning "whirlpool" and 巻く meaning "to roll." A rolling whirlpool is still a whirlpool, just a really violent one.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of the words 渦 and 巻く. 巻く becomes 巻き and you just add 渦 to it. So reading this should be pretty simple.

Name: Working Earnestly
Mnemonic: A miner works with such sincerity that her arms and legs start turning rust colored from working earnestly. All the clay and rocks she's putting her effort into digging are turning her the same color. That color is how you know someone works with serious diligence.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Actual
Mnemonic: If it appears to exist, then it's probably an actual thing... you know, existing and stuff. That should be pretty obvious.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Anecdote
Mnemonic: How do you deviate from a normal talk? With lots of anecdotes. If you add enough of them into your conversations no one will ever be able to keep track of what you were talking about to begin with.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Apricot
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading with the kanji! Yay!

Name: Army Provisions
Mnemonic: Provisions that are only for soldiers are army provisions.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the reading for the second kanji but not the first one yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you: The army said it would provide you with some army provisions. That's great! You go to the drop site where the provisions are, and you see the provisions. "Heyo! It's roe!" (ひょうろう) you say out loud. You're pretty happy that your provisions consist of tons and tons of roe!

Name: Autobiography
Mnemonic: Tell everyone how you describe yourself in your autobiography. It's the only way they'll be able to understand the real you.

Name: Baby Bottle
Mnemonic: A milk bottle that babies use to nurse is called a baby bottle.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bathroom

ReadingMnemonic: This word consists of the jukugo word 風呂 and the kun'yomi reading for 場. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading for 場 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: You step into the bathroom and hear an angry chorus of baas (ば). You're mortified to find that you've accidentally entered the side of the public bath reserved exclusively for sheep. You rush back out, bowing and baaing apologies.

Name: Bias
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 偏る, so you should be able to read this one too!

Name: Blank Space
Mnemonic: A space as empty as the sky is a blank space. You're probably supposed to fill that in with something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bonsai
Mnemonic: Tray planting is bonsai. It makes sense because that's exactly what you're doing: planting a tree in a tray!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bookmark
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Buddhist High Priest

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 和 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The only thing you ever hear the Buddhist High Priest say is "Oooooo" (お). It must be some kind of Buddhist humming or chanting. Every time you think about him you hear that o sound in your head.

Name: Column
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Conferring Of Decorations
Mnemonic: Describe someone's merit at a ceremony for the conferring of decorations. That's when medals are given out to people who deserve them. Usually in the military or something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Crest

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Crown

ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, and that is its most common reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In your mind, the only person who can wear a crown is Bill Murray. He asks you, "Can I wear the crown?" and you say "Yes you can, Murray (かんむり)". Murray goes ahead and puts on the crown. He's movie royalty, after all.

Name: Crown
Mnemonic: A king's cap is his crown. It's a hat only he can wear.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cruel
Mnemonic: A cruel cool person is more cruel and coldhearted than just a normal cruel person. It's probably because they're cold all the time and it makes them mad. You should stay away from people like that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cruel
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cruel? Cruel or awful.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think of a man who is cruel. Doesn't matter who, but pick one that you know of that is actually cruel. He can be a real person or someone in a movie or on TV. What does this man do? He do (ひど) cruel things.

Name: Cruelty
Mnemonic: The remainder of cruelness is cruelty. There always seems to be plenty to go around, and it kind of sucks.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cultivation
Mnemonic: Planting seeds in land to cultivate crops is called cultivation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Decoration
Mnemonic: To show that you had merit for a chapter of your life you will be given a decoration or a medal. Especially if you're a soldier or an athlete.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dementia
Mnemonic: If you seem stupid and shocked all the time you might have dementia. It makes it so everything is unfamiliar and confusing, so you can't help looking silly and confused all the time.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Depopulation
Mnemonic: If the neglect of an area surpasses what was expected, then the result will be depopulation. No one wants to live in a neglected town, especially one that's worse than what they were told.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Deviation
Mnemonic: If you deviate from the plan and escape from it, that's a serious deviation and could ruin everything! Stick to the plan! Stop deviating!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Discovery
Mnemonic: You expose something new and it appears in front of the whole world as your discovery.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Disease
Mnemonic: Something that you are afflicted with rapidly is a disease. You should go to the doctor's right away to treat this fast-acting ailment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Disorder
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 秩序 means "order?" Well if you have nothing like that then it falls into disorder and chaos!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Epic Poem
Mnemonic: If you describe a bunch of occurrences in a poem, it's probably an epic poem. This is for those super long, really descriptive poems you might be forced to read in school, like The Epic of Gilgamesh (ギルガメシュ叙事詩).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Especially

ReadingMnemonic: This is the kanji followed by the particle に, so it uses the kun'yomi reading like a kanji does if it's alone. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you wear when it's especially cold out? Your favorite coat (こと). You only wear it when it's unusually cold though, never any other time.

Name: Essential Condition
Mnemonic: You already learned that 必須 can mean "essential" and that 条件 means "condition," so put them together and you get essential condition! That basically means that it's a must.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Estrangement
Mnemonic: Neglect someone so much that you remove yourself from their inner circle and live outside of their life and it's called estrangement. You might never see them again. But that's okay with you, your relationship is too weird to fix now.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Estrangement
Mnemonic: If your neglect of family members goes too far you'll end up with estrangement in your relationships with them. And they'll probably neglect you as much as you neglect them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Eternity
Mnemonic: Leisure that last for a long time ends up going on for all eternity. It never ends, and why should it? You're soooo relaaaaaxed, you can't possibly ever stop.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ethical
Mnemonic: Things that are ethic al are ethical.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ethics
Mnemonic: You already learned that 倫理 means "ethics" so when you add study it means the ethics you study in school.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Evacuation
Mnemonic: You’re looking for a neglected place that you can open up and use for evacuation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Excellence
Mnemonic: Do you excel when you deviate from the norm? Well, then you're made for excellence, my friend!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Exchange
Mnemonic: Repay what someone lent you in response to them already lending YOU money, and the two of you will have exchanged money.

Name: Exploitation
Mnemonic: If you use something in a cruel way it's called exploitation. You're probably going to overuse it, at that rate too. Cut it out, dude.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Exposure
Mnemonic: Present and expose wrongdoing to get proper exposure. The world needs disclosure and so do you!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Family Crest

ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Fingerprint
Mnemonic: The family crest on your finger? That's just your fingerprint. It can be used to identify you, so it's pretty much the same as your own personal family crest.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Folk Song

Name: Fool

Name: Foolish

ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Furthermore
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When do people tend to use the word furthermore? Right now (なお)!

Name: Gale
Mnemonic: A rapid wind is a gale or a strong wind.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Gem
Mnemonic: Deviate from normal, everyday products and buy lots of gems and treasures! Especially if you're buying presents. Normal stuff just isn't going to cut it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: General Affairs
Mnemonic: Common tasks are a part of the general affairs of the people. That's why they're general, they're the ones everyone is involved in.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ginkgo
Mnemonic: If it looks like a silver apricot, it's probably a ginkgo. Ever seen a ginkgo nut from a ginkgo tree? They really do look like little silver apricots. (Go ahead and google it if you don't believe me.)
ReadingMnemonic: This word is an exception. You'd think it would be the same in Japanese as it is in English, but it's not. And it has two different readings and meanings. Yikes, sorry. Here's a mnemonic to help you out: Before you read this PLEASE PLEASE REMEMBER this is NOT a jukugo word. It's weird. You're gonna want to type ぎんこう but that's wrong. Stop that now. When you think of the ginkgo tree meaning, think about this: Ginkgos are a favorite nesting place for eagles (い), but evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう) likes to eat eagles AND whole ginkgo trees. She prefers eating eagles WHILE THEY'RE IN THE GINKGO TREES AND STILL ALIVE. So いちょう. Eagles and Mrs. Chou. And ginkgo trees. It's horrible to think about. Just like this reading not being jukugo. The other reading is for the ginkgo nut meaning. The nut tastes like 銀 (ぎん) naan (なん). Mmm, soft and metallic — but still not a jukugo word. How sad for you and all Japanese learners everywhere.

Name: Giving An Account
Mnemonic: When you describe an event by mentioning everything that happened, you must be giving an account of it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Gravity
Mnemonic: If everyone is acting solemn and strict then you should probably pay special attention to the gravity of the situation you're in. Don't start playing the trumpet when you're supposed to be bowing your head!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Groper
Mnemonic: A stupid man is a groper. I mean, not always. But it's probably fair to call a groper or molester a stupid man.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Guardrail
Mnemonic: A column made of dry wood is turned into a guardrail to help people walk up and down stairs.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Harsh
Mnemonic: Something that's cruel tends to be harsh, severe, and terrible. And of course, it's still cruel to boot.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: High
Mnemonic: You only hold someone in high esteem if they are really high, noble people. They have to be refined to be held so highly by you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Holiday House
Mnemonic: A villa separate from your normal house is a holiday house. You go there when you're sick of your normal house to relax.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Honoring
Mnemonic: Sometimes someone will appear before you and it's clear they're worth honoring. If Koichi appeared before you, for example, it should be pretty clear what you should do.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ibaraki Prefecture
Mnemonic: The prefecture famous for its ancient thorn castle is Ibaraki prefecture. I may or may not be making this up. Don't fact check me, just look at that cool thorny castle in Ibaraki that I put in your head. Ooooh, how cool!
ReadingMnemonic: This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for 茨, an exception for 城, and the on'yomi for 県. Phew! You haven't learned this weird reading for 城 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Ibaraki prefecture is famous for making keys (き)! It's their biggest export. The key to knowing this reading is in the keys they make! Or, just knowing that it's the same in English and Japanese.

Name: Idle Complaint
Mnemonic: A foolish and stupid person will make lots of idle complaints. You really don't like being around them because they grumble about how nothing is good enough all the time. But they really just don't get it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Illness
Mnemonic: A rapid sickness is an illness or a disease.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses on'yomi readings, but you haven't seen the へい reading for 病 yet. In fact, this is pretty much the only word it appears in, and on top of that it gets rendaku'd. So here's a mnemonic to help you out: If you don't treat an illness right away, you might pay (ぺい) with your life. And if you don't die, you'll still have to pay a lot for doctor and hospital fees. Yuck.

Name: Intense Heat
Mnemonic: Cruel hot weather is the kind that's too much for anyone to handle. It's intense heat. Stranded in the desert in summer, heat.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 暑 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Intense heat will show (しょ) on your face. You'll turn red and get all sweaty. You really can't hide it.

Name: Kidnapping
Mnemonic: Invite someone to kidnap you and you'll have a kidnapping on your hands. That wasn't very smart. You should try to be more careful.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Leisurely
Mnemonic: Long leisure makes everything you do leisurely and slow. You're able to perform tasks at a deliberate rate because nothing's rushing you. And you've been like this for so long, why would anything try?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lyricism
Mnemonic: The best way to describe your feelings is with lyricism. Making a clear description of feelings is difficult, but it will make you feel better.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Madder Red
Mnemonic: Rose madder color is more simply called madder red, which is a kind of deep red or crimson. This word is used most often to describe the color of the sky at sunset in literature.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings are the same as the ones you learned with the kanji.

Name: Margin
Mnemonic: If you write outside the columns in your notebook paper you're actually writing in the margins. It's a good space to put doodles.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Masses
Mnemonic: Common peoples make up the masses. They are the common people and no society is complete without them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Meritorious Deeds
Mnemonic: You do things especially worthy of merit and they're called meritorious deeds.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Metabolism
Mnemonic: Your body thinks you want to substitute new exhibits inside yourself but it apologizes and replaces them more than you'd like. What it's actually doing is controlling your metabolism. Picture your body using food you eat by setting it up in an exhibit in your stomach. But it gets bored of it and wants to substitute it with a newer one, so it makes you hungry again, digesting the food fast.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You already know all of these, but 代 uses the less common たい reading, so here’s a mnemonic in case you’d like some help remembering that: As everyone knows, the best way to boost your metabolism is to wear a tie (たい). They make your body more efficient overall, which includes your metabolism, so make sure you’re always wearing a tie for that metabolism boost!

Name: Most Favorable Treatment
Mnemonic: The most superior treatment is another way of saying it's the most favorable treatment you've ever received. It's when you get the warmest reception out of everyone around you. Like they think you're the president or something. Either way, it's pretty great!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mountain Retreat
Mnemonic: A mountain villa is a mountain retreat.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mutual Understanding
Mnemonic: If you never neglect to pass through your thoughts to another person the two of you will be able to have a special mutual understanding.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Nishiki Market
Mnemonic: You might already know 市場 means "market," like in 株式市場 (stock market). So is this a brocade market? Well, "brocade" actually refers to the name of a street here, not brocade fabrics. It's a place name, so we can just call this the Nishiki Market!
ReadingMnemonic: As you could probably guess from the meaning, 錦 is read にしき here. 市場 is usually read with kun'yomi when it refers to a real, physical street market. You haven't learned this reading for 市場 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: There's one thing you look for when you visit Nishiki Market: an itchy baa (いちば). Sheep go "baa," and the ones you buy must be exceptionally itchy. Itchy baas produce the best mutton and wool, so you keep an eye out for them whenever you go to Nishiki Market!

Name: Nursery Rhyme
Mnemonic: Noh chanting for juveniles are nursery rhymes. Kids won't understand the heavy stuff, so you have to dumb it down for them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Nursing
Mnemonic: Nurse and raise your baby by nursing. Milk helps babies grow up big and strong.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Orphanage
Mnemonic: You already learned that the word 孤児 means "orphan," so when you put a bunch of orphans in an institution it's called an orphanage.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Paradise
Mnemonic: This place has extreme comfort. It is paradise.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 極 has two on'yomi readings, though. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: In paradise, you meet Goku (ごく) from Dragon Ball Z. He grins and tells you he's taking a break from extreme battles and enjoying the extreme comfort of this heavenly paradise.

Name: Practice
Mnemonic: To tell you the truth, practice is practice. You can't just substitute something else for it. You'll only make progress with real practice! You can do it!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Premature
Mnemonic: You already learned that the word 時期 means "time period," so when you add furthermore and early to that, it means that something happened ahead of time. It means premature.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Presentation
Mnemonic: Present your presents at the presentation. Presents for everyone!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Presentation
Mnemonic: Present your findings in advance during an early presentation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pride
Mnemonic: If you ridicule other people because you're so proud of yourself that everyone seems like crap in comparison, you've got too much pride. You should also work on toning down your arrogance and haughtiness, because people won't like you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Public Bathhouse
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 風呂 means "bath?" Well the store you pay to take a bath in is the public bathhouse!
ReadingMnemonic: This word consists of the jukugo word 風呂 and the kun'yomi reading for 屋. You've learned all of these readings, so you should be able to read this already too!

Name: Quiet
Mnemonic: Leisure with more leisure added on? That's a really quiet and leisurely life you've got going on!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is just the on'yomi readings (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

Name: Remarkable
Mnemonic: When an author appears in public it's always remarkable. People usually don't remember there's anyone behind those pages, so when the actual author shows up in person it's pretty striking.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Reparations
Mnemonic: Gold you get as compensation for reparations is called reparations.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Resemblance
Mnemonic: If you resemble someone who's cruel, you, well, you resemble them. Maybe you're really mean too. I guess only you can know that. But you do look like that other guy...
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 似 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Which cruel guy do you resemble? Jesus (じ), of course. I mean, you look just like him. Look in the mirror if you don't believe me. Look, there he is. Wait, what do you mean he isn't a cruel guy? I guess you're the cruel one then. Sucks to be you.

Name: Reward
Mnemonic: Repay people for the news they tell you by rewarding them! Everyone deserves compensation for the time they take to pass information to you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ripple
Mnemonic: Throw your family crest into the waves and you'll make lots of ripples. There will probably also be repercussions with your family because those things are important and you really shouldn't be tossing them into the sea's waves.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Self Control
Mnemonic: If you're solemn by yourself, you have a lot of self control. You don't need anyone to tell you to be that way, you have your own self discipline.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Severe Criticism
Mnemonic: Evaluate in a cruel way so you can lay some severe criticism down on your competition! It's not the nicest thing to do, and it's not very constructive for them, but it will make you look better.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Severity
Mnemonic: Your boss surpasses his normal cruelty and rains severity down on your head. You had other things to do this weekend and now you have to work through it? Harsh...
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Showroom
Mnemonic: The room where you exhibit things in a row is a showroom. Maybe there are cars lined up, or boats, or tiny porcelain cats! Either way, they need a nice big showroom to show them off.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sickle
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Silent
Mnemonic: A solemn quiet person will always be silent. They never ever speak.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Solemnity
Mnemonic: A villa that's kept under really strict rules will press solemnity on everyone who tries to stay there.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 厳 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To help you understand the solemnity of a moment of silence, usually a gong (ごん) will play a few times. As you listen to the echo and silence that comes after it. The gravity of what you're being silent for really sinks in.

Name: Song
Mnemonic: Noh chanting out a song makes it an even longer, more confusing song. But it's still a song nonetheless!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sparse
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When things are sparse, you won't have food or toys or internet. It's hard for everyone. So your mama would baa (まば) to entertain you and get you to stop thinking about how thin you and her were getting. Mama baaing made you calm and happy. Thanks mama.

Name: Sprint
Mnemonic: A rapid run is called a sprint or a dash.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Stem
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: To Burst Out
Mnemonic: "To Remove" an eruption it needs to burst out of the earth or volcano it's in.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember how you learned the word 吹き出す? Well this is read the exact same way and means almost the exact same thing. If you know one reading, you know both!

Name: To Expand
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means swell, so the verb version is to swell or to expand.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If someone comes up to you and says, "Hey it looks like you've really started to expand around the middle." Go ahead and say a big old, "F@#$ (ふく) you!" If someone is rude to you, dish it right back out. F@#$ that guy!

Name: To Grow Senile
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shock. What happens when you're so old that your brain goes into shock? You start to grow senile. It's sad, but lots of people can't handle being old and they get like this.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you start to grow senile you'll make a new friend. It's Bobo (ぼ) the clown! No one else can see him though, but that's okay! He'll become your very best friend. And he won't leave until you finally kick the bucket.

Name: Tone Deafness
Mnemonic: If you're stupid when it comes to sounds, then you're tone deaf.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Neglect
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means neglect and lazy, so the verb version is to neglect or to be idle.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to neglect everything. Your school, your family, even your own name (なま). You've managed to slack for so long that you can't even remember your name? That's pretty impressive, actually.

Name: To Sell Wholesale
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wholesale, so the verb version is to sell wholesale.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: To Stick To
Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 貫く (to go through) and 通す (to let pass). Literally, it can describe piercing fully through an object. However, 貫き通す is usually used figuratively to mean to stick to something to the very end. Just like piercing an object from one side to the other, 貫き通す implies you push forward no matter what, sticking to your beliefs or determinations all the way.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of two words you already know, so you should already know this too!

Name: To Turn Away
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deviate, so the verb version is to turn away or to avert.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to turn away from this movie because it's not worth watching. I mean, it isn't bad, but it isn't good. It's just so-so (そ). But that's not enough to keep your interest.

Name: Vain
Mnemonic: The sky has an air of neglect about it and makes it seems like everything you're doing is in vain. Why even bother? The sky doesn't even believe in you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Victim
Mnemonic: You already learned that 犠牲 means "victim," so when you add someone to that, it still means victim.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Whale
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: A whale is actually gojira's (godzilla) cool cousin kujira (くじら). Godzilla mutated from a whale, so they're still related. That's where he gets his name from!

Name: Whale Meat
Mnemonic: Whale meat is whale meat.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Whaling
Mnemonic: If you catch a whale you're whaling, and that's illegal now so you should probably put the whale back.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Wholesale
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Wholesale
Mnemonic: Sell something at the wholesale price and it's... well it's wholesale.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Sometimes it's spelled 卸売り too.

Name: Wholesale Price
Mnemonic: When you sell something at wholesale value it's being sold at a wholesale price.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Accumulation
Mnemonic: Accumulate and accumulate make accumulation!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Adhesion
Mnemonic: What do you wear to heal a really serious injury? An adhesion. Okay, so you don't actually wear these, but your body makes them for your insides to wear so you can heal. Nice job insides!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: A Little
Mnemonic: Erase one part of your feelings and you'll only feel a little bit of them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ambush
Mnemonic: A soldier only lays herself down when she's about to ambush the enemy! If you see some soldiers laying around, it's not that they're lazy, it's because they're getting ready to pounce!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Anxiety
Mnemonic: All you can do is consider your grief and how it's ruining your life. That's called anxiety, and it can be a real problem. You end up being concerned about everything, but don't worry. There are ways to combat it. You'll be okay!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Attendance
Mnemonic: Dedicate yourself to doing the best at school by having perfect attendance! That's how you can show you're really dedicated to learning.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Belief
Mnemonic: Dedicate your life to what you believe in and you'll have really strong belief and faith in whatever that thing is. Just try to dedicate yourself to something nice.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bone Marrow
Mnemonic: Bone marrow is bone marrow!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bottle Opener
Mnemonic: What do you use to pull out a cork? A bottle opener! Or a corkscrew if you're feeling adventurous.
ReadingMnemonic: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 栓 and the kun'yomi reading for 抜, which you learned with 抜く. If you can remember that, you'll be able to remember this too!

Name: Captive
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The worst thing to see as a captive is a 鳥子 (とりこ), a bird child. Imagine seeing a baby bird held captive in a cage. So sad!

Name: Circulation
Mnemonic: Circulation in a loop is still circulation. Or rotation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Coarse
Mnemonic: If it's coarse in a bad way it's still coarse but it's also crude or inferior. You don't want a fuzzy sweater to be coarse, do you? Or a carpet? If they are, they're this kind of coarse.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Coarse
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of coarse? Coarse or rough.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The most coarse thing you can think of is a rock (あら). You rubbed it on your face and it was really rough and kinda painful. You probably shouldn't be rubbing a rock on your face, actually.

Name: Conceal
Mnemonic: Bow your head to conceal yourself better than you were concealing yourself before. If you want to go into hiding you need to know how to lay low!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Condolence

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cork
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Correspond
Mnemonic: If the above is correct then please sign the corresponding line to agree with it. And make sure you correspond in a timely manner.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cumulative Total

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dedication
Mnemonic: If you dedicate your entire supply of food to the gods it's called an offering, and it takes real dedication to do something like that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Depression
