ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Detergent
Mnemonic: You already learned that the word 洗浄 means "washing." So when you're washing the laundry you have to use just the right dose of detergent to make sure they wash properly. If you use too little detergent they'll still smell, but if you use too much detergent the washer will explode with bubbles! Just be careful okay, don't end up like me.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Eito
Mnemonic: A crystal ladle is the Japanese given name Eito. If you know the singer-songwriter Eito, imagine him holding a crystal ladle. If not, any Eito will do! Other public figures with the name include pro baseball player Tanaka Eito (田中 瑛斗) and Takarazuka actor Namiki Eito (波輝 瑛斗).
ReadingMnemonic: This name uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned both these readings with the kanji. Get yourself a crystal ladle to celebrate! Note: This name can also sometimes be read あきと, as is the case for pro baseball player Takabe Akito (髙部 瑛斗).

Name: Erase
Mnemonic: If you want to erase and extinguish every lamp and every picture of a lamp in the world, just erase them all. Simple as that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Essence
Mnemonic: The marrow of reality is the true essence of life. If you look deep down into reality you might even find the true meaning of life! Hmm I wonder what that is... it probably has something to do with a certain two digit number. Oh well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Essence
Mnemonic: The marrow of a god contains their essence and spirit. I don't know how you found that out, it was probably really dangerous. You shouldn't mess with gods.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Evil Breeds Evil
Mnemonic: The evil cause yields the evil fruit, or more simply, evil breeds evil.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The last 悪果 gets the 悪 shortened a little bit.

Name: Fine Work
Mnemonic: Make something excellent and everyone will call it a fine work. Or make something that sucks and let everyone down. It's your call.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Foreshadowing
Mnemonic: Connect a bunch of things laying in a line. Something's happening here. You can't put your finger on it, but you're pretty sure this is foreshadowing for something else.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fried Chicken
Mnemonic: You've got a combination of China and 揚げ, meaning "fried." That makes this Chinese-style Fried Chicken, or as you'll probably also know it, karaage.
ReadingMnemonic: You know how to read the 揚げ part, but this uses the kun'yomi reading for 唐, which is new. You'll likely be able to remember this reading by associating fried chicken with Japanese karaage, but in case you're not familiar with it, here's a mnemonic to help you: To make this kind of fried chicken, you have to first give it one strong からて chop. If you fry it up without that からて chop, it just comes out terrible no matter what you do. So just remember that next time you make it for me, kay?

Name: Guest
Mnemonic: A VIP comes to your door. They're your guest! I hope you aren't going to make them sleep in the couch.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Guest Of Honor
Mnemonic: A VIP guest is a guest of honor. They're even more important than a normal guest.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Healing
Mnemonic: A healing cure will be great for healing sick people.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Inequality
Mnemonic: When something is not equal is of course unequal. It's an inequality. You'll usually see this word in technical contexts like math and engineering, but it does pop up in more general formal writing, too.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Leader
Mnemonic: You’ll need a heavy dose to tranquilize yourself enough to be a leader. It can pretty stressful to be a leader so most of them are sedated. Tranquilize yourself too and you'll be just like them!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Look On
Mnemonic: Nearby there is a beautiful view. Look on as the sun sets and the sky changes color. You would give up anything to be able to spectate this kind of thing all the time.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Loss Of A Close Game
Mnemonic: Your team was about to win the game but you decided to be frugal with your shots near the end and it resulted in defeat, making it a loss of a close game. If you had just taken those shots your team probably would have won. What a regrettable defeat.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Master
Mnemonic: At dawn what's the first thing you're supposed to see? Your master. He wants you to wake him up and bring his slippers.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Matcha
Mnemonic: Erase your need for normal tea by drinking matcha. It is far superior to all others and you'll never turn back once you've had a taste.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Monitoring
Mnemonic: Only accept new people moving in nearby once you've finished properly monitoring them! Tapping into their phones will probably help too, but don't tell anyone I told you to do that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mourning
Mnemonic: Follow people who grieve by mourning with them. You don't want to be the only one who doesn't seem sad.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned this reading with the word 追随, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case: You're mourning the loss of your pet bird. You can't help but yell TWEET (つい) to the sky, hoping she'll come back to life. It doesn't work so you stay in a state of mourning for the rest of your life. She was your best bird friend, after all.

Name: Move For A Different Job
Mnemonic: Proceed to a new place to do your duty. That's just a fancy way to say you're about to move for a different job. This is usually a job at the same company you're already at, it's just a different position for you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Near
Mnemonic: Something nearby is near to you. It's very close.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: There is a restaurant near your house that only sells dishes with soba (そば) noodles in them. They're delicious, but it's so close to your home that you can smell them all the time. Sometimes it feels like that's all you'll ever smell anymore.

Name: New Year's Day
Mnemonic: The origin of dawn can be found on New Year's Day. That's when the new sun is born and rises above the earth for a whole year until it dies. And that's the origin of dawn, children. Don't let your teachers tell you otherwise.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 元 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who's always there on the dawn of New Year's Day welcoming the new sun? Gandhi (がん). He sits on the edge of the earth and makes sure the sun feels welcome. What a nice guy.

Name: Noble Visitor
Mnemonic: A valuable VIP is a noble visitor. They're probably a queen or a diplomat or something. So you better treat them really well.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Obliteration
Mnemonic: To erase or kill something results in total obliteration. This word refers to the erasure, denial, ignoring, or killing of something's very existence. It can even mean murder in some cases.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Of Course
Mnemonic: You must not consider this a theory, because of course it's a fact. Needless to say, this is the way things are.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. Needless to say, you should be able to read this on your own!

Name: Old Shop
Mnemonic: An elderly shop is an old shop.
ReadingMnemonic: This reading is an exception, so here's a mnemonic: You go to an old shop and come across a sheep knee sale (しにせ). When you ask what a sheep knee sale is, the clerk tells you quite matter-of-factly that it's a sale on all the sheep knees. You've never seen this in newer shops, so it must be a pretty old practice to buy and sell sheep knees.

Name: Once
Mnemonic: You only have time to do one thing at dawn once. Dawn is really short so you can do whatever it is for a moment, but that's it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Outline
Mnemonic: Trace the enclosure of a wheel on paper and you'll have drawn its outline.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Oval Face
Mnemonic: If you ask me to tell the truth I'll say your face is shaped like a melon. No no, it's not a bad thing! You just have a really oval face!
ReadingMnemonic: This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for 瓜 and 顔, but in the middle there, 実 has a bit of an exceptional reading. You certainly haven't learned this weirdness before, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know who has an oval face? Zayn (ざね) formerly from One Direction. When you think of handsome oval faces, picture Zayn's.

Name: Painkiller
Mnemonic: Tranquilize your pain with a strong dose of painkillers! Yum yum. Don't take too many though!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Patriotic Concern
Mnemonic: Whenever something bad happens to your country you feel an exceptional amount of grief for your fellow country people. This is some serious patriotic concern you've got going on. Let's hope you use those concerns for something good and don't get too carried away.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pleasant
Mnemonic: A pleasant pleasant person is super pleasant! They're happy and nice to everybody all the time!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Prisoner Of War
Mnemonic: Catch a captive and he'll be a prisoner of war. Or, if you're not in a war, just an ordinary captive.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Prosperity
Mnemonic: Overgrown prosperity is still prosperity. Why, it's even thriving. Nice!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes しょう to じょう!

Name: Pumpkin
Mnemonic: Melons from the south are lumpy and orange, sometimes orange and green because they try to look like the hot sun. Wait, those aren't melons, they're pumpkins and squash. Or... kind of a mix of the two, if you already know what kabocha tastes like.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this is an exception, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Japanese pumpkins don't taste like American pumpkins. They taste more like canned boiled chocolate (かぼちゃ). Oh, you don't know that either? Well then just taste the pumpkin and you'll know what that tastes like too. This word is also sometimes read なんきん, especially in the east of Japan.

Name: Regrettable
Mnemonic: If you leave behind something and it makes you feel remorse it's a really regrettable situation. You should probably go back for whatever it was so you won't lead an unsatisfactory life.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Repose Of Souls
Mnemonic: To tranquilize souls you have to a have a mass repose of souls. Then their souls will move on to the next life and stop hanging around here, haunting umbrellas.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rustic
Mnemonic: Your home is out in the middle of a coarse looking field. Whenever you bring friends over the only word they say to describe your dirt and grass home is that it's rustic. That's pretty rude of them, you love your dirt home! Even if it is kinda small and stinky and in a field.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ryota
Mnemonic: Distant fat makes up the Japanese given name Ryota. Imagine soccer player Noguchi Ryota (野口 遼太) kicking a fat soccer ball into the distance while voice actor Asari Ryota (浅利 遼太) commentates.
ReadingMnemonic: This name uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You haven't learned this particular on'yomi for 太 yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Ryota's diet consists only of tacos (た). Tacos, tacos, tacos for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Yum!

Name: Service
Mnemonic: Dedicate yourself to the public by doing community service!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Simple
Mnemonic: People made from simple elements are also pretty simple. And they can be naive too. But that's just how they're built.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Solidify
Mnemonic: Your pudding congealed and is all hard. How on earth did it solidify like this? It shouldn't freeze unless you put it in the freezer. Unless, did you? Oh...
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Spinal Cord
Mnemonic: Marrow that gives you stature is inside of your spinal cord.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Stare
Mnemonic: Freeze and look at me. Your stare is giving me the creeps! You can move now. Hey. You can move now. Stop I said!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: State Guest
Mnemonic: A VIP from another country is a state guest.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Stepfather
Mnemonic: A father you've inherited isn't your original father, he's your stepfather.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. This word can also be read as ままちち, because 継 can take the special reading まま when it's used as the prefix "step," as in "stepfather."

Name: Successive Promotion
Mnemonic: Accumulate enough of a good reputation at your company in advance and you'll be able to have successive promotions. You'll be boss in no time!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Suppression
Mnemonic: Tranquilize pressure with medication that helps with its suppression. Then you won't have to feel it anymore.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Surrender
Mnemonic: Bow as you descend into enemy territory. This is how you have to surrender if you want to live. Keep your head nice and low and descend into their ranks.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: This
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: To Appease
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tranquilize, so the verb version is what happens when you've already been able to tranquilize someone. It's to appease or to suppress.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to appease her because she's (しず) SUPER mad. She's pissed and she's angry and she's going to beat you up if you don't find out how to calm her down!

Name: To Be Anxious
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grieve, so the verb version is to grieve or to be anxious.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your aunt starts to grieve really loudly at your Uncle Ray's funeral. "Ooh, Ray (うれ)! OOoh, Ray why did you have to leave me!" It's really sad. You even hear it in your head after you've left and gone home. You've never seen someone start to be distressed like that in public.

Name: To Be Frugal
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means frugal, so the verb version is to be frugal or to be sparing.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You should try to be frugal when you go to the ocean (おし). There are lots of things to buy, like delicious food, sun hats, and tofugu dolls, but you really shouldn't spend all your money there. Try to plan on spending less when you head to the ocean next time, okay?

Name: To Be Passionate About
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means congeal or freeze, so the verb version is to grow stiff. Remember 肩こり (shoulder stiffness)? This is where that こり part comes from.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What have all your friends started to be passionate about? Their 子s (こ). They all keep having kids and now that's all they seem to care about. Damn kids.

Name: Tochigi Prefecture
Mnemonic: The prefecture with lots of horse chestnut trees is Tochigi prefecture.
ReadingMnemonic: This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for 栃 and 木 and the on'yomi for 県, like most with prefectures. As long as you remember that き is changed to ぎ here, you should be able to remember this reading easily!

Name: To Cover
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bow or lay, so the verb version is what when you try to cover or to hide something. You're doing the action to something, you're not the one hiding.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who's that you're trying to cover up? It's your fool (ふ) brother. He keeps doing embarrassing things and trying to get you in trouble. So you're trying to hide him with your jacket. Well we see him, we know he's a fool, so you can stop now.

Name: To Install
Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 据える, meaning "to install," and 付ける, meaning "to attach." Put them together and you're still going to install something or to equip something. There's just more hands on work happening.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Undulation
Mnemonic: Wake up, now lay yourself down, now wake up again, okay now lay again. What you're doing is called undulation. If your emotions do it it's called ups and downs. Everyone goes through stuff like this sometimes.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Urine
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Vividly Depicted
Mnemonic: A leap of likeness is when something that's not real takes a big leap towards the likeness to reality. This happens when something is vividly depicted or clearly expressed.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Wasabi
Mnemonic: If you dig up hollyhocks in the mountains, and grind up their roots, you'll have wasabi! Don't eat too much, or you'll burn your tongue off.
ReadingMnemonic: This reading is an exception, but I'm sure (at least I hope) that you've heard the word wasabi before. It's the same in Japanese so just remember the meaning and you'll know the reading too!

Name: Wedding Reception
Mnemonic: You already learned that 披露 means "announcement" or "display," so add a banquet to that and you're at a wedding reception! Or if no one's getting married but they're showing off something at a big place with food and stuff it's a just a normal reception.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Yayoi Period
Mnemonic: Life in Japan was increasing at its fastest rate during the Yayoi Period. It's one of the earliest periods of history in Japan that we know about! You should look it up, if you don't already know about it.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is an exception but it's the same in Japanese as it is in English. So if you just remember it's Yayoi (やよい) in English, you'll remember the Japanese too!

Name: All The More
Mnemonic: Having a furthermore renewal means things become all the more... good, bad, cute, ugly, whatever it is you’re talking about! Or, on the opposite side of things, still less.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: And Yet
Mnemonic: Someone keeps saying furthermore and also over and over again. Just when you think they've stopped, they turn around and say "and yet," before going back to repeating furthermore and besides again and again. It's driving you crazy.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Applause
Mnemonic: Hands beating together is actually applause. Though... you might be doing it wrong if you're actually beating them together.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Artisan
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You meet an artisan and they're tacking pictures on a wall to sell. You want the artisan to make a picture of you too so you yell, "TACK ME (たくみ)!"

Name: Auspicious Day
Mnemonic: A day you hold in high esteem is an auspicious day. That's a fancy way of saying it's a really lucky day!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bitter Enemies In The Same Boat
Meaning: Bitter Enemies In The Same Boat
Mnemonic: You give your rival information that will go beyond what you normally say and you realize the two of you are in the same boat on a lot of personal things. You are bitter enemies in the same boat! Or classic rivals, like you see in movies and read about. You never would have known if you hadn't gone beyond what you normally give people.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 舟 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The problem with bitter enemies in the same boat is that they never try stepping into each other's shoes (しゅう).

Name: Butterfly
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Butterfly
Mnemonic: A butterfly with another butterfly added to it? It's still a butterfly, just a really big one with... with four wings. And laser eyes? Oh well, just go with it. It's a butterfly.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is just the on'yomi readings (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

Name: Captain

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Centigrade
Mnemonic: Okay, so this is a stretch but stay with me! In addition to your family name, the first thing you need to learn as a child is how to understand centigrade. If you can't tell what temperature it is outside, or in your house, or in your body to tell if you're sick, you won't do so well with this living thing. So when you think back to the first things you learned in addition to your own family name, think centigrade!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Common

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Confusion

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Delight

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Direct Control

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Distress
Mnemonic: Destitute conditions lead to distress.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Extension

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Far Away

ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading! Just don't forget the か at the end.

Name: Firewood
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: First Lieutenant
Mnemonic: A military officer who's in the middle of their career has become a first lieutenant.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Flood
Mnemonic: A flood of water still makes a flood.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. But watch out because すい becomes ずい here.

Name: Foolish
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: A foolish person will take the old road (おろ), instead of the new, safe one. You have to be really stupid to take an old road that's all cracked and full of scary people. Take the new one!

Name: Gallant
Mnemonic: A cold cold person is so cold that they're super cool. They're sooo cool and gallant and manly. Touch a manly person and feel how cold their skin is. It's like that all the way down to their heart.
ReadingMnemonic: Usually when you see 々 it means that the reading is two on'yomi readings repeating. Well this is a bit of an exception. Saying りんりん is kinda hard so just drop the んs and you'll have the reading りり!

Name: Gentleman
Mnemonic: Gentlemen who are also samurai are still gentlemen. They just carry swords.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Grain
Mnemonic: Grain things are grains and cereal!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Grains
Mnemonic: Grains are types of grains! You thought they would be something else? Nope. Grains are pretty boring.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Gravestone
Mnemonic: Combine a grave and a tombstone and you make a gravestone.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Hill
Mnemonic: Just because there's a mausoleum on this hill doesn't mean it isn't still a hill. (It is. It's still a hill.)
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Illusion
Mnemonic: You thought you memorized what this picture looked like, but suddenly everything looks confused and different. That's because it's an illusion.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Imported
Mnemonic: A boat that comes from somewhere else is bringing imported goods.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Inscription
Mnemonic: The writing on a tombstone makes up the inscription or epitaph the family members decided to put there.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Intake
Mnemonic: Your body takes nutrients into itself in addition to all the extra crap you eat. It's called your daily intake. And it gets all of those nutrients in your body through absorption.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Jurisdiction
Mnemonic: Whoever holds the pipe has control of the situation so you give them jurisdiction to do whatever they want. It's better than getting hit by a pipe.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Jurisdiction
Mnemonic: The place you have control over is your jurisdiction.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lazy Person
Mnemonic: A lazy someone is a lazy person.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lonely
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of lonely? It's still lonely!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: No one is as lonely as a sad bee (さび). The sad bee is sad because it has no friends and that makes is super lonely. Poor sad bee.

Name: Master
Mnemonic: An artisan who is a giant in their field is a master! Everyone knows their name! Or, they're just really large... like tall, so everyone calls them a master cause they don't want to get crushed.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Master
Mnemonic: An artisan who's good enough to be a teacher has to be a master of her craft.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mediocre
Mnemonic: Mediocre and commonplace things are still mediocre and commonplace.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Milking
Mnemonic: Squeeze an udder to get milk. Look at that, you're milking a cow!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mistake
Mnemonic: If you're confused and you make a mistake, no matter how much you didn't mean it, it's still a mistake. You should ask for help next time you don't know what you're doing and you won't make these errors.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mixture
Mnemonic: You mix a bunch of ingredients into a confused mixture. That's going to be one weird cake, or whatever the mixture's for.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Monument
Mnemonic: Some tombstones are used to write down the thoughts of dead people. They're monuments. They can be really big or really small, but they have to be dedicated to somebody (usually a dead somebody).
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Nachi Falls
Mnemonic: What wisdom waterfall is Nachi Falls, one of the most famous (and wisest) waterfalls in Japan.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned all three of these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Neglect
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: You notice a lot of neglect when it comes to old road soap cars (おろそか). If you drive down the old road you'll see neglected cars made of soap all over the place. It's sad, really.

Name: Nitrogen
Mnemonic: An element that can cause a person to suffocate is nitrogen. Too much or too little will cause it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: No Sense Of Direction
Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 方向 and 音痴. When your sense of direction is tone-deaf, it means you have no sense of direction. You get lost no matter how hard you try.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ordinary
Mnemonic: Remember how 庶民 means "common people"? Well, anything that's "common-people-like" is ordinary, unpretentious, and approachable.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ordinary Person
Mnemonic: A mediocre person is an ordinary person. There isn't anything weird or interesting about them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Our Company
Mnemonic: An evil company is actually our company or our humble company. We're not going to say our company is virtuous, are we? That wouldn't be humble at all. So instead we call it evil, to show our humility.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Perversion
Mnemonic: When your confused urges overthrow normal thoughts and feelings it's a perversion. Some are harmless, but some are not.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Popular Song
Mnemonic: You already learned that 歌謡 means "song," so when you add music to that it becomes a super popular song. It's not just a song anymore. It's in everything you hear!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Poverty
Mnemonic: You'll be distressed and destitute if you're living in poverty.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Poverty
Mnemonic: Towns destitute and scarce of food will end up in poverty and destitution.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Prime Minister
Mnemonic: The person everyone comes to a mutual agreement about to be the manager of the country is the Prime Minister.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You already know both readings, but make sure to read 相 as しょう. This should be easy to remember since Shoguns (しょう) were like prime ministers back in the day!

Name: Prodigy
Mnemonic: It's an injustice that so many people in this world are mediocre and we can't all be a prodigy at something. Everyone deserves to be unique, but it just isn't true.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pulse
Mnemonic: The beating in your veins is your pulse.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Respectful
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of respect? It's respectful.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji so you should be able to read this too.

Name: Restraint
Mnemonic: Bind a bundle of sticks to a person as a type of restraint. They can't get away when they're tied to a bunch of sticks, can they?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rice
Mnemonic: Rice grains make up the rice we eat everyday.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Satiation
Mnemonic: You're bored but you keep eating. Maybe you're eating because you're bored. If you're bored all the time, eventually your main goal in life becomes satiation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Saturation
Mnemonic: If you're so bored of peace because all there IS is peace, it's called saturation of the peace market. You've pretty much been soaked through with peace and now you want a little chaotic excitement!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Second Lieutenant
Mnemonic: Someone who's only been a military officer for a few years hasn't been able to get very far in the ranks. They're an ensign, or a second lieutenant. That's still not a bad position to be in!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sewing
Mnemonic: Sew to manufacture things by sewing.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sewing
Mnemonic: Sew so well that people will judge you to be the best and you'll be a champion at sewing!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Shiba Inu
Mnemonic: The brushwood dog is the Shiba Inu. They're the same pretty orange color as brushwood trees, so that's how they got their name.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ship
Mnemonic: A boat ship is still a ship.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Silence
Mnemonic: If you're lonely and quiet you'll be surrounded in silence.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sluggish
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of lazy? It's sluggish and dull.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: If you're feeling sluggish just turn on Darude's (だる) "Sandstorm" and it will perk you right up. But a world where people don't know Darude's "Sandstorm"  is full of sluggish, dull nerds.

Name: Stone Monument
Mnemonic: A tombstone made of a big stone is used as a stone monument. These stones are usually so big that they're used for multiple people who died together.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: String
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word share meanings — in this case, the musical string and bowstring meanings!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading can be either the kun'yomi or on'yomi reading, so you have a choice. Since you learned the on'yomi げん with the kanji already, let's learn the つる reading here. When people see your mysterious bow, their curiosity takes over. Without even asking, they walk right up and start pulling the bowstring. Too rude (つる)! Seriously, some people have no manners. Who just yanks on someone's bowstring like that?! TOO RUDE! Keep in mind that the on'yomi reading げん refers to the strings of a stringed instrument, whereas the kun'yomi つる refers to the string of a bow.

Name: String Music
Mnemonic: Remember how 楽 was used in 音楽 (music)? Well this is that 楽 again. So this is string music, which of course means string music.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, and you've learned both. 楽 has two on'yomi readings, but when it's from 音楽, it's read がく. Because remember: if you play your music too loud, people will come and gawk (がく) at you. And it's the same with loud string music!

Name: Suffocation
Mnemonic: Suffocate to the point that you have no breath left and you'll die of suffocation. Chew your food and this shouldn't happen!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Suicide
Mnemonic: When your self decides on something, that's called self-determination. But the word is mainly used in Japan as a euphemism for suicide. It's kind of important that you know that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Supervision
Mnemonic: The master manager rules over all of the other managers and he's in charge of their supervision. If anything goes wrong it will be blamed on him! He has to keep a close watch on them!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tight
Mnemonic: Don't yield to anything when you're destitute because it'll make things even more tight. Usually you have to be pretty rigid about what you can and cannot afford.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Be Amazed
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shock, so the verb version is to be shocked or to be amazed.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you were going to be shocked, you'd shout, "ACK (あき)!"

Name: To Get Tired Of
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bored, so the verb version is to get tired of or to lose interest in.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you start to get tired of something you can't help but yawn "Ahh (あ)." It doesn't matter how hard you try to hold back. The "A-ah's" keep coming out.

Name: To Sew
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sew, so the verb version is to sew or to stitch.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to sew yourself some clothes because if you don't you'll be completely nude (ぬ). You don't want anyone to see your bits! Sew quickly!

Name: To Squeeze
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means squeeze, so the verb version is to squeeze. The way that this word differs from 絞る is that 絞る means "to wring out" and 搾る means to squeeze or to juice fruits/vegetables or to milk a cow.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: After the farmer milks the cow, she bows (しぼ) to the cow to say thank you for letting her squeeze out some fresh milk.

Name: To Stray
Mnemonic: This is the intransitive form of 逸らす (to turn away), meaning it doesn't take a direct object. 逸れる is like when something turns off from the normal course of things, so it means to stray. A conversation straying from the main topic, a car that strays from the main road, or your focus straying in a moment of distraction — all of these work with 逸れる.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. The two kun'yomi readings have difference nuances, so here's a mnemonic to help you with those: In conversation you always seem to stray from the point and talk about soap (そ). You just love soap — the scents, the bubbles, the cleanliness. The one thing you never stray from is… straying from the topic just to bring up soap. And because you're lost in thoughts about suds all the time, you tend to get separated from your friends whenever you're out together. When they finally come find you, they give you a big hug (はぐ). It's only natural to give someone a hug after you've been separated a while, right?

Name: To Tie
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bind, so the verb version is to tie or to bind.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want to tie up? Your Shiba (しば) Inu! She's always running off and getting into trouble. You have to tie her up outside when you leave the house. It's sad, but at least it keeps her safe!

Name: Wisdom
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Without Pay
Mnemonic: You already learned that 報酬 means "compensation," so adding not to it means the person working isn't getting paid, aka working without pay.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Yasukuni Shrine
Mnemonic: You already know that 神社 means "shinto shrine," so add peaceful and country to it and you get a shrine that calls for the peace of the entire country. It's Yasukuni Shrine. If you watch the news you know that this name and everything it stands for is always a topic of current debates.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of two words. The first two kanji take the kun'yomi readings and the second two are the jukugo word 神社. You already learned all of these readings, so you should already be able to read this word!

Name: A And B
Mnemonic: A and B make A and B!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Abortion
Mnemonic: If you bring degradation to a womb, and there was a fetus in it, it causes an abortion. Or, in the case of an unwanted criminal abortion, feticide.

Name: Brewing

Name: Browsing

Name: Censor

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Channel

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Circulatory Organ
Mnemonic: You already know that 循環 means "circulation," so adding container makes it what holds things that circulate. They're your circulatory organs. They contain all the blood moving throughout your body like a container.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Clownfish
Mnemonic: I want you to try to bear this truth and that's these kanji make up the word clownfish! Do you think a clownfish is this bear? I'm telling the truth! Maybe.
ReadingMnemonic: This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for all the kanji. You haven't learned these readings for 之 or 実 yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you get too close to a clownfish, it will hide inside its stinging anemone and shout, "YOU DON'T KNOW ME (のみ)! It's true, you don't know this clownfish, but you want to. I guess all of them are afraid of strangers though... how will you know me if you don't give me a chance, clownfish?!

Name: Color Blindness
Mnemonic: If you're only blind to color then you have color blindness.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Compass
Mnemonic: Spread out a needle in a tray of water after rubbing it with a magnet and you'll have made a compass! Try it at home kids! It really works!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Conception
Mnemonic: Accept a child into your womb with conception. Now there's a baby in there!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Condolence
Mnemonic: Express your unique idea of condolence by offering your condolences and sympathy to people who are going through hard times.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cornea
Mnemonic: Membranes that wrap around at an angle are in your eye. Eyes are round and the membranes have to bend around the front part at an angle. It's called your cornea.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Covering

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Crow
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Dare To
Mnemonic: This is the adverb version of the kanji daring, so it means dare to or daringly.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're about to daringly jump off a cliff and you shout, "AAAHHH (あ)!" to get your courage up! You always have to yell AAHH before you dare to do daring things!

Name: Dark Navy Blue
Mnemonic: Put a thick drop of navy blue paint on a canvas and it will look like an even bolder dark navy blue.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Decisive Action

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Depravity
Mnemonic: A degradation fall is a fall into depravity. Meaning you'll probably lead a life of degradation. Stealing, stabbing, money laundering, various excesses… That kind of depravity.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Drum
Mnemonic: A fat drum is still a drum. This word can be used for any type of drum, but a common one in Japan is the taiko. There are lots of different types of taiko, and most of them are big and fat, and make a lovely deep sound. They're super cool to watch and play!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Eardrum
Mnemonic: You can hear something beat because of a membrane in your ear called an eardrum. Make sure you don't stick your fingers too far in your ear or you could really hurt it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Embryo
Mnemonic: A child that's still in a womb is a fetus.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Enumeration
Mnemonic: Spread out a complete row of numbers in the right order and you have enumeration!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Enzyme
Mnemonic: The one element you need to ferment something is an enzyme. That breaks whatever you're trying to ferment down in just the right way.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Equilibrium
Mnemonic: Equal out your equilibrium and you'll have solid equilibrium.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Experiences
Mnemonic: It’s a universal truth that we are the continuation of our experiences and history.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fermentation
Mnemonic: When you ferment something it makes a departure from what it originally was and transforms during fermentation into something new.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fighting Bravely
Mnemonic: If you're involved in a daring fight, you're probably fighting bravely. You could get hurt, or worse, but you don't even care! Talk about fighting bravely… And good luck with that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fish Tank
Mnemonic: A tank of water can be used as a fish tank or a water tank for drinking. It really only depends on you and how many fish you have.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Germination
Mnemonic: A sprout that sprouts can thank germination for being able to sprout nice and big and strong.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 芽 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When a plant sprouts out of the ground it's still a baby so all it can say is goo goo ga ga (が).

Name: Grief
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, but wait! It's not an adjective, it's just a noun (tricky, tricky). The kanji means grief, so this word means grief or distress.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 憂える. Remember that and you'll remember this!

Name: Hand Drum
Mnemonic: What do you hit to make a sick beat? A cool little hand drum.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You like to use your hand drum when two dudes meet (つづみ). You drum and tap it and it as they high five and it makes them super uncomfortable which makes you super happy. That's why you love your hand drum so much.

Name: How Many Times
Mnemonic: What's universal? How many times do you think that question's been asked throughout time? Probably a lot of times.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word with an unusual reading, where the first kanji uses kun'yomi and the second uses on'yomi. You've seen these readings before, so you should be able to read this. Just watch out, because へん becomes べん here!

Name: Inspiration
Mnemonic: The beat makes you want to dance. It's the inspiration you need to dance. The beat gives you encouragement to dance all night long. And without such a rockin' beat you would have lame dance moves.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Intestines

Name: Isolation

Name: Large Intestine

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Letterpress

ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because はん becomes ぱん here.

Name: Lineage
Mnemonic: Blood flows through your veins, carrying the stories of your lineage, your bloodline.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Lumbering
Mnemonic: Fell trees and gather them up. That's called lumbering. Or if you cut them all down and take every last one, it's deforestation and you should be ashamed!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Magistrate
Mnemonic: If you can dedicate yourself to going to a bunch of meetings and dealing with everyone's problems you'll make a good magistrate.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned either of these readings yet. Sorry! Here's a mnemonic to help you: The magistrate is the only person who's allowed to drink booze and eat gyoza (ぶぎょう). If you see someone simultaneously drinking booze and eating dumplings in Japan, you'll know that person is the magistrate!

Name: Maple
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Maple Sugar
Mnemonic: Maple sugar is maple sugar!
ReadingMnemonic: 楓 uses the kun'yomi and 糖 uses the on'yomi. You already learned both of these, so you should have no problem with this word's reading: かえでとう. You might see some stores use this instead of メープルシュガー to keep things short and… maple-sweet. 楓糖 can also be read as ふうとう, using the on'yomi for both kanji. Since 楓 contains the 風 component, it makes sense that its on'yomi is ふう, right? Just know that ふうとう sounds a bit more technical or formal than something you'd sprinkle in your morning oatmeal.

Name: Melody
Mnemonic: If you follow the law of rotation while you play music you'll end up with a lovely melody. If you don't, you'll miss all the cues on beat that rotation gives you and it will sound like crap.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Membrane
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Memorial Address
Mnemonic: When someone quits living you need to offer your condolences during their memorial address. Let it all out and tell everyone what you thought about that dead guy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Navy Blue
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Once
Mnemonic: One universal event can only happen once. It's too rare to happen more than that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because へん becomes ぺん here.

Name: Oolong Tea
Mnemonic: Imperial tea the color of a crow's feathers can only be the famous, delicious Oolong tea. It came from the imperial people of China to Japan (probably) and there are lots of different variants. But the leaves are all that blackish/grey crow feather color.
ReadingMnemonic: This word takes the on'yomi readings except for 龍 which is an exception (sorry). You haven't learned the on'yomi for 烏 yet either, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who loves Oolong tea more than anyone else? Oooo Ron (うーろん) Weasley from Harry Potter. He's British, so of course you'd think he loves tea, but Oolong is his jam. Just picture him and think, oooooh it's Ron, when you drink this kind of tea. And make sure you remember that, because this is also a written in katakana when the kanji isn't used, to type out the long mark ー when you enter your answer.

Name: Pallid
Mnemonic: If you're pale white, you're pale, or pallid. This word is usually used to talk about the pallor of someone's face.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word and uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You learned those readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pirate
Mnemonic: Robbers who sail on the high seas are pirates! Arrr!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Placenta
Mnemonic: Something comes out of a womb and is then put on a tray. It's the afterbirth. Yeah, yeah, eww. Grow up, it's a word you should know.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ravine
Mnemonic: A ravine in a valley is still a ravine. It can also be a gorge or a canyon. They're usually really big. Like the Grand Canyon!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 谷 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're going to travel through a huge ravine you have to stay hydrated. The best thing to bring is some taste, cold Coke (こく). Nothing quenches your thirst from sweating through a long, rough ravine like delicious Coke!

Name: Reception Hall
Mnemonic: A public building where you welcome VIP guests is a reception hall. Or a guest house if they're staying the night.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Regrettable
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of frugal? It's regrettable or precious. If you're too frugal to buy something your actions are regrettable later when you realize you wanted that thing. If you're so frugal you only buy one single thing, it's very precious to you.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You made a regrettable decision. You didn't buy that clock you wanted and now it's been discontinued. The salesperson tells you this and all you can say is, "Oh..." (お) really really quietly. How disappointing.

Name: Resolute
Mnemonic: A daring fruit is very resolute and bold! She's going to go out and be a fruit superhero or scientist or something.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Retina
Mnemonic: In the back of your eye there's a net-like membrane called the retina. It's net-like because it catches… light! You know, to help you see.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Revision
Mnemonic: An inspection you make of your homework before school is a revision. Sometimes proofreading will help you find mistakes before you hand it in too. Just make sure you look everything over.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Revolution
Mnemonic: It doesn't matter how many times a rotation goes around, it's still a rotation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Salary Reduction
Mnemonic: Your boss says she's going to decrease your salary with a company-wide salary reduction. You should probably start looking for a new job that won't do salary cuts like this.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because ほう becomes ぽう here.

Name: Sea Salt
Mnemonic: If you want to find some coarse salt just dive in the sea and collect sea salt! The pieces are nice and big and lumpy, so you really taste it when you're cooking.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Second
Mnemonic: If something is the latter, it can't be first, it has to be at least second. This works for lists too. So if you have A through D, it's going to be B.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Squid
Mnemonic: Look in the sea and you'll see what looks like a crow moving under the water and it's a thief! It's stealing from all the fish. As it comes closer you see that it isn't a crow, it's a squid. Or a cuttlefish? One or the other.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is completely irregular, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: You call the fish police to arrest that thieving squid, but it jumps into it's eagle car (いか) and makes a swift getaway. In case you didn't know, an eagle car is an eagle moonlighting as a car. The eagle car is zooming up into the sky, so there's no way the fish police can catch it now.

Name: Stomach
Mnemonic: Intestines and stomach make up the stomach in your body.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Takuya
Mnemonic: The cultivation of a question mark is something that only people called Takuya can do. Imagine a famous Takuya, like actor and singer Kimura Takuya (木村 拓哉 a.k.a. キムタク), or a Takuya you know, cultivating a huge field of question marks. Rows and rows of question marks. I wonder what he's going to do with all those question marks once they're ready to harvest. Other people who must have an abundance of question marks are pro baseball player Kinoshita Takuya (木下 拓哉 a.k.a. キノタク) and actor, model, and K-Pop star Terada Takuya (寺田 拓哉).
ReadingMnemonic: You learned both of these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this name on your own.

Name: Thief
Mnemonic: A robber who steals is a thief. And still a robber, I guess.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Brew
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means brew, so the verb version is to brew or to distill.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to brew up some beer but not the regular boring stuff. You're going to make it from the water in the hump of a camel (かも). Camel beer is definitely not a horrible idea, right?

Name: To Heal Something
Mnemonic: The kanji means healing and the verb version means to heal something, to cure something, and even to quench a thirst, both literally and metaphorically. As you can probably guess, this last use has a poetic feel to it.
ReadingMnemonic: To heal something it's sometimes necessary to do something いや (gross). Even if you dislike it, even if it's gross, you do it anyway, because you want to heal whatever it is.

Name: To Interrupt
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means intercept, so the verb version is to intercept or to interrupt.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you want to interrupt and to intercept is your roommate's sighing guitar (さえぎ). He keeps playing it and all it does is make these horrible, long sighing sounds. You want to interrupt it any cost.

Name: To Mourn For
Meaning: To Hold A Memorial Service For
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means condolence, so the verb version is to mourn for or to condole.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You seem to mourn for things you really care about. Well then you would mourn for your toe mural (とむら). You had a mural made for your favorite toe so if anything were to happen to it, you would want to mourn for it.

Name: To Quiet Down
Mnemonic: You already learned that 鎮める means "to appease," but this one is what happens after they've been appeased. They start to quiet down.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you're in the library the librarian is always telling you to quiet down. She's (しず) so mean! She never lets you talk in the library. Who's mean to you? She's mean to you!!

Name: Tree Thinning
Mnemonic: Fell trees in intervals, instead of all at once, and it's called tree thinning. That way there's still some forest there, but you get your wood to use for other things too.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Tsubo
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Uneven
Mnemonic: A surface covered in convex and concave parts is going to be really uneven and rough.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Universal
Mnemonic: Something normal and universal is still universal. Normally.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Unpleasant
Mnemonic: You already learned that 愉快 means "pleasant" or "happy," so add not to that and you're unpleasant and unhappy.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Unwritten Law
Mnemonic: This not writing law is a law that hasn't been written down. It's an unwritten law, like taking your shoes off and showering every day.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Name: Vicious Cycle
Mnemonic: You already know that 循環 means "circulation" or "cycle," so adding bad to that makes it a vicious cycle.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: While
Mnemonic: The kanji 傍 literally means nearby or side, but here in 傍ら it's being used figuratively, which is why this means while or alongside.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You do your job while thinking about the cutter war (かたわ) — a never-ending war to cut budgets at work. Imagine all the colleagues you've already lost to the cutter war layoffs… You never know whether you've survived the latest round of cuts either, so you gotta work while worrying about these corporate bloodbaths. Yeesh!

Name: Whirlwind
Mnemonic: A rotation of wind forms a whirlwind, in both the physical and figurative senses. On the figurative side, it can also mean commotion and sensation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because ふう becomes ぷう here (hehe).

Name: Yeast
Mnemonic: The mother of good fermentation is yeast! If you want to bake a pie or bread you have to have the best. And if you don't have any, maybe your neighbor has some extra that you can borrow?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Aid
Mnemonic: Help and aid someone and you will help and aid them! Good job, you're a good person.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Amnesty
Mnemonic: Pardon someone out of the kindness in your heart and you'll have granted them amnesty. How kind of you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Anger
Mnemonic: You resent someone so much that you sigh with anger whenever they're around. Everything they do makes you feel really strong resentment.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Autopsy
Mnemonic: Divide a body and untie its organs to perform an autopsy. You have to cut it all up and untangle the parts to see why this person or animal died.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Beat
Mnemonic: Break down a beat into all of its children and you’ve got more than just a single beat. You’ve got an assortment of beats, making a rhythm, and setting a tempo.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of its kanji.
