However, 拍 uses its secondary reading, which you haven’t learned yet, so here’s a mnemonic to help you: You get the beat and the rhythm going in your body. You can't help but sing out loud, "Heyo (ひょう), heyo!" Feel that rhythm and sing with me! HEYO HEYO!

Name: Bright Blue
Mnemonic: What is lapis lazuli glassy color? It's bright blue. If you've never seen the rock lapis lazuli, look it up and you'll see why this means bright blue!
ReadingMnemonic: You learned all three of these readings when you learned the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Catalyst
Mnemonic: If a mediator touches people the right way, they will become a catalyst for change. This could be good or bad change depending on what they stuck their hands in.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chicken
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: A chicken is a 庭 (garden) 鳥 (bird) (にわとり). It's a bird that you keep in your garden, after all!

Name: Chicken Egg
Mnemonic: A chicken egg is a chicken egg.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 卵 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who loves chicken eggs? Randy (らん) Savage! Especially when he eats them with slim jims. Mmm eggs and slim jims. You should give it a try.

Name: Chicken Farming
Mnemonic: Foster a bunch of chickens and start chicken farming! They will be your best friends! Your only friends.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Chicken Meat
Mnemonic: Chicken meat is chicken meat!
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses a kun'yomi reading for 鶏 that you haven't learned yet (とり), plus the usual on'yomi for 肉. Sounds tricky, but remember how 鳥 is とり? Chicken meat is basically just bird meat, so think of it like that when you're trying to remember this reading!

Name: Chronological Record
Mnemonic: Write down the years of your genealogy in order and it makes a chronological record of your life. Look back on it when you're old and sigh about the old days.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dawn
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Decrepit
Mnemonic: Elderly people start to decay and they get all decrepit and gross. Like a corpse. Bleh. Good thing I'll never be too old. Ho ho ho!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Drama
Mnemonic: A play that uses lots of intense, emotional music is a drama.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dumbfounded
Mnemonic: The energy of being shocked fills your body and leaves you dumbfounded. You're so taken aback by this surge of shock that all you can do is stand still and let the energy go through you.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for one kanji and the on'yomi reading for the other. Just remember that they're the two readings you didn't learn when you learned the kanji and you should be okay.

Name: Earth's Crust
Mnemonic: The earth's shell is called the earth's crust. You should have learned that in earth science. And if you didn't, at least you know now!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Enjoyment
Mnemonic: The best thing to receive and accept into your life is enjoyment! Don't block it out, let it in! Be happy!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Evening Drink
Mnemonic: At night you are served an evening drink. It's okay to have a strong drink with dinner every now and then.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Feudal Lord
Mnemonic: The master of a fiefdom is the feudal lord. We also call them Daimyo.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Fiefdom
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Fresh
Mnemonic: You give your congratulations to someone a few times because they seem so fresh and vibrant. You feel like you should because it must be nice to be like that still. Someday it will be gone, so make sure you say it a few times right away.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is just the kun'yomi reading (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

Name: Game
Mnemonic: You play and play all day! What do you play? A game! Or a sport! Which are technically games!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Game Records
Mnemonic: Write down the scores people get from taking all of their opponent's chess pieces and you'll be writing down game records. This is usually only used for old-fashioned Japanese games like go and shogi. Let's see who has the highest score at the end!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Genealogy
Mnemonic: Your lineage and genealogy make up your genealogy, also known as your family history.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Gentlemen's Agreement
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 紳士 means "gentleman?" Well when two men determine that the best thing to do is cooperate they form a gentlemen's agreement.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Graceful
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're trying to be graceful and polite you have to keep your secret sheep toe (しと) under wraps. You're kind of fond of your sheep toe (it's unique after all) but you're careful to hide it when you want to be all modest and gentle and all that.

Name: Handcuffs
Mnemonic: You want to lock this criminal's hands up so he won't go punching anymore grandpas. You need some handcuffs to make sure he doesn't go around being a criminal anymore. Then you can lock him up good.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for one kanji and the on'yomi reading for the other. You know them both, so this shouldn't be too hard to remember!

Name: Hanging
Mnemonic: Remember how 縛る means "to tie?" Well if you tie something around someone's neck then it's called hanging. They'll probably die from it too, so it can also be death by hanging.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of the words 縛る and 首. Both use the kun'yomi readings, so just change the る to り and it's pretty simple!

Name: Hero
Mnemonic: If you look back in history and see someone of exceptional greatness, they're probably a hero. Not just a normal person, but an extraordinary person like Hercules or Mae Jemison.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Idiot
Mnemonic: Someone who's shocked at everything all the time will seem like an idiot. At this point, putting your drinks in a glass shouldn't be surprising. I mean, come on. Only a fool lets himself be shocked by everything he sees.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember when you learned 呆ける? Well just cut the る part off the end and it's exactly the same! If you can remember that, you'll remember this reading as well.

Name: Immortal
Mnemonic: If it does not rot then it's immortal. It will live forever!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Intermediary
Mnemonic: A mediator jammed in the middle of a group of angry people ends up becoming the intermediary between them. The mediator can't just ignore what's happening around them, and they have the tools to fix this.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Joruri
Mnemonic: If you cleanse a lapis lazuli rock until it goes glassy, you can use it in a joruri performance. In case you haven't heard of joruri, it's traditional Japanese chanted storytelling, sort of like a ballad, that's accompanied by shamisen music, and often puppets.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned all these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Jury
Mnemonic: Who is going to accompany the judge in deciding the results of the trial? The jury! They're the only other people besides the judge who can decide someone's fate in court.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lady
Mnemonic: A graceful woman is a proper, fancy lady.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lock
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Making Allowances
Mnemonic: If you serve someone a certain quantity of understanding, you're making allowances. You're taking into consideration all extenuating circumstances.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You learned these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Masterpiece
Mnemonic: Something you make that oozes with greatness is your masterpiece. The very best work you'll ever make in your entire life.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Media
Mnemonic: A mediator who works with someone who doesn't have a body has to use some kind of mortal media to record what they're saying. Print media? Sure. Electronic media? Alright? Ghost media? No! Humans can't read that stuff!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Muddy Stream
Mnemonic: A muddy stream is a muddy stream!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Musical Score
Mnemonic: A comforting score is a musical score. Music is really relaxing, and so is reading sheet music. You should try it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Narrow Victory
Mnemonic: A spicy win is a narrow victory. Kind of makes sense, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Orchestral Music
Mnemonic: You already know that 弦楽 means "string music," so add some pipes to that, like trumpets and saxophones, and you'll have orchestral music. You can't have a whole orchestra with just the string section!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. 楽 has two on'yomi readings, but you know it's がく here because it's about 音楽 (music)!

Name: Pardon
Mnemonic: An excuse and a pardon is a pardon or amnesty.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pardon
Mnemonic: Form a pardon with your mouth and actually pardon someone. Show your forgiveness with the words "I'm sorry."
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Part Time Employee
Mnemonic: A company requests consignment work and you take it to become a part time employee.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pill
Mnemonic: You take a dose of medicine but it gets locked in your throat because it's the kind of pill you chew, not swallow! You need to pay attention to which one is which or it won't help at all.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pollution
Mnemonic: If the air is muddy and dirty it's because there is too much pollution in that area. You should wear a mask and be careful of contamination.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Portrait
Mnemonic: When art resembles the image of a person, it's a portrait. And it doesn't just resemble them, it captures their image perfectly. Now that's what I call a portrait.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Pouring Alcohol
Mnemonic: If you serve someone, you're pouring alcohol or pouring sake for them. You're filling someone's glass.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading with the kanji. Cheers!

Name: Resentment
Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji resent, so it means resentment.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You feel some pretty strong resentment toward your roommate because you had to touch their icky door (いきどお) today and it was covered in what you hope was glue. Or frosting. UHG what an icky door. This is an outrage!!!

Name: Reshuffle
Mnemonic: You renew and alternate certain positions or people, making this a reshuffle, or dismissal.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Resignation
Mnemonic: When you give up and just try to enjoy the view, that's resignation. You know things aren't going well, and you know you can't do anything about it now, so you resign yourself to what's to come.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 諦, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In resignation, you throw all of your tater (てい) tots onto the ground. Look at the tater tots at your feet. Now they're lying scattered there, a symbol of your feelings of resignation.

Name: Running About
Mnemonic: If you bustle and run around all day from being busy you end up running about to get them all done. You'll be busy getting it all done, but your efforts won't be in vain!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sail
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you sail in a ship you can't forget to bring a garden hoe (ほ). If you lose your sails or your paddles, you can always use a hoe to paddle your way back. Or if you wreck on an island you can use the hoe to garden so you won't die of starvation! Hoes are very handy!

Name: Sailing
Mnemonic: A sail runs boats along the sea by sailing! You can't run along the water unless the sail is out and catching the wind.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Seam
Mnemonic: Remember how 縫う means "to sew." Well the only way you can see if a pair of jeans has been sewed with your eye is if you see a seam. If your eyes can't spot the stitches, then it probably wasn't sewed at all. Maybe it was superglued together.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of the words 縫う and 目. Both use the kun'yomi readings so just change the う to い and it's easy! You'll also see this word spelled 縫い目 too. They're exactly the same!

Name: Sheet Music
Mnemonic: The score on a surface is your sheet music or musical score.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Shell
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word isn't limited to animal shells though! It covers seed shells, or husks, too.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Shells are a good defense against からて chops. You can't get hurt if you have a nice strong shell to protect you from that からて-chopping weirdo who just showed up out of nowhere.

Name: Silk Thread
Mnemonic: A silk thread is silk thread!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned these readings for 絹 and 糸 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who only uses clothes made with silk thread? Ken's (けん) sheep (し)! Ken's sheep is very particular, and only wears clothes made from silk thread while it's waiting for its wool to grow back. Note that this word can also be read with the kun'yomi as きぬいと. While けんし tends to sound more technical or formal, often referring to silk thread as a textile material or in industrial contexts, きぬいと is more natural in everyday conversation.

Name: Sleep Paralysis
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 縛る means "to bind?" Well, in Japanese being bound by gold means you're experiencing sleep paralysis, or temporary paralysis. Just imagine that you're waking from a dream where you're bound up in gold thread, and it's stopping you from moving.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of the words 金 and 縛る. Both use the kun'yomi readings, but 金 becomes かな instead of かね. If you can remember that exception, this should be easy!

Name: Spine
Mnemonic: Your stature's spine is really just your spine, when you think about it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Stringed Instrument
Mnemonic: You already know that 楽器 means "musical instrument." Well, this one has strings, making it a stringed instrument.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Sure, 楽 has two on'yomi readings, but remember: when it's about 音楽 (music), it's read がく. Just bear in mind that がく shortens to がっ here.

Name: Strong Feelings
Mnemonic: Feelings that make you sigh out loud are really strong feelings. You wouldn't sigh if they didn't move you so much.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sugahara
Mnemonic: Sedge field is both Sugahara and Sugawara, the Japanese family names. Sedgefield is a family name (and a place-name) in English too, so that might help you with this one!
ReadingMnemonic: The only reading you haven't learned for this name is the irregular わら reading for 原, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Sugawara-san went to war a (わら) long time ago, but these days he enjoys a quiet life tending to his sedge fields.

Name: Sulfuric Acid
Mnemonic: Mix sulfur and acid and you'll get sulfuric acid! That's how science works! How simple!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Support
Mnemonic: Aid and foster someone to show your support for them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Suspended Sentence
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 猶予 means "extension?" You were supposed to carry out your sentence and go to jail, but the judge gave you a 猶予 (extension). In other words, you've received a suspended sentence.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Suspension Of Indictment
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 猶予 means "extension?" Well you wake up ready to sue people when you're told there has been an extension, meaning there was a suspension of indictment on your case. What the heck, you woke up ready for this! Now you have to wait to try and sue them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Theft
Mnemonic: You decided to steal... and then you steal again a few minutes later! Now you're wanted for theft. Stealing is wrong, you should have known better!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Be Utterly Amazed
Mnemonic: This is a combination of the word 呆れる meaning "to be amazed" and 返る meaning "to be returned." You're so amazed at something that it keeps returning to your mind. It means to be utterly amazed!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of the words 呆れる and 返る. 呆れる becomes 呆れ and you just add 返る to it. So reading this should be pretty simple.

Name: To Decay
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decay, so the verb version is to decay or to die out.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The entire world would start to die out if there were no cookies (く) left! Can you imagine your life without cookies? The trees and animals would all die too. Because they love cookies. Not just us humans.

Name: To Endure
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure, so the verb version is to endure or to keep out.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: To Make Muddy
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means muddy, so the verb version is to make muddy or to make cloudy.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to make muddy, meaning make yourself muddy, you should have your knees go (にご) first. When you have your knees go first the mud splashes all over you but you don't hurt your hands or your butt doing it.

Name: To Serve
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means serve, and the verb version is to scoop or to serve.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you decide to scoop out for your guests? Cookies (く)! But not just any cookies. Cookie smoothies! They're delicious and you won't serve anyone anything else. They must drink your delicious cookie drinks.

Name: To The Last
Mnemonic: I'm so bored. On top of my boredom is くまでも. If you took this separately, it would mean "even as a bear." So it's like you're saying I'm so bored, even if I was a bear. If you're so bored that you'd be bored even as a bear, you're going to be bored to the last or to the end. Nothing will please you, you bored bear person.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned 飽きる so you should be able to read this one too!

Name: To Toy With
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means play, so the verb version is to play with or to toy with someone.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Everyone always seems to yell at you when you start to toy with your towel and your towel moves (たわむ). Just because you don't have anything on under it doesn't mean you can't play with it! Right?!

Name: Wasteful
Mnemonic: You must not use your body for anything wasteful, because that would be a waste. You're too good for that!
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji, except that もち becomes もっ.

Name: Weariness
Mnemonic: If you're bored all the time it makes you tired and the weariness you feel will show on your face.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember how you learned 飽きる? Well just take of the る and it's the same thing. If you can remember that, you'll know this no problem!

Name: Wild
Mnemonic: Some day you'll run around, released from the world and its troubles and you'll end up running wild. All your actions will be completely uninhibited when you aren't tied to your school or your job. It will be great!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because ほう becomes ぽう here.

Name: Atoll
Mnemonic: A reef in the shape of a loop is an atoll. If you don't know what that is, it's a circular coral reef.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: At Once
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 一遍 means "once?" Well if you add に and make it an adverb, it becomes at once.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading you learned with 一遍 so you should be able to remember this too!

Name: Auspicious Event
Mnemonic: If you can congratulate someone for an occurrence in their life, it must be an auspicious event. You'll remember this happy event for a long, long time.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Azusa River
Mnemonic: Japanese birch river is Azusa River or simply Azusagawa. Azusagawa is both the Japanese name for the Azusa River, and a Japanese family name.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned both of these readings with the kanji. You just need to remember that rendaku turns かわ into がわ.

Name: Benkei
Mnemonic: You should congratulate a person who speaks lots of dialects because they have to be a really strong person, just like Mr. Benkei was. You think learning Japanese is hard now, just wait till you hear Osaka-ben and Hokkaido-ben. It takes a really strong person — a Benkei — to learn all those dialects, so congratulate them and tell them how strong they are!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bitterness
Mnemonic: If you have grief in your eyes, it means you've gone through a lot of bitterness and misery. You can always see in someone's eyes if they've experienced it too.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses one of the kun'yomi readings for the kanji. You haven't learned this kun'yomi reading for 憂, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Why the bitterness in your eyes? You visited a famed uni (う) restaurant, only to find it closed and locked. And as a lover of uni, you know no greater misery than to miss out on some uni.

Name: Bold
Mnemonic: If you have really big guts you're a super bold and daring person. In fact, you might even be superman. That's how big your guts are. Don't worry, I don't tell anyone I know who you are. It'll be our little secret.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Cape
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Casting
Mnemonic: If you want to create a cast you need to learn casting first. Then you can make lots of neat art, crafts, and counterfeit money. Wait, no, don't do that last one.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned both of them, so you should already know this word!

Name: Change
Mnemonic: Change and transition mean change and transition! Nifty.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Congratulation
Mnemonic: You congratulate someone and celebrate by saying congratulations and having a celebration!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Congratulations And Condolences
Mnemonic: If you are saying congratulations and also giving your condolences then they are congratulations and condolences. Pretty easy, right?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Critical Condition
Mnemonic: If someone is so dangerous that they deliberately hurt you, you're going to end up in critical condition. This wasn't an accident, they knew what they were doing and they didn't miss. Now you're on the verge of death. Hold on, kiddo.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Crossing Gate
Mnemonic: Remember how 遮断 means "isolation?" Well the machine that isolates you from a train is a crossing gate. That way you won't walk, bike, or drive your car into an oncoming train.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dairy Farming
Mnemonic: Dairy farming is dairy farming!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Death Anniversary
Mnemonic: The times when you are in mourning each year are for a loved one's death anniversary. They come around again every year. It's important you remember your loved ones at this time.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Deep Feeling
Mnemonic: If you compose something with a sigh, it's because you're experiencing a deep feeling. You might express this deep feeling with an exclamation, as you marvel at the wonders of the world.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You should be able to read it on your own.

Name: Demotion
Mnemonic: Usually if you're going to the left in Japanese, it's not a good thing. So if you transition to the left it's seen as a demotion. Going to the right is way better.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Deserted
Mnemonic: It's such a leisurely day that everyone has scattered and left the area deserted. It's just you now. Lounging in the shade.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Discouragement
Mnemonic: Your guts feel like they're falling when you experience a lot of discouragement. You know that sinking feeling you get in the pit of your stomach? That's your guts falling!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Disguise
Mnemonic: Use attire that imitates your surroundings to create a disguise. Or throw on some camouflage so that no one will be able to find you in Walmart.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: East Asia
Mnemonic: East Asia is East Asia! That's where Japan is!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: E. Coli
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 大腸 means "large intestines?" Well when you get bacteria in there you end up with E. Coli. Go to a doctor right away! You're gonna be stuck in the bathroom for a while. Sorry...
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Female
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Female Flower
Mnemonic: A female flower is a female flower!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi, but you haven't learned this kun'yomi for 雌 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Just think of someone asking you to differentiate female flowers from male flowers. Can you? "Meh (め), probably not." The reading of 花 is the rendaku version, so watch out for that too.

Name: First Anniversary Of Death
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 一周 means "one time around?" Well if you're mourning one time like this a year, then it's because it's the first anniversary of death for a family member. Maybe it was the death of your mom, your grandad or your goldfish, this is the first year since they died.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: For The Time Being
Mnemonic: If you only take daring and you don't have any yourself, you only have it for the time being. It will go away if you can't make it yourself.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for the kanji. You learned both of these already, so you should be able to read this with no problems!

Name: Friendship
Mnemonic: If a parent is friendly enough you can form a friendship with them, not just a kid/parent bond.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Gallstones
Mnemonic: Gallbladder stones are more commonly known as gallstones. Sometimes you have to get them surgically removed. Scary!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Guts
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

Name: Imbalance
Mnemonic: Remember how 均衡 means "balance?" Well if you do not have any balance, you're going to have an imbalance instead.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Imitation
Mnemonic: Food that imitates an imitation of some OTHER food, is an even worse imitation. You don't want to eat that. It's a sham! It's mocking real food! It's probably made of dust and cardboard!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Immense
Mnemonic: Another way to say something is very big is to say it is immense or enormous.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Insult
Mnemonic: You despise this one guy so much that you want to humiliate him so you insult him in public. That wasn't very nice, but it did seem to embarrass him. I guess you won.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Jet Black
Mnemonic: Lacquer black looks jet black, or pitch black. It's as black as black can be!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lacquer
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You make lacquer out of uni root sh*t (うるし). You gotta get deep in the uni to the root of its sh*t and rub it into a paste to make the lacquer. Then rub that on wooden stuff! Yay! Uni root sh*t!

Name: Lacquerware
Mnemonic: Lacquer containers are called Lacquerware. Those pretty bowls you're eating out of? That shininess is because it's lacquerware!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Lawyer
Mnemonic: The official method of doing anything requires hiring a lawyer. They have to be there when you sign forms or sue people, or it isn't official at all.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Loftiness
Mnemonic: You worship someone who is so high above you that you can't help but be in awe of their loftiness. Their nobility is the reason you feel like you should worship them in the first place.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Marriage
Mnemonic: Marry and marriage still make marriage. Congratulations! Wooh! Yay!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mean
Mnemonic: If you treat someone in a lowly manner because you think they're inferior to you then you're a mean person. Plain and simple.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mountain Pass
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: You climb along the mountain pass and see adorable little Tokyo geckos (とうげ) climbing all over the place. They're climbing with you now!

Name: Mourning
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Move The Capital
Mnemonic: If you want to transition the capital to a new, better place, you need to move the capital. This used to happen a lot way back in Japanese history. It's actually pretty interesting so you might want to read up on it!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Neglecting To Contact
Mnemonic: If you select to talk to nothing but sand for a really long time, you're neglecting to contact anyone else. Your relatives miss you! Stop talking to sand and call them!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Plot
Mnemonic: The soul and guts of a story lie in the plot!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Poem
Mnemonic: A composed song is a poem, or a song. This can also refer to the act of composing a poem or song, which makes a lot of sense given the kanji.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Quiet
Mnemonic: Leisurely quiet is the best kind of quiet. Even your brain gets to be quiet because you don't have a care left in the world.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Reef
Mnemonic: A reef made of boulders is still a reef, but it's made of sunken rocks.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Reef
Mnemonic: A dark reef is still a reef. It's just really deep underwater so it's kinda dark under there. Because of that it can also be called a sunken reef.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rice Planting Girl
Mnemonic: A young woman who is planting rice from early morning into the latter evenings is a rice planting girl. You'll see them out there all day long, from dawn till dusk, planting, taking care of, and picking rice.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a really weird exception, sorry. You've kind of learned these reading, but they're like... weird variations of them. Take the さ from 早速, the おつ becomes おと, and then the 女 kun'yomi め (hey that one's normal!). And you get さおとめ. You might need to just memorize this one.

Name: Ronin
Mnemonic: A person who wanders because their lord was killed, is known as a ronin, or a masterless samurai. Now they're just like the rest of us, but they can't stop wandering because they have nowhere they belong.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Root Of Evil
Mnemonic: Evil's root is the root of evil. It's the source of evil things.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sara
Mnemonic: If sand is spread out you get the given name Sara. You've written your name in sand, right? Now imagine a Sara you know spreading out sand so that it spells her name. Or imagine a pro athlete, like wrestler Doshō Sara (土性 沙羅), judoka Asahina Sara (朝比奈 沙羅), or ski jumper Takanashi Sara (髙梨 沙羅) spreading out the sand. I bet they'd find some skillful ways to do it.
ReadingMnemonic: This name uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji.

Name: Scorn
Mnemonic: Despise someone and your scorn for them just becomes even stronger scorn.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Scorn
Mnemonic: Lightweight scorn, no matter how light, is still scorn. Those feelings are pretty strong no matter what.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 軽 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have more scorn and disdain for the KKK (けい) than any other group in the whole world. And I'm not going to argue with you, they're pretty hatable.

Name: Scrutiny
Mnemonic: If you tasted the air at a recital the flavor would taste like scrutiny. That's really what everyone is doing when they watch. They don't really want to hear you, they just want to judge you.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Spinning
Mnemonic: A spinning achievement is just the spinning you produce — like thread or yarn spinning.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Spinning And Weaving
Mnemonic: Spinning and weaving means spinning and weaving. Yay!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 織 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: While you're spinning and weaving you are always absolutely shocked (しょく) by what you make. You never really know when you start and then BAM! You made elephant slippers. That's just how it works and it shocks you every single time.

Name: Sprouting
Mnemonic: What is a sprout doing? It's sprouting and budding. A crush you have on someone can sprout too.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about that newly sprouting moe (もえ) character you have a crush on. Yes, this is the same moe. Congrats, you already know it!

Name: Stationed
Mnemonic: Resident soldiers live in barracks when they've been stationed in another country. They have to serve their occupancy for a certain amount of time before they get to go back home.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Subservient
Mnemonic: A lowly person who yields to everyone is really subservient. They'll do everything people tell them because they don't have the nerves to speak up and just say no.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Taboo
Mnemonic: Prohibition of something with a punishment so serious that you'll end up in mourning after is a taboo.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Compose
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means compose, so the verb version is to compose.
ReadingMnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to compose a poem but all you have for inspiration is what's in your pocket. You reach in and find a yo-yo (よ). Ah yes, this will do. So you compose a poem about your yo-yo: One string to rule them all,
One string to find them,
One string to- hey wait a minute...

Name: To Despise
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means despise, so the verb version is to despise.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think of all the things you start to despise and to disdain. Now come up with some anecdotes (あなど) for each one of those things. Be sure to think in your head, "I'm coming up with anecdotes for things I disdain, why am I coming up with anecdotes?"

Name: To Endure
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure, so the verb version is to endure or to bear.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji!

Name: To Get Dented
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means concave, but "to concave" doesn't really make sense. So the verb version is to get dented. Or, more figuratively, to feel down.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You feel like you've started to get dented when you have a head cold (へこ). Like all that sniffling makes dents on the sides of your nose. It's easy to feel down when you have a head cold too, but try not to let it get to you.

Name: To Scorn
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scorn, so the verb version is to scorn and to despise.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You start to scorn your boss because she's been wearing that same sage suit (さげす) for a month now. She knows you want to wear a sage suit too but you can't wear the same color as her! It's really making you start to despise her. Uhg!

Name: To Spin
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means spinning, so the verb version is to spin and to make yarn.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Before you start to spin you have to let out two moos (つむ) as tribute to the cows that gave you their fur to make yarn out of. Go on, two moos, right now. Hey, out loud, not in your head!

Name: Uneven
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 凹凸 means "uneven?" Well spin something uneven around and it's still uneven! Just kinda backwards, just like this word!
ReadingMnemonic: However, just because the meaning stays the same when you flip it, doesn't mean the reading does. Doing that actually made the reading change from on'yomi to kun'yomi readings! You haven't learned either of these yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you have the convex parts first and the concave parts second in something uneven it ends up looking like a deco box (でこぼこ). An art deco box that is. They have lots of stuff stick out of them on the outside, but you can open them up and put stuff on the inside.

Name: Universal
Mnemonic: Remember how 普遍 means "universal?" Well when you add like it's still universal! Easy!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Unpleasant
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with しい on the end, meaning it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of mourning? It's unpleasant or disgusting. Nobody said mourning was fun.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your mourning is especially unpleasant because it's your pet eagle (い) you're mourning for. Your parents wouldn't let you bury him so you're just staring at his week old, dead eagle body. It's super disgusting, actually.

Name: Unskillful
Mnemonic: Clumsy and immature people end up being really unskillful. You can't do your job if you're always dropping things and whining, can you? They're usually also really childish, if you didn't already guess that.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Vagrancy
Mnemonic: Wander from stream to stream and you'll get really used to vagrancy. You'll love wandering so much that you'll convert to nomadism. The open sky is your home!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Since you haven't learned this particular reading for 流, here's a mnemonic to help you: When you think about it, vagrancy is kind of a loophole (る). No one ever knows where you could be, making it hard to track you down.

Name: Vagrant
Mnemonic: Someone who floats and wanders from place to place is a vagrant. They don't really have a home, but they keep hanging around yours. It's kind of annoying. (This word has a negative connotation, you wouldn't use it for someone who is just homeless, unless you're really mean.)
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 浮 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: All the vagrants you know are fools (ふ). They just left their homes and now they float around your city for no reason. You ask them why and they shrug. You've never seen a better definition of a fool before in your life!

Name: Very
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're very tired and very giggly, you'll try to say your friend's name but start laughing right away so it ends up sounds like,  "Hannah ha ha ha (はなは)."

Name: Wandering
Mnemonic: Release your worldly ties and wander the world. You'll get used to wandering and you'll spend the rest of your days roaming the world until you die. It's quite the life! But you can only do it if you let go of everything else.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: War Damages
Mnemonic: One of the most evil things about war are the war damages that happen during it. Whole countrysides, cities, and lots of people can die. So I'd say the ravages of war are the most evil thing about war. Period.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Waste
Mnemonic: If you wander around doing nothing at your own expense it will be a huge waste of money. It's not like you were doing or buying anything important, you were just wandering around, after all.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Without Sparing
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 惜しむ means "to be sparing?" Well if you make that negative with ない, then you're doing it without sparing anything instead.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, so you should be able to read this already too!

Name: Worship
Mnemonic: Worship in the morning, worship in the night, worship all day! Worship that WaniKani poster. Do it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: A Certain Country
Mnemonic: A certain country is a certain country!
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: A Certain Person
Mnemonic: A certain family name belongs to a certain person.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: A Certain Place
Mnemonic: No surprises here. A certain place is a certain place.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Agreement
Mnemonic: An article you write a promise on is an agreement. Make sure you read them thoroughly before you sign them!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Anatomy
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 解剖 means "autopsy?" Well you have to learn about anatomy before you're going to be allowed to perform an autopsy or dissect anything.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Anonymity
Mnemonic: Hide your name for anonymity. There's lots of that here on the internet. In fact, you're probably using a pseudonym right now, aren't you? Yeah, you are. You can't hide THAT from me at least... uh... Ssssteve?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Articles Of Incorporation
Mnemonic: Articles that determine the rules and regulations of your job or a company are called articles of incorporation.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Barbarism
Mnemonic: Barbarians go around and commit acts of barbarism! What else would they do? They're barbarians!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Bow
Mnemonic: Tap your head against the floor to show your subservient respect by doing this deep bow. This is the most respectful bow you can possibly do.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 叩 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who's that bowing before you? It's none other than こういち! He's bowing out of deep respect for you finally hitting level 60 on WaniKani. Congrats!

Name: Bridegroom
Mnemonic: A groom gets a flower on his lapel and he's finally a real bridegroom! Before that he was just waiting to be one. The flower makes it for real.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Busy
Mnemonic: If you annoy someone who's busy they're still going to be busy. You annoying them can't change them. Though now they're probably busy AND annoyed.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Certain
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Cigarette Butt
Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 吸う meaning "to smoke" and 殻 meaning "shell" or "husk." The husk left over after you're done smoking is the cigarette butt. Or tobacco ashes if you just have a pile of them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of the words 吸う and 殻. Change the う to い and don't forget the rendaku, and you should be able to remember this reading too!

Name: Complex
Mnemonic: If you think someone is trying to annoy you at random, just pay attention and you'll see that they have a complex annoying pattern they're using on you. Once you figure that out, it won't annoy you as much and you'll win!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Correction
Mnemonic: Correct something you thought was already correct by making a correction.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Death
Mnemonic: Die in the past and it was death that you suffered from!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Deep Emotion
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 感慨 means "strong feelings?" Well feelings so strong that you can not even think of a quantity to measure or explain how much you feel. These are really deep emotions. They fill you all the way up and you can't help but tell everyone about them.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Deeply Moving
Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 感慨 meaning "strong feelings" and 深い meaning "deep." Something that makes you feel strong emotions deep down inside is deeply moving.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a combination of a jukugo word and an i-adjective. You've learned both of them so just mash them together, with the rendaku making ふ to ぶ, and you've got the reading down pat!

Name: Delusion
Mnemonic: Reckless things you imagine are just delusions. You shouldn't dwell on them, they probably aren't going to happen.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Diarrhea
Mnemonic: Diarrhea that goes below you is still diarrhea, unfortunately. I hope it's going down into a toilet...
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Die At One's Post
Mnemonic: If you want to become a martyr during your employment you need to die at your post. I don't know why you'd WANT to do that though.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dismissal
Mnemonic: You quit your job but with a pretty good excuse to back it up, so you get a dismissal instead of just quitting outright. If you're in the army and you do this it's called a discharge.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Dysentery
Mnemonic: Red diarrhea means there's blood in there and you're probably dying of dysentery! Have you been playing too much Oregon Trail? Either way, get to a doctor!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 赤 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know what dysentery isn't? Sexy (せき). That's right. If anyone tries to seduce you by saying they have dysentery and they'd like to share it with you, tell them how NOT sexy that is and get the heck away from them!

Name: Excuse Me
Mnemonic: It's kind of like you're saying say say, and it’s used in classical Japanese to get someone’s attention, so this is excuse me or hello.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the reading you learned with the kanji. You should know it already.

Name: Finally
Mnemonic: If you do something gradually for a long time, when you finish it gives you that FINALLY feeling. It took so long and you worked so hard and you're finally done!
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is an exception, but you learned it with the kanji. Congratulations!

Name: Grid
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Happy New Year
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 新年 means "New Year?" Well when you say humble congratulations on the new year, you're really saying Happy New Year!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Head
Mnemonic: The neck of the squad is the most important part of the squad, for if you lose the neck you lose the head (they're all one thing). This person is the head or leader of a group.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word so it uses the on'yomi readings. You learned the on'yomi for 首 in the words 部首 and 首位, and you learned the on'yomi for 班 with the kanji. Go you!

Name: Hide
Mnemonic: Hide and hide make hide! Lots of hiding going on around here. I think... I can't find anyone so I can only assume.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Husband
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Impeachment
Mnemonic: The final bullet of censure is impeachment. You've already been publicly humiliated and now you're being impeached because of it. Yikes.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Indigo
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, so you should know this too!

Name: Lake Shore
Mnemonic: The lake shore is the lake shore!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Leader
Mnemonic: Someone who has territory under their sleeve is the leader. They're the boss of all this territory because they say so, and because they shoved it all into their big sleeves.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi reading for 袖, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: It's always hard to fill a leaders' shoes (しゅう). Leaders have big responsibilities and power. Just big shoes to fill! Picture these big ol' leader's shoes, like in a literal sense. Not only do they have big responsibilities, leaders have big shoes as well.

Name: Long Shamisen Song
Mnemonic: A long shamisen song is a long shamisen song! They're also called nagauta, and they're usually pretty epic too.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Low Price
Mnemonic: Buy something at bargain value and you'll be getting it at a really low price. Good for you!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mast
Mnemonic: The pillar the sail is attached to is called a mast. Without it the sail wouldn't do it's job and your sailboat wouldn't move at all.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned these readings with other vocabulary, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Mountain Stream
Mnemonic: A stream that runs through a valley is a mountain stream. Valleys happen in between mountains, so just picture the river running through the middle of them in your head.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Noisy
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of annoy? It's annoying!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What's noisy? That uni's rude sighing (うるさい). It just keeps sighing loudly over and over. It's sooo annoying!

Name: Orchestra
Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 管弦楽 means "orchestral music?" Well the group that plays that music is an orchestra.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. 楽 has two on'yomi readings, but you know it's がく here because it's about 音楽 (music)!

Name: Pier
Mnemonic: Add a bridge to a jetty and you'll have a pretty cool pier. Put a ferris wheel on there and make some money!
ReadingMnemonic: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 桟 and the kun'yomi reading for 橋. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too!

Name: Play Flirt
Mnemonic: Remember how 戯れる can mean "to play" or "to flirt?" Well this is when you play flirt! Or just make a joke.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Name: Pluto
Mnemonic: The underworld king star is the dwarf planet Pluto. Since Pluto was the ruler of the underworld in classical mythology, this makes a lot of sense!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Realm Of The Dead
Mnemonic: The underworld dirt is another word for the realm of the dead, underworld, or Hades. Like the word 冥界 (also in this level), it's rather poetic, and mostly used in written contexts involving spirituality, Buddhism, and ancient mythologies.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Relentlessly
Mnemonic: Remember how 容赦 can mean "forgiveness" and "mercy?" Well add なく (basically making it NOT that), and it becomes relentlessly and mercilessly. The exact opposite of what it was before!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji (with なく attached to it). You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Rento
Mnemonic: This isn't a ripples ladle, but the Japanese given name Rento!
ReadingMnemonic: This name uses the on'yomi for both kanji, which you already learned. Lucky!

Name: Sailboat
Mnemonic: A sail boat is a sailboat!
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi readings. You know them!

Name: Savage
Mnemonic: Barbarians who live in fields, not even in huts or houses or anything, are called savage by people who DO live in huts and houses. They think if you live out in a field you're really uncivilized. But that's all a matter of opinion, I guess.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Scandal
Mnemonic: What do you hear that is really ugly? A scandal. Scandals are the ugliest topics for gossip.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Seaweed
Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Swim into a floating group of seaweed and shivers will go up your spine. It feels so gross and slimy that you can't help but moan (も) out in distress.

Name: Seaweed
Mnemonic: Sea seaweed is still seaweed!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Secretion
Mnemonic: Part of you is starting to secrete some kind of secretion. It's kinda gross, so maybe you should go to the doctor to check if it's normal.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. But 泌 is using an on'yomi reading you haven't learned yet (ひつ), which also happens to get rendaku'd here, so use this mnemonic to remember it: The part of your body that produces the most secretions is… your pits (ぴつ). Yeah, it's a gross image, but next time you're walking around Tokyo in summer and "secreting" through your shirt, at least you'll have the vocab to describe all that 分泌.

Name: Shameful Sight
Mnemonic: Something with an ugly appearance is a shameful sight, or disgraceful behavior. You feel bad just looking at it. It probably feels bad too.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Silent
Mnemonic: Tell a widow to shut up and she'll be silent for the rest of the day. That wasn't very nice. You're a mean person.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Someone Or Other
Mnemonic: The kanji means certain, but when it's used as a standalone word, or after a family name, it means things like someone or other, you-know-who, or something. It's basically a vague way to refer to someone who's name you've forgotten, or you don't want to mention for some reason.
ReadingMnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi of the kanji, and you haven't learned that yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You bump into someone or other, and just as you're wondering what on earth her name is, her nanny gashes (なにがし) her on the leg. It looks like it hurts. Poor you-know-who, whatever her name is. The nanny looks horrified, and is trying to patch her up.

Name: Song
Mnemonic: A shamisen song is a shamisen song, yes. But did you know it's also... a song?! Oh, you did? Well okay then.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Name: Son In Law
Mnemonic: Your daughter's groom will become your son in law. He's a great guy! Congratulations!
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Southern Barbarians
Mnemonic: Southern barbarians are called Southern barbarians! While it originally referred to the people of Southeast Asia, the term Nanban was used to refer to Western traders who began arriving in Japan in the 1500s. There's yummy food named after them too!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Square
Mnemonic: Measure that shape on the paper with your eyes. It's got four sides.. it's.. it's a square! Or a box from above maybe... But it's definitely the kind you fill in on a graph.
ReadingMnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Sulfur
Mnemonic: Sulfur that's yellow is still sulfur. It smells like rotten eggs, which are also kinda yellow.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: This sulfur smells like an eagle's OOHHH (いおう)!! Oh no. Sulfur smells... it smells... like an eagle's... OH.. Oh eww no.

Name: Tease
Mnemonic: A bad kind of playing is when you tease or prank someone. It's mean and you shouldn't do it! Depending on the context this can sometimes have a far more negative connotation and mean lewd behavior.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: If you tease someone with a prank that makes them eat zoo rats (いたずら), you're a jerk. That's less of a prank and more like abuse. Cut it out.

Name: Thrift
Mnemonic: I promise this will be a really thrifty place because it's a thrift store! They wouldn't lie about that!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Adore
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means yearn for, so the verb version is to yearn for. But that sounds kinda old fashioned, so you can just use to adore too.
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You realize you're starting to yearn for someone way more than you used to. "Sh*t (した)... " you say to yourself. This wasn't supposed to happen. Anytime you start to adore someone like that you always know you're getting into a bunch of sh*t you don't want to deal with. Damn these emotions!

Name: To Become Muddy
Mnemonic: You already know that 濁す means "to make muddy," but this is when you're the one getting muddy. It means to become muddy.
ReadingMnemonic: This has the same reading as 濁す. If you can remember that one, you should be able to remember this one.

Name: To Compose
Mnemonic: The verb form of compose is to compose. This particular verb is usually used in relation to poetry, and can also mean to recite or to sing, though more in the sense of singing someone's praises than singing a song.
ReadingMnemonic: This word shares the same origin as 歌う and 唄う, and they share the same readings as well.

Name: To Drink Together
Mnemonic: 酌む means "to serve" and the kanji 交 means mix. What happens if you serve and mix together? You're going to pour each other a drink because you plan  to drink together.
ReadingMnemonic: You haven't learned this reading for 交 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: All the bars are closed so you and your friends are going to drink together in your car (か). You set up a little bar in the back of your car and settle down for some drinks. It's cramped but cosy.

Name: Torture
Mnemonic: Torture may be a problem but that doesn't stop people from using torture to get their way.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: To Sing
Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means Shamisen song, so the verb version is to sing.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember how 歌う means "to sing" too? Well it has the same reading. If you know that one, you know this one. Yay!

Name: Tunnel
Mnemonic: A pit that's used as a road is called a tunnel. Or a mine, if they're taking valuable things out of it.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ugly
Mnemonic: Ugly, bad things are ugly, mean, and offensive.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Ugly
Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of ugly? It's ugly still!
ReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The most ugly thing you've ever seen was a mini cookie (みにく). Why would any one want a tiny cookie? Cookies should be huge, and enough to fill you up. The more you look at the mini cookie it seems to become uglier and uglier to you.

Name: Underworld
Mnemonic: The underworld world is the underworld, Hades, or the realm of the dead.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned those with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Urinary Organs
Mnemonic: The containers your urine secretes into are your urinary organs.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Valley
Mnemonic: A valley in a valley is still a valley!
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Widow
Mnemonic: A widowed wife is a widow.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Name: Yearning
Mnemonic: If you can't stop thinking about how much you yearn for someone, that yearning can drive you crazy. Try to keep it in check, and enjoy how you can hold such deep affection for someone.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
